1 Super Bowl 50 was an American football game to determine the champion of the National Football League NFL for the 2015 season.
2 The American Football Conference AFC champion Denver Broncos defeated the National Football Conference NFC champion Carolina Panthers 24–10 to earn their third Super Bowl title.
3 The game was played on February 7 2016 at Levis Stadium in the San Francisco Bay Area at Santa Clara California.
4 As this was the 50th Super Bowl the league emphasized the golden anniversary with various goldthemed initiatives as well as temporarily suspending the tradition of naming each Super Bowl game with Roman numerals under which the game would have been known as Super Bowl L so that the logo could prominently feature the Arabic numerals 50.

1 The Panthers finished the regular season with a 15–1 record and quarterback Cam Newton was named the NFL Most Valuable Player MVP.
2 They defeated the Arizona Cardinals 49–15 in the NFC Championship Game and advanced to their second Super Bowl appearance since the franchise was founded in 1995.
3 The Broncos finished the regular season with a 12–4 record and denied the New England Patriots a chance to defend their title from Super Bowl XLIX by defeating them 20–18 in the AFC Championship Game.
4 They joined the Patriots Dallas Cowboys and Pittsburgh Steelers as one of four teams that have made eight appearances in the Super Bowl.

1 The league announced on October 16 2012 that the two finalists were Sun Life Stadium and Levis Stadium.
2 The South FloridaMiami area has previously hosted the event 10 times tied for most with New Orleans with the most recent one being Super Bowl XLIV in 2010.

4 The Miami bid depended on whether the stadium underwent renovations.
5 However on May 3 2013 the Florida legislature refused to approve the funding plan to pay for the renovations dealing a significant blow to Miamis chances.

1 For the third straight season the number one seeds from both conferences met in the Super Bowl.
2 The Carolina Panthers became one of only ten teams to have completed a regular season with only one loss and one of only six teams to have acquired a 15–1 record while the Denver Broncos became one of four teams to have made eight appearances in the Super Bowl.
3 The Broncos made their second Super Bowl appearance in three years having reached Super Bowl XLVIII while the Panthers made their second Super Bowl appearance in franchise history their other appearance being Super Bowl XXXVIII.
4 Coincidentally both teams were coached by John Fox in their last Super Bowl appearance prior to Super Bowl 50.
5 Who coached each Super Bowl 50 participant in their most recent Super Bowl appearance prior to Super Bowl 50?	John Fox	4

1 Despite waiving longtime running back DeAngelo Williams and losing top wide receiver Kelvin Benjamin to a torn ACL in the preseason the Carolina Panthers had their best regular season in franchise history becoming the seventh team to win at least 15 regular season games since the league expanded to a 16game schedule in 1978.
2 Carolina started the season 14–0 not only setting franchise records for the best start and the longest singleseason winning streak but also posting the best start to a season by an NFC team in NFL history breaking the 13–0 record previously shared with the 2009 New Orleans Saints and the 2011 Green Bay Packers.
3 With their NFCbest 15–1 regular season record the Panthers clinched homefield advantage throughout the NFC playoffs for the first time in franchise history.
4 Ten players were selected to the Pro Bowl the most in franchise history along with eight AllPro selections.
5 Whic Carolina Panthers running back was waived?	DeAngelo Williams	1
6 Which Carolina Panthers wide receiver suffered a torn ACL before the season began?	Kelvin Benjamin	1

1 The Panthers offense which led the NFL in scoring 500 points was loaded with talent boasting six Pro Bowl selections.
2 Pro Bowl quarterback Cam Newton had one of his best seasons throwing for 3837 yards and rushing for 636 while recording a careerhigh and leagueleading 45 total touchdowns 35 passing 10 rushing a careerlow 10 interceptions and a careerbest quarterback rating of 994.
3 Newtons leading receivers were tight end Greg Olsen who caught a careerhigh 77 passes for 1104 yards and seven touchdowns and wide receiver Ted Ginn Jr who caught 44 passes for 739 yards and 10 touchdowns Ginn also rushed for 60 yards and returned 27 punts for 277 yards.
4 Other key receivers included veteran Jerricho Cotchery 39 receptions for 485 yards rookie Devin Funchess 31 receptions for 473 yards and five touchdowns and secondyear receiver Corey Brown 31 receptions for 447 yards.
5 The Panthers backfield featured Pro Bowl running back Jonathan Stewart who led the team with 989 rushing yards and six touchdowns in 13 games along with Pro Bowl fullback Mike Tolbert who rushed for 256 yards and caught 18 passes for another 154 yards.
6 Carolinas offensive line also featured two Pro Bowl selections center Ryan Kalil and guard Trai Turner.
7 How many Pro Bowlers were on the Panthers offense?	six	1

9 How many interceptions did Cam Newton throw?	10	2

1 The Panthers defense gave up just 308 points ranking sixth in the league while also leading the NFL in interceptions with 24 and boasting four Pro Bowl selections.
2 Pro Bowl defensive tackle Kawann Short led the team in sacks with 11 while also forcing three fumbles and recovering two.
3 Fellow lineman Mario Addison added 6½ sacks.
4 The Panthers line also featured veteran defensive end Jared Allen a 5time pro bowler who was the NFLs active career sack leader with 136 along with defensive end Kony Ealy who had 5 sacks in just 9 starts.
5 Behind them two of the Panthers three starting linebackers were also selected to play in the Pro Bowl Thomas Davis and Luke Kuechly.
6 Davis compiled 5½ sacks four forced fumbles and four interceptions while Kuechly led the team in tackles 118 forced two fumbles and intercepted four passes of his own.
7 Carolinas secondary featured Pro Bowl safety Kurt Coleman who led the team with a career high seven interceptions while also racking up 88 tackles and Pro Bowl cornerback Josh Norman who developed into a shutdown corner during the season and had four interceptions two of which were returned for touchdowns.

11 How many balls did Josh Norman intercept?	four	1

19 Who had five sacks in nine games as a Carolina Panthers starter?	Kony Ealy	4
20 Who was the Panthers tackle leader for 2015?	Luke Kuechly	5
21 How many interceptions did Josh Norman score touchdowns with in 2015?	two	2
1 Following their loss in the divisional round of the previous seasons playoffs the Denver Broncos underwent numerous coaching changes including a mutual parting with head coach John Fox who had won four divisional championships in his four years as Broncos head coach and the hiring of Gary Kubiak as the new head coach.
2 Under Kubiak the Broncos planned to install a runoriented offense with zone blocking to blend in with quarterback Peyton Mannings shotgun passing skills but struggled with numerous changes and injuries to the offensive line as well as Manning having his worst statistical season since his rookie year with the Indianapolis Colts in 1998 due to a plantar fasciitis injury in his heel that he had suffered since the summer and the simple fact that Manning was getting old as he turned 39 in the 2015 offseason.
3 Although the team had a 7–0 start Manning led the NFL in interceptions.
4 In week 10 Manning suffered a partial tear of the plantar fasciitis in his left foot.
5 He set the NFLs alltime record for career passing yards in this game but was benched after throwing four interceptions in favor of backup quarterback Brock Osweiler who took over as the starter for most of the remainder of the regular season.
6 Osweiler was injured however leading to Mannings return during the Week 17 regular season finale where the Broncos were losing 13–7 against the 4–11 San Diego Chargers resulting in Manning reclaiming the starting quarterback position for the playoffs by leading the team to a key 27–20 win that enabled the team to clinch the number one overall AFC seed.
7 Under defensive coordinator Wade Phillips the Broncos defense ranked number one in total yards allowed passing yards allowed and sacks and like the previous three seasons the team has continued to set numerous individual league and franchise records.
8 With the defense carrying the team despite the issues with the offense the Broncos finished the regular season with a 12–4 record and earned homefield advantage throughout the AFC playoffs.
9 Who is the head coach of the Broncos?	Gary Kubiak	1
10 Who played quarterback for the Broncos after Peyton Manning was benched?	Brock Osweiler	5
11 Who did Peyton Manning play for as a rookie?	Indianapolis Colts	2
12 Who did the Broncos play in the last week of the regular season?	San Diego Chargers	6
13 Who is Denvers defensive coordinator?	Wade Phillips	7

1 Manning finished the year with a careerlow 679 passer rating throwing for 2249 yards and nine touchdowns with 17 interceptions.
2 In contrast Osweiler threw for 1967 yards 10 touchdowns and six interceptions for a rating of 864.
3 Veteran receiver Demaryius Thomas led the team with 105 receptions for 1304 yards and six touchdowns while Emmanuel Sanders caught 76 passes for 1135 yards and six scores while adding another 106 yards returning punts.
4 Tight end Owen Daniels was also a big element of the passing game with 46 receptions for 517 yards.
5 Running back C J Anderson was the teams leading rusher 863 yards and seven touchdowns while also catching 25 passes for 183 yards.
6 Running back Ronnie Hillman also made a big impact with 720 yards five touchdowns 24 receptions and a 47 yards per carry average.
7 Overall the offense ranked 19th in scoring with 355 points and did not have any Pro Bowl selections.

1 The Broncos defense ranked first in the NFL yards allowed 4530 for the first time in franchise history and fourth in points allowed 296.
2 Defensive ends Derek Wolfe and Malik Jackson each had 5½ sacks.
3 Pro Bowl linebacker Von Miller led the team with 11 sacks forced four fumbles and recovered three.
4 Linebacker DeMarcus Ware was selected to play in the Pro Bowl for the ninth time in his career ranking second on the team with 7½ sacks.
5 Linebacker Brandon Marshall led the team in total tackles with 109 while Danny Trevathan ranked second with 102.
6 Cornerbacks Aqib Talib three interceptions and Chris Harris Jr two interceptions were the other two Pro Bowl selections from the defense.

1 Concerns were raised over whether Levis Stadiums field was of a high enough quality to host a Super Bowl during the inaugural season the field had to be resodded multiple times due to various issues and during a week 6 game earlier in the 2015 season a portion of the turf collapsed under Baltimore Ravens kicker Justin Tucker causing him to slip and miss a field goal although the field has not had any major issues since.
2 As is customary for Super Bowl games played at natural grass stadiums the NFL resodded the field with a new playing surface a hybrid Bermuda 419 turf.
3 NFL and Atlanta Braves field director Ed Mangan stated that the field was in great shape for gameday.
4 However the turf showed problem throughout the game with a number of players needing to change their cleats during the game and player slipping during plays all throughout the game.

1 As the designated home team in the annual rotation between AFC and NFC teams the Broncos elected to wear their road white jerseys with matching white pants.
2 Elway stated Weve had Super Bowl success in our white uniforms.
3 The Broncos last wore matching white jerseys and pants in the Super Bowl in Super Bowl XXXIII Elways last game as Denver QB when they defeated the Atlanta Falcons 34–19.
4 In their only other Super Bowl win in Super Bowl XXXII Denver wore blue jerseys which was their primary color at the time.
5 They also lost Super Bowl XXI when they wore white jerseys but they are 04 in Super Bowls when wearing orange jerseys losing in Super Bowl XII XXII XXIV and XLVIII.
6 The only other AFC champion team to have worn white as the designated home team in the Super Bowl was the Pittsburgh Steelers they defeated the Seattle Seahawks 21–10 in Super Bowl XL 10 seasons prior.
7 The Broncos decision to wear white meant the Panthers would wear their standard home uniform black jerseys with silver pants.

1 On June 4 2014 the NFL announced that the practice of branding Super Bowl games with Roman numerals a practice established at Super Bowl V would be temporarily suspended and that the game would be named using Arabic numerals as Super Bowl 50 as opposed to Super Bowl L The use of Roman numerals will be reinstated for Super Bowl LI.
2 Jaime Weston the leagues vice president of brand and creative explained that a primary reason for the change was the difficulty of designing an aesthetically pleasing logo with the letter L using the standardized logo template introduced at Super Bowl XLV.
3 The logo also deviates from the template by featuring large numerals colored in gold behind the Vince Lombardi Trophy instead of underneath and in silver as in the standard logo.
4 When did the NFL announce the suspension of using Roman numerals to brand the Super Bowl?	June 4  2014	1
5 What was the first Super Bowl branded with Roman numerals?	Super Bowl V	1
6 Who is the NFLs vice president of brand and creative?	Jaime Weston	2
7 What was the first Super Bowl to use the standardized logo template?	Super Bowl XLV	2
8 Who is the trophy featured on the logo named for?	Vince Lombardi	3
9 In what year was it declared that no Roman numerals would be used in the name of the 50th Super Bowl?	2014	1
10 Which Super Bowl after the 50th one will begin have Roman numerals in the title again?	Super Bowl LI	1
11 If Roman numerals were used in the naming of the 50th Super Bowl which one would have been used?	L	1
12 What color are the numbers in the Super Bowl 50 logo?	gold	3
13 When did the NFL announce that it would not use Roman numbers to designate the Super Bowl number?	June 4  2014	1
14 Rather than Roman numerals what did the NFL decide to use?	Arabic numerals	1
15 What is the Roman numeral for 50?	L	1
16 Normally silver what color was used for the number 50?	gold	3

1 In the United States the game was televised by CBS as part of a cycle between the three main broadcast television partners of the NFL.
2 The networks lead broadcast team of Jim Nantz and Phil Simms called the contest with Tracy Wolfson and Evan Washburn on the sidelines.
3 CBS introduced new features during the telecast including pylon cameras and microphones along with EyeVision 360—an array of 36 cameras along the upper deck that can be used to provide a 360degree view of plays and bullet time effects.
4 An earlier version of EyeVision was last used in Super Bowl XXXV for Super Bowl 50 the cameras were upgraded to 5K resolution.

1 On December 28 2015 ESPN Deportes announced that they had reached an agreement with CBS and the NFL to be the exclusive Spanishlanguage broadcaster of the game marking the third dedicated Spanishlanguage broadcast of the Super Bowl.
2 Unlike NBC and Fox CBS does not have a Spanishlanguage outlet of its own that could broadcast the game though per league policy a separate Spanish playbyplay call was carried on CBSs second audio program channel for overtheair viewers.
3 The game was called by ESPN Deportes Monday Night Football commentary crew of Alvaro Martin and Raul Allegre and sideline reporter John Sutcliffe.
4 ESPN Deportes broadcast pregame and postgame coverage while Martin Allegre and Sutcliffe contributed Englishlanguage reports for ESPNs SportsCenter and Mike  Mike.

1 After a punt from both teams Carolina got on track with a 9play 73yard scoring drive.
2 Newton completed 4 of 4 passes for 51 yards and rushed twice for 25 yards while Jonathan Stewart finished the drive with a 1yard touchdown run cutting the score to 10–7 with 1128 left in the second quarter.
3 Later on Broncos receiver Jordan Norwood received Brad Nortmans short 28yard punt surrounded by Panthers players but none of them attempted to make a tackle apparently thinking Norwood had called a fair catch.
4 Norwood had not done so and with no resistance around him he took off for a Super Bowl record 61yard return before Mario Addison dragged him down on the Panthers 14yard line.
5 Despite Denvers excellent field position they could not get the ball into the end zone so McManus kicked a 33yard field goal that increased their lead to 13–7.

1 With 451 left in regulation Carolina got the ball on their own 24yard line with a chance to mount a gamewinning drive and soon faced 3rdand9.
2 On the next play Miller stripped the ball away from Newton and after several players dove for it it took a long bounce backwards and was recovered by Ward who returned it five yards to the Panthers 4yard line.
3 Although several players dove into the pile to attempt to recover it Newton did not and his lack of aggression later earned him heavy criticism.
4 Meanwhile Denvers offense was kept out of the end zone for three plays but a holding penalty on cornerback Josh Norman gave the Broncos a new set of downs.
5 Then Anderson scored on a 2yard touchdown run and Manning completed a pass to Bennie Fowler for a 2point conversion giving Denver a 24–10 lead with 308 left and essentially putting the game away.
6 Carolina had two more drives but failed to get a first down on each one.

1 Manning finished the game 13 of 23 for 141 yards with one interception and zero touchdowns.
2 Sanders was his top receiver with six receptions for 83 yards.
3 Anderson was the games leading rusher with 90 yards and a touchdown along with four receptions for 10 yards.
4 Miller had six total tackles five solo 2½ sacks and two forced fumbles.
5 Ware had five total tackles and two sacks.
6 Ward had seven total tackles a fumble recovery and an interception.
7 McManus made all four of his field goals making him perfect on all 11 attempts during the postseason.
8 Newton completed 18 of 41 passes for 265 yards with one interception.
9 He was also the teams leading rusher with 45 yards on six carries.
10 Brown caught four passes for 80 yards while Ginn had four receptions for 74.
11 Ealy was the top defensive performer for Carolina with four total tackles three sacks a forced fumble a fumble recovery and an interception.
12 Defensive End Charles Johnson had four total tackles a sack and a forced fumble.
13 Linebacker Luke Kuechly had 11 total tackles while Thomas Davis had seven despite playing just two weeks after breaking his right arm in the NFC title game.

26 How many of the four field goal attempts did McManus succeed at during SUper Bowl 50?	all four	7
27 How many intercpetions did Newton have in Super Bowl 50?	one	1

1 Super Bowl 50 featured numerous records from individuals and teams.
2 Denver won despite being massively outgained in total yards 315 to 194 and first downs 21 to 11.
3 Their 194 yards and 11 first downs were both the lowest totals ever by a Super Bowl winning team.
4 The previous record was 244 yards by the Baltimore Ravens in Super Bowl XXXV.
5 Only seven other teams had ever gained less than 200 yards in a Super Bowl and all of them had lost.
6 The Broncos seven sacks tied a Super Bowl record set by the Chicago Bears in Super Bowl XX.
7 Kony Ealy tied a Super Bowl record with three sacks.
8 Jordan Norwoods 61yard punt return set a new record surpassing the old record of 45 yards set by John Taylor in Super Bowl XXIII.
9 Denver was just 1of14 on third down while Carolina was barely better at 3of15.
10 The two teams combined third down conversion percentage of 138 was a Super Bowl low.
11 Manning and Newton had quarterback passer ratings of 566 and 554 respectively and their added total of 112 is a record lowest aggregate passer rating for a Super Bowl.
12 Manning became the oldest quarterback ever to win a Super Bowl at age 39 and the first quarterback ever to win a Super Bowl with two different teams while Gary Kubiak became the first head coach to win a Super Bowl with the same franchise he went to the Super Bowl with as a player.

1 One of the most famous people born in Warsaw was Maria SkłodowskaCurie who achieved international recognition for her research on radioactivity and was the first female recipient of the Nobel Prize.
2 Famous musicians include Władysław Szpilman and Frédéric Chopin.
3 Though Chopin was born in the village of Żelazowa Wola about 60 km 37 mi from Warsaw he moved to the city with his family when he was seven months old.
4 Casimir Pulaski a Polish general and hero of the American Revolutionary War was born here in 1745.
5 What was Maria Curie the first female recipient of?	Nobel Prize	1

1 The Saxon Garden covering the area of 155 ha was formally a royal garden.
2 There are over 100 different species of trees and the avenues are a place to sit and relax.
3 At the east end of the park the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier is situated.
4 In the 19th century the Krasiński Palace Garden was remodelled by Franciszek Szanior.
5 Within the central area of the park one can still find old trees dating from that period maidenhair tree black walnut Turkish hazel and Caucasian wingnut trees.
6 With its benches flower carpets a pond with ducks on and a playground for kids the Krasiński Palace Garden is a popular strolling destination for the Varsovians.
7 The Monument of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising is also situated here.
8 The Łazienki Park covers the area of 76 ha.
9 The unique character and history of the park is reflected in its landscape architecture pavilions sculptures bridges cascades ponds and vegetation domestic and foreign species of trees and bushes.
10 What makes this park different from other green spaces in Warsaw is the presence of peacocks and pheasants which can be seen here walking around freely and royal carps in the pond.
11 The Wilanów Palace Park dates back to the second half of the 17th century.
12 It covers the area of 43 ha.
13 Its central Frenchstyled area corresponds to the ancient baroque forms of the palace.
14 The eastern section of the park closest to the Palace is the twolevel garden with a terrace facing the pond.
15 The park around the Królikarnia Palace is situated on the old escarpment of the Vistula.
16 The park has lanes running on a few levels deep into the ravines on both sides of the palace.
17 Over how many species of trees can be found in the Saxon Garden?	100	2
18 What is a popular strolling destination for the Varsovians?	Krasiński Palace Garden	6
19 What garden was formally only for royalty?	The Saxon Garden	1
20 Which end of the Saxon Garden is the Tom of the Unknown Soldier located at?	east end	3
21 What park covers an area of 76 ha?	Łazienki	8
1 There are 13 natural reserves in Warsaw – among others Bielany Forest Kabaty Woods Czerniaków Lake.
2 About 15 kilometres 9 miles from Warsaw the Vistula rivers environment changes strikingly and features a perfectly preserved ecosystem with a habitat of animals that includes the otter beaver and hundreds of bird species.
3 There are also several lakes in Warsaw – mainly the oxbow lakes like Czerniaków Lake the lakes in the Łazienki or Wilanów Parks Kamionek Lake.
4 There are lot of small lakes in the parks but only a few are permanent – the majority are emptied before winter to clean them of plants and sediments.
5 How far from Warsaw does the Vistula rivers environment change noticeably?	15 kilometres	2
6 What animals does the Vistula rivers ecosystem include?	otter  beaver and hundreds of bird species	2
7 How many natural reserves are in Warsaw?	13	1
8 How many lakes are there in Warsaw?	several	3
9 Why are the small lakes in the parks emptied before winter?	to clean them	4
1 Demographically it was the most diverse city in Poland with significant numbers of foreignborn inhabitants.
2 In addition to the Polish majority there was a significant Jewish minority in Warsaw.
3 According to Russian census of 1897 out of the total population of 638000 Jews constituted 219000 around 34 percent.
4 Warsaws prewar Jewish population of more than 350000 constituted about 30 percent of the citys total population.
5 In 1933 out of 1178914 inhabitants 833500 were of Polish mother tongue.
6 World War II changed the demographics of the city and to this day there is much less ethnic diversity than in the previous 300 years of Warsaws history.
7 Most of the modern day population growth is based on internal migration and urbanisation.

11 What was there a significant minority of in Warsaw?	Jewish	2
12 What is most of Warsaws modern growth based on?	migration and urbanisation	7
1 The University of Warsaw was established in 1816 when the partitions of Poland separated Warsaw from the oldest and most influential Polish academic center in Kraków.
2 Warsaw University of Technology is the second academic school of technology in the country and one of the largest in EastCentral Europe employing 2000 professors.
3 Other institutions for higher education include the Medical University of Warsaw the largest medical school in Poland and one of the most prestigious the National Defence University highest military academic institution in Poland the Fryderyk Chopin University of Music the oldest and largest music school in Poland and one of the largest in Europe the Warsaw School of Economics the oldest and most renowned economic university in the country and the Warsaw University of Life Sciences the largest agricultural university founded in 1818.

1 Like many cities in Central and Eastern Europe infrastructure in Warsaw suffered considerably during its time as an Eastern Bloc economy – though it is worth mentioning that the initial ThreeYear Plan to rebuild Poland especially Warsaw was a major success but what followed was very much the opposite.
2 However over the past decade Warsaw has seen many improvements due to solid economic growth an increase in foreign investment as well as funding from the European Union.
3 In particular the citys metro roads sidewalks health care facilities and sanitation facilities have improved markedly.

5 The infrastructure has developed a lot over the past years.

1 Nearby in Ogród Saski the Saxon Garden the Summer Theatre was in operation from 1870 to 1939 and in the interwar period the theatre complex also included Momus Warsaws first literary cabaret and Leon Schillers musical theatre Melodram.

1 Several commemorative events take place every year.
2 Gatherings of thousands of people on the banks of the Vistula on Midsummer’s Night for a festival called Wianki Polish for Wreaths have become a tradition and a yearly event in the programme of cultural events in Warsaw.
3 The festival traces its roots to a peaceful pagan ritual where maidens would float their wreaths of herbs on the water to predict when they would be married and to whom.
4 By the 19th century this tradition had become a festive event and it continues today.
5 The city council organize concerts and other events.
6 Each Midsummer’s Eve apart from the official floating of wreaths jumping over fires looking for the fern flower there are musical performances dignitaries speeches fairs and fireworks by the river bank.
7 What is the polish word for wreaths?	Wianki	2
8 How man people gather along the banks of the Vistula for the Wianki festival?	thousands	2
9 When is the Wianki festival held?	Midsummer’s Night	2
10 What will maidens be able to predict by floating their wreaths down the Vistula?	when they would be married	3
11 What type of flower is sought on Midsummers Eve?	the fern	6

1 The mermaid syrenka is Warsaws symbol and can be found on statues throughout the city and on the citys coat of arms.
2 This imagery has been in use since at least the mid14th century.
3 The oldest existing armed seal of Warsaw is from the year 1390 consisting of a round seal bordered with the Latin inscription Sigilium Civitatis Varsoviensis Seal of the city of Warsaw.
4 City records as far back as 1609 document the use of a crude form of a sea monster with a female upper body and holding a sword in its claws.
5 In 1653 the poet Zygmunt Laukowski asks the question.

1 The origin of the legendary figure is not fully known.
2 The bestknown legend by Artur Oppman is that long ago two of Tritons daughters set out on a journey through the depths of the oceans and seas.
3 One of them decided to stay on the coast of Denmark and can be seen sitting at the entrance to the port of Copenhagen.
4 The second mermaid reached the mouth of the Vistula River and plunged into its waters.
5 She stopped to rest on a sandy beach by the village of Warszowa where fishermen came to admire her beauty and listen to her beautiful voice.
6 A greedy merchant also heard her songs he followed the fishermen and captured the mermaid.

6 No one will ever see the Warsaw I knew.

1 In 2012 the Economist Intelligence Unit ranked Warsaw as the 32nd most liveable city in the world.
2 It was also ranked as one of the most liveable cities in Central Europe.
3 Today Warsaw is considered an Alpha– global city a major international tourist destination and a significant cultural political and economic hub.
4 Warsaws economy by a wide variety of industries is characterised by FMCG manufacturing metal processing steel and electronic manufacturing and food processing.
5 The city is a significant centre of research and development BPO ITO as well as of the Polish media industry.
6 The Warsaw Stock Exchange is one of the largest and most important in Central and Eastern Europe.
7 Frontex the European Union agency for external border security has its headquarters in Warsaw.
8 It has been said that Warsaw together with Frankfurt London Paris and Barcelona is one of the cities with the highest number of skyscrapers in the European Union.
9 Warsaw has also been called Eastern Europe’s chic cultural capital with thriving art and club scenes and serious restaurants.

13 What exchange in Warsaw is one of the most important for Central and Eastern Europe?	Stock	6
14 What is the name of the European Union agency for external border security?	Frontex	7
1 The first historical reference to Warsaw dates back to the year 1313 at a time when Kraków served as the Polish capital city.
2 Due to its central location between the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealths capitals of Kraków and Vilnius Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596.
3 After the Third Partition of Poland in 1795 Warsaw was incorporated into the Kingdom of Prussia.
4 In 1806 during the Napoleonic Wars the city became the official capital of the Grand Duchy of Warsaw a puppet state of the First French Empire established by Napoleon Bonaparte.
5 In accordance with the decisions of the Congress of Vienna the Russian Empire annexed Warsaw in 1815 and it became part of the Congress Kingdom.
6 Only in 1918 did it regain independence from the foreign rule and emerge as a new capital of the independent Republic of Poland.
7 The German invasion in 1939 the massacre of the Jewish population and deportations to concentration camps led to the uprising in the Warsaw ghetto in 1943 and to the major and devastating Warsaw Uprising between August and October 1944.
8 Warsaw gained the title of the Phoenix City because it has survived many wars conflicts and invasions throughout its long history.
9 Most notably the city required painstaking rebuilding after the extensive damage it suffered in World War II which destroyed 85 of its buildings.
10 On 9 November 1940 the city was awarded Polands highest military decoration for heroism the Virtuti Militari during the Siege of Warsaw 1939.
11 When is the first reference in history to Warsaw?	1313	1
12 What city served as Polands capital in 1313?	Kraków	1
13 When did Warsaw become the capital of the Kingdom of Poland?	1596	2
14 Who moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596?	King Sigismund III Vasa	2
15 Why did Warsaw gain the title of the Phoenix City?	survived many wars  conflicts and invasions	8
1 The city is the seat of a Roman Catholic archdiocese left bank of the Vistula and diocese right bank and possesses various universities most notably the Polish Academy of Sciences and the University of Warsaw two opera houses theatres museums libraries and monuments.
2 The historic citycentre of Warsaw with its picturesque Old Town in 1980 was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
3 Other main architectural attractions include the Castle Square with the Royal Castle and the iconic King Sigismunds Column St Johns Cathedral Market Square palaces churches and mansions all displaying a richness of colour and architectural detail.
4 Buildings represent examples of nearly every European architectural style and historical period.
5 Warsaw provides many examples of architecture from the gothic renaissance baroque and neoclassical periods and around a quarter of the city is filled with luxurious parks and royal gardens.
6 What archdiocese is Warsaw the seat of?	Roman Catholic	1
7 What is another notable university in Warsaw after the University of Warsaw?	Polish Academy of Sciences	1
8 What was Warsaws Old Town listed as in 1980?	a UNESCO World Heritage Site	2
9 King Sigimunds Column is an example of what kind of attraction in Warsaw?	architectural	3
10 What is a quarter of Warsaw filled with?	luxurious parks and royal gardens	5
1 Warsaws name in the Polish language is Warszawa approximately vɑːrˈʃɑːvə also formerly spelled Warszewa and Warszowa meaning belonging to Warsz Warsz being a shortened form of the masculine name of Slavic origin Warcisław see also etymology of Wrocław.
2 Folk etymology attributes the city name to a fisherman Wars and his wife Sawa.
3 According to legend Sawa was a mermaid living in the Vistula River with whom Wars fell in love.
4 In actuality Warsz was a 12th13thcentury nobleman who owned a village located at the modernday site of Mariensztat neighbourhood.
5 See also the Vršovci family which had escaped to Poland.
6 The official city name in full is miasto stołeczne Warszawa English The Capital City of Warsaw.
7 A native or resident of Warsaw is known as a Varsovian – in Polish warszawiak male warszawianka female warszawiacy plural.
8 What is Warsaws name in the Polish language?	Warszawa	1
9 What does Warszawa mean in Polish?	belonging to Warsz	1
10 Who was Warsz?	12th13thcentury nobleman	4
11 What did Warsz own?	a village	4
12 What is the full official city name of Warsaw?	miasto stołeczne Warszawa	6
1 The first fortified settlements on the site of todays Warsaw were located in Bródno 9th10th century and Jazdów 12th13th century.
2 After Jazdów was raided by nearby clans and dukes a new similar settlement was established on the site of a small fishing village called Warszowa.
3 The Prince of Płock Bolesław II of Masovia established this settlement the modernday Warsaw in about 1300.
4 In the beginning of the 14th century it became one of the seats of the Dukes of Masovia becoming the official capital of Masovian Duchy in 1413.
5 14thcentury Warsaws economy rested on mostly crafts and trade.
6 Upon the extinction of the local ducal line the duchy was reincorporated into the Polish Crown in 1526.
7 What city raided by clans and dukes preceded the founding of Warszowa?	Jazdów	2
8 Who was Boleslaw II of Masovia?	The Prince of Płock	3
9 When was the settlement which would become Warsaw established?	1300	3
10 In what year did Warszowa become the official capital of the Masovian Duchy?	1413	4
11 When was the Masovian Duchy reincorporated into the Polish Crown?	1526	706
1 In 1529 Warsaw for the first time became the seat of the General Sejm permanent from 1569.
2 In 1573 the city gave its name to the Warsaw Confederation formally establishing religious freedom in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
3 Due to its central location between the Commonwealths capitals of Kraków and Vilnius Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596.
4 In the following years the town expanded towards the suburbs.
5 Several private independent districts were established the property of aristocrats and the gentry which were ruled by their own laws.
6 Three times between 1655–1658 the city was under siege and three times it was taken and pillaged by the Swedish Brandenburgian and Transylvanian forces.
7 Who did Warsaw serve as the seat for in 1529?	General Sejm	1
8 When did the General Sejm make Warsaw its permanent seat?	1569	1
9 What did the Warsaw Confederation formally establish in 1573?	religious freedom	2
10 Why did Warsaw become the capital of the Commonwealth?	Due to its central location	3
11 What year did King Sigismund III Vasa move his court to Warsaw?	1596	3
1 Warsaw remained the capital of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth until 1796 when it was annexed by the Kingdom of Prussia to become the capital of the province of South Prussia.
2 Liberated by Napoleons army in 1806 Warsaw was made the capital of the newly created Duchy of Warsaw.
3 Following the Congress of Vienna of 1815 Warsaw became the centre of the Congress Poland a constitutional monarchy under a personal union with Imperial Russia.
4 The Royal University of Warsaw was established in 1816.
5 How long was Warsaw the capital of the PolishLithuanian Commonwealth?	until 1796	1
6 What kingdom annexed Warsaw in 1796?	Prussia	1
7 Whose army liberated Warsaw in 1806?	Napoleons	2
8 When did Warsaw become the center of the Congress Poland?	1815	3
9 When was the Royal University of Warsaw established?	1816	4
1 Warsaw was occupied by Germany from 4 August 1915 until November 1918.
2 The Allied Armistice terms required in Article 12 that Germany withdraw from areas controlled by Russia in 1914 which included Warsaw.
3 Germany did so and underground leader Piłsudski returned to Warsaw on 11 November and set up what became the Second Polish Republic with Warsaw the capital.
4 In the course of the PolishBolshevik War of 1920 the huge Battle of Warsaw was fought on the eastern outskirts of the city in which the capital was successfully defended and the Red Army defeated.
5 Poland stopped by itself the full brunt of the Red Army and defeated an idea of the export of the revolution.
6 How long was Warsaw occupied by Germany?	from 4 August 1915 until November 1918	1
7 What did Article 12 of the Allied Armistice terms require Germany to withdraw from?	areas controlled by Russia in 1914	2
8 Who set up what became the Second Polish Republic?	underground leader Piłsudski	3
9 When was the PolishBolshevik war fought?	1920	4
10 What army did Warsaw successfully defend itself against?	the Red Army	4
1 After the German Invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939 began the Second World War Warsaw was defended till September 27.
2 Central Poland including Warsaw came under the rule of the General Government a German Nazi colonial administration.
3 All higher education institutions were immediately closed and Warsaws entire Jewish population – several hundred thousand some 30 of the city – herded into the Warsaw Ghetto.
4 The city would become the centre of urban resistance to Nazi rule in occupied Europe.
5 When the order came to annihilate the ghetto as part of Hitlers Final Solution on 19 April 1943 Jewish fighters launched the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising.
6 Despite being heavily outgunned and outnumbered the Ghetto held out for almost a month.
7 When the fighting ended almost all survivors were massacred with only a few managing to escape or hide.
8 When did Germany invade Poland and in doing so start World War II?	September 1939	1
9 Who was Warsaw under the administration of when it came under the rule of the General Goverment?	a German Nazi colonial administration	2
10 How much of Warsaws population was Jewish?	some 30 of the city	3
11 When did Hitler order the annihilation of the Warsaw Ghetto?	April 1943	5
12 How long were the fighters of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising able to hold out?	almost a month	6
1 By July 1944 the Red Army was deep into Polish territory and pursuing the Germans toward Warsaw.
2 Knowing that Stalin was hostile to the idea of an independent Poland the Polish governmentinexile in London gave orders to the underground Home Army AK to try to seize control of Warsaw from the Germans before the Red Army arrived.
3 Thus on 1 August 1944 as the Red Army was nearing the city the Warsaw Uprising began.
4 The armed struggle planned to last 48 hours was partially successful however it went on for 63 days.
5 Eventually the Home Army fighters and civilians assisting them were forced to capitulate.
6 They were transported to PoW camps in Germany while the entire civilian population was expelled.
7 Polish civilian deaths are estimated at between 150000 and 200000.
8 What army was pushing deep into Polish territory to pursue the Germans in 1944?	the Red Army	1
9 Why did the exiled Polish government in London order the underground Home Army to seize control of Warsaw prior to the arrival of the Red Army?	Stalin was hostile to the idea of an independent Poland	2
10 When did the Warsaw Uprising begin?	August 1944	3
11 How many days did the Warsaw Uprising last?	63 days	4
12 What is the estimated death toll for Polish civilians?	between 150 000 and 200 000	7
1 After World War II under a Communist regime set up by the conquering Soviets the Bricks for Warsaw campaign was initiated and large prefabricated housing projects were erected in Warsaw to address the housing shortage along with other typical buildings of an Eastern Bloc city such as the Palace of Culture and Science a gift from the Soviet Union.
2 The city resumed its role as the capital of Poland and the countrys centre of political and economic life.
3 Many of the historic streets buildings and churches were restored to their original form.
4 In 1980 Warsaws historic Old Town was inscribed onto UNESCOs World Heritage list.
5 What campaign did the Communist regime initiate after WWII?	Bricks for Warsaw	1
6 What type of housing was erected in Warsaw as part of the Bricks for Warsaw process?	prefabricated	1
7 What were the structures built by the Soviets typical of?	an Eastern Bloc city	1
8 What building was a gift from the Soviet Union?	Palace of Culture and Science	1
9 What list was Warsaws Old Town inscribed onto in 1980?	UNESCOs World Heritage list	4
1 John Paul IIs visits to his native country in 1979 and 1983 brought support to the budding solidarity movement and encouraged the growing anticommunist fervor there.
2 In 1979 less than a year after becoming pope John Paul celebrated Mass in Victory Square in Warsaw and ended his sermon with a call to renew the face of Poland Let Thy Spirit descend.
3 Let Thy Spirit descend and renew the face of the land.
4 This land.
5 These words were very meaningful for the Polish citizens who understood them as the incentive for the democratic changes.

9 Where did John Paul II celebrate Mass in Warsaw?	Victory Square	2

1 Warsaw lies in eastcentral Poland about 300 km 190 mi from the Carpathian Mountains and about 260 km 160 mi from the Baltic Sea 523 km 325 mi east of Berlin Germany.
2 The city straddles the Vistula River.
3 It is located in the heartland of the Masovian Plain and its average elevation is 100 metres 330 ft above sea level.
4 The highest point on the left side of the city lies at a height of 1157 metres 3796 ft Redutowa bus depot district of Wola on the right side – 1221 metres 4006 ft Groszówka estate district of Wesoła by the eastern border.
5 The lowest point lies at a height 756 metres 2480 ft at the right bank of the Vistula by the eastern border of Warsaw.
6 There are some hills mostly artificial located within the confines of the city – eg.
7 Warsaw Uprising Hill 121 metres 3970 ft Szczęśliwice hill 138 metres 4528 ft – the highest point of Warsaw in general.
8 How many kilometers is Warsaw from the Carpathian Mountains?	about 300	1
9 How many miles east of Berlin is Warsaw?	325	1
10 What river does Warsaw straddle?	Vistula River	2
11 How high is the highest point in Warsaw?	4528 ft	7
12 Where is the lowest point of Warsaw located?	at the right bank of the Vistula	5
1 Warsaw is located on two main geomorphologic formations the plain moraine plateau and the Vistula Valley with its asymmetrical pattern of different terraces.
2 The Vistula River is the specific axis of Warsaw which divides the city into two parts left and right.
3 The left one is situated both on the moraine plateau 10 to 25 m 328 to 820 ft above Vistula level and on the Vistula terraces max.
4 65 m 213 ft above Vistula level.
5 The significant element of the relief in this part of Warsaw is the edge of moraine plateau called Warsaw Escarpment.
6 It is 20 to 25 m 656 to 820 ft high in the Old Town and Central district and about 10 m 328 ft in the north and south of Warsaw.
7 It goes through the city and plays an important role as a landmark.
8 How many geomorphologic formations is Warsaw on?	two	1
9 What formation has an asymmetrical pattern of different terraces?	Vistula Valley	1
10 Which plateau is the left part of Warsaw on?	moraine	3
11 What is the axis of Warsaw which divides it into two parts?	Vistula River	2
12 What is the edge of the moraine plateau called?	Warsaw Escarpment	5
1 The plain moraine plateau has only a few natural and artificial ponds and also groups of clay pits.
2 The pattern of the Vistula terraces is asymmetrical.
3 The left side consist mainly of two levels the highest one contains former flooded terraces and the lowest one the flood plain terrace.
4 The contemporary flooded terrace still has visible valleys and ground depressions with water systems coming from the Vistula old – riverbed.
5 They consist of still quite natural streams and lakes as well as the pattern of drainage ditches.
6 The right side of Warsaw has a different pattern of geomorphological forms.
7 There are several levels of the plain Vistula terraces flooded as well as former flooded once and only small part and not so visible moraine escarpment.
8 Aeolian sand with a number of dunes parted by peat swamps or small ponds cover the highest terrace.
9 These are mainly forested areas pine forest.
10 What plateau has groups of clay pits?	moraine	1
11 What does the highest level of the Vistula plateau contain?	former flooded terraces	3
12 What does the currently flooded terrace still have visible?	valleys	4
13 Where can Aeolian sand with a number of dunes be found?	plain Vistula terraces	7
14 What type of forested areas can be found on the highest terrace?	pine	9
1 Warsaws mixture of architectural styles reflects the turbulent history of the city and country.
2 During the Second World War Warsaw was razed to the ground by bombing raids and planned destruction.
3 After liberation rebuilding began as in other cities of the communistruled PRL.
4 Most of the historical buildings were thoroughly reconstructed.
5 However some of the buildings from the 19th century that had been preserved in reasonably reconstructible form were nonetheless eradicated in the 1950s and 1960s eg.
6 Leopold Kronenberg Palace.
7 Mass residential blocks were erected with basic design typical of Eastern bloc countries.
8 What does Warsaws mixture of architectural styles reflect?	turbulent history of the city	1
9 When was Warsaw completely razed to the ground by bombing raids?	During the Second World War	2
10 When did Warsaw start to rebuild?	After liberation	3
11 What building from the 19th century was destroyed between the 1950s and 1960s?	Leopold Kronenberg Palace	6
12 What style were the mass constructed residential blocks designed in?	typical of Eastern bloc countries	7
1 Gothic architecture is represented in the majestic churches but also at the burgher houses and fortifications.
2 The most significant buildings are St Johns Cathedral 14th century the temple is a typical example of the socalled Masovian gothic style St Marys Church 1411 a town house of Burbach family 14th century Gunpowder Tower after 1379 and the Royal Castle Curia Maior 1407–1410.
3 The most notable examples of Renaissance architecture in the city are the house of Baryczko merchant family 1562 building called The Negro early 17th century and Salwator tenement 1632.
4 The most interesting examples of mannerist architecture are the Royal Castle 1596–1619 and the Jesuit Church 1609–1626 at Old Town.
5 Among the first structures of the early baroque the most important are St Hyacinths Church 1603–1639 and Sigismunds Column 1644.
6 What type of architecture is represented in the majestic churches?	Gothic	1
7 When was St Johns Cathedral constructed?	14th century	2
8 What is St Johns Cathedral an example of stylistically?	Masovian gothic	2
9 The house of the Baryczko merchant family is a notable example of what type of architecture?	Renaissance	3
10 What is the Royal Castle the most interesting example of?	mannerist architecture	4
1 Building activity occurred in numerous noble palaces and churches during the later decades of the 17th century.
2 One of the best examples of this architecture are Krasiński Palace 1677–1683 Wilanów Palace 1677–1696 and St Kazimierz Church 1688–1692.
3 The most impressive examples of rococo architecture are Czapski Palace 1712–1721 Palace of the Four Winds 1730s and Visitationist Church façade 1728–1761.
4 The neoclassical architecture in Warsaw can be described by the simplicity of the geometrical forms teamed with a great inspiration from the Roman period.
5 Some of the best examples of the neoclassical style are the Palace on the Water rebuilt 1775–1795 Królikarnia 1782–1786 Carmelite Church façade 1761–1783 and Evangelical Holy Trinity Church 1777–1782.
6 The economic growth during the first years of Congress Poland caused a rapid rise architecture.
7 The Neoclassical revival affected all aspects of architecture the most notable are the Great Theater 1825–1833 and buildings located at Bank Square 1825–1828.
8 When did building activity in the palaces and churches take place in the later decades of?	17th century	1
9 When did building activity occur on St Kazimierz Church?	1688–1692	2
10 What type of architecture is the Palace of Four Windows an impressive example of?	rococo	3
11 What is being described when simplicity of geometrical forms are teamed with inspiration from the Roman period?	neoclassical architecture	4
12 When was the Palace on the Water rebuilt?	1775–1795	5
1 Exceptional examples of the bourgeois architecture of the later periods were not restored by the communist authorities after the war like mentioned Kronenberg Palace and Insurance Company Rosja building or they were rebuilt in socialist realism style like Warsaw Philharmony edifice originally inspired by Palais Garnier in Paris.
2 Despite that the Warsaw University of Technology building 1899–1902 is the most interesting of the late 19thcentury architecture.
3 Some 19thcentury buildings in the Praga district the Vistula’s right bank have been restored although many have been poorly maintained.
4 Warsaw’s municipal government authorities have decided to rebuild the Saxon Palace and the Brühl Palace the most distinctive buildings in prewar Warsaw.
5 The Kronenberg Palace had been an exceptional example of what type of architecture?	bourgeois	1
6 Why arent the examples of bouregois architecture visible today?	not restored by the communist authorities	1

1 There are also many places commemorating the heroic history of Warsaw.
2 Pawiak an infamous German Gestapo prison now occupied by a Mausoleum of Memory of Martyrdom and the museum is only the beginning of a walk in the traces of Heroic City.
3 The Warsaw Citadel an impressive 19thcentury fortification built after the defeat of the November Uprising was a place of martyr for the Poles.
4 Another important monument the statue of Little Insurgent located at the ramparts of the Old Town commemorates the children who served as messengers and frontline troops in the Warsaw Uprising while the impressive Warsaw Uprising Monument by Wincenty Kućma was erected in memory of the largest insurrection of World War II.

1 Other green spaces in the city include the Botanic Garden and the University Library garden.
2 They have extensive botanical collection of rare domestic and foreign plants while a palm house in the New Orangery displays plants of subtropics from all over the world.
3 Besides within the city borders there are also Pole Mokotowskie a big park in the northern Mokotów where was the first horse racetrack and then the airport Park Ujazdowski close to the Sejm and John Lennon street Park of Culture and Rest in Powsin by the southern city border Park Skaryszewski by the right Vistula bank in Praga.
4 The oldest park in Praga the Praga Park was established in 1865–1871 and designed by Jan Dobrowolski.
5 In 1927 a zoological garden Ogród Zoologiczny was established on the park grounds and in 1952 a bear run still open today.

1 The flora of the city may be considered very rich in species.
2 The species richness is mainly due to the location of Warsaw within the border region of several big floral regions comprising substantial proportions of closetowilderness areas natural forests wetlands along the Vistula as well as arable land meadows and forests.
3 Bielany Forest located within the borders of Warsaw is the remaining part of the Masovian Primeval Forest.
4 Bielany Forest nature reserve is connected with Kampinos Forest.
5 It is home to rich fauna and flora.
6 Within the forest there are three cycling and walking trails.
7 Other big forest area is Kabaty Forest by the southern city border.
8 Warsaw has also two botanic gardens by the Łazienki park a didacticresearch unit of the University of Warsaw as well as by the Park of Culture and Rest in Powsin a unit of the Polish Academy of Science.

10 Where is Bielany Forest located?	within the borders of Warsaw	3
11 What is the Bielany Forest the last remnant of?	Masovian Primeval Forest	3
12 What forest is by Warsaws southern border?	Kabaty	7
13 How many botanical gardens does Warsaw have?	two	8
1 In 1939 c 1300000 people lived in Warsaw but in 1945 – only 420000.
2 During the first years after the war the population growth was c 6 so shortly the city started to suffer from the lack of flats and of areas for new houses.
3 The first remedial measure was the Warsaw area enlargement 1951 – but the city authorities were still forced to introduce residency registration limitations only the spouses and children of the permanent residents as well as some persons of public importance like renowned specialists were allowed to get the registration hence halving the population growth in the following years.
4 It also bolstered some kind of conviction among Poles that Varsovians thought of themselves as better only because they lived in the capital.
5 Unfortunately this belief still lives on in Poland although not as much as it used to be – even though since 1990 there are no limitations to residency registration anymore.
6 How many people lived in Warsaw in 1939?	1 300 000	1
7 What had the number of people living in Warsaw declined to by 1945?	420 000	1
8 When did the Warsaw area enlargement take place?	1951	3
9 What conviction did many Poles have regarding how the Varsovians thought of themselves?	as better	4
10 What are there no longer limitations on since 1990?	residency registration	5
1 Throughout its existence Warsaw has been a multicultural city.
2 According to the 1901 census out of 711988 inhabitants 562 were Catholics 357 Jews 5 Greek orthodox Christians and 28 Protestants.
3 Eight years later in 1909 there were 281754 Jews 369 18189 Protestants 24 and 2818 Mariavites 04.
4 This led to construction of hundreds of places of religious worship in all parts of the town.
5 Most of them were destroyed in the aftermath of the Warsaw Uprising of 1944.
6 After the war the new communist authorities of Poland discouraged church construction and only a small number were rebuilt.
7 What type of city has Warsaw been for as long as its been a city?	multicultural	1
8 What was Warsaws population in 1901?	711 988	2
9 Of Warsaws inhabitants in 1901 what percentage was Catholic?	562	2
10 What percentage of Warsaws population was Protestant in 1901?	28	2
11 When were most of the places of religious worship destroyed in Warsaw?	1944	5
1 The basic unit of territorial division in Poland is a commune gmina.
2 A city is also a commune – but with the city charter.
3 Both cities and communes are governed by a mayor – but in the communes the mayor is vogt wójt in Polish however in the cities – burmistrz.
4 Some bigger cities obtain the entitlements ie.
5 tasks and privileges which are possessed by the units of the second level of the territorial division – counties or powiats.
6 An example of such entitlement is a car registration a gmina cannot register cars this is a powiats task ie.
7 a registration number depends on what powiat a car had been registered not gmina.
8 In this case we say about city county or powiat grodzki.
9 Such cities are for example Lublin Kraków Gdańsk Poznań.
10 In Warsaw its districts additionally have some of powiats entitlements – like already mentioned car registration.
11 For example the district Wola has its own evidence and the district Ursynów – its own and the cars from Wola have another type of registration number than these from Ursynów.
12 But for instance the districts in Kraków do not have entitlements of powiat so the registration numbers in Kraków are of the same type for all districts.
13 What is the basic unit of territorial division in Poland?	a commune	1
14 What is the second level of territorial division in Poland?	counties or powiats	5
15 In what districts are the registration numbers for cars all of the same type?	Kraków	12
1 Legislative power in Warsaw is vested in a unicameral Warsaw City Council Rada Miasta which comprises 60 members.
2 Council members are elected directly every four years.
3 Like most legislative bodies the City Council divides itself into committees which have the oversight of various functions of the city government.
4 Bills passed by a simple majority are sent to the mayor the President of Warsaw who may sign them into law.
5 If the mayor vetoes a bill the Council has 30 days to override the veto by a twothirds majority vote.
6 Who in Warsaw has the power of legislative action?	Warsaw City Council	1
7 How many members are on the Warsaw City Counil?	60	1
8 How often are elections for the counsel held?	every four years	2
9 What does the City Council divide itself into?	committees	3
10 How many days does the Council have to override the mayors veto?	30 days	5
1 The mayor of Warsaw is called President.
2 Generally in Poland the mayors of bigger cities are called presidents – ie.
3 such cities which have over 100000 people or these where already was president before 1990.
4 The first Warsaw President was Jan Andrzej Menich 1695–1696.
5 Between 1975 and 1990 the Warsaw Presidents was simultaneously the Warsaw Voivode.
6 Since 1990 the President of Warsaw had been elected by the City council.
7 In the years of 1994–1999 the mayor of the district Centrum automatically was designated as the President of Warsaw the mayor of Centrum was elected by the district council of Centrum and the council was elected only by the Centrum residents.
8 Since 2002 the President of Warsaw is elected by all of the citizens of Warsaw.
9 What is the mayor of Warsaw called?	President	1
10 Who was the first Warsaw President?	Jan Andrzej Menich	4
11 When did Menich serve as President?	1695–1696	4
12 Who has elected the President of Warsaw since 1990?	the City council	6
13 What district of Warsaw chose the President between 1994 and 1999?	Centrum	7
1 Warsaw especially its city centre Śródmieście is home not only to many national institutions and government agencies but also to many domestic and international companies.
2 In 2006 304016 companies were registered in the city.
3 Warsaws evergrowing business community has been noticed globally regionally and nationally.
4 MasterCard Emerging Market Index has noted Warsaws economic strength and commercial center.
5 Moreover Warsaw was ranked as the 7th greatest emerging market.
6 Foreign investors financial participation in the citys development was estimated in 2002 at over 650 million euro.
7 Warsaw produces 12 of Polands national income which in 2008 was 3051 of the Polish average per capita or 160 of the European Union average.
8 The GDP per capita in Warsaw amounted to PLN 94 000 in 2008 c EUR 23 800 USD 33 000.
9 Total nominal GDP of the city in 2010 amounted to 191766 billion PLN 111696 PLN per capita which was 3011  of Polish average.
10 Warsaw leads the region of EastCentral Europe in foreign investment and in 2006 GDP growth met expectations with a level of 61.
11 It also has one of the fastest growing economies with GDP growth at 65 percent in 2007 and 61 percent in the first quarter of 2008.

1 Warsaws first stock exchange was established in 1817 and continued trading until World War II.
2 It was reestablished in April 1991 following the end of the postwar communist control of the country and the reintroduction of a freemarket economy.
3 Today the Warsaw Stock Exchange WSE is according to many indicators the largest market in the region with 374 companies listed and total capitalization of 162 584 mln EUR as of 31 August 2009.
4 From 1991 until 2000 the stock exchange was ironically located in the building previously used as the headquarters of the Polish United Workers Party PZPR.

1 The FSO Car Factory was established in 1951.
2 A number of vehicles have been assembled there over the decades including the Warszawa Syrena Fiat 125p under license from Fiat later renamed FSO 125p when the license expired and the Polonez.
3 The last two models listed were also sent abroad and assembled in a number of other countries including Egypt and Colombia.
4 In 1995 the factory was purchased by the South Korean car manufacturer Daewoo which assembled the Tico Espero Nubia Tacuma Leganza Lanos and Matiz there for the European market.
5 In 2005 the factory was sold to AvtoZAZ a Ukrainian car manufacturer which assembled there the Chevrolet Aveo.
6 The license for the production of the Aveo expired in February 2011 and has since not been renewed.
7 Currently the company is defunct.
8 When was the FSO Car Factory founded?	1951	1
9 What car is licensed by the FSO Car Factory and built in Egypt?	Polonez	2
10 What South Korean car manufacturer purchased the factor in 1995?	Daewoo	4
11 Who bought the factory in 2005?	AvtoZAZ	5
12 What did the license to build this type of car expire in 2011?	Chevrolet Aveo	5
1 Warsaw Polish Warszawa varˈʂava  listen see also other names is the capital and largest city of Poland.
2 It stands on the Vistula River in eastcentral Poland roughly 260 kilometres 160 mi from the Baltic Sea and 300 kilometres 190 mi from the Carpathian Mountains.
3 Its population is estimated at 1740 million residents within a greater metropolitan area of 2666 million residents which makes Warsaw the 9th mostpopulous capital city in the European Union.
4 The city limits cover 5169 square kilometres 1996 sq mi while the metropolitan area covers 610043 square kilometres 235539 sq mi.
5 What is Warsaw known as in Polish?	Warszawa	1
6 What is the largest city in Poland?	Warsaw	1
7 What river runs through Warsaw?	Vistula River	2
