1 The Normans Norman Nourmands French Normands Latin Normanni were the people who in the 10th and 11th centuries gave their name to Normandy a region in France.
2 They were descended from Norse Norman comes from Norseman raiders and pirates from Denmark Iceland and Norway who under their leader Rollo agreed to swear fealty to King Charles III of West Francia.
3 Through generations of assimilation and mixing with the native Frankish and RomanGaulish populations their descendants would gradually merge with the Carolingianbased cultures of West Francia.
4 The distinct cultural and ethnic identity of the Normans emerged initially in the first half of the 10th century and it continued to evolve over the succeeding centuries.
5 In what country is Normandy located?	France	1
6 When were the Normans in Normandy?	10th and 11th centuries	1
7 From which countries did the Norse originate?	Denmark  Iceland and Norway	2
8 Who was the Norse leader?	Rollo	2
9 What century did the Normans first gain their separate identity?	10th century	4
1 The Norman dynasty had a major political cultural and military impact on medieval Europe and even the Near East.
2 The Normans were famed for their martial spirit and eventually for their Christian piety becoming exponents of the Catholic orthodoxy into which they assimilated.
3 They adopted the GalloRomance language of the Frankish land they settled their dialect becoming known as Norman Normaund or Norman French an important literary language.
4 The Duchy of Normandy which they formed by treaty with the French crown was a great fief of medieval France and under Richard I of Normandy was forged into a cohesive and formidable principality in feudal tenure.
5 The Normans are noted both for their culture such as their unique Romanesque architecture and musical traditions and for their significant military accomplishments and innovations.
6 Norman adventurers founded the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger II after conquering southern Italy on the Saracens and Byzantines and an expedition on behalf of their duke William the Conqueror led to the Norman conquest of England at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.
7 Norman cultural and military influence spread from these new European centres to the Crusader states of the Near East where their prince Bohemond I founded the Principality of Antioch in the Levant to Scotland and Wales in Great Britain to Ireland and to the coasts of north Africa and the Canary Islands.
8 Who was the duke in the battle of Hastings?	William the Conqueror	6
9 Who ruled the duchy of Normandy	Richard I 	4.
10 What religion were the Normans	Catholic 	2.
1 The English name Normans comes from the French words NormansNormanz plural of Normant modern French normand which is itself borrowed from Old Low Franconian Nortmann Northman or directly from Old Norse Norðmaðr Latinized variously as Nortmannus Normannus or Nordmannus recorded in Medieval Latin 9th century to mean Norseman Viking.
2 What is the original meaning of the word Norman?	Viking	1
3 When was the Latin version of the word Norman first recorded?	9th century	1
1 In the course of the 10th century the initially destructive incursions of Norse war bands into the rivers of France evolved into more permanent encampments that included local women and personal property.
2 The Duchy of Normandy which began in 911 as a fiefdom was established by the treaty of SaintClairsurEpte between King Charles III of West Francia and the famed Viking ruler Rollo and was situated in the former Frankish kingdom of Neustria.
3 The treaty offered Rollo and his men the French lands between the river Epte and the Atlantic coast in exchange for their protection against further Viking incursions.
4 The area corresponded to the northern part of presentday Upper Normandy down to the river Seine but the Duchy would eventually extend west beyond the Seine.
5 The territory was roughly equivalent to the old province of Rouen and reproduced the Roman administrative structure of Gallia Lugdunensis II part of the former Gallia Lugdunensis.
6 When was the Duchy of Normandy founded?	911	2
7 Who did Rollo sign the treaty of SaintClairsurEpte with?	King Charles III	2
8 What river originally bounded the Duchy	Seine 	4.
1 Before Rollos arrival its populations did not differ from Picardy or the ÎledeFrance which were considered Frankish.
2 Earlier Viking settlers had begun arriving in the 880s but were divided between colonies in the east Roumois and Pays de Caux around the low Seine valley and in the west in the Cotentin Peninsula and were separated by traditional pagii where the population remained about the same with almost no foreign settlers.
3 Rollos contingents who raided and ultimately settled Normandy and parts of the Atlantic coast included Danes Norwegians Norse–Gaels Orkney Vikings possibly Swedes and AngloDanes from the English Danelaw under Norse control.
4 Who upon arriving gave the original viking settlers a common identity?	Rollo	1
1 The descendants of Rollos Vikings and their Frankish wives would replace the Norse religion and Old Norse language with Catholicism Christianity and the GalloRomance language of the local people blending their maternal Frankish heritage with Old Norse traditions and customs to synthesize a unique Norman culture in the north of France.
2 The Norman language was forged by the adoption of the indigenous langue doïl branch of Romance by a Norsespeaking ruling class and it developed into the regional language that survives today.
3 What was the Norman religion?	Catholicism	1
4 What part of France were the Normans located?	north	1
1 The Normans thereafter adopted the growing feudal doctrines of the rest of France and worked them into a functional hierarchical system in both Normandy and in England.
2 The new Norman rulers were culturally and ethnically distinct from the old French aristocracy most of whom traced their lineage to Franks of the Carolingian dynasty.
3 Most Norman knights remained poor and landhungry and by 1066 Normandy had been exporting fighting horsemen for more than a generation.
4 Many Normans of Italy France and England eventually served as avid Crusaders under the ItaloNorman prince Bohemund I and the AngloNorman king Richard the LionHeart.
5 What was one of the Normans major exports?	fighting horsemen	3
1 Opportunistic bands of Normans successfully established a foothold in Southern Italy the Mezzogiorno.
2 Probably as the result of returning pilgrims stories the Normans entered the Mezzogiorno as warriors in 1017 at the latest.
3 In 999 according to Amatus of Montecassino Norman pilgrims returning from Jerusalem called in at the port of Salerno when a Saracen attack occurred.
4 The Normans fought so valiantly that Prince Guaimar III begged them to stay but they refused and instead offered to tell others back home of the princes request.
5 William of Apulia tells that in 1016 Norman pilgrims to the shrine of the Archangel Michael at Monte Gargano were met by Melus of Bari a Lombard nobleman and rebel who persuaded them to return with more warriors to help throw off the Byzantine rule which they did.
6 When did the attack occur in which the Normans impressed Prince Guaimar III occur?	999	3
7 Whose shrine did the pilgrims go to in 1016?	Archangel Michael	5
8 Where was the Archangel Michael shrine located?	Monte Gargano	5
1 The two most prominent Norman families to arrive in the Mediterranean were descendants of Tancred of Hauteville and the Drengot family of whom Rainulf Drengot received the county of Aversa the first Norman toehold in the south from Duke Sergius IV of Naples in 1030.
2 The Hauteville family achieved princely rank by proclaiming prince Guaimar IV of Salerno Duke of Apulia and Calabria.
3 He promptly awarded their elected leader William Iron Arm with the title of count in his capital of Melfi.
4 The Drengot family thereafter attained the principality of Capua and emperor Henry III legally ennobled the Hauteville leader Drogo as dux et magister Italiae comesque Normannorum totius Apuliae et Calabriae Duke and Master of Italy and Count of the Normans of all Apulia and Calabria in 1047.
5 What was the name of the leader ennobled by Henry III	Drogo 	4.
6 Who was Count of Melfi	William Iron Arm 	3.
1 From these bases the Normans eventually captured Sicily and Malta from the Saracens under the leadership of the famous Robert Guiscard a Hauteville and his younger brother Roger the Great Count.
2 Rogers son Roger II of Sicily was crowned king in 1130 exactly one century after Rainulf was crowned count by Antipope Anacletus II.
3 The Kingdom of Sicily lasted until 1194 when it was transferred to the House of Hohenstaufen through marriage.
4 The Normans left their legacy in many castles such as William Iron Arms citadel at Squillace and cathedrals such as Roger IIs Cappella Palatina chapel at Palermo which dot the landscape and give a wholly distinct architectural flavor to accompany its unique history.
5 Who controlled Sicily before the Normans?	Saracens	1
6 In what year was Roger II made king?	1130	2
7 Where was William Iron Arms castle located?	Squillace	4
1 Institutionally the Normans combined the administrative machinery of the Byzantines Arabs and Lombards with their own conceptions of feudal law and order to forge a unique government.
2 Under this state there was great religious freedom and alongside the Norman nobles existed a meritocratic bureaucracy of Jews Muslims and Christians both Catholic and Eastern Orthodox.
3 The Kingdom of Sicily thus became characterized by Norman Byzantine Greek Arab Lombard and native Sicilian populations living in harmony and its Norman rulers fostered plans of establishing an Empire that would have encompassed Fatimid Egypt as well as the Crusader states in the Levant.
4 One of the great geographical treatises of the Middle Ages the Tabula Rogeriana was written by the Andalusian alIdrisi for king Roger II of Sicily and entitled Kitab Rudjdjar The Book of Roger.
5 What is another name for the Tabula Rogeriana?	Kitab Rudjdjar	4
6 What does Kitab Rudjdjar mean in English?	The Book of Roger	4
7 What kind of bureaucracy did the Normans institute?	meritocratic	2
1 Soon after the Normans began to enter Italy they entered the Byzantine Empire and then Armenia fighting against the Pechenegs the Bulgars and especially the Seljuk Turks.
2 Norman mercenaries were first encouraged to come to the south by the Lombards to act against the Byzantines but they soon fought in Byzantine service in Sicily.
3 They were prominent alongside Varangian and Lombard contingents in the Sicilian campaign of George Maniaces in 1038–40.
4 There is debate whether the Normans in Greek service actually were from Norman Italy and it now seems likely only a few came from there.
5 It is also unknown how many of the Franks as the Byzantines called them were Normans and not other Frenchmen.
6 Who was the Normans main enemy in Italy the Byzantine Empire and Armenia?	Seljuk Turks	1
1 One of the first Norman mercenaries to serve as a Byzantine general was Hervé in the 1050s.
2 By then however there were already Norman mercenaries serving as far away as Trebizond and Georgia.
3 They were based at Malatya and Edessa under the Byzantine duke of Antioch Isaac Komnenos.
4 In the 1060s Robert Crispin led the Normans of Edessa against the Turks.
5 Roussel de Bailleul even tried to carve out an independent state in Asia Minor with support from the local population but he was stopped by the Byzantine general Alexius Komnenos.
6 When did Herve serve as a Byzantine general?	1050s	1
7 When did Robert Crispin go up against the Turks?	1060s	4
8 Who ruined Roussel de Bailleuls plans for an independent state?	Alexius Komnenos	5
1 Some Normans joined Turkish forces to aid in the destruction of the Armenians vassalstates of Sassoun and Taron in far eastern Anatolia.
2 Later many took up service with the Armenian state further south in Cilicia and the Taurus Mountains.
3 A Norman named Oursel led a force of Franks into the upper Euphrates valley in northern Syria.
4 From 1073 to 1074 8000 of the 20000 troops of the Armenian general Philaretus Brachamius were Normans—formerly of Oursel—led by Raimbaud.
5 They even lent their ethnicity to the name of their castle Afranji meaning Franks.
6 The known trade between Amalfi and Antioch and between Bari and Tarsus may be related to the presence of ItaloNormans in those cities while Amalfi and Bari were under Norman rule in Italy.
7 What was the name of the Norman castle?	Afranji	5
8 Who was the leader when the Franks entered the Euphrates valley?	Oursel	3
9 Who did the Normans team up with in Anatolia?	Turkish forces	1
1 Several families of Byzantine Greece were of Norman mercenary origin during the period of the Comnenian Restoration when Byzantine emperors were seeking out western European warriors.
2 The Raoulii were descended from an ItaloNorman named Raoul the Petraliphae were descended from a Pierre dAulps and that group of Albanian clans known as the Maniakates were descended from Normans who served under George Maniaces in the Sicilian expedition of 1038.
3 What were the origins of the Raouliii family?	Norman mercenary	1
1 Robert Guiscard an other Norman adventurer previously elevated to the dignity of count of Apulia as the result of his military successes ultimately drove the Byzantines out of southern Italy.
2 Having obtained the consent of pope Gregory VII and acting as his vassal Robert continued his campaign conquering the Balkan peninsula as a foothold for western feudal lords and the Catholic Church.
3 After allying himself with Croatia and the Catholic cities of Dalmatia in 1081 he led an army of 30000 men in 300 ships landing on the southern shores of Albania capturing Valona Kanina Jericho Orikumi and reaching Butrint after numerous pillages.
4 They joined the fleet that had previously conquered Corfu and attacked Dyrrachium from land and sea devastating everything along the way.
5 Under these harsh circumstances the locals accepted the call of emperor Alexius I Comnenus to join forces with the Byzantines against the Normans.
6 The Albanian forces could not take part in the ensuing battle because it had started before their arrival.
7 Immediately before the battle the Venetian fleet had secured a victory in the coast surrounding the city.
8 Forced to retreat Alexius ceded the command to a high Albanian official named Comiscortes in the service of Byzantium.
9 The citys garrison resisted until February 1082 when Dyrrachium was betrayed to the Normans by the Venetian and Amalfitan merchants who had settled there.
10 The Normans were now free to penetrate into the hinterland they took Ioannina and some minor cities in southwestern Macedonia and Thessaly before appearing at the gates of Thessalonica.
11 Dissension among the high ranks coerced the Normans to retreat to Italy.
12 They lost Dyrrachium Valona and Butrint in 1085 after the death of Robert.
13 What was the name of the count of Apulia 	Robert Guiscard 	1.
14 When did Dyrrachium  fall to the Normans?	1082	9
15 How many men were in Roberts army?	30 000	3
1 A few years after the First Crusade in 1107 the Normans under the command of Bohemond Roberts son landed in Valona and besieged Dyrrachium using the most sophisticated military equipment of the time but to no avail.
2 Meanwhile they occupied Petrela the citadel of Mili at the banks of the river Deabolis Gllavenica Ballsh Kanina and Jericho.
3 This time the Albanians sided with the Normans dissatisfied by the heavy taxes the Byzantines had imposed upon them.
4 With their help the Normans secured the Arbanon passes and opened their way to Dibra.
5 The lack of supplies disease and Byzantine resistance forced Bohemond to retreat from his campaign and sign a peace treaty with the Byzantines in the city of Deabolis.
6 Where did the Normans and Byzantines sign the peace treaty?	Deabolis	2
7 Who was Roberts son?	Bohemond	1
8 What river was Petrela located by?	Deabolis	2
1 The further decline of Byzantine stateofaffairs paved the road to a third attack in 1185 when a large Norman army invaded Dyrrachium owing to the betrayal of high Byzantine officials.
2 Some time later Dyrrachium—one of the most important naval bases of the Adriatic—fell again to Byzantine hands.
3 When did the Normans attack Dyrrachium?	1185	1

1 The Normans were in contact with England from an early date.
2 Not only were their original Viking brethren still ravaging the English coasts they occupied most of the important ports opposite England across the English Channel.
3 This relationship eventually produced closer ties of blood through the marriage of Emma sister of Duke Richard II of Normandy and King Ethelred II of England.
4 Because of this Ethelred fled to Normandy in 1013 when he was forced from his kingdom by Sweyn Forkbeard.
5 His stay in Normandy until 1016 influenced him and his sons by Emma who stayed in Normandy after Cnut the Greats conquest of the isle.

1 When finally Edward the Confessor returned from his fathers refuge in 1041 at the invitation of his halfbrother Harthacnut he brought with him a Normaneducated mind.
2 He also brought many Norman counsellors and fighters some of whom established an English cavalry force.
3 This concept never really took root but it is a typical example of the attitudes of Edward.
4 He appointed Robert of Jumièges archbishop of Canterbury and made Ralph the Timid earl of Hereford.
5 He invited his brotherinlaw Eustace II Count of Boulogne to his court in 1051 an event which resulted in the greatest of early conflicts between Saxon and Norman and ultimately resulted in the exile of Earl Godwin of Wessex.
6 Who was Edward the Confessors halfbrother?	Harthacnut	1
7 When did Edward return?	1041	1
8 Who did Edward make archbishop of Canterbury?	Robert of Jumièges	4
1 In 1066 Duke William II of Normandy conquered England killing King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings.
2 The invading Normans and their descendants replaced the AngloSaxons as the ruling class of England.
3 The nobility of England were part of a single Normans culture and many had lands on both sides of the channel.
4 Early Norman kings of England as Dukes of Normandy owed homage to the King of France for their land on the continent.
5 They considered England to be their most important holding it brought with it the title of King—an important status symbol.
6 Where did Harold II die?	Battle of Hastings	1
7 Who killed Harold II?	William II	1
8 When was the Battle of Hastings?	1066	1
9 Who was the ruling class ahead of the Normans?	AngloSaxons	2
1 Eventually the Normans merged with the natives combining languages and traditions.
2 In the course of the Hundred Years War the Norman aristocracy often identified themselves as English.
3 The AngloNorman language became distinct from the Latin language something that was the subject of some humour by Geoffrey Chaucer.
4 The AngloNorman language was eventually absorbed into the AngloSaxon language of their subjects see Old English and influenced it helping along with the Norse language of the earlier AngloNorse settlers and the Latin used by the church in the development of Middle English.
5 It in turn evolved into Modern English.
6 What was the AngloNorman languages final form?	Modern English	5
1 The Normans had a profound effect on Irish culture and history after their invasion at Bannow Bay in 1169.
2 Initially the Normans maintained a distinct culture and ethnicity.
3 Yet with time they came to be subsumed into Irish culture to the point that it has been said that they became more Irish than the Irish themselves.
4 The Normans settled mostly in an area in the east of Ireland later known as the Pale and also built many fine castles and settlements including Trim Castle and Dublin Castle.
5 Both cultures intermixed borrowing from each others language culture and outlook.
6 Norman descendants today can be recognised by their surnames.
7 Names such as French De Roche Devereux DArcy Treacy and Lacy are particularly common in the southeast of Ireland especially in the southern part of County Wexford where the first Norman settlements were established.
8 Other Norman names such as Furlong predominate there.
9 Another common NormanIrish name was Morell Murrell derived from the French Norman name Morel.
10 Other names beginning with Fitz from the Norman for son indicate Norman ancestry.
11 These included Fitzgerald FitzGibbons Gibbons dynasty Fitzmaurice.
12 Other families bearing such surnames as Barry de Barra and De Búrca Burke are also of Norman extraction.
13 In what year did the Normans invade at Bannow Bay?	1169	1
14 What country did the Normans invade in 1169?	Ireland	4
15 What culture did the Normans combine with in Ireland?	Irish	1
1 One of the claimants of the English throne opposing William the Conqueror Edgar Atheling eventually fled to Scotland.
2 King Malcolm III of Scotland married Edgars sister Margaret and came into opposition to William who had already disputed Scotlands southern borders.
3 William invaded Scotland in 1072 riding as far as Abernethy where he met up with his fleet of ships.
4 Malcolm submitted paid homage to William and surrendered his son Duncan as a hostage beginning a series of arguments as to whether the Scottish Crown owed allegiance to the King of England.
5 Who was Margarets brother?	Edgar	1
6 Who was Margarets husband?	King Malcolm III of Scotland	2
7 When was Scotland invaded by William?	1072	3
8 Who was the hostage?	Duncan	4
1 Normans came into Scotland building castles and founding noble families who would provide some future kings such as Robert the Bruce as well as founding a considerable number of the Scottish clans.
2 King David I of Scotland whose elder brother Alexander I had married Sybilla of Normandy was instrumental in introducing Normans and Norman culture to Scotland part of the process some scholars call the Davidian Revolution.
3 Having spent time at the court of Henry I of England married to Davids sister Maud of Scotland and needing them to wrestle the kingdom from his halfbrother Máel Coluim mac Alaxandair David had to reward many with lands.
4 The process was continued under Davids successors most intensely of all under William the Lion.
5 The Normanderived feudal system was applied in varying degrees to most of Scotland.
6 Scottish families of the names Bruce Gray Ramsay Fraser Ogilvie Montgomery Sinclair Pollock Burnard Douglas and Gordon to name but a few and including the later royal House of Stewart can all be traced back to Norman ancestry.
7 Who did Alexander I marry?	Sybilla of Normandy	2
8 What cultures arrival in Scotland is know as the Davidian Revolution?	Norman	2
1 Even before the Norman Conquest of England the Normans had come into contact with Wales.
2 Edward the Confessor had set up the aforementioned Ralph as earl of Hereford and charged him with defending the Marches and warring with the Welsh.
3 In these original ventures the Normans failed to make any headway into Wales.

1 Subsequent to the Conquest however the Marches came completely under the dominance of Williams most trusted Norman barons including Bernard de Neufmarché Roger of Montgomery in Shropshire and Hugh Lupus in Cheshire.
2 These Normans began a long period of slow conquest during which almost all of Wales was at some point subject to Norman interference.
3 Norman words such as baron barwn first entered Welsh at that time.
4 What country was under the control of Norman barons?	Wales	2

1 The conquest of Cyprus by the AngloNorman forces of the Third Crusade opened a new chapter in the history of the island which would be under Western European domination for the following 380 years.
2 Although not part of a planned operation the conquest had much more permanent results than initially expected.
3 How long did Western Europe control Cyprus?	380 years	1
1 In April 1191 Richard the Lionhearted left Messina with a large fleet in order to reach Acre.
2 But a storm dispersed the fleet.
3 After some searching it was discovered that the boat carrying his sister and his fiancée Berengaria was anchored on the south coast of Cyprus together with the wrecks of several other ships including the treasure ship.
4 Survivors of the wrecks had been taken prisoner by the islands despot Isaac Komnenos.
5 On 1 May 1191 Richards fleet arrived in the port of Limassol on Cyprus.
6 He ordered Isaac to release the prisoners and the treasure.
7 Isaac refused so Richard landed his troops and took Limassol.
8 What ruined Richards plans to reach Acre?	a storm	2
9 Who was Richards fiancee?	Berengaria	3
10 What year did the storm hit Richards fleet?	1191	1
11 Who ruled Cyprus in 1191?	Isaac Komnenos	4
1 Various princes of the Holy Land arrived in Limassol at the same time in particular Guy de Lusignan.
2 All declared their support for Richard provided that he support Guy against his rival Conrad of Montferrat.
3 The local barons abandoned Isaac who considered making peace with Richard joining him on the crusade and offering his daughter in marriage to the person named by Richard.
4 But Isaac changed his mind and tried to escape.
5 Richard then proceeded to conquer the whole island his troops being led by Guy de Lusignan.
6 Isaac surrendered and was confined with silver chains because Richard had promised that he would not place him in irons.
7 By 1 June Richard had conquered the whole island.
8 His exploit was well publicized and contributed to his reputation he also derived significant financial gains from the conquest of the island.
9 Richard left for Acre on 5 June with his allies.
10 Before his departure he named two of his Norman generals Richard de Camville and Robert de Thornham as governors of Cyprus.
11 Who was Guys Rival?	Conrad of Montferrat	2
12 What were Isaacs chains made out of?	silver	6
13 Who led Richards troops when Cyprus was conquered?	Guy de Lusignan	1
1 While in Limassol Richard the LionHeart married Berengaria of Navarre firstborn daughter of King Sancho VI of Navarre.
2 The wedding was held on 12 May 1191 at the Chapel of St George and it was attended by Richards sister Joan whom he had brought from Sicily.
3 The marriage was celebrated with great pomp and splendor.
4 Among other grand ceremonies was a double coronation Richard caused himself to be crowned King of Cyprus and Berengaria Queen of England and Queen of Cyprus as well.
5 Who did Berengaria of Navarre marry?	Richard the LionHeart	1
6 What was the wedding date?	12 May 1191	2
7 What kind of coronation happened?	double coronation	4
1 The rapid AngloNorman conquest proved more important than it seemed.
2 The island occupied a key strategic position on the maritime lanes to the Holy Land whose occupation by the Christians could not continue without support from the sea.
3 Shortly after the conquest Cyprus was sold to the Knights Templar and it was subsequently acquired in 1192 by Guy de Lusignan and became a stable feudal kingdom.
4 It was only in 1489 that the Venetians acquired full control of the island which remained a Christian stronghold until the fall of Famagusta in 1571.
5 When did the Venetians take total control of Cyprus?	1489	4

1 The customary law of Normandy was developed between the 10th and 13th centuries and survives today through the legal systems of Jersey and Guernsey in the Channel Islands.
2 Norman customary law was transcribed in two customaries in Latin by two judges for use by them and their colleagues These are the Très ancien coutumier Very ancient customary authored between 1200 and 1245 and the Grand coutumier de Normandie Great customary of Normandy originally Summa de legibus Normanniae in curia laïcali authored between 1235 and 1245.
3 Where are Jersey and Guernsey	Channel Islands 	1.
4 How many customaries does Norman customary law have?	two	2
1 Norman architecture typically stands out as a new stage in the architectural history of the regions they subdued.
2 They spread a unique Romanesque idiom to England and Italy and the encastellation of these regions with keeps in their north French style fundamentally altered the military landscape.
3 Their style was characterised by rounded arches particularly over windows and doorways and massive proportions.
4 What is the Norman architecture idiom?	Romanesque	2
5 What kind of arches does Norman architecture have?	rounded	3
1 In England the period of Norman architecture immediately succeeds that of the AngloSaxon and precedes the Early Gothic.
2 In southern Italy the Normans incorporated elements of Islamic Lombard and Byzantine building techniques into their own initiating a unique style known as NormanArab architecture within the Kingdom of Sicily.
3 What architecture type came after Norman in England?	Early Gothic	1
4 What architecture type came before Norman in England?	AngloSaxon	1
5 What place had the Norman Arab architectural style?	Sicily	2
1 In the visual arts the Normans did not have the rich and distinctive traditions of the cultures they conquered.
2 However in the early 11th century the dukes began a programme of church reform encouraging the Cluniac reform of monasteries and patronising intellectual pursuits especially the proliferation of scriptoria and the reconstitution of a compilation of lost illuminated manuscripts.
3 The church was utilised by the dukes as a unifying force for their disparate duchy.
4 The chief monasteries taking part in this renaissance of Norman art and scholarship were MontSaintMichel Fécamp Jumièges Bec SaintOuen SaintEvroul and SaintWandrille.
5 These centres were in contact with the socalled Winchester school which channeled a pure Carolingian artistic tradition to Normandy.
6 In the final decade of the 11th and first of the 12th century Normandy experienced a golden age of illustrated manuscripts but it was brief and the major scriptoria of Normandy ceased to function after the midpoint of the century.
7 When did the church reform begin?	early 11th century	2
8 Who used the church to unify themselves?	dukes	2
1 The French Wars of Religion in the 16th century and French Revolution in the 18th successively destroyed much of what existed in the way of the architectural and artistic remnant of this Norman creativity.
2 The former with their violence caused the wanton destruction of many Norman edifices the latter with its assault on religion caused the purposeful destruction of religious objects of any type and its destabilisation of society resulted in rampant pillaging.
3 When were the French wars of religion?	16th century	1
1 By far the most famous work of Norman art is the Bayeux Tapestry which is not a tapestry but a work of embroidery.
2 It was commissioned by Odo the Bishop of Bayeux and first Earl of Kent employing natives from Kent who were learned in the Nordic traditions imported in the previous half century by the Danish Vikings.
3 What kind of needlework was used in the creation of the Bayeux Tapestry?	embroidery	1
4 What is Norman arts most well known piece?	Bayeux Tapestry	1
5 Who commissioned the Tapestry?	Odo	2
1 In Britain Norman art primarily survives as stonework or metalwork such as capitals and baptismal fonts.
2 In southern Italy however Norman artwork survives plentifully in forms strongly influenced by its Greek Lombard and Arab forebears.
3 Of the royal regalia preserved in Palermo the crown is Byzantine in style and the coronation cloak is of Arab craftsmanship with Arabic inscriptions.
4 Many churches preserve sculptured fonts capitals and more importantly mosaics which were common in Norman Italy and drew heavily on the Greek heritage.
5 Lombard Salerno was a centre of ivorywork in the 11th century and this continued under Norman domination.
6 Finally should be noted the intercourse between French Crusaders traveling to the Holy Land who brought with them French artefacts with which to gift the churches at which they stopped in southern Italy amongst their Norman cousins.
7 For this reason many south Italian churches preserve works from France alongside their native pieces.
8 What is the most important type of Norman art preserved in churches?	mosaics	4
1 Normandy was the site of several important developments in the history of classical music in the 11th century.
2 Fécamp Abbey and SaintEvroul Abbey were centres of musical production and education.
3 At Fécamp under two Italian abbots William of Volpiano and John of Ravenna the system of denoting notes by letters was developed and taught.
4 It is still the most common form of pitch representation in English and Germanspeaking countries today.
5 Also at Fécamp the staff around which neumes were oriented was first developed and taught in the 11th century.
6 Under the German abbot Isembard La TrinitéduMont became a centre of musical composition.
7 In what century did important classical music developments occur in Normandy?	11th	1
8 Who were the two abbots at Fécamp Abbey?	William of Volpiano and John of Ravenna	3
1 At Saint Evroul a tradition of singing had developed and the choir achieved fame in Normandy.
2 Under the Norman abbot Robert de Grantmesnil several monks of SaintEvroul fled to southern Italy where they were patronised by Robert Guiscard and established a Latin monastery at SantEufemia.
3 There they continued the tradition of singing.
4 Where did the monks flee to?	southern Italy	2
5 What monastery did the SaintEvroul monks establish in Italy?	Latin monastery at SantEufemia	2
6 Who patronized the monks in Italy?	Robert Guiscard	2
7 What tradition were the SaintEvroul monks known for?	singing	1
1 Nikola Tesla Serbian Cyrillic Никола Тесла 10 July 1856 – 7 January 1943 was a Serbian American inventor electrical engineer mechanical engineer physicist and futurist best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current AC electricity supply system.
2 In what year was Nikola Tesla born?	1856	1
3 What was Nikola Teslas ethnicity?	Serbian	1
4 In what year did Tesla die?	1943	1
5 When was Nikola Tesla born?	1856	1
6 In what year did Tesla die?	1943	1
7 What is Teslas home country?	Serbian	1
8 What does AC stand for?	alternating current	1
1 Tesla gained experience in telephony and electrical engineering before emigrating to the United States in 1884 to work for Thomas Edison in New York City.
2 He soon struck out on his own with financial backers setting up laboratories and companies to develop a range of electrical devices.
3 His patented AC induction motor and transformer were licensed by George Westinghouse who also hired Tesla for a short time as a consultant.
4 His work in the formative years of electric power development was involved in a corporate alternating currentdirect current War of Currents as well as various patent battles.
5 In what year did Nikola Tesla emigrate to the United States?	1884	1
6 Who did Tesla work for in the 1880s?	Thomas Edison	1
7 Teslas induction motor and transformer was licensed by whom?	George Westinghouse	3
8 In what area of the United States did Tesla move to?	New York City	1
9 What war was Tesla involved in?	War of Currents	4
10 When did Tesla come to the US?	1884	1
11 What other inventor did he work with?	Thomas Edison	1
12 Where did Tesla work with Edison?	New York City	1
13 Who licensed Teslas induction motor?	George Westinghouse	3
14 What other invention of Teslas did Westinghouse license?	transformer	3
1 Tesla went on to pursue his ideas of wireless lighting and electricity distribution in his highvoltage highfrequency power experiments in New York and Colorado Springs and made early 1893 pronouncements on the possibility of wireless communication with his devices.
2 He tried to put these ideas to practical use in an illfated attempt at intercontinental wireless transmission his unfinished Wardenclyffe Tower project.
3 In his lab he also conducted a range of experiments with mechanical oscillatorsgenerators electrical discharge tubes and early Xray imaging.
4 He also built a wireless controlled boat one of the first ever exhibited.
5 When did Tesla discover the possibility of wireless connectivity?	1893	1
6 Were Teslas experiments highvoltage or lowvoltage?	highvoltage	1
7 What were some of Teslas experiments?	mechanical oscillatorsgenerators  electrical discharge tubes  and early Xray imaging	3
8 Other than New York where did Tesla conduct experiments?	Colorado Springs	1
9 When did he first mention wireless communication?	1893	1
10 What remote control vehicle did he make?	boat	4
11 Where was his unfinished project called?	Wardenclyffe Tower project	2
1 Tesla was renowned for his achievements and showmanship eventually earning him a reputation in popular culture as an archetypal mad scientist.
2 His patents earned him a considerable amount of money much of which was used to finance his own projects with varying degrees of success.
3 121154 He lived most of his life in a series of New York hotels through his retirement.
4 Tesla died on 7 January 1943.
5 His work fell into relative obscurity after his death but in 1960 the General Conference on Weights and Measures named the SI unit of magnetic flux density the tesla in his honor.
6 There has been a resurgence in popular interest in Tesla since the 1990s.
7 What year did Tesla die?	1943	4
8 What was named The Tesla in his honor?	SI unit of magnetic flux density	5
9 Where did Tesla live for much of his life?	New York hotels	3

11 How did Tesla finance his work?	patents	2
12 What year did Tesla die?	1943	4
13 What did the General Conference on Weights and Measures name after Tesla in 1960?	SI unit of magnetic flux density	5
14 When did people once again start to show an interest in Tesla?	1990s	6
15 Other than his scientific achievements what was Tesla famous for?	showmanship	1
1 Tesla was born on 10 July OS.
2 28 June 1856 into a Serb family in the village of Smiljan Austrian Empire modernday Croatia.
3 His father Milutin Tesla was a Serbian Orthodox priest.
4 Teslas mother Đuka Tesla née Mandić whose father was also an Orthodox priest10 had a talent for making home craft tools mechanical appliances and the ability to memorize Serbian epic poems.
5 Đuka had never received a formal education.
6 Nikola credited his eidetic memory and creative abilities to his mothers genetics and influence.
7 Teslas progenitors were from western Serbia near Montenegro.

1 Tesla was the fourth of five children.
2 He had an older brother named Dane and three sisters Milka Angelina and Marica.
3 Dane was killed in a horseriding accident when Nikola was five.
4 In 1861 Tesla attended the Lower or Primary School in Smiljan where he studied German arithmetic and religion.
5 In 1862 the Tesla family moved to Gospić Austrian Empire where Teslas father worked as a pastor.
6 Nikola completed Lower or Primary School followed by the Lower Real Gymnasium or Normal School.

1 In 1870 Tesla moved to Karlovac to attend school at the Higher Real Gymnasium where he was profoundly influenced by a math teacher Martin Sekulić.
2 32 The classes were held in German as it was a school within the AustroHungarian Military Frontier.
3 Tesla was able to perform integral calculus in his head which prompted his teachers to believe that he was cheating.
4 He finished a fouryear term in three years graduating in 187333.

1 In 1874 Tesla evaded being drafted into the AustroHungarian Army in Smiljan by running away to Tomingaj near Gračac.
2 There he explored the mountains in hunters garb.
3 Tesla said that this contact with nature made him stronger both physically and mentally.
4 He read many books while in Tomingaj and later said that Mark Twains works had helped him to miraculously recover from his earlier illness.

1 In 1875 Tesla enrolled at Austrian Polytechnic in Graz Austria on a Military Frontier scholarship.
2 During his first year Tesla never missed a lecture earned the highest grades possible passed nine exams nearly twice as many required started a Serbian culture club and even received a letter of commendation from the dean of the technical faculty to his father which stated Your son is a star of first rank.
3 Tesla claimed that he worked from 3 am to 11 pm no Sundays or holidays excepted.
4 He was mortified when his father made light of those hard won honors.
5 After his fathers death in 1879 Tesla found a package of letters from his professors to his father warning that unless he were removed from the school Tesla would be killed through overwork.
6 During his second year Tesla came into conflict with Professor Poeschl over the Gramme dynamo when Tesla suggested that commutators werent necessary.
7 At the end of his second year Tesla lost his scholarship and became addicted to gambling.
8 During his third year Tesla gambled away his allowance and his tuition money later gambling back his initial losses and returning the balance to his family.
9 Tesla said that he conquered his passion then and there but later he was known to play billiards in the US.
10 When exam time came Tesla was unprepared and asked for an extension to study but was denied.
11 He never graduated from the university and did not receive grades for the last semester.
12 What year did Tesla enroll at an engineering school?	1875	1
13 What school did he enroll in during 1875?	Austrian Polytechnic	1
14 In what year did Teslas father die?	1879	5
15 What did Tesla struggle with while in school?	gambling	7
16 Did Tesla graduate from the university?	no	3
17 Where was Austrian Polytechnic located?	Graz  Austria	1
18 When did Tesla enroll in Austrian Polytechnic?	1875	1
19 When did Teslas father die?	1879	5
20 How did Tesla lose his tuition money?	gambled	8
21 What was Teslas father afraid would happen to him in school?	Tesla would be killed through overwork	5
1 In December 1878 Tesla left Graz and severed all relations with his family to hide the fact that he dropped out of school.
2 His friends thought that he had drowned in the Mur River.
3 Tesla went to Maribor now in Slovenia where he worked as a draftsman for 60 florins a month.
4 He spent his spare time playing cards with local men on the streets.
5 In March 1879 Milutin Tesla went to Maribor to beg his son to return home but Nikola refused.
6 Nikola suffered a nervous breakdown at around the same time.

1 In 1881 Tesla moved to Budapest to work under Ferenc Puskás at a telegraph company the Budapest Telephone Exchange.
2 Upon arrival Tesla realized that the company then under construction was not functional so he worked as a draftsman in the Central Telegraph Office instead.
3 Within a few months the Budapest Telephone Exchange became functional and Tesla was allocated the chief electrician position.
4 During his employment Tesla made many improvements to the Central Station equipment and claimed to have perfected a telephone repeater or amplifier which was never patented nor publicly described.

1 In 1882 Tesla began working for the Continental Edison Company in France designing and making improvements to electrical equipment.
2 In June 1884 he relocated to New York City57–60 where he was hired by Thomas Edison to work at his Edison Machine Works on Manhattans lower east side.
3 Teslas work for Edison began with simple electrical engineering and quickly progressed to solving more difficult problems.

1 Tesla was offered the task of completely redesigning the Edison Companys direct current generators.
2 In 1885 he said that he could redesign Edisons inefficient motor and generators making an improvement in both service and economy.
3 According to Tesla Edison remarked Theres fifty thousand dollars in it for you—if you can do it.
4 54–57 64 This has been noted as an odd statement from an Edison whose company was stingy with pay and who did not have that sort of cash on hand.
5 After months of work Tesla fulfilled the task and inquired about payment.
6 Edison saying that he was only joking replied Tesla you dont understand our American humor.
7 64  Instead Edison offered a US10 a week raise over Teslas US18 per week salary Tesla refused the offer and immediately resigned.
8 How much did Edison offer Tesla to redesign a motor and generators?	fifty thousand dollars	3
9 What did Edison offer Tesla after completing the project?	10 a week raise	7
10 how long did Tesla spend redesigning the motor and generators?	months	5
11 How much did Tesla say Edison offered him to redesign his motor and generators?	fifty thousand dollars	3
12 What was Edisons reply as to what Tesla didnt understand when Tesla asked for payment?	American humor	6
13 What alternate payment did Edison offer Tesla?	US10 a week raise	7

1 The investors showed little interest in Teslas ideas for new types of motors and electrical transmission equipment and also seemed to think it was better to develop an electrical utility than invent new systems.
2 They eventually forced Tesla out leaving him penniless.
3 He even lost control of the patents he had generated since he had assigned them to the company in lieu of stock.
4 He had to work at various electrical repair jobs and even as a ditch digger for 2 per day.
5 Tesla considered the winter of 18861887 as a time of terrible headaches and bitter tears.
6 During this time he questioned the value of his education.

1 In late 1886 Tesla met Alfred S Brown a Western Union superintendent and New York attorney Charles F Peck.
2 The two men were experienced in setting up companies and promoting inventions and patents for financial gain.
3 Based on Teslas patents and other ideas they agreed to back him financially and handle his patents.
4 Together in April 1887 they formed the Tesla Electric Company with an agreement that profits from generated patents would go ⅓ to Tesla ⅓ to Peck and Brown and ⅓ to fund development.
5 They set up a laboratory for Tesla at 89 Liberty Street in Manhattan where he worked on improving and developing new types of electric motors generators and other devices.
6 Who was Alfred S brown?	a Western Union superintendent	1
7 When was Tesla Electric Company formed?	April 1887	4

14 What was Tesla Brown and Pecks new company?	Tesla Electric Company	4
1 One of the things Tesla developed at that laboratory in 1887 was an induction motor that ran on alternating current a power system format that was starting to be built in Europe and the United States because of its advantages in longdistance highvoltage transmission.
2 The motor used polyphase current which generated a rotating magnetic field to turn the motor a principle Tesla claimed to have conceived in 1882.
3 This innovative electric motor patented in May 1888 was a simple selfstarting design that did not need a commutator thus avoiding sparking and the high maintenance of constantly servicing and replacing mechanical brushes.
4 What did Tesla develop in 1887?	an induction motor	1
5 When was Teslas innovative motor patented?	May 1888	3
6 What did Teslas design not need?	a commutator	3
7 What did his design avoid in not having a commutator?	sparking	3
8 what sort of design was this motor?	selfstarting	3
9 When did Tesla make the induction motor?	1887	1
10 Why was AC electricity gaining popularity?	because of its advantages in longdistance  highvoltage transmission	1
11 What high maintenance part did Teslas AC motor not require?	mechanical brushes	3
12 When did Tesla patent the motor?	1888	3
1 In 1888 the editor of Electrical World magazine Thomas Commerford Martin a friend and publicist arranged for Tesla to demonstrate his alternating current system including his induction motor at the American Institute of Electrical Engineers now IEEE.
2 Engineers working for the Westinghouse Electric  Manufacturing Company reported to George Westinghouse that Tesla had a viable AC motor and related power system — something for which Westinghouse had been trying to secure patents.
3 Westinghouse looked into getting a patent on a similar commutatorless rotating magnetic fieldbased induction motor presented in a paper in March 1888 by the Italian physicist Galileo Ferraris but decided Teslas patent would probably control the market.
4 Who was Thomas Commerford Martin?	editor of Electrical World magazine	1
5 What is the IEEE?	American Institute of Electrical Engineers	1

1 In July 1888 Brown and Peck negotiated a licensing deal with George Westinghouse for Teslas polyphase induction motor and transformer designs for 60000 in cash and stock and a royalty of 250 per AC horsepower produced by each motor.
2 Westinghouse also hired Tesla for one year for the large fee of 2000 52700 in todays dollars per month to be a consultant at the Westinghouse Electric  Manufacturing Companys Pittsburgh labs.
3 In what year were Teslas motor and transformer designs licensed to Westinghouse?	1888	1

1 During that year Tesla worked in Pittsburgh helping to create an alternating current system to power the citys streetcars.
2 He found the time there frustrating because of conflicts between him and the other Westinghouse engineers over how best to implement AC power.
3 Between them they settled on a 60cycle AC current system Tesla proposed to match the working frequency of Teslas motor although they soon found that since Teslas induction motor could only run at a constant speed it would not work for street cars.
4 They ended up using a DC traction motor instead.
5 Where did Tesla work in 1888?	Pittsburgh	1
6 What did Tesla work on in 1888?	system to power the citys streetcars	1
7 What cycle AC current system did Tesla propose?	60cycle	3
8 What motor did they end up using instead of the one Tesla wanted?	DC traction motor	4

10 What ended up being used for the streetcars in the place of Teslas system?	a DC traction motor	4
1 Teslas demonstration of his induction motor and Westinghouses subsequent licensing of the patent both in 1888 put Tesla firmly on the AC side of the socalled War of Currents an electrical distribution battle being waged between Thomas Edison and George Westinghouse that had been simmering since Westinghouses first AC system in 1886 and had reached the point of allout warfare by 1888.
2 This started out as a competition between rival lighting systems with Edison holding all the patents for DC and the incandescent light and Westinghouse using his own patented AC system to power arc lights as well as incandescent lamps of a slightly different design to get around the Edison patent.
3 The acquisition of a feasible AC motor gave Westinghouse a key patent in building a completely integrated AC system but the financial strain of buying up patents and hiring the engineers needed to build it meant development of Teslas motor had to be put on hold for a while.
4 The competition resulted in Edison Machine Works pursuing AC development in 1890 and by 1892 Thomas Edison was no longer in control of his own company which was consolidated into the conglomerate General Electric and converting to an AC delivery system at that point.
5 Who was the War of Currents waged between?	Thomas Edison and George Westinghouse	1
6 What did the war first start out as being between?	lighting systems	2
7 What did Edison Machine Works persue in 1890?	AC development	4
8 What company took over Edison Machine Works?	General Electric	4
9 Which current type was Tesla in favor of?	AC	1
10 Who was Westinghouses chief rival?	Thomas Edison	1
11 When did the rivalry between Westinghouse and Edison reach its peak?	1888	1
12 What caused the delay during the development of the AC motor	financial strain 	3.
13 Who took control of Edisons company	General Electric 	4.
1 In 1893 George Westinghouse won the bid to light the 1893 Worlds Columbian Exposition in Chicago with alternating current beating out a General Electric bid by one million dollars.
2 This Worlds Fair devoted a building to electrical exhibits.
3 It was a key event in the history of AC power as Westinghouse demonstrated the safety reliability and efficiency of a fully integrated alternating current system to the American public.
4 At the Columbian Exposition under a banner announcing the Tesla Polyphase System Tesla demonstrated a series of electrical effects previously performed throughout America and Europe76 included using highvoltage highfrequency alternating current to light a wireless gasdischarge lamp.
5 79 An observer noted.
6 In 1893 who won the bid to light the Worlds Columbian Exposition?	George Westinghouse	1
7 Where was the 1893 Worlds Columbian Exposition held?	Chicago	1
8 Who did George Westinghouse beat out to light the Worlds Columbian Exposition?	General Electric	1
9 What did Tesla call his electrical effects in 1893?	Tesla Polyphase System	4
10 What was it called when Tesla lit a wireless gasdischarge lamp using a highfrequency highvoltage alternating current?	Tesla Polyphase System	4
11 Who outbid General Electric to provide light to the Worlds Columbian Exposition?	George Westinghouse	1
12 Where did the Exposition take place?	Chicago	1
13 In what year was the Worlds Columbian Exposition?	1893	1
14 What type of power was displayed at the Worlds fair by Westinghouse and Tesla?	AC power	3
1 In 1893 Richard Dean Adams who headed up the Niagara Falls Cataract Construction Company sought Teslas opinion on what system would be best to transmit power generated at the falls.
2 Over several years there had been a series of proposals and open competitions on how best to utilize power generated by the falls with many systems being proposed by several US and European companies including twophase and threephase AC highvoltage DC and even compressed air.
3 Adams pumped Tesla for information about the current state of all the competing systems.
4 Tesla advised Adams that a twophased system would be the most reliable and that there was a Westinghouse system to light incandescent bulbs using twophase alternating current.
5 Based on Teslas advice and Westinghouses demonstration that they could build a complete AC system at the Columbian Exposition a contract for building a twophase AC generating system at the Niagara Falls was awarded to Westinghouse Electric.
6 A further contract to build the AC distribution system was awarded to General Electric.
7 Who headed the Niagara Falls Cataract Construction Company in 1893?	Richard Dean Adams	1
8 What landmark was Tesla asked about in regards to electricity in 1893?	Niagara Falls	1
9 What company was chosen to build a twophase AC generating system at Niagara Falls?	Westinghouse Electric	5
10 What company was chosen to build an AC distribution system at Niagara Falls?	General Electric	6
11 What system did Tesla recommend to Niagara Falls in 1893?	a twophased system	4
12 Who was the head of the company?	Richard Dean Adams	1
13 When did Richard Dean Adams make his inquiry?	1893	1
14 What type of system did Tesla suggest to Adams?	twophased system	4
15 What was the advantage of the twophased system 	most reliable 	4.
1 The mid 1890s saw the conglomerate General Electric backed by financier J P Morgan involved in takeover attempts and patent battles with Westinghouse Electric.
2 Although a patentsharing agreement was signed between the two companies in 1896 Westinghouse was still cashstrapped from the financial warfare.
3 To secure further loans Westinghouse was forced to revisit Teslas AC patent which bankers considered a financial strain on the company at that point Westinghouse had paid out an estimated 200000 in licenses and royalties to Tesla Brown and Peck.
4 In 1897 Westinghouse explained his financial difficulties to Tesla in stark terms saying that if things continue the way they were he would no longer be in control of Westinghouse Electric and Tesla would have to deal with the bankers to try to collect future royalties.
5 Westinghouse convinced Tesla to release his company from the licensing agreement over Teslas AC patents in exchange for Westinghouse Electric purchasing the patents for a lump sum payment of 216000 this provided Westinghouse a break from what due to alternating currents rapid gain in popularity had turned out to be an overly generous 250 per AC horsepower royalty.
6 When was a patentsharing agreement signed between Westinghouse Electric and General Electric?	1896	2
7 How much did Tesla sell his AC patents to Westinghouse Electric for?	216 000	5
8 What was the overly generous royalty amount that Tesla had been receiving?	250 per AC horsepower royalty	5
9 By 1897 how much had Tesla Brown and Peck received in royalties and licenses over the patents?	200 000	3
10 Who financed General Electrics attempts to takeover Westinghouse?	J P Morgan	1
11 How much had Westinghouse paid to Tesla Brown and Peck?	an estimated 200 000	3
12 How much did Westinghouse pay for Teslas patents in order to escape its financial problems?	216 000	5
1 On 30 July 1891 at the age of 35 Tesla became a naturalized citizen of the United States and established his South Fifth Avenue laboratory and later another at 46 E Houston Street in New York.
2 He lit electric lamps wirelessly at both locations demonstrating the potential of wireless power transmission.
3 In the same year he patented the Tesla coil.

1 Tesla served as a vice president of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers the forerunner along with the Institute of Radio Engineers of the modernday IEEE from 1892 to 1894.
2 What organization did Tesla serve as vice president of?	American Institute of Electrical Engineers	1

1 Starting in 1894 Tesla began investigating what he referred to as radiant energy of invisible kinds after he had noticed damaged film in his laboratory in previous experiments later identified as Roentgen rays or XRays.
2 His early experiments were with Crookes tubes a cold cathode electrical discharge tube.
3 Soon after much of Teslas early research—hundreds of invention models plans notes laboratory data tools photographs valued at 50000—was lost in the 5th Avenue laboratory fire of March 1895.
4 Tesla is quoted by The New York Times as saying I am in too much grief to talk.
5 What can I say.
6 Tesla may have inadvertently captured an Xray image—predating by a few weeks Wilhelm Röntgens December 1895 announcement of the discovery of xrays—when he tried to photograph Mark Twain illuminated by a Geissler tube an earlier type of gas discharge tube.
7 The only thing captured in the image was the metal locking screw on the camera lens.
8 134.
9 Why did Tesla begin investigating invisible energy?	he had noticed damaged film in his laboratory in previous experiments	1
10 What took place in his lab in 1895 causing him to lose thousands of dollars of data and tools?	5th Avenue laboratory fire of March 1895	3
11 When were xrays discovered?	December 1895	6
12 When Tesla attempted to photograph Mark Twain what was the only thing that showed up on the image?	the metal locking screw on the camera lens	7
13 When die Tesla turn his attention to trying to understand invisible radiant energy?	1894	1
14 What is this invisible radiant energy now known as?	XRays	1
15 What happened to most of Teslas work from this time?	lost in the 5th Avenue laboratory fire of March 1895	3
16 What type of image was Tesla thought to have accidentally taken a week prior to the announcement of its discovery?	Xray image	6
17 Who was Tesla trying to photograph when he accidentally took the XRay image?	Mark Twain	6
1 In March 1896 after hearing of Wilhelm Röntgens discovery of Xray and Xray imaging radiography Tesla proceeded to do his own experiments in Xray imaging developing a high energy single terminal vacuum tube of his own design that had no target electrode and that worked from the output of the Tesla Coil the modern term for the phenomenon produced by this device is bremsstrahlung or braking radiation.
2 In his research Tesla devised several experimental setups to produce Xrays.
3 Tesla held that with his circuits the instrument will  enable one to generate Roentgen rays of much greater power than obtainable with ordinary apparatus.
4 What did Tesla begin to research in March 1896?	Xray imaging	1
5 when did tesla begin researching xray imaging?	March 1896	1
6 What is another term for xray imaging?	radiography	1
7 What did Tesla design several experimental setups to produce?	Xrays	2
8 What did Teslas device work from the output of?	Tesla Coil	1
9 When did Tesla start deliberately experimenting with Xray imaging?	1896	1
10 What powered Teslas high energy terminal vacuum tube?	Tesla Coil	1
11 What were Xrays known as at the time?	Roentgen rays	3
1 Tesla noted the hazards of working with his circuit and singlenode Xrayproducing devices.
2 In his many notes on the early investigation of this phenomenon he attributed the skin damage to various causes.
3 He believed early on that damage to the skin was not caused by the Roentgen rays but by the ozone generated in contact with the skin and to a lesser extent by nitrous acid.
4 Tesla incorrectly believed that Xrays were longitudinal waves such as those produced in waves in plasmas.
5 These plasma waves can occur in forcefree magnetic fields.
6 What did tesla incorrectly believe about xrays?	Xrays were longitudinal waves	4
7 what did tesla attribute skin damage to?	damage to the skin was not caused by the Roentgen rays  but by the ozone generated in contact with the skin	3
8 what did Tesla think nitrous acid contributed to?	skin damage	2
9 what did tesla note the hazards of working with?	his circuit and singlenode Xrayproducing devices	1
10 where do plasma waves occur?	forcefree magnetic fields	5
11 At first what did Tesla think was the main cause of damage to skin cells when they were exposed to Xrays?	ozone generated in contact with the skin	3
12 What did Tesla mistakenly believe Xrays were?	longitudinal waves	4
13 Where are longitudinal waves found?	forcefree magnetic fields	5
14 Where can Teslas theories as to what caused the skin damage be found?	In his many notes	2
1 At the beginning of 1893 Westinghouse engineer Benjamin Lamme had made great progress developing an efficient version of Teslas induction motor and Westinghouse Electric started branding their complete polyphase phase AC system as the Tesla Polyphase System noting how they believed Teslas patents gave them patent priority over other AC systems.
2 Which engineer made the induction motor more efficient?	Benjamin Lamme	1
3 In which year did Benjamin Lamme achieve success making the motor more efficient?	1893	1
4 Who called their system the Tesla Polyphase System?	Westinghouse Electric	1
1 Tesla also explained the principles of the rotating magnetic field in an induction motor by demonstrating how to make a copper egg stand on end using a device he constructed known as the Egg of Columbus.
2 What was Teslas device called?	Egg of Columbus	1
3 Who demonstrated the Egg of Columbus?	Tesla	1
1 On 11 July 1934 the New York Herald Tribune published an article on Tesla in which he recalled an event that would occasionally take place while experimenting with his singleelectrode vacuum tubes a minute particle would break off the cathode pass out of the tube and physically strike him.
2 Tesla said he could feel a sharp stinging pain where it entered his body and again at the place where it passed out.
3 In comparing these particles with the bits of metal projected by his electric gun Tesla said The particles in the beam of force  will travel much faster than such particles  and they will travel in concentrations.
4 When did the Herald Tribune publish its Tesla article?	1934	1
5 What did the particle do to Tesla?	physically strike him	1
6 How did Tesla know he was being struck by the particle?	he could feel a sharp stinging pain where it entered his body	2
7 What other projectiles did Tesla compare the electric particles to?	bits of metal	3
1 Teslas theories on the possibility of the transmission by radio waves go back as far as lectures and demonstrations in 1893 in St Louis Missouri the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia Pennsylvania and the National Electric Light Association.
2 Teslas demonstrations and principles were written about widely through various media outlets.
3 Many devices such as the Tesla Coil were used in the further development of radio.
4 What association did Tesla demonstrate his radio wave theories to?	National Electric Light Association	1
5 Which of Teslas inventions was used in radio development?	Tesla Coil	3
6 What Philadelphia institution did Tesla give a demonstration to?	the Franklin Institute	1
1 In 1898 Tesla demonstrated a radiocontrolled boat—which he dubbed teleautomaton—to the public during an electrical exhibition at Madison Square Garden.
2 The crowd that witnessed the demonstration made outrageous claims about the workings of the boat such as magic telepathy and being piloted by a trained monkey hidden inside.
3 Tesla tried to sell his idea to the US military as a type of radiocontrolled torpedo but they showed little interest.
4 Remote radio control remained a novelty until World War I and afterward when a number of countries used it in military programs.
5 Tesla took the opportunity to further demonstrate Teleautomatics in an address to a meeting of the Commercial Club in Chicago while he was travelling to Colorado Springs on 13 May 1899.
6 When did Tesla give a demonstration of his remote control boat?	1898	1
7 What was the boat called?	teleautomaton	1
8 Where was the boat demonstration given?	Madison Square Garden	1
9 What was the occasion for the boat demonstration?	an electrical exhibition	1
10 What type of animal did onlookers claim was piloting the boat?	monkey	2
1 In 1900 Tesla was granted patents for a system of transmitting electrical energy and an electrical transmitter.
2 When Guglielmo Marconi made his famous firstever transatlantic radio transmission in 1901 Tesla quipped that it was done with 17 Tesla patents though there is little to support this claim.
3 This was the beginning of years of patent battles over radio with Teslas patents being upheld in 1903 followed by a reverse decision in favor of Marconi in 1904.
4 In 1943 a Supreme Court of the United States decision restored the prior patents of Tesla Oliver Lodge and John Stone.
5 The court declared that their decision had no bearing on Marconis claim as the first to achieve radio transmission just that since Marconis claim to certain patents were questionable he could not claim infringement on those same patents there are claims the high court was trying to nullify a World War I claim against the US government by the Marconi Company via simply restoring Teslas prior patent.
6 When did Tesla attain his electrical transmitter patent?	1900	1
7 Who first sent radio waves across the Atlantic?	Marconi	2
8 When was Marconis radio demonstration?	1901	2
9 When were Teslas patents restored?	1943	4
10 A decision made by what entity restored Teslas patents?	Supreme Court of the United States	4
1 On 17 May 1899 Tesla moved to Colorado Springs where he would have room for his highvoltage highfrequency experiments his lab was located near Foote Ave and Kiowa St.
2 He chose this location because the polyphase alternating current power distribution system had been introduced there and he had associates who were willing to give him all the power he needed without charging for it.
3 Upon his arrival he told reporters that he was conducting wireless telegraphy experiments transmitting signals from Pikes Peak to Paris.
4 citation needed The 1978 book Colorado Springs Notes 1899–1900 contains descriptions of Teslas experiments.
5 On 15 June 1899 Tesla performed his first experiments at his Colorado Springs lab he recorded his initial spark length at five inches long but very thick and noisy.
6 In what year did Tesla go to Colorado Springs?	1899	1
7  Where did he claim he would transport energy to?	Paris	3
8 What date did Tesla begin his Colorado Springs experiments?	15 June 1899	5
9 What was the recorded length of the first spark?	five inches	5
1 Tesla investigated atmospheric electricity observing lightning signals via his receivers.
2 He stated that he observed stationary waves during this time.
3 The great distances and the nature of what Tesla was detecting from lightning storms confirmed his belief that the earth had a resonant frequency.
4 What kind of electricity was Tesla investigating?	atmospheric	1
5 What sort of waves did he claim to observe?	stationary	2
6 What was Teslas idea regarding Earth?	that the earth had a resonant frequency	3
1 He produced artificial lightning with discharges consisting of millions of volts and up to 135 feet long.
2 Thunder from the released energy was heard 15 miles away in Cripple Creek Colorado.
3 People walking along the street observed sparks jumping between their feet and the ground.
4 Sparks sprang from water line taps when touched.
5 Light bulbs within 100 feet of the lab glowed even when turned off.
6 Horses in a livery stable bolted from their stalls after receiving shocks through their metal shoes.
7 Butterflies were electrified swirling in circles with blue halos of St Elmos fire around their wings.
8 What natural phenomenon did Tesla create artificially?	lightning	1
9 How big were his artificial bolts?	135 feet	1
10 From what distance could the artificial thunder be heard	15 miles 	2.
11 What happened to nearby light bulbs?	glowed even when turned off	5
12 What was notable about the butterflies?	Butterflies were electrified	7
1 While experimenting Tesla inadvertently faulted a power station generator causing a power outage.
2 In August 1917 Tesla explained what had happened in The Electrical Experimenter As an example of what has been done with several hundred kilowatts of high frequency energy liberated it was found that the dynamos in a power house six miles away were repeatedly burned out due to the powerful high frequency currents set up in them and which caused heavy sparks to jump through the windings and destroy the insulation.
3 What did Tesla accidentally cause?	power outage	1
4 What happened to the dynamos in the power station?	repeatedly burned out	2
5 What caused the dynamos to be burnt out?	powerful high frequency currents	2
6 What did the sparks do to the insulation?	destroy	2
1 During his time at his lab Tesla observed unusual signals from his receiver which he concluded may be communications from another planet.
2 He mentioned them in a letter to reporter Julian Hawthorne at the Philadelphia North American on 8 December 1899 and in a December 1900 letter about possible discoveries in the new century to the Red Cross Society where he referred to messages from another world that read 1 2 3.
3 Reporters treated it as a sensational story and jumped to the conclusion Tesla was hearing signals from Mars.
4 He expanded on the signals he heard in a 9 February 1901 Colliers Weekly article Talking With Planets where he said it had not been immediately apparent to him that he was hearing intelligently controlled signals and that the signals could come from Mars Venus or other planets.
5 It has been hypothesized that he may have intercepted Marconis European experiments in July 1899—Marconi may have transmitted the letter S dotdotdot in a naval demonstration the same three impulses that Tesla hinted at hearing in Colorado—or signals from another experimenter in wireless transmission.
6 To what did Tesla attribute the unknown signals his radio received?	communications from another planet	1
7 What planet did the reporters decide the signals were from?	Mars	3
8 What magazine did Tesla talk to about the strange signals?	Colliers Weekly	4
9 What is another possible explanation for the source of the signals?	intercepted Marconis European experiments	5
10 When did Marconi transmit similar signals to those Tesla received?	July 1899	5

1 Tesla later approached Morgan to ask for more funds to build a more powerful transmitter.
2 When asked where all the money had gone Tesla responded by saying that he was affected by the Panic of 1901 which he Morgan had caused.
3 Morgan was shocked by the reminder of his part in the stock market crash and by Teslas breach of contract by asking for more funds.
4 Tesla wrote another plea to Morgan but it was also fruitless.
5 Morgan still owed Tesla money on the original agreement and Tesla had been facing foreclosure even before construction of the tower began.

1 In December 1901 Marconi successfully transmitted the letter S from England to Newfoundland terminating Teslas relationship with Morgan.
2 improper synthesis.
3 Over the next five years Tesla wrote over 50 letters to Morgan pleading for and demanding additional funding to complete the construction of Wardenclyffe.
4 Tesla continued the project for another nine months.
5 The tower was erected to its full 187 feet 57 m.
6 In July 1903 Tesla wrote to Morgan that in addition to wireless communication Wardenclyffe would be capable of wireless transmission of electric power.
7 On 14 October 1904 Morgan finally replied through his secretary stating It will be impossible for me to do anything in the matter after Tesla had written to Morgan when the financier was meeting with the Archbishop of Canterbury in an attempt to appeal to his Christian spirit.
8 How much correspondence did Tesla send Morgan in the five years following 1901?	over 50 letters	3

1 Tesla invented a steampowered mechanical oscillator—Teslas oscillator.
2 While experimenting with mechanical oscillators at his Houston Street lab Tesla allegedly generated a resonance of several buildings.
3 As the speed grew it is said that the machine oscillated at the resonance frequency of his own building and belatedly realizing the danger he was forced to use a sledge hammer to terminate the experiment just as the police arrived.
4 162–164 In February 1912 an article—Nikola Tesla Dreamer by Allan L Benson—was published in World Today in which an artists illustration appears showing the entire earth cracking in half with the caption Tesla claims that in a few weeks he could set the earths crust into such a state of vibration that it would rise and fall hundreds of feet and practically destroy civilization.
5 A continuation of this process would he says eventually split the earth in two.
6 How was Teslas mechanical oscillator powered?	steam	1
7 Where did he work on the oscillators?	Houston Street lab	2
8 What unforeseen problem caused Tesla to hit his experiment with a sledgehammer?	the machine oscillated at the resonance frequency of his own building	3
9 What publication published an article about Tesla in 1912?	World Today	4
10 What did Tesla claim his resonant frequencies could do in the World Today article?	eventually split the earth in two	5
1 Tesla theorized that the application of electricity to the brain enhanced intelligence.
2 In 1912 he crafted a plan to make dull students bright by saturating them unconsciously with electricity wiring the walls of a schoolroom and saturating the schoolroom with infinitesimal electric waves vibrating at high frequency.
3 The whole room will thus Mr Tesla claims be converted into a healthgiving and stimulating electromagnetic field or bath.
4 The plan was at least provisionally approved by then superintendent of New York City schools William H Maxwell.
5 What did Tesla think could improve the brains intelligence?	application of electricity	1
6 What was Teslas plan to make students bright?	saturating them unconsciously with electricity	2
7 Who approved of this plan?	William H Maxwell	4

1 In the August 1917 edition of the magazine Electrical Experimenter Tesla postulated that electricity could be used to locate submarines via using the reflection of an electric ray of tremendous frequency with the signal being viewed on a fluorescent screen a system that has been noted to have a superficial resemblance to modern radar.
2 Tesla was incorrect in his assumption that high frequency radio waves would penetrate water but Émile Girardeau who helped develop Frances first radar system in the 1930s noted in 1953 that Teslas general speculation that a very strong high frequency signal would be needed was correct stating Tesla was prophesying or dreaming since he had at his disposal no means of carrying them out but one must add that if he was dreaming at least he was dreaming correctly.
3 266.

1 On 6 November 1915 a Reuters news agency report from London had the 1915 Nobel Prize in Physics awarded to Thomas Edison and Nikola Tesla however on 15 November a Reuters story from Stockholm stated the prize that year was being awarded to Sir William Henry Bragg and William Lawrence Bragg for their services in the analysis of crystal structure by means of Xrays.
2 245 There were unsubstantiated rumors at the time that Tesla andor Edison had refused the prize.
3 245 The Nobel Foundation said Any rumor that a person has not been given a Nobel Prize because he has made known his intention to refuse the reward is ridiculous a recipient could only decline a Nobel Prize after he is announced a winner.
4 245.
5 Who did Reuters claim won the 1915 Nobel prize in Physics?	Thomas Edison and Nikola Tesla	1
6 Who actually won the prize?	Sir William Henry Bragg and William Lawrence Bragg	1
7 What was the rumored reason Edison and Tesla were not awarded the prize?	Tesla andor Edison had refused the prize	2
8 According to the Nobel Foundation what has to happen before someone can decline a prize?	announced a winner	3
1 There have been subsequent claims by Tesla biographers that Edison and Tesla were the original recipients and that neither was given the award because of their animosity toward each other that each sought to minimize the others achievements and right to win the award that both refused ever to accept the award if the other received it first that both rejected any possibility of sharing it and even that a wealthy Edison refused it to keep Tesla from getting the 20000 prize money.
2 245.
3 What was another possible reason that Tesla and Edison did not get the award?	animosity toward each other	1

1 In 1928 Tesla received his last patent US Patent 1655114 for a biplane capable of taking off vertically VTOL aircraft and then be gradually tilted through manipulation of the elevator devices in flight until it was flying like a conventional plane.

1 Starting in 1934 the Westinghouse Electric  Manufacturing Company began paying Tesla 125 per month as well as paying his rent at the Hotel New Yorker expenses the Company would pay for the rest of Teslas life.
2 Accounts on how this came about vary.
3 Several sources say Westinghouse was worried about potential bad publicity surrounding the impoverished conditions their former star inventor was living under.

1 In 1935 in an annual birthday celebration interview Tesla announced a method of transmitting mechanical energy with minimal loss over any terrestrial distance a related new means of communication and a method of accurately determining the location of underground mineral deposits.
