1 In the fall of 1937 after midnight one night Tesla left the Hotel New Yorker to make his regular commute to the cathedral and the library to feed the pigeons.
2 While crossing a street a couple of blocks from the hotel Tesla was unable to dodge a moving taxicab and was thrown heavily to the ground.
3 Teslas back was severely wrenched and three of his ribs were broken in the accident the full extent of his injuries will never be known Tesla refused to consult a doctor—an almost lifelong custom.
4 Tesla didnt raise any question as to who was at fault and refused medical aid only asking to be taken to his hotel via cab.
5 Tesla was bedridden for some months and was unable to continue feeding pigeons from his window soon they failed to come.
6 In early 1938 Tesla was able to get up.
7 He at once resumed the pigeonfeeding walks on a much more limited scale but frequently had a messenger act for him.
8 What was Tesla on his way to do when he was struck by the cab?	feed the pigeons	1
9 Who did Tesla refuse to see following the accident?	a doctor	3
10 What happened to his ribs in the accident?	broken	3
11 When did he first get out of bed following the accident?	early 1938	6
12 When did the accident occur?	the fall of 1937	1

2 I have built demonstrated and used it.
3 Only a little time will pass before I can give it to the world.
4 His records indicate that the device is based on a narrow stream of small tungsten pellets that are accelerated via high voltage by means akin to his magnifying transformer.

1 During the same year Tesla wrote a treatise The Art of Projecting Concentrated Nondispersive Energy through the Natural Media concerning charged particle beam weapons.
2 Tesla published the document in an attempt to expound on the technical description of a superweapon that would put an end to all war.
3 This treatise is currently in the Nikola Tesla Museum archive in Belgrade.
4 It describes an openended vacuum tube with a gas jet seal that allows particles to exit a method of charging particles to millions of volts and a method of creating and directing nondispersive particle streams through electrostatic repulsion.
5 Tesla tried to interest the US War Department the United Kingdom the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia in the device.

1 On 7 January 1943 at the age of 86 Tesla died alone in room 3327 of the New Yorker Hotel.

1 Tesla was 6 feet 2 inches 188 m tall and weighed 142 pounds 64 kg with almost no weight variance from 1888 to about 1926292 He was an elegant stylish figure in New York City meticulous in his grooming clothing and regimented in his daily activities.

1 Tesla read many works memorizing complete books and supposedly possessed a photographic memory.
2 33 He was a polyglot speaking eight languages SerboCroatian Czech English French German Hungarian Italian and Latin.
3 282 Tesla related in his autobiography that he experienced detailed moments of inspiration.
4 During his early life Tesla was repeatedly stricken with illness.
5 He suffered a peculiar affliction in which blinding flashes of light would appear before his eyes often accompanied by visions.
6 33 Often the visions were linked to a word or idea he might have come across at other times they would provide the solution to a particular problem he had encountered.
7 Just by hearing the name of an item he would be able to envision it in realistic detail.
8 33 Tesla would visualize an invention in his mind with extreme precision including all dimensions before moving to the construction stage a technique sometimes known as picture thinking.
9 He typically did not make drawings by hand but worked from memory.
10 Beginning in his childhood Tesla had frequent flashbacks to events that had happened previously in his life.
11 33.
12 How many languages did Tesla know?	eight	2

14 What is another term for Teslas visualization ability?	picture thinking	8
15 What other visual phenomena accompanied Teslas visions?	blinding flashes of light	5
16 What kind of memory was Tesla thought to have?	photographic memory	1
1 During his second year of study at Graz Tesla developed a passion for and became very proficient at billiards chess and cardplaying sometimes spending more than 48 hours in a stretch at a gaming table.
2 43 301 On one occasion at his laboratory Tesla worked for a period of 84 hours without sleep or rest.
3 208 Kenneth Swezey a journalist whom Tesla had befriended confirmed that Tesla rarely slept.
4 Swezey recalled one morning when Tesla called him at 3 am I was sleeping in my room like one dead .
5 Suddenly the telephone ring awakened me  Tesla spoke animatedly with pauses as he  worked out a problem comparing one theory to another commenting and when he felt he had arrived at the solution he suddenly closed the telephone.

1 Tesla never married he said his chastity was very helpful to his scientific abilities.

3 citation needed Tesla though polite and softspoken did not have any known relationships.

1 Tesla was asocial and prone to seclude himself with his work.

1 Tesla exhibited a preatomic understanding of physics in his writings he disagreed with the theory of atoms being composed of smaller subatomic particles stating there was no such thing as an electron creating an electric charge he believed that if electrons existed at all they were some fourth state of matter or subatom that could only exist in an experimental vacuum and that they had nothing to do with electricity.
2 249 Tesla believed that atoms are immutable—they could not change state or be split in any way.
3 He was a believer in the 19th century concept of an all pervasive ether that transmitted electrical energy.

1 Tesla claimed to have developed his own physical principle regarding matter and energy that he started working on in 1892 and in 1937 at age 81 claimed in a letter to have completed a dynamic theory of gravity that would put an end to idle speculations and false conceptions as that of curved space.

1 Computational complexity theory is a branch of the theory of computation in theoretical computer science that focuses on classifying computational problems according to their inherent difficulty and relating those classes to each other.
2 A computational problem is understood to be a task that is in principle amenable to being solved by a computer which is equivalent to stating that the problem may be solved by mechanical application of mathematical steps such as an algorithm.
3 What branch of theoretical computer science deals with broadly classifying computational problems by difficulty and class of relationship?	Computational complexity theory	1
4 By what main attribute are computational problems classified utilizing computational complexity theory?	inherent difficulty	1
5 What is the term for a task that generally lends itself to being solved by a computer?	computational problems	1
1 A problem is regarded as inherently difficult if its solution requires significant resources whatever the algorithm used.
2 The theory formalizes this intuition by introducing mathematical models of computation to study these problems and quantifying the amount of resources needed to solve them such as time and storage.
3 Other complexity measures are also used such as the amount of communication used in communication complexity the number of gates in a circuit used in circuit complexity and the number of processors used in parallel computing.
4 One of the roles of computational complexity theory is to determine the practical limits on what computers can and cannot do.
5 What measure of a computational problem broadly defines the inherent difficulty of the solution?	if its solution requires significant resources	1
6 What method is used to intuitively assess or quantify the amount of resources required to solve a computational problem?	mathematical models of computation	2
7 What are two basic primary resources used to guage complexity?	time and storage	2
8 What unit is measured to determine circuit complexity?	number of gates in a circuit	3
9 What practical role does defining the complexity of problems play in everyday computing?	determine the practical limits on what computers can and cannot do	4
1 Closely related fields in theoretical computer science are analysis of algorithms and computability theory.
2 A key distinction between analysis of algorithms and computational complexity theory is that the former is devoted to analyzing the amount of resources needed by a particular algorithm to solve a problem whereas the latter asks a more general question about all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem.
3 More precisely it tries to classify problems that can or cannot be solved with appropriately restricted resources.
4 In turn imposing restrictions on the available resources is what distinguishes computational complexity from computability theory the latter theory asks what kind of problems can in principle be solved algorithmically.
5 What two fields of theoretical computer science closely mirror computational complexity theory?	analysis of algorithms and computability theory	1
6 What field of computer science analyzes the resource requirements of a specific algorithm isolated unto itself within a given problem?	analysis of algorithms	1
7 What field of computer science analyzes all possible algorithms in aggregate to determine the resource requirements needed to solve to a given problem?	computational complexity theory	2
8 What field of computer science is primarily concerned with determining the likelihood of whether or not a problem can ultimately be solved using algorithms?	computability theory	1
1 A computational problem can be viewed as an infinite collection of instances together with a solution for every instance.
2 The input string for a computational problem is referred to as a problem instance and should not be confused with the problem itself.
3 In computational complexity theory a problem refers to the abstract question to be solved.
4 In contrast an instance of this problem is a rather concrete utterance which can serve as the input for a decision problem.
5 For example consider the problem of primality testing.
6 The instance is a number eg.
7 15 and the solution is yes if the number is prime and no otherwise in this case no.
8 Stated another way the instance is a particular input to the problem and the solution is the output corresponding to the given input.
9 What is the name given to the input string of a computational problem?	problem instance	2
10 In computational complexity theory what is the term given to describe the baseline abstract question needing to be solved?	the problem	2
11 Is a problem instance typically characterized as abstract or concrete?	concrete	4
12 What is another name for any given measure of input associated with a problem?	instances	1
13 What is the general term used to describe the output to any given input in a problem instance?	solution	1
1 To further highlight the difference between a problem and an instance consider the following instance of the decision version of the traveling salesman problem Is there a route of at most 2000 kilometres passing through all of Germanys 15 largest cities.
2 The quantitative answer to this particular problem instance is of little use for solving other instances of the problem such as asking for a round trip through all sites in Milan whose total length is at most 10 km.
3 For this reason complexity theory addresses computational problems and not particular problem instances.
4 By how many kilometers does the traveling salesman problem seek to classify a route between the 15 largest cities in Germany?	2000	1
5 What is one example of an instance that the quantitative answer to the traveling salesman problem fails to answer?	round trip through all sites in Milan	2
6 What does computational complexity theory most specifically seek to answer?	computational problems	3
1 When considering computational problems a problem instance is a string over an alphabet.
2 Usually the alphabet is taken to be the binary alphabet ie the set 01 and thus the strings are bitstrings.
3 As in a realworld computer mathematical objects other than bitstrings must be suitably encoded.
4 For example integers can be represented in binary notation and graphs can be encoded directly via their adjacency matrices or by encoding their adjacency lists in binary.
5 In a computational problem what can be described as a string over an alphabet?	problem instance	1
6 What is the name of the alphabet is most commonly used in a problem instance?	binary alphabet	2
7 What is another term for the string of a problem instance?	bitstrings	2
8 In the encoding of mathematical objects what is the way in which integers are commonly expressed?	binary notation	4
9 What is one way in which graphs can be encoded?	adjacency matrices	4
1 Decision problems are one of the central objects of study in computational complexity theory.
2 A decision problem is a special type of computational problem whose answer is either yes or no or alternately either 1 or 0.
3 A decision problem can be viewed as a formal language where the members of the language are instances whose output is yes and the nonmembers are those instances whose output is no.
4 The objective is to decide with the aid of an algorithm whether a given input string is a member of the formal language under consideration.
5 If the algorithm deciding this problem returns the answer yes the algorithm is said to accept the input string otherwise it is said to reject the input.
6 What kind of problems are one of the main topics studied in computational complexity theory?	Decision problems	1
7 What are the two simple word responses to a decision problem?	yes or no	2
8 What are the two integer responses to a decision problem?	1 or 0	2
9 What will the output be for a member of the language of a decision problem?	yes	2
10 What answer denotes that an algorithm has accepted an input string?	yes	2
1 An example of a decision problem is the following.
2 The input is an arbitrary graph.
3 The problem consists in deciding whether the given graph is connected or not.
4 The formal language associated with this decision problem is then the set of all connected graphs—of course to obtain a precise definition of this language one has to decide how graphs are encoded as binary strings.
5 What kind of graph is an example of an input used in a decision problem?	arbitrary graph	2
6 What is the term for the set of all connected graphs related to this decision problem?	formal language	4
7 What encoding decision needs to be made in order to determine an exact definition of the formal language?	how graphs are encoded as binary strings	4
1 A function problem is a computational problem where a single output of a total function is expected for every input but the output is more complex than that of a decision problem that is it isnt just yes or no.
2 Notable examples include the traveling salesman problem and the integer factorization problem.
3 A function problem is an example of what?	a computational problem	1
4 How many outputs are expected for each input in a function problem?	a single output	1
5 The traveling salesman problem is an example of what type of problem?	A function problem	1
6 In addition to the traveling salesman problem what is another example of a function problem?	the integer factorization problem	2
7 Is the output of a functional problem typically characterized by a simple or complex answer?	complex	1
1 It is tempting to think that the notion of function problems is much richer than the notion of decision problems.
2 However this is not really the case since function problems can be recast as decision problems.
3 For example the multiplication of two integers can be expressed as the set of triples a b c such that the relation a × b  c holds.
4 Deciding whether a given triple is a member of this set corresponds to solving the problem of multiplying two numbers.
5 How can function problems typically be restated?	decision problems	1
6 If two integers are multiplied and output a value what is this expression set called?	set of triples	3
1 To measure the difficulty of solving a computational problem one may wish to see how much time the best algorithm requires to solve the problem.
2 However the running time may in general depend on the instance.
3 In particular larger instances will require more time to solve.
4 Thus the time required to solve a problem or the space required or any measure of complexity is calculated as a function of the size of the instance.
5 This is usually taken to be the size of the input in bits.
6 Complexity theory is interested in how algorithms scale with an increase in the input size.
7 For instance in the problem of finding whether a graph is connected how much more time does it take to solve a problem for a graph with 2n vertices compared to the time taken for a graph with n vertices.
8 What is a commonly used measurement used to determine the complexity of a computational problem?	how much time the best algorithm requires to solve the problem	1
9 What is one variable on which the running time may be contingent?	the instance	2
10 How is the time needed to obtain the solution to a problem calculated?	as a function of the size of the instance	4
11 In what unit is the size of the input measured?	bits	5
12 Complexity theory seeks to define the relationship between the scale of algorithms with respect to what other variable?	an increase in the input size	6
1 If the input size is n the time taken can be expressed as a function of n Since the time taken on different inputs of the same size can be different the worstcase time complexity Tn is defined to be the maximum time taken over all inputs of size n If Tn is a polynomial in n then the algorithm is said to be a polynomial time algorithm.
2 Cobhams thesis says that a problem can be solved with a feasible amount of resources if it admits a polynomial time algorithm.
3 Whose thesis states that the solution to a problem is solvable with reasonable resources assuming it allows for a polynomial time algorithm?	Cobhams thesis	2
4 If input size is is equal to n what can respectively be assumed is the function of n?	the time taken	1
5 What term corresponds to the maximum measurement of time across all functions of n?	worstcase time complexity	1
6 How is worstcase time complexity written as an expression?	Tn	1
7 Assuming that T represents a polynomial in Tn what is the term given to the corresponding algorithm?	polynomial time algorithm	1
1 A Turing machine is a mathematical model of a general computing machine.
2 It is a theoretical device that manipulates symbols contained on a strip of tape.
3 Turing machines are not intended as a practical computing technology but rather as a thought experiment representing a computing machine—anything from an advanced supercomputer to a mathematician with a pencil and paper.
4 It is believed that if a problem can be solved by an algorithm there exists a Turing machine that solves the problem.
5 Indeed this is the statement of the Church–Turing thesis.
6 Furthermore it is known that everything that can be computed on other models of computation known to us today such as a RAM machine Conways Game of Life cellular automata or any programming language can be computed on a Turing machine.
7 Since Turing machines are easy to analyze mathematically and are believed to be as powerful as any other model of computation the Turing machine is the most commonly used model in complexity theory.
8 What is the term for a mathematical model that theoretically represents a general computing machine?	A Turing machine	1
9 It is generally assumed that a Turing machine can solve anything capable of also being solved using what?	an algorithm	4
10 What is the most commonplace model utilized in complexity theory?	the Turing machine	7
11 What does a Turing machine handle on a strip of tape?	symbols	2
1 A deterministic Turing machine is the most basic Turing machine which uses a fixed set of rules to determine its future actions.
2 A probabilistic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an extra supply of random bits.
3 The ability to make probabilistic decisions often helps algorithms solve problems more efficiently.
4 Algorithms that use random bits are called randomized algorithms.
5 A nondeterministic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an added feature of nondeterminism which allows a Turing machine to have multiple possible future actions from a given state.
6 One way to view nondeterminism is that the Turing machine branches into many possible computational paths at each step and if it solves the problem in any of these branches it is said to have solved the problem.
7 Clearly this model is not meant to be a physically realizable model it is just a theoretically interesting abstract machine that gives rise to particularly interesting complexity classes.
8 For examples see nondeterministic algorithm.
9 What is generally considered to be the most basic iteration of a Turing machine?	A deterministic Turing machine	1
10 What fixed set of factors determine the actions of a deterministic Turing machine	rules 	1.
11 What is the term used to identify a deterministic Turing machine that has additional random bits?	A probabilistic Turing machine	2
12 What type of Turing machine is capable of multiple actions and extends into a variety of computational paths?	A nondeterministic Turing machine	5
13 What is the term given to algorithms that utilize random bits?	randomized algorithms	4
1 Many types of Turing machines are used to define complexity classes such as deterministic Turing machines probabilistic Turing machines nondeterministic Turing machines quantum Turing machines symmetric Turing machines and alternating Turing machines.
2 They are all equally powerful in principle but when resources such as time or space are bounded some of these may be more powerful than others.
3 Turing machines are commonly employed to define what?	complexity classes	1
4 What are two factors that directly effect how powerful a Turing machine may or may not be?	time or space	2
5 In the determination of complexity classes what are two examples of types of Turing machines?	probabilistic Turing machines  nondeterministic Turing machines	1
1 Many machine models different from the standard multitape Turing machines have been proposed in the literature for example random access machines.
2 Perhaps surprisingly each of these models can be converted to another without providing any extra computational power.
3 The time and memory consumption of these alternate models may vary.
4 What all these models have in common is that the machines operate deterministically.
5 What is an example of a machine model that deviates from a generally accepted multitape Turing machine?	random access machines	1
6 In considering Turing machines and alternate variables what measurement left unaffected by conversion between machine models?	computational power	2
7 What two resources commonly consumed by alternate models are typically known to vary?	time and memory	3
8 What commonality do alternate machine models such as random access machines share with Turing machines?	the machines operate deterministically	4
1 However some computational problems are easier to analyze in terms of more unusual resources.
2 For example a nondeterministic Turing machine is a computational model that is allowed to branch out to check many different possibilities at once.
3 The nondeterministic Turing machine has very little to do with how we physically want to compute algorithms but its branching exactly captures many of the mathematical models we want to analyze so that nondeterministic time is a very important resource in analyzing computational problems.
4 What type of Turing machine can be characterized by checking multiple possibilities at the same time?	nondeterministic	2
5 What often affects or facilitates ease of analysis in computational problems?	unusual resources	1
6 A nondeterministic Turing machine has the ability to capture what facet of useful analysis?	mathematical models	3
7 What is the most critical resource in the analysis of computational problems associated with nondeterministic Turing machines?	time	3
1 For a precise definition of what it means to solve a problem using a given amount of time and space a computational model such as the deterministic Turing machine is used.
2 The time required by a deterministic Turing machine M on input x is the total number of state transitions or steps the machine makes before it halts and outputs the answer yes or no.
3 A Turing machine M is said to operate within time fn if the time required by M on each input of length n is at most fn.
4 A decision problem A can be solved in time fn if there exists a Turing machine operating in time fn that solves the problem.
5 Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based on their difficulty one defines sets of problems based on some criteria.
6 For instance the set of problems solvable within time fn on a deterministic Turing machine is then denoted by DTIMEfn.
7 The time required to output an answer on a deterministic Turing machine is expressed as what?	state transitions	2
8 Complexity theory classifies problems based on what primary attribute?	difficulty	5
9 What is the expression used to identify any given series of problems capable of being solved within time on a deterministic Turing machine?	DTIMEfn	6
10 What is the most critical resource measured to in assessing the determination of a Turing machines ability to solve any given set of problems?	time	1
1 Analogous definitions can be made for space requirements.
2 Although time and space are the most wellknown complexity resources any complexity measure can be viewed as a computational resource.
3 Complexity measures are very generally defined by the Blum complexity axioms.
4 Other complexity measures used in complexity theory include communication complexity circuit complexity and decision tree complexity.
5 Time and space are both examples of what type of resource?	complexity resources	2
6 A complexity resource can also be described as what other type of resource?	computational resource	2
7 What is typically used to broadly define complexity measures?	Blum complexity axioms	3
8 Communication complexity is an example of what type of measure?	Complexity measures	3
9 Decision tree is an example of what type of measure?	Complexity measures	3
1 The best worst and average case complexity refer to three different ways of measuring the time complexity or any other complexity measure of different inputs of the same size.
2 Since some inputs of size n may be faster to solve than others we define the following complexities.
3 What are the three primary expressions used to represent case complexity?	best  worst and average	1
4 Case complexity likelihoods provide variable probabilities of what general measure?	complexity measure	1
5 What is one common example of a critical complexity measure?	time	1
6 Case complexities provide three likelihoods of what differing variable that remains the same size?	inputs	1
1 For example consider the deterministic sorting algorithm quicksort.
2 This solves the problem of sorting a list of integers that is given as the input.
3 The worstcase is when the input is sorted or sorted in reverse order and the algorithm takes time On2 for this case.
4 If we assume that all possible permutations of the input list are equally likely the average time taken for sorting is On log n.
5 The best case occurs when each pivoting divides the list in half also needing On log n time.
6 What provides a solution to a list of integers provided as input that ned to be sorted?	deterministic sorting algorithm quicksort	1
7 When extensive time is required to sort integers this represents what case complexity?	worstcase	3
8 What is the expression used to denote a worst case complexity as expressed by time taken?	On2	3
1 To classify the computation time or similar resources such as space consumption one is interested in proving upper and lower bounds on the minimum amount of time required by the most efficient algorithm solving a given problem.
2 The complexity of an algorithm is usually taken to be its worstcase complexity unless specified otherwise.
3 Analyzing a particular algorithm falls under the field of analysis of algorithms.
4 To show an upper bound Tn on the time complexity of a problem one needs to show only that there is a particular algorithm with running time at most Tn.
5 However proving lower bounds is much more difficult since lower bounds make a statement about all possible algorithms that solve a given problem.
6 The phrase all possible algorithms includes not just the algorithms known today but any algorithm that might be discovered in the future.
7 To show a lower bound of Tn for a problem requires showing that no algorithm can have time complexity lower than Tn.
8 Classification of resources is contingent on determining the upper and lower bounds of minimum time required by what?	the most efficient algorithm	1
9 The analysis of a specific algorithm is typically assigned to what field of computational science?	analysis of algorithms	3
10 Which bound of time is more difficult to establish?	lower bounds	1
11 A specific algorithm demonstrating Tn represents what measure of time complexity?	upper bound	4
12 What is the colloquial phrase used to convey the continuum of algorithms with unlimited availability irrespective of time?	all possible algorithms	5
1 Upper and lower bounds are usually stated using the big O notation which hides constant factors and smaller terms.
2 This makes the bounds independent of the specific details of the computational model used.
3 For instance if Tn  7n2  15n  40 in big O notation one would write Tn  On2.
4 What expression is generally used to convey upper or lower bounds?	big O notation	1
5 What does a big O notation hide?	constant factors and smaller terms	1
6 How would one write Tn  7n2  15n  40 in big O notation?	Tn  On2	3
7 Big O notation provides autonomy to upper and lower bounds with relationship to what?	the computational model	2
1 Of course some complexity classes have complicated definitions that do not fit into this framework.
2 Thus a typical complexity class has a definition like the following.
3 What has complicated definitions that prevent classification into a framework?	complexity classes	1
4 Complexity classes are generally classified into what?	framework	1
5 Difficulty in establishing a framework for complexity classes can be caused by what variable?	complicated definitions	1
1 But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function fn often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model.
2 For instance the language xx  x is any binary string can be solved in linear time on a multitape Turing machine but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of singletape Turing machines.
3 If we allow polynomial variations in running time CobhamEdmonds thesis states that the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related Goldreich 2008 Chapter 12.
4 This forms the basis for the complexity class P which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time.
5 The corresponding set of function problems is FP.
6 Concrete bounding of computation time frequently produces complexity classes contingent upon what?	chosen machine model	1
7 A multitape Turing machine requires what type of time for a solution?	linear time	2
8 A language solved in quadratic time implies the use of what type of Turing machine?	singletape Turing machines	2
9 What thesis specifies that a polynomial relationship exists within time complexities in a computational model?	CobhamEdmonds thesis	3
10 Decision problems capable of being solved by a deterministic Turing machine while maintaining adherence to polynomial time belong to what class?	complexity class P	4
1 Many important complexity classes can be defined by bounding the time or space used by the algorithm.
2 Some important complexity classes of decision problems defined in this manner are the following.
3 What are two examples of measurements are bound within algorithms to establish complexity classes?	time or space	1
4 What function is used by algorithms to define measurements like time or space?	bounding	1
5 Bounding of time and space or similar measurements is often used by algorithms to define what?	complexity classes	1
1 Other important complexity classes include BPP ZPP and RP which are defined using probabilistic Turing machines AC and NC which are defined using Boolean circuits and BQP and QMA which are defined using quantum Turing machines.
2 P is an important complexity class of counting problems not decision problems.
3 Classes like IP and AM are defined using Interactive proof systems.
4 ALL is the class of all decision problems.
5 What are three examples of complexity classes associated with definitions established by probabilistic Turing machines?	BPP  ZPP and RP	1
6 AC and NC are complexity classes typically associated with what type of circuit?	Boolean	1
7 BQP and QMA are examples of complexity classes most commonly associated with what type of Turing machine?	quantum	1
8 What is the expression used to represent a complexity class of counting problems?	P	2
9 IP and AM are most commonly defined by what type of proof system?	Interactive	3
1 For the complexity classes defined in this way it is desirable to prove that relaxing the requirements on say computation time indeed defines a bigger set of problems.
2 In particular although DTIMEn is contained in DTIMEn2 it would be interesting to know if the inclusion is strict.
3 For time and space requirements the answer to such questions is given by the time and space hierarchy theorems respectively.
4 They are called hierarchy theorems because they induce a proper hierarchy on the classes defined by constraining the respective resources.
5 Thus there are pairs of complexity classes such that one is properly included in the other.
6 Having deduced such proper set inclusions we can proceed to make quantitative statements about how much more additional time or space is needed in order to increase the number of problems that can be solved.
7 What is an example of a measurement within a complexity class that would create a bigger set of problems if the bounds were relaxed?	computation time	1
8 In what expression can one expect to find DTIMEn	DTIMEn2 	2.
9 What theorems are responsible for determining questions of time and space requirements?	time and space hierarchy theorems	3
10 Resources are constrained by hierarchy theorems to produce what?	a proper hierarchy on the classes defined	4
11 What kind of statement is made in the effort of establishing the time and space requirements needed to enhance the ultimate number of problems solved?	quantitative statements	6
1 The time and space hierarchy theorems form the basis for most separation results of complexity classes.
2 For instance the time hierarchy theorem tells us that P is strictly contained in EXPTIME and the space hierarchy theorem tells us that L is strictly contained in PSPACE.
3 What is the foundation for separation results within complexity classes?	time and space hierarchy theorems	1
4 What is responsible for constraining P according to the time hierarchy theorem?	EXPTIME	2
5 Within what variable is L constrained according to the space hierarchy theorem?	PSPACE	2
1 Many complexity classes are defined using the concept of a reduction.
2 A reduction is a transformation of one problem into another problem.
3 It captures the informal notion of a problem being at least as difficult as another problem.
4 For instance if a problem X can be solved using an algorithm for Y X is no more difficult than Y and we say that X reduces to Y.
5 There are many different types of reductions based on the method of reduction such as Cook reductions Karp reductions and Levin reductions and the bound on the complexity of reductions such as polynomialtime reductions or logspace reductions.
6 What concept is frequently used to define complexity classes?	reduction	1
7 Reduction essentially takes one problem and converts into what?	another problem	2
8 According to reduction if X and Y can be solved by the same algorithm then X performs what function in relationship to Y?	reduces	4
9 What are two examples of different types of reduction?	Karp reductions and Levin reductions	5
10 Polynomial time reductions are an example of what?	the bound on the complexity of reductions	5
1 The most commonly used reduction is a polynomialtime reduction.
2 This means that the reduction process takes polynomial time.
3 For example the problem of squaring an integer can be reduced to the problem of multiplying two integers.
4 This means an algorithm for multiplying two integers can be used to square an integer.
5 Indeed this can be done by giving the same input to both inputs of the multiplication algorithm.
6 Thus we see that squaring is not more difficult than multiplication since squaring can be reduced to multiplication.
7 What is the most frequently employed type of reduction?	polynomialtime reduction	1
8 What equates to a squared integer according to polynomial time reduction?	multiplying two integers	3
9 What measurement of time is used in polynomial time reduction?	polynomial time	2
10 What would need to remain constant in a multiplication algorithm to produce the same outcome whether multiplying or squaring two integers?	input	5
11 According to polynomial time reduction squaring can ultimately be logically reduced to what?	multiplication	5
1 This motivates the concept of a problem being hard for a complexity class.
2 A problem X is hard for a class of problems C if every problem in C can be reduced to X.
3 Thus no problem in C is harder than X since an algorithm for X allows us to solve any problem in C Of course the notion of hard problems depends on the type of reduction being used.
4 For complexity classes larger than P polynomialtime reductions are commonly used.
5 In particular the set of problems that are hard for NP is the set of NPhard problems.
6 The complexity of problems often depends on what?	the type of reduction being used	3
7 What would create a conflict between a problem X and problem C within the context of reduction?	if every problem in C can be reduced to X	2
8 An algorithm for X which reduces to C would us to do what?	solve any problem in C	3
9 A problem set that that is hard for the expression NP can also be stated how?	NPhard	5
1 If a problem X is in C and hard for C then X is said to be complete for C This means that X is the hardest problem in C Since many problems could be equally hard one might say that X is one of the hardest problems in C Thus the class of NPcomplete problems contains the most difficult problems in NP in the sense that they are the ones most likely not to be in P Because the problem P  NP is not solved being able to reduce a known NPcomplete problem Π2 to another problem Π1 would indicate that there is no known polynomialtime solution for Π1.
2 This is because a polynomialtime solution to Π1 would yield a polynomialtime solution to Π2.
3 Similarly because all NP problems can be reduced to the set finding an NPcomplete problem that can be solved in polynomial time would mean that P  NP.
4 The hardest problems in NP can be analogously written as what class of problems?	NPcomplete	1
5 NP complete problems contain the lowest likelihood of being located in what problem class?	NP	1
6 If P  NP is unsolved and reduction is applied to a known NPcomplete problem vis a vis Π2 to  Π1 what conclusion can be drawn for Π1?	there is no known polynomialtime solution	1
7 If polynomial time can be utilized within an NPcomplete problem what does the imply P is equal to?	NP	1
1 The complexity class P is often seen as a mathematical abstraction modeling those computational tasks that admit an efficient algorithm.
2 This hypothesis is called the Cobham–Edmonds thesis.
3 The complexity class NP on the other hand contains many problems that people would like to solve efficiently but for which no efficient algorithm is known such as the Boolean satisfiability problem the Hamiltonian path problem and the vertex cover problem.
4 Since deterministic Turing machines are special nondeterministic Turing machines it is easily observed that each problem in P is also member of the class NP.
5 What complexity class is characterized by a computational tasks and efficient algorithms?	P	1
6 What hypothesis is associated with the complexity class of P viewed as a mathematical abstraction with efficient algorithmic functionality?	Cobham–Edmonds thesis	2
7 What complexity class is commonly characterized by unknown algorithms to enhance solvability?	NP	3
8 What is an example of a problem that rests within the NP complexity class?	Boolean satisfiability problem	3
9 In what theoretical machine is it confirmed that a problem in P belies membership in the NP class?	Turing machines	4
1 The question of whether P equals NP is one of the most important open questions in theoretical computer science because of the wide implications of a solution.
2 If the answer is yes many important problems can be shown to have more efficient solutions.
3 These include various types of integer programming problems in operations research many problems in logistics protein structure prediction in biology and the ability to find formal proofs of pure mathematics theorems.
4 The P versus NP problem is one of the Millennium Prize Problems proposed by the Clay Mathematics Institute.
5 There is a US1000000 prize for resolving the problem.
6 If P is ultimately proven to be equal tot NP what effect would this have on the efficiency of problems?	more efficient solutions	2
7 What is a particular problem in biology that would benefit from determining that P  NP?	protein structure prediction	3
8 What is the prize offered for finding a solution to PNP?	1 000 000	5
1 It was shown by Ladner that if P ≠ NP then there exist problems in NP that are neither in P nor NPcomplete.
2 Such problems are called NPintermediate problems.
3 The graph isomorphism problem the discrete logarithm problem and the integer factorization problem are examples of problems believed to be NPintermediate.
4 They are some of the very few NP problems not known to be in P or to be NPcomplete.
5 Who demonstrated that P NP implies problems not present in P or NPcomplete?	Ladner	1
6 What is the name for a problem that meets Ladners assertion?	NPintermediate problems	2
7 What is an example of an NPintermediate problem not known to exist in P or NPcomplete?	graph isomorphism problem	3
1 The graph isomorphism problem is the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic.
2 An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the graph isomorphism problem is in P NPcomplete or NPintermediate.
3 The answer is not known but it is believed that the problem is at least not NPcomplete.
4 If graph isomorphism is NPcomplete the polynomial time hierarchy collapses to its second level.
5 Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NPcomplete.
6 The best algorithm for this problem due to Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks has run time 2O√n logn for graphs with n vertices.
7 What is the problem attributed to defining if two finite graphs are isomorphic?	The graph isomorphism problem	1
8 What class is most commonly not ascribed to the graph isomorphism problem in spite of definitive determination?	NPcomplete	2
9 What finite hierarchy implies that the graph isomorphism problem is NPcomplete?	polynomial time hierarchy	4
10 To what level would the polynomial time hierarchy collapse if graph isomorphism is NPcomplete?	second level	4
11 Who are commonly associated with the algorithm typically considered the most effective with respect to finite polynomial hierarchy and graph isomorphism?	Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks	6
1 The integer factorization problem is the computational problem of determining the prime factorization of a given integer.
2 Phrased as a decision problem it is the problem of deciding whether the input has a factor less than k No efficient integer factorization algorithm is known and this fact forms the basis of several modern cryptographic systems such as the RSA algorithm.
3 The integer factorization problem is in NP and in coNP and even in UP and coUP.
4 If the problem is NPcomplete the polynomial time hierarchy will collapse to its first level ie NP will equal coNP.
5 The best known algorithm for integer factorization is the general number field sieve which takes time Oe64913nlog 213log nlog 223 to factor an nbit integer.
6 However the best known quantum algorithm for this problem Shors algorithm does run in polynomial time.
7 Unfortunately this fact doesnt say much about where the problem lies with respect to nonquantum complexity classes.
8 What computational problem is commonly associated with prime factorization?	The integer factorization problem	1
9 The integer factorization problem essentially seeks to determine if the value of of an input is less than what variable?	k	2
10 That there currently exists no known integer factorization problem underpins what commonly used system?	modern cryptographic systems	2
11 What is the most wellknown algorithm associated with the integer factorization problem?	the general number field sieve	5
1 Many known complexity classes are suspected to be unequal but this has not been proved.
2 For instance P ⊆ NP ⊆ PP ⊆ PSPACE but it is possible that P  PSPACE.
3 If P is not equal to NP then P is not equal to PSPACE either.
4 Since there are many known complexity classes between P and PSPACE such as RP BPP PP BQP MA PH etc it is possible that all these complexity classes collapse to one class.
5 Proving that any of these classes are unequal would be a major breakthrough in complexity theory.
6 What is the unproven assumption generally ascribed to the value of complexity classes?	suspected to be unequal	1
7 What is an expression that can be used to illustrate the suspected inequality of complexity classes?	P ⊆ NP ⊆ PP ⊆ PSPACE	2
8 Where can the complexity classes RP BPP PP BQP MA and PH be located?	between P and PSPACE	4
9 What evidence between and among complexity classes would signify a theoretical watershed for complexity theory?	Proving that any of these classes are unequal	5
1 Along the same lines coNP is the class containing the complement problems ie.
2 problems with the yesno answers reversed of NP problems.
3 It is believed that NP is not equal to coNP however it has not yet been proven.
4 It has been shown that if these two complexity classes are not equal then P is not equal to NP.
5 In what complexity class do complement problems of NP problems exist?	coNP	1
6 How do the yesno answers of a complement problem of NP appear?	reversed	2
7 What is commonly believed to be the value relationship between P and coNP	not equal 	3.
8 What implication can be derived for P and NP if P and coNP are established to be unequal?	P is not equal to NP	4
1 Similarly it is not known if L the set of all problems that can be solved in logarithmic space is strictly contained in P or equal to P Again there are many complexity classes between the two such as NL and NC and it is not known if they are distinct or equal classes.
2 What variable is associated with all problems solved within logarithmic space?	L	1
3 Though unkown what are the most commonly ascribed attributes of L in relation to P	strictly contained in P or equal to P 	1.
4 What lies between L and P that prevents a definitive determination of the relationship between L and P?	complexity classes	1
5 What are two complexity classes between L and P?	NL and NC	1
6 What is unknown about the complexity classes between L and P that further prevents determining the value relationship between L and P?	if they are distinct or equal classes	1
1 Problems that can be solved in theory eg given large but finite time but which in practice take too long for their solutions to be useful are known as intractable problems.
2 In complexity theory problems that lack polynomialtime solutions are considered to be intractable for more than the smallest inputs.
3 In fact the Cobham–Edmonds thesis states that only those problems that can be solved in polynomial time can be feasibly computed on some computational device.
4 Problems that are known to be intractable in this sense include those that are EXPTIMEhard.
5 If NP is not the same as P then the NPcomplete problems are also intractable in this sense.
6 To see why exponentialtime algorithms might be unusable in practice consider a program that makes 2n operations before halting.
7 For small n say 100 and assuming for the sake of example that the computer does 1012 operations each second the program would run for about 4 × 1010 years which is the same order of magnitude as the age of the universe.
8 Even with a much faster computer the program would only be useful for very small instances and in that sense the intractability of a problem is somewhat independent of technological progress.
9 Nevertheless a polynomial time algorithm is not always practical.
10 If its running time is say n15 it is unreasonable to consider it efficient and it is still useless except on small instances.
11 Problems capable of theoretical solutions but consuming unreasonable time in practical application are known as what?	intractable problems	1
12 Intractable problems lacking polynomial time solutions necessarily negate the practical efficacy of what type of algorithm?	exponentialtime algorithms	6
13 If NP is not equal to P viewed through this lens what type of problems can also be considered intractable?	NPcomplete problems	5
1 What intractability means in practice is open to debate.
2 Saying that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large cases of the problem are hard or even that most of them are.
3 For example the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic has been shown not to be in P yet algorithms have been written that solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases.
4 Similarly algorithms can solve the NPcomplete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic time and SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of the NPcomplete Boolean satisfiability problem.
5 What eponymous variation of arithmetic presents a decision problem not evidenced in P?	Presburger arithmetic	3
6 Despite the Presburger problem and in view of intractability what has been done to establish solutions in reasonable periods of time?	algorithms have been written	3
7 What is an example of a problem to which effective algorithms have provided a solution in spite of the intractability associated with the breadth of sizes?	NPcomplete knapsack problem	4
8 How quickly can an algorithm solve an NPcomplete knapsack problem?	in less than quadratic time	4
9 What is the example of another problem characterized by large instances that is routinely solved by SAT handlers employing efficient algorithms?	NPcomplete Boolean satisfiability problem	4
1 Before the actual research explicitly devoted to the complexity of algorithmic problems started off numerous foundations were laid out by various researchers.
2 Most influential among these was the definition of Turing machines by Alan Turing in 1936 which turned out to be a very robust and flexible simplification of a computer.
3 What tactic did researchers employ to offset the former deficit of work surrounding the complexity of algorithmic problems?	foundations were laid out	1
4 Who was the most influential researcher among those grappling with the deficit of work surrounding the complexity posed by algorithmic problems?	Alan Turing	2
5 What theoretical device is attributed to Alan Turing?	Turing machines	2
6 In what year was the Alan Turings definitional model of a computing device received?	1936	2
7 In the most basic sense what did a Turing machine emulate?	a computer	2
1 As Fortnow  Homer 2003 point out the beginning of systematic studies in computational complexity is attributed to the seminal paper On the Computational Complexity of Algorithms by Juris Hartmanis and Richard Stearns 1965 which laid out the definitions of time and space complexity and proved the hierarchy theorems.
2 Also in 1965 Edmonds defined a good algorithm as one with running time bounded by a polynomial of the input size.
3 What paper is commonly considered the bellwether ushering in systematic studies computational complexity?	On the Computational Complexity of Algorithms	1
4 What individuals were responsible for authoring On the Computational Complexity of Algorithms?	Juris Hartmanis and Richard Stearns	1
5 In what year was Hatmanis and Stearns seminal work in computational complexity received?	1965	1
6 What complex measurements were defined by On the Computational Complexity of Algorithms?	time and space	1
7 In what year did Edmonds characterize a good algorithm?	1965	1
1 Earlier papers studying problems solvable by Turing machines with specific bounded resources include  John Myhills definition of linear bounded automata Myhill 1960 Raymond Smullyans study of rudimentary sets 1961 as well as Hisao Yamadas paper on realtime computations 1962.
2 Somewhat earlier Boris Trakhtenbrot 1956 a pioneer in the field from the USSR studied another specific complexity measure.
3 As he remembers.
4 Who provided a definition of linear bounded automata in 1960?	John Myhill	1
5 In what year did Raymond Sullivan publish a study of rudimentary sets?	1961	1
6 In 1962 who was responsible for the authorship of a paper published on real timecomputations?	Hisao Yamada	1
1 Even though some proofs of complexitytheoretic theorems regularly assume some concrete choice of input encoding one tries to keep the discussion abstract enough to be independent of the choice of encoding.
2 This can be achieved by ensuring that different representations can be transformed into each other efficiently.
3 What is the concrete choice typically assumed by most complexitytheoretic theorems?	input encoding	1
4 In the effort of maintaining a level of abstraction what choice is typically left independent?	encoding	1
1 In 1967 Manuel Blum developed an axiomatic complexity theory based on his axioms and proved an important result the socalled speedup theorem.
2 The field really began to flourish in 1971 when the US researcher Stephen Cook and working independently Leonid Levin in the USSR proved that there exist practically relevant problems that are NPcomplete.
3 In 1972 Richard Karp took this idea a leap forward with his landmark paper Reducibility Among Combinatorial Problems in which he showed that 21 diverse combinatorial and graph theoretical problems each infamous for its computational intractability are NPcomplete.
4 Who is responsible for axiomatic complexity theory?	Manuel Blum	1
5 What theorem was implicated by Manuel Blums axioms?	speedup theorem	1
6 What is the paper written by Richard Karp in 1972 that ushered in a new era of understanding between intractability and NPcomplete problems?	Reducibility Among Combinatorial Problems	3
7 How many combinatory and graph theoretical problems formerly believed to be plagued by intractability did Karps paper address?	21	3
1 The role of teacher is often formal and ongoing carried out at a school or other place of formal education.
2 In many countries a person who wishes to become a teacher must first obtain specified professional qualifications or credentials from a university or college.
3 These professional qualifications may include the study of pedagogy the science of teaching.
4 Teachers like other professionals may have to continue their education after they qualify a process known as continuing professional development.
5 Teachers may use a lesson plan to facilitate student learning providing a course of study which is called the curriculum.

1 Teaching using pedagogy also involve assessing the educational levels of the students on particular skills.
2 Understanding the pedagogy of the students in a classroom involves using differentiated instruction as well as supervision to meet the needs of all students in the classroom.
3 Pedagogy can be thought of in two manners.
4 First teaching itself can be taught in many different ways hence using a pedagogy of teaching styles.
5 Second the pedagogy of the learners comes into play when a teacher assesses the pedagogic diversity of hisher students and differentiates for the individual students accordingly.
6 For example an experienced teacher and parent described the place of a teacher in learning as follows The real bulk of learning takes place in selfstudy and problem solving with a lot of feedback around that loop.
7 The function of the teacher is to pressure the lazy inspire the bored deflate the cocky encourage the timid detect and correct individual flaws and broaden the viewpoint of all.
8 This function looks like that of a coach using the whole gamut of psychology to get each new class of rookies off the bench and into the game.

10 In what areas does most of the learning take place?	selfstudy and problem solving	6

12 What would a teacher do for someone who is cocky?	deflate	7
13 What function is a teachers role similar to?	a coach	8
1 Perhaps the most significant difference between primary school and secondary school teaching is the relationship between teachers and children.
2 In primary schools each class has a teacher who stays with them for most of the week and will teach them the whole curriculum.
3 In secondary schools they will be taught by different subject specialists each session during the week and may have ten or more different teachers.
4 The relationship between children and their teachers tends to be closer in the primary school where they act as form tutor specialist teacher and surrogate parent during the course of the day.
5 Whats the biggest difference in the teaching relationship for primary and secondary school?	the relationship between teachers and children	1
6 What does a teacher teach in primary school?	the whole curriculum	2
7 Who teaches in secondary schools?	different subject specialists	3
8 Which type of school has a closer teacherchild relationship?	primary school	1
9 What type of parenting role does a teacher take on?	surrogate	4
1 This is true throughout most of the United States as well.
2 However alternative approaches for primary education do exist.
3 One of these sometimes referred to as a platoon system involves placing a group of students together in one class that moves from one specialist to another for every subject.
4 The advantage here is that students learn from teachers who specialize in one subject and who tend to be more knowledgeable in that one area than a teacher who teaches many subjects.
5 Students still derive a strong sense of security by staying with the same group of peers for all classes.
6 What type of approaches for primary school are available that are different than the norm?	alternative	2
7 What type of system takes students from one specialist to another for each subject?	platoon	3
8 In a platoon style teaching what gives the children security?	staying with the same group of peers for all classes	5
9 The teachers in a platoon style teaching are usually more ?	knowledgeable	4
10 What country is this teaching subject discussing?	United States	1
1 Coteaching has also become a new trend amongst educational institutions.
2 Coteaching is defined as two or more teachers working harmoniously to fulfill the needs of every student in the classroom.
3 Coteaching focuses the student on learning by providing a social networking support that allows them to reach their full cognitive potential.
4 Coteachers work in sync with one another to create a climate of learning.
5 What is a new trend in teaching?	Coteaching	1
6 How many teachers are usually involved when coteaching?	two or more	2
7 What does coteaching get the students to focus on?	learning	3
8 How do coteachers work with each other to fulfill the needs of students?	harmoniously	2
9 What type of support does coteaching provide?	social networking support	3
1 Throughout the history of education the most common form of school discipline was corporal punishment.
2 While a child was in school a teacher was expected to act as a substitute parent with all the normal forms of parental discipline open to them.
3 What was the usual type of school discipline?	corporal punishment	1
4 What was the teachers role while the child was with them?	substitute parent	2
5 What types of discipline did the teacher have access to?	all the normal forms of parental discipline	2
6 How common of a type was corporal punishment in schools?	the most common	1
7 When could a teacher act in the role of a parent?	While a child was in school	2
1 In past times corporal punishment spanking or paddling or caning or strapping or birching the student in order to cause physical pain was one of the most common forms of school discipline throughout much of the world.
2 Most Western countries and some others have now banned it but it remains lawful in the United States following a US Supreme Court decision in 1977 which held that paddling did not violate the US Constitution.
3 How common was the form of corporal punishment in the past?	one of the most common	1
4 Where is corporal punishment no longer practiced?	Most Western countries	2
5 What Western country is corporal punishment still allowed?	United States	2
6 What US entity said that corporal punishment was Constitutional?	Supreme Court	2
7 What does corporal punishment cause a student?	physical pain	1
1 30 US states have banned corporal punishment the others mostly in the South have not.
2 It is still used to a significant though declining degree in some public schools in Alabama Arkansas Georgia Louisiana Mississippi Oklahoma Tennessee and Texas.
3 Private schools in these and most other states may also use it.
4 Corporal punishment in American schools is administered to the seat of the students trousers or skirt with a specially made wooden paddle.
5 This often used to take place in the classroom or hallway but nowadays the punishment is usually given privately in the principals office.
6 How many US states do no practice corporal punishment?	30	1
7 Where is corporal punishment practiced the most?	the South	1
8 Is corporal punishment increasing or declining in the South?	declining	2
9 What tool is used in corporal punishment?	a specially made wooden paddle	4
10 Where is corporal punishment usually performed these days?	privately in the principals office	5
1 Official corporal punishment often by caning remains commonplace in schools in some Asian African and Caribbean countries.
2 For details of individual countries see School corporal punishment.
3 What is a common practice in official corporal punishment?	caning	1
4 What countries is corporal punishment still a normal practice?	some Asian  African and Caribbean countries	1
5 Where can you find more information on a countrys practices?	see School corporal punishment	2
1 Currently detention is one of the most common punishments in schools in the United States the UK Ireland Singapore and other countries.
2 It requires the pupil to remain in school at a given time in the school day such as lunch recess or after school or even to attend school on a nonschool day eg.
3 Saturday detention held at some schools.
4 During detention students normally have to sit in a classroom and do work write lines or a punishment essay or sit quietly.
5 What is a common punishment in Singapore?	detention	1
6 What is a common punishment in the UK and Ireland?	detention	1
7 Where does the pupil remain while in detention	in schools 	1.
8 If a detention requires a pupil to just sit there how are they required to sit?	quietly	4
9 If a detention asks the student to write what do they write?	lines or a punishment essay	4
1 A modern example of school discipline in North America and Western Europe relies upon the idea of an assertive teacher who is prepared to impose their will upon a class.
2 Positive reinforcement is balanced with immediate and fair punishment for misbehavior and firm clear boundaries define what is appropriate and inappropriate behavior.
3 Teachers are expected to respect their students sarcasm and attempts to humiliate pupils are seen as falling outside of what constitutes reasonable discipline.
4 verification needed.
5 What type of teacher is required in the Western Europe model of discipline?	assertive	1
6 What is the balance for positive reinforcement?	immediate and fair punishment for misbehavior	2
7 What type of boundaries help to define the way kids behave?	firm  clear boundaries	2
8 What is not considered appropriate disclipine?	sarcasm and attempts to humiliate pupils	3
9 What are teachers expected to give their students?	respect	3
1 Whilst this is the consensus viewpoint amongst the majority of academics some teachers and parents advocate a more assertive and confrontational style of discipline.
2 citation needed Such individuals claim that many problems with modern schooling stem from the weakness in school discipline and if teachers exercised firm control over the classroom they would be able to teach more efficiently.
3 This viewpoint is supported by the educational attainment of countries—in East Asia for instance—that combine strict discipline with high standards of education.
4 citation needed.
5 Who wants a more confrontational type of discipline?	some teachers and parents	1
6 What countries are used as an example of harsher discipline with successful education?	East Asia	3
7 What do critics think the cause of problems with modern schooling is?	weakness in school discipline	2
8 What type of discipline do critics want to see?	a more assertive and confrontational style	1
1 Its not clear however that this stereotypical view reflects the reality of East Asian classrooms or that the educational goals in these countries are commensurable with those in Western countries.
2 In Japan for example although average attainment on standardized tests may exceed those in Western countries classroom discipline and behavior is highly problematic.
3 Although officially schools have extremely rigid codes of behavior in practice many teachers find the students unmanageable and do not enforce discipline at all.
4 What country has higher scores on standardized tests than the US?	Japan	2
5 What country has such unmanageable students that many teachers do not discipline them?	Japan	2
6 What country has a problem with classroom discipline even though scores on tests are high?	Japan	2
7 What countrys schools have codes of behavior that are very strict?	Japan	2
1 Where school class sizes are typically 40 to 50 students maintaining order in the classroom can divert the teacher from instruction leaving little opportunity for concentration and focus on what is being taught.
2 In response teachers may concentrate their attention on motivated students ignoring attentionseeking and disruptive students.
3 The result of this is that motivated students facing demanding university entrance examinations receive disproportionate resources.
4 Given the emphasis on attainment of university places administrators and governors may regard this policy as appropriate.
5 What class sizes can make keeping order difficult?	40 to 50 students	1
6 If the teacher focuses on maintaining order what does this take time away from?	instruction	1
7 Who may teachers focus on in order to prioritize attention?	motivated students	2
8 Who may teachers ignore in order to prioritize attention?	attentionseeking and disruptive students	2
9 Who ends up getting more of the teachers resources in this scenario?	motivated students	2
1 Sudbury model democratic schools claim that popularly based authority can maintain order more effectively than dictatorial authority for governments and schools alike.
2 They also claim that in these schools the preservation of public order is easier and more efficient than anywhere else.
3 Primarily because rules and regulations are made by the community as a whole thence the school atmosphere is one of persuasion and negotiation rather than confrontation since there is no one to confront.
4 Sudbury model democratic schools proponents argue that a school that has good clear laws fairly and democratically passed by the entire school community and a good judicial system for enforcing these laws is a school in which community discipline prevails and in which an increasingly sophisticated concept of law and order develops against other schools today where rules are arbitrary authority is absolute punishment is capricious and due process of law is unknown.
5 What type of authority do Sudbury schools prefer?	popularly based authority	1
6 In addition to schools where else is popularly based authority effective?	governments	1
7 What is the atmosphere in a school using popularly based authority?	persuasion and negotiation	3
8 In schools using popularly based authority what is public order like?	easier and more efficient	2
9 What must be passed using democratic means by the entire school community?	good  clear laws	4
1 Since teachers can affect how students perceive the course materials it has been found that teachers who showed enthusiasm towards the course materials and students can affect a positive learning experience towards the course materials.
2 On teachercourse evaluations it was found that teachers who have a positive disposition towards the course content tend to transfer their passion to receptive students.
3 These teachers do not teach by rote but attempt to find new invigoration for the course materials on a daily basis.
4 One of the difficulties in this approach is that teachers may have repeatedly covered a curriculum until they begin to feel bored with the subject which in turn bores the students as well.
5 Students who had enthusiastic teachers tend to rate them higher than teachers who didnt show much enthusiasm for the course materials.
6 What must a teacher show towards the course materials for increase learning?	enthusiasm	1
7 What gets transferred to students who are receptive to the teacher?	passion	2
8 What do these teachers NOT do?	teach by rote	3
9 How do students rate teachers that they feel are enthusiastic?	higher	5
1 Teachers that exhibit enthusiasm can lead to students who are more likely to be engaged interested energetic and curious about learning the subject matter.
2 Recent research has found a correlation between teacher enthusiasm and students intrinsic motivation to learn and vitality in the classroom.
3 Controlled experimental studies exploring intrinsic motivation of college students has shown that nonverbal expressions of enthusiasm such as demonstrative gesturing dramatic movements which are varied and emotional facial expressions result in college students reporting higher levels of intrinsic motivation to learn.
4 Students who experienced a very enthusiastic teacher were more likely to read lecture material outside of the classroom.
5 What increases students motivation to learn?	teacher enthusiasm	2
6 Students exposed to an enthusiastic teacher usually did what more often outside class?	read lecture material	4
7 What is dramatic gesturing an example of?	nonverbal expressions of enthusiasm	3
8 What type of studies explored student motivation?	Controlled  experimental studies	3
9 Nonverbal expressions resulted in what kind of levels of motivation to learn?	higher	3
1 There are various mechanisms by which teacher enthusiasm may facilitate higher levels of intrinsic motivation.
2 Teacher enthusiasm may contribute to a classroom atmosphere full of energy and enthusiasm which feed student interest and excitement in learning the subject matter.
3 Enthusiastic teachers may also lead to students becoming more selfdetermined in their own learning process.
4 The concept of mere exposure indicates that the teachers enthusiasm may contribute to the students expectations about intrinsic motivation in the context of learning.
5 Also enthusiasm may act as a motivational embellishment increasing a students interest by the variety novelty and surprise of the enthusiastic teachers presentation of the material.
6 Finally the concept of emotional contagion may also apply.
7 Students may become more intrinsically motivated by catching onto the enthusiasm and energy of the teacher.
8 citation needed.
9 Enthusiastic teachers may cause students to become more  about their learning process?	selfdetermined	3
10 What may cause motivational embellishment?	enthusiasm	1
11 What is the term for catching the motivation expressed by the teacher?	emotional contagion	6
12 What might cause a higher student interest in learning the presented subject?	Teacher enthusiasm	2
1 Research shows that student motivation and attitudes towards school are closely linked to studentteacher relationships.
2 Enthusiastic teachers are particularly good at creating beneficial relations with their students.
3 Their ability to create effective learning environments that foster student achievement depends on the kind of relationship they build with their students.
4 Useful teachertostudent interactions are crucial in linking academic success with personal achievement.
5 Here personal success is a students internal goal of improving himself whereas academic success includes the goals he receives from his superior.
6 A teacher must guide his student in aligning his personal goals with his academic goals.
7 Students who receive this positive influence show stronger selfconfidence and greater personal and academic success than those without these teacher interactions.
8 What is student motivation about school linked to?	studentteacher relationships	1
9 What type of relationships do enthusiastic teachers cause?	beneficial	2
10 What does a students academic goals include?	the goals he receives from his superior	5
11 What should a teacher guide a student in?	aligning his personal goals with his academic goals	6
12 What is strongly linked to good studentteacher relationships?	student motivation and attitudes towards school	1
1 Students are likely to build stronger relations with teachers who are friendly and supportive and will show more interest in courses taught by these teachers.
2 Teachers that spend more time interacting and working directly with students are perceived as supportive and effective teachers.
3 Effective teachers have been shown to invite student participation and decision making allow humor into their classroom and demonstrate a willingness to play.
4 Students show more interest in classes taught by what type of teachers?	friendly and supportive	1
5 Students build stronger relationships with what type of teachers?	friendly and supportive	1
6 What do supportive teachers spend more time doing?	interacting and working directly with students	2
7 Humor is a part of the classroom for what type of teacher?	effective	2
1 The way a teacher promotes the course they are teaching the more the student will get out of the subject matter.
2 The three most important aspects of teacher enthusiasm are enthusiasm about teaching enthusiasm about the students and enthusiasm about the subject matter.
3 A teacher must enjoy teaching.
4 If they do not enjoy what they are doing the students will be able to tell.
5 They also must enjoy being around their students.
6 A teacher who cares for their students is going to help that individual succeed in their life in the future.
7 The teacher also needs to be enthusiastic about the subject matter they are teaching.
8 For example a teacher talking about chemistry needs to enjoy the art of chemistry and show that to their students.

1 Misconduct by teachers especially sexual misconduct has been getting increased scrutiny from the media and the courts.
2 A study by the American Association of University Women reported that 96 of students in the United States claim to have received unwanted sexual attention from an adult associated with education be they a volunteer bus driver teacher administrator or other adult sometime during their educational career.
3 What is the largest type of misconduct being reviewed by the media?	sexual misconduct	1
4 How many students have received unwanted sexual attention from a teacher or other education figure?	96	2

6 What is the time period of this statistic?	sometime during their educational career	2
7 Who conducted this survey?	American Association of University Women	2
1 A study in England showed a 03 prevalence of sexual abuse by any professional a group that included priests religious leaders and case workers as well as teachers.
2 It is important to note however that the British study referenced above is the only one of its kind and consisted of a random  probability sample of 2869 young people between the ages of 18 and 24 in a computerassisted study and that the questions referred to sexual abuse with a professional not necessarily a teacher.
3 It is therefore logical to conclude that information on the percentage of abuses by teachers in the United Kingdom is not explicitly available and therefore not necessarily reliable.
4 The AAUW study however posed questions about fourteen types of sexual harassment and various degrees of frequency and included only abuses by teachers.
5 The sample was drawn from a list of 80000 schools to create a stratified twostage sample design of 2065 8th to 11th grade studentsIts reliability was gauged at 95 with a 4 margin of error.
6 Where was it shown to have a 03 prevalence of sexual abuse by professionals?	England	1
7 What was the definition of professionals for this study?	priests  religious leaders  and case workers as well as teachers	1
8 How many people were involved in the study?	2 869	2
9 What study covered subjects in 80000 schools?	The AAUW study	4
1 In the United States especially several highprofile cases such as Debra LaFave Pamela Rogers and Mary Kay Letourneau have caused increased scrutiny on teacher misconduct.

1 Chris Keates the general secretary of National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said that teachers who have sex with pupils over the age of consent should not be placed on the sex offenders register and that prosecution for statutory rape is a real anomaly in the law that we are concerned about.
2 This has led to outrage from child protection and parental rights groups.
3 Fears of being labelled a pedophile or hebephile has led to several men who enjoy teaching avoiding the profession.
4 This has in some jurisdictions reportedly led to a shortage of male teachers.
5 Why have some men avoided becoming teachers?	Fears of being labelled a pedophile or hebephile	3
