1 Teachers face several occupational hazards in their line of work including occupational stress which can negatively impact teachers mental and physical health productivity and students performance.
2 Stress can be caused by organizational change relationships with students fellow teachers and administrative personnel working environment expectations to substitute long hours with a heavy workload and inspections.
3 Teachers are also at high risk for occupational burnout.
4 What can hurt a teachers mental and physical health?	occupational stress	1
5 What when combined with a large workload can contribute to occupational stress?	long hours	2
6 What is something that teachers are at a high risk for?	occupational burnout	3
7 What can be the result of a change in an organization?	stress	1
8 What on the part of a teacher can result in a decrease in student performance	occupational stress 	1.
1 A 2000 study found that 42 of UK teachers experienced occupational stress twice the figure for the average profession.
2 A 2012 study found that teachers experienced double the rate of anxiety depression and stress than average workers.
3 How many teachers were found to have felt occupational stress in a 2000 study?	42	1
4 Where was the 2000 study conducted?	UK	1
5 How much higher was the 42 occupation stress figure compared to other jobs?	twice the figure for the average profession	1
6 Which study showed double the rate of anxiety?	2012	2
7 The 2012 study showed teachers experienced more stress than whom?	average workers	2
1 There are several ways to mitigate the occupational hazards of teaching.
2 Organizational interventions like changing teachers schedules providing support networks and mentoring changing the work environment and offering promotions and bonuses may be effective in helping to reduce occupational stress among teachers.
3 Individuallevel interventions including stressmanagement training and counseling are also used to relieve occupational stress among teachers.
4 How many ways are available to help reduce the stress of teaching?	several	1
5 What is providing support networks considered to be?	Organizational interventions	2
6 What is stressmanagement training considered to be?	Individuallevel interventions	3
7 What might offering bonuses help reduce?	occupational stress among teachers	2
8 What type of intervention would changing the work environment be?	Organizational interventions	2
1 There are many similarities and differences among teachers around the world.
2 In almost all countries teachers are educated in a university or college.
3 Governments may require certification by a recognized body before they can teach in a school.
4 In many countries elementary school education certificate is earned after completion of high school.
5 The high school student follows an education specialty track obtain the prerequisite studentteaching time and receive a special diploma to begin teaching after graduation.
6 In addition to certification many educational institutions especially within the US require that prospective teachers pass a background check and psychiatric evaluation to be able to teach in classroom.
7 This is not always the case with adult further learning institutions but is fast becoming the norm in many countries as security concerns grow.

1 In Scotland anyone wishing to teach must be registered with the General Teaching Council for Scotland GTCS.

1 In the United States each state determines the requirements for getting a license to teach in public schools.
2 Teaching certification generally lasts three years but teachers can receive certificates that last as long as ten years.
3 Public school teachers are required to have a bachelors degree and the majority must be certified by the state in which they teach.
4 Many charter schools do not require that their teachers be certified provided they meet the standards to be highly qualified as set by No Child Left Behind.
5 Additionally the requirements for substitutetemporary teachers are generally not as rigorous as those for fulltime professionals.
6 The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that there are 14 million elementary school teachers 674000 middle school teachers and 1 million secondary school teachers employed in the US.
7 In the US who decides on the requirements for teachers?	each state	1
8 What is the longest time that a teaching certificate is good for?	ten years	2
9 What must a public school teacher have at a minimum?	a bachelors degree	3
10 Who may not require that its teachers be certified?	charter schools	4
11 What may a Charter school require that their teachers meet the standards to be highly qualified by?	No Child Left Behind	4
1 In the past teachers have been paid relatively low salaries.
2 However average teacher salaries have improved rapidly in recent years.
3 US teachers are generally paid on graduated scales with income depending on experience.
4 Teachers with more experience and higher education earn more than those with a standard bachelors degree and certificate.
5 Salaries vary greatly depending on state relative cost of living and grade taught.
6 Salaries also vary within states where wealthy suburban school districts generally have higher salary schedules than other districts.
7 The median salary for all primary and secondary teachers was 46000 in 2004 with the average entry salary for a teacher with a bachelors degree being an estimated 32000.
8 Median salaries for preschool teachers however were less than half the national median for secondary teachers clock in at an estimated 21000 in 2004.
9 For high school teachers median salaries in 2007 ranged from 35000 in South Dakota to 71000 in New York with a national median of 52000.
10 Some contracts may include longterm disability insurance life insurance emergencypersonal leave and investment options.
11 The American Federation of Teachers teacher salary survey for the 200607 school year found that the average teacher salary was 51009.
12 In a salary survey report for K12 teachers elementary school teachers had the lowest median salary earning 39259.
13 High school teachers had the highest median salary earning 41855.
14 Many teachers take advantage of the opportunity to increase their income by supervising afterschool programs and other extracurricular activities.
15 In addition to monetary compensation public school teachers may also enjoy greater benefits like health insurance compared to other occupations.
16 Merit pay systems are on the rise for teachers paying teachers extra money based on excellent classroom evaluations high test scores and for high success at their overall school.
17 Also with the advent of the internet many teachers are now selling their lesson plans to other teachers through the web in order to earn supplemental income most notably on TeachersPayTeacherscom.
18 In general what were teachers paid in the past?	relatively low salaries	1
19 What has been getting much better in the most recent years?	average teacher salaries	2
20 What two factors can generally increase a teachers salary?	more experience and higher education	4
21 In a report on K12 teachers which teachers had the lowest median salary?	elementary school teachers	12
22 What website are teachers using to sell their lesson plans?	TeachersPayTeacherscom	17
1 There are many forms of spiritual or religious teachers in Christianity across all three major traditions  Roman Catholic Eastern Orthodox Catholic and ProtestantNonDenominational with a stronger tradition of spiritual formation in the more historic and authoritarianhierarchical Christian traditions with a long tradition of discernment of spirits of vocations and other aspects of spiritual life especially the Roman and Orthodox Catholic Churches.
2 These positions include the honoured but informal position of starets or elder  a man or less often woman often a monastic considered to be graced by God with certain gifts for the guidance of souls and the detection and correction of prelest spiritual pride or deception  who acts as a spiritual guide or father in the Orthodox Catholic tradition especially Russian Orthodoxy see Optina Monastery which had a long line of said starets the Priest or Confessor in Roman Catholicism who is often a man in Holy Orders but may be a monastic or other person respected for his spiritual accomplishments or acumen even the Pope of Rome has a Confessor who is not always a bishop and due to the hierarchical structure of the Roman Church can not be his equal in authority which is often a semiofficial to official position as opposed to the unofficial positions of spiritual guides in the Orthodox Catholic and Protestant traditions and the almostexclusively informal arrangements generally formal only in members who are under some form of church discipline of mentorship both of adults and children in the latter case often a youth pastor in the Protestant and NonDenominational traditions which boundaries can be blurred with the more typically Roman confessor position in some of the more historic and conservative Reformation Churches such as some of the Lutheran and Anglican.
3 In keeping with the individualistic nature of most Protestant denominations the emphasis on being guided in spiritual development is small with a heavy emphasis placed on heavy reading and personal Spiritenlightened interpretation of the Holy Bible.
4 How many types of religious or spiritual teachers are there in Christianity?	many	1
5 Which denomination has more of an individualistic streak?	Protestant	1
6 Is the Popes confessor a Bishop?	not always	2
7 What are the three major traditions present in Christianity?	Roman Catholic  Eastern Orthodox Catholic  and ProtestantNonDenominational	1
1 In The Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints LDS Church the teacher is an office in the Aaronic priesthood generally conferred on young boys or recent converts and has little in common with the spiritual teacher archetype.
2 The role of spiritual teacher may be filled by many individuals in the LDS Church often a trusted friend who may hold any office from Elder to Bishop or no office at all.
3 The emphasis on spiritual mentorship in the LDS Church is similar to that in the more lowchurch traditions of Protestantism with a stronger emphasis placed on the husband and father of a family to provide spiritual guidance for all of his family ideally in consultation with his wife even if the husband is not a member of the LDS Church based on interpretatios of certain Biblical texts which proclaim the spiritual authority of husbands in marriage.
4 Even Priesthood representatives are expected to defer to the father of the house when in his home.
5 Further additional spiritual guidance is offered by those holding the office of Patriarch which is supposed by Latterday Saints to grant certain gifts of the Spirit such as the ability to prophesy to its holders.
6 This guidance is generally offered during a ceremony called the patriarchal blessing.
7 What is an abbreviation for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints?	LDS Church	1
8 Who may be a spiritual teacher in the LDS Church?	many individuals	2
9 What type of mentorship does the LDS Church focus on?	spiritual	1
10 Who is expected to lead the family in spiritual mentorship?	the husband and father	3
11 Who do Priesthood representatives defer to at times?	the father of the house	4
1 In Hinduism the spiritual teacher is known as a guru and in many traditions of Hinduism  especially those common in the West  the emphasis on spiritual mentorship is extremely high with gurus often exercising a great deal of control over the lives of their disciples.
2 What is the name of the spiritual teacher in Hinduism?	guru	1
3 Is the focus on spiritual mentorship in Hinduism high or low?	extremely high	1
4 Who do gurus control?	their disciples	1
5 In what area is it common for spiritual mentorship to be extremely high?	the West	1
1 In Tibetan Buddhism the teachers of Dharma in Tibet are most commonly called a Lama.
2 A Lama who has through phowa and siddhi consciously determined to be reborn often many times in order to continue their Bodhisattva vow is called a Tulku.
3 What is the name of a teacher in Tibetan Buddhism?	a Lama	1
4 What has a Lama determined to do?	be reborn	2
5 What is the name of a Bodhisattva vow?	Tulku	2
6 How much has a Lama agreed to be reborn?	often many times	2
7 What helped the Lama determine to be reborn?	through phowa and siddhi	2
1 There are many concepts of teachers in Islam ranging from mullahs the teachers at madrassas to ulemas who teach of the laws of Islam for the proper way of Islamic living according to the Sunnah and Ahadith and can render legal verdicts upon matters of Islamic law in accordance with the teaching of one of the Four Schools of Jurisprudence.
2 In the more spiritual or mystical Islamic tradition of Sufism the position of spiritual teacher and an esoteric as opposed to exoteric or actionsoriented eg.
3 the Five Pillars of Islam spirituality and spiritual knowledge takes on a more important dimension with emphasis on learning from living saints  the highest of which is a Qutb  and of traditions passed down from initiate to initiate and traceable back to the founder of the order.
4 Who teaches the proper way of living in Islam?	ulemas	1
5 Who can decide on legal matters in Islam?	ulemas	1
6 What is the name of the mystical type of Islam?	Sufism	2
7 What is another name for exoteric?	actionsoriented	2
8 What is the term for the highest living saint?	Qutb	3
1 Martin Luther ˈluːθər or ˈluːðər German ˈmaɐ̯tiːn ˈlʊtɐ  listen 10 November 1483 – 18 February 1546 was a German professor of theology composer priest former monk and a seminal figure in the Protestant Reformation.
2 Luther came to reject several teachings and practices of the Late Medieval Catholic Church.
3 He strongly disputed the claim that freedom from Gods punishment for sin could be purchased with money.
4 He proposed an academic discussion of the power and usefulness of indulgences in his NinetyFive Theses of 1517.
5 His refusal to retract all of his writings at the demand of Pope Leo X in 1520 and the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V at the Diet of Worms in 1521 resulted in his excommunication by the Pope and condemnation as an outlaw by the Emperor.
6 Of what nationality was Martin Luther?	German	1
7 When did Martin Luther die?	18 February 1546	1
8 What organizations teaching did Luther reject?	Catholic Church	2
9 What did the Church claim could be avoided with money?	Gods punishment	3
10 What did the Church do when Luther refused to retract his writings?	excommunication	5
1 Luther taught that salvation and subsequently eternal life is not earned by good deeds but is received only as a free gift of Gods grace through faith in Jesus Christ as redeemer from sin.
2 His theology challenged the authority and office of the Pope by teaching that the Bible is the only source of divinely revealed knowledge from God and opposed sacerdotalism by considering all baptized Christians to be a holy priesthood.
3 Those who identify with these and all of Luthers wider teachings are called Lutherans even though Luther insisted on Christian or Evangelical as the only acceptable names for individuals who professed Christ.
4 Since he didnt believe that salvation was acquired through good deeds how was it achieved?	gift of Gods grace	1
5 What did Martin Luther believe achieved Gods Grace?	faith in Jesus Christ	1
6 Whose authority did Luthers theology oppose?	the Pope	2
7 What did Luther think was the only source of knowledge of God?	Bible	2
8 To Luther what were all baptized Christians considered to be?	holy priesthood	2
1 His translation of the Bible into the vernacular instead of Latin made it more accessible which had a tremendous impact on the church and German culture.
2 It fostered the development of a standard version of the German language added several principles to the art of translation and influenced the writing of an English translation the Tyndale Bible.
3 His hymns influenced the development of singing in churches.
4 His marriage to Katharina von Bora set a model for the practice of clerical marriage allowing Protestant clergy to marry.
5 What book did Martin Luther translate to impact German culture?	Bible	1
6 What did Luthers translation of the Bible promote in the German language?	standard version	2
7 What version of the English translation of the Bible did Luthers translation affect?	Tyndale Bible	2
8 What development did Luthers hymns translations influence?	singing in churches	3
9 What did Martin Luthers marriage allow?	Protestant clergy to marry	4
1 Martin Luther was born to Hans Luder or Ludher later Luther and his wife Margarethe née Lindemann on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben Saxony then part of the Holy Roman Empire.
2 He was baptized as a Catholic the next morning on the feast day of St Martin of Tours.
3 His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484 where his father was a leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council.
4 The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luthers mother as a hardworking woman of tradingclass stock and middling means and notes that Luthers enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant.
5 He had several brothers and sisters and is known to have been close to one of them Jacob.
6 Hans Luther was ambitious for himself and his family and he was determined to see Martin his eldest son become a lawyer.
7 He sent Martin to Latin schools in Mansfeld then Magdeburg in 1497 where he attended a school operated by a lay group called the Brethren of the Common Life and Eisenach in 1498.
8 The three schools focused on the socalled trivium grammar rhetoric and logic.
9 Luther later compared his education there to purgatory and hell.
10 When was Martin Luther born?	10 November 1483	1
11 Where was Luther born?	Eisleben  Saxony	1
12 Of what region was Saxony a part?	Holy Roman Empire	1
13 Into what religion was Martin Luther baptized?	Catholic	2
14 What profession did Martins father want his son to pursue?	lawyer	6
1 In 1501 at the age of 19 he entered the University of Erfurt which he later described as a beerhouse and whorehouse.
2 He was made to wake at four every morning for what has been described as a day of rote learning and often wearying spiritual exercises.
3 He received his masters degree in 1505.
4 Where did Martin Luther go to school?	University of Erfurt	1
5 How did Luther describe the University of Erfurt?	beerhouse and whorehouse	1
6 How early did Luther say he had to awaken every day?	at four	2
7 How did Luther describe his learning at the university?	rote learning	2
8 In what year did Luther get his degree?	1505	3
1 In accordance with his fathers wishes Luther enrolled in law school at the same university that year but dropped out almost immediately believing that law represented uncertainty.
2 Luther sought assurances about life and was drawn to theology and philosophy expressing particular interest in Aristotle William of Ockham and Gabriel Biel.
3 He was deeply influenced by two tutors Bartholomaeus Arnoldi von Usingen and Jodocus Trutfetter who taught him to be suspicious of even the greatest thinkers and to test everything himself by experience.
4 Philosophy proved to be unsatisfying offering assurance about the use of reason but none about loving God which to Luther was more important.
5 Reason could not lead men to God he felt and he thereafter developed a lovehate relationship with Aristotle over the latters emphasis on reason.
6 For Luther reason could be used to question men and institutions but not God.
7 Human beings could learn about God only through divine revelation he believed and Scripture therefore became increasingly important to him.
8 What educational study did Luther start to pursue and immediately  drop?	law	1
9 What did Luther think the study of law meant?	uncertainty	1
10 What fields of study did Martin Luther prefer?	theology and philosophy	2
11 How did Luthers tutors advise him to test what he learned?	by experience	3
12 What did Luther think reason could not be used to test?	God	7
1 He later attributed his decision to an event on 2 July 1505 he was returning to university on horseback after a trip home.
2 During a thunderstorm a lightning bolt struck near him.
3 Later telling his father he was terrified of death and divine judgment he cried out Help.
4 Saint Anna I will become a monk.
5 He came to view his cry for help as a vow he could never break.
6 He left law school sold his books and entered a closed Augustinian cloister in Erfurt on 17 July 1505.
7 One friend blamed the decision on Luthers sadness over the deaths of two friends.
8 Luther himself seemed saddened by the move.
9 Those who attended a farewell supper walked him to the door of the Black Cloister.
10 This day you see me and then not ever again he said.
11 His father was furious over what he saw as a waste of Luthers education.
12 What did Martin Luther fear after a lightening bolt struck near him?	death and divine judgment 	3
13 When did the lightening event happen?	2 July 1505	1
14 Where did Luther go on 17 July 1505?	Augustinian cloister in Erfurt	6
15 On what did Luthers friend blame his sadness and entrance into the cloister?	deaths of two friends	7
16 What did Martins father view his entering the cloister as a waste of?	Luthers education	11
1 Luther dedicated himself to the Augustinian order devoting himself to fasting long hours in prayer pilgrimage and frequent confession.
2 Luther described this period of his life as one of deep spiritual despair.
3 He said I lost touch with Christ the Savior and Comforter and made of him the jailer and hangman of my poor soul.
4 Johann von Staupitz his superior pointed Luthers mind away from continual reflection upon his sins toward the merits of Christ.
5 He taught that true repentance does not involve selfinflicted penances and punishments but rather a change of heart.
6 To what did Martin Luther devote all his attention ?	Augustinian order	1
7 How did Luther describe his time in the order?	deep spiritual despair	2
8 What did Luther feel he made of Christ?	jailer and hangman	3
9 Who directed Luther away from selfreflection and towards the merits of Christ?	Johann von Staupitz	4
10 What lesson did Johann von Staupitz teach Luther  repentance was?	a change of heart	5
1 In 1507 he was ordained to the priesthood and in 1508 von Staupitz first dean of the newly founded University of Wittenberg sent for Luther to teach theology.
2 He received a bachelors degree in Biblical studies on 9 March 1508 and another bachelors degree in the Sentences by Peter Lombard in 1509.

1 On 19 October 1512 he was awarded his Doctor of Theology and on 21 October 1512 was received into the senate of the theological faculty of the University of Wittenberg having been called to the position of Doctor in Bible.
2 He spent the rest of his career in this position at the University of Wittenberg.

1 In 1516 Johann Tetzel a Dominican friar and papal commissioner for indulgences was sent to Germany by the Roman Catholic Church to sell indulgences to raise money to rebuild St Peters Basilica in Rome.
2 Roman Catholic theology stated that faith alone whether fiduciary or dogmatic cannot justify man justification rather depends only on such faith as is active in charity and good works fides caritate formata.
3 The benefits of good works could be obtained by donating money to the church.
4 When was Johann Tetzel sent by the Roman Catholic Church to Germany to sell indulgences?	1516	1
5 Why was Tetzel seeking money in Germany?	rebuild St Peters Basilica	1
6 What theology states that faith alone isnt enough to justify man?	Roman Catholic	2
7 What does mans justification depend on in faith?	charity and good works	2
8 What is the Catholic doctrine of fides caritate formata?	charity and good works	2
1 On 31 October 1517 Luther wrote to his bishop Albert of Mainz protesting the sale of indulgences.
2 He enclosed in his letter a copy of his Disputation of Martin Luther on the Power and Efficacy of Indulgences which came to be known as The NinetyFive Theses.
3 Hans Hillerbrand writes that Luther had no intention of confronting the church but saw his disputation as a scholarly objection to church practices and the tone of the writing is accordingly searching rather than doctrinaire.
4 Hillerbrand writes that there is nevertheless an undercurrent of challenge in several of the theses particularly in Thesis 86 which asks Why does the pope whose wealth today is greater than the wealth of the richest Crassus build the basilica of St Peter with the money of poor believers rather than with his own money.
5 When did Martin Luther protest the sale of indulgences to his bishop?	31 October 1517	1
6 In 1517 who was Luthers bishop?	Albert of Mainz	1
7 What was Luthers Disputation of Martin Luther on the Power and Efficacy of Indulgences later called?	The NinetyFive Theses	2
8 Who contends that Luther did not intend to oppose the church?	Hans Hillerbrand	3
9 Which Thesis questions the Popes actions in building the basilica of St Peter with the money of the poor?	Thesis 86	4
1 Luther objected to a saying attributed to Johann Tetzel that As soon as the coin in the coffer rings the soul from purgatory also attested as into heaven springs.

3 How did Tetzel state that the soul could leave purgatory?	coin in the coffer	1
4 Who objected to Tetzels collections of money to free souls from purgatory?	Luther	1
5 What church money collector said that the sould would spring from purgatory through monetary donations?	Johann Tetzel	1
1 He insisted that since forgiveness was Gods alone to grant those who claimed that indulgences absolved buyers from all punishments and granted them salvation were in error.
2 Christians he said must not slacken in following Christ on account of such false assurances.

4 What were these indulgences supposed to grant the giver?	salvation	1
5 What did giving money to the church absolve the giver from?	punishments	1
6 What did Luther call these donations?	false assurances	2
7 Who did Luther say that Christians must not slacken in following?	Christ	2
1 However this oftquoted saying of Tetzel was by no means representative of contemporary Catholic teaching on indulgences but rather a reflection of his capacity to exaggerate.
2 Yet if Tetzel overstated the matter in regard to indulgences for the dead his teaching on indulgences for the living was in line with Catholic dogma of the time.

1 According to scholars Walter Krämer Götz Trenkler Gerhard Ritter and Gerhard Prause the story of the posting on the door even though it has settled as one of the pillars of history has little foundation in truth.

1 It was not until January 1518 that friends of Luther translated the 95 Theses from Latin into German and printed and widely copied them making the controversy one of the first in history to be aided by the printing press.
2 Within two weeks copies of the theses had spread throughout Germany within two months they had spread throughout Europe.
3 When was Luthers 95 Theses translated into German?	January 1518	1

5 Who translated and printed Luthers 95 These?	friends of Luther	1

1 Luthers writings circulated widely reaching France England and Italy as early as 1519.
2 Students thronged to Wittenberg to hear Luther speak.
3 He published a short commentary on Galatians and his Work on the Psalms.
4 This early part of Luthers career was one of his most creative and productive.
5 Three of his bestknown works were published in 1520 To the Christian Nobility of the German Nation On the Babylonian Captivity of the Church and On the Freedom of a Christian.
6 When did Luthers writings to spread to France England and Italy?	1519	1
7 Who went to Wittenberg to hear Luther speak?	Students	2
8 What part of Luthers career was one of his most productive?	early part	4
9 When were some of Luthers bestknown works published?	1520	5

1 From 1510 to 1520 Luther lectured on the Psalms the books of Hebrews Romans and Galatians.
2 As he studied these portions of the Bible he came to view the use of terms such as penance and righteousness by the Catholic Church in new ways.
3 He became convinced that the church was corrupt in its ways and had lost sight of what he saw as several of the central truths of Christianity.
4 The most important for Luther was the doctrine of justification – Gods act of declaring a sinner righteous – by faith alone through Gods grace.
5 He began to teach that salvation or redemption is a gift of Gods grace attainable only through faith in Jesus as the Messiah.
6 This one and firm rock which we call the doctrine of justification he wrote is the chief article of the whole Christian doctrine which comprehends the understanding of all godliness.
7 What did Martin Luther do during 1510 to 1520?	lectured	1
8 What sections of Church dogma did Luther come to view in another way?	penance and righteousness	2
9 What did Luther decide about the Catholic Church?	corrupt in its ways	3
10 What to Luther had the Church lost sight of?	central truths of Christianity	3
11 What is the central article of the Christian doctrine?	doctrine of justification	4
1 Luther came to understand justification as entirely the work of God.
2 This teaching by Luther was clearly expressed in his 1525 publication On the Bondage of the Will which was written in response to On Free Will by Desiderius Erasmus 1524.
3 Luther based his position on predestination on St Pauls epistle to the Ephesians 28–10.
4 Against the teaching of his day that the righteous acts of believers are performed in cooperation with God Luther wrote that Christians receive such righteousness entirely from outside themselves that righteousness not only comes from Christ but actually is the righteousness of Christ imputed to Christians rather than infused into them through faith.
5 That is why faith alone makes someone just and fulfills the law he wrote.
6 Faith is that which brings the Holy Spirit through the merits of Christ.
7 Faith for Luther was a gift from God the experience of being justified by faith was as though I had been born again.
8 His entry into Paradise no less was a discovery about the righteousness of God – a discovery that the just person of whom the Bible speaks as in Romans 117 lives by faith.
9 He explained his concept of justification in the Smalcald Articles.
10 Of whom to Luther was justification entirely the work ?	God	1
11 When did Luther publish On the Bondage of the Will?	1525	2
12 What did Luther consider faith to be?	gift from God	7
13 Where did Luther explain his idea of justification?	Smalcald Articles	9
14 By what did Luther believe the just person lives?	lives by faith	8
1 Luthers rediscovery of Christ and His salvation was the first of two points that became the foundation for the Reformation.
2 His railing against the sale of indulgences was based on it.
3 What was the first point of the Reformation?	Christ and His salvation	1
4 What became the foundation of the Reformation?	Christ and His salvation	1
5 What fueled Luthers  concept of Christ and His Salvation?	sale of indulgences	2
6 How many points are there in the foundation of the Reformation?	two points	1
1 Archbishop Albrecht of Mainz and Magdeburg did not reply to Luthers letter containing the 95 Theses.
2 He had the theses checked for heresy and in December 1517 forwarded them to Rome.
3 He needed the revenue from the indulgences to pay off a papal dispensation for his tenure of more than one bishopric.
4 As Luther later noted the pope had a finger in the pie as well because one half was to go to the building of St Peters Church in Rome.
5 To whom did Luther send a letter containing his 95 Theses?	Archbishop Albrecht	1
6 After Archbishop Albrecht reviewed the Theses where did he send them?	Rome	2
7 What did Albrecht need the indulgences to pay for?	papal dispensation	3
8 How much of the indulgences went to Rome?	one half	4
9 When did Archbishop Albrecht send Luthers letter containing the 95 Theses to Rome?	December 1517	2
1 Pope Leo X was used to reformers and heretics and he responded slowly with great care as is proper.
2 Over the next three years he deployed a series of papal theologians and envoys against Luther which served only to harden the reformers antipapal theology.
3 First the Dominican theologian Sylvester Mazzolini drafted a heresy case against Luther whom Leo then summoned to Rome.
4 The Elector Frederick persuaded the pope to have Luther examined at Augsburg where the Imperial Diet was held.
5 There in October 1518 under questioning by papal legate Cardinal Cajetan Luther stated that he did not consider the papacy part of the biblical Church because historistical interpretation of Bible prophecy concluded that the papacy was the Antichrist.
6 The prophecies concerning the Antichrist soon became the center of controversy.
7 The hearings degenerated into a shouting match.
8 More than his writing the 95 Theses Luthers confrontation with the church cast him as an enemy of the pope.
9 Cajetans original instructions had been to arrest Luther if he failed to recant but the legate desisted from doing so.
10 Luther slipped out of the city at night unbeknownst to Cajetan.
11 Which Pope sought to undermine Luthers theories?	Pope Leo X	1
12 What did Pope Leo X launch against Luther?	papal theologians and envoys	2
13 When was Luther examined at Augsburg by the papal legate?	October 1518	5
14 What did Luther tell the legate about the papacy?	papacy was the Antichrist	5
15 What were the papal legates orders from the Pope?	arrest Luther	9
1 In January 1519 at Altenburg in Saxony the papal nuncio Karl von Miltitz adopted a more conciliatory approach.
2 Luther made certain concessions to the Saxon who was a relative of the Elector and promised to remain silent if his opponents did.
3 The theologian Johann Eck however was determined to expose Luthers doctrine in a public forum.
4 In June and July 1519 he staged a disputation with Luthers colleague Andreas Karlstadt at Leipzig and invited Luther to speak.
5 Luthers boldest assertion in the debate was that Matthew 1618 does not confer on popes the exclusive right to interpret scripture and that therefore neither popes nor church councils were infallible.
6 For this Eck branded Luther a new Jan Hus referring to the Czech reformer and heretic burned at the stake in 1415.
7 From that moment he devoted himself to Luthers defeat.
8 When did papal nuncio Karl von Miltitz get Luther to make concessions ?	January 1519	1
9 What did Luther promise to do as a concession?	remain silent	2
10 Who was determined to expose Luther at this time?	Johann Eck	3
11 What scripture did Luther use to back up his opinion that churchmen were not infallible?	Matthew 1618	5
12 What did Johann Eck call Luther?	new Jan Hus	6
1 On 15 June 1520 the Pope warned Luther with the papal bull edict Exsurge Domine that he risked excommunication unless he recanted 41 sentences drawn from his writings including the 95 Theses within 60 days.
2 That autumn Johann Eck proclaimed the bull in Meissen and other towns.
3 Karl von Miltitz a papal nuncio attempted to broker a solution but Luther who had sent the Pope a copy of On the Freedom of a Christian in October publicly set fire to the bull and decretals at Wittenberg on 10 December 1520 an act he defended in Why the Pope and his Recent Book are Burned and Assertions Concerning All Articles.
4 As a consequence Luther was excommunicated by Pope Leo X on 3 January 1521 in the bull Decet Romanum Pontificem.
5 When did the Pope warned Luther of excommunication?	15 June 1520	1
6 What did Luther need to do to avoid excommunication?	recanted 41 sentences	1
7 What was the time limit on Luthers recantation of sentences?	60 days	1
8 Who attempted to arrange a compromise?	Karl von Miltitz	3
9 When did Pope Leo X  excommunicate Luther?	3 January 1521	4
1 The enforcement of the ban on the 95 Theses fell to the secular authorities.
2 On 18 April 1521 Luther appeared as ordered before the Diet of Worms.
3 This was a general assembly of the estates of the Holy Roman Empire that took place in Worms a town on the Rhine.
4 It was conducted from 28 January to 25 May 1521 with Emperor Charles V presiding.
5 Prince Frederick III Elector of Saxony obtained a safe conduct for Luther to and from the meeting.
6 What authority enforced the ban on the 95 Theses?	secular authorities	1
7 When did Luther appeared before the Diet of Worms?	18 April 1521	2
8 Of what was the Diet of Worms an assembly?	estates of the Holy Roman Empire	3
9 Who presided over the assembly?	Emperor Charles V	4
10 Who got a safe conduct pass for Luther to come and leave the event?	Prince Frederick III	5
1 Johann Eck speaking on behalf of the Empire as assistant of the Archbishop of Trier presented Luther with copies of his writings laid out on a table and asked him if the books were his and whether he stood by their contents.
2 Luther confirmed he was their author but requested time to think about the answer to the second question.
3 He prayed consulted friends and gave his response the next day.
4 Who spoke to Luther about his books on behalf of the Empire?	Johann Eck	1
5 To whom was Johann Eck the assistant?	Archbishop of Trier	1
6 After asking if the books were his what else did Eck ask Luther?	stood by their contents	1
7 When did Luther give his response to Eck?	next day	3
8 How did Luther respond after being asked if the books were his?	confirmed	2
1 At the end of this speech Luther raised his arm in the traditional salute of a knight winning a bout.
2 Michael Mullett considers this speech as a world classic of epochmaking oratory.
3 What did Luther do at the end of his speech?	raised his arm	1
4 What was the style of Luthers salute at the end of his speech?	knight winning a bout	1
5 Who considers Luthers speech a world classic?	Michael Mullett	2
6 What did Michael Mullet call Luthers speech?	epochmaking oratory	2
1 Luther refused to recant his writings.
2 He is sometimes also quoted as saying Here I stand.
3 I can do no other.
4 Recent scholars consider the evidence for these words to be unreliable since they were inserted before May God help me only in later versions of the speech and not recorded in witness accounts of the proceedings.
5 However Mullett suggests that given his nature we are free to believe that Luther would tend to select the more dramatic form of words.
6 What did Luther refuse to do?	recant his writings	1
7 Who said Here I stand I can do no other?	Luther	1
8 Why is the statement doubtful in the eyes of scholars?	not recorded	4
9 What manner of words does Mullet think Luther would choose?	more dramatic form	5
1 Over the next five days private conferences were held to determine Luthers fate.
2 The Emperor presented the final draft of the Edict of Worms on 25 May 1521 declaring Luther an outlaw banning his literature and requiring his arrest We want him to be apprehended and punished as a notorious heretic.
3 It also made it a crime for anyone in Germany to give Luther food or shelter.
4 It permitted anyone to kill Luther without legal consequence.
5 How was the fate of Luther decided?	private conferences	1
6 When was the Edict of Worms presented?	25 May 1521	2
7 Who presented the Edict of Worms declaring Luther to be an outlaw?	Emperor	2
8 Besides declaring Luther to be an outlaw and banning his works what else was decided?	his arrest	2
9 What could anyone do to Martin Luther without legal consequence?	kill Luther	4
1 Luthers disappearance during his return trip back to Wittenberg was planned.
2 Frederick III had him intercepted on his way home in the forest near Wittenberg by masked horsemen who were made to appear as armed highwaymen.
3 They escorted Luther to the security of the Wartburg Castle at Eisenach.
4 During his stay at Wartburg which he referred to as my Patmos Luther translated the New Testament from Greek into German and poured out doctrinal and polemical writings.
5 These included a renewed attack on Archbishop Albrecht of Mainz whom he shamed into halting the sale of indulgences in his episcopates and a Refutation of the Argument of Latomus in which he expounded the principle of justification to Jacobus Latomus an orthodox theologian from Louvain.
6 What was planned for Luther by Frederick III after the meeting?	Luthers disappearance	1
7 Where did the highwaymen take Luther?	Wartburg Castle	3
8 What did Luther call his stay a Wartburg Castle?	my Patmos	4
9 What book did Luther translate into German at this time?	New Testament	4
10 How did Luther persuade Archbishop Albrecht to stop the sale of indulgences?	shamed	5
1 In this work one of his most emphatic statements on faith he argued that every good work designed to attract Gods favor is a sin.
2 All humans are sinners by nature he explained and Gods grace which cannot be earned alone can make them just.
3 On 1 August 1521 Luther wrote to Melanchthon on the same theme Be a sinner and let your sins be strong but let your trust in Christ be stronger and rejoice in Christ who is the victor over sin death and the world.
4 We will commit sins while we are here for this life is not a place where justice resides.
5 What did Luther call good works that existed solely to attract Gods favor?	a sin	1
6 What did Luther explain about acquiring Gods grace?	cannot be earned	2
7 When did Luther write to Melanchhon about Gods grace?	1 August 1521	3
8 What did Luther expound to be greater than sin?	trust in Christ	3
9 What does Luther write that this life doesnt have?	justice	4
1 In the summer of 1521 Luther widened his target from individual pieties like indulgences and pilgrimages to doctrines at the heart of Church practices.
2 In On the Abrogation of the Private Mass he condemned as idolatry the idea that the mass is a sacrifice asserting instead that it is a gift to be received with thanksgiving by the whole congregation.
3 His essay On Confession Whether the Pope has the Power to Require It rejected compulsory confession and encouraged private confession and absolution since every Christian is a confessor.
4 In November Luther wrote The Judgement of Martin Luther on Monastic Vows.
5 He assured monks and nuns that they could break their vows without sin because vows were an illegitimate and vain attempt to win salvation.
6 When did Luther broaden his attacks to include core Church doctrines?	summer of 1521	1
7 How did Luther describe the mass that was viewed as sacrifice?	condemned as idolatry	2
8 What did Luther call the mass instead of sacrifice?	a gift	2
9 After rejecting compulsory confession what did Luther call for?	private confession and absolution	3
10 What did Luther tell monks and nuns about their vows?	break their vows	5
1 In 1521 Luther dealt largely with prophecy in which he broadened the foundations of the Reformation placing them on prophetic faith.
2 His main interest was centered on the prophecy of the Little Horn in Daniel 89–12 23–25.
3 The antichrist of 2 Thessalonians 2 was identified as the power of the Papacy.
4 So too was the Little Horn of Daniel 7 coming up among the divisions of Rome explicitly applied.
5 How did Luther broaden the Reformation in terms of prophecy?	prophetic faith	1
6 When did Luther start preaching Prophetic faith?	1521	1
7 At this time where was Luthers focus centered?	Daniel 89–12  23–25	2
8 What is the prophecy in Daniel that interested Luther?	the Little Horn	2
9 What did Luther identify the Papacy as?	antichrist	3
1 Luther made his pronouncements from Wartburg in the context of rapid developments at Wittenberg of which he was kept fully informed.
2 Andreas Karlstadt supported by the exAugustinian Gabriel Zwilling embarked on a radical programme of reform there in June 1521 exceeding anything envisaged by Luther.
3 The reforms provoked disturbances including a revolt by the Augustinian friars against their prior the smashing of statues and images in churches and denunciations of the magistracy.
4 After secretly visiting Wittenberg in early December 1521 Luther wrote A Sincere Admonition by Martin Luther to All Christians to Guard Against Insurrection and Rebellion.
5 Wittenberg became even more volatile after Christmas when a band of visionary zealots the socalled Zwickau prophets arrived preaching revolutionary doctrines such as the equality of man adult baptism and Christs imminent return.
6 When the town council asked Luther to return he decided it was his duty to act.
7 Who supported Andreas Karistadt in reform at Wittenberg?	Gabriel Zwilling	2
8 When did Zwilling and Karistadt become active at Wittenberg?	June 1521	2
9 What did the reforms cause?	disturbances	3
10 What group was responsible for causing more violence in Wittenberg?	Zwickau prophets	5
11 Who asked Luther to return to the city?	town council	6
1 Luther secretly returned to Wittenberg on 6 March 1522.
2 He wrote to the Elector During my absence Satan has entered my sheepfold and committed ravages which I cannot repair by writing but only by my personal presence and living word.
3 For eight days in Lent beginning on Invocavit Sunday 9 March Luther preached eight sermons which became known as the Invocavit Sermons.
4 In these sermons he hammered home the primacy of core Christian values such as love patience charity and freedom and reminded the citizens to trust Gods word rather than violence to bring about necessary change.
5 When did Luther return to Wittenberg?	6 March 1522	1
6 What did Luther think was required to stop the violence?	personal presence	2
7 What did Luther do during Lent at this time?	preached eight sermons	3
8 What are the eight sermons called that Luther preached in March 1522?	Invocavit Sermons	3
9 How did Luther want people to bring about change?	trust Gods word	4
1 The effect of Luthers intervention was immediate.
2 After the sixth sermon the Wittenberg jurist Jerome Schurf wrote to the elector Oh what joy has Dr Martins return spread among us.
3 His words through divine mercy are bringing back every day misguided people into the way of the truth.
4 How quick was the effect of Luthers preaching?	immediate	1
5 Who wrote a resounding letter to the elector praising Luther?	Jerome Schurf	2
6 At what point in Luthers sermons did Schurf write to the elector?	After the sixth sermon	2
7 What did Schurfs letter say  Luthers return caused?	joy	2
8 What type of people were being brought back to the way of truth?	misguided	3
1 Luther next set about reversing or modifying the new church practices.
2 By working alongside the authorities to restore public order he signalled his reinvention as a conservative force within the Reformation.
3 After banishing the Zwickau prophets he now faced a battle against not only the established Church but also the radical reformers who threatened the new order by fomenting social unrest and violence.
4 What did Luther seek to restore?	public order	2
5 What was Luthers force within the Reformation?	conservative	2
6 Who did Luther banish?	Zwickau prophets	3
7 What did the radical reformers cause in the new order?	unrest and violence	3
8 Besides the radicals who else did Luther have to deal with?	established Church	3
1 Despite his victory in Wittenberg Luther was unable to stifle radicalism further afield.
2 Preachers such as Zwickau prophet Nicholas Storch and Thomas Müntzer helped instigate the German Peasants War of 1524–25 during which many atrocities were committed often in Luthers name.
3 There had been revolts by the peasantry on a smaller scale since the 15th century.
4 Luthers pamphlets against the Church and the hierarchy often worded with liberal phraseology now led many peasants to believe he would support an attack on the upper classes in general.
5 Revolts broke out in Franconia Swabia and Thuringia in 1524 even drawing support from disaffected nobles many of whom were in debt.
6 Gaining momentum under the leadership of radicals such as Müntzer in Thuringia and Michael Gaismair in Tyrol the revolts turned into war.
7 What was Nicholas Storch ?	Zwickau prophet	2
8 What event did Storch and Muntzer help instigate?	German Peasants War	2
9 When did The German Peasants War happen?	1524–25	2
10 What did the peasants believe Luther would do for them?	support an attack	4
11 Who did the peasants think Luther would support an attack on?	upper classes	4
1 Luther sympathised with some of the peasants grievances as he showed in his response to the Twelve Articles in May 1525 but he reminded the aggrieved to obey the temporal authorities.
2 During a tour of Thuringia he became enraged at the widespread burning of convents monasteries bishops palaces and libraries.
3 In Against the Murderous Thieving Hordes of Peasants written on his return to Wittenberg he gave his interpretation of the Gospel teaching on wealth condemned the violence as the devils work and called for the nobles to put down the rebels like mad dogs.
4 Who did Luther remind the peasants to obey?	temporal authorities	1
5 Where did Luther become angry at the widespread destruction of church property?	tour of Thuringia	2
6 What did Luther call the revolting peasants?	mad dogs	3
7 How did Luther express the destruction?	the devils work	3
8 Who did Luther call on to stop the revolt?	the nobles	3
1 Luther justified his opposition to the rebels on three grounds.
2 First in choosing violence over lawful submission to the secular government they were ignoring Christs counsel to Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesars St Paul had written in his epistle to the Romans 131–7 that all authorities are appointed by God and therefore should not be resisted.
3 This reference from the Bible forms the foundation for the doctrine known as the Divine Right of Kings or in the German case the divine right of the princes.
4 Second the violent actions of rebelling robbing and plundering placed the peasants outside the law of God and Empire so they deserved death in body and soul if only as highwaymen and murderers.
5 Lastly Luther charged the rebels with blasphemy for calling themselves Christian brethren and committing their sinful acts under the banner of the Gospel.
6 How many ways did Luther justify his opposition to revolt?	on three grounds	1
7 What were the protesters doing with Christs counsel?	ignoring Christs counsel	2
8 By whom did St Paul say all authorities were appointed?	God	2
9 What is this doctrine of God appointing authorities called?	Divine Right of Kings	3
10 What kind of death did Luther say the revolting peasants deserve?	in body and soul	4
1 Without Luthers backing for the uprising many rebels laid down their weapons others felt betrayed.
2 Their defeat by the Swabian League at the Battle of Frankenhausen on 15 May 1525 followed by Müntzers execution brought the revolutionary stage of the Reformation to a close.
3 Thereafter radicalism found a refuge in the anabaptist movement and other religious movements while Luthers Reformation flourished under the wing of the secular powers.
4 What did Luther deny the rebels?	backing for the uprising	1
5 Who defeated the rebels at the Battle of Frankenhausen?	Swabian League	2
6 When was the Battle of Frankenhausen?	15 May 1525	2
7 What event followed the battle?	Müntzers execution	2
8 What protection caused Luthers Reformation to flourish?	the secular powers	3
1 Martin Luther married Katharina von Bora one of 12 nuns he had helped escape from the Nimbschen Cistercian convent in April 1523 when he arranged for them to be smuggled out in herring barrels.
2 Suddenly and while I was occupied with far different thoughts he wrote to Wenceslaus Link the Lord has plunged me into marriage.
3 At the time of their marriage Katharina was 26 years old and Luther was 41 years old.
4 Who did Martin Luther marry?	Katharina von Bora	1
5 How did Luther smuggle 12 nuns out of a convent during the rebellion?	in herring barrels	1
6 How old was Katharina when she married Luther?	26 years old	3
7 How old was Martin Luther when he married?	41 years old	3
8 When did Luther save the group of nuns from the convent?	April 1523	1
1 On 13 June 1525 the couple was engaged with Johannes Bugenhagen Justus Jonas Johannes Apel Philipp Melanchthon and Lucas Cranach the Elder and his wife as witnesses.
2 On the evening of the same day the couple was married by Bugenhagen.
3 The ceremonial walk to the church and the wedding banquet were left out and were made up two weeks later on 27 June.
4 When were Luther and his prospective bride engaged?	13 June 1525	1
5 At what point in the day was the couple married?	evening	2
6 Besides the walk to the church what else was left out of the days celebration?	wedding banquet	3
7 When was the wedding banquet celebrated?	27 June	3
8 Who married the wedding couple?	Johannes Bugenhagen	1
1 Some priests and former religious had already married including Andreas Karlstadt and Justus Jonas but Luthers wedding set the seal of approval on clerical marriage.
2 He had long condemned vows of celibacy on Biblical grounds but his decision to marry surprised many not least Melanchthon who called it reckless.
3 Luther had written to George Spalatin on 30 November 1524 I shall never take a wife as I feel at present.
4 Not that I am insensible to my flesh or sex for I am neither wood nor stone but my mind is averse to wedlock because I daily expect the death of a heretic.
5 Before marrying Luther had been living on the plainest food and as he admitted himself his mildewed bed was not properly made for months at a time.
6 What was Luthers marriage seen as by others?	seal of approval	1
7 What kind of marriage was this ?	clerical marriage	1
8 Why did Luther condemn vows of celibacy?	on Biblical grounds	2
9 What did Luther fear to cause him to avoid marriage?	death of a heretic	4
10 What did Melanchthon call the marriage?	reckless	2
1 Luther and his wife moved into a former monastery The Black Cloister a wedding present from the new elector John the Steadfast 1525–32.
2 They embarked on what appeared to have been a happy and successful marriage though money was often short.
3 Between bearing six children Hans – June 1526 Elizabeth – 10 December 1527 who died within a few months Magdalene – 1529 who died in Luthers arms in 1542 Martin – 1531 Paul – January 1533 and Margaret – 1534 Katharina helped the couple earn a living by farming the land and taking in boarders.
4 Luther confided to Michael Stiefel on 11 August 1526 My Katie is in all things so obliging and pleasing to me that I would not exchange my poverty for the riches of Croesus.
5 When did Luther and his wife live?	The Black Cloister	1
6 What was the Black Cloister?	former monastery	1
7 How many children did Luther and his wife have?	six children	3
8 What did Luther state he would not exchange for his life with his wife?	riches of Croesus	4
9 Besides taking in boarders how did Katharina help support the family?	farming the land	3
1 By 1526 Luther found himself increasingly occupied in organising a new church.
2 His Biblical ideal of congregations choosing their own ministers had proved unworkable.
3 According to Bainton Luthers dilemma was that he wanted both a confessional church based on personal faith and experience and a territorial church including all in a given locality.
4 If he were forced to choose he would take his stand with the masses and this was the direction in which he moved.
5 From 1525 to 1529 he established a supervisory church body laid down a new form of worship service and wrote a clear summary of the new faith in the form of two catechisms.
6 Luthers thought is revolutionary to the extent that it is a theology of the cross the negation of every affirmation as long as the cross is at the center the system building tendency of reason is held in check and system building does not degenerate into System.
7 In organizing a new church what did Luther find to be unworkable for congregations?	choosing their own ministers	2
8 What did Luther form in 1525 to 1529?	supervisory church body	5
9 What did Luther establish as a worship service in his church?	new form	5
10 What did Luther write as an outline of the new faith?	two catechisms	5
11 What is Luthers thought about the extent of his church?	revolutionary	6
1 To avoid confusing or upsetting the people Luther avoided extreme change.
2 He also did not wish to replace one controlling system with another.
3 He concentrated on the church in the Electorate of Saxony acting only as an adviser to churches in new territories many of which followed his Saxon model.
4 He worked closely with the new elector John the Steadfast to whom he turned for secular leadership and funds on behalf of a church largely shorn of its assets and income after the break with Rome.
5 For Luthers biographer Martin Brecht this partnership was the beginning of a questionable and originally unintended development towards a church government under the temporal sovereign.
6 The elector authorised a visitation of the church a power formerly exercised by bishops.
7 At times Luthers practical reforms fell short of his earlier radical pronouncements.
8 For example the Instructions for the Visitors of Parish Pastors in Electoral Saxony 1528 drafted by Melanchthon with Luthers approval stressed the role of repentance in the forgiveness of sins despite Luthers position that faith alone ensures justification.
9 The Eisleben reformer Johannes Agricola challenged this compromise and Luther condemned him for teaching that faith is separate from works.
10 The Instruction is a problematic document for those seeking a consistent evolution in Luthers thought and practice.
11 What did Luther try to avoid in setting up his church?	extreme change	1
12 Where was Luther mostly concentrating his efforts on reform?	Electorate of Saxony	3
13 What role did Luther play in other areas churches?	adviser	3
14 Who was the new elector of Saxony?	John the Steadfast	4
15 What unintended development did the relationship with the elector have on church government?	under the temporal sovereign	5
1 In response to demands for a German liturgy Luther wrote a German Mass which he published in early 1526.
2 He did not intend it as a replacement for his 1523 adaptation of the Latin Mass but as an alternative for the simple people a public stimulation for people to believe and become Christians.
3 Luther based his order on the Catholic service but omitted everything that smacks of sacrifice and the Mass became a celebration where everyone received the wine as well as the bread.
4 He retained the elevation of the host and chalice while trappings such as the Mass vestments altar and candles were made optional allowing freedom of ceremony.
5 Some reformers including followers of Huldrych Zwingli considered Luthers service too papistic and modern scholars note the conservatism of his alternative to the Catholic mass.
6 Luthers service however included congregational singing of hymns and psalms in German as well as of parts of the liturgy including Luthers unison setting of the Creed.
7 To reach the simple people and the young Luther incorporated religious instruction into the weekday services in the form of the catechism.
8 He also provided simplified versions of the baptism and marriage services.
9 When did Luther write  a German mass?	early 1526	1
10 What did Luther not mean for the new mass to replace?	1523 adaptation of the Latin Mass	2
11 For whom was this new mass intended?	simple people	2
12 What parts of the original Catholic mass did Luther leave out of  his new mass?	sacrifice	3
13 What did the new mass allow as regards ceremony?	freedom of ceremony	4
1 Luther and his colleagues introduced the new order of worship during their visitation of the Electorate of Saxony which began in 1527.
2 They also assessed the standard of pastoral care and Christian education in the territory.
3 Merciful God what misery I have seen Luther wrote the common people knowing nothing at all of Christian doctrine  and unfortunately many pastors are wellnigh unskilled and incapable of teaching.
4 When did Luther introduce the new worship?	1527	1
5 What began in 1527 when Luther introdued the new order of worship?	visitation of the Electorate	1
6 What type of education was assessed during this time?	Christian education	2
7 What did Luther say the common people knew nothing about?	Christian doctrine	3
8 What were many pastors unable to do?	incapable of teaching	3
1 Luther devised the catechism as a method of imparting the basics of Christianity to the congregations.
2 In 1529 he wrote the Large Catechism a manual for pastors and teachers as well as a synopsis the Small Catechism to be memorised by the people themselves.
3 The catechisms provided easytounderstand instructional and devotional material on the Ten Commandments the Apostles Creed the Lords Prayer baptism and the Lords Supper.
4 Luther incorporated questions and answers in the catechism so that the basics of Christian faith would not just be learned by rote the way monkeys do it but understood.
5 What did Luther devise to teach  Christianity to the congregation?	catechism	1
6 When did Luther write the Large Catechism?	1529	2
7 To whom was the Large Catechism directed?	pastors and teachers	2
8 For whom was the Small Catechism meant?	the people	2
9 What did Luther add to his catechisms?	questions and answers	4
1 The catechism is one of Luthers most personal works.
2 Regarding the plan to collect my writings in volumes he wrote I am quite cool and not at all eager about it because roused by a Saturnian hunger I would rather see them all devoured.
3 For I acknowledge none of them to be really a book of mine except perhaps the Bondage of the Will and the Catechism.
4 The Small Catechism has earned a reputation as a model of clear religious teaching.
5 It remains in use today along with Luthers hymns and his translation of the Bible.
6 What was one of Luthers most personal writings?	The catechism	1
7 What effort was Luther not particularly in favor of?	writings in volumes	2
8 Besides the Bondage of the Will what other work did Luther view as a book of his?	the Catechism	3
9 What work of Luthers is seen as a clear religious teaching?	Small Catechism	4
10 What translation of Luthers is still used today?	the Bible	5
1 Luthers Small Catechism proved especially effective in helping parents teach their children likewise the Larger Catechism was effective for pastors.
2 Using the German vernacular they expressed the Apostles Creed in simpler more personal Trinitarian language.
3 He rewrote each article of the Creed to express the character of the Father the Son or the Holy Spirit.
4 Luthers goal was to enable the catechumens to see themselves as a personal object of the work of the three persons of the Trinity each of which works in the catechumens life.
5 That is Luther depicted the Trinity not as a doctrine to be learned but as persons to be known.
6 The Father creates the Son redeems and the Spirit sanctifies a divine unity with separate personalities.
7 Salvation originates with the Father and draws the believer to the Father.
8 Luthers treatment of the Apostles Creed must be understood in the context of the Decalogue the Ten Commandments and the Lords Prayer which are also part of the Lutheran catechical teaching.
9 Which work of Luthers is effective in teaching children?	Small Catechism	1
10 What work is useful for pastors?	Larger Catechism	1
11 What are the Catechisms of Martin Luther written in?	German vernacular	2
12 How did Luther show the Trinity in his catechisms?	as persons	5
13 Where does Luther place Salvation?	with the Father	7
1 Luther had published his German translation of the New Testament in 1522 and he and his collaborators completed the translation of the Old Testament in 1534 when the whole Bible was published.
2 He continued to work on refining the translation until the end of his life.
3 Others had translated the Bible into German but Luther tailored his translation to his own doctrine.
4 When he was criticised for inserting the word alone after faith in Romans 328 he replied in part The text itself and the meaning of St Paul urgently require and demand it.
5 For in that very passage he is dealing with the main point of Christian doctrine namely that we are justified by faith in Christ without any works of the Law.
6 .
7 But when works are so completely cut away – and that must mean that faith alone justifies – whoever would speak plainly and clearly about this cutting away of works will have to say Faith alone justifies us and not works.
8 When did Martin Luther publish his translation of the New Testament?	1522	1
9 When was the Old Testament translation finished?	1534	1
10 What did he work on refining until the end of his life?	the translation	2
11 What word was Luther criticized for adding in Romans328?	alone	4
12 According to Luther what justifies us?	Faith alone	7
1 Luthers translation used the variant of German spoken at the Saxon chancellery intelligible to both northern and southern Germans.
2 He intended his vigorous direct language to make the Bible accessible to everyday Germans for we are removing impediments and difficulties so that other people may read it without hindrance.
3 Where was the language Luther used in his translations spoken?	Saxon chancellery	1
4 Which Germans could understand the language Luther used?	northern and southern	1
5 What group did Luther want to understand his works?	everyday Germans	2
6 Why did he want to make the language accessible to people?	read it without hindrance	2
7 To promote accessibility of the works what did Luther remove?	impediments and difficulties	2
1 Published at a time of rising demand for Germanlanguage publications Luthers version quickly became a popular and influential Bible translation.
2 As such it made a significant contribution to the evolution of the German language and literature.
3 Furnished with notes and prefaces by Luther and with woodcuts by Lucas Cranach that contained antipapal imagery it played a major role in the spread of Luthers doctrine throughout Germany.
4 The Luther Bible influenced other vernacular translations such as William Tyndales English Bible 1525 forward a precursor of the King James Bible.
5 At the time of Martin Luther what was in demand?	Germanlanguage publications	1
6 What work of Luthers became popular?	Bible translation	1
7 What did the popularity of Luthers translation contribute to?	evolution of the German language	2
8 What artist provided the woodcuts for Luthers Bible?	Lucas Cranach	3
9 Whose English translation of the Bible did the Luther Bible influence?	William Tyndale	4
1 Luther was a prolific hymnwriter authoring hymns such as Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott A Mighty Fortress Is Our God based on Psalm 46 and Vom Himmel hoch da komm ich her From Heaven Above to Earth I Come based on Luke 211–12.
2 Luther connected high art and folk music also all classes clergy and laity men women and children.
3 His tool of choice for this connection was the singing of German hymns in connection with worship school home and the public arena.
4 He often accompanied the sung hymns with a lute later recreated as the waldzither that became a national instrument of Germany in the 20th century.
5 In what type of work was Luther prolific?	authoring hymns	1
6 What art forms did Luther use to connect his hymns?	high art and folk music	2
7 What did Luther use to celebrate worship?	singing of German hymns	3
8 What did Luther use as accompaniment to his hymns?	lute	4
9 What instrument became a national instrument in Germany?	waldzither	4
1 Luthers hymns were frequently evoked by particular events in his life and the unfolding Reformation.
2 This behavior started with his learning of the execution of Johann Esch and Heinrich Voes the first individuals to be martyred by the Roman Catholic Church for Lutheran views prompting Luther to write the hymn Ein neues Lied wir heben an A new song we raise which is generally known in English by John C Messengers translation by the title and first line Flung to the Heedless Winds and sung to the tune Ibstone composed in 1875 by Maria C Tiddeman.
3 What caused Luther to write hymns?	events in his life	1
4 Why were Johann Esch and Heinrich Voes executed by the Catholic Church?	for Lutheran views	2
5 What hymn did Luther write after the martyrdom of Esch and Voes?	Ein neues Lied wir heben an	2
6 Who is the English translator of this hymn?	John C Messenger	2
7 What is the hymn known as in English?	Flung to the Heedless Winds	2
1 Luthers 1524 creedal hymn Wir glauben all an einen Gott We All Believe in One True God is a threestanza confession of faith prefiguring Luthers 1529 threepart explanation of the Apostles Creed in the Small Catechism.
2 Luthers hymn adapted and expanded from an earlier German creedal hymn gained widespread use in vernacular Lutheran liturgies as early as 1525.
3 Sixteenthcentury Lutheran hymnals also included Wir glauben all among the catechetical hymns although 18thcentury hymnals tended to label the hymn as Trinitarian rather than catechetical and 20thcentury Lutherans rarely use the hymn because of the perceived difficulty of its tune.
4 When did Luther write Wir glauben all an einen Gott?	1524	1
5 What did this hymn presage?	Apostles Creed	1
6 Where is the Apostles located?	Small Catechism	1
7 What earlier hymn was Luthers  adapted from?	German creedal hymn	2
8 Why have modern Lutherans stopped using the hymn?	difficulty of its tune	3
1 Luthers 1538 hymnic version of the Lords Prayer Vater unser im Himmelreich corresponds exactly to Luthers explanation of the prayer in the Small Catechism with one stanza for each of the seven prayer petitions plus opening and closing stanzas.
2 The hymn functioned both as a liturgical setting of the Lords Prayer and as a means of examining candidates on specific catechism questions.
3 The extant manuscript shows multiple revisions demonstrating Luthers concern to clarify and strengthen the text and to provide an appropriately prayerful tune.
4 Other 16th and 20thcentury versifications of the Lords Prayer have adopted Luthers tune although modern texts are considerably shorter.
5 When did Luther produce a hymnic version of the Lords Prayer?	1538	1
6 Where is the comparison found of this Lords Prayer hymn?	Small Catechism	1
7 What was the hymn meant to examine students on?	specific catechism questions	2
8 What does the original manuscript show?	multiple revisions	3
9 What do later versions of the Lords Prayer hymn still use?	Luthers tune	4
1 Luther wrote Aus tiefer Not schrei ich zu dir From depths of woe I cry to you in 1523 as a hymnic version of Psalm 130 and sent it as a sample to encourage evangelical colleagues to write psalmhymns for use in German worship.
2 In a collaboration with Paul Speratus this and seven other hymns were published in the Achtliederbuch the first Lutheran hymnal.
3 In 1524 Luther developed his original fourstanza psalm paraphrase into a fivestanza Reformation hymn that developed the theme of grace alone more fully.
4 Because it expressed essential Reformation doctrine this expanded version of Aus tiefer Not was designated as a regular component of several regional Lutheran liturgies and was widely used at funerals including Luthers own.
5 Along with Erhart Hegenwalts hymnic version of Psalm 51 Luthers expanded hymn was also adopted for use with the fifth part of Luthers catechism concerning confession.
6 When did Luther write the hymn From Depths of Woe I cry to You?	1523	1
7 What is the basis of the hymn?	Psalm 130	1
8 What did Luther use the hymn to encourage colleagues to do?	write psalmhymns	1
9 What was the first Lutheran hymnal?	Achtliederbuch	2
10 What did the hymn Aus tiefer Not express?	Reformation doctrine	4
1 Luther wrote Ach Gott vom Himmel sieh darein Oh God look down from heaven.
2 Nun komm der Heiden Heiland Now come Savior of the gentiles based on Veni redemptor gentium became the main hymn Hauptlied for Advent.
3 He transformed A solus ortus cardine to Christum wir sollen loben schon We should now praise Christ and Veni Creator Spiritus to Komm Gott Schöpfer Heiliger Geist Come Holy Spirit Lord God.
4 He wrote two hymns on the Ten Commandments Dies sind die heilgen Zehn Gebot and Mensch willst du leben seliglich.
5 His Gelobet seist du Jesu Christ Praise be to You Jesus Christ became the main hymn for Christmas.
6 He wrote for Pentecost Nun bitten wir den Heiligen Geist and adopted for Easter Christ ist erstanden Christ is risen based on Victimae paschali laudes.
7 Mit Fried und Freud ich fahr dahin a paraphrase of Nunc dimittis was intended for Purification but became also a funeral hymn.
8 He paraphrased the Te Deum as Herr Gott dich loben wir with a simplified form of the melody.
9 It became known as the German Te Deum.
10 Which of Luthers hymn was the main one for Advent?	Nun komm  der Heiden Heiland	2
11 What was the hymn based on?	Veni redemptor gentium	2
12 What is a Hauptlied?	main hymn	2
13 How many hymns did Luther write based on the Ten Commandments?	two hymns	4
14 What did Herr Gott dich loben wir become known as ?	German Te Deum	9
1 Luthers 1541 hymn Christ unser Herr zum Jordan kam To Jordan came the Christ our Lord reflects the structure and substance of his questions and answers concerning baptism in the Small Catechism.
2 Luther adopted a preexisting Johann Walter tune associated with a hymnic setting of Psalm 67s prayer for grace Wolf Heintzs fourpart setting of the hymn was used to introduce the Lutheran Reformation in Halle in 1541.
3 Preachers and composers of the 18th century including J S Bach used this rich hymn as a subject for their own work although its objective baptismal theology was displaced by more subjective hymns under the influence of late19thcentury Lutheran pietism.
4 What does Luthers hymn Christ unser Herr zum jordan kam concern?	baptism	1
5 Whose tune did Luther adapt for the hymn of Psalm 67?	Johann Walter	2
6 What is Psalm 67 about?	prayer for grace	2
7 What famous composer used a Lutheran hymn in his work?	J S Bach	3
8 Where was the baptismal hymn used to introduce the Reformation?	Halle	2
1 Luthers hymns were included in early Lutheran hymnals and spread the ideas of the Reformation.
2 He supplied four of eight songs of the First Lutheran hymnal Achtliederbuch 18 of 26 songs of the Erfurt Enchiridion and 24 of the 32 songs in the first choral hymnal with settings by Johann Walter Eyn geystlich Gesangk Buchleyn all published in 1524.
3 Where were Luthers hymns included?	early Lutheran hymnals	1
4 How many hymns of Luther were included in the Achtliederbuch?	four	2
5 How many hymns did Luther contribute to the Erfurt Enchiridion?	18	2
6 How many hymns did Luther write for the first choral hymnal?	24	2
7 What was the title of the first choral hymnal?	Eyn geystlich Gesangk Buchleyn	2
1 Luthers hymns inspired composers to write music.
2 Johann Sebastian Bach included several verses as chorales in his cantatas and based chorale cantatas entirely on them namely Christ lag in Todes Banden BWV 4 as early as possibly 1707 in his second annual cycle 1724 to 1725 Ach Gott vom Himmel sieh darein BWV 2 Christ unser Herr zum Jordan kam BWV 7 Nun komm der Heiden Heiland BWV 62 Gelobet seist du Jesu Christ BWV 91 and Aus tiefer Not schrei ich zu dir BWV 38 later Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott BWV 80 and in 1735 Wär Gott nicht mit uns diese Zeit BWV 14.
3 What composer used Luthers hymns in his works?	Johann Sebastian Bach	2
4 What did Bach base entirely on Luther chorales?	chorale cantatas	2
5 What is the earliest that Bach began using Luther hymns?	1707	2
6 In what years did Bach use more of Luthers hymns in his compositions?	1724 to 1725	2
7 When was the last use by Bach of Luthers work?	1735	2
1 In contrast to the views of John Calvin and Philipp Melanchthon throughout his life Luther maintained that it was not false doctrine to believe that a Christians soul sleeps after it is separated from the body in death and accordingly he disputed traditional interpretations of some Bible passages such as the parable of the rich man and Lazarus.
2 This also led Luther to reject the idea of torments for the saints It is enough for us to know that souls do not leave their bodies to be threatened by the torments and punishments of hell but enter a prepared bedchamber in which they sleep in peace.
3 He also rejected the existence of Purgatory which involved Christian souls undergoing penitential suffering after death.
4 He affirmed the continuity of ones personal identity beyond death.
5 In his Smalcald Articles he described the saints as currently residing in their graves and in heaven.
6 What did Luther believe that the soul does after death?	sleeps	1
7 What other doctrines did Luther disavow about saints?	idea of torments	2
8 What did Luther expound happened to souls after death?	sleep in peace	2
9 What did Luther think of Purgatory?	rejected the existence	3
10 Where did Luther describe the resting place of the saints?	Smalcald Articles	5
1 The Lutheran theologian Franz Pieper observed that Luthers teaching about the state of the Christians soul after death differed from the later Lutheran theologians such as Johann Gerhard.
2 Lessing 1755 had earlier reached the same conclusion in his analysis of Lutheran orthodoxy on this issue.
3 Who noticed that Luthers view of the soul after death differed from later theologians?	Franz Pieper	1
4 What theologian differed in views about the soul from Luther?	Johann Gerhard	1
5 Who else observed that Luther view of souls was different form later views?	Gerhard Lessing	1
6 When did Gerhard Lessing reach his conclusions about Luther?	1755	2
1 Luthers Commentary on Genesis contains a passage which concludes that the soul does not sleep anima non sic dormit but wakes sed vigilat and experiences visions.
2 Francis Blackburne in 1765 argued that John Jortin misread this and other passages from Luther while Gottfried Fritschel pointed out in 1867 that it actually refers to the soul of a man in this life homo enim in hac vita tired from his daily labour defatigus diurno labore who at night enters his bedchamber sub noctem intrat in cubiculum suum and whose sleep is interrupted by dreams.
3 Where did Luther say that the soul doesnt sleep but rather has visions?	Commentary on Genesis	1
4 Who stated that John Jortin misunderstood Luther?	Francis Blackburne	2
5 When did Blackburne make his argument about Luther and souls?	1765	2
6 Who pointed out that the passage under dispute actually refers to a living man?	Gottfried Fritschel	2
7 What did Fritschel say the mans sleep was disturbed by?	dreams	2
1 In October 1529 Philip I Landgrave of Hesse convoked an assembly of German and Swiss theologians at the Marburg Colloquy to establish doctrinal unity in the emerging Protestant states.
2 Agreement was achieved on fourteen points out of fifteen the exception being the nature of the Eucharist – the sacrament of the Lords Supper—an issue crucial to Luther.
3 When did Philip I convene an assembly to set doctrine in the Protestant states?	October 1529	1
4 Who was Philip I?	Landgrave of Hesse	1
5 What was the Marburg Colloquy meant to establish?	doctrinal unity	1
6 How many of the fifteen points of discussion were agreed on?	fourteen points	2
7 What one point was not agreed on that was dear to Luther?	nature of the Eucharist	2
1 The theologians including Zwingli Melanchthon Martin Bucer and Johannes Oecolampadius differed on the significance of the words spoken by Jesus at the Last Supper This is my body which is for you and This cup is the new covenant in my blood 1 Corinthians 1123–26.
2 Luther insisted on the Real Presence of the body and blood of Christ in the consecrated bread and wine which he called the sacramental union while his opponents believed God to be only spiritually or symbolically present.
