3 Zwingli for example denied Jesus ability to be in more than one place at a time but Luther stressed the omnipresence of his human nature.
4 According to transcripts the debate sometimes became confrontational.
5 Citing Jesus words The flesh profiteth nothing John 663 Zwingli said This passage breaks your neck.
6 Dont be too proud Luther retorted German necks dont break that easily.
7 This is Hesse not Switzerland.
8 On his table Luther wrote the words Hoc est corpus meum This is my body in chalk to continually indicate his firm stance.
9 What point did the theologians differ on concerning the Last Supper?	words spoken by Jesus	1
10 What did Luther insist was present in the bread and wine?	body and blood of Christ	2
11 What did Luther call  the consecrated bread and wine?	sacramental union	2
12 What did Luthers opponents think that it meant about Gods presence?	symbolically present	2
13 What did the meeting often become in argument?	confrontational	4
1 Despite the disagreements on the Eucharist the Marburg Colloquy paved the way for the signing in 1530 of the Augsburg Confession and for the formation of the Schmalkaldic League the following year by leading Protestant nobles such as John of Saxony Philip of Hesse and George Margrave of BrandenburgAnsbach.
2 The Swiss cities however did not sign these agreements.
3 When was the Augsburg Confession signed?	1530	1
4 What paved the way for the Augsburg Confession?	Marburg Colloquy	1
5 What did Protestant nobles form the following year after the signing of the Augsburg Confession?	Schmalkaldic League	1
6 Which group did not agree to sign these agreements?	The Swiss cities	2
7 What ruler besides John of Saxony and Philip of Hesse formed the Schmalkaldic League?	George  Margrave of BrandenburgAnsbach	1
1 Some scholars have asserted that Luther taught that faith and reason were antithetical in the sense that questions of faith could not be illuminated by reason.
2 He wrote All the articles of our Christian faith which God has revealed to us in His Word are in presence of reason sheerly impossible absurd and false.
3 and That Reason in no way contributes to faith.
4  For reason is the greatest enemy that faith has it never comes to the aid of spiritual things.
5 However though seemingly contradictorily he also wrote in the latter work that human reason strives not against faith when enlightened but rather furthers and advances it bringing claims he was a fideist into dispute.
6 Contemporary Lutheran scholarship however has found a different reality in Luther.
7 Luther rather seeks to separate faith and reason in order to honor the separate spheres of knowledge that each applies to.
8 Bernhard Lohse for example has demonstrated in his classic work Fides und Ratio that Luther ultimately sought to put the two together.
9 More recently HansPeter Grosshans has demonstrated that Luthers work on Biblical Criticism stresses the need for external coherence in the right exegetical method.
10 This means that for Luther it is more important that the Bible is reasonable according to the reality outside of the scriptures than that the Bible makes sense to itself that it has internal coherence.
11 The right tool for understanding the world outside of the Bible for Luther is none other than reason which for him is the field of science philosophy history and empirical observation.
12 Here a different picture is presented of a Luther who deeply valued both faith and reason and held them in dialectical partnership.
13 Luthers concern thus in separating them is honoring their different epistemological spheres.
14 What do scholars sometimes assert that Luther believed about what faith and reason were to each other?	antithetical	1
15 What did Luther think that faith could not be understood by?	reason	1
16 How did Luther say that reason contributes to faith?	no way contributes	3
17 What was faiths greatest enemy according to Luther?	reason	4
18 By separating faith and reason what does Luther honor?	different epistemological spheres	13
1 In 1523 Luther wrote that Jesus Christ was born a Jew which discouraged mistreatment of the Jews and advocated their conversion by proving that the Old Testament could be shown to speak of Jesus Christ.
2 However as the Reformation continued Luther began to lose hope in largescale Jewish conversion to Christianity.
3 In his later years Luther grew more hostile toward the Jews writing against them with the kind of venom he had already unleashed on the Anabaptists Zwinglianism and the papacy.
4 His 1543 treatise Von den Juden und ihren Lügen On the Jews and Their Lies took its place among other antiJewish literature of the times although historians acknowledge that this treatise was particularly extreme even by the standards of sixteenth century Europe.
5 In it he takes a hardline against Judaism writing that synagogues and Jewish homes should be destroyed their money confiscated and liberty curtailed.
6 These statements and their influence on antisemitism have contributed to his controversial status.
7 What did Luther state as a means of discouraging mistreatment of Jews?	Jesus Christ was born a Jew	1
8 What did Luther gradually see as hopeless in the Reformation?	Jewish conversion to Christianity	2
9 Who did Luther strike out against in later years?	Jews	3
10 Luther treated Jews in a like way as he treated what group?	Anabaptists	3
11 When did Luther write an extreme treatise against the Jews?	1543	4
1 At the time of the Marburg Colloquy Suleiman the Magnificent was besieging Vienna with a vast Ottoman army.
2 Luther had argued against resisting the Turks in his 1518 Explanation of the Ninetyfive Theses provoking accusations of defeatism.
3 He saw the Turks as a scourge sent to punish Christians by God as agents of the Biblical apocalypse that would destroy the antichrist whom Luther believed to be the papacy and the Roman Church.
4 He consistently rejected the idea of a Holy War as though our people were an army of Christians against the Turks who were enemies of Christ.
5 This is absolutely contrary to Christs doctrine and name.
6 On the other hand in keeping with his doctrine of the two kingdoms Luther did support nonreligious war against the Turks.
7 In 1526 he argued in Whether Soldiers can be in a State of Grace that national defence is reason for a just war.
8 By 1529 in On War against the Turk he was actively urging Emperor Charles V and the German people to fight a secular war against the Turks.
9 He made clear however that the spiritual war against an alien faith was separate to be waged through prayer and repentance.
10 Around the time of the Siege of Vienna Luther wrote a prayer for national deliverance from the Turks asking God to give to our emperor perpetual victory over our enemies.
11 How did Luther view the Ottoman Turks?	as a scourge	3
12 What was the purpose of the Turks in Luthers mind?	to punish Christians	3
13 Since Luther believed that the Turks were sent by God what was their purpose?	destroy the antichrist	3
14 Who did Luther view to be the Antichrist?	the papacy	3
15 What kind of war did Luther support against the Turks even if he did not oppose a religious war?	secular war	8
1 In 1542 Luther read a Latin translation of the Quran.
2 He went on to produce several critical pamphlets on Islam which he called Mohammedanism or the Turk.
3 Though Luther saw the Muslim faith as a tool of the devil he was indifferent to its practice Let the Turk believe and live as he will just as one lets the papacy and other false Christians live.
4 He opposed banning the publication of the Quran wanting it exposed to scrutiny.
5 What book did Luther read in 1542?	Quran	1
6 What type of writings did the reading of the Quran bring out in Luther?	critical pamphlets on Islam	2
7 What were Mohammedanism and the Turk?	Islam	2
8 How did Luther view Islam?	tool of the devil	3
9 What purpose would Luther have in not wanting to ban the Quran?	exposed to scrutiny	4
1 Early in 1537 Johannes Agricola 1494–1566 – serving at the time as pastor in Luthers birthplace Eisleben – preached a sermon in which he claimed that Gods gospel not Gods moral law the Ten Commandments revealed Gods wrath to Christians.
2 Based on this sermon and others by Agricola Luther suspected that Agricola was behind certain anonymous antinomian theses circulating in Wittenberg.
3 These theses asserted that the law is no longer to be taught to Christians but belonged only to city hall.
4 Luther responded to these theses with six series of theses against Agricola and the antinomians four of which became the basis for disputations between 1538 and 1540.
5 He also responded to these assertions in other writings such as his 1539 open letter to C Güttel Against the Antinomians and his book On the Councils and the Church from the same year.
6 What did Johannes Agricola preach that Gods gospel revealed?	Gods wrath to Christians	1
7 Who did Luther think was behind the antinomian theses circulating in Wittenberg?	Johannes Agricola	1
8 What did Agricola apparently believe about who should be in control  law?	city hall	3
9 How did Luther respond to Agricola?	theses against Agricola	4
10 What book did Luther write in response to Agricola and the antinomians?	On the Councils and the Church	5
1 In his theses and disputations against the antinomians Luther reviews and reaffirms on the one hand what has been called the second use of the law that is the law as the Holy Spirits tool to work sorrow over sin in mans heart thus preparing him for Christs fulfillment of the law offered in the gospel.
2 Luther states that everything that is used to work sorrow over sin is called the law even if it is Christs life Christs death for sin or Gods goodness experienced in creation.
3 Simply refusing to preach the Ten Commandments among Christians – thereby as it were removing the three letters law from the church – does not eliminate the accusing law.
4 Claiming that the law – in any form – should not be preached to Christians anymore would be tantamount to asserting that Christians are no longer sinners in themselves and that the church consists only of essentially holy people.
5 What did Luthers answer to the antinomians reaffirms?	second use of the law	1
6 What is the use of the law by the Holy Spirit?	work sorrow over sin	1
7 What is Luthers opinion of what the law covers?	everything	2
8 What does refusing to preach the Ten Commandments not do?	eliminate the accusing law	3
9 What did Luther claim the church would have to comprise if the law were not taught?	essentially holy people	4
1 On the other hand Luther also points out that the Ten Commandments – when considered not as Gods condemning judgment but as an expression of his eternal will that is of the natural law – also positively teach how the Christian ought to live.
2 This has traditionally been called the third use of the law.
3 For Luther also Christs life when understood as an example is nothing more than an illustration of the Ten Commandments which a Christian should follow in his or her vocations on a daily basis.
4 What do the Ten Commandments teach Christians how to do?	ought to live	1
5 What is Gods expression of eternal will according to Luther?	Ten Commandments	1
6 Teaching Christians how they should live is what use of the law?	third use of the law	2
7 What did Luther consider Christs life?	illustration of the Ten Commandments	3
8 What should a Christian follow in his life?	Ten Commandments	3
1 The Ten Commandments and the beginnings of the renewed life of Christians accorded to them by the sacrament of baptism are a present foreshadowing of the believers future angellike life in heaven in the midst of this life.
2 Luthers teaching of the Ten Commandments therefore has clear eschatological overtones which characteristically for Luther do not encourage worldflight but direct the Christian to service to the neighbor in the common daily vocations of this perishing world.
3 What sacrament accords Christians renewed life?	baptism	1
4 Besides baptism what shows the future of heaven to Christians?	Ten Commandments	1
5 What does the Ten Commandments ask of the Christians?	service to the neighbor	2
1 From December 1539 Luther became implicated in the bigamy of Philip I Landgrave of Hesse who wanted to marry one of his wifes ladiesinwaiting.
2 Philip solicited the approval of Luther Melanchthon and Bucer citing as a precedent the polygamy of the patriarchs.
3 The theologians were not prepared to make a general ruling and they reluctantly advised the landgrave that if he was determined he should marry secretly and keep quiet about the matter.
4 As a result on 4 March 1540 Philip married a second wife Margarethe von der Saale with Melanchthon and Bucer among the witnesses.
5 However Philip was unable to keep the marriage secret and he threatened to make Luthers advice public.
6 Luther told him to tell a good strong lie and deny the marriage completely which Philip did during the subsequent public controversy.
7 In the view of Luthers biographer Martin Brecht giving confessional advice for Philip of Hesse was one of the worst mistakes Luther made and next to the landgrave himself who was directly responsible for it history chiefly holds Luther accountable.
8 Brecht argues that Luthers mistake was not that he gave private pastoral advice but that he miscalculated the political implications.
9 The affair caused lasting damage to Luthers reputation.
10 What did Philip I wish to do around 1539?	wanted to marry	1
11 What did Luther get implicated in concerning Philip I?	bigamy	1
12 Who did Philip I want to marry?	one of his wifes ladiesinwaiting	1
13 Who does history view as accountable for the error Philip I made and Luthers advice in the matter?	holds Luther accountable	7
14 What did this affair cause to Luthers reputation?	lasting damage	9
1 Luther wrote about the Jews throughout his career though only a few of his works dealt with them directly.
2 Luther rarely encountered Jews during his life but his attitudes reflected a theological and cultural tradition which saw Jews as a rejected people guilty of the murder of Christ and he lived within a local community that had expelled Jews some ninety years earlier.
3 He considered the Jews blasphemers and liars because they rejected the divinity of Jesus whereas Christians believed Jesus was the Messiah.
4 But Luther believed that all human beings who set themselves against God were equally guilty.
5 As early as 1516 he wrote that many people are proud with marvelous stupidity when they call the Jews dogs evildoers or whatever they like while they too and equally do not realize who or what they are in the sight of God.
6 In 1523 Luther advised kindness toward the Jews in That Jesus Christ was Born a Jew and also aimed to convert them to Christianity.
7 When his efforts at conversion failed he grew increasingly bitter toward them.
8 In his 2010 book Bonhoeffer Pastor Martyr Prophet Spy Christian author Eric Metaxas claimed that Luthers attitude towards Jews unraveled along with his health.
9 What had Luthers community done to Jews years earlier?	expelled Jews	2
10 Who did Luther write about but seldom met?	Jews	2
11 What did Luthers area and tradition believe Jews to be guilty of?	murder of Christ	2
12 What did Jews refuse to accept that caused Luther to call them blasphemers and liars?	divinity of Jesus	3
13 What did Luther try to do for the Jews?	convert them to Christianity	6
1 Luthers other major works on the Jews were his 60000word treatise Von den Juden und Ihren Lügen On the Jews and Their Lies and Vom Schem Hamphoras und vom Geschlecht Christi On the Holy Name and the Lineage of Christ both published in 1543 three years before his death.
2 Luther argued that the Jews were no longer the chosen people but the devils people and referred to them with violent vile language.
3 Citing Deuteronomy 13 wherein Moses commands the killing of idolaters and the burning of their cities and property as an offering to God Luther called for a scharfe Barmherzigkeit sharp mercy against the Jews to see whether we might save at least a few from the glowing flames.
4 Luther advocated setting synagogues on fire destroying Jewish prayerbooks forbidding rabbis from preaching seizing Jews property and money and smashing up their homes so that these envenomed worms would be forced into labour or expelled for all time.
5 In Robert Michaels view Luthers words We are at fault in not slaying them amounted to a sanction for murder.
6 Gods anger with them is so intense Luther concluded that gentle mercy will only tend to make them worse while sharp mercy will reform them but little.
7 Therefore in any case away with them.
8 What was Luthers major work of 60000 words on the Jews?	Von den Juden und Ihren Lügen	1
9 When was the large work published?	1543	1
10 How near to his death was the work published?	three years before	1
11 What did Luther contend the Jews to be?	the devils people	2
12 As what did Robert Michael view Luthers violent language towards the Jews?	sanction for murder	5
1 Luther spoke out against the Jews in Saxony Brandenburg and Silesia.
2 Josel of Rosheim the Jewish spokesman who tried to help the Jews of Saxony in 1537 later blamed their plight on that priest whose name was Martin Luther—may his body and soul be bound up in hell—who wrote and issued many heretical books in which he said that whoever would help the Jews was doomed to perdition.
3 Josel asked the city of Strasbourg to forbid the sale of Luthers antiJewish works they refused initially but did so when a Lutheran pastor in Hochfelden used a sermon to urge his parishioners to murder Jews.
4 Luthers influence persisted after his death.
5 Throughout the 1580s riots led to the expulsion of Jews from several German Lutheran states.
6 What did Luther speak out about in Saxony?	the Jews	1
7 Who did Josel of Rosheim blame for the condition of Jews in Saxony?	Martin Luther	2
8 What did Josel of Rosheim claimed that Luther said of those who might aid the Jews?	doomed to perdition	2
9 What did Josel ask the city of Strasbourg to forbid the sale of?	Luthers antiJewish works	3
10 When did riots cause the expulsion of Jews from several German states?	Throughout the 1580s	5
1 Luther was the most widely read author of his generation and within Germany he acquired the status of a prophet.
2 According to the prevailing view among historians his antiJewish rhetoric contributed significantly to the development of antisemitism in Germany and in the 1930s and 1940s provided an ideal underpinning for the Nazis attacks on Jews.
3 Reinhold Lewin writes that anybody who wrote against the Jews for whatever reason believed he had the right to justify himself by triumphantly referring to Luther.
4 According to Michael just about every antiJewish book printed in the Third Reich contained references to and quotations from Luther.
5 Heinrich Himmler wrote admiringly of his writings and sermons on the Jews in 1940.
6 The city of Nuremberg presented a first edition of On the Jews and their Lies to Julius Streicher editor of the Nazi newspaper Der Stürmer on his birthday in 1937 the newspaper described it as the most radically antiSemitic tract ever published.
7 It was publicly exhibited in a glass case at the Nuremberg rallies and quoted in a 54page explanation of the Aryan Law by Dr EH Schulz and Dr R Frercks.
8 Who was the most widely read writer of his generation?	Luther	1
9 What action by Luther added to antisemitism in Germany?	antiJewish rhetoric	2
10 What later actions by the Nazis could be traced back to Luthers rhetoric?	attacks on Jews	2
11 Whose writings were widely quoted by the Third Reich?	Luther	4
12 How did Der Sturmer describe Luthers On the Jews and their Lies	radically antiSemitic 	6.
1 On 17 December 1941 seven Protestant regional church confederations issued a statement agreeing with the policy of forcing Jews to wear the yellow badge since after his bitter experience Luther had already suggested preventive measures against the Jews and their expulsion from German territory.
2 According to Daniel Goldhagen Bishop Martin Sasse a leading Protestant churchman published a compendium of Luthers writings shortly after Kristallnacht for which Diarmaid MacCulloch Professor of the History of the Church in the University of Oxford argued that Luthers writing was a blueprint.
3 Sasse applauded the burning of the synagogues and the coincidence of the day writing in the introduction On 10 November 1938 on Luthers birthday the synagogues are burning in Germany.
4 The German people he urged ought to heed these words of the greatest antisemite of his time the warner of his people against the Jews.
5 When did seven Protestant churches agree with the Nazi policy of forcing Jews to wear yellow arm bands?	17 December 1941	1
6 Who did the churches claim had suggested expulsion of Jews from Germany?	Luther	1
7 Who claimed Luthers writings were a blueprint of actions against Jews?	Diarmaid MacCulloch	2
8 Who agreed with the burning of synagogues?	Bishop Martin Sasse	2
9 What did Sasse proclaim Luther to be?	greatest antisemite	4
1 At the heart of scholars debate about Luthers influence is whether it is anachronistic to view his work as a precursor of the racial antisemitism of the Nazis.
2 Some scholars see Luthers influence as limited and the Nazis use of his work as opportunistic.
3 Biographer Martin Brecht points out that There is a world of difference between his belief in salvation and a racial ideology.
4 Nevertheless his misguided agitation had the evil result that Luther fatefully became one of the church fathers of antiSemitism and thus provided material for the modern hatred of the Jews cloaking it with the authority of the Reformer.
5 Johannes Wallmann argues that Luthers writings against the Jews were largely ignored in the 18th and 19th centuries and that there was no continuity between Luthers thought and Nazi ideology.
6 Uwe SiemonNetto agreed arguing that it was because the Nazis were already antiSemites that they revived Luthers work.
7 Hans J Hillerbrand agreed that to focus on Luther was to adopt an essentially ahistorical perspective of Nazi antisemitism that ignored other contributory factors in German history.
8 Similarly Roland Bainton noted church historian and Luther biographer wrote One could wish that Luther had died before ever On the Jews and Their Lies was written.
9 His position was entirely religious and in no respect racial.
10 How do some scholars view the Nazi use of Luthers work?	opportunistic	2
11 What did Martin Brecht call Luthers stand on the Jews?	misguided agitation	4
12 What did this agitation provide later generations material for?	modern hatred of the Jews	4
13 When was Luthers writings about the Jews ignored according to Johannes Wallmann?	18th and 19th centuries	5
14 What did Roland Bainton say about Luthers position on Jews?	religious and in no respect racial	9
1 Other scholars argue that even if his views were merely antiJudaic—that is opposed to Judaism and its adherence rather than the Jews as an ethnic group—their violence lent a new element to the standard Christian suspicion of Judaism.
2 Ronald Berger writes that Luther is credited with Germanizing the Christian critique of Judaism and establishing antiSemitism as a key element of German culture and national identity.
3 Paul Rose argues that he caused a hysterical and demonizing mentality about Jews to enter German thought and discourse a mentality that might otherwise have been absent.
4 Christopher J Probst in his book Demonizing the Jews Luther and the Protestant Church in Nazi Germany 2012 shows that a large number of German Lutheran clergy and theologians during the Nazi Third Reich used Luthers hostile publications towards the Jews and their Jewish religion to justify at least in part the antiSemitic policies of the National Socialists.
5 Other scholars contend that Luthers words lent what element to Christian suspicion of Jews?	violence	1
6 Who thinks that Luther added antisemitism as a cultural element to Germany?	Ronald Berger	2
7 What did Paul Rose say Luther added to German thought?	hysterical and demonizing mentality	3
8 Who aide the Reich in Germany in antisemitism?	Lutheran clergy and theologians	4
9 What did these Lutheran clerics use as fuel to bolster the Policies of the Nazis?	Luthers hostile publications	4
1 Some scholars such as Mark U Edwards in his book Luthers Last Battles Politics and Polemics 1531–46 1983 suggest that since Luthers increasingly antisemitic views developed during the years his health deteriorated it is possible they were at least partly the product of a declining state of mind.
2 Edwards also comments that Luther often deliberately used vulgarity and violence for effect both in his writings condemning the Jews and in diatribes against Turks Muslims and Catholics.
3 What does Mark U Edwards claim as a possible cause of Luthers antisemitism?	declining state of mind	1
4 What about Luther declined as his antisemitism increased?	his health	1
5 What kind of affect did Luther often use in his discourses?	vulgarity and violence	2
6 Who else did Luther use violent rhetoric towards?	Muslims and Catholics	2
7 What is the title of Edwards book about Luther?	Luthers Last Battles Politics and Polemics 1531–46	1
1 Since the 1980s Lutheran Church denominations have repudiated Martin Luthers statements against the Jews and have rejected the use of them to incite hatred against Lutherans.
2 Strommen et al.
3 s 1970 survey of 4745 North American Lutherans aged 15–65 found that compared to the other minority groups under consideration Lutherans were the least prejudiced toward Jews.
4 Nevertheless Professor Richard Dick Geary former Professor of Modern History at the University of Nottingham England and the author of Hitler and Nazism Routledge 1993 wrote in the journal History Today an article on who voted for the Nazis in elections held from 19281933 where he claimed that from his research he found that the Nazis gained disproportionately more votes from Protestant than Catholic areas of Germany.
5 When have Lutheran Churches repudiated Luthers statements about the Jews?	Since the 1980s	1
6 What did a survey of North American Lutherans find that Lutherans felt about Jews compared to other minority groups?	least prejudiced	3
7 Who found that Protestants voted for Nazis more than Catholics?	Richard Dick Geary	4
8 When were the elections that produced a higher vote by Protestant Nazi sympathizers than by Catholics?	19281933	4
1 Luther had been suffering from ill health for years including Ménières disease vertigo fainting tinnitus and a cataract in one eye.
2 From 1531 to 1546 his health deteriorated further.
3 The years of struggle with Rome the antagonisms with and among his fellow reformers and the scandal which ensued from the bigamy of the Philip of Hesse incident in which Luther had played a leading role all may have contributed.
4 In 1536 he began to suffer from kidney and bladder stones and arthritis and an ear infection ruptured an ear drum.
5 In December 1544 he began to feel the effects of angina.
6 How was Luthers health for the years of 1531 to 1546?	his health deteriorated	2
7 Besides the arguments with Rome and his own fellow reformers what scandal  contributed to Luthers failing health?	bigamy of the Philip of Hesse	3
8 What did Luther begin to experience in 1536?	kidney and bladder stones	4
9 What other health issues did Luther have?	arthritis  and an ear infection	4
10 By 1544 what did Luther have to deal with in his health?	angina	5
1 His poor physical health made him shorttempered and even harsher in his writings and comments.
2 His wife Katharina was overheard saying Dear husband you are too rude and he responded They are teaching me to be rude.
3 In 1545 and 1546 Luther preached three times in the Market Church in Halle staying with his friend Justus Jonas during Christmas.
4 What made Luther even more short tempered than usual?	poor physical health	1
5 What other aspect of Luthers life was affected by his health?	writings and comments	1
6 How did Luthers writings sound as he became less healthy?	harsher	1
7 Who scolded Luther about his rudeness?	His wife Katharina	2
8 How many times did Luther preach in Halle in 1545 and 1546?	three times	3
1 His last sermon was delivered at Eisleben his place of birth on 15 February 1546 three days before his death.
2 It was entirely devoted to the obdurate Jews whom it was a matter of great urgency to expel from all German territory according to Léon Poliakov.
3 James Mackinnon writes that it concluded with a fiery summons to drive the Jews bag and baggage from their midst unless they desisted from their calumny and their usury and became Christians.
4 Luther said we want to practice Christian love toward them and pray that they convert but also that they are our public enemies  and if they could kill us all they would gladly do so.
5 And so often they do.
6 Where was Luthers last sermon preached?	Eisleben	1
7 When was Luthers last sermon?	15 February 1546	1
8 What was the focus of Luthers last sermon?	Jews	2
9 From whence did Luther want to expel the Jews?	all German territory	2
10 What did Luther say would allow the Jews to stay?	that they convert	4
1 Luthers final journey to Mansfeld was taken because of his concern for his siblings families continuing in their father Hans Luthers copper mining trade.
2 Their livelihood was threatened by Count Albrecht of Mansfeld bringing the industry under his own control.
3 The controversy that ensued involved all four Mansfeld counts Albrecht Philip John George and Gerhard.
4 Luther journeyed to Mansfeld twice in late 1545 to participate in the negotiations for a settlement and a third visit was needed in early 1546 for their completion.
5 To where was Luthers final journey?	Mansfeld	1
6 What was Luther involved in dealing with the minds in Mansfeld?	negotiations	4
7 When did Luther travel to Mansfeld twice?	late 1545	4
8 When was a third visit to Mnafeld scheduled?	early 1546	4
9 For whom was Luther concerned about in Mansfeld?	his siblings families	1
1 The negotiations were successfully concluded on 17 February 1546.
2 After 8 am he experienced chest pains.
3 When he went to his bed he prayed Into your hand I commit my spirit you have redeemed me O Lord faithful God Ps.
4 315 the common prayer of the dying.
5 At 1 am he awoke with more chest pain and was warmed with hot towels.
6 He thanked God for revealing his Son to him in whom he had believed.
7 His companions Justus Jonas and Michael Coelius shouted loudly Reverend father are you ready to die trusting in your Lord Jesus Christ and to confess the doctrine which you have taught in his name.
8 A distinct Yes was Luthers reply.
9 When were the negotiations finished in Mansfeld?	17 February 1546	1
10 After the negotiations were done what did Luther experience?	chest pains	2
11 Luther went to bed quoting what scripture?	Ps 315	3
12 What is Psalm 315?	prayer of the dying	4
13 When did Luther waken with more chest pains?	1 am	5
1 An apoplectic stroke deprived him of his speech and he died shortly afterwards at 245 am on 18 February 1546 aged 62 in Eisleben the city of his birth.
2 He was buried in the Castle Church in Wittenberg beneath the pulpit.
3 The funeral was held by his friends Johannes Bugenhagen and Philipp Melanchthon.
4 A year later troops of Luthers adversary Charles V Holy Roman Emperor entered the town but were ordered by Charles not to disturb the grave.
5 What event took away his ability of speech?	apoplectic stroke	1
6 At what time did Martin Luther die?	245 am	1
7 On what date did Luther die?	18 February 1546	1
8 Where was Luther buried?	in the Castle Church	2
9 Who performed the funeral for Martin Luther?	Johannes Bugenhagen and Philipp Melanchthon	3
1 A piece of paper was later found on which Luther had written his last statement.
2 The statement was in Latin apart from We are beggars which was in German.
3 What was later discovered written by Luther?	his last statement	1
4 In what language was most of the statement written?	Latin	2
5 What portion of Luthers last statement was in German?	We are beggars 	2
1 In the 1530s and 1540s printed images of Luther that emphasized his monumental size were crucial to the spread of Protestantism.
2 In contrast to images of frail Catholic saints Luther was presented as a stout man with a double chin strong mouth piercing deepset eyes fleshy face and squat neck.
3 He was shown to be physically imposing an equal in stature to the secular German princes with whom he would join forces to spread Lutheranism.
4 His large body also let the viewer know that he did not shun earthly pleasures like drinking—behavior that was a stark contrast to the ascetic life of the medieval religious orders.
5 Famous images from this period include the woodcuts by Hans Brosamer 1530 and Lucas Cranach the Elder and Lucas Cranach the Younger 1546.
6 What kind of images of Luther were used to advertise Protestantism?	monumental	1
7 In contrast how were Catholic saints portrayed?	frail Catholic saints	2
8 How was Luther presented as an image to spread Protestantism?	physically imposing	3
9 What was the image of Luther a contrast to the life of?	religious orders	4
10 When were images being used to promote the spread of Lutheranism?	1530s and 1540s	1

2 In the Church of Englands Calendar of Saints he is commemorated on 31 October.
3 When is Luther commemorated in the Lutheran Calendar of Saints ?	18 February	1
4 On what other calendar is Luther commemorated?	Episcopal United States Calendar of Saints	1
5 When is Luther commemorated by the Church of England?	31 October	2
6 On what English calendar is Luther commemorated?	Church of Englands Calendar of Saints	2
7 How is Luther commemorated on the Lutheran Episcopal and  Church of England  calendars?	Luther is honoured	1
1 Southern California often abbreviated SoCal is a geographic and cultural region that generally comprises Californias southernmost 10 counties.
2 The region is traditionally described as eight counties based on demographics and economic ties Imperial Los Angeles Orange Riverside San Bernardino San Diego Santa Barbara and Ventura.
3 The more extensive 10county definition including Kern and San Luis Obispo counties is also used based on historical political divisions.
4 Southern California is a major economic center for the state of California and the United States.

1 Southern California includes the heavily builtup urban area stretching along the Pacific coast from Ventura through the Greater Los Angeles Area and the Inland Empire and down to Greater San Diego.
2 Southern Californias population encompasses seven metropolitan areas or MSAs the Los Angeles metropolitan area consisting of Los Angeles and Orange counties the Inland Empire consisting of Riverside and San Bernardino counties the San Diego metropolitan area the Oxnard–Thousand Oaks–Ventura metropolitan area the Santa Barbara metro area the San Luis Obispo metropolitan area and the El Centro area.
3 Out of these three are heavy populated areas the Los Angeles area with over 12 million inhabitants the RiversideSan Bernardino area with over four million inhabitants and the San Diego area with over 3 million inhabitants.
4 For CSA metropolitan purposes the five counties of Los Angeles Orange Riverside San Bernardino and Ventura are all combined to make up the Greater Los Angeles Area with over 175 million people.
5 With over 22 million people southern California contains roughly 60 percent of Californias population.

1 Southern California is not a formal geographic designation and definitions of what constitutes southern California vary.
2 Geographically Californias northsouth midway point lies at exactly 37° 9 5823 latitude around 11 miles 18 km south of San Jose however this does not coincide with popular use of the term.
3 When the state is divided into two areas northern and southern California the term southern California usually refers to the ten southernmost counties of the state.
4 This definition coincides neatly with the county lines at 35° 47′ 28″ north latitude which form the northern borders of San Luis Obispo Kern and San Bernardino counties.
5 Another definition for southern California uses Point Conception and the Tehachapi Mountains as the northern boundary.
6 Geographically speaking where is Californias north  south midway point in terms of latitude?	37° 9 5823	2

1 Though there is no official definition for the northern boundary of southern California such a division has existed from the time when Mexico ruled California and political disputes raged between the Californios of Monterey in the upper part and Los Angeles in the lower part of Alta California.
2 Following the acquisition of California by the United States the division continued as part of the attempt by several proslavery politicians to arrange the division of Alta California at 36 degrees 30 minutes the line of the Missouri Compromise.
3 Instead the passing of the Compromise of 1850 enabled California to be admitted to the Union as a free state preventing southern California from becoming its own separate slave state.
4 Which country used to rule California?	Mexico	1
5 Los Angeles is in the lower part of what?	Alta California	1
6 Which Californio is located in the upper part?	Monterey	1
7 What was the name of the legislation passed in 1850?	the Missouri Compromise	2
8 The legislation allowed California to be admitted to the Union as what kind of state?	free	3
1 Subsequently Californios dissatisfied with inequitable taxes and land laws and proslavery southerners in the lightly populated Cow Counties of southern California attempted three times in the 1850s to achieve a separate statehood or territorial status separate from Northern California.
2 The last attempt the Pico Act of 1859 was passed by the California State Legislature and signed by the State governor John B Weller.
3 It was approved overwhelmingly by nearly 75 of voters in the proposed Territory of Colorado.
4 This territory was to include all the counties up to the then much larger Tulare County that included what is now Kings most of Kern and part of Inyo counties and San Luis Obispo County.
5 The proposal was sent to Washington DC with a strong advocate in Senator Milton Latham.
6 However the secession crisis following the election of Abraham Lincoln in 1860 led to the proposal never coming to a vote.
7 Other than land laws what else were the Californios dissatisfied with?	inequitable taxes	1
8 What was the name given to the regions in which the pro  slavery southerners lived?	Cow Counties	1
9 How many times did southern California attempt to achieve a separate statehood?	three	1
10 What was the percentage of people that voted in favor of the Pico Act of 1859?	75	3
11 Which Senator was a strong advocate for the Pico Act?	Milton Latham	5

1 The state is most commonly divided and promoted by its regional tourism groups as consisting of northern central and southern California regions.
2 The two AAA Auto Clubs of the state the California State Automobile Association and the Automobile Club of Southern California choose to simplify matters by dividing the state along the lines where their jurisdictions for membership apply as either northern or southern California in contrast to the threeregion point of view.
3 Another influence is the geographical phrase South of the Tehachapis which would split the southern region off at the crest of that transverse range but in that definition the desert portions of north Los Angeles County and eastern Kern and San Bernardino Counties would be included in the southern California region due to their remoteness from the central valley and interior desert landscape.

1 Southern California consists of a heavily developed urban environment home to some of the largest urban areas in the state along with vast areas that have been left undeveloped.
2 It is the third most populated megalopolis in the United States after the Great Lakes Megalopolis and the Northeastern megalopolis.
3 Much of southern California is famous for its large spreadout suburban communities and use of automobiles and highways.
4 The dominant areas are Los Angeles Orange County San Diego and RiversideSan Bernardino each of which is the center of its respective metropolitan area composed of numerous smaller cities and communities.
5 The urban area is also host to an international metropolitan region in the form of San Diego–Tijuana created by the urban area spilling over into Baja California.
6 Where does southern Californias megalopolis standard in terms of population nationwide?	third	2
7 Although southern california consts of a heavily developed urban environment how much of it has been left undeveloped?	vast areas	1
8 Southern Californian communities are well known to be large spread  out and what other characteristic?	suburban	3
9 Outside of its use of automobiles what else is southern California famous for using?	highways	3
10 What kind of region can be found inside the urban area of southern California?	international metropolitan	5
1 Traveling south on Interstate 5 the main gap to continued urbanization is Camp Pendleton.
2 The cities and communities along Interstate 15 and Interstate 215 are so interrelated that Temecula and Murrieta have as much connection with the San Diego metropolitan area as they do with the Inland Empire.
3 To the east the United States Census Bureau considers the San Bernardino and Riverside County areas RiversideSan Bernardino area as a separate metropolitan area from Los Angeles County.
4 While many commute to LA and Orange Counties there are some differences in development as most of San Bernardino and Riverside Counties the nondesert portions were developed in the 1980s and 1990s.
5 Newly developed exurbs formed in the Antelope Valley north of Los Angeles the Victor Valley and the Coachella Valley with the Imperial Valley.
6 Also population growth was high in the BakersfieldKern County Santa Maria and San Luis Obispo areas.

1 Southern California contains a Mediterranean climate with infrequent rain and many sunny days.
2 Summers are hot and dry while winters are a bit warm or mild and wet.
3 Serious rain can occur unusually.
4 In the summers temperature ranges are 9060s while as winters are 7050s usually all of Southern California have Mediterranean climate.
5 But snow is very rare in the Southwest of the state it occurs on the Southeast of the state.

1 Southern California consists of one of the more varied collections of geologic topographic and natural ecosystem landscapes in a diversity outnumbering other major regions in the state and country.
2 The region spans from Pacific Ocean islands shorelines beaches and coastal plains through the Transverse and Peninsular Ranges with their peaks into the large and small interior valleys to the vast deserts of California.

1 Each year the southern California area has about 10000 earthquakes.
2 Nearly all of them are so small that they are not felt.
3 Only several hundred are greater than magnitude 30 and only about 15–20 are greater than magnitude 40.
4 The magnitude 67 1994 Northridge earthquake was particularly destructive causing a substantial number of deaths injuries and structural collapses.
5 It caused the most property damage of any earthquake in US history estimated at over 20 billion.
6 How many earthquakes does southern California experience in a year?	10 000	1
7 Generally speaking what size are the earthquakes that hit southern California?	small	2
8 What magnitude was the 1994 Northridge earthquake?	67	4
9 What kind of destruction did the 1994 earthquake cause the most of in US history?	property damage	5

1 Southern Californias economy is diverse and one of the largest in the United States.
2 It is dominated and heavily dependent upon abundance of petroleum as opposed to other regions where automobiles not nearly as dominant the vast majority of transport runs on this fuel.

4 Other industries include software automotive ports finance tourism biomedical and regional logistics.
5 The region was a leader in the housing bubble 2001–2007 and has been heavily impacted by the housing crash.

1 Since the 1920s motion pictures petroleum and aircraft manufacturing have been major industries.
2 In one of the richest agricultural regions in the US cattle and citrus were major industries until farmlands were turned into suburbs.
3 Although military spending cutbacks have had an impact aerospace continues to be a major factor.
4 Motion pictures petroleum and aircraft manufacturing have been major industries since which decade?	1920s	1
5 What characteristic best describes the agricultural regions that could be found?	richest	2
6 Outside of livestock what else was considered a major industry in the agriculture regions?	citrus	2
7 Which type of livestock was the argricultural region known for?	cattle	2
8 What industry has managed to survive major military spending cutbacks?	aerospace	3
1 Southern California is home to many major business districts.

1 Southern California is home to Los Angeles International Airport the secondbusiest airport in the United States by passenger volume see Worlds busiest airports by passenger traffic and the third by international passenger volume see Busiest airports in the United States by international passenger traffic San Diego International Airport the busiest single runway airport in the world Van Nuys Airport the worlds busiest general aviation airport major commercial airports at Orange County Bakersfield Ontario Burbank and Long Beach and numerous smaller commercial and general aviation airports.

1 Formed in November 1990 by the equal merger of Sky Television and British Satellite Broadcasting BSkyB became the UKs largest digital subscription television company.
2 Following BSkyBs 2014 acquisition of Sky Italia and a majority 9004 interest in Sky Deutschland in November 2014 its holding company British Sky Broadcasting Group plc changed its name to Sky plc.
3 The United Kingdom operations also changed the company name from British Sky Broadcasting Limited to Sky UK Limited still trading as Sky.
4 What company was formed by the merger of Sky Television and British Satellite Broadcasting?	BSkyB	1
5 Who is the UKs largest digital subscription television company?	BSkyB	1
6 What year did BSkyB acquire Sky Italia?	2014	2
7 What is the name of the holding company for BSkyB?	Sky plc	2
8 What is the name of the United Kingdom operation for BSkyB?	Sky UK Limited	3
1 Following a lengthy legal battle with the European Commission which deemed the exclusivity of the rights to be against the interests of competition and the consumer BSkyBs monopoly came to an end from the 2007–08 season.
2 In May 2006 the Irish broadcaster Setanta Sports was awarded two of the six Premier League packages that the English FA offered to broadcasters.
3 Sky picked up the remaining four for £13bn.
4 In February 2015 Sky bid £42bn for a package of 120 premier league games across the three seasons from 2016.
5 This represented an increase of 70 on the previous contract and was said to be £1bn more than the company had expected to pay.
6 The move has been followed by staff cuts increased subscription prices including 9 in Skys family package and the dropping of the 3D channel.
7 What year was Setanta Sports awarded Primeier Leage rights to broadcast?	2006	2
8 How many of the six total packages available to broadcasters was Setanta awarded?	two	2
9 Who purhcased the remaining 4 pacakages available to broadcasters?	Sky	3
10 How much did Sky bid to win the 4 broadcast pacakges they bought?	£13bn	3
1 While BSkyB had been excluded from being a part of the ONdigital consortium thereby making them a competitor by default BSkyB was able to join ITV Digitals freetoair replacement Freeview in which it holds an equal stake with the BBC ITV Channel 4 and National Grid Wireless.
2 Prior to October 2005 three BSkyB channels were available on this platform Sky News Sky Three and Sky Sports News.
3 Initially BSkyB provided Sky Travel to the service.
4 However this was replaced by Sky Three on 31 October 2005 which was itself later rebranded as Pick TV in 2011.
5 What consortium was BSkyB excluded from?	ONdigital	1
6 Who did BSkyB team up with because it was not part of the consortium?	Freeview	1
7 How many BSkyB channels were available to customers prior to October 2005?	three	2
8 What channel replaced Sky Travel?	Sky Three	4
9 What was Sky Travel later rebranded as?	Pick TV	4
1 BSkyB initially charged additional subscription fees for using a Sky PVR with their service waiving the charge for subscribers whose package included two or more premium channels.
2 This changed as from 1 July 2007 and now customers that have Sky and subscribe to any BSkyB subscription package get Sky included at no extra charge.
3 Customers that do not subscribe to BSkyBs channels can still pay a monthly fee to enable Sky functions.
4 In January 2010 BSkyB discontinued the Sky Box limited the standard Sky Box to Multiroom upgrade only and started to issue the SkyHD Box as standard thus giving all new subscribers the functions of Sky.
5 In February 2011 BSkyB discontinued the nonHD variant of its Multiroom box offering a smaller version of the SkyHD box without Sky functionality.
6 In September 2007 Sky launched a new TV advertising campaign targeting Sky at women.
7 As of 31 March 2008 Sky had 3393000 Sky users.
8 What service did BSkyB chare additional subscription fees for?	Sky PVR	1
9 When did Sky launch a TV advertising campaign target towards women?	September 2007	6
10 WHat allows customers to get Sky functions if they do not subscribe to BSkyBs channels?	monthly fee	3
11 When did BSkyB discontinue the Sky Box?	January 2010	4
12 What replaced the SkyBox?	SkyHD Box	4
1 BSkyB utilises the VideoGuard payTV scrambling system owned by NDS a Cisco Systems company.
2 There are tight controls over use of VideoGuard decoders they are not available as standalone DVB CAMs conditionalaccess modules.
3 BSkyB has design authority over all digital satellite receivers capable of receiving their service.
4 The receivers though designed and built by different manufacturers must conform to the same user interface lookandfeel as all the others.
5 This extends to the Personal video recorder PVR offering branded Sky.
6 What is the name of the TV scrambling system BSkyB uses?	VideoGuard	1
7 Who is VideoGuard owned by?	NDS	1
8 Who is the parent company of NDS?	Cisco Systems	1
9 Who has design authority over all of the digital satellite receivers that are capable of using their service?	BSkyB	3
10 What is the name brand of the personal video recorder that BSkyB offers?	Sky	5
1 In 2007 BSkyB and Virgin Media became involved in a dispute over the carriage of Sky channels on cable TV.
2 The failure to renew the existing carriage agreements negotiated with NTL and Telewest resulted in Virgin Media removing the basic channels from the network on 1 March 2007.
3 Virgin Media claimed that BSkyB had substantially increased the asking price for the channels a claim which BSkyB denied on the basis that their new deal offered substantially more value by including HD channels and Video On Demand content which was not previously carried by cable.
4 What channels were removed from the network in March of 2007?	basic channels	2
5 What year did BSkyB and Virgin Media have a dispute over the carriage of Sky Channels on cable TV?	2007	1
6 What did Virgin Media claim BSkyB did that resulted Virgin not carrying the channels anymore?	substantially increased the asking price	3
7 What additional srevice did BSkyB offer besides HD channels that they claimed offered substantially more value?	Video On Demand	3
8 What additional srevice did BSkyB offer besides Video on Demand that they claimed offered substantially more value?	HD channels	3
1 In July 2013 the English High Court of Justice found that Microsoft’s use of the term SkyDrive infringed on Sky’s right to the Sky trademark.
2 On 31 July 2013 BSkyB and Microsoft announced their settlement in which Microsoft will not appeal the ruling and will rename its SkyDrive cloud storage service after an unspecified reasonable period of time to allow for an orderly transition to a new brand plus financial and other terms the details of which are confidential.
3 On 27 January 2014 Microsoft announced that SkyDrive will soon become OneDrive and SkyDrive Pro becomes OneDrive for Business.
4 when did the English High court find Microsofts use of the term SkyDrive infringed on Skys right?	July 2013	1
5 What year did BSkyB and Microsoft announce their settlement?	2013	2
6 What did Microsoft announce that it would rename Sky Drive to?	OneDrive	3
7 What did Microsoft announce that it would rename Sky Drive Pro to?	OneDrive for Business	3
8 What kind of service is the SkyDrive Service?	cloud storage	2
1 The service started on 1 September 1993 based on the idea from the then chief executive officer Sam Chisholm and Rupert Murdoch of converting the company business strategy to an entirely feebased concept.
2 The new package included four channels formerly available freetoair broadcasting on Astras satellites as well as introducing new channels.
3 The service continued until the closure of BSkyBs analogue service on 27 September 2001 due to the launch and expansion of the Sky Digital platform.
4 Some of the channels did broadcast either in the clear or soft encrypted whereby a Videocrypt decoder was required to decode without a subscription card prior to their addition to the Sky Multichannels package.
5 Within two months of the launch BSkyB gained 400000 new subscribers with the majority taking at least one premium channel as well which helped BSkyB reach 35 million households by mid1994.
6 Michael Grade criticized the operations in front of the Select Committee on National Heritage mainly for the lack of original programming on many of the new channels.
7 Who was the chief executive officer when the service began?	Sam Chisholm	1
8 Whos satellites would the new freetoair channels be broadcast from?	Astra	2
9 When did BSkyB end their analogue service?	27 September 2001	3
10 What platform caused BSkyB to end their analogue service?	Sky Digital	3
11 How many households had BSkyB service in 1994?	35 million	5
1 Sky UK Limited formerly British Sky Broadcasting or BSkyB is a British telecommunications company which serves the United Kingdom.
2 Sky provides television and broadband internet services and fixed line telephone services to consumers and businesses in the United Kingdom.
3 It is the UKs largest payTV broadcaster with 11 million customers as of 2015.
4 It was the UKs most popular digital TV service until it was overtaken by Freeview in April 2007.
5 Its corporate headquarters are based in Isleworth.
6 Sky UK Limited is formerly known by what name?	BSkyB	1
7 What kind of company is Sky UK Limited?	telecommunications	1
8 How many customers does Sky UK Limited have as a payTV broadcaster as of 2015?	11 million	3
9 what other digital TV service took Sky UK Limiteds most popular spot?	Freeview	4
1 On 18 November 2015 Sky announced Sky Q a range of products and services to be available in 2016.
2 The Sky Q range consists of three set top boxes Sky Q Sky Q Silver and Sky Q Mini a broadband router Sky Q Hub and mobile applications.
3 The Sky Q set top boxes introduce a new user interface WiFi hotspot functionality Powerline and Bluetooth connectivity and a new touchsensitive remote control.
4 The Sky Q Mini set top boxes connect to the Sky Q Silver set top boxes with a WiFi or Powerline connection rather than receive their own satellite feeds.
5 This allows all set top boxes in a household to share recordings and other media.
6 The Sky Q Silver set top box is capable of receiving and displaying UHD broadcasts which Sky will introduce later in 2016.
7 What is the name of Sky Qs broadband router?	Sky Q Hub	2
8 What are the Sky Q mini set top boxes able to connect to?	Sky Q Silver set top boxes	4
9 What does connecting different Sky Q boxes enable them to do?	share recordings	5
10 When is Sky going to introduce UHD broadcasts?	2016	763
11 When are the new Sky Q products going to be available?	2016	1
1 BSkyBs standard definition broadcasts are in DVBcompliant MPEG2 with the Sky Movies and Sky Box Office channels including optional Dolby Digital soundtracks for recent films although these are only accessible with a Sky box.
2 Sky HD material is broadcast using MPEG4 and most of the HD material uses the DVBS2 standard.
3 Interactive services and 7day EPG use the proprietary OpenTV system with settop boxes including modems for a return path.
4 Sky News amongst other channels provides a pseudovideo on demand interactive service by broadcasting looping video streams.
5 What are BSkyBs standard definition broadcasts compliant with?	DVBcompliant MPEG2	1
6 Sky Movies and Sky Box office also include what optional soundtracks?	Dolby Digital	1
7 What is Sky HD material broadcast using?	MPEG4	2
8 What is the proprietary system that SkyHD uses?	OpenTV	3
9 What does most of the HD material use as a standard?	DVBS2	2
1 When Sky Digital was launched in 1998 the new service used the Astra 2A satellite which was located at the 285°E orbital position unlike the analogue service which was broadcast from 192°E.
2 This was subsequently followed by more Astra satellites as well as Eutelsats Eurobird 1 now Eutelsat 33C at 285°E enabled the company to launch a new alldigital service Sky with the potential to carry hundreds of television and radio channels.
3 The old position was shared with broadcasters from several European countries while the new position at 285°E came to be used almost exclusively for channels that broadcast to the United Kingdom.
4 When was Sky Digital launched?	1998	1
5 What satellite was used when Sky digital was launched?	Astra 2A	1
6 What satellite enabled Sky Digital to launch an all new digital service?	Eutelsats Eurobird 1	2
7 How many television and radio channels could the new digital service carry?	hundreds	2
8 What is the position of the satellite that allowed sky to broadcast channels almost elclusively for the United Kingdom?	285°E	3
1 BSkyB launched its HDTV service Sky HD on 22 May 2006.
2 Prior to its launch BSkyB claimed that 40000 people had registered to receive the HD service.
3 In the week before the launch rumours started to surface that BSkyB was having supply issues with its set top box STB from manufacturer Thomson.
4 On Thursday 18 May 2006 and continuing through the weekend before launch people were reporting that BSkyB had either cancelled or rescheduled its installation.
5 Finally the BBC reported that 17000 customers had yet to receive the service due to failed deliveries.
6 On 31 March 2012 Sky announced the total number of homes with SkyHD was 4222000.
7 When did BSkyB launch its HDTV service?	22 May 2006	1
8 How many people were registered to receive the HD service prior to launch?	40 000	2
9 What was the name of the set top box manufacturer that BSkyB was having issues with?	Thomson	3
10 What was the number of customers that the BBC  reported had yet to receive the service due to failed deliveries?	17 000	5
11 What was the total number of homes Sky announced that had SkyHD in March of 2012?	4 222 000	6
1 On 8 February 2007 BSkyB announced its intention to replace its three freetoair digital terrestrial channels with four subscription channels.
2 It was proposed that these channels would offer a range of content from the BSkyB portfolio including sport including English Premier League Football films entertainment and news.
3 The announcement came a day after Setanta Sports confirmed that it would launch in March as a subscription service on the digital terrestrial platform and on the same day that NTLs services rebranded as Virgin Media.
4 However industry sources believe BSkyB will be forced to shelve plans to withdraw its channels from Freeview and replace them with subscription channels due to possible lost advertising revenue.
5 When did BSkyB announce its intention to replace its freetoair digital channels?	8 February 2007	1
6 When did Setanta Sports say it would launch as a subscription service?	March	3
7 What platform was Sentanta Sports planning on launching on?	digital terrestrial	3
8 What were NTLs services rebranded as?	Virgin Media	3
9 What does BSkyBs sport portfolio include?	English Premier League Football	2
1 Provided is a universal Ku band LNB 97510600 GHz which is fitted at the end of the dish and pointed at the correct satellite constellation most digital receivers will receive the free to air channels.
2 Some broadcasts are freetoair and unencrypted some are encrypted but do not require a monthly subscription known as freetoview some are encrypted and require a monthly subscription and some are payperview services.
3 To view the encrypted content a VideoGuard UK equipped receiver all of which are dedicated to the Sky service and cannot be used to decrypt other services needs to be used.
4 Unofficial CAMs are now available to view the service although use of them breaks the users contract with Sky and invalidates the users rights to use the card.
5 What are freetoair encrypted broadcasts known as?	freetoview	2
6 What do some encrypted broadcasts require to view?	monthly subscription	2
7 What does a receiver have to be equipped with to view encrypted content?	VideoGuard UK	3
8 What is the universal band that digital recievers will receive free to air channels on?	Ku band	1
9 What service is a VideoGuard UK equipped receiver dedicated to decrypt?	Sky	3
1 In the autumn of 1991 talks were held for the broadcast rights for Premier League for a fiveyear period from the 1992 season.
2 ITV were the current rights holders and fought hard to retain the new rights.
3 ITV had increased its offer from £18m to £34m per year to keep control of the rights.
4 BSkyB joined forces with the BBC to make a counter bid.
5 The BBC was given the highlights of most of the matches while BSkyB paying £304m for the Premier League rights would give them a monopoly of all live matches up to 60 per year from the 1992 season.
6 Murdoch described sport as a battering ram for paytelevision providing a strong customer base.
7 A few weeks after the deal ITV went to the High Court to get an injunction as it believed their bid details had been leaked before the decision was taken.
8 ITV also asked the Office of Fair Trading to investigate since it believed Rupert Murdochs media empire via its newspapers had influenced the deal.
9 A few days later neither action took effect ITV believed BSkyB was telephoned and informed of its £262m bid and Premier League advised BSkyB to increase its counter bid.
10 When were the talks held for braodcast right to the Primier league for a five year period from the 1992 season?	1991	1
11 Who were the current rights holders for the Primer League?	ITV	2
12 What did ITV increase their yearly offer for control of the rights to broadcast the Primer League to?	£34m	3
13 Who was given the highlights of most of the matches?	BBC	5
14 How much was BSkyB going to pay for the Primier League rights?	£304m	5
1 BSkyB has no veto over the presence of channels on their EPG with open access being an enforced part of their operating licence from Ofcom.
2 Any channel which can get carriage on a suitable beam of a satellite at 28° East is entitled to access to BSkyBs EPG for a fee ranging from £15–100000.
3 Thirdparty channels which opt for encryption receive discounts ranging from reduced price to free EPG entries free carriage on a BSkyB leased transponder or actual payment for being carried.
4 However even in this case BSkyB does not carry any control over the channels content or carriage issues such as picture quality.
5 Who does BSkyB have an operating license from?	Ofcom	1
6 what is the fee range for accessing BSkyBs EPG?	£15–100 000	2
7 Can BSkyB veto the presence of channels on their EPG?	no	1
8 Does BSkyB carry any control over a channels content?	not	4
9 Does BSkyB carry any control over the picture quality of a channel?	not	4
1 BSkyBs digital service was officially launched on 1 October 1998 under the name Sky Digital although smallscale tests were carried out before then.
2 At this time the use of the Sky Digital brand made an important distinction between the new service and Skys analogue services.
3 Key selling points were the improvement in picture and sound quality increased number of channels and an interactive service branded Open now called Sky Active BSkyB competed with the ONdigital later ITV Digital terrestrial offering and cable services.
4 Within 30 days over 100000 digiboxes had been sold which help bolstered BSkyBs decision to give away free digiboxes and minidishes from May 1999.
5 When was BSkyBs digital service launched?	1 October 1998	1
6 What was the name of BSkyBs digital service launched under?	Sky Digital	1
7 What did BSkyB name their interactive service?	Sky Active	3
8 Who did BSkyB compete with initially?	ONdigital	3
9 Within the 30 days how many digiboxes had been sold?	100 000	4
1 Virgin Media rebranded in 2007 from NTLTelewest started to offer a highdefinition television HDTV capable set top box although from 30 November 2006 until 30 July 2009 it only carried one linear HD channel BBC HD after the conclusion of the ITV HD trial.
2 Virgin Media has claimed that other HD channels were locked up or otherwise withheld from their platform although Virgin Media did in fact have an option to carry Channel 4 HD in the future.
3 Nonetheless the linear channels were not offered Virgin Media instead concentrating on its Video On Demand service to carry a modest selection of HD content.
4 Virgin Media has nevertheless made a number of statements over the years suggesting that more linear HD channels are on the way.

1 BSkyBs directtohome satellite service became available in 10 million homes in 2010 Europes first payTV platform in to achieve that milestone.

3 The target was first announced in August 2004 since then an additional 24m customers had subscribed to BSkyBs directtohome service.

1 The Daily Mail newspaper reported in 2012 that the UK governments benefits agency was checking claimants Sky TV bills to establish if a woman in receipt of benefits as a single mother is wrongly claiming to be living alone – as it claimed subscription to sports channels would betray a mans presence in the household.

1 The agreements include fixed annual carriage fees of £30m for the channels with both channel suppliers able to secure additional capped payments if their channels meet certain performancerelated targets.
2 Currently there is no indication as to whether the new deal includes the additional Video On Demand and High Definition content which had previously been offered by BSkyB.

1 The economy of Victoria is highly diversified service sectors including financial and property services health education wholesale retail hospitality and manufacturing constitute the majority of employment.
2 Victorias total gross state product GSP is ranked second in Australia although Victoria is ranked fourth in terms of GSP per capita because of its limited mining activity.
3 Culturally Melbourne is home to a number of museums art galleries and theatres and is also described as the sporting capital of Australia.
4 The Melbourne Cricket Ground is the largest stadium in Australia and the host of the 1956 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Commonwealth Games.
5 The ground is also considered the spiritual home of Australian cricket and Australian rules football and hosts the grand final of the Australian Football League AFL each year usually drawing crowds of over 95000 people.
6 Victoria includes eight public universities with the oldest the University of Melbourne having been founded in 1853.
7 What kind of economy does Victoria have?	diversified	1
8 Where according to gross state product does Victoria rank in Australia?	second	2
9 At what rank does GPS per capita set Victoria?	fourth	2
10 What city in Victoria is called the sporting capital of Australia?	Melbourne	4
11 What is the largest stadium in Australia?	Melbourne Cricket Ground	4
1 Immigrants arrived from all over the world to search for gold especially from Ireland and China.
2 Many Chinese miners worked in Victoria and their legacy is particularly strong in Bendigo and its environs.
3 Although there was some racism directed at them there was not the level of antiChinese violence that was seen at the Lambing Flat riots in New South Wales.
4 However there was a riot at Buckland Valley near Bright in 1857.
5 Conditions on the gold fields were cramped and unsanitary an outbreak of typhoid at Buckland Valley in 1854 killed over 1000 miners.
6 Where is the Asian influence strongest in Victoria?	Bendigo	2
7 Where were the Lambing Flat riots?	New South Wales	3
8 Where was the 1857 riot?	Buckland Valley	4
9 How many miners died in the typhoid outbreak of 1854?	over 1 000	5
10 What were the conditions for miners in the gold fields in Victoria?	cramped and unsanitary	5
1 In November 2006 the Victorian Legislative Council elections were held under a new multimember proportional representation system.
2 The State of Victoria was divided into eight electorates with each electorate represented by five representatives elected by Single Transferable Vote.
3 The total number of upper house members was reduced from 44 to 40 and their term of office is now the same as the lower house members—four years.
4 Elections for the Victorian Parliament are now fixed and occur in November every four years.
5 Prior to the 2006 election the Legislative Council consisted of 44 members elected to eightyear terms from 22 twomember electorates.
6 What kind of representational system does the Victorian Legislative Council have?	multimember proportional	1
7 How many electorates does the State of Victoria have?	eight	2
8 How many representatives does each electorate have?	five	2
9 What is the term of office for each house member?	four years	3
10 How often are elections held for the Victorian Parliament?	every four years	4
1 The centreleft Australian Labor Party ALP the centreright Liberal Party of Australia the ruralbased National Party of Australia and the environmentalist Australian Greens are Victorias main political parties.
2 Traditionally Labor is strongest in Melbournes working class western and northern suburbs and the regional cities of Ballarat Bendigo and Geelong.
3 The Liberals main support lies in Melbournes more affluent eastern and outer suburbs and some rural and regional centres.
4 The Nationals are strongest in Victorias North Western and Eastern rural regional areas.
5 The Greens who won their first lower house seats in 2014 are strongest in inner Melbourne.
6 What political party is strongest in Melbournes working class suburbs?	Australian Labor Party	1
7 What party is strongest in Melbournes affluent areas?	Liberal Party	1
8 Which party is strongest in Victorias northwestern and eastern regions?	National Party	1
9 What party rules in Melbournes inner regions?	The Greens	5
10 What party is favored in Bedigo and Geelong?	Labor	2
1 About 611 of Victorians describe themselves as Christian.
2 Roman Catholics form the single largest religious group in the state with 267 of the Victorian population followed by Anglicans and members of the Uniting Church.
3 Buddhism is the states largest nonChristian religion with 168637 members as of the most recent census.
4 Victoria is also home of 152775 Muslims and 45150 Jews.
5 Hinduism is the fastest growing religion.
6 Around 20 of Victorians claim no religion.
7 Amongst those who declare a religious affiliation church attendance is low.
8 What percentage of Victorians are Christian?	611	1
9 How many Victorians are Catholic?	267	2
10 What is Victorias largest nonChristian religion?	Buddhism	3
11 How many Victorians are Buddhist?	168 637	3
12 How many Victorians are nonreligious?	20	6
1 Victoria abbreviated as Vic is a state in the southeast of Australia.
2 Victoria is Australias most densely populated state and its secondmost populous state overall.
3 Most of its population is concentrated in the area surrounding Port Phillip Bay which includes the metropolitan area of its capital and largest city Melbourne which is Australias secondlargest city.
4 Geographically the smallest state on the Australian mainland Victoria is bordered by Bass Strait and Tasmania to the southnote 1 New South Wales to the north the Tasman Sea to the east and South Australia to the west.
5 Where in Australia is Victoria located?	southeast	1
6 How does Victoria rank as to population density?	most densely populated	2
7 How populous is Victoria compared to other Australian states?	second	2
8 What city is the capital of Victoria?	Melbourne	3
9 Compared to other Australian cities what is the size of Melbourne?	secondlargest	3
1 Prior to European settlement the area now constituting Victoria was inhabited by a large number of Aboriginal peoples collectively known as the Koori.
2 With Great Britain having claimed the entire Australian continent east of the 135th meridian east in 1788 Victoria was included in the wider colony of New South Wales.
3 The first settlement in the area occurred in 1803 at Sullivan Bay and much of what is now Victoria was included in the Port Phillip District in 1836 an administrative division of New South Wales.
4 Victoria was officially created a separate colony in 1851 and achieved selfgovernment in 1855.
5 The Victorian gold rush in the 1850s and 1860s significantly increased both the population and wealth of the colony and by the Federation of Australia in 1901 Melbourne had become the largest city and leading financial centre in Australasia.
6 Melbourne also served as capital of Australia until the construction of Canberra in 1927 with the Federal Parliament meeting in Melbournes Parliament House and all principal offices of the federal government being based in Melbourne.
7 What is the term for the original Aboriginal people of Victoria?	Koori	1
8 When did Great Britain claim Australia?	1788	2
9 Where was Victoria first set to be located in Australia?	New South Wales	2
10 Where was the first settlement in Victoria?	Sullivan Bay	3
11 When was Victoria first settled?	1803	3
1 More than 26000 square kilometres 10000 sq mi of Victorian farmland are sown for grain mostly in the states west.
2 More than 50 of this area is sown for wheat 33 for barley and 7 for oats.
3 A further 6000 square kilometres 2300 sq mi is sown for hay.
4 In 2003–04 Victorian farmers produced more than 3 million tonnes of wheat and 2 million tonnes of barley.
5 Victorian farms produce nearly 90 of Australian pears and third of apples.
6 It is also a leader in stone fruit production.
7 The main vegetable crops include asparagus broccoli carrots potatoes and tomatoes.
8 Last year 121200 tonnes of pears and 270000 tonnes of tomatoes were produced.
9 How much Victorian farmland is farmed in grains?	26 000 square kilometres	1
10 What percentage of farmland grows wheat?	50	2
11 How much of Victorias farmland grows hay?	6 000 square kilometres	3
12 How much does Victoria produce in Australian pears?	90	5
13 How many tonnes of tomatoes does Victoria produce?	270 000	8
1 Victoria has a written constitution enacted in 1975 but based on the 1855 colonial constitution passed by the United Kingdom Parliament as the Victoria Constitution Act 1855 which establishes the Parliament as the states lawmaking body for matters coming under state responsibility.
2 The Victorian Constitution can be amended by the Parliament of Victoria except for certain entrenched provisions that require either an absolute majority in both houses a threefifths majority in both houses or the approval of the Victorian people in a referendum depending on the provision.
3 When did Victoria enact its constitution?	1975	1
4 On what is Victorias constitution based ?	1855 colonial constitution	1
5 What group can amend the Victorian constitution?	Parliament of Victoria	2
6 What are the exceptions in the constitution  that require special considerations to amend?	entrenched provisions	2
7 What document formed the Parliament of Victoria?	Victoria Constitution Act 1855	1
1 The Mallee and upper Wimmera are Victorias warmest regions with hot winds blowing from nearby semideserts.
2 Average temperatures exceed 32 °C 90 °F during summer and 15 °C 59 °F in winter.
3 Except at cool mountain elevations the inland monthly temperatures are 2–7 °C 4–13 °F warmer than around Melbourne see chart.
4 Victorias highest maximum temperature since World War II of 488 °C 1198 °F was recorded in Hopetoun on 7 February 2009 during the 2009 southeastern Australia heat wave.
5 What is the weather type of Mallee and upper Wimmera?	warmest regions	1
6 What does the average temperatures exceed in the summer?	32 °C	2
7 How cold does this region of Victoria get in the winner?	15 °C	2
8 What is Victorias highest monthly temperature?	488 °C	4
9 When was the heatwave in which Hopetoun recorded its highest temperature?	2009	4
1 Victorian schools are either publicly or privately funded.
2 Public schools also known as state or government schools are funded and run directly by the Victoria Department of Education .
3 Students do not pay tuition fees but some extra costs are levied.
4 Private feepaying schools include parish schools run by the Roman Catholic Church and independent schools similar to British public schools.
5 Independent schools are usually affiliated with Protestant churches.
6 Victoria also has several private Jewish and Islamic primary and secondary schools.
7 Private schools also receive some public funding.
8 All schools must comply with governmentset curriculum standards.
9 In addition Victoria has four government selective schools Melbourne High School for boys MacRobertson Girls High School for girls the coeducational schools John Monash Science School Nossal High School and Suzanne Cory High School and The Victorian College of the Arts Secondary School.
10 Students at these schools are exclusively admitted on the basis of an academic selective entry test.

12 What organization runs the public schools in Victoria?	Victoria Department of Education	2

14 What church runs some private schools in Victoria?	Roman Catholic Church	4

1 Historically Victoria has been the base for the manufacturing plants of the major car brands Ford Toyota and Holden however closure announcements by all three companies in the 21st century will mean that Australia will no longer be a base for the global car industry with Toyotas statement in February 2014 outlining a closure year of 2017.
2 Holdens announcement occurred in May 2013 followed by Fords decision in December of the same year Fords Victorian plants—in Broadmeadows and Geelong—will close in October 2016.

1 Victoria contains many topographically geologically and climatically diverse areas ranging from the wet temperate climate of Gippsland in the southeast to the snowcovered Victorian alpine areas which rise to almost 2000 m 6600 ft with Mount Bogong the highest peak at 1986 m 6516 ft.
2 There are extensive semiarid plains to the west and northwest.
3 There is an extensive series of river systems in Victoria.
4 Most notable is the Murray River system.
5 Other rivers include Ovens River Goulburn River Patterson River King River Campaspe River Loddon River Wimmera River Elgin River Barwon River Thomson River Snowy River Latrobe River Yarra River Maribyrnong River Mitta River Hopkins River Merri River and Kiewa River.
6 The state symbols include the pink heath state flower Leadbeaters possum state animal and the helmeted honeyeater state bird.
