10 What type of topological systems are found in numbers in Victoria?	river systems	3
11 What is the Victoria state bird?	helmeted honeyeater	6
1 The Victorian Alps in the northeast are the coldest part of Victoria.
2 The Alps are part of the Great Dividing Range mountain system extending eastwest through the centre of Victoria.
3 Average temperatures are less than 9 °C 48 °F in winter and below 0 °C 32 °F in the highest parts of the ranges.
4 The states lowest minimum temperature of −117 °C 109 °F was recorded at Omeo on 13 June 1965 and again at Falls Creek on 3 July 1970.
5 Temperature extremes for the state are listed in the table below.

1 Rail transport in Victoria is provided by several private and public railway operators who operate over governmentowned lines.

1 Politically Victoria has 37 seats in the Australian House of Representatives and 12 seats in the Australian Senate.
2 At state level the Parliament of Victoria consists of the Legislative Assembly the lower house and the Legislative Council the upper house.
3 Victoria is currently governed by the Labor Party with Daniel Andrews the current Premier.
4 The personal representative of the Queen of Australia in the state is the Governor of Victoria currently Linda Dessau.
5 Local government is concentrated in 79 municipal districts including 33 cities although a number of unincorporated areas still exist which are administered directly by the state.

1 On 1 July 1851 writs were issued for the election of the first Victorian Legislative Council and the absolute independence of Victoria from New South Wales was established proclaiming a new Colony of Victoria.
2 Days later still in 1851 gold was discovered near Ballarat and subsequently at Bendigo.
3 Later discoveries occurred at many sites across Victoria.
4 This triggered one of the largest gold rushes the world has ever seen.
5 The colony grew rapidly in both population and economic power.
6 In ten years the population of Victoria increased sevenfold from 76000 to 540000.
7 All sorts of gold records were produced including the richest shallow alluvial goldfield in the world and the largest gold nugget.
8 Victoria produced in the decade 1851–1860 20 million ounces of gold one third of the worlds outputcitation needed.
9 On what date was Victoria declared independent from New South Wales?	1 July 1851	1
10 When was gold found near Ballarat?	1851	2
11 What did the finding of gold in Victoria cause?	gold rush	4
12 How much did the population of Victoria increase in ten years after the discovery of gold?	sevenfold	6
13 How much gold did Victoria produce in the years of 18511860?	20 million ounces	8
1 As of August 2010 Victoria had 1548 public schools 489 Catholic schools and 214 independent schools.
2 Just under 540800 students were enrolled in public schools and just over 311800 in private schools.
3 Over 61 per cent of private students attend Catholic schools.
4 More than 462000 students were enrolled in primary schools and more than 390000 in secondary schools.
5 Retention rates for the final two years of secondary school were 77 per cent for public school students and 90 per cent for private school students.
6 Victoria has about 63519 fulltime teachers.

1 Victoria is the centre of dairy farming in Australia.
2 It is home to 60 of Australias 3 million dairy cattle and produces nearly twothirds of the nations milk almost 64 billion litres.
3 The state also has 24 million beef cattle with more than 22 million cattle and calves slaughtered each year.
4 In 2003–04 Victorian commercial fishing crews and aquaculture industry produced 11634 tonnes of seafood valued at nearly A109 million.
5 Blacklipped abalone is the mainstay of the catch bringing in A46 million followed by southern rock lobster worth A137 million.
6 Most abalone and rock lobster is exported to Asia.

1 There are also several smaller freight operators and numerous tourist railways operating over lines which were once parts of a stateowned system.
2 Victorian lines mainly use the 1600 mm 5 ft 3 in broad gauge.

1 After the founding of the colony of New South Wales in 1788 Australia was divided into an eastern half named New South Wales and a western half named New Holland under the administration of the colonial government in Sydney.
2 The first European settlement in the area later known as Victoria was established in October 1803 under LieutenantGovernor David Collins at Sullivan Bay on Port Phillip.
3 It consisted of 402 people 5 Government officials 9 officers of marines 2 drummers and 39 privates 5 soldiers wives and a child 307 convicts 17 convicts wives and 7 children.
4 They had been sent from England in HMS Calcutta under the command of Captain Daniel Woodriff principally out of fear that the French who had been exploring the area might establish their own settlement and thereby challenge British rights to the continent.
5 When was the colony of New South Wales founded?	1788	1
6 What was the name of the eastern half of the colony of 1788?	New South Wales	1
7 What name was given to the western half of the colony?	New Holland	1
8 Where was the location of the colonial government that administered the new colony?	Sydney	1
1 In 1854 at Ballarat there was an armed rebellion against the government of Victoria by miners protesting against mining taxes the Eureka Stockade.
2 This was crushed by British troops but the discontents prompted colonial authorities to reform the administration particularly reducing the hated mining licence fees and extend the franchise.
3 Within a short time the Imperial Parliament granted Victoria responsible government with the passage of the Colony of Victoria Act 1855.
4 Some of the leaders of the Eureka rebellion went on to become members of the Victorian Parliament.
5 When was there a armed protest at Ballarat about mining taxes?	1854	1
6 What armed group stopped the uprising at Ballarat?	British troops	2
7 What was the incident over taxes at Ballarat called?	Eureka Stockade	1
8 What did colonial authorities  reduce because of the Ballarat revolt?	mining licence fees	2
9 The passage of what act gave Victoria its own government?	Colony of Victoria Act	3
1 The Premier of Victoria is the leader of the political party or coalition with the most seats in the Legislative Assembly.
2 The Premier is the public face of government and with cabinet sets the legislative and political agenda.
3 Cabinet consists of representatives elected to either house of parliament.
4 It is responsible for managing areas of government that are not exclusively the Commonwealths by the Australian Constitution such as education health and law enforcement.
5 The current Premier of Victoria is Daniel Andrews.

1 Huguenot numbers peaked near an estimated two million by 1562 concentrated mainly in the southern and central parts of France about oneeighth the number of French Catholics.
2 As Huguenots gained influence and more openly displayed their faith Catholic hostility grew in spite of increasingly liberal political concessions and edicts of toleration from the French crown.
3 A series of religious conflicts followed known as the Wars of Religion fought intermittently from 1562 to 1598.
4 The wars finally ended with the granting of the Edict of Nantes which granted the Huguenots substantial religious political and military autonomy.
5 Where was Frances Huguenot population largely centered?	the southern and central parts of France	1
6 What was the proportion of Huguenots to Catholics at their peak?	about oneeighth the number	1
7 When were the Wars of Religion fought?	from 1562 to 1598	3
8 What treaty ended the Wars of Religion?	the Edict of Nantes	4
9 What did this agreement do?	granted the Huguenots substantial religious  political and military autonomy	4
1 A term used originally in derision Huguenot has unclear origins.
2 Various hypotheses have been promoted.
3 The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besançon Hugues died 1532 and the religiously conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Huisgenoten literally housemates referring to the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse Confederates as in a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy.
4 Geneva was John Calvins adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement.
5 In Geneva Hugues though Catholic was a leader of the Confederate Party so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the citystate of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation.
6 The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church involved in the Amboise plot of 1560 a foiled attempt to wrest power in France from the influential House of Guise.
7 The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss.
8 Thus Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.
9 citation needed.
10 The term Huguenot was originally meant to confer?	derision	1
11 What Swiss city was the center of the Calvinist movement?	Geneva	4
12 The term may be related to what politician from Switzerland?	Besançon Hugues	3
13 What name was given to the plot to usurp power from the French House of Guise?	Amboise plot	6
14 When did this attempt take place?	1560	6
1 The availability of the Bible in vernacular languages was important to the spread of the Protestant movement and development of the Reformed church in France.
2 The country had a long history of struggles with the papacy by the time the Protestant Reformation finally arrived.
3 Around 1294 a French version of the Scriptures was prepared by the Roman Catholic priest Guyard de Moulin.
4 A twovolume illustrated folio paraphrase version based on his manuscript by Jean de Rély was printed in Paris in 1487.
5 What helped spread Protestantism in France?	availability of the Bible in vernacular languages	1
6 When did the first French language bible appear?	Around 1294	3
7 Who translated this version of the scriptures?	Guyard de Moulin	3
8 An illustrated paraphrased version of this appeared when?	1487	4
9 Jean De Relys illustrated Frenchlanguage scriptures were first published in what city?	Paris	4
1 Montpellier was among the most important of the 66 villes de sûreté that the Edict of 1598 granted to the Huguenots.
2 The citys political institutions and the university were all handed over to the Huguenots.
3 Tension with Paris led to a siege by the royal army in 1622.
4 Peace terms called for the dismantling of the citys fortifications.
5 A royal citadel was built and the university and consulate were taken over by the Catholic party.
6 Even before the Edict of Alès 1629 Protestant rule was dead and the ville de sûreté was no more.
7 citation needed.
8 What were the towns granted to the Huguenots in 1598 collectively called?	villes de sûreté	1
9 What was the most important of these cities or towns?	Montpellier	1
10 What proclamation officially ended limited Huguenot autonomy?	Edict of Alès	6
11 France laid siege to Montpellier in what year?	1622	3
12 When was this proclamation issued?	1629	6
1 Individual Huguenots settled at the Cape of Good Hope from as early as 1671 with the arrival of François Villion Viljoen.
2 The first Huguenot to arrive at the Cape of Good Hope was however Maria de la Queillerie wife of commander Jan van Riebeeck and daughter of a Walloon church minister who arrived on 6 April 1652 to establish a settlement at what is today Cape Town.
3 The couple left for the Far East ten years later.
4 On 31 December 1687 the first organised group of Huguenots set sail from the Netherlands to the Dutch East India Company post at the Cape of Good Hope.
5 The largest portion of the Huguenots to settle in the Cape arrived between 1688 and 1689 in seven ships as part of the organised migration but quite a few arrived as late as 1700 thereafter the numbers declined and only small groups arrived at a time.
6 Where did the first Huguenot colonists settle?	at the Cape of Good Hope	1
7 What modern city is located on the original Huguenot colony?	Cape Town	2
8 Who was the first Huguenot to arrive at the Cape of Good Hope?	Maria de la Queillerie	2
9 What trading company helped settle Huguenots near the Cape?	Dutch East India Company	4
10 The number of new Huguenot colonists declined after what year?	1700	5
1 Barred by the government from settling in New France Huguenots led by Jessé de Forest sailed to North America in 1624 and settled instead in the Dutch colony of New Netherland later incorporated into New York and New Jersey as well as Great Britains colonies including Nova Scotia.
2 A number of New Amsterdams families were of Huguenot origin often having emigrated as refugees to the Netherlands in the previous century.
3 In 1628 the Huguenots established a congregation as LÉglise française à la NouvelleAmsterdam the French church in New Amsterdam.
4 This parish continues today as LEglise du SaintEsprit part of the Episcopal Anglican communion and welcomes Francophone New Yorkers from all over the world.
5 Upon their arrival in New Amsterdam Huguenots were offered land directly across from Manhattan on Long Island for a permanent settlement and chose the harbor at the end of Newtown Creek becoming the first Europeans to live in Brooklyn then known as Boschwick in the neighborhood now known as Bushwick.
6 When did Huguenots colonize in North America?	1624	1
7 Who led the North American Huguenot colonial expedition?	Jessé de Forest	1
8 What was the name of the first Huguenot church in the New World?	LÉglise française à la NouvelleAmsterdam	3
9 By what name is that first Huguenot church known today?	LEglise du SaintEsprit	4
10 The Huguenots were the first Europeans to live in what modern New York borough?	Brooklyn	5
1 In the early years many Huguenots also settled in the area of presentday Charleston South Carolina.
2 In 1685 Rev.
3 Elie Prioleau from the town of Pons in France was among the first to settle there.
4 He became pastor of the first Huguenot church in North America in that city.
5 After the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685 several Huguenot families of Norman and Carolingian nobility and descent including Edmund Bohun of Suffolk England from the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne Jean Postell of Dieppe France Alexander Pepin Antoine Poitevin of Orsement France and Jacques de Bordeaux of Grenoble immigrated to the Charleston Orange district.
6 They were very successful at marriage and property speculation.
7 After petitioning the British Crown in 1697 for the right to own land in the Baronies they prospered as slave owners on the Cooper Ashepoo Ashley and Santee River plantations they purchased from the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger.
8 Some of their descendants moved into the Deep South and Texas where they developed new plantations.
9 Where in South Carolina did Huguenot nobility settle?	the Charleston Orange district	5
10 From whom did the Huguenots in South Carolina purchase land from?	the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger	7
11 Charleston settler Elie Prioleau was from what French town?	Pons	3
12 When did the Huguenots secure the right to own land in the Baronies?	1697	7
13 What southern city did the Huguenots settle near?	Charleston  South Carolina	1
1 Stadtholder William III of Orange who later became King of England emerged as the strongest opponent of king Louis XIV after the French attacked the Dutch Republic in 1672.
2 William formed the League of Augsburg as a coalition to oppose Louis and the French state.
3 Consequently many Huguenots considered the wealthy and Calvinist Dutch Republic which led the opposition to Louis XIV as the most attractive country for exile after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.
4 They also found many Frenchspeaking Calvinist churches there.
5 Who was Louis XIVs main rival?	William III of Orange	1
6 William would eventually gain what throne?	King of England	1
7 What coalition rose up to oppose Louis XIVs France?	League of Augsburg	2
8 With what European country did the Huguenots feel kinship for emigration to?	Dutch Republic	3
9 When did France and the Dutch fight in the 17th century?	1672	1
1 Renewed religious warfare in the 1620s caused the political and military privileges of the Huguenots to be abolished following their defeat.
2 They retained the religious provisions of the Edict of Nantes until the rule of Louis XIV who progressively increased persecution of them until he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau 1685 which abolished all legal recognition of Protestantism in France and forced the Huguenots to convert.
3 While nearly threequarters eventually were killed  or submitted roughly 500000 Huguenots had fled France by the early 18th centurycitation needed.
4 What proclamation abolished protestantism in France?	Edict of Fontainebleau	2
5 When was this edict declared?	1685	2
6 Which French kind issued this declaration?	Louis XIV	2
7 How many Huguenots fled France by the 1700s?	500 000	3
1 The Catholic Church in France and many of its members opposed the Huguenots.
2 Some Huguenot preachers and congregants were attacked as they attempted to meet for worship.
3 The height of this persecution was the St Bartholomews Day massacre when 5000 to 30000 were killed although there were also underlying political reasons for this as well as some of the Huguenots were nobles trying to establish separate centers of power in southern France.
4 Retaliating against the French Catholics the Huguenots had their own militia.
5 What group specifically opposed the Huguenots?	Catholic Church in France	1
6 What event was the worst example of Huguenot persecution?	St Bartholomews Day massacre	3
7 How many Huguenots were killed during this purge?	5 000 to 30 000	3
8 How did the Huguenots defend themselves?	their own militia	4
9 What was a nonreligious reason for the massacre?	some of the Huguenots were nobles trying to establish separate centers of power in southern France	3
1 By 1620 the Huguenots were on the defensive and the government increasingly applied pressure.
2 A series of three small civil wars known as the Huguenot rebellions broke out mainly in southwestern France between 1621 and 1629 revolted against royal authority.
3 The uprising occurred a decade following the death of Henry IV a Huguenot before converting to Catholicism who had protected Protestants through the Edict of Nantes.
4 His successor Louis XIII under the regency of his Italian Catholic mother Marie de Medici became more intolerant of Protestantism.
5 The Huguenots respond by establishing independent political and military structures establishing diplomatic contacts with foreign powers and openly revolting against central power.
6 The rebellions were implacably suppressed by the French Crown.
7 citation needed.
8 When did these rebellions take place?	between 1621 and 1629	2
9 Where did these uprisings take place?	southwestern France	2
10 What King and former Huguenot looked out for the welfare of the group?	Henry IV	3
11 Which successor to Henry resumed persecution of the Huguenots?	Louis XIII	4
12 What were the civil wars caused by the Huguenots called?	Huguenot rebellions	2
1 Approximately one million Protestants in modern France represent some 2 of its population.
2 Most are concentrated in Alsace in northeast France and the Cévennes mountain region in the south who still regard themselves as Huguenots to this day.
3 citation needed A diaspora of French Australians still considers itself Huguenot even after centuries of exile.
4 Long integrated into Australian society it is encouraged by the Huguenot Society of Australia to embrace and conserve its cultural heritage aided by the Societys genealogical research services.
5 How many protestants live in France today?	one million	1
6 What percentage of Frances population is protestant today?	2	1
7 What northern province in France has a large protestant population?	Alsace	2
8 What is the southern region where protestants are concentrated?	Cévennes	2
9 What country currently has a group who call themselves Huguenots?	Australia	4
1 Huguenot immigrants did not disperse or settle in different parts of the country but rather formed three societies or congregations one in the city of New York another 21 miles north of New York in a town which they named New Rochelle and a third further upstate in New Paltz.
2 The Huguenot Street Historic District in New Paltz has been designated a National Historic Landmark site and contains the oldest street in the United States of America.
3 A small group of Huguenots also settled on the south shore of Staten Island along the New York Harbor for which the current neighborhood of Huguenot was named.
4 What city north of New York was settled by Huguenots?	New Rochelle	1
5 What town in upstate New York was settled by Huguenots?	New Paltz	1
6 What Huguenot area is designated as a historical landmark?	Huguenot Street Historic District in New Paltz	2
7 What is located within this district?	the oldest street in the United States of America	2
8 In what borough is there a neighborhood called Huguenot?	Staten Island	3
1 After the revocation of the Edict of Nantes the Dutch Republic received the largest group of Huguenot refugees an estimated total of 75000 to 100000 people.
2 Amongst them were 200 clergy.
3 Many came from the region of the Cévennes for instance the village of FraissinetdeLozère.
4 This was a huge influx as the entire population of the Dutch Republic amounted to ca.
5 2 million at that time.
6 Around 1700 it is estimated that nearly 25 of the Amsterdam population was Huguenot.
7 citation needed In 1705 Amsterdam and the area of West Frisia were the first areas to provide full citizens rights to Huguenot immigrants followed by the Dutch Republic in 1715.
8 Huguenots intermarried with Dutch from the outset.

1 In this last connection the name could suggest the derogatory inference of superstitious worship popular fancy held that Huguon the gate of King Hugo was haunted by the ghost of le roi Huguet regarded by Roman Catholics as an infamous scoundrel and other spirits who instead of being in Purgatory came back to harm the living at night.
2 It was in this place in Tours that the prétendus réformés these supposedly reformed habitually gathered at night both for political purposes and for prayer and singing psalms.
3 Such explanations have been traced to the contemporary Reguier de la Plancha d 1560 who in De lEstat de France offered the following account as to the origin of the name as cited by The Cape Monthly.

1 Other evidence of the Walloons and Huguenots in Canterbury includes a block of houses in Turnagain Lane where weavers windows survive on the top floor as many Huguenots worked as weavers.
2 The Weavers a halftimbered house by the river was the site of a weaving school from the late 16th century to about 1830.
3 It has been adapted as a restaurant—see illustration above.
4 The house derives its name from a weaving school which was moved there in the last years of the 19th century reviving an earlier use.
5 Others refugees practised the variety of occupations necessary to sustain the community as distinct from the indigenous population.
6 Such economic separation was the condition of the refugees initial acceptance in the City.
7 They also settled elsewhere in Kent particularly Sandwich Faversham and Maidstone—towns in which there used to be refugee churches.

1 A number of Huguenots served as mayors in Dublin Cork Youghal and Waterford in the 17th and 18th centuries.
2 Numerous signs of Huguenot presence can still be seen with names still in use and with areas of the main towns and cities named after the people who settled there.

5 At the time they constituted the majority of the townspeople.

1 The exodus of Huguenots from France created a brain drain as many Huguenots had occupied important places in society.
2 The kingdom did not fully recover for years.
3 The French crowns refusal to allow nonCatholics to settle in New France may help to explain that colonys slow rate of population growth compared to that of the neighbouring British colonies which opened settlement to religious dissenters.
4 By the time of the French and Indian War the North American front of the Seven Years War a sizeable population of Huguenot descent lived in the British colonies and many participated in the British defeat of New France in 175960.
5 What is the common term for the loss of key members of French society to Huguenot emigration?	brain drain	1
6 What was the name of Frances primary colony in the New World?	New France	3
7 What persons were not allowed to settle in New France?	nonCatholics	3
8 The French and Indian War was the New World aspect of what European conflict?	Seven Years War	4
9 When did the British defeat New France?	175960	4
1 The pattern of warfare followed by brief periods of peace continued for nearly another quartercentury.
2 The warfare was definitively quelled in 1598 when Henry of Navarre having succeeded to the French throne as Henry IV and having recanted Protestantism in favour of Roman Catholicism issued the Edict of Nantes.
3 The Edict reaffirmed Catholicism as the state religion of France but granted the Protestants equality with Catholics under the throne and a degree of religious and political freedom within their domains.
4 The Edict simultaneously protected Catholic interests by discouraging the founding of new Protestant churches in Catholiccontrolled regions.
5 citation needed.
6 What was Henry IV known as before taking the throne?	Henry of Navarre	2
7 When did Henry issue the Edict of Nantes?	1598	2
8 What did the Edict do for Huguenots in France?	granted the Protestants equality with Catholics	3
9 The edict protected Catholics by discouraging what?	the founding of new Protestant churches	4
10 What religion did Henry renounce upon ascending the throne?	Protestantism	2
1 The revocation forbade Protestant services required education of children as Catholics and prohibited emigration.
2 It proved disastrous to the Huguenots and costly for France.
3 It precipitated civil bloodshed ruined commerce and resulted in the illegal flight from the country of hundreds of thousands of Protestants many of whom became intellectuals doctors and business leaders in Britain as well as Holland Prussia and South Africa.
4 Four thousand emigrated to the North American colonies where they settled in New York and Virginia especially.
5 The English welcomed the French refugees providing money from both government and private agencies to aid their relocation.
6 Those Huguenots who stayed in France became Catholics and were called new converts.
7 What was required of Huguenot children after the Edict was revoked?	education of children as Catholics	1
8 How did the revocation restrict Huguenot travel?	prohibited emigration	1
9 How many Huguenots emigrated to North America as colonists?	Four thousand	4
10 What were Huguenots who stayed in France eventually known as?	new converts	6
11 Besides Britain and North America where else did Huguenot refugees settle?	Holland  Prussia  and South Africa	3
1 The first Huguenots to leave France sought freedom from persecution in Switzerland and the Netherlands.
2 citation needed A group of Huguenots was part of the French colonisers who arrived in Brazil in 1555 to found France Antarctique.
3 A couple of ships with around 500 people arrived at the Guanabara Bay presentday Rio de Janeiro and settled in a small island.
4 A fort named Fort Coligny was built to protect them from attack from the Portuguese troops and Brazilian Native Americans.
5 It was an attempt to establish a French colony in South America.
6 The fort was destroyed in 1560 by the Portuguese who captured part of the Huguenots.
7 The Portuguese threatened the prisoners with death if they did not convert to Catholicism.
8 The Huguenots of Guanabara as they are now known produced a declaration of faith to express their beliefs to the Portuguese.
9 This was their death sentence.
10 This document the Guanabara Confession of Faith became the first Protestant confession of faith in the whole of the Americas.
11 citation needed.
12 What were the first two destinations of Huguenot emigres?	Switzerland and the Netherlands	1
13 When was the French colony in modern day Brazil founded?	1555	2
14 What was the Brazilian French colony called?	France Antarctique	2
15 In what year was Fort Coligny destroyed?	1560	6
16 By what document did the Huguenots confess their faith to the Portuguese in Brazil?	the Guanabara Confession of Faith	10

1 Paul Revere was descended from Huguenot refugees as was Henry Laurens who signed the Articles of Confederation for South Carolina Jack Jouett who made the ride from Cuckoo Tavern to warn Thomas Jefferson and others that Tarleton and his men were on their way to arrest him for crimes against the king Francis Marion and a number of other leaders of the American Revolution and later statesmen.
2 The last active Huguenot congregation in North America worships in Charleston South Carolina at a church that dates to 1844.
3 The Huguenot Society of America maintains Manakin Episcopal Church in Virginia as an historic shrine with occasional services.
4 The Society has chapters in numerous states with the one in Texas being the largest.
5 What Revolutionary War midnight rider was a Huguenot descendant?	Paul Revere	1
6 What signer of the Articles of Confederation was descended from Huguenots?	Henry Laurens	1
7 In what city is the last Huguenot congregation in the US?	Charleston  South Carolina	2
8 What church in Virginia is maintained by Huguenots as a historic shrine?	Manakin Episcopal Church	3
9 In what state is the largest Huguenot Society located?	Texas	4
1 Some Huguenots settled in Bedfordshire one of the main centres of the British lace industry at the time.
2 Although 19th century sources have asserted that some of these refugees were lacemakers and contributed to the East Midlands lace industry this is contentious.
3 The only reference to immigrant lacemakers in this period is of twentyfive widows who settled in Dover and there is no contemporary documentation to support there being Huguenot lacemakers in Bedfordshire.
4 The implication that the style of lace known as Bucks Point demonstrates a Huguenot influence being a combination of Mechlin patterns on Lille ground is fallacious what is now known as Mechlin lace did not develop until first half of the eighteenth century and lace with Mechlin patterns and Lille ground did not appear until the end of the 18th century when it was widely copied throughout Europe.
5 What industry was centered in Bedfordshire?	lace	1
6 What style of lace is erroneously believed by some to have Huguenot influence?	Bucks Point	4
7 What reference is there to Huguenot lacemakers in the 19th century?	twentyfive widows who settled in Dover	3
8 When did Mechlin lace develop?	first half of the eighteenth century	4
1 In Berlin the Huguenots created two new neighbourhoods Dorotheenstadt and Friedrichstadt.
2 By 1700 onefifth of the citys population was French speaking.
3 The Berlin Huguenots preserved the French language in their church services for nearly a century.
4 They ultimately decided to switch to German in protest against the occupation of Prussia by Napoleon in 180607.
5 Many of their descendents rose to positions of prominence.
6 Several congregations were founded such as those of Fredericia Denmark Berlin Stockholm Hamburg Frankfurt Helsinki and Emden.

11 What other Northern European cities had Huguenot congregations?	Fredericia Denmark  Berlin  Stockholm  Hamburg  Frankfurt  Helsinki  and Emden	6
1 After this Huguenots with estimates ranging from 200000 to 1000000 fled to surrounding Protestant countries England the Netherlands Switzerland Norway Denmark and Prussia — whose Calvinist Great Elector Frederick William welcomed them to help rebuild his warravaged and underpopulated country.
2 Following this exodus Huguenots remained in large numbers in only one region of France the rugged Cévennes region in the south.
3 In the early 18th century a regional group known as the Camisards who were Huguenots rioted against the Catholic Church in the region burning churches and killing clergy.
4 It took French troops years to hunt down and destroy all the bands of Camisards between 1702 and 1709.
5 Which central European country had a Calvinist ruler?	Prussia	1
6 After Huguenots fled France their last remaining bastion was where?	Cévennes	2

8 Against whom did the Camisards rise up to fight?	the Catholic Church in the region	3

1 In 1564 a group of Norman Huguenots under the leadership of Jean Ribault established the small colony of Fort Caroline on the banks of the St Johns River in what is today Jacksonville Florida.
2 The effort was the first at any permanent European settlement in the presentday continental United States but survived only a short time.
3 A September 1565 French naval attack against the new Spanish colony at St Augustine failed when its ships were hit by a hurricane on their way to the Spanish encampment at Fort Matanzas.
4 Hundreds of French soldiers were stranded and surrendered to the numerically inferior Spanish forces led by Pedro Menendez.
5 Menendez proceeded to massacre the defenseless Huguenots after which he wiped out the Fort Caroline garrison.
6 There was a 16th century Huguenot settlement near what modern day Florida city?	Jacksonville	1
7 Who was the leader who established the colony at Florida?	Jean Ribault	1
8 What was the name of the Florida Huguenot colony?	Fort Caroline	1
9 Which army attacked and destroyed this colony?	Spanish	3
10 When was the colony destroyed?	1565	3
1 French Huguenots made two attempts to establish a haven in North America.
2 In 1562 naval officer Jean Ribault led an expedition that explored Florida and the presentday Southeastern US and founded the outpost of Charlesfort on Parris Island South Carolina.
3 The Wars of Religion precluded a return voyage and the outpost was abandoned.
4 In 1564 Ribaults former lieutenant René Goulaine de Laudonnière launched a second voyage to build a colony he established Fort Caroline in what is now Jacksonville Florida.
5 War at home again precluded a resupply mission and the colony struggled.
6 In 1565 the Spanish decided to enforce their claim to La Florida and sent Pedro Menéndez de Avilés who established the settlement of St Augustine near Fort Caroline.
7 Menéndez forces routed the French and executed most of the Protestant captives.
8 What was the name of the first Huguenot outpost in South Carolina?	Charlesfort	2
9 What presentday area was this settlement near?	Parris Island	2
10 Which Spanish officer established the settlement at St Augustine?	Pedro Menéndez de Avilés	6
11 When did Ribault first establish a settlement in South Carolina?	1562	2
12 What European event caused the Huguenots to abandon Charlesfort?	The Wars of Religion	3
1 In 1700 several hundred French Huguenots migrated from England to the colony of Virginia where the English Crown had promised them land grants in Lower Norfolk County.
2 When they arrived colonial authorities offered them instead land 20 miles above the falls of the James River at the abandoned Monacan village known as Manakin Town now in Powhatan County.
3 Some settlers landed in presentday Chesterfield County.
4 On 12 May 1705 the Virginia General Assembly passed an act to naturalise the 148 Huguenots still resident at Manakintown.
5 Of the original 390 settlers in the isolated settlement many had died others lived outside town on farms in the English style and others moved to different areas.
6 Gradually they intermarried with their English neighbors.
7 Through the 18th and 19th centuries descendants of the French migrated west into the Piedmont and across the Appalachian Mountains into the West of what became Kentucky Tennessee Missouri and other states.
8 In the Manakintown area the Huguenot Memorial Bridge across the James River and Huguenot Road were named in their honor as were many local features including several schools including Huguenot High School.
9 In what English colony were Huguenot settlers promised land?	Virginia	1
10 In what area of this British colony were Huguenot land grants?	Lower Norfolk County	1
11 What town was actually granted to the Huguenots on arrival?	Manakin Town	2
12 How many settlers original settled in Manakintown?	390	5
13 When were these settlers naturalized as English colonists?	12 May 1705	4
1 Some Huguenots fought in the Low Countries alongside the Dutch against Spain during the first years of the Dutch Revolt 1568–1609.
2 The Dutch Republic rapidly became a destination for Huguenot exiles.
3 Early ties were already visible in the Apologie of William the Silent condemning the Spanish Inquisition which was written by his court minister the Huguenot Pierre LOyseleur lord of Villiers.
4 Louise de Coligny daughter of the murdered Huguenot leader Gaspard de Coligny married William the Silent leader of the Dutch Calvinist revolt against Spanish Catholic rule.
5 As both spoke French in daily life their court church in the Prinsenhof in Delft held services in French.
6 The practice has continued to the present day.
7 The Prinsenhof is one of the 14 active Walloon churches of the Dutch Reformed Church.
8 The ties between Huguenots and the Dutch Republics military and political leadership the House of OrangeNassau which existed since the early days of the Dutch Revolt helped support the many early settlements of Huguenots in the Dutch Republics colonies.
9 They settled at the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa and New Netherland in North America.
10 When was the Dutch Revolt?	1568–1609	1
11 Who did the Dutch fight in the Dutch Revolt?	Spain	1
12 What Dutch document condemned the Spanish Inquisition?	Apologie	3
13 What leader led the Dutch Revolt and wrote Apologie?	William the Silent	4
14 What was the Dutch leaders religious affiliation?	Calvinist	4
1 Both before and after the 1708 passage of the Foreign Protestants Naturalization Act an estimated 50000 Protestant Walloons and Huguenots fled to England with many moving on to Ireland and elsewhere.
2 In relative terms this was one of the largest waves of immigration ever of a single ethnic community to Britain.
3 Andrew Lortie born André Lortie a leading Huguenot theologian and writer who led the exiled community in London became known for articulating their criticism of the Pope and the doctrine of transubstantiation during Mass.
4 What English law made that country more welcoming to Huguenots?	Foreign Protestants Naturalization Act	1
5 When was this naturalization act passed?	1708	1

1 Following the French Crowns revocation of the Edict of Nantes many Huguenots settled in Ireland in the late 17th and early 18th centuries encouraged by an act of parliament for Protestants settling in Ireland.
2 Huguenot regiments fought for William of Orange in the Williamite war in Ireland for which they were rewarded with land grants and titles many settling in Dublin.
3 Significant Huguenot settlements were in Dublin Cork Portarlington Lisburn Waterford and Youghal.
4 Smaller settlements which included Killeshandra in County Cavan contributed to the expansion of flax cultivation and the growth of the Irish linen industry.

1 Prince Louis de Condé along with his sons Daniel and Osiascitation needed arranged with Count Ludwig von NassauSaarbrücken to establish a Huguenot community in presentday Saarland in 1604.
2 The Count supported mercantilism and welcomed technically skilled immigrants into his lands regardless of their religion.
3 The Condés established a thriving glassmaking works which provided wealth to the principality for many years.
4 Other founding families created enterprises based on textiles and such traditional Huguenot occupations in France.
5 The community and its congregation remain active to this day with descendants of many of the founding families still living in the region.
6 Some members of this community emigrated to the United States in the 1890s.
7 Which noble helped establish the Huguenot settlement in Saarland?	Prince Louis de Condé	1
8 Which Count did the Prince strike an arrangement with?	Count Ludwig von NassauSaarbrücken	1
9 What industry did the nobleman establish with this settlement?	glassmaking	3
10 In what era did some members of this community emigrate to the US?	1890s	6
11 In what year was the agreement to allow the Saarland settlement reached?	1604	1
1 The bulk of Huguenot émigrés relocated to Protestant European nations such as England Wales Scotland Denmark Sweden Switzerland the Dutch Republic the Electorate of Brandenburg and Electorate of the Palatinate in the Holy Roman Empire the Duchy of Prussia the Channel Islands and Ireland.
2 They also spread beyond Europe to the Dutch Cape Colony in South Africa the Dutch East Indies the Caribbean and several of the English colonies of North America and Quebec where they were accepted and allowed to worship freely.
3 What two member nations of the Holy Roman Empire received Huguenot refugees?	Electorate of Brandenburg and Electorate of the Palatinate	1

1 Some disagree with such double or triple nonFrench linguistic origins arguing that for the word to have spread into common use in France it must have originated in the French language.
2 The Hugues hypothesis argues that the name was derived by association with Hugues Capet king of France who reigned long before the Reformation.
3 He was regarded by the Gallicans and Protestants as a noble man who respected peoples dignity and lives.
4 Janet Gray and other supporters of the hypothesis suggest that the name huguenote would be roughly equivalent to little Hugos or those who want Hugo.
5 From what French King did the Huguenot name possibly descend?	Hugues Capet	2
6 What is the theory that this Kings name is the origin of Huguenot called?	The Hugues hypothesis	2
7 Who is one prominent advocate of this theory?	Janet Gray	4
8 According to the theory what does the name Huguenot mean?	little Hugos  or those who want Hugo	4
9 Other theories of the words origin can be generally classed as what?	double or triple nonFrench linguistic origins	1
1 Other predecessors of the Reformed church included the proreform and Gallican Roman Catholics such as Jacques Lefevre c 1455–1536.
2 The Gallicans briefly achieved independence for the French church on the principle that the religion of France could not be controlled by the Bishop of Rome a foreign power.
3 During the Protestant Reformation Lefevre a professor at the University of Paris published his French translation of the New Testament in 1523 followed by the whole Bible in the French language in 1530.
4 William Farel was a student of Lefevre who went on to become a leader of the Swiss Reformation establishing a Protestant government in Geneva.
5 Jean Cauvin John Calvin another student at the University of Paris also converted to Protestantism.
6 Long after the sect was suppressed by Francis I the remaining French Waldensians then mostly in the Luberon region sought to join William Farel Calvin and the Reformation and Olivetan published a French Bible for them.
7 The French Confession of 1559 shows a decidedly Calvinistic influence.
8 Sometime between 1550 and 1580 members of the Reformed church in France came to be commonly known as Huguenots.
9 citation needed.
10 Who was one French proreform Roman Catholic of the 15th century?	Jacques Lefevre	1
11 Where did this proreform leader teach?	University of Paris	3
12 When did this leader publish a French language Bible?	1530	3
13 What leader of the Swiss reformation was a student of Lefevre?	William Farel	4
14 What other European Protestant leader was educated at the University of Paris?	Jean Cauvin John Calvin	5
1 In what became known as the St Bartholomews Day Massacre of 24 August – 3 October 1572 Catholics killed thousands of Huguenots in Paris.
2 Similar massacres took place in other towns in the weeks following.
3 The main provincial towns and cities experiencing the Massacre were Aix Bordeaux Bourges Lyons Meaux Orleans Rouen Toulouse and Troyes.
4 Nearly 3000 Protestants were slaughtered in Toulouse alone.
5 The exact number of fatalities throughout the country is not known.
6 On 23–24 August between about 2000 and 3000 Protestants were killed in Paris and between 3000 and 7000 more in the French provinces.
7 By 17 September almost 25000 Protestants had been massacred in Paris alone.
8 Beyond Paris the killings continued until 3 October.
9 An amnesty granted in 1573 pardoned the perpetrators.
10 citation needed.
11 When was the St Bartholomews Day Massacre?	24 August – 3 October 1572	1
12 What group killed thousands of Huguenots?	Catholics	1
13 How many Huguenots were killed in Toulouse?	Nearly 3 000	4
14 When was amnesty granted to those responsible for the massacre?	1573	9
15 Reports document that how many Parisien Protestants were killed by September 17?	almost 25 000	7
1 Louis XIV gained the throne in 1643 and acted increasingly aggressively to force the Huguenots to convert.
2 At first he sent missionaries backed by a fund to financially reward converts to Catholicism.
3 Then he imposed penalties closed Huguenot schools and excluded them from favored professions.
4 Escalating he instituted dragonnades which included the occupation and looting of Huguenot homes by military troops in an effort to forcibly convert them.
5 In 1685 he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau revoking the Edict of Nantes and declaring Protestantism illegal.
6 citation needed.
7 Who became king in 1643?	Louis XIV	1
8 How did the new king react to the Huguenots?	acted increasingly aggressively to force the Huguenots to convert	1
9 What was the kings first approach to the Huguenots?	he sent missionaries  backed by a fund to financially reward converts	2
10 What did the king do to regarding Huguenot education?	closed Huguenot schools	3
11 The practice of occupying and looting Huguenot homes was called?	dragonnades	4
1 New Rochelle located in the county of Westchester on the north shore of Long Island Sound seemed to be the great location of the Huguenots in New York.
2 It is said that they landed on the coastline peninsula of Davenports Neck called Bauffets Point after traveling from England where they had previously taken refuge on account of religious persecution four years before the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.
3 They purchased from John Pell Lord of Pelham Manor a tract of land consisting of six thousand one hundred acres with the help of Jacob Leisler.
4 It was named New Rochelle after La Rochelle their former stronghold in France.
5 A small wooden church was first erected in the community followed by a second church that built of stone.
6 Previous to the erection of it the strong men would often walk twentythree miles on Saturday evening the distance by the road from New Rochelle to New York to attend the Sunday service.
7 The church was eventually replaced by a third TrinitySt Pauls Episcopal Church which contains heirlooms including the original bell from the French Huguenot Church Eglise du St Esperit on Pine Street in New York City which is preserved as a relic in the tower room.
8 The Huguenot cemetery or Huguenot Burial Ground has since been recognized as a historic cemetery that is the final resting place for a wide range of the Huguenot founders early settlers and prominent citizens dating back more than three centuries.
9 What present day county is New Rochelle in?	Westchester	1
10 Where did the Huguenots land in New York originally?	Bauffets Point	2
11 From whom did the Huguenots purchase the land where they settled?	John Pell  Lord of Pelham Manor	3
12 What French City was New Rochelle named after?	La Rochelle	4
13 What is the name of the third permanent Huguenot church in New Rochelle?	TrinitySt Pauls Episcopal Church	7
1 Most of the Huguenot congregations or individuals in North America eventually affiliated with other Protestant denominations with more numerous members.
2 The Huguenots adapted quickly and often married outside their immediate French communities which led to their assimilation.
3 Their descendants in many families continued to use French first names and surnames for their children well into the nineteenth century.
4 Assimilated the French made numerous contributions to United States economic life especially as merchants and artisans in the late Colonial and early Federal periods.
5 For example EI.
6 du Pont a former student of Lavoisier established the Eleutherian gunpowder mills.
7 How did Huguenots evolve their religious beliefs in the New World?	affiliated with other Protestant denominations	1
8 How were Huguenot settlers assimilated into North American society at large?	married outside their immediate French communities	2
9 Who was one prominent Huguenotdescended arms manufacturer?	EI du Pont	6
10 For how long did Huguenots continue to use French names?	into the nineteenth century	3
11 What was the name of du Ponts gunpowder operation?	Eleutherian gunpowder mills	6
1 One of the most prominent Huguenot refugees in the Netherlands was Pierre Bayle.
2 He started teaching in Rotterdam where he finished writing and publishing his multivolume masterpiece Historical and Critical Dictionary.
3 It became one of the 100 foundational texts of the US Library of Congress.
4 Some Huguenot descendants in the Netherlands may be noted by French family names although they typically use Dutch given names.
5 Due to the Huguenots early ties with the leadership of the Dutch Revolt and their own participation some of the Dutch patriciate are of partHuguenot descent.
6 Some Huguenot families have kept alive various traditions such as the celebration and feast of their patron Saint Nicolas similar to the Dutch Sint Nicolaas Sinterklaas feast.
7 Who was a prominent Huguenot in Holland?	Pierre Bayle	1
8 Where did he begin teaching?	Rotterdam	2
9 What books did Bayle publish?	Historical and Critical Dictionary	2
10 These books became a foundational text for what library?	US Library of Congress	3
11 Who is the patron saint of the Huguenots?	Saint Nicolas	6
1 The French Protestant Church of London was established by Royal Charter in 1550.
2 It is now located at Soho Square.
3 Huguenot refugees flocked to Shoreditch London.
4 They established a major weaving industry in and around Spitalfields see Petticoat Lane and the Tenterground in East London.
5 In Wandsworth their gardening skills benefited the Battersea market gardens.
6 The Old Truman Brewery then known as the Black Eagle Brewery was founded in 1724.
7 The flight of Huguenot refugees from Tours France drew off most of the workers of its great silk mills which they had built.
8 citation needed Some of these immigrants moved to Norwich which had accommodated an earlier settlement of Walloon weavers.
9 The French added to the existing immigrant population then comprising about a third of the population of the city.

1 Around 1685 Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia.
2 Nearly 50000 Huguenots established themselves in Germany 20000 of whom were welcomed in BrandenburgPrussia where they were granted special privileges Edict of Potsdam and churches in which to worship such as the Church of St Peter and St Paul Angermünde by Frederick William Elector of Brandenburg and Duke of Prussia.
3 The Huguenots furnished two new regiments of his army the Altpreußische Infantry Regiments No.
4 13 Regiment on foot Varenne and 15 Regiment on foot Wylich.
5 Another 4000 Huguenots settled in the German territories of Baden Franconia Principality of Bayreuth Principality of Ansbach Landgraviate of HesseKassel Duchy of Württemberg in the Wetterau Association of Imperial Counts in the Palatinate and PalatinateZweibrücken in the RhineMainArea Frankfurt in modernday Saarland and 1500 found refuge in Hamburg Bremen and Lower Saxony.
6 Three hundred refugees were granted asylum at the court of George William Duke of BrunswickLüneburg in Celle.
7 What protestant religions made Northern European counties safe for Huguenot immigration?	Lutheran and Reformed	1
8 Which areas of Northern Europe practiced those religions?	Germany and Scandinavia	1
9 What proclamation gave Huguenots special privileges in Brandenburg?	Edict of Potsdam	2
10 What dual titles did Frederick William hold?	Elector of Brandenburg and Duke of Prussia	2

1 Frederick William Elector of Brandenburg invited Huguenots to settle in his realms and a number of their descendants rose to positions of prominence in Prussia.
2 Several prominent German military cultural and political figures were ethnic Huguenot including poet Theodor Fontane General Hermann von François the hero of the First World War Battle of Tannenberg Luftwaffe General and fighter ace Adolf Galland Luftwaffe flying ace HansJoachim Marseille and famed Uboat captain Lothar von Arnauld de la Perière.
3 The last Prime Minister of the East German Democratic Republic Lothar de Maizière is also a descendant of a Huguenot family as is the German Federal Minister of the Interior Thomas de Maizière.
