1 Steam engines are external combustion engines where the working fluid is separate from the combustion products.
2 Noncombustion heat sources such as solar power nuclear power or geothermal energy may be used.
3 The ideal thermodynamic cycle used to analyze this process is called the Rankine cycle.
4 In the cycle water is heated and transforms into steam within a boiler operating at a high pressure.
5 When expanded through pistons or turbines mechanical work is done.
6 The reducedpressure steam is then condensed and pumped back into the boiler.
7 Along with geothermal and nuclear what is a notable noncombustion heat source?	solar	2
8 What ideal thermodynamic cycle analyzes the process by which steam engines work?	Rankine	3
9 In the Rankine cycle what does water turn into when heated?	steam	4
10 At what pressure is water heated in the Rankine cycle?	high	4
11 What types of engines are steam engines?	external combustion	1
1 The first commercially successful true engine in that it could generate power and transmit it to a machine was the atmospheric engine invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712.
2 It was an improvement over Saverys steam pump using a piston as proposed by Papin.
3 Newcomens engine was relatively inefficient and in most cases was used for pumping water.
4 It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing steam under a piston within a cylinder.
5 It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible and also for providing a reusable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away from a suitable head.
6 Water that had passed over the wheel was pumped back up into a storage reservoir above the wheel.
7 What was the first true engine that was commercially successful?	atmospheric engine	1
8 Who was the inventor of the atmospheric engine?	Thomas Newcomen	1
9 About what year was the atmospheric engine invented?	1712	1
10 What was invented by Savery?	steam pump	2
11 Who conceptualized the piston?	Papin	2
1 The first fullscale working railway steam locomotive was built by Richard Trevithick in the United Kingdom and on 21 February 1804 the worlds first railway journey took place as Trevithicks unnamed steam locomotive hauled a train along the tramway from the Penydarren ironworks near Merthyr Tydfil to Abercynon in south Wales.
2 The design incorporated a number of important innovations that included using highpressure steam which reduced the weight of the engine and increased its efficiency.
3 Trevithick visited the Newcastle area later in 1804 and the colliery railways in northeast England became the leading centre for experimentation and development of steam locomotives.
4 In what country was a fullscale working railway steam locomotive first invented?	United Kingdom	1
5 On what date did the first railway trip in the world occur?	21 February 1804	1
6 Where did the worlds first railway journey terminate?	Abercynon	1
7 In what constituent country of the United Kingdom is Merthyr Tydfil located?	Wales	1
8 In what geographical portion of Wales is Abercynon located?	south	1
1 The Rankine cycle and most practical steam engines have a water pump to recycle or top up the boiler water so that they may be run continuously.
2 Utility and industrial boilers commonly use multistage centrifugal pumps however other types are used.
3 Another means of supplying lowerpressure boiler feed water is an injector which uses a steam jet usually supplied from the boiler.
4 Injectors became popular in the 1850s but are no longer widely used except in applications such as steam locomotives.
5 What device is used to recycle the boiler water in most steam engines?	water pump	1
6 What types of pumps are typically used in industrial boilers?	multistage centrifugal	2
7 In what decade were injectors widely used in steam engines?	1850s	4
8 What is a notable application of injectors today?	steam locomotives	4
9 What are injectors used to supply?	lowerpressure boiler feed water	3
1 It is a logical extension of the compound engine described above to split the expansion into yet more stages to increase efficiency.
2 The result is the multiple expansion engine.
3 Such engines use either three or four expansion stages and are known as triple and quadruple expansion engines respectively.
4 These engines use a series of cylinders of progressively increasing diameter.
5 These cylinders are designed to divide the work into equal shares for each expansion stage.
6 As with the double expansion engine if space is at a premium then two smaller cylinders may be used for the lowpressure stage.
7 Multiple expansion engines typically had the cylinders arranged inline but various other formations were used.
8 In the late 19th century the YarrowSchlickTweedy balancing system was used on some marine triple expansion engines.
9 YST engines divided the lowpressure expansion stages between two cylinders one at each end of the engine.
10 This allowed the crankshaft to be better balanced resulting in a smoother fasterresponding engine which ran with less vibration.
11 This made the 4cylinder tripleexpansion engine popular with large passenger liners such as the Olympic class but this was ultimately replaced by the virtually vibrationfree turbine engine.
12 citation needed.
13 How many expansion stages are used by the triple expansion engine?	three	3
14 What are engines using four expansion stages known as?	quadruple expansion engines	3
15 In what century was the YarrowSchlickTweedy balancing system used?	19th	8
16 What sort of engines utilized the YarrowSchlickTweedy balancing system?	marine triple expansion	8
17 What class of ships is an example of large passenger liners?	Olympic	11
1 In the 1840s and 50s there were attempts to overcome this problem by means of various patent valve gears with a separate variable cutoff expansion valve riding on the back of the main slide valve the latter usually had fixed or limited cutoff.
2 The combined setup gave a fair approximation of the ideal events at the expense of increased friction and wear and the mechanism tended to be complicated.
3 The usual compromise solution has been to provide lap by lengthening rubbing surfaces of the valve in such a way as to overlap the port on the admission side with the effect that the exhaust side remains open for a longer period after cutoff on the admission side has occurred.
4 This expedient has since been generally considered satisfactory for most purposes and makes possible the use of the simpler Stephenson Joy and Walschaerts motions.
5 Corliss and later poppet valve gears had separate admission and exhaust valves driven by trip mechanisms or cams profiled so as to give ideal events most of these gears never succeeded outside of the stationary marketplace due to various other issues including leakage and more delicate mechanisms.
6 Along with poppet valve gears what type of gears utilized separate admission and exhaust valves to give ideal events?	Corliss	5
7 Along with Stephenson and Walschaerts what is an example of a simple motion?	Joy	4
8 How is lap provided by overlapping the admission side port?	lengthening rubbing surfaces of the valve	3
1 Lead fusible plugs may be present in the crown of the boilers firebox.
2 If the water level drops such that the temperature of the firebox crown increases significantly the lead melts and the steam escapes warning the operators who may then manually suppress the fire.
3 Except in the smallest of boilers the steam escape has little effect on dampening the fire.
4 The plugs are also too small in area to lower steam pressure significantly depressurizing the boiler.
5 If they were any larger the volume of escaping steam would itself endanger the crew.
6 citation needed.
7 What are sometimes present in the boilers firebox crown?	Lead fusible plugs	1
8 What happens to the lead fusible plugs if the water level of the boiler drops?	melts	2
9 What happens after the lead melts?	steam escapes	2
10 After the operators are warned by the escape of the steam what may they then do?	manually suppress the fire	2
11 What is the escape of the steam unlikely to accomplish in all but the smallest boilers?	dampening the fire	3
1 In 1781 James Watt patented a steam engine that produced continuous rotary motion.
2 Watts tenhorsepower engines enabled a wide range of manufacturing machinery to be powered.
3 The engines could be sited anywhere that water and coal or wood fuel could be obtained.
4 By 1883 engines that could provide 10000 hp had become feasible.
5 The stationary steam engine was a key component of the Industrial Revolution allowing factories to locate where water power was unavailable.
6 The atmospheric engines of Newcomen and Watt were large compared to the amount of power they produced but high pressure steam engines were light enough to be applied to vehicles such as traction engines and the railway locomotives.
7 Who patented a steam engine in 1781?	James Watt	1
8 What sort of motion did Watts steam engine continuously produce?	rotary	1
9 How many horsepower was Watts engine?	ten	2
10 As of what year were 10000 horsepower engines available?	1883	4
11 What was the steam engine an important component of?	Industrial Revolution	5
1 The history of the steam engine stretches back as far as the first century AD the first recorded rudimentary steam engine being the aeolipile described by Greek mathematician Hero of Alexandria.
2 In the following centuries the few steampowered engines known were like the aeolipile essentially experimental devices used by inventors to demonstrate the properties of steam.
3 A rudimentary steam turbine device was described by Taqi alDin in 1551 and by Giovanni Branca in 1629.
4 Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont received patents in 1606 for fifty steam powered inventions including a water pump for draining inundated mines.
5 Denis Papin a Huguenot refugee did some useful work on the steam digester in 1679 and first used a piston to raise weights in 1690.
6 In what century did the history of the steam engine begin?	first	1
7 Who conceptualized the aeolipile?	Hero of Alexandria	1
8 What was Hero of Alexandrias nationality?	Greek	1
9 Who described a steam turbine in 1629?	Giovanni Branca	3
10 In what year did Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont patent a water pump for draining mines?	1606	4
1 Near the end of the 19th century compound engines came into widespread use.
2 Compound engines exhausted steam in to successively larger cylinders to accommodate the higher volumes at reduced pressures giving improved efficiency.
3 These stages were called expansions with double and triple expansion engines being common especially in shipping where efficiency was important to reduce the weight of coal carried.
4 Steam engines remained the dominant source of power until the early 20th century when advances in the design of electric motors and internal combustion engines gradually resulted in the replacement of reciprocating piston steam engines with shipping in the 20thcentury relying upon the steam turbine.
5 What type of engines became widespread around the end of the 19th century?	compound	1
6 What are the stages in a compound engine called?	expansions	3
7 In what field were double and triple expansion engines common?	shipping	3
8 Along with electric motors what power sources overtook steam engines in the 20th century?	internal combustion engines	4
9 What product was notably shipped in vessels equipped with double and triple expansion engines?	coal	3
1 The final major evolution of the steam engine design was the use of steam turbines starting in the late part of the 19th century.
2 Steam turbines are generally more efficient than reciprocating piston type steam engines for outputs above several hundred horsepower have fewer moving parts and provide rotary power directly instead of through a connecting rod system or similar means.
3 Steam turbines virtually replaced reciprocating engines in electricity generating stations early in the 20th century where their efficiency higher speed appropriate to generator service and smooth rotation were advantages.
4 Today most electric power is provided by steam turbines.
5 In the United States 90 of the electric power is produced in this way using a variety of heat sources.
6 Steam turbines were extensively applied for propulsion of large ships throughout most of the 20th century.
7 The use of what device represented the last major evolution of the steam engine?	steam turbines	1
8 In what part of the 19th century were steam turbines introduced?	late	1
9 Above what horsepower are steam turbines usually more efficient than steam engines that use reciprocating pistons?	several hundred	2
10 What percentage of electrical power in the United States is made by steam turbines?	90	5
11 Most power of what sort is generated by steam turbines today?	electric	4
1 The heat required for boiling the water and supplying the steam can be derived from various sources most commonly from burning combustible materials with an appropriate supply of air in a closed space called variously combustion chamber firebox.
2 In some cases the heat source is a nuclear reactor geothermal energy solar energy or waste heat from an internal combustion engine or industrial process.
3 In the case of model or toy steam engines the heat source can be an electric heating element.
4 What is the usual source of heat for boiling water in the steam engine?	burning combustible materials	1
5 Aside from firebox what is another name for the space in which combustible material is burned in the engine?	combustion chamber	1
6 Along with nuclear geothermal and internal combustion engine waste heat what sort of energy might supply the heat for a steam engine?	solar	2
7 What type of heating element is often used in toy steam engines?	electric	3
1 The most useful instrument for analyzing the performance of steam engines is the steam engine indicator.
2 Early versions were in use by 1851 but the most successful indicator was developed for the high speed engine inventor and manufacturer Charles Porter by Charles Richard and exhibited at London Exhibition in 1862.
3 The steam engine indicator traces on paper the pressure in the cylinder throughout the cycle which can be used to spot various problems and calculate developed horsepower.
4 It was routinely used by engineers mechanics and insurance inspectors.
5 The engine indicator can also be used on internal combustion engines.
6 See image of indicator diagram below in Types of motor units section.
7 What instrument is used to examine steam engine performance?	steam engine indicator	1
8 What year saw the earliest recorded use of the steam engine indicator?	1851	2
9 What company developed the most successful steam engine indicator?	Charles Porter	2
10 Who developed a successful steam engine indicator for Charles Porter?	Charles Richard	2
11 Where was the Charles Porter steam engine indicator shown?	London Exhibition	2
1 With twocylinder compounds used in railway work the pistons are connected to the cranks as with a twocylinder simple at 90° out of phase with each other quartered.
2 When the double expansion group is duplicated producing a 4cylinder compound the individual pistons within the group are usually balanced at 180° the groups being set at 90° to each other.
3 In one case the first type of Vauclain compound the pistons worked in the same phase driving a common crosshead and crank again set at 90° as for a twocylinder engine.
4 With the 3cylinder compound arrangement the LP cranks were either set at 90° with the HP one at 135° to the other two or in some cases all three cranks were set at 120°.
5 citation needed.
6 At what degree are the pistons of a twocylinder compound connected to the cranks?	90	1
7 In a 4cylinder compound engine what degree were the individual pistons balanced at?	180	2
8 At what angle were the groups of pistons set in relation to one another in a 4cylinder compound?	90	2
1 In most reciprocating piston engines the steam reverses its direction of flow at each stroke counterflow entering and exhausting from the cylinder by the same port.
2 The complete engine cycle occupies one rotation of the crank and two piston strokes the cycle also comprises four events – admission expansion exhaust compression.
3 These events are controlled by valves often working inside a steam chest adjacent to the cylinder the valves distribute the steam by opening and closing steam ports communicating with the cylinder ends and are driven by valve gear of which there are many types.
4 citation needed.
5 What is a term for the reversing of steam flow in a piston engine after each stroke?	counterflow	1
6 How many piston strokes occur in an engine cycle?	two	2
7 How many crank rotations are there in an engine cycle?	one	2
8 How many events occur in an engine cycle?	four	2
9 Along with admission exhaust and compression what is an event in the engine cycle?	expansion	2
1 Uniflow engines attempt to remedy the difficulties arising from the usual counterflow cycle where during each stroke the port and the cylinder walls will be cooled by the passing exhaust steam whilst the hotter incoming admission steam will waste some of its energy in restoring working temperature.
2 The aim of the uniflow is to remedy this defect and improve efficiency by providing an additional port uncovered by the piston at the end of each stroke making the steam flow only in one direction.
3 By this means the simpleexpansion uniflow engine gives efficiency equivalent to that of classic compound systems with the added advantage of superior partload performance and comparable efficiency to turbines for smaller engines below one thousand horsepower.
4 However the thermal expansion gradient uniflow engines produce along the cylinder wall gives practical difficulties.
5 citation needed.
6 The Quasiturbine is a uniflow rotary steam engine where steam intakes in hot areas while exhausting in cold areas.
7 What is the name of a uniflow engine that takes in steam in hot areas and exhausts it in cold?	Quasiturbine	6
8 The uniflow engine is an attempt to fix an issue that arises in what cycle?	counterflow	1
9 What part is added to the uniflow engine to resolve the issue in the counterflow cycle?	port	2
1 An oscillating cylinder steam engine is a variant of the simple expansion steam engine which does not require valves to direct steam into and out of the cylinder.
2 Instead of valves the entire cylinder rocks or oscillates such that one or more holes in the cylinder line up with holes in a fixed port face or in the pivot mounting trunnion.
3 These engines are mainly used in toys and models because of their simplicity but have also been used in full size working engines mainly on ships where their compactness is valued.
4 citation needed.
5 What type of steam engine doesnt need valves to direct steam?	oscillating cylinder	1
6 What is another term for the pivot mounting?	trunnion	2
7 Along with toys where are oscillating cylinder steam engines typically used?	models	3
8 Full size working engines on what vehicles sometimes use oscillating cylinder steam engines?	ships	3
1 The working fluid in a Rankine cycle can operate as a closed loop system where the working fluid is recycled continuously or may be an open loop system where the exhaust steam is directly released to the atmosphere and a separate source of water feeding the boiler is supplied.
2 Normally water is the fluid of choice due to its favourable properties such as nontoxic and unreactive chemistry abundance low cost and its thermodynamic properties.
3 Mercury is the working fluid in the mercury vapor turbine.
4 Low boiling hydrocarbons can be used in a binary cycle.
5 What happens to the working fluid in a closed loop system?	recycled continuously	1
6 What sort of system releases the exhaust steam into the atmosphere?	open loop	1
7 What working fluid is used in a mercury vapor turbine?	Mercury	3
8 What is the typical working fluid in a steam engine?	water	2
1 The efficiency of a Rankine cycle is usually limited by the working fluid.
2 Without the pressure reaching supercritical levels for the working fluid the temperature range the cycle can operate over is quite small in steam turbines turbine entry temperatures are typically 565 °C the creep limit of stainless steel and condenser temperatures are around 30 °C.
3 This gives a theoretical Carnot efficiency of about 63 compared with an actual efficiency of 42 for a modern coalfired power station.
4 This low turbine entry temperature compared with a gas turbine is why the Rankine cycle is often used as a bottoming cycle in combinedcycle gas turbine power stations.
5 citation needed.
6 What limits the Rankine cycles efficiency?	working fluid	1
7 What is the turbine entry temperature of a steam turbine in degrees Celsius?	565	2
8 What is  565 °C the creep limit of?	stainless steel	2
9 What is a turbines theoretical Carnot efficiency?	63	3
10 What is the approximate condenser temperature in a turbine?	30 °C	2
1 Steam engines can be said to have been the moving force behind the Industrial Revolution and saw widespread commercial use driving machinery in factories mills and mines powering pumping stations and propelling transport appliances such as railway locomotives ships steamboats and road vehicles.
2 Their use in agriculture led to an increase in the land available for cultivation.
3 There have at one time or another been steampowered farm tractors motorcycles without much success and even automobiles as the Stanley Steamer.
4 What devices have been credited as the moving force of the Industrial Revolution?	Steam engines	1
5 Along with road vehicles locomotives and ships on what vehicles were steam engines used during the Industrial Revolution?	steamboats	1
6 What is an example of a steampowered automobile?	Stanley Steamer	3
7 Along with mills and mines in what industrial locations did steam drive machines?	factories	1
8 What did the use of steam engines in farming lead to?	increase in the land available for cultivation	2
1 Trevithick continued his own experiments using a trio of locomotives concluding with the Catch Me Who Can in 1808.
2 Only four years later the successful twincylinder locomotive Salamanca by Matthew Murray was used by the edge railed rack and pinion Middleton Railway.
3 In 1825 George Stephenson built the Locomotion for the Stockton and Darlington Railway.
4 This was the first public steam railway in the world and then in 1829 he built The Rocket which was entered in and won the Rainhill Trials.
5 The Liverpool and Manchester Railway opened in 1830 making exclusive use of steam power for both passenger and freight trains.
6 What was the name of the locomotive that debuted in 1808?	Catch Me Who Can	1
7 Who designed Salamanca?	Matthew Murray	2
8 What type of locomotive was Salamanca?	twincylinder	2
9 On what railroad was Salamanca used?	Middleton Railway	2
10 For what railroad did Stephenson build a locomotive in 1825?	Stockton and Darlington	3
1 A method to lessen the magnitude of this heating and cooling was invented in 1804 by British engineer Arthur Woolf who patented his Woolf highpressure compound engine in 1805.
2 In the compound engine highpressure steam from the boiler expands in a highpressure HP cylinder and then enters one or more subsequent lowerpressure LP cylinders.
3 The complete expansion of the steam now occurs across multiple cylinders and as less expansion now occurs in each cylinder less heat is lost by the steam in each.
4 This reduces the magnitude of cylinder heating and cooling increasing the efficiency of the engine.
5 By staging the expansion in multiple cylinders torque variability can be reduced.
6 To derive equal work from lowerpressure steam requires a larger cylinder volume as this steam occupies a greater volume.
7 Therefore the bore and often the stroke are increased in lowpressure cylinders resulting in larger cylinders.
8 Who patented a highpressure compound engine in 1805?	Arthur Woolf	1
9 What nationality was Arthur Woolf?	British	1
10 What is decreased by staging expansion across multiple cylinders?	torque variability	5
11 What needs to be larger to get the same work out of lower pressure steam?	cylinder volume	6
1 The main use for steam turbines is in electricity generation in the 1990s about 90 of the worlds electric production was by use of steam turbines however the recent widespread application of large gas turbine units and typical combined cycle power plants has resulted in reduction of this percentage to the 80 regime for steam turbines.
2 In electricity production the high speed of turbine rotation matches well with the speed of modern electric generators which are typically direct connected to their driving turbines.
3 In marine service pioneered on the Turbinia steam turbines with reduction gearing although the Turbinia has direct turbines to propellers with no reduction gearbox dominated large ship propulsion throughout the late 20th century being more efficient and requiring far less maintenance than reciprocating steam engines.
4 In recent decades reciprocating Diesel engines and gas turbines have almost entirely supplanted steam propulsion for marine applications.
5 What percentage of electricity was made by steam turbine in the 1990s?	90	1
6 What marine engines were less efficient than steam turbines?	reciprocating steam engines	3
7 Along with diesel engines what engines have overtaken steam engines for marine propulsion?	gas turbines	4
8 What engines were used throughout most of the 20th century to propel ships?	steam turbines	3
9 What gearing was used on steam turbine marine engines in the 20th century?	reduction	3
1 The Rankine cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine.
2 The cycle is an arrangement of components as is typically used for simple power production and utilizes the phase change of water boiling water producing steam condensing exhaust steam producing liquid water to provide a practical heatpower conversion system.
3 The heat is supplied externally to a closed loop with some of the heat added being converted to work and the waste heat being removed in a condenser.
4 The Rankine cycle is used in virtually all steam power production applications.
5 In the 1990s Rankine steam cycles generated about 90 of all electric power used throughout the world including virtually all solar biomass coal and nuclear power plants.
6 It is named after William John Macquorn Rankine a Scottish polymath.
7 What is the steam engines thermodynamic basis?	Rankine cycle	1
8 What happens to waste heat in the Rankine cycle?	removed in a condenser	3
9 In what decade did the Rankine cycle create 90 of electric power?	1990s	5
10 Along with solar coal and nuclear what sort of plants notable use the Rankine process?	biomass	5
11 What is William Rankines nationality?	Scottish	6
1 The historical measure of a steam engines energy efficiency was its duty.
2 The concept of duty was first introduced by Watt in order to illustrate how much more efficient his engines were over the earlier Newcomen designs.
3 Duty is the number of footpounds of work delivered by burning one bushel 94 pounds of coal.
4 The best examples of Newcomen designs had a duty of about 7 million but most were closer to 5 million.
5 Watts original lowpressure designs were able to deliver duty as high as 25 million but averaged about 17.
6 This was a threefold improvement over the average Newcomen design.
7 Early Watt engines equipped with highpressure steam improved this to 65 million.
8 How was the efficiency of a steam engine typically evaluated?	duty	1
9 What was the average duty of a lowpressure Watt engine?	17	6
10 What was the ideal duty of a Newcomen engine?	7 million	4
11 What is the weight of a bushel of coal in pounds?	94	3
12 Who invented the notion of a steam engines duty?	Watt	2
1 Reciprocating piston type steam engines remained the dominant source of power until the early 20th century when advances in the design of electric motors and internal combustion engines gradually resulted in the replacement of reciprocating piston steam engines in commercial usage and the ascendancy of steam turbines in power generation.
2 Considering that the great majority of worldwide electric generation is produced by turbine type steam engines the steam age is continuing with energy levels far beyond those of the turn of the 19th century.
3 What type of engines became popular for power generation after piston steam engines?	steam turbines	1
4 What type of steam engines produced most power up to the early 20th century?	Reciprocating piston	1
5 What type of steam engine produces most electricity in the world today?	turbine	2
6 Along with electric motors what type of engines superseded piston steam engines?	internal combustion	1
1 The first commercial steampowered device was a water pump developed in 1698 by Thomas Savery.
2 It used condensing steam to create a vacuum which was used to raise water from below then it used steam pressure to raise it higher.
3 Small engines were effective though larger models were problematic.
4 They proved only to have a limited lift height and were prone to boiler explosions.
5 It received some use in mines pumping stations and for supplying water wheels used to power textile machinery.
6 An attractive feature of the Savery engine was its low cost.
7 Bento de Moura Portugal introduced an ingenious improvement of Saverys construction to render it capable of working itself as described by John Smeaton in the Philosophical Transactions published in 1751.
8 It continued to be manufactured until the late 18th century.
9 One engine was still known to be operating in 1820.
10 Who developed the first commercial steam powered device?	Thomas Savery	1
11 What was the first steam powered device used commercially?	water pump	1
12 In what year was the first commercial steam powered device invented?	1698	1
13 Who notably improved the Savery water pump?	Bento de Moura Portugal	7
14 Who wrote of the Savery water pump in 1751s Philosophical Transactions?	John Smeaton	7
1 Around 1800 Richard Trevithick and separately Oliver Evans in 1801 introduced engines using highpressure steam Trevithick obtained his highpressure engine patent in 1802.
2 These were much more powerful for a given cylinder size than previous engines and could be made small enough for transport applications.
3 Thereafter technological developments and improvements in manufacturing techniques partly brought about by the adoption of the steam engine as a power source resulted in the design of more efficient engines that could be smaller faster or more powerful depending on the intended application.
4 Who invented a highpressure steam engine around 1800?	Richard Trevithick	1
5 Who created an engine using high pressure steam in 1801?	Oliver Evans	1
6 In what year did Richard Trevithick patent his device?	1802	1
7 High pressure steam engines were small enough that they could be used in what application?	transport	2
8 What were steam engines used as a source of?	power	3
1 Although the reciprocating steam engine is no longer in widespread commercial use various companies are exploring or exploiting the potential of the engine as an alternative to internal combustion engines.
2 The company Energiprojekt AB in Sweden has made progress in using modern materials for harnessing the power of steam.
3 The efficiency of Energiprojekts steam engine reaches some 2730 on highpressure engines.
4 It is a singlestep 5cylinder engine no compound with superheated steam and consumes approx.
5 4 kg 88 lb of steam per kWh.
6 not in citation given.
7 What modern company has been notably working on a steam engine using modern materials?	Energiprojekt AB	2
8 Where is Energiprojekt AB based?	Sweden	2
9 How many cylinders does the Energiprojekt AB engine have?	5	4
10 How many pounds of steam per kilowatt hour does the Energiprojekt AB engine use?	88	5
11 What percentage of a high pressure engines efficiency has the Energiprojekt AB engine achieved?	2730	3
1 Where CHP is not used steam turbines in power stations use surface condensers as a cold sink.
2 The condensers are cooled by water flow from oceans rivers lakes and often by cooling towers which evaporate water to provide cooling energy removal.
3 The resulting condensed hot water output from the condenser is then put back into the boiler via a pump.
4 A dry type cooling tower is similar to an automobile radiator and is used in locations where water is costly.
5 Evaporative wet cooling towers use the rejected heat to evaporate water this water is kept separate from the condensate which circulates in a closed system and returns to the boiler.
6 Such towers often have visible plumes due to the evaporated water condensing into droplets carried up by the warm air.
7 Evaporative cooling towers need less water flow than oncethrough cooling by river or lake water a 700 megawatt coalfired power plant may use about 3600 cubic metres of makeup water every hour for evaporative cooling but would need about twenty times as much if cooled by river water.
8 citation needed.
9 What do power station steam turbines use as a cold sink in the absence of CHP?	surface condensers	1
10 What device is a dry cooling tower similar to?	automobile radiator	4
11 In what sort of places are dry cooling towers used?	where water is costly	4
12 An evaporative cooling tower is also referred to as what kind of cooling tower?	wet	5
13 About how many cubic meters of makeup water is used by a 700megawatt coalfired power plant for evaporative cooling hourly?	3600	7
1 The centrifugal governor was adopted by James Watt for use on a steam engine in 1788 after Watt’s partner Boulton saw one at a flour mill Boulton  Watt were building.
2 The governor could not actually hold a set speed because it would assume a new constant speed in response to load changes.
3 The governor was able to handle smaller variations such as those caused by fluctuating heat load to the boiler.
4 Also there was a tendency for oscillation whenever there was a speed change.
5 As a consequence engines equipped only with this governor were not suitable for operations requiring constant speed such as cotton spinning.
6 The governor was improved over time and coupled with variable steam cut off good speed control in response to changes in load was attainable near the end of the 19th century.
7 What did Watt add to the steam engine in 1788?	centrifugal governor	1
8 What was the name of Watts partner?	Boulton	1
9 Where was the centrifugal governor first observed by Boulton?	flour mill	1
10 What is an examine of work that a centrifugal governorequipped steam engine wasnt suitable for?	cotton spinning	5
11 What was the centrifugal governor incapable of doing?	hold a set speed	2
1 The adoption of compounding was common for industrial units for road engines and almost universal for marine engines after 1880 it was not universally popular in railway locomotives where it was often perceived as complicated.
2 This is partly due to the harsh railway operating environment and limited space afforded by the loading gauge particularly in Britain where compounding was never common and not employed after 1930.
3 However although never in the majority it was popular in many other countries.
4 After what year was compounding frequently used in marine engines?	1880	1
5 Compounding was not popular in the construction of what machines?	railway locomotives	1
6 What was compounding seen as being in the locomotive construction industry?	complicated	1
7 After what year did compounding cease to be used in Britain?	1930	2
8 Along with marine engines and industrial units in what machines was compounding popular?	road engines	1
1 The simplest valve gears give events of fixed length during the engine cycle and often make the engine rotate in only one direction.
2 Most however have a reversing mechanism which additionally can provide means for saving steam as speed and momentum are gained by gradually shortening the cutoff or rather shortening the admission event this in turn proportionately lengthens the expansion period.
3 However as one and the same valve usually controls both steam flows a short cutoff at admission adversely affects the exhaust and compression periods which should ideally always be kept fairly constant if the exhaust event is too brief the totality of the exhaust steam cannot evacuate the cylinder choking it and giving excessive compression kick back.
4 citation needed.
5 What is another term for shortening the admission event?	shortening the cutoff	2
6 What is another term for excessive compression?	kick back	3
7 What can the exhaust steam not fully do when the exhaust event is insufficiently long?	evacuate the cylinder	3
8 Of what length are engine cycle events when the simplest valve gears are used?	fixed	1
1 Using boiling water to produce mechanical motion goes back over 2000 years but early devices were not practical.
2 The Spanish inventor Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont obtained the first patent for a steam engine in 1606.
3 In 1698 Thomas Savery patented a steam pump that used steam in direct contact with the water being pumped.
4 Saverys steam pump used condensing steam to create a vacuum and draw water into a chamber and then applied pressurized steam to further pump the water.
5 Thomas Newcomens atmospheric engine was the first commercial true steam engine using a piston and was used in 1712 for pumping in a mine.
6 Who received the first steam engine patent?	Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont	2
7 What was the nationality of Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont?	Spanish	2
8 In what year did Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont receive a steam engine patent?	1606	2
9 In what year did Savery patent his steam pump?	1698	3
10 In what year did Newcomens engine pump in a mine?	1712	5
1 A steam turbine consists of one or more rotors rotating discs mounted on a drive shaft alternating with a series of stators static discs fixed to the turbine casing.
2 The rotors have a propellerlike arrangement of blades at the outer edge.
3 Steam acts upon these blades producing rotary motion.
4 The stator consists of a similar but fixed series of blades that serve to redirect the steam flow onto the next rotor stage.
5 A steam turbine often exhausts into a surface condenser that provides a vacuum.
6 The stages of a steam turbine are typically arranged to extract the maximum potential work from a specific velocity and pressure of steam giving rise to a series of variably sized high and lowpressure stages.
7 Turbines are only efficient if they rotate at relatively high speed therefore they are usually connected to reduction gearing to drive lower speed applications such as a ships propeller.
8 In the vast majority of large electric generating stations turbines are directly connected to generators with no reduction gearing.
9 Typical speeds are 3600 revolutions per minute RPM in the USA with 60 Hertz power 3000 RPM in Europe and other countries with 50 Hertz electric power systems.
10 In nuclear power applications the turbines typically run at half these speeds 1800 RPM and 1500 RPM.
11 A turbine rotor is also only capable of providing power when rotating in one direction.
12 Therefore a reversing stage or gearbox is usually required where power is required in the opposite direction.
13 citation needed.
14 What is another term for rotors?	rotating discs	1
15 In a steam turbine what are rotors mounted on?	drive shaft	1
16 What is another way of referring to stators?	static discs	1
17 What are stators attached to?	turbine casing	1
18 In the United States what is a usual turbine speed with 60 Hertz of power?	3600 revolutions per minute	9
1 The weight of boilers and condensers generally makes the powertoweight ratio of a steam plant lower than for internal combustion engines.
2 For mobile applications steam has been largely superseded by internal combustion engines or electric motors.
3 However most electric power is generated using steam turbine plant so that indirectly the worlds industry is still dependent on steam power.
4 Recent concerns about fuel sources and pollution have incited a renewed interest in steam both as a component of cogeneration processes and as a prime mover.
5 This is becoming known as the Advanced Steam movement.
6 citation needed.
7 What is the powertoweight ratio of a steam plant compared to that of an internal combustion engine?	lower	1
8 Along with internal combustion engines what machines have superseded steam in some areas?	electric motors	2
9 What plants create most electric power?	steam turbine	3
10 What is the name of the movement that seeks renewed use of steam power in the modern era?	Advanced Steam	5
11 Along with fuel sources what concern has contributed to the development of the Advanced Steam movement?	pollution	4
1 It is possible to use a mechanism based on a pistonless rotary engine such as the Wankel engine in place of the cylinders and valve gear of a conventional reciprocating steam engine.
2 Many such engines have been designed from the time of James Watt to the present day but relatively few were actually built and even fewer went into quantity production see link at bottom of article for more details.
3 The major problem is the difficulty of sealing the rotors to make them steamtight in the face of wear and thermal expansion the resulting leakage made them very inefficient.
4 Lack of expansive working or any means of control of the cutoff is also a serious problem with many such designs.
5 citation needed.
6 What is an example of a rotary engine without pistons?	Wankel	1
7 What parts of a conventional reciprocating steam engine could be replaced by a pistonless rotary engine?	cylinders and valve gear	1
8 Along with wear what development makes it difficult to seal the rotors in an engine that lacks pistons?	thermal expansion	3
1 The next major step occurred when James Watt developed 1763–1775 an improved version of Newcomens engine with a separate condenser.
2 Boulton and Watts early engines used half as much coal as John Smeatons improved version of Newcomens.
3 Newcomens and Watts early engines were atmospheric.
4 They were powered by air pressure pushing a piston into the partial vacuum generated by condensing steam instead of the pressure of expanding steam.
5 The engine cylinders had to be large because the only usable force acting on them was due to atmospheric pressure.
6 When did Watt finish the development of his improvements to Newcomens engine?	1775	1
7 What did Watt add to Newcomens engine between 1763 and 1775?	condenser	1
8 Compared to Smeatons improvement on Newcomens engine how much coal did Watts engine use?	half	2
9 In addition to Watt Boulton and Smeaton whose engine was an atmosphere design?	Newcomens	2
10 In an atmospheric engine what does air pressure push against?	piston	4
1 Steam engines frequently possess two independent mechanisms for ensuring that the pressure in the boiler does not go too high one may be adjusted by the user the second is typically designed as an ultimate failsafe.
2 Such safety valves traditionally used a simple lever to restrain a plug valve in the top of a boiler.
3 One end of the lever carried a weight or spring that restrained the valve against steam pressure.
4 Early valves could be adjusted by engine drivers leading to many accidents when a driver fastened the valve down to allow greater steam pressure and more power from the engine.
5 The more recent type of safety valve uses an adjustable springloaded valve which is locked such that operators may not tamper with its adjustment unless a seal illegally is broken.
6 This arrangement is considerably safer.
7 citation needed.
8 How many mechanisms does a typical steam engine have to keep boiler pressure from getting too high?	two	1
9 What is restrained with a lever in the top of a boiler?	plug valve	2
10 What type of valve is used by recent safety valves?	adjustable springloaded	5
11 In an adjustable springloaded valve what needs to be broken to allow an operator to tamper with it?	seal	5
12 Along with a desire for more steam pressure what were early drivers looking to generate when they fastened safety valves down?	more power	4
1 The acme of the horizontal engine was the Corliss steam engine patented in 1849 which was a fourvalve counter flow engine with separate steam admission and exhaust valves and automatic variable steam cutoff.
2 When Corliss was given the Rumford medal the committee said that no one invention since Watts time has so enhanced the efficiency of the steam engine.
3 In addition to using 30 less steam it provided more uniform speed due to variable steam cut off making it well suited to manufacturing especially cotton spinning.
4 What was the ultimate development of the horizontal engine?	Corliss steam engine	1
5 In what year was the Corliss engine patented?	1849	1
6 How much less steam did the Corliss engine use compared to the Watt engine?	30	3
7 How many valves did the Corliss engine use?	four	1
8 What award was given to Corliss?	Rumford medal	2
1 The steam engine contributed much to the development of thermodynamic theory however the only applications of scientific theory that influenced the steam engine were the original concepts of harnessing the power of steam and atmospheric pressure and knowledge of properties of heat and steam.
2 The experimental measurements made by Watt on a model steam engine led to the development of the separate condenser.
3 Watt independently discovered latent heat which was confirmed by the original discoverer Joseph Black who also advised Watt on experimental procedures.
4 Watt was also aware of the change in the boiling point of water with pressure.
5 Otherwise the improvements to the engine itself were more mechanical in nature.
6 The thermodynamic concepts of the Rankine cycle did give engineers the understanding needed to calculate efficiency which aided the development of modern highpressure and temperature boilers and the steam turbine.
7 What scientific fields theory has received contributions from the steam engine?	thermodynamic	1
8 Who made experimental measurements on a model steam engine?	Watt	2
9 What was developed from Watts measurements on a model steam engine?	condenser	2
10 Who confirmed Watts discovery of latent heat?	Joseph Black	3
11 What concept originally discovered by Black was later discovered independently by Watt?	latent heat	3
1 One of the principal advantages the Rankine cycle holds over others is that during the compression stage relatively little work is required to drive the pump the working fluid being in its liquid phase at this point.
2 By condensing the fluid the work required by the pump consumes only 1 to 3 of the turbine power and contributes to a much higher efficiency for a real cycle.
3 The benefit of this is lost somewhat due to the lower heat addition temperature.
4 Gas turbines for instance have turbine entry temperatures approaching 1500 °C.
5 Nonetheless the efficiencies of actual large steam cycles and large modern gas turbines are fairly well matched.
6 citation needed.
7 What is a main advantage of the Rankine cycle?	during the compression stage relatively little work is required to drive the pump	1
8 During the compression stage of the Rankine cycle what state is the working fluid in?	liquid	1
9 How much turbine power is consumed by the pump while the work fluid is condensed?	1 to 3	2
10 What is the approximate turbine entry temperature of a gas turbine?	1500 °C	4
1 Other components are often present pumps such as an injector to supply water to the boiler during operation condensers to recirculate the water and recover the latent heat of vaporisation and superheaters to raise the temperature of the steam above its saturated vapour point and various mechanisms to increase the draft for fireboxes.
2 When coal is used a chain or screw stoking mechanism and its drive engine or motor may be included to move the fuel from a supply bin bunker to the firebox.
3 See Mechanical stoker.
4 What is an example of a pump component?	injector	1
5 In addition to recirculating water what do condensers do?	recover the latent heat of vaporisation	1
6 What components raise steam temperature above its saturated vapor point?	superheaters	1
7 What is another name for a coal supply bin?	bunker	2
8 What mechanism moves coal from a bunker to the firebox?	stoking	2
1 Landbased steam engines could exhaust much of their steam as feed water was usually readily available.
2 Prior to and during World War I the expansion engine dominated marine applications where high vessel speed was not essential.
3 It was however superseded by the British invention steam turbine where speed was required for instance in warships such as the dreadnought battleships and ocean liners.
4 HMS Dreadnought of 1905 was the first major warship to replace the proven technology of the reciprocating engine with the thennovel steam turbine.
5 citation needed.
6 The frequent availability of what substance allowed landbased steam engines to exhaust a great deal of steam?	feed water	1
7 People of what nationality invented the steam turbine?	British	3
8 What was an example of a type of warship that required high speed?	dreadnought battleships	3
9 Other than warships what ships typically required high speeds?	ocean liners	3
10 In what year was HMS Dreadnought launched?	1905	4
1 Virtually all nuclear power plants generate electricity by heating water to provide steam that drives a turbine connected to an electrical generator.
2 Nuclearpowered ships and submarines either use a steam turbine directly for main propulsion with generators providing auxiliary power or else employ turboelectric transmission where the steam drives a turbo generator set with propulsion provided by electric motors.
3 A limited number of steam turbine railroad locomotives were manufactured.
4 Some noncondensing directdrive locomotives did meet with some success for long haul freight operations in Sweden and for express passenger work in Britain but were not repeated.
5 Elsewhere notably in the USA more advanced designs with electric transmission were built experimentally but not reproduced.
6 It was found that steam turbines were not ideally suited to the railroad environment and these locomotives failed to oust the classic reciprocating steam unit in the way that modern diesel and electric traction has done.
7 citation needed.
8 What do nuclear power plants heat to create electricity?	water	1
9 What does the steam generated by a nuclear power plant drive?	turbine	1
10 In a nuclear power plant what is the steam turbine connected to?	electrical generator	1
11 What is it called when steam propels a turbo generator with electric motor propulsion?	turboelectric transmission	2
12 Where were noncondensing directdrive locomotives notably used for fast passenger trains?	Britain	4
1 The Rankine cycle is sometimes referred to as a practical Carnot cycle because when an efficient turbine is used the TS diagram begins to resemble the Carnot cycle.
2 The main difference is that heat addition in the boiler and rejection in the condenser are isobaric constant pressure processes in the Rankine cycle and isothermal constant temperature processes in the theoretical Carnot cycle.
3 In this cycle a pump is used to pressurize the working fluid which is received from the condenser as a liquid not as a gas.
4 Pumping the working fluid in liquid form during the cycle requires a small fraction of the energy to transport it compared to the energy needed to compress the working fluid in gaseous form in a compressor as in the Carnot cycle.
5 The cycle of a reciprocating steam engine differs from that of turbines because of condensation and reevaporation occurring in the cylinder or in the steam inlet passages.
6 What is the Rankine cycle sometimes called?	practical Carnot cycle	1
7 Where does heat rejection occur in the Rankine cycle?	in the condenser	2
8 What does isobaric mean?	constant pressure	2
9 What is a term that means constant temperature?	isothermal	2
10 In the Rankine cycle in what state is the working fluid received in the condenser?	liquid	3
1 Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8.
2 It is a member of the chalcogen group on the periodic table and is a highly reactive nonmetal and oxidizing agent that readily forms compounds notably oxides with most elements.
3 By mass oxygen is the thirdmost abundant element in the universe after hydrogen and helium.
4 At standard temperature and pressure two atoms of the element bind to form dioxygen a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the formula O2.
5 Diatomic oxygen gas constitutes 208 of the Earths atmosphere.
6 However monitoring of atmospheric oxygen levels show a global downward trend because of fossilfuel burning.
7 Oxygen is the most abundant element by mass in the Earths crust as part of oxide compounds such as silicon dioxide making up almost half of the crusts mass.
8 The atomic number of the periodic table for oxygen?	8	1
9 What is the second most abundant element?	helium	3
10 How many atoms combine to form dioxygen?	two atoms	4
11 Roughly how much oxygen makes up the Earth crust?	almost half	7
12 Which gas makes up 208 of the Earths atmosphere?	Diatomic oxygen	5
13 How much of the earths atmosphere is diatomic oxygen?	208	5
14 What element makes up almost half of the earths crust by mass?	Oxygen	7
15 What is the atomic number for oxygen?	8	1
16 Are atmospheric oxygen levels going up down or staying the same?	monitoring of atmospheric oxygen levels show a global downward trend	6
17 What are the three most abundent elements of the universe by mass?	By mass  oxygen is the thirdmost abundant element in the universe  after hydrogen and helium	3
18 What is the atomic number of the element oxygen?	8	1
19 Of what group in the periodic table is oxygen a member?	chalcogen	2
20 What type of compounds does oxygen most commonly form?	oxides	2
21 Compared to other elements how abundant does oxygen rank?	third	3
22 Under normal conditions what do two atoms of oxygen form?	dioxygen	4
1 Many major classes of organic molecules in living organisms such as proteins nucleic acids carbohydrates and fats contain oxygen as do the major inorganic compounds that are constituents of animal shells teeth and bone.
2 Most of the mass of living organisms is oxygen as it is a part of water the major constituent of lifeforms.
3 Oxygen is used in cellular respiration and released by photosynthesis which uses the energy of sunlight to produce oxygen from water.
4 It is too chemically reactive to remain a free element in air without being continuously replenished by the photosynthetic action of living organisms.
5 Another form allotrope of oxygen ozone O3 strongly absorbs UVB radiation and consequently the highaltitude ozone layer helps protect the biosphere from ultraviolet radiation but is a pollutant near the surface where it is a byproduct of smog.
6 At even higher low earth orbit altitudes sufficient atomic oxygen is present to cause erosion for spacecraft.
7 Oxygen is released in cellular respiration by?	photosynthesis	3
8 Photosynthesis uses which energy to for oxygen from water?	sunlight	3
9  Helps the biospher from UV	highaltitude ozone layer 	5.
10 What element is found in most organic organisms?	oxygen	1
11 In what major portion of living things is oxygen found?	water	2
12 What life process produces oxygen in the presence of light?	photosynthesis	3
13 From what does photosynthesis get oxygen?	water	3
14 What form of oxygen is composed of three oxygen atoms?	ozone	5
1 In the late 17th century Robert Boyle proved that air is necessary for combustion.
2 English chemist John Mayow 1641–1679 refined this work by showing that fire requires only a part of air that he called spiritus nitroaereus or just nitroaereus.
3 In one experiment he found that placing either a mouse or a lit candle in a closed container over water caused the water to rise and replace onefourteenth of the airs volume before extinguishing the subjects.
4 From this he surmised that nitroaereus is consumed in both respiration and combustion.
5 Who proved that air is necessary for combustion?	Robert Boyle	1
6 What English chemist showed that fire only needed nitoaereus?	John Mayow	2
7 What is consumed in both combustion and respiration?	nitroaereus	4
8 John Mayow died in what year?	1679	2
9 What researcher showed that air is a necessity for combustion?	Robert Boyle	1
10 What did John Mayow  name the part of air that caused combustion?	nitroaereus	2
11 In what century did Mayow and Boyle perform their experiments?	17th century	1
12 Besides combustion for what other action did Mayow show nitroaereus responsible?	respiration	4
13 What chemist showed that fire needed only a part of air?	John Mayow	2
1 In the meantime on August 1 1774 an experiment conducted by the British clergyman Joseph Priestley focused sunlight on mercuric oxide HgO inside a glass tube which liberated a gas he named dephlogisticated air.
2 He noted that candles burned brighter in the gas and that a mouse was more active and lived longer while breathing it.
3 After breathing the gas himself he wrote The feeling of it to my lungs was not sensibly different from that of common air but I fancied that my breast felt peculiarly light and easy for some time afterwards.
4 Priestley published his findings in 1775 in a paper titled An Account of Further Discoveries in Air which was included in the second volume of his book titled Experiments and Observations on Different Kinds of Air.
5 Because he published his findings first Priestley is usually given priority in the discovery.
6 An Account of Further Discoveries in Air was published by who in 1775?	Joseph Priestley	1
7 What was the occupation of Joseph Priestley?	clergyman	1
8 The symbol for mercuric oxide is?	HgO	1
9 By sunlight what compound did  Priestley concentrate on to make the gas he called dephlogisticated air?	mercuric oxide HgO	1
10 What chemical did Priestley use in his experiments on oxygen?	mercuric oxide	1
11 What did Priestley name the gas his experiment produced?	dephlogisticated air	1
12 In what year did Priestley publish the findings of his experiments?	1775	4
13 Why is Priestley usually given credit for being first to discover oxygen?	published his findings first	5
14 What effect did breathing Priestleys discovered gas have on the experiments mouse?	active	2
1 One of the first known experiments on the relationship between combustion and air was conducted by the 2nd century BCE Greek writer on mechanics Philo of Byzantium.
2 In his work Pneumatica Philo observed that inverting a vessel over a burning candle and surrounding the vessels neck with water resulted in some water rising into the neck.
3 Philo incorrectly surmised that parts of the air in the vessel were converted into the classical element fire and thus were able to escape through pores in the glass.
4 Many centuries later Leonardo da Vinci built on Philos work by observing that a portion of air is consumed during combustion and respiration.
5 What inventor built on to the findings of Philo of  Byzantium?	Leonardo da Vinci	4
6 Pneumatica was written by what Greek writer?	Philo of Byzantium	1
7 In what year was the first known experiments on combustion and air conducted?	2nd century BCE	1
8 Philo of Byzantium  surmised that air converted to fire	incorrectly 	3.
9 What early Greek wrote about experiments on air and combustion?	Philo of Byzantium	1
10 What did Philo incorrectly assume that the air became?	fire	3
11 What was the title of Philos work?	Pneumatica	2
12 What famous artist later further investigated Philos experiments?	Leonardo da Vinci	4
13 Of what did da Vinci think a part  was consumed during combustion?	air	4
1 Highly concentrated sources of oxygen promote rapid combustion.
2 Fire and explosion hazards exist when concentrated oxidants and fuels are brought into close proximity an ignition event such as heat or a spark is needed to trigger combustion.
3 Oxygen is the oxidant not the fuel but nevertheless the source of most of the chemical energy released in combustion.
4 Combustion hazards also apply to compounds of oxygen with a high oxidative potential such as peroxides chlorates nitrates perchlorates and dichromates because they can donate oxygen to a fire.
5 What is needed to make combustion happen?	heat or a spark	2
6 Combustion is caused by an oxidant and a fuel What role does oxygen play in combustion?	Oxygen is the oxidant	3
7 Peroxides nitrates and dichromates are examples of what type of compounds?	compounds of oxygen with a high oxidative	4
8 Although not a fuel   is the chemical compound the generates the most occurrence of explosions	Oxygen 	3.
9 What is a spark or heat to the progress of a fire?	ignition event	2
10 Rather than the fuel what is oxygen to a fire?	oxidant	3
11 What can concentrated oxygen produce?	rapid combustion	1
12 What does oxygen the basis for in combustion?	chemical energy	3
13 What other sources of high oxidative potential can add to a fire?	compounds of oxygen	4
1 Concentrated O2 will allow combustion to proceed rapidly and energetically.
2 Steel pipes and storage vessels used to store and transmit both gaseous and liquid oxygen will act as a fuel and therefore the design and manufacture of O2 systems requires special training to ensure that ignition sources are minimized.
3 The fire that killed the Apollo 1 crew in a launch pad test spread so rapidly because the capsule was pressurized with pure O2 but at slightly more than atmospheric pressure instead of the 1⁄3 normal pressure that would be used in a mission.
4 k.
5 What chemical element was the cause of the Apollo 1 disastrous outcome?	pure O	3

7 To ensure safety of future space missions Oxygen was used at  of the normal pressure	1⁄3 	3.
8 To reduce the chances of combustion  is required for safely handeling pure O	special training 	2.

10 Because of the danger inherent in concentrated oxygen what is a concern about keeping it?	storage vessels	2
11 What does the transport and storage demand for safety in dealing with oxygen?	special training	2
12 Who did a pressurized oxygen cabin fire kill?	Apollo 1 crew	3
1 Oxygen is present in the atmosphere in trace quantities in the form of carbon dioxide CO2.
2 The Earths crustal rock is composed in large part of oxides of silicon silica SiO2 as found in granite and quartz aluminium aluminium oxide Al2O3 in bauxite and corundum iron ironIII oxide Fe2O3 in hematite and rust and calcium carbonate in limestone.
3 The rest of the Earths crust is also made of oxygen compounds in particular various complex silicates in silicate minerals.
4 The Earths mantle of much larger mass than the crust is largely composed of silicates of magnesium and iron.
5 Granite is made up largely of what chemical compound?	oxides of silicon	2
6 Oxygen exists in the atmosphere by way of what?	carbon dioxide	1
