10 What part of the Earth is composed of mostly of silicates of iron and magnesium?	Earths mantle	4
11 What part of the Earths geological structure is larger than the crust?	mantle	4
12 Aside from oxides what other compounds comprise a large portion of the Earths crust?	complex silicates	3
1 John Daltons original atomic hypothesis assumed that all elements were monatomic and that the atoms in compounds would normally have the simplest atomic ratios with respect to one another.
2 For example Dalton assumed that waters formula was HO giving the atomic mass of oxygen as 8 times that of hydrogen instead of the modern value of about 16.
3 In 1805 Joseph Louis GayLussac and Alexander von Humboldt showed that water is formed of two volumes of hydrogen and one volume of oxygen and by 1811 Amedeo Avogadro had arrived at the correct interpretation of waters composition based on what is now called Avogadros law and the assumption of diatomic elemental molecules.
4 a.
5 What did John Dalton think that all elements were in number present in compounds?	monatomic	1
6 What did Dalton think the atomic ratios were between atoms in compounds?	simplest	1
7 What was Daltons erroneous formula for water?	HO	2
8 What element did GayLussac and von Humboldt discover was present in twice the amount of oxygen in water?	hydrogen	3
9 What theory was arrived at in 1811 that presented the assumption of diatomic molecules?	Avogadros law	3
1 Highly combustible materials that leave little residue such as wood or coal were thought to be made mostly of phlogiston whereas noncombustible substances that corrode such as iron contained very little.
2 Air did not play a role in phlogiston theory nor were any initial quantitative experiments conducted to test the idea instead it was based on observations of what happens when something burns that most common objects appear to become lighter and seem to lose something in the process.
3 The fact that a substance like wood gains overall weight in burning was hidden by the buoyancy of the gaseous combustion products.
4 Indeed one of the first clues that the phlogiston theory was incorrect was that metals too gain weight in rusting when they were supposedly losing phlogiston.
5 Of what were materials that left little residue thought to contain?	phlogiston	2
6 What type of combustible materials were considered to have little philogiston?	noncombustible	1
7 What distinct quality of combustion was  absent from philogiston theory?	Air	2
8 What materials weight gain during rusting was an early clue that philogiston theory was wrong?	metals	4
9 What characteristic due most items display after burning?	become lighter	2
1 In this dioxygen the two oxygen atoms are chemically bonded to each other.
2 The bond can be variously described based on level of theory but is reasonably and simply described as a covalent double bond that results from the filling of molecular orbitals formed from the atomic orbitals of the individual oxygen atoms the filling of which results in a bond order of two.
3 More specifically the double bond is the result of sequential lowtohigh energy or Aufbau filling of orbitals and the resulting cancellation of contributions from the 2s electrons after sequential filling of the low σ and σ orbitals σ overlap of the two atomic 2p orbitals that lie along the OO molecular axis and π overlap of two pairs of atomic 2p orbitals perpendicular to the OO molecular axis and then cancellation of contributions from the remaining two of the six 2p electrons after their partial filling of the lowest π and π orbitals.
4 How is dioxygen most simply described?	covalent double bond	2
5 What is the bond order of dioxygen molecules?	two	2
6 What is a descriptive term for a lowtohigh energy bond?	Aufbau	3
7 In dioxygen how are the two oxygen atoms bonded together?	chemically	1
8 Of what does the covalent double bond result from ?	molecular orbitals	2
1 Oxygen was discovered independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in Uppsala in 1773 or earlier and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire in 1774 but Priestley is often given priority because his work was published first.
2 The name oxygen was coined in 1777 by Antoine Lavoisier whose experiments with oxygen helped to discredit the thenpopular phlogiston theory of combustion and corrosion.
3 Its name derives from the Greek roots ὀξύς oxys acid literally sharp referring to the sour taste of acids and γενής genes producer literally begetter because at the time of naming it was mistakenly thought that all acids required oxygen in their composition.
4 Common uses of oxygen includes the production cycle of steel plastics and textiles brazing welding and cutting of steels and other metals rocket propellant in oxygen therapy and life support systems in aircraft submarines spaceflight and diving.
5 When did Carl Wilhelm Scheele discover oxygen?	1773	1
6 In what year did Joseph Priestley recognize oxygen?	1774	1
7 What gave Priestley the claim to being the first discovered of oxygen?	work was published first	1
8 What researcher first used the word oxygen ?	Antoine Lavoisier	2
9 What previous work did Lavoisier experiments discredit?	phlogiston theory	2
1 This combination of cancellations and σ and π overlaps results in dioxygens double bond character and reactivity and a triplet electronic ground state.
2 An electron configuration with two unpaired electrons as found in dioxygen see the filled π orbitals in the diagram orbitals that are of equal energy—ie degenerate—is a configuration termed a spin triplet state.
3 Hence the ground state of the O2 molecule is referred to as triplet oxygen.
4 b The highest energy partially filled orbitals are antibonding and so their filling weakens the bond order from three to two.
5 Because of its unpaired electrons triplet oxygen reacts only slowly with most organic molecules which have paired electron spins this prevents spontaneous combustion.
6 What is the term for the arrangement of two unpaired electrons in dioxygen?	spin triplet state	2
7 How is the O2 molecule referred to in its ground state?	triplet oxygen	3
8 What causes triplet oxygen to react slowly?	unpaired electrons	5
9 What type of combustion does the slow reaction of triplet oxygen prevent?	spontaneous	5
10 What are the weakly filled higher orbitals of oxygen?	antibonding	4
1 In one experiment Lavoisier observed that there was no overall increase in weight when tin and air were heated in a closed container.
2 He noted that air rushed in when he opened the container which indicated that part of the trapped air had been consumed.
3 He also noted that the tin had increased in weight and that increase was the same as the weight of the air that rushed back in.
4 This and other experiments on combustion were documented in his book Sur la combustion en général which was published in 1777.
5 In that work he proved that air is a mixture of two gases vital air which is essential to combustion and respiration and azote Gk.
6 ἄζωτον lifeless which did not support either.
7 Azote later became nitrogen in English although it has kept the name in French and several other European languages.
8 What did Lavoisier conclude was consumed by combustion in his experiments?	air	2
9 In what way did Lavoisier see that the tin he used in his experiment had increased?	weight	3
10 What did Lavoisier perceive the air had lost as much as the tin had gained	weight 	3.
11 In what year did Lavoisier publish his work on combustion?	1777	4
12 What second part of air was deemed lifeless by Lavoisier?	azote	5
1 Trioxygen O3 is usually known as ozone and is a very reactive allotrope of oxygen that is damaging to lung tissue.
2 Ozone is produced in the upper atmosphere when O2 combines with atomic oxygen made by the splitting of O2 by ultraviolet UV radiation.
3 Since ozone absorbs strongly in the UV region of the spectrum the ozone layer of the upper atmosphere functions as a protective radiation shield for the planet.
4 Near the Earths surface it is a pollutant formed as a byproduct of automobile exhaust.
5 The metastable molecule tetraoxygen O4 was discovered in 2001 and was assumed to exist in one of the six phases of solid oxygen.
6 It was proven in 2006 that this phase created by pressurizing O2 to 20 GPa is in fact a rhombohedral O8 cluster.
7 This cluster has the potential to be a much more powerful oxidizer than either O2 or O3 and may therefore be used in rocket fuel.
8 A metallic phase was discovered in 1990 when solid oxygen is subjected to a pressure of above 96 GPa and it was shown in 1998 that at very low temperatures this phase becomes superconducting.
9 What is the name for O3 most often used?	ozone	1
10 Of what is ozone a reactive part of oxygen?	allotrope	1
11 What  does ozones characteristic to cause damage effect?	lung tissue	1
12 What function does ozone perform for the planet?	protective radiation shield	3
13 What light radiation does ozone absorb?	UV	3
1 The common allotrope of elemental oxygen on Earth is called dioxygen O2.
2 It is the form that is a major part of the Earths atmosphere see Occurrence.
3 O2 has a bond length of 121 pm and a bond energy of 498 kJ·mol−1 which is smaller than the energy of other double bonds or pairs of single bonds in the biosphere and responsible for the exothermic reaction of O2 with any organic molecule.
4 Due to its energy content O2 is used by complex forms of life such as animals in cellular respiration see Biological role.
5 Other aspects of O2 are covered in the remainder of this article.
6 What is the most common form of oxygen on the planet?	dioxygen	1
7 What is the scientific designation of oxygen?	O2	3
8 What part the composition of the Earths atmosphere is comprised of oxygen?	major	2
9 What characteristic of oxygen makes it necessary to life?	energy content	4
10 For what purpose is oxygen used by animal life?	cellular respiration	4
1 In 1891 Scottish chemist James Dewar was able to produce enough liquid oxygen to study.
2 The first commercially viable process for producing liquid oxygen was independently developed in 1895 by German engineer Carl von Linde and British engineer William Hampson.
3 Both men lowered the temperature of air until it liquefied and then distilled the component gases by boiling them off one at a time and capturing them.
4 Later in 1901 oxyacetylene welding was demonstrated for the first time by burning a mixture of acetylene and compressed O2.
5 This method of welding and cutting metal later became common.
6 What chemist managed to make enough liquid oxygen to use for study?	James Dewar	1
7 In what year did Dewar experiment on liquid oxygen?	1891	1
8 When was liquid oxygen developed for commercial use?	1895	2
9 What welding process was demonstrated in 1901?	oxyacetylene	4
1 Oxygen is more soluble in water than nitrogen is.
2 Water in equilibrium with air contains approximately 1 molecule of dissolved O2 for every 2 molecules of N2 compared to an atmospheric ratio of approximately 14.
3 The solubility of oxygen in water is temperaturedependent and about twice as much 146 mg·L−1 dissolves at 0 °C than at 20 °C 76 mg·L−1.
4 At 25 °C and 1 standard atmosphere 1013 kPa of air freshwater contains about 604 milliliters mL of oxygen per liter whereas seawater contains about 495 mL per liter.
5 At 5 °C the solubility increases to 90 mL 50 more than at 25 °C per liter for water and 72 mL 45 more per liter for sea water.
6 What component of water is more soluble than nitrogen?	Oxygen	1
7 Upon what chemical characteristic is oxygens solubility dependent?	temperature	3
8 How much oxygen is found is a liter of fresh water under normal conditions?	604 milliliters	4
9 In what type of water does oxygen dissolve more slowly?	seawater	4
10 How much more oxygen dissolves at 0 degrees C than at 20 degrees C?	twice	3
1 Oxygen is the most abundant chemical element by mass in the Earths biosphere air sea and land.
2 Oxygen is the third most abundant chemical element in the universe after hydrogen and helium.
3 About 09 of the Suns mass is oxygen.
4 Oxygen constitutes 492 of the Earths crust by mass and is the major component of the worlds oceans 888 by mass.
5 Oxygen gas is the second most common component of the Earths atmosphere taking up 208 of its volume and 231 of its mass some 1015 tonnes.
6 d Earth is unusual among the planets of the Solar System in having such a high concentration of oxygen gas in its atmosphere Mars with 01 O2 by volume and Venus have far lower concentrations.
7 The O2 surrounding these other planets is produced solely by ultraviolet radiation impacting oxygencontaining molecules such as carbon dioxide.
8 Where does oxygen rank by mass in the planets biosphere?	most abundant	1
9 How is oxygen ranked as abundant in the universe?	third	2
10 How much of the sun is made up of oxygen?	09	3
11 Where  by mass is oxygen a major part?	worlds oceans	4
12 How is oxygen produced from carbon dioxide on the other planets of the solar system?	ultraviolet radiation	7
1 By the late 19th century scientists realized that air could be liquefied and its components isolated by compressing and cooling it.
2 Using a cascade method Swiss chemist and physicist Raoul Pierre Pictet evaporated liquid sulfur dioxide in order to liquefy carbon dioxide which in turn was evaporated to cool oxygen gas enough to liquefy it.
3 He sent a telegram on December 22 1877 to the French Academy of Sciences in Paris announcing his discovery of liquid oxygen.
4 Just two days later French physicist Louis Paul Cailletet announced his own method of liquefying molecular oxygen.
5 Only a few drops of the liquid were produced in either case so no meaningful analysis could be conducted.
6 Oxygen was liquified in stable state for the first time on March 29 1883 by Polish scientists from Jagiellonian University Zygmunt Wróblewski and Karol Olszewski.
7 By what century did researchers see that they could liquefy air?	late 19th	1
8 By what means were scientists able to liquefy air?	compressing and cooling	1
9 What scientist told the French Academy of Sciences that he had found how to liquefy oxygen?	Raoul Pierre Pictet	2
10 What minor amount of liquid oxygen was produced by early French experimenters?	few drops	5
11 On what date was oxygen liquefied in a stable form?	March 29  1883	6
1 Planetary geologists have measured different abundances of oxygen isotopes in samples from the Earth the Moon Mars and meteorites but were long unable to obtain reference values for the isotope ratios in the Sun believed to be the same as those of the primordial solar nebula.
2 Analysis of a silicon wafer exposed to the solar wind in space and returned by the crashed Genesis spacecraft has shown that the Sun has a higher proportion of oxygen16 than does the Earth.
3 The measurement implies that an unknown process depleted oxygen16 from the Suns disk of protoplanetary material prior to the coalescence of dust grains that formed the Earth.
4 What celestial object eluded efforts to measure oxygen?	Sun	1
5 What molecule does the Sun have in higher proportion than Earth?	oxygen16	2
6 What spacecraft contained data to determine the oxygen content of the Sun?	Genesis spacecraft	2
7 What type of process was involved the the depletion of the Suns oxygen 16?	unknown	3
8 Before the formation of which planet did Sol lose oxygen 16?	Earth	3
1 Singlet oxygen is a name given to several higherenergy species of molecular O2 in which all the electron spins are paired.
2 It is much more reactive towards common organic molecules than is molecular oxygen per se.
3 In nature singlet oxygen is commonly formed from water during photosynthesis using the energy of sunlight.
4 It is also produced in the troposphere by the photolysis of ozone by light of short wavelength and by the immune system as a source of active oxygen.
5 Carotenoids in photosynthetic organisms and possibly also in animals play a major role in absorbing energy from singlet oxygen and converting it to the unexcited ground state before it can cause harm to tissues.
6 What is the name for a form of oxygen in which electrons are paired?	Singlet	1
7 To what is singlet oxygen more reactive?	organic molecules	2
8 In what process is singlet oxygen usually formed?	photosynthesis	3
9 By what process is singlet oxygen made in the tropophere?	photolysis of ozone	4
10 What objects in organisms absorb singlet oxygen to prevent harm?	Carotenoids	5
1 Paleoclimatologists measure the ratio of oxygen18 and oxygen16 in the shells and skeletons of marine organisms to determine what the climate was like millions of years ago see oxygen isotope ratio cycle.
2 Seawater molecules that contain the lighter isotope oxygen16 evaporate at a slightly faster rate than water molecules containing the 12 heavier oxygen18 this disparity increases at lower temperatures.
3 During periods of lower global temperatures snow and rain from that evaporated water tends to be higher in oxygen16 and the seawater left behind tends to be higher in oxygen18.
4 Marine organisms then incorporate more oxygen18 into their skeletons and shells than they would in a warmer climate.
5 Paleoclimatologists also directly measure this ratio in the water molecules of ice core samples that are up to several hundreds of thousands of years old.
6 What group of scientists seek to measure the amounts of oxygen in marine animals?	Paleoclimatologists	1
7 About what weather feature do paleoclimatologists want information ?	climate	1
8 How much heavier is oxygen 18 than oxygen 16?	12	2
9 What form of oxygen do marine animals acquire in greater amounts during cooler climatic conditions?	oxygen18	3
10 During what type of climate is oxygen 18 in seawater at higher levels?	lower global temperatures	3
1 Oxygen presents two spectrophotometric absorption bands peaking at the wavelengths 687 and 760 nm.
2 Some remote sensing scientists have proposed using the measurement of the radiance coming from vegetation canopies in those bands to characterize plant health status from a satellite platform.
3 This approach exploits the fact that in those bands it is possible to discriminate the vegetations reflectance from its fluorescence which is much weaker.
4 The measurement is technically difficult owing to the low signaltonoise ratio and the physical structure of vegetation but it has been proposed as a possible method of monitoring the carbon cycle from satellites on a global scale.
5 At what wavelength do the spectrophotometric bands peak?	687 and 760 nm	1
6 To monitor what event would measuring radiance from vegetation provide information?	carbon cycle	4
7 From where would scientists like measure vegetation radiance?	satellite platform	2
8 On what scale would scientists show measurements of vegetation?	global	4
9 What style of sensing do scientist like to use to measure global radiance?	remote sensing	2
1 In the triplet form O2 molecules are paramagnetic.
2 That is they impart magnetic character to oxygen when it is in the presence of a magnetic field because of the spin magnetic moments of the unpaired electrons in the molecule and the negative exchange energy between neighboring O2 molecules.
3 Liquid oxygen is attracted to a magnet to a sufficient extent that in laboratory demonstrations a bridge of liquid oxygen may be supported against its own weight between the poles of a powerful magnet.
4 c.
5 What magnetic character do triplet O2 have?	paramagnetic	1
6 In experiments a bridge of what element can be built between poles of a magnet?	Liquid oxygen	3
7 The spin of what can produce a magnetic effect to oxygen molecules?	unpaired electrons	2
8 What kind of field is necessary to produce a magnet effect in oxygen molecules?	magnetic field	2
9 What device is used to test the magnetic attractions involved in liquid oxygen?	powerful magnet	3
1 Reactive oxygen species such as superoxide ion O−2 and hydrogen peroxide H2O2 are dangerous byproducts of oxygen use in organisms.
2 Parts of the immune system of higher organisms create peroxide superoxide and singlet oxygen to destroy invading microbes.
3 Reactive oxygen species also play an important role in the hypersensitive response of plants against pathogen attack.
4 Oxygen is toxic to obligately anaerobic organisms which were the dominant form of early life on Earth until O2 began to accumulate in the atmosphere about 25 billion years ago during the Great Oxygenation Event about a billion years after the first appearance of these organisms.
5 What do the reactive forms of oxygen produce in organisms?	dangerous byproducts	1
6 For what purpose do organisms make peroxide and superoxide?	destroy invading microbes	2
7 Against what does reactive oxygen play in plant defense?	pathogen attack	3
8 To what type of organisms is oxygen toxic?	anaerobic	4
9 When did O2 begin to acculturate in the atmosphere?	25 billion years ago	4
1 Oxygen condenses at 9020 K −18295 °C −29731 °F and freezes at 5436 K −21879 °C −36182 °F.
2 Both liquid and solid O2 are clear substances with a light skyblue color caused by absorption in the red in contrast with the blue color of the sky which is due to Rayleigh scattering of blue light.
3 Highpurity liquid O2 is usually obtained by the fractional distillation of liquefied air.
4 Liquid oxygen may also be produced by condensation out of air using liquid nitrogen as a coolant.
5 It is a highly reactive substance and must be segregated from combustible materials.
6 At what temperature will oxygen condense?	9020 K	1
7 What is the clarity of liquid oxygen?	clear	2
8 What substance is used to make high quality liquid O2?	liquefied air	3
9 What element is used as a coolant in the process of making liquid oxygen?	liquid nitrogen	4
10 From what type of materials must liquid oxygen be separated?	combustible materials	5
1 Free oxygen also occurs in solution in the worlds water bodies.
2 The increased solubility of O2 at lower temperatures see Physical properties has important implications for ocean life as polar oceans support a much higher density of life due to their higher oxygen content.
3 Water polluted with plant nutrients such as nitrates or phosphates may stimulate growth of algae by a process called eutrophication and the decay of these organisms and other biomaterials may reduce amounts of O2 in eutrophic water bodies.
4 Scientists assess this aspect of water quality by measuring the waters biochemical oxygen demand or the amount of O2 needed to restore it to a normal concentration.
5 Where on Earth is free oxygen found?	water	1
6 At what temperatures is O2 more soluble?	lower	2
7 Why do polar water bodies support a higher amount of life?	higher oxygen content	2
8 Pollution of water by nitrates and phosphates will encourage the growth of what?	algae	3
9 What measurement do scientists used to determine the quality of water?	biochemical oxygen demand	4
1 Free oxygen gas was almost nonexistent in Earths atmosphere before photosynthetic archaea and bacteria evolved probably about 35 billion years ago.
2 Free oxygen first appeared in significant quantities during the Paleoproterozoic eon between 30 and 23 billion years ago.
3 For the first billion years any free oxygen produced by these organisms combined with dissolved iron in the oceans to form banded iron formations.
4 When such oxygen sinks became saturated free oxygen began to outgas from the oceans 3–27 billion years ago reaching 10 of its present level around 17 billion years ago.
5 When did photosynthetic organisms evolve on Earth?	35 billion years ago	1
6 During which eon did free oxygen begin appearing in quantity?	Paleoproterozoic	2
7 At first what did oxygen and iron combine to form?	banded iron formations	3
8 How long ago did oxygen reach 10 of its present level?	17 billion years ago	4
9 When did oxygen begin to move from the oceans to the atmosphere?	3–27 billion years ago	4
1 The unusually high concentration of oxygen gas on Earth is the result of the oxygen cycle.
2 This biogeochemical cycle describes the movement of oxygen within and between its three main reservoirs on Earth the atmosphere the biosphere and the lithosphere.
3 The main driving factor of the oxygen cycle is photosynthesis which is responsible for modern Earths atmosphere.
4 Photosynthesis releases oxygen into the atmosphere while respiration and decay remove it from the atmosphere.
5 In the present equilibrium production and consumption occur at the same rate of roughly 12000th of the entire atmospheric oxygen per year.
6 What produces the high levels of oxygen on Earth?	oxygen cycle	1
7 What type of process is the oxygen cycle?	biogeochemical	2
8 In how many places is oxygen stored in its cycle?	three	2
9 What process is responsible for the planets oxygen content?	photosynthesis	3
10 What does photosynthesis release into the Earths atmosphere?	oxygen	4
1 The other major method of producing O2 gas involves passing a stream of clean dry air through one bed of a pair of identical zeolite molecular sieves which absorbs the nitrogen and delivers a gas stream that is 90 to 93 O2.
2 Simultaneously nitrogen gas is released from the other nitrogensaturated zeolite bed by reducing the chamber operating pressure and diverting part of the oxygen gas from the producer bed through it in the reverse direction of flow.
3 After a set cycle time the operation of the two beds is interchanged thereby allowing for a continuous supply of gaseous oxygen to be pumped through a pipeline.
4 This is known as pressure swing adsorption.
5 Oxygen gas is increasingly obtained by these noncryogenic technologies see also the related vacuum swing adsorption.
6 What mechanism can be used to make oxygen?	zeolite molecular sieves	1
7 What percentage of oxygen will a zeolite sieve produce?	90 to 93	1
8 While producing oxygen what gas does a zeolite sieve absorb?	nitrogen	1
9 What type of technology is the non organic separating of gases?	noncryogenic	5
10 How much is the sieve method of gas production used?	major method	1
1 Oxygen gas can also be produced through electrolysis of water into molecular oxygen and hydrogen.
2 DC electricity must be used if AC is used the gases in each limb consist of hydrogen and oxygen in the explosive ratio 21.
3 Contrary to popular belief the 21 ratio observed in the DC electrolysis of acidified water does not prove that the empirical formula of water is H2O unless certain assumptions are made about the molecular formulae of hydrogen and oxygen themselves.
4 A similar method is the electrocatalytic O2 evolution from oxides and oxoacids.
5 Chemical catalysts can be used as well such as in chemical oxygen generators or oxygen candles that are used as part of the lifesupport equipment on submarines and are still part of standard equipment on commercial airliners in case of depressurization emergencies.
6 Another air separation technology involves forcing air to dissolve through ceramic membranes based on zirconium dioxide by either high pressure or an electric current to produce nearly pure O2 gas.
7 Electrolysis of what can be used to produce oxygen and hydrogen?	water	1
8 What does the electrolysis of water produce?	oxygen and hydrogen	1
9 What type of electric current is needed for electrolysis?	DC	2
10 What is the source of oxygen production through electrocatalytic means?	oxides and oxoacids	4
11 What other catalysts can be used to produce oxygen?	Chemical	5
1 Oxygen as a supposed mild euphoric has a history of recreational use in oxygen bars and in sports.
2 Oxygen bars are establishments found in Japan California and Las Vegas Nevada since the late 1990s that offer higher than normal O2 exposure for a fee.
3 Professional athletes especially in American football also sometimes go off field between plays to wear oxygen masks in order to get a boost in performance.
4 The pharmacological effect is doubtful a placebo effect is a more likely explanation.
5 Available studies support a performance boost from enriched O2 mixtures only if they are breathed during aerobic exercise.

7 What is the effect on humans of oxygen?	mild euphoric	1
8 What do professional athletes seek to boost from breathing oxygen?	performance	3
9 What is the most likely effect of breathing oxygen?	placebo	4
10 What type of exercise does research show receives a boost in performance from oxygen?	aerobic	5
1 Hyperbaric highpressure medicine uses special oxygen chambers to increase the partial pressure of O2 around the patient and when needed the medical staff.
2 Carbon monoxide poisoning gas gangrene and decompression sickness the bends are sometimes treated using these devices.
3 Increased O2 concentration in the lungs helps to displace carbon monoxide from the heme group of hemoglobin.
4 Oxygen gas is poisonous to the anaerobic bacteria that cause gas gangrene so increasing its partial pressure helps kill them.
5 Decompression sickness occurs in divers who decompress too quickly after a dive resulting in bubbles of inert gas mostly nitrogen and helium forming in their blood.
6 Increasing the pressure of O2 as soon as possible is part of the treatment.
7 What device is used to treat various conditions such as carbon monoxide poisoning?	Hyperbaric highpressure medicine	1
8 What does increased oxygen concentrations in the patients lungs displace?	carbon monoxide	3
9 To what pathogen that causes gas gangrene is oxygen poisonous?	anaerobic bacteria	4
10 What occurs after a dive in which a diver decompresses too quickly?	Decompression sickness	5
1 Uptake of O2 from the air is the essential purpose of respiration so oxygen supplementation is used in medicine.
2 Treatment not only increases oxygen levels in the patients blood but has the secondary effect of decreasing resistance to blood flow in many types of diseased lungs easing work load on the heart.
3 Oxygen therapy is used to treat emphysema pneumonia some heart disorders congestive heart failure some disorders that cause increased pulmonary artery pressure and any disease that impairs the bodys ability to take up and use gaseous oxygen.
4 What medical treatment is used to benefit patients with hearth and lung disorders?	Oxygen therapy	3
5 By decreasing resistance to blood flow in the lungs what organs workload  can be eased?	heart	2
6 What medical treatment is used to increase oxygen uptake in a patient?	oxygen supplementation	1
7 In what process is the uptake from oxygen necessary?	respiration	1
8 What does  oxygen therapy promote the body to take up?	gaseous oxygen	3
1 Due to its electronegativity oxygen forms chemical bonds with almost all other elements to give corresponding oxides.
2 The surface of most metals such as aluminium and titanium are oxidized in the presence of air and become coated with a thin film of oxide that passivates the metal and slows further corrosion.
3 Many oxides of the transition metals are nonstoichiometric compounds with slightly less metal than the chemical formula would show.
4 For example the mineral FeO wüstite is written as Fe1 − xO where x is usually around 005.
5 What characteristic of oxygen causes it to form bonds with other elements?	electronegativity	1
6 What is usual form of oxygen bound compounds?	oxides	1
7 What is the mineral wustite?	FeO	4
8 What does oxygen cause to form on metals?	oxide	2
9 What does the film of oxide on metals delay?	corrosion	2
1 People who climb mountains or fly in nonpressurized fixedwing aircraft sometimes have supplemental O2 supplies.
2 h Passengers traveling in pressurized commercial airplanes have an emergency supply of O2 automatically supplied to them in case of cabin depressurization.
3 Sudden cabin pressure loss activates chemical oxygen generators above each seat causing oxygen masks to drop.
4 Pulling on the masks to start the flow of oxygen as cabin safety instructions dictate forces iron filings into the sodium chlorate inside the canister.
5 A steady stream of oxygen gas is then produced by the exothermic reaction.
6 What event would necessitate airline passengers to need a supplemental supply of oxygen?	cabin depressurization	2
7 What is the type of oxygen production for emergency oxygen in airlines?	chemical	3
8 What type of reaction is present in the emergency oxygen generator of an airplane?	exothermic	5
9 What gas does the airline exothermic reaction produce?	oxygen gas	5
1 Oxygen storage methods include high pressure oxygen tanks cryogenics and chemical compounds.
2 For reasons of economy oxygen is often transported in bulk as a liquid in specially insulated tankers since one liter of liquefied oxygen is equivalent to 840 liters of gaseous oxygen at atmospheric pressure and 20 °C 68 °F.
3 Such tankers are used to refill bulk liquid oxygen storage containers which stand outside hospitals and other institutions with a need for large volumes of pure oxygen gas.
4 Liquid oxygen is passed through heat exchangers which convert the cryogenic liquid into gas before it enters the building.
5 Oxygen is also stored and shipped in smaller cylinders containing the compressed gas a form that is useful in certain portable medical applications and oxyfuel welding and cutting.
6 What do oxygen tanks cryogenics and chemical compounds serve as for oxygen?	storage	1
7 By what means is bulk oxygen shipped?	insulated tankers	2
8 In what state is oxygen shipped in bulk?	liquid	2
9 In what form is oxygen transported in smaller containers?	compressed gas	5
10 What type of organization would need large quantities of pure oxygen?	hospitals	3
1 Among the most important classes of organic compounds that contain oxygen are where R is an organic group alcohols ROH ethers ROR ketones RCOR aldehydes RCOH carboxylic acids RCOOH esters RCOOR acid anhydrides RCOOCOR and amides RCONR2.
2 There are many important organic solvents that contain oxygen including acetone methanol ethanol isopropanol furan THF diethyl ether dioxane ethyl acetate DMF DMSO acetic acid and formic acid.
3 Acetone CH32CO and phenol C6H5OH are used as feeder materials in the synthesis of many different substances.
4 Other important organic compounds that contain oxygen are glycerol formaldehyde glutaraldehyde citric acid acetic anhydride and acetamide.
5 Epoxides are ethers in which the oxygen atom is part of a ring of three atoms.
6 What type of compounds such as acetonecontain oxygen?	organic solvents	2
7 In what group of compounds is oxygen a necessary part?	organic compounds	1
8 What function do compounds like phenol and acetone serve in the manufacture of many other substances?	feeder materials	3
9 In what compound is oxygen part of a ring arrangement?	Epoxides	5
10 How are the compounds that contain oxygen considered in commerce?	important	1
1 The element is found in almost all biomolecules that are important to or generated by life.
2 Only a few common complex biomolecules such as squalene and the carotenes contain no oxygen.
3 Of the organic compounds with biological relevance carbohydrates contain the largest proportion by mass of oxygen.
4 All fats fatty acids amino acids and proteins contain oxygen due to the presence of carbonyl groups in these acids and their ester residues.
5 Oxygen also occurs in phosphate PO3−4 groups in the biologically important energycarrying molecules ATP and ADP in the backbone and the purines except adenine and pyrimidines of RNA and DNA and in bones as calcium phosphate and hydroxylapatite.
6 In what type of molecules are oxygen found?	biomolecules	1
7 How many biomolecules contain no oxygen?	Only a few	2
8 Which organic compounds contain the greatest amount of oxygen by mass?	carbohydrates	3
9 Besides fats fatty acids and amino acidswhat other organic compounds contain oxygen?	proteins	4
10 In what calcium containing body part is oxygen a part?	bones	5
1 Oxygen toxicity to the lungs and central nervous system can also occur in deep scuba diving and surface supplied diving.
2 Prolonged breathing of an air mixture with an O2 partial pressure more than 60 kPa can eventually lead to permanent pulmonary fibrosis.
3 Exposure to a O2 partial pressures greater than 160 kPa about 16 atm may lead to convulsions normally fatal for divers.
4 Acute oxygen toxicity causing seizures its most feared effect for divers can occur by breathing an air mixture with 21 O2 at 66 m or more of depth the same thing can occur by breathing 100 O2 at only 6 m.
5 What health condition can deep sea diving cause?	Oxygen toxicity	1
6 To what can the use of prolonged breathing of oxygen at 60 kPa lead?	pulmonary fibrosis	2
7 Pressures greater than what can lead to convulsions?	160 kPa	3
8 What is the most feared condition that divers want to avoid?	Acute oxygen toxicity	4
9 What physical condition can acute oxygen toxicity cause?	seizures	4
1 Breathing pure O2 in space applications such as in some modern space suits or in early spacecraft such as Apollo causes no damage due to the low total pressures used.
2 In the case of spacesuits the O2 partial pressure in the breathing gas is in general about 30 kPa 14 times normal and the resulting O2 partial pressure in the astronauts arterial blood is only marginally more than normal sealevel O2 partial pressure for more information on this see space suit and arterial blood gas.
3 Why is breathing oxygen in space craft not dangerous to health?	low total pressures	1
4 What is the oxygen partial pressure of space suits?	30 kPa	2
5 How much of normal is the oxygen breathed in space suits?	14 times normal	2
6 How much damage does breathing oxygen in space conditions cause?	no damage	1
7 What si the comparison to sea level with the oxygen level in space suits?	only marginally more	2
1 Oxygen gas O2 can be toxic at elevated partial pressures leading to convulsions and other health problems.
2 j Oxygen toxicity usually begins to occur at partial pressures more than 50 kilopascals kPa equal to about 50 oxygen composition at standard pressure or 25 times the normal sealevel O2 partial pressure of about 21 kPa.
3 This is not a problem except for patients on mechanical ventilators since gas supplied through oxygen masks in medical applications is typically composed of only 30–50 O2 by volume about 30 kPa at standard pressure.
4 although this figure also is subject to wide variation depending on type of mask.
5 When can oxygen gas produce a toxic condition?	at elevated partial pressures	1
6 At what point does oxygen toxicity begin to happen?	50 kilopascals	2
7 To what is 50 kilopascals equal?	50 oxygen	2
8 What medical appliance can be a concern for oxygen toxicity?	mechanical ventilators	3
9 What percentage of oxygen is usually supplied by a medical mask?	30–50	3
1 The 1973 oil crisis began in October 1973 when the members of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries OAPEC consisting of the Arab members of OPEC plus Egypt and Syria proclaimed an oil embargo.
2 By the end of the embargo in March 1974 the price of oil had risen from US3 per barrel to nearly 12 globally US prices were significantly higher.
3 The embargo caused an oil crisis or shock with many short and longterm effects on global politics and the global economy.
4 It was later called the first oil shock followed by the 1979 oil crisis termed the second oil shock.
5 When did the 1973 oil crisis begin?	October 1973	1
6 What was the price of oil in March of 1974?	nearly 12	2
7 When was the second oil crisis?	1979	4
8 What was another term used for the oil crisis?	first oil shock	4
9 Who proclaimed the oil embargo?	members of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries	1
1 The crisis had a major impact on international relations and created a rift within NATO.
2 Some European nations and Japan sought to disassociate themselves from United States foreign policy in the Middle East to avoid being targeted by the boycott.
3 Arab oil producers linked any future policy changes to peace between the belligerents.
4 To address this the Nixon Administration began multilateral negotiations with the combatants.
5 They arranged for Israel to pull back from the Sinai Peninsula and the Golan Heights.
6 By January 18 1974 US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger had negotiated an Israeli troop withdrawal from parts of the Sinai Peninsula.
7 The promise of a negotiated settlement between Israel and Syria was enough to convince Arab oil producers to lift the embargo in March 1974.
8 Why did the European nations and Japan separated themselves from United States during the crisis?	to avoid being targeted by the boycott	2
9 How did the Nixon administration negotiate with the uncooperative countries?	They arranged for Israel to pull back from the Sinai Peninsula and the Golan Heights	5
10 On what date did Henry Kissinger negotiate an Israeli troop withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula?	January 18  1974 	6
11 When did the Arab oil producers lift the embargo?	March 1974	7
1 On August 15 1971 the United States unilaterally pulled out of the Bretton Woods Accord.
2 The US abandoned the Gold Exchange Standard whereby the value of the dollar had been pegged to the price of gold and all other currencies were pegged to the dollar whose value was left to float rise and fall according to market demand.
3 Shortly thereafter Britain followed floating the pound sterling.
4 The other industrialized nations followed suit with their respective currencies.
5 Anticipating that currency values would fluctuate unpredictably for a time the industrialized nations increased their reserves by expanding their money supplies in amounts far greater than before.
6 The result was a depreciation of the dollar and other industrialized nations currencies.
7 Because oil was priced in dollars oil producers real income decreased.
8 In September 1971 OPEC issued a joint communiqué stating that from then on they would price oil in terms of a fixed amount of gold.
9 When did the United States withdraw from the Bretton Woods Accord?	On August 15  1971	1
10 What does it mean when currencies are left to float?	to float rise and fall according to market demand	2
11 Why was there a depreciation of the industrialized nations dollars?	industrialized nations increased their reserves	5
12 When did oil start getting priced in the terms of gold?	In September 1971	8
13 Why did oil start getting priced in terms of gold?	oil was priced in dollars  oil producers real income decreased	7
1 This contributed to the Oil Shock.
2 After 1971 OPEC was slow to readjust prices to reflect this depreciation.
3 From 1947 to 1967 the dollar price of oil had risen by less than two percent per year.
4 Until the oil shock the price had also remained fairly stable versus other currencies and commodities.
5 OPEC ministers had not developed institutional mechanisms to update prices in sync with changing market conditions so their real incomes lagged.
6 The substantial price increases of 1973–1974 largely returned their prices and corresponding incomes to Bretton Woods levels in terms of commodities such as gold.
7 From 1947 to 1967 how much did the price of oil increase?	risen by less than two percent per year	3
8 When did OPEC start to readjust oil prices?	After 1971	2
9 When did oil finally returned to its Bretton Woods levels?	1973–1974	6
10 The price of oil is usually a stable commodity until when?	Until the oil shock	4
1 On October 6 1973 Syria and Egypt with support from other Arab nations launched a surprise attack on Israel on Yom Kippur.
2 This renewal of hostilities in the Arab–Israeli conflict released the underlying economic pressure on oil prices.
3 At the time Iran was the worlds secondlargest oil exporter and a close US ally.
4 Weeks later the Shah of Iran said in an interview Of course the price of oil is going to rise.
5 Certainly.
6 And how.
7 Youve Western nations increased the price of the wheat you sell us by 300 percent and the same for sugar and cement You buy our crude oil and sell it back to us refined as petrochemicals at a hundred times the price youve paid us.
8 Its only fair that from now on you should pay more for oil.
9 Lets say ten times more.
10 When did Syria and Egypt launch a surprise attack on Israel?	On October 6  1973	1
11 Who was the worlds second largest oil producer?	Iran	3
12 How many times more did the other nations have to pay for oil after the surprise attack?	ten times more	9
13 Which oil producer is a close ally of the United States?	Iran	3
14 Why did the Shah of Iran gave an interview?	renewal of hostilities in the Arab–Israeli conflict	2
1 In response to American aid to Israel on October 16 1973 OPEC raised the posted price of oil by 70 to 511 a barrel.
2 The following day oil ministers agreed to the embargo a cut in production by five percent from Septembers output and to continue to cut production in five percent monthly increments until their economic and political objectives were met.
3 On October 19 Nixon requested Congress to appropriate 22 billion in emergency aid to Israel including 15 billion in outright grants.
4 George Lenczowski notes Military supplies did not exhaust Nixons eagerness to prevent Israels collapseThis 22 billion decision triggered a collective OPEC response.
5 Libya immediately announced it would embargo oil shipments to the United States.
6 Saudi Arabia and the other Arab oilproducing states joined the embargo on October 20 1973.
7 At their Kuwait meeting OAPEC proclaimed the embargo that curbed exports to various countries and blocked all oil deliveries to the US as a principal hostile country.
8 Why did OPEC raise the price of oil to 511?	In response to American aid to Israel	1
9 When did they raise the price of oil to 511?	October 16  1973 	1
10 Why did the oil ministers agree to a cut in oil production?	until their economic and political objectives were met	2
11 How much was the emergency aid to Israel?	22 billion	3
12 Why did OPEC block oil deliveries to the United States?	American aid to Israel	1
1 Some of the income was dispensed in the form of aid to other underdeveloped nations whose economies had been caught between higher oil prices and lower prices for their own export commodities amid shrinking Western demand.
2 Much went for arms purchases that exacerbated political tensions particularly in the Middle East.
3 Saudi Arabia spent over 100 billion dollars in the ensuing decades for helping spread its fundamentalist interpretation of Islam known as Wahhabism throughout the world via religious charities such alHaramain Foundation which often also distributed funds to violent Sunni extremist groups such as AlQaeda and the Taliban.
4 How much did Saudi Arabia spend on spreading Wahhabism?	over 100 billion dollars	3
5 Which group benefited from the funds distributed by the religious charity alHaramain Foundation?	AlQaeda and the Taliban	3
6 Some of the income went to the purchase of arms which exacerbated political tension especially in which area?	Middle East	2
7 What is one of the reason that underdeveloped nations received aid from the oil income?	shrinking Western demand	1
8 What is a fundamentalist interpretation of Islam called?	Wahhabism	3
1 In the United States scholars argue that there already existed a negotiated settlement based on equality between both parties prior to 1973.
2 The possibility that the Middle East could become another superpower confrontation with the USSR was of more concern to the US than oil.
3 Further interest groups and government agencies more worried about energy were no match for Kissingers dominance.
4 In the US production distribution and price disruptions have been held responsible for recessions periods of excessive inflation reduced productivity and lower economic growth.

1 The embargo had a negative influence on the US economy by causing immediate demands to address the threats to US energy security.
2 On an international level the price increases changed competitive positions in many industries such as automobiles.
3 Macroeconomic problems consisted of both inflationary and deflationary impacts.
4 The embargo left oil companies searching for new ways to increase oil supplies even in rugged terrain such as the Arctic.
5 Finding oil and developing new fields usually required five to ten years before significant production.

7 On an international level which industrys competitive positions is affected?	automobiles	2

9 The oil crisis caused oil companies to increase oil supplies in which area?	Arctic	4
10 How long does it take for new areas to have significant oil production?	five to ten years	5
1 The embargo was not uniform across Europe.
2 Of the nine members of the European Economic Community EEC the Netherlands faced a complete embargo the UK and France received almost uninterrupted supplies having refused to allow America to use their airfields and embargoed arms and supplies to both the Arabs and the Israelis while the other six faced partial cutbacks.
3 The UK had traditionally been an ally of Israel and Harold Wilsons government supported the Israelis during the SixDay War.
4 His successor Ted Heath reversed this policy in 1970 calling for Israel to withdraw to its pre1967 borders.
5 Which country faced a complete embargo in the EEC?	Netherlands	2

1 Despite being relatively unaffected by the embargo the UK nonetheless faced an oil crisis of its own  a series of strikes by coal miners and railroad workers over the winter of 1973–74 became a major factor in the change of government.
2 Heath asked the British to heat only one room in their houses over the winter.
3 The UK Germany Italy Switzerland and Norway banned flying driving and boating on Sundays.
4 Sweden rationed gasoline and heating oil.
5 The Netherlands imposed prison sentences for those who used more than their ration of electricity.

10 Which country rationed gasoline and heating gas?	Sweden	4
1 Price controls exacerbated the crisis in the US.
2 The system limited the price of old oil that which had already been discovered while allowing newly discovered oil to be sold at a higher price to encourage investment.
3 Predictably old oil was withdrawn from the market creating greater scarcity.
4 The rule also discouraged development of alternative energies.
5 The rule had been intended to promote oil exploration.
6 Scarcity was addressed by rationing as in many countries.
7 Motorists faced long lines at gas stations beginning in summer 1972 and increasing by summer 1973.
8 What made the oil crisis worse in the US?	Price controls	1
9 Why are newly discovered oil sold at a higher price?	encourage investment	2
10 Why was old oil withdrawn from the market?	Price controls	1
11 How was scarcity managed in many countries?	rationing	6
1 In 1973 Nixon named William E Simon as the first Administrator of the Federal Energy Office a shortterm organization created to coordinate the response to the embargo.
2 Simon allocated states the same amount of domestic oil for 1974 that each had consumed in 1972 which worked for states whose populations were not increasing.
3 In other states lines at gasoline stations were common.
4 The American Automobile Association reported that in the last week of February 1974 20 of American gasoline stations had no fuel.

6 When was he elected by Nixon?	In 1973	1
7 Why was this short termed organization created?	coordinate the response to the embargo	1

1 To help reduce consumption in 1974 a national maximum speed limit of 55 mph about 88 kmh was imposed through the Emergency Highway Energy Conservation Act.
2 Development of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve began in 1975 and in 1977 the cabinetlevel Department of Energy was created followed by the National Energy Act of 1978.
3 citation needed On November 28 1995 Bill Clinton signed the National Highway Designation Act ending the federal 55 mph 89 kmh speed limit allowing states to restore their prior maximum speed limit.

1 The energy crisis led to greater interest in renewable energy nuclear power and domestic fossil fuels.
2 There is criticism that American energy policies since the crisis have been dominated by crisismentality thinking promoting expensive quick fixes and singleshot solutions that ignore market and technology realities.
3 Instead of providing stable rules that support basic research while leaving plenty of scope for entrepreneurship and innovation congresses and presidents have repeatedly backed policies which promise solutions that are politically expedient but whose prospects are doubtful.
4 What was the catalyst that created greater interest in renewable resources?	energy crisis	1
5 There is criticism that the energy policies are expensive quick fixes that ignore which facts?	market and technology realities	2
6 Who backed policies that have solutions that sound good but have poor prospects?	congresses and presidents	3
1 In 2004 declassified documents revealed that the US was so distraught by the rise in oil prices and being challenged by underdeveloped countries that they briefly considered military action to forcibly seize Middle Eastern oilfields in late 1973.
2 Although no explicit plan was mentioned a conversation between US Secretary of Defense James Schlesinger and British Ambassador to the United States Lord Cromer revealed Schlesinger had told him that it was no longer obvious to him that the US could not use force.
3 British Prime Minister Edward Heath was so worried by this prospect that he ordered a British intelligence estimate of US intentions which concluded America might consider it could not tolerate a situation in which the US and its allies were at the mercy of a small group of unreasonable countries and that they would prefer a rapid operation to seize oilfields in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait and possibly Abu Dhabi in military action was decided upon.
4 Although the Soviet response to such an act would likely not involve force intelligence warned the American occupation would need to last 10 years as the West developed alternative energy sources and would result in the ‘total alienation’ of the Arabs and much of the rest of the Third World.
5 Which country was thinking about going to war to forcibly take Middle Eastern oil fields?	US	1
6 Which country was worried that the US would invade the Middle East?	British Prime Minister Edward Heath	3
7 How long would the invasion of the Middle East have to last in order to develop renewable resources?	10 years	4
8 Who would the occupation alienate?	Arabs and much of the rest of the Third World	4
1 Although lacking historical connections to the Middle East Japan was the country most dependent on Arab oil.
2 71 of its imported oil came from the Middle East in 1970.
3 On November 7 1973 the Saudi and Kuwaiti governments declared Japan a nonfriendly country to encourage it to change its noninvolvement policy.
4 It received a 5 production cut in December causing a panic.
5 On November 22 Japan issued a statement asserting that Israel should withdraw from all of the 1967 territories advocating Palestinian selfdetermination and threatening to reconsider its policy toward Israel if Israel refused to accept these preconditions.
6 By December 25 Japan was considered an Arabfriendly state.

1 The USSRs invasion of Afghanistan was only one sign of insecurity in the region also marked by increased American weapons sales technology and outright military presence.
2 Saudi Arabia and Iran became increasingly dependent on American security assurances to manage both external and internal threats including increased military competition between them over increased oil revenues.
3 Both states were competing for preeminence in the Persian Gulf and using increased revenues to fund expanded militaries.
4 By 1979 Saudi arms purchases from the US exceeded five times Israels.
5 Another motive for the large scale purchase of arms from the US by Saudi Arabia was the failure of the Shah during January 1979 to maintain control of Iran a nonArabic but largely Shiite Muslim nation which fell to a theocratic Islamist government under the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the wake of the 1979 Iranian Revolution.
6 Saudi Arabia on the other hand is an Arab largely Sunni Muslim nation headed by a near absolutist monarchy.
7 In the wake of the Iranian revolution the Saudis were forced to deal with the prospect of internal destabilization via the radicalism of Islamism a reality which would quickly be revealed in the seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca by Wahhabi extremists during November 1979 and a Shiite revolt in the oil rich AlHasa region of Saudi Arabia in December of the same year.
8 In November 2010 Wikileaks leaked confidential diplomatic cables pertaining to the United States and its allies which revealed that the late Saudi King Abdullah urged the United States to attack Iran in order to destroy its potential nuclear weapons program describing Iran as a snake whose head should be cut off without any procrastination.
9 Which countrys invasion show the insecurity of the Middle East?	USSRs invasion	1
10 Which countries became dependent on USs security assurance to threats?	Saudi Arabia and Iran	2
11 Which countrys arms purchase from the US became 5 times more than Israel?	Saudi Arabia	2
12 When did the Shah kingdom start to collapse?	January 1979	5
13 When did the Wahhabi seized the Grand Mosque in Mecca?	November 1979	7

3 Japanese imports became massmarket leaders with unibody construction and frontwheel drive which became de facto standards.

1 An increase in imported cars into North America forced General Motors Ford and Chrysler to introduce smaller and fuelefficient models for domestic sales.
2 The Dodge Omni  Plymouth Horizon from Chrysler the Ford Fiesta and the Chevrolet Chevette all had fourcylinder engines and room for at least four passengers by the late 1970s.
3 By 1985 the average American vehicle moved 174 miles per gallon compared to 135 in 1970.
4 The improvements stayed even though the price of a barrel of oil remained constant at 12 from 1974 to 1979.
5 Sales of large sedans for most makes except Chrysler products recovered within two model years of the 1973 crisis.
6 The Cadillac DeVille and Fleetwood Buick Electra Oldsmobile 98 Lincoln Continental Mercury Marquis and various other luxury oriented sedans became popular again in the mid1970s.
7 The only fullsize models that did not recover were lower price models such as the Chevrolet Bel Air and Ford Galaxie 500.
8 Slightly smaller midsize models such as the Oldsmobile Cutlass Chevrolet Monte Carlo Ford Thunderbird and various other models sold well.

3 By 1979 virtually all fullsize American cars had shrunk featuring smaller engines and smaller outside dimensions.

1 OPEC soon lost its preeminent position and in 1981 its production was surpassed by that of other countries.
2 Additionally its own member nations were divided.

5 Adjusted for inflation oil briefly fell back to pre1973 levels.

1 The Apollo program also known as Project Apollo was the third United States human spaceflight program carried out by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration NASA which accomplished landing the first humans on the Moon from 1969 to 1972.
2 First conceived during Dwight D Eisenhowers administration as a threeman spacecraft to follow the oneman Project Mercury which put the first Americans in space Apollo was later dedicated to President John F Kennedys national goal of landing a man on the Moon and returning him safely to the Earth by the end of the 1960s which he proposed in a May 25 1961 address to Congress.
3 Project Mercury was followed by the twoman Project Gemini 1962–66.
4 The first manned flight of Apollo was in 1968.
5 What project put the first Americans into space?	Project Mercury	2
6 What program was created to carry out these projects and missions?	National Aeronautics and Space Administration NASA	1
7 What year did the first manned Apollo flight occur?	1968	4
8 What President is credited with the original notion of putting Americans in space?	Dwight D Eisenhower	2
9 How many people were on the project that followed Project Mercury?	two	3
1 Apollo ran from 1961 to 1972 and was supported by the twoman Gemini program which ran concurrently with it from 1962 to 1966.
2 Gemini missions developed some of the space travel techniques that were necessary for the success of the Apollo missions.
3 Apollo used Saturn family rockets as launch vehicles.
4 ApolloSaturn vehicles were also used for an Apollo Applications Program which consisted of Skylab a space station that supported three manned missions in 1973–74 and the Apollo–Soyuz Test Project a joint Earth orbit mission with the Soviet Union in 1975.
5 How long did Project Apollo run?	1961 to 1972	1
6 What program helped develop space travel techniques that Project Apollo used?	Gemini program	1
7 Who did the US collaborate with on an Earth orbit mission in 1975?	Soviet Union	4
8 What space station supported three manned missions in 19731974?	Skylab	4
1 The Apollo program succeeded in achieving its goal of manned lunar landing despite the major setback of a 1967 Apollo 1 cabin fire that killed the entire crew during a prelaunch test.
2 After the first landing sufficient flight hardware remained for nine followon landings with a plan for extended lunar geological and astrophysical exploration.
3 Budget cuts forced the cancellation of three of these.
4 Five of the remaining six missions achieved successful landings but the Apollo 13 landing was prevented by an oxygen tank explosion in transit to the Moon which disabled the command spacecrafts propulsion and life support.
5 The crew returned to Earth safely by using the Lunar Module as a lifeboat for these functions.
6 In what year did the Apollo 1 cabin fire occur?	1967	1
7 What type of launch was happening during the Apollo 1 incident?	prelaunch test	1
8 What forced the cancellations of three future landings?	Budget cuts	3
9 How many of the remaining launches were successful?	Five	4
10 What happened to Apollo 13?	oxygen tank explosion in transit to the Moon	4
1 Apollo set several major human spaceflight milestones.
2 It stands alone in sending manned missions beyond low Earth orbit.
3 Apollo 8 was the first manned spacecraft to orbit another celestial body while the final Apollo 17 mission marked the sixth Moon landing and the ninth manned mission beyond low Earth orbit.
4 The program returned 842 pounds 382 kg of lunar rocks and soil to Earth greatly contributing to the understanding of the Moons composition and geological history.
5 The program laid the foundation for NASAs current human spaceflight capability and funded construction of its Johnson Space Center and Kennedy Space Center.
6 Apollo also spurred advances in many areas of technology incidental to rocketry and manned spaceflight including avionics telecommunications and computers.
7 What was the first spacecraft to orbit another celestial body?	Apollo 8	3
8 What Apollo mission was the sixth moon landing?	Apollo 17	3
9 How many kgs of moon rocks did the program bring back?	382 kg	4
10 What other areas did the Apollo missions help spur advancements in?	avionics  telecommunications  and computers	6
1 The Apollo program was conceived during the Eisenhower administration in early 1960 as a followup to Project Mercury.
2 While the Mercury capsule could only support one astronaut on a limited Earth orbital mission Apollo would carry three astronauts.
3 Possible missions included ferrying crews to a space station circumlunar flights and eventual manned lunar landings.
4 The program was named after the Greek god of light music and the sun by NASA manager Abe Silverstein who later said that I was naming the spacecraft like Id name my baby.
5 Silverstein chose the name at home one evening early in 1960 because he felt Apollo riding his chariot across the Sun was appropriate to the grand scale of the proposed program.
6 How many people could the Mercury capsule hold?	one	2
7 How many people could Apollo be projected to hold?	three	2
8 Who named the Apollo missions?	Abe Silverstein	4
9 What was the eventual final goal of the Apollo projects?	manned lunar landings	3
10 When was the Apollo project conceived?	early 1960	1
1 In July 1960 NASA Deputy Administrator Hugh L Dryden announced the Apollo program to industry representatives at a series of Space Task Group conferences.
2 Preliminary specifications were laid out for a spacecraft with a mission module cabin separate from the command module piloting and reentry cabin and a propulsion and equipment module.
3 On August 30 a feasibility study competition was announced and on October 25 three study contracts were awarded to General DynamicsConvair General Electric and the Glenn L Martin Company.
4 Meanwhile NASA performed its own inhouse spacecraft design studies led by Maxime Faget to serve as a gauge to judge and monitor the three industry designs.
5 In what year was the Apollo program announced?	1960	1
6 Who led the in house design studies for NASA?	Maxime Faget	4
7 How many study contracts were awarded on October 25th?	three	3
8 Who was the deputy administrator of NASA in 1960?	Hugh L Dryden	1
1 In November 1960 John F Kennedy was elected president after a campaign that promised American superiority over the Soviet Union in the fields of space exploration and missile defense.
2 Up to the election of 1960 Kennedy had been speaking out against the missile gap that he and many other senators felt had formed between the Soviets and themselves due to the inaction of President Eisenhower.
3 Beyond military power Kennedy used aerospace technology as a symbol of national prestige pledging to make the US not first but first and first if but first period.
4 Despite Kennedys rhetoric he did not immediately come to a decision on the status of the Apollo program once he became president.
5 He knew little about the technical details of the space program and was put off by the massive financial commitment required by a manned Moon landing.
6 When Kennedys newly appointed NASA Administrator James E Webb requested a 30 percent budget increase for his agency Kennedy supported an acceleration of NASAs large booster program but deferred a decision on the broader issue.
7 Who was elected President in November 1960?	John F Kennedy	1
8 Against what country was Kennedy promising superiority over?	Soviet Union	1
9 What was President Kennedy put off by regarding the space program?	massive financial commitment	5
10 Who was NASAs administrator?	James E Webb	6
11 What was the term Kennedy used to show that America was falling behind the Soviet Union due to inactivity in space programs?	missile gap	2
1 On April 12 1961 Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first person to fly in space reinforcing American fears about being left behind in a technological competition with the Soviet Union.
2 At a meeting of the US House Committee on Science and Astronautics one day after Gagarins flight many congressmen pledged their support for a crash program aimed at ensuring that America would catch up.
3 Kennedy was circumspect in his response to the news refusing to make a commitment on Americas response to the Soviets.
4 Who was the first person in space?	Yuri Gagarin	1
5 From what country did the first person in space come from?	Soviet Union	1
6 How many days after Gagarins flight did the US House Committee on Science and Astronautics meet?	one day	2
7 What did President Kennedy do in response to the Soviet flight in regards of Americas program?	refusing to make a commitment	3
1 On April 20 Kennedy sent a memo to Vice President Lyndon B Johnson asking Johnson to look into the status of Americas space program and into programs that could offer NASA the opportunity to catch up.
2 Johnson responded approximately one week later concluding that we are neither making maximum effort nor achieving results necessary if this country is to reach a position of leadership.
3 His memo concluded that a manned Moon landing was far enough in the future that it was likely the United States would achieve it first.
4 What month and day did Kennedy message his vice president about the status of the program?	April 20	1
5 Who was Kennedys vice president?	Lyndon B Johnson	1
6 How long did it take Johnson to respond to Kennedy?	approximately one week	2
7 What was the general consensus Johnson came to regarding Americas progress on going to space and reaching a position of leadership?	neither making maximum effort nor achieving results necessary	2
1 It became clear that managing the Apollo program would exceed the capabilities of Robert R Gilruths Space Task Group which had been directing the nations manned space program from NASAs Langley Research Center.
2 So Gilruth was given authority to grow his organization into a new NASA center the Manned Spacecraft Center MSC.
3 A site was chosen in Houston Texas on land donated by Rice University and Administrator Webb announced the conversion on September 19 1961.
4 It was also clear NASA would soon outgrow its practice of controlling missions from its Cape Canaveral Air Force Station launch facilities in Florida so a new Mission Control Center would be included in the MSC.
5 Who originally led the Space Task Group?	Robert R Gilruth	1
6 Where was the Space Task Group located?	NASAs Langley Research Center	1
7 Where was the Manned Spacecraft Center located?	Houston  Texas	3
8 What university donated the land for the Manned Spacecraft Center?	Rice University	3
9 In what state were the original launching facilities for missions?	Florida	4
1 It also became clear that Apollo would outgrow the Canaveral launch facilities in Florida.
2 The two newest launch complexes were already being built for the Saturn I and IB rockets at the northernmost end LC34 and LC37.
3 But an even bigger facility would be needed for the mammoth rocket required for the manned lunar mission so land acquisition was started in July 1961 for a Launch Operations Center LOC immediately north of Canaveral at Merritt Island.
4 The design development and construction of the center was conducted by Kurt H Debus a member of Dr Wernher von Brauns original V2 rocket engineering team.
5 Debus was named the LOCs first Director.
6 Construction began in November 1962.
7 Upon Kennedys death President Johnson issued an executive order on November 29 1963 to rename the LOC and Cape Canaveral in honor of Kennedy.
8 Where would the Launch Operations Center be located as more land was needed for a bigger rocket?	Merritt Island	3
9 Who conducted the construction of the new center?	Kurt H Debus	4
10 Kurt H Debus was appointed what position for the Launch Operations Center?	Director	5
11 President Johnson issued an executive order to rename the Launch Operations Center after whom?	Kennedy	7
1 The LOC included Launch Complex 39 a Launch Control Center and a 130 million cubic foot 37 million cubic meter Vertical Assembly Building VAB in which the space vehicle launch vehicle and spacecraft would be assembled on a Mobile Launcher Platform and then moved by a transporter to one of several launch pads.
2 Although at least three pads were planned only two designated A and B were completed in October 1965.
3 The LOC also included an Operations and Checkout Building OCB to which Gemini and Apollo spacecraft were initially received prior to being mated to their launch vehicles.
4 The Apollo spacecraft could be tested in two vacuum chambers capable of simulating atmospheric pressure at altitudes up to 250000 feet 76 km which is nearly a vacuum.
5 How many launch pads were originally planned?	three	2
6 What spacecraft was tested in two vacuum chambers to simulate atmospheric pressure?	Apollo spacecraft	4
7 How high in altitude in feet could the vacuum chambers simulate?	250 000 feet	4
8 How big was the Vertical Assembly Building?	130 million cubic foot	1
1 Administrator Webb realized that in order to keep Apollo costs under control he had to develop greater project management skills in his organization so he recruited Dr George E Mueller for a high management job.
2 Mueller accepted on the condition that he have a say in NASA reorganization necessary to effectively administer Apollo.
3 Webb then worked with Associate Administrator later Deputy Administrator Robert Seamans to reorganize the Office of Manned Space Flight OMSF.
4 On July 23 1963 Webb announced Muellers appointment as Deputy Associate Administrator for Manned Space Flight to replace then Associate Administrator D Brainerd Holmes on his retirement effective September 1.
5 Under Webbs reorganization the directors of the Manned Spacecraft Center Gilruth Marshall Space Flight Center von Braun and the Launch Operations Center Debus effectively reported to Mueller.
6 Who did Webb recruit for better project management?	Dr George E Mueller	1
7 When was Mueller announced and appointed as Deputy Associate Administrator?	July 23  1963	4
8 Who was Mueller replaced as Associate Administrator?	D Brainerd Holmes	4
9 The administrators and directors Gilruth von Braun and Debus reported to who?	Mueller	5
1 Based on his industry experience on Air Force missile projects Mueller realized some skilled managers could be found among highranking officers in the United States Air Force so he got Webbs permission to recruit General Samuel C Phillips who gained a reputation for his effective management of the Minuteman program as OMSF program controller.
2 Phillips superior officer Bernard A Schriever agreed to loan Phillips to NASA along with a staff of officers under him on the condition that Phillips be made Apollo Program Director.
3 Mueller agreed and Phillips managed Apollo from January 1964 until it achieved the first manned landing in July 1969 after which he returned to Air Force duty.
4 What did Mueller have experience with prior to joining the space program?	Air Force missile projects	1
5 From what military branch did Mueller recruit managers from?	United States Air Force	1
6 Who did Mueller recruit to be a manager for NASA projects on a loaned situation?	General Samuel C Phillips	1
7 How long did Phillips manage the Apollo missions?	January 1964  until it achieved the first manned landing in July 1969	3
8 What was Phillips official title for NASA?	Apollo Program Director	2
1 In early 1961 direct ascent was generally the mission mode in favor at NASA.
2 Many engineers feared that a rendezvous —let alone a docking— neither of which had been attempted even in Earth orbit would be extremely difficult in lunar orbit.
3 Dissenters including John Houbolt at Langley Research Center emphasized the important weight reductions that were offered by the LOR approach.
4 Throughout 1960 and 1961 Houbolt campaigned for the recognition of LOR as a viable and practical option.
5 Bypassing the NASA hierarchy he sent a series of memos and reports on the issue to Associate Administrator Robert Seamans while acknowledging that he spoke somewhat as a voice in the wilderness Houbolt pleaded that LOR should not be discounted in studies of the question.
6 What did the engineers fear would be difficult in space due to it never being attempted in Earth orbit?	a rendezvous —let alone a docking	2
7 In what year was direct ascent the primary mission focus at NASA?	1961	1
8 Who was the Associate Administrator that Houbolt spoke with?	Robert Seamans	5
1  Seamans establishment of an adhoc committee headed by his special technical assistant Nicholas E Golovin in July 1961 to recommend a launch vehicle to be used in the Apollo program represented a turning point in NASAs mission mode decision.
2 This committee recognized that the chosen mode was an important part of the launch vehicle choice and recommended in favor of a hybrid EORLOR mode.
3 Its consideration of LOR —as well as Houbolts ceaseless work— played an important role in publicizing the workability of the approach.
4 In late 1961 and early 1962 members of the Manned Spacecraft Center began to come around to support LOR including the newly hired deputy director of the Office of Manned Space Flight Joseph Shea who became a champion of LOR.
5 The engineers at Marshall Space Flight Center MSFC took longer to become convinced of its merits but their conversion was announced by Wernher von Braun at a briefing in June 1962.
6 Who led the committee established by Seaman?	Nicholas E Golovin	1
7 When was this committee by Seaman established?	July 1961	1
8 Which NASA faction came around first to support the LOR?	Manned Spacecraft Center	4
9 Who was hired to be the deputy director of the Office of Manned Space Flight?	Joseph Shea	4
10 Which NASA location came around last to the idea of the LOR?	Marshall Space Flight Center	5
1 But even after NASA reached internal agreement it was far from smooth sailing.
2 Kennedys science advisor Jerome Wiesner who had expressed his opposition to manned spaceflight to Kennedy before the President took office and had opposed the decision to land men on the Moon hired Golovin who had left NASA to chair his own Space Vehicle Panel ostensibly to monitor but actually to secondguess NASAs decisions on the Saturn V launch vehicle and LOR by forcing Shea Seamans and even Webb to defend themselves delaying its formal announcement to the press on July 11 1962 and forcing Webb to still hedge the decision as tentative.
3 Who was Kennedys science adviser that opposed manned spacecraft flights?	Jerome Wiesner	2
4 Who did Wiesner hire to monitor and second guess NASAs decisions?	Golovin	2
5 Where did Golovin work prior to joining the Space Vehicle Panel?	NASA	2
6 When was the announcement for the LOR made after being delayed?	July 11  1962	2
1 Wiesner kept up the pressure even making the disagreement public during a twoday September visit by the President to Marshall Space Flight Center.
2 Wiesner blurted out No thats no good in front of the press during a presentation by von Braun.
3 Webb jumped in and defended von Braun until Kennedy ended the squabble by stating that the matter was still subject to final review.
4 Webb held firm and issued a request for proposal to candidate Lunar Excursion Module LEM contractors.
5 Wiesner finally relented unwilling to settle the dispute once and for all in Kennedys office because of the Presidents involvement with the October Cuban missile crisis and fear of Kennedys support for Webb.
6 NASA announced the selection of Grumman as the LEM contractor in November 1962.
7 Who was keeping pressure and showing disagreements for the LOR even in front of the President?	Wiesner	1
8 What did Wiesner shout out in front of the press during a presentation by von Braun?	No  thats no good	2
9 What does the acronym LEM stand for?	Lunar Excursion Module	4
10 Who was announced as the LEM contractor in November 1962?	Grumman	6
1 The LOR method had the advantage of allowing the lander spacecraft to be used as a lifeboat in the event of a failure of the command ship.
2 Some documents prove this theory was discussed before and after the method was chosen.
3 A 1964 MSC study concluded The LM as lifeboat  was finally dropped because no single reasonable CSM failure could be identified that would prohibit use of the SPS.
4 Ironically just such a failure happened on Apollo 13 when an oxygen tank explosion left the command ship without electrical power.
5 The Lunar Module provided propulsion electrical power and life support to get the crew home safely.
6 What was the advantage that the LOR method produced in the event of a spacecraft failure?	spacecraft to be used as a lifeboat	1
7 What Apollo mission was this LOR method used and needed?	Apollo 13	4
8 What did the Lunar Module provide to help get the Apollo 13 home safely?	propulsion  electrical power and life support	5
9 In what year was the Lunar Module LM dropped because it wasnt seen as useful?	1964	3
1 Maxime Fagets preliminary Apollo design employed a coneshaped command module supported by one of several service modules providing propulsion and electrical power sized appropriately for the space station cislunar and lunar landing missions.
