2 Once Kennedys Moon landing goal became official detailed design began of a CommandService Module CSM in which the crew would spend the entire directascent mission and lift off from the lunar surface for the return trip after being softlanded by a larger landing propulsion module.
3 The final choice of lunar orbit rendezvous changed the CSMs role to the translunar ferry used to transport the crew along with a new spacecraft the Lunar Excursion Module LEM later shortened to Lunar Module LM which would take two men to the lunar surface and return them to the CSM.
4 What was the shape that Faget designed for the Apollo command module?	coneshaped	1
5 What does the acronym CSM stand for?	CommandService Module	2
6 How many men would the LM take to the lunar surface and return to the CSM?	two	3
1 The Command Module CM was the conical crew cabin designed to carry three astronauts from launch to lunar orbit and back to an Earth ocean landing.
2 It was the only component of the Apollo spacecraft to survive without major configuration changes as the program evolved from the early Apollo study designs.
3 Its exterior was covered with an ablative heat shield and had its own reaction control system RCS engines to control its attitude and steer its atmospheric entry path.
4 Parachutes were carried to slow its descent to splashdown.
5 The module was 1142 feet 348 m tall 1283 feet 391 m in diameter and weighed approximately 12250 pounds 5560 kg.
6 How many people was the CM designed to carry in the end?	three	1
7 Where was the CM intended to land upon re entering the Earths atmosphere?	ocean	1
8 The outside of the CM was covered in what kind of material?	ablative heat shield	3
9 What was incorporated to help slow the CMs decent back to Earth?	Parachutes	4
10 How much did the CM weigh in kgs?	5 560 kg	5
1 A cylindrical Service Module SM supported the Command Module with a service propulsion engine and an RCS with propellants and a fuel cell power generation system with liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen reactants.
2 A highgain Sband antenna was used for longdistance communications on the lunar flights.
3 On the extended lunar missions an orbital scientific instrument package was carried.
4 The Service Module was discarded just before reentry.
5 The module was 246 feet 75 m long and 1283 feet 391 m in diameter.
6 The initial lunar flight version weighed approximately 51300 pounds 23300 kg fully fueled while a later version designed to carry a lunar orbit scientific instrument package weighed just over 54000 pounds 24000 kg.
7 What helped support the Command Module with a propulsion engine and propellants?	Service Module SM	1
8 What type of antenna was used for communication on the lunar flights?	highgain Sband antenna	2
9 What happened to the SM upon reentry to the atmosphere?	discarded	4
10 How much did the initial version of the SM weigh in pounds?	51 300 pounds	6
11 What was carried on extended lunar missions?	orbital scientific instrument package	3
1 North American Aviation won the contract to build the CSM and also the second stage of the Saturn V launch vehicle for NASA.
2 Because the CSM design was started early before the selection of lunar orbit rendezvous the service propulsion engine was sized to lift the CSM off of the Moon and thus was oversized to about twice the thrust required for translunar flight.
3 Also there was no provision for docking with the Lunar Module.
4 A 1964 program definition study concluded that the initial design should be continued as Block I which would be used for early testing while Block II the actual lunar spacecraft would incorporate the docking equipment and take advantage of the lessons learned in Block I development.
5 Who was rewarded with building the CSM?	North American Aviation	1
6 How much thrust was estimated for the translunar flight?	twice the thrust	2
7 In what year was a program study done on the modules labeled as Block I and Block II?	1964	4
8 What was the name of the launch vehicle for NASA which North American Aviation designed the second stage of?	Saturn V	1
1 The Lunar Module LM was designed to descend from lunar orbit to land two astronauts on the Moon and take them back to orbit to rendezvous with the Command Module.
2 Not designed to fly through the Earths atmosphere or return to Earth its fuselage was designed totally without aerodynamic considerations and was of an extremely lightweight construction.
3 It consisted of separate descent and ascent stages each with its own engine.
4 The descent stage contained storage for the descent propellant surface stay consumables and surface exploration equipment.
5 The ascent stage contained the crew cabin ascent propellant and a reaction control system.
6 The initial LM model weighed approximately 33300 pounds 15100 kg and allowed surface stays up to around 34 hours.
7 An Extended Lunar Module weighed over 36200 pounds 16400 kg and allowed surface stays of over 3 days.
8 How many astronauts was the LM intended to take from orbit of the moon to the surface of the moon?	two	1
9 Was the LM intended to return to Earth at all?	Not	2
10 The initial LM weighed how much in kgs?	15 100 kg	6
11 For about how long would the extended LM allow a surface stay on the moon?	3 days	7
1 Before the Apollo program began Wernher von Braun and his team of rocket engineers had started work on plans for very large launch vehicles the Saturn series and the even larger Nova series.
2 In the midst of these plans von Braun was transferred from the Army to NASA and made Director of the Marshall Space Flight Center.
3 The initial direct ascent plan to send the threeman Apollo CommandService Module directly to the lunar surface on top of a large descent rocket stage would require a Novaclass launcher with a lunar payload capability of over 180000 pounds 82000 kg.
4 The June 11 1962 decision to use lunar orbit rendezvous enabled the Saturn V to replace the Nova and the MSFC proceeded to develop the Saturn rocket family for Apollo.
5 Who had worked on the Saturn series even before the Apollo program began officially?	Wernher von Braun	1
6 From where was von Braun transferred to go to NASA?	Army	2
7 When was the decision made to replace the Nova rockets with the Saturn V?	June 11  1962	4
1 The first four Saturn I test flights were launched from LC34 with only live first stages carrying dummy upper stages filled with water.
2 The first flight with a live SIV was launched from LC37.
3 This was followed by five launches of boilerplate CSMs designated AS101 through AS105 into orbit in 1964 and 1965.
4 The last three of these further supported the Apollo program by also carrying Pegasus satellites which verified the safety of the translunar environment by measuring the frequency and severity of micrometeorite impacts.
5 What did the initial first stages of the Saturn I tests carry?	dummy upper stages filled with water	1
6 When did the launches of boilerplate CSMs occur in orbit?	1964 and 1965	3
7 What did the last few of the boilerplate CSM launches carry with them?	Pegasus satellites	4
8 What did Pegasus satellites measure to propose the safety of the environment in space and on the moon?	frequency and severity of micrometeorite impacts	4
1 The Saturn IB was an upgraded version of the Saturn I.
2 The SIB first stage increased the thrust to 1600000 poundsforce 7120 kN and the second stage replaced the SIV with the SIVB200 powered by a single J2 engine burning liquid hydrogen fuel with LOX to produce 200000 lbf 890 kN of thrust.
3 A restartable version of the SIVB was used as the third stage of the Saturn V The Saturn IB could send over 40000 pounds 18100 kg into low Earth orbit sufficient for a partially fueled CSM or the LM.
4 Saturn IB launch vehicles and flights were designated with an AS200 series number AS indicating Apollo Saturn and the 2 indicating the second member of the Saturn rocket family.
5 What was the name of the upgraded Saturn I called?	Saturn IB	1
6 How much did the second stage increase thrust by with the integration of the SIVB200?	200 000 lbf	2
7 The SIVB200 was used in what stage of the Saturn V?	third stage	3
8 How much weight could the Saturn IB send into space with this amount of thrust?	40 000 pounds	3
1 The threestage Saturn V was designed to send a fully fueled CSM and LM to the Moon.
2 It was 33 feet 101 m in diameter and stood 363 feet 1106 m tall with its 96800pound 43900 kg lunar payload.
3 Its capability grew to 103600 pounds 47000 kg for the later advanced lunar landings.
4 The SIC first stage burned RP1LOX for a rated thrust of 7500000 poundsforce 33400 kN which was upgraded to 7610000 poundsforce 33900 kN.
5 The second and third stages burned liquid hydrogen and the third stage was a modified version of the SIVB with thrust increased to 230000 lbf 1020 kN and capability to restart the engine for translunar injection after reaching a parking orbit.
6 What was intended to take a CSM and LM fully fueled to the moon?	threestage Saturn V	1
7 What was the diameter of the Saturn V in feet?	33 feet	2
8 How many stages did the Saturn V end up having?	three	1
9 What did the second stage in the Saturn V end up doing?	burned liquid hydrogen	5
1 The Apollo astronauts were chosen from the Project Mercury and Gemini veterans plus from two later astronaut groups.
2 All missions were commanded by Gemini or Mercury veterans.
3 Crews on all development flights except the Earth orbit CSM development flights through the first two landings on Apollo 11 and Apollo 12 included at least two sometimes three Gemini veterans.
4 Dr Harrison Schmitt a geologist was the first NASA scientist astronaut to fly in space and landed on the Moon on the last mission Apollo 17.
5 Schmitt participated in the lunar geology training of all of the Apollo landing crews.
6 From what project groups were the Apollo astronauts selected?	Mercury and Gemini	1
7 How many Apollo missions were manned by the previous Mercury and Gemini veterans?	All missions	2
8 Who was the first NASA scientist in space?	Dr Harrison Schmitt	4
9 Which mission did Schmitt finally land on the moon?	Apollo 17	4
10 Apollo 17 was significant for what reason?	last mission	4
1 NASA awarded all 32 of these astronauts its highest honor the Distinguished Service Medal given for distinguished service ability or courage and personal contribution representing substantial progress to the NASA mission.
2 The medals were awarded posthumously to Grissom White and Chaffee in 1969 then to the crews of all missions from Apollo 8 onward.
3 The crew that flew the first Earth orbital test mission Apollo 7 Walter M Schirra Donn Eisele and Walter Cunningham were awarded the lesser NASA Exceptional Service Medal because of discipline problems with the Flight Directors orders during their flight.
4 The NASA Administrator in October 2008 decided to award them the Distinguished Service Medals by this time posthumously to Schirra and Eisele.
5 How many astronauts visited space on missions and were rewarded for their efforts?	32	1
6 What type of medal did NASA give the astronauts who visited space and the moon?	Distinguished Service Medal	1
7 In what year were the Distinguished Service Medals awarded to Grissom White and Chaffee?	1969	2
8 What happened during the Apollo 7 test mission to elicit them a lesser version of the DSM?	discipline problems	3
9 From what mission and onward were the DSMs awarded?	Apollo 8	2
1 Two Block I CSMs were launched from LC34 on suborbital flights in 1966 with the Saturn IB.
2 The first AS201 launched on February 26 reached an altitude of 2657 nautical miles 4921 km and splashed down 4577 nautical miles 8477 km downrange in the Atlantic ocean.
3 The second AS202 on August 25 reached 6171 nautical miles 11429 km altitude and was recovered 13900 nautical miles 25700 km downrange in the Pacific ocean.
4 These flights validated the Service Module engine and the Command Module heat shield.
5 In what year were two Block I CSMs launched?	1966	1
6 How high in miles did the first block AS201 reach when launched?	2657 nautical miles	2
7 How far did the second block AS202 travel downrange in km?	25 700 km	3
8 What did these flights test on the CM?	heat shield	4
1 After an unmanned LM test flight AS206 a crew would fly the first Block II CSM and LM in a dual mission known as AS207208 or AS278 each spacecraft would be launched on a separate Saturn IB.
2 The Block II crew positions were titled Commander CDR Command Module Pilot CMP and Lunar Module Pilot LMP.
3 The astronauts would begin wearing a new Apollo spacesuit designed to accommodate lunar extravehicular activity EVA.
4 The traditional visor helmet was replaced with a clear fishbowl type for greater visibility and the lunar surface EVA suit would include a watercooled undergarment.
5 How many people were on the test flight of the AS206?	unmanned	1
6 What were the astronauts wearing during the dual mission AS278?	new Apollo spacesuit	3
7 What was originally on the spacesuits prior to the clear fishbowl helmet?	traditional visor helmet	4
8 What type of undergarment if any was included into the Apollo spacesuit?	a watercooled undergarment	4
9 What did the LMP acronym stand for regarding the Block II launch positions?	Lunar Module Pilot	2
1 Deke Slayton the grounded Mercury astronaut who became Director of Flight Crew Operations for the Gemini and Apollo programs selected the first Apollo crew in January 1966 with Grissom as Command Pilot White as Senior Pilot and rookie Donn F Eisele as Pilot.
2 But Eisele dislocated his shoulder twice aboard the KC135 weightlessness training aircraft and had to undergo surgery on January 27.
3 Slayton replaced him with Chaffee.
4 NASA announced the final crew selection for AS204 on March 21 1966 with the backup crew consisting of Gemini veterans James McDivitt and David Scott with rookie Russell L Rusty Schweickart.
5 MercuryGemini veteran Wally Schirra Eisele and rookie Walter Cunningham were announced on September 29 as the prime crew for AS205.
6 Who selected the first Apollo crew?	Deke Slayton	1
7 For which project did Deke Slayton work with before becoming Director of Flight Crew Operations?	Mercury	1
8 What year did Slayton select the first Apollo crew?	1966	1
9 Who was the original pilot for the first Apollo mission?	Donn F Eisele	1
10 What crew did Eisele eventually get relocated to after having surgery and not making the first mission?	AS205	5
1 In December 1966 the AS205 mission was canceled since the validation of the CSM would be accomplished on the 14day first flight and AS205 would have been devoted to space experiments and contribute no new engineering knowledge about the spacecraft.
2 Its Saturn IB was allocated to the dual mission now redesignated AS205208 or AS258 planned for August 1967.
3 McDivitt Scott and Schweickart were promoted to the prime AS258 crew and Schirra Eisele and Cunningham were reassigned as the Apollo 1 backup crew.
4 What happened to the AS205 mission originally?	canceled	1
5 In what month and year was the AS258 scheduled to launch?	August 1967	2
6 What was the dual mission AS258 a combination of?	AS205208	2
7 Where were Schirra Eisele and Cunningham relocated to after different astronauts were selected for the AS258 mission?	Apollo 1 backup crew	3
1 The problems with North American were severe enough in late 1965 to cause Manned Space Flight Administrator George Mueller to appoint program director Samuel Phillips to head a tiger team to investigate North Americans problems and identify corrections.
2 Phillips documented his findings in a December 19 letter to NAA president Lee Atwood with a strongly worded letter by Mueller and also gave a presentation of the results to Mueller and Deputy Administrator Robert Seamans.
3 Meanwhile Grumman was also encountering problems with the Lunar Module eliminating hopes it would be ready for manned flight in 1967 not long after the first manned CSM flights.
4 Who was appointed to head a team to find the problems North America had regarding manned space flight?	Samuel Phillips	1
5 What was the nickname given to the team Samuel Phillips was appointed to?	tiger team	1
6 What year was the first manned flight with the Lunar Module scheduled?	1967	3
7 Who appointed Samuel Phillips to man the tiger team to find answers?	George Mueller	1
1 Grissom White and Chaffee decided to name their flight Apollo 1 as a motivational focus on the first manned flight.
2 They trained and conducted tests of their spacecraft at North American and in the altitude chamber at the Kennedy Space Center.
3 A plugsout test was planned for January which would simulate a launch countdown on LC34 with the spacecraft transferring from padsupplied to internal power.
4 If successful this would be followed by a more rigorous countdown simulation test closer to the February 21 launch with both spacecraft and launch vehicle fueled.
5 Where did Apollo 1s crew conduct tests at Kennedy Space Center?	altitude chamber	2
6 Who was the main crew of Apollo 1 of which they named themselves?	Grissom  White  and Chaffee	1
7 What was a plugsout test done to simulate on the LC34?	launch countdown	3
8 What other location did Apollo 1 test at besides Kennedy Space Center?	North American	2
1 The plugsout test began on the morning of January 27 1967 and immediately was plagued with problems.
2 First the crew noticed a strange odor in their spacesuits which delayed the sealing of the hatch.
3 Then communications problems frustrated the astronauts and forced a hold in the simulated countdown.
4 During this hold an electrical fire began in the cabin and spread quickly in the high pressure 100 oxygen atmosphere.
5 Pressure rose high enough from the fire that the cabin burst and the fire erupted onto the pad area frustrating attempts to rescue the crew.
6 The astronauts were asphyxiated before the hatch could be opened.
7 What was the first problem astronauts encountered during the plugsout test?	strange odor in their spacesuits	2
8 When did the very first plugsout test occur?	January 27  1967	1
9 What happened during the plugsout test during the delay for the spacesuit odor?	electrical fire	4
10 What happened to the crew onboard during the plugsout test?	asphyxiated	6
11 What type of atmosphere helped fuel the fire throughout the cabin?	100 oxygen	4
1 NASA immediately convened an accident review board overseen by both houses of Congress.
2 While the determination of responsibility for the accident was complex the review board concluded that deficiencies existed in Command Module design workmanship and quality control.
3 At the insistence of NASA Administrator Webb North American removed Harrison Storms as Command Module program manager.
4 Webb also reassigned Apollo Spacecraft Program Office ASPO Manager Joseph Francis Shea replacing him with George Low.
5 Who kept tabs on the accident review board that NASA created?	both houses of Congress	1
6 What was found to be at fault for the fire in the cabin on Apollo 1 regarding the CM design?	deficiencies	2
7 Who ended up replacing Joseph Francis Shea as ASPO Manager?	George Low	4
8 How soon after the cabin fire incident did NASA create its accident review board?	immediately	1
1 To remedy the causes of the fire changes were made in the Block II spacecraft and operational procedures the most important of which were use of a nitrogenoxygen mixture instead of pure oxygen before and during launch and removal of flammable cabin and space suit materials.
2 The Block II design already called for replacement of the Block I plugtype hatch cover with a quickrelease outward opening door.
3 NASA discontinued the manned Block I program using the Block I spacecraft only for unmanned Saturn V flights.
4 Crew members would also exclusively wear modified fireresistant Block II space suits and would be designated by the Block II titles regardless of whether a LM was present on the flight or not.
5 What type of mixture was created to replace the pure oxygen atmosphere inside the cabin?	nitrogenoxygen mixture	1
6 What type of materials inside the cabin were removed to help prevent more fire hazards in the future?	flammable cabin and space suit materials	1
7 The door on the Block II design was eventually replaced with what kind of model?	quickrelease  outward opening door	2
8 What eventually happened to the Block I program after the incident?	discontinued	3
9 Crew members were required to wear what type of space suit during testing after the incident?	fireresistant Block II	4
1 In September 1967 Mueller approved a sequence of mission types which had to be successfully accomplished in order to achieve the manned lunar landing.
2 Each step had to be successfully accomplished before the next ones could be performed and it was unknown how many tries of each mission would be necessary therefore letters were used instead of numbers.
3 The A missions were unmanned Saturn V validation B was unmanned LM validation using the Saturn IB C was manned CSM Earth orbit validation using the Saturn IB D was the first manned CSMLM flight this replaced AS258 using a single Saturn V launch E would be a higher Earth orbit CSMLM flight F would be the first lunar mission testing the LM in lunar orbit but without landing a dress rehearsal and G would be the first manned landing.
4 The list of types covered followon lunar exploration to include H lunar landings I for lunar orbital survey missions and J for extendedstay lunar landings.
5 What type of missions were approved by Mueller after the incident?	sequence	1
6 What had to happen to each mission before they would continue on to the next mission?	successful	2
7 Since NASA didnt know how many attempts each test would end up requiring what did they use instead of numbers for the trials?	letters	2
1 The delay in the CSM caused by the fire enabled NASA to catch up on manrating the LM and Saturn V Apollo 4 AS501 was the first unmanned flight of the Saturn V carrying a Block I CSM on November 9 1967.
2 The capability of the Command Modules heat shield to survive a translunar reentry was demonstrated by using the Service Module engine to ram it into the atmosphere at higher than the usual Earthorbital reentry speed.
3 This was followed on April 4 1968 by Apollo 6 AS502 which carried a CSM and a LM Test Article as ballast.
4 The intent of this mission was to achieve translunar injection followed closely by a simulated directreturn abort using the Service Module engine to achieve another highspeed reentry.
5 The Saturn V experienced pogo oscillation a problem caused by nonsteady engine combustion which damaged fuel lines in the second and third stages.
6 Two SII engines shut down prematurely but the remaining engines were able to compensate.
7 The damage to the third stage engine was more severe preventing it from restarting for translunar injection.
8 Mission controllers were able to use the Service Module engine to essentially repeat the flight profile of Apollo 4.
9 Based on the good performance of Apollo 6 and identification of satisfactory fixes to the Apollo 6 problems NASA declared the Saturn V ready to fly men cancelling a third unmanned test.
10 What was the technical name of the first unmanned Saturn V flight Apollo 4?	AS501	1
11 What was one thing that was specifically tested on the Apollo 4 test launch regarding the CM?	heat shield	2
12 When was Apollo 6 or AS502 tested?	April 4  1968	3
13 What was cancelled by NASA after the Apollo 6 testing after deeming the Saturn V ready to hold men?	third unmanned test	9
1 Apollo 5 AS204 was the first unmanned test flight of LM in Earth orbit launched from pad 37 on January 22 1968 by the Saturn IB that would have been used for Apollo 1.
2 The LM engines were successfully testfired and restarted despite a computer programming error which cut short the first descent stage firing.
3 The ascent engine was fired in abort mode known as a fireinthehole test where it was lit simultaneously with jettison of the descent stage.
4 Although Grumman wanted a second unmanned test George Low decided the next LM flight would be manned.
5 Which Apollo was the first testing of the LM unmanned in Earths orbit?	Apollo 5	1
6 From what pad was Apollo 5 launched from?	pad 37	1
7 Who initially wanted more unmanned testing done regarding the LM?	Grumman	4
8 Was the testing of the LM during Apollo 5 a failure or a success?	success	2
9 What was the nickname for the test where during abort mode the ascent engine was started and fired?	fireinthehole	3
1 Apollo 8 was planned to be the D mission in December 1968 crewed by McDivitt Scott and Schweickart launched on a Saturn V instead of two Saturn IBs.
2 In the summer it had become clear that the LM would not be ready in time.
3 Rather than waste the Saturn V on another simple Earthorbiting mission ASPO Manager George Low suggested the bold step of sending Apollo 8 to orbit the Moon instead deferring the D mission to the next mission in March 1969 and eliminating the E mission.
4 This would keep the program on track.
5 The Soviet Union had sent animals around the Moon on September 15 1968 aboard Zond 5 and it was believed they might soon repeat the feat with human cosmonauts.
6 The decision was not announced publicly until successful completion of Apollo 7.
7 Gemini veterans Frank Borman and James Lovell and rookie William Anders captured the worlds attention by making 10 lunar orbits in 20 hours transmitting television pictures of the lunar surface on Christmas Eve and returning safely to Earth.
8 What type of Saturn was originally going to be used for Apollo 8?	two Saturn IBs	1
9 What spacecraft did the Soviets use to send animals to space and around the moons orbit?	Zond 5	5
10 On what day were images of the moons surface transmitted to Earth via television images?	Christmas Eve	7
11 What did Low suggest using Apollo 8 for instead of simply orbiting the Earths surface?	orbit the Moon	3
12 What did the Soviets intend to use in spacecraft after the success of Zond 5?	human cosmonauts	5
1 The G mission was achieved on Apollo 11 in July 1969 by an allGemini veteran crew consisting of Neil Armstrong Michael Collins and Buzz Aldrin.
2 Armstrong and Aldrin performed the first landing at the Sea of Tranquility at 201740 UTC on July 20 1969.
3 They spent a total of 21 hours 36 minutes on the surface and spent 2 hours 31 minutes outside the spacecraft walking on the surface taking photographs collecting material samples and deploying automated scientific instruments while continuously sending blackandwhite television back to Earth.
4 The astronauts returned safely on July 24.
5 From what project did the Apollo 11 crew consist entirely of?	Gemini	1
6 In what month and year did the Apollo 11 mission occur?	July 1969	1
7 What did the astronauts on the moon send back to Earth live via signals?	blackandwhite television	3
8 Who were the astronauts aboard the Apollo 11 mission?	Neil Armstrong  Michael Collins and Buzz Aldrin	1
9 What day did the Apollo 11 crew return to Earth?	July 24	4
1 In November 1969 Gemini veteran Charles Pete Conrad and rookie Alan L Bean made a precision landing on Apollo 12 within walking distance of the Surveyor 3 unmanned lunar probe which had landed in April 1967 on the Ocean of Storms.
2 The Command Module Pilot was Gemini veteran Richard F Gordon Jr Conrad and Bean carried the first lunar surface color television camera but it was damaged when accidentally pointed into the Sun.
3 They made two EVAs totaling 7 hours and 45 minutes.
4 On one they walked to the Surveyor photographed it and removed some parts which they returned to Earth.
5 Charles Conrad and Alan Bean were on what spacecraft to the moon?	Apollo 12	1
6 Which lunar probe was near the Apollo 12 crews landing site?	Surveyor 3	1
7 What did the crew of Apollo 12 do with parts of the Surveyor they landed near after photographing them?	returned to Earth	4
8 What damaged the color TV camera that Apollo 12 had taken into space?	the Sun	2
1 The contracted batch of 15 Saturn Vs were enough for lunar landing missions through Apollo 20.
2 NASA publicized a preliminary list of eight more planned landing sites with plans to increase the mass of the CSM and LM for the last five missions along with the payload capacity of the Saturn V These final missions would combine the I and J types in the 1967 list allowing the CMP to operate a package of lunar orbital sensors and cameras while his companions were on the surface and allowing them to stay on the Moon for over three days.
3 These missions would also carry the Lunar Roving Vehicle LRV increasing the exploration area and allowing televised liftoff of the LM.
4 Also the Block II spacesuit was revised for the extended missions to allow greater flexibility and visibility for driving the LRV.
5 What would the latter Apollo missions carry to the moon to increase exploration?	Lunar Roving Vehicle LRV	3
6 What was redesigned to allow better maneuverability in the LRV?	Block II spacesuit	4
7 How many more landing sites for the Apollo missions did NASA have planned?	eight	2
8 How long would the astronauts be project to be able to stay on the moon for in the latter missions?	over three days	2
9 What would have to be increased regarding the LM and CSM for the last five missions?	mass	2
1 The success of the first two landings allowed the remaining missions to be crewed with a single veteran as Commander with two rookies.
2 Apollo 13 launched Lovell Jack Swigert and Fred Haise in April 1970 headed for the Fra Mauro formation.
3 But two days out a liquid oxygen tank exploded disabling the Service Module and forcing the crew to use the LM as a life boat to return to Earth.
4 Another NASA review board was convened to determine the cause which turned out to be a combination of damage of the tank in the factory and a subcontractor not making a tank component according to updated design specifications.
5 Apollo was grounded again for the remainder of 1970 while the oxygen tank was redesigned and an extra one was added.
6 What happened to the Apollo 13 crew to force them to use the LM as a life boat as it had been designed?	liquid oxygen tank exploded	3
7 Along with one veteran what other two types of crew could be included in lieu of veterans after the successful landings of Apollo 11 and 12?	rookies	1
8 What happened to the Apollo program in for the rest of 1970 after the incident regarding Apollo 13?	grounded	5
9 What was redesigned during the Apollo program being grounded during 1970?	oxygen tank	5
10 What month and year was Apollo 13 launched?	April 1970	2
1 About the time of the first landing in 1969 it was decided to use an existing Saturn V to launch the Skylab orbital laboratory prebuilt on the ground replacing the original plan to construct it in orbit from several Saturn IB launches this eliminated Apollo 20.
2 NASAs yearly budget also began to shrink in light of the successful landing and NASA also had to make funds available for the development of the upcoming Space Shuttle.
3 By 1971 the decision was made to also cancel missions 18 and 19.
4 The two unused Saturn Vs became museum exhibits at the John F Kennedy Space Center on Merritt Island Florida George C Marshall Space Center in Huntsville Alabama Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans Louisiana and Lyndon B Johnson Space Center in Houston Texas.
5 What Apollo mission was first cancelled due to not being needed to build the Skylab in space as it was prebuilt on the ground?	Apollo 20	1
6 What happened to NASAs budget after the first successful moon landing?	began to shrink	2
7 After Apollo missions 18 and 19 were cancelled what happened to the Saturn Vs that were never used?	museum exhibits	4
8 What year was the decision made to cancel Apollo missions 18 and 19?	1971	3
1 The rocks collected from the Moon are extremely old compared to rocks found on Earth as measured by radiometric dating techniques.
2 They range in age from about 32 billion years for the basaltic samples derived from the lunar maria to about 46 billion years for samples derived from the highlands crust.
3 As such they represent samples from a very early period in the development of the Solar System that are largely absent on Earth.
4 One important rock found during the Apollo Program is dubbed the Genesis Rock retrieved by astronauts David Scott and James Irwin during the Apollo 15 mission.
5 This anorthosite rock is composed almost exclusively of the calciumrich feldspar mineral anorthite and is believed to be representative of the highland crust.
6 A geochemical component called KREEP was discovered which has no known terrestrial counterpart.
7 KREEP and the anorthositic samples have been used to infer that the outer portion of the Moon was once completely molten see lunar magma ocean.
8 How did the rocks on the moon compare to those on Earth?	extremely old	1
9 How old were some of the oldest rock samples found on the moon?	46 billion years	2
10 What new component was found in certain rocks from the moon?	KREEP	6
11 What was the name of the rock found during the Apollo 15 mission that KREEP was discovered in?	Genesis Rock	4
1 Almost all the rocks show evidence of impact process effects.
2 Many samples appear to be pitted with micrometeoroid impact craters which is never seen on Earth rocks due to the thick atmosphere.
3 Many show signs of being subjected to high pressure shock waves that are generated during impact events.
4 Some of the returned samples are of impact melt materials melted near an impact crater.
5 All samples returned from the Moon are highly brecciated as a result of being subjected to multiple impact events.
6 As the moon has no atmosphere what is prevalant in many moon rock samples brought back from Apollo missions?	micrometeoroid impact craters	2
7 What do a great majority of rocks sampled from the moon show?	impact process effects	1
8 What is impact melt that some samples of moon rocks show?	materials melted near an impact crater	4
1 In 2009 NASA held a symposium on project costs which presented an estimate of the Apollo program costs in 2005 dollars as roughly 170 billion.
2 This included all research and development costs the procurement of 15 Saturn V rockets 16 CommandService Modules 12 Lunar Modules plus program support and management costs construction expenses for facilities and their upgrading and costs for flight operations.
3 This was based on a Congressional Budget Office report A Budgetary Analysis of NASAs New Vision for Space September 2004.
4 The Space Review estimated in 2010 the cost of Apollo from 1959 to 1973 as 204 billion or 109 billion in 2010 dollars.
5 How much was NASAs procured spending on the Apollo project estimated to be at in 2005 after inflation?	170 billion	1
6 How many Saturn V rockets were produced by NASA during the Apollo project?	15	2
7 How much was the Apollo project estimated to have cost from 1959 to 1973 the length of the program?	204 billion	4
1 Looking beyond the manned lunar landings NASA investigated several postlunar applications for Apollo hardware.
2 The Apollo Extension Series Apollo X proposed up to 30 flights to Earth orbit using the space in the Spacecraft Lunar Module Adapter SLA to house a small orbital laboratory workshop.
3 Astronauts would continue to use the CSM as a ferry to the station.
4 This study was followed by design of a larger orbital workshop to be built in orbit from an empty SIVB Saturn upper stage and grew into the Apollo Applications Program AAP.
5 The workshop was to be supplemented by Apollo Telescope Missions which would replace the LMs descent stage equipment and engine with a solar telescope observatory.
6 The most ambitious plan called for using an empty SIVB as an interplanetary spacecraft for a Venus flyby mission.
7 What did NASA name the series seeking up to 30 more flights to Earths orbit?	Apollo X	2
8 What did the acronym AAP stand for?	Apollo Applications Program	4
9 What planet was named for a flyby mission by an empty SIVB?	Venus	6
1 The SIVB orbital workshop was the only one of these plans to make it off the drawing board.
2 Dubbed Skylab it was constructed complete on the ground rather than in space and launched in 1973 using the two lower stages of a Saturn V It was equipped with an Apollo Telescope Mount the solar telescope that would have been used on the Apollo Telescope Missions.
3 Skylabs last crew departed the station on February 8 1974 and the station itself reentered the atmosphere in 1979 by which time it had become the oldest operational ApolloSaturn component.
4 When was the Skylab launched?	1973	2
5 Was the Skylab assembled on Earths surface or in space?	on the ground	2
6 When was Skylabs last crew on the station before it reentered Earths atmosphere?	February 8  1974	3
7 The Skylab had what type of equipment onboard that was supposed to be used in a different mission?	Apollo Telescope Mount	2
1 In 2008 Japan Aerospace Exploration Agencys SELENE probe observed evidence of the halo surrounding the Apollo 15 Lunar Module blast crater while orbiting above the lunar surface.
2 In 2009 NASAs robotic Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter while orbiting 50 kilometers 31 mi above the Moon began photographing the remnants of the Apollo program left on the lunar surface and photographed each site where manned Apollo flights landed.
3 All of the U S flags left on the Moon during the Apollo missions were found to still be standing with the exception of the one left during the Apollo 11 mission which was blown over during that missions liftoff from the lunar surface and return to the mission Command Module in lunar orbit the degree to which these flags retain their original colors remains unknown.
4 Which NASA orbiter photographed evidence of each site on the moon that a manned Apollo mission landing occurred?	Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter	2
5 The flags on the moon left by the US manned Apollo missions are all still standing save for which missions flag?	Apollo 11	3
6 Do the US flags on the moon still have their original coloring or were they faded due to the Sun?	unknown	3
1 The crew of Apollo 8 sent the first live televised pictures of the Earth and the Moon back to Earth and read from the creation story in the Book of Genesis on Christmas Eve 1968.
2 An estimated onequarter of the population of the world saw—either live or delayed—the Christmas Eve transmission during the ninth orbit of the Moon.
3 The mission and Christmas provided an inspiring end to 1968 which had been a troubled year for the US marked by Vietnam War protests race riots and the assassinations of civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr and Senator Robert F Kennedy.
4 What crew sent the first ever live images of the Earth and Moon to earth?	Apollo 8	1
5 From what Bible book did the crew of Apollo 8 read from during this stream of images?	Book of Genesis	1
6 How much of the population of Earth ended up seeing the images of the Earth and the Moon?	onequarter	2
7 After an eventful and tiring year for the world during 1968 what type of ending to the year did the images from space provide?	inspiring end	3
1 The Moon landing data was recorded by a special Apollo TV camera which recorded in a format incompatible with broadcast TV.
2 This resulted in lunar footage that had to be converted for the live television broadcast and stored on magnetic telemetry tapes.
3 During the following years a magnetic tape shortage prompted NASA to remove massive numbers of magnetic tapes from the National Archives and Records Administration to be recorded over with newer satellite data.
4 Stan Lebar who led the team that designed and built the lunar television camera at Westinghouse Electric Corporation also worked with Nafzger to try to locate the missing tapes.
5 What type of camera was used to record the Moon landing?	special Apollo TV camera	1
6 Was this footage compatible or incompatible with live broadcast TV formats?	incompatible	1
7 What happened to prompt NASA to record over archived magnetic tapes?	magnetic tape shortage	3
8 What did NASA record over the older archived tapes?	newer satellite data	3
9 Who worked later on to find these missing magnetic tapes that had data stored on them?	Stan Lebar	4
1 With a budget of 230000 the surviving original lunar broadcast data from Apollo 11 was compiled by Nafzger and assigned to Lowry Digital for restoration.
2 The video was processed to remove random noise and camera shake without destroying historical legitimacy.
3 The images were from tapes in Australia the CBS News archive and kinescope recordings made at Johnson Space Center.
4 The restored video remaining in black and white contains conservative digital enhancements and did not include sound quality improvements.
5 Who compiled the original surviving Apollo 11 landing data?	Nafzger	1
6 Were the tapes able to be restored and processed without destroying historical legitimacy or did some aspects of the tapes lose legitimacy?	without destroying historical legitimacy	2
7 What types of recordings at Johnson Space Center were used to help restore the original tapes?	kinescope recordings	3
8 Which company was tasked with trying to restore the original tapes?	Lowry Digital	1
9 Were the restored tapes able to have color added to them to enhance the picture or did they remain black and white?	black and white	4
1 European Union law is a body of treaties and legislation such as Regulations and Directives which have direct effect or indirect effect on the laws of European Union member states.
2 The three sources of European Union law are primary law secondary law and supplementary law.
3 The main sources of primary law are the Treaties establishing the European Union.
4 Secondary sources include regulations and directives which are based on the Treaties.
5 The legislature of the European Union is principally composed of the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union which under the Treaties may establish secondary law to pursue the objective set out in the Treaties.
6 What are the three sources of European Union law?	primary law  secondary law and supplementary law	2
7 What is European Union Law?	a body of treaties and legislation	1
8 What are the main sources of primary law?	Treaties establishing the European Union	3
9 What are the secondary sources of primary law?	regulations and directives	4
10 What are the two bodies that make up the European Unions legislature?	European Parliament and the Council of the European Union	5
11 What is European Union law?	a body of treaties and legislation	1
12 What effect does European Union law have on laws of member states?	direct effect or indirect effect	1
13 What are the three sources of European Union law?	primary law  secondary law and supplementary law	2
14 What are the main legislative bodies of the European Union?	European Parliament and the Council of the European Union	5
15 What are the three main sources of European Union law?	primary law  secondary law and supplementary law	2
16 What are the main sources of primary law?	the Treaties establishing the European Union	3
17 What is the legislature of the European Union comprised of?	the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union	5
18 How many sources of European Union law are there?	three	2
1 European Union law is applied by the courts of member states and the Court of Justice of the European Union.
2 Where the laws of member states provide for lesser rights European Union law can be enforced by the courts of member states.
3 In case of European Union law which should have been transposed into the laws of member states such as Directives the European Commission can take proceedings against the member state under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
4 The European Court of Justice is the highest court able to interpret European Union law.
5 Supplementary sources of European Union law include case law by the Court of Justice international law and general principles of European Union law.
6 Who applies European Union law?	courts of member states and the Court of Justice of the European Union	1
7 Who can enforce the European Union law when member states provide lesser rights?	courts of member states	2
8 Under what treaty can the European Commission take action against member states?	Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union	3
9 What is the highest court in the European Union?	The European Court of Justice	4
10 What is one of the supplementary sources of European Union law?	international law	5
11 Which two courts apply European Union law?	courts of member states and the Court of Justice of the European Union	1
12 Under what treaty can the European Commission take action against member states?	the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union	3
13 Which court is the highest court in the European Union?	The European Court of Justice	4
14 What is one supplementary source of European Union law?	international law	5
15 By whom is European Law applied by?	the courts of member states and the Court of Justice of the European Union	1
16 Who can enforce European Union law?	the courts of member states	2
17 What is the highest court in European Union law?	The European Court of Justice	4
18 What are some supplementary sources of European Union law?	case law by the Court of Justice  international law and general principles of European Union law	5
1 Although the European Union does not have a codified constitution like every political body it has laws which constitute its basic governance structure.
2 The EUs primary constitutional sources are the Treaty on European Union TEU and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union TFEU which have been agreed or adhered to among the governments of all 28 member states.
3 The Treaties establish the EUs institutions list their powers and responsibilities and explain the areas in which the EU can legislate with Directives or Regulations.
4 The European Commission has the initiative to propose legislation.
5 During the ordinary legislative procedure the Council which are ministers from member state governments and the European Parliament elected by citizens can make amendments and must give their consent for laws to pass.
6 The Commission oversees departments and various agencies that execute or enforce EU law.
7 The European Council rather than the Council made up of different government Ministers is composed of the Prime Ministers or executive Presidents of the member states.
8 It appoints the Commissioners and the board of the European Central Bank.
9 The European Court of Justice is the supreme judicial body which interprets EU law and develops it through precedent.
10 The Court can review the legality of the EU institutions actions in compliance with the Treaties.
11 It can also decide upon claims for breach of EU laws from member states and citizens.
12 What are the two primary constitutional sources of the European Union?	Treaty on European Union TEU and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union TFEU	2
13 Who has the power to initiate legislation within the European Union?	The European Commission	4
14 Who elects the members of the European Parliament?	citizens	5
15 What court is able to interpret European Union law?	The European Court of Justice	9
16 What governing body appoints commissioners and the board of European Central Bank?	The European Council	7
1 The primary law of the EU consists mainly of the founding treaties the core treaties being the Treaty on European Union TEU and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union TFEU.
2 The Treaties contain formal and substantive provisions which frame policies of the European Union institutions and determine the division of competences between the European Union and its member states.
3 The TEU establishes that European Union law applies to the metropolitan territories of the member states as well as certain islands and overseas territories including Madeira the Canary Islands and the French overseas departments.
4 European Union law also applies in territories where a member state is responsible for external relations for example Gibraltar and the Åland islands.
5 The TEU allows the European Council to make specific provisions for regions as for example done for customs matters in Gibraltar and SaintPierreetMiquelon.
6 The TEU specifically excludes certain regions for example the Faroe Islands from the jurisdiction of European Union law.
7 Treaties apply as soon as they enter into force unless stated otherwise and are generally concluded for an unlimited period.
8 The TEU provides that commitments entered into by the member states between themselves before the treaty was signed no longer apply.
9 vague All EU member states are regarded as subject to the general obligation of the principle of cooperation as stated in the TEU whereby member states are obliged not to take measure which could jeopardise the attainment of the TEU objectives.
10 The Court of Justice of the European Union can interpret the Treaties but it cannot rule on their validity which is subject to international law.
11 Individuals may rely on primary law in the Court of Justice of the European Union if the Treaty provisions have a direct effect and they are sufficiently clear precise and unconditional.
12 Which treaty provides that the European Union law be applied to metropolitan territories of member states?	Treaty on European Union TEU	1
13 Are there any regions where the Treaty of European Union excludes from jurisdiction?	the Faroe Islands	6
14 What powers does the Court of Justice of the European Union have in regards to treaties?	can interpret the Treaties  but it cannot rule on their validity	10
15 Under what instances can individuals rely on primary law in the Court of Justice of European Union?	if the Treaty provisions have a direct effect and they are sufficiently clear  precise and unconditional	11
16 When do treaties apply?	as soon as they enter into force  unless stated otherwise	7
17 What are the core treaties that the primary law of the EU consists of?	Treaty on European Union TEU and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union TFEU	1
18 What are some examples of territories where a member state is responsible for external relations?	Gibraltar and the Åland islands	4
19 When do the stated Treaties apply?	Treaties apply as soon as they enter into force  unless stated otherwise	7
20 Who is suited to interpret the Treaties?	The Court of Justice of the European Union can interpret the Treaties	10
1 The principal Treaties that form the European Union began with common rules for coal and steel and then atomic energy but more complete and formal institutions were established through the Treaty of Rome 1957 and the Maastricht Treaty 1992 now TFEU.
2 Minor amendments were made during the 1960s and 1970s.
3 Major amending treaties were signed to complete the development of a single internal market in the Single European Act 1986 to further the development of a more social Europe in the Treaty of Amsterdam 1997 and to make minor amendments to the relative power of member states in the EU institutions in the Treaty of Nice 2001 and the Treaty of Lisbon 2007.
4 Since its establishment more member states have joined through a series of accession treaties from the UK Ireland Denmark and Norway in 1972 though Norway did not end up joining Greece in 1979 Spain and Portugal 1985 Austria Finland Norway and Sweden in 1994 though again Norway failed to join because of lack of support in the referendum the Czech Republic Cyprus Estonia Hungary Latvia Lithuania Malta Poland Slovakia and Slovenia in 2004 Romania and Bulgaria in 2007 and Croatia in 2013.
5 Greenland signed a Treaty in 1985 giving it a special status.
6 How did the principle treaties that form the European Union begin?	with common rules for coal and steel  and then atomic energy	1
7 Which two treaties provided more formal institutions of the European Union?	Treaty of Rome 1957 and the Maastricht Treaty 1992	1
8 In what years did Spain and Portugal join the European Union?	1985	4
9 In 1972 did Norway end up joining the European Union?	in 1972 though Norway did not end up joining	4
10 Which country in 1985 signed a treaty to give it special status?	Greenland	5
11 What caused the need for principal Treaties that ended up forming the EU?	common rules for coal and steel  and then atomic energy	1
12 When year was the Maastrich Treaty signed?	1992	1
13  When was the Single European Act made?	1986	3
14 When did Denmark join the EU?	1972	4
15 When did Greenland sign a Treaty granting them special status?	1985	5
1 Following the Nice Treaty there was an attempt to reform the constitutional law of the European Union and make it more transparent this would have also produced a single constitutional document.
2 However as a result of the referendum in France and the referendum in the Netherlands the 2004 Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe never came into force.
3 Instead the Lisbon Treaty was enacted.
4 Its substance was very similar to the proposed constitutional treaty but it was formally an amending treaty and – though it significantly altered the existing treaties – it did not completely replace them.
5 When was there an attempt to reform the law of the EU?	Following the Nice Treaty	1
6 What two countrys referendums curtailed a constitution for Europe?	referendum in France and the referendum in the Netherlands	2
7 How similar was the Lisbon Treaty to the constitutional treaty?	very similar	4
8 What type of treaty was the Lisbon Treaty?	an amending treaty	4
9 Is the Lisbon Treaty one that would alter existing treaties or replace them?	altered the existing treaties	4
10 What reform was attempted following the Nice Treaty?	there was an attempt to reform the constitutional law of the European Union and make it more transparent	1
11 What was an additional projected effect of the attempted reform?	this would have also produced a single constitutional document	1
12 Which caused the reform to never come into force?	the referendum in France and the referendum in the Netherlands	2
13 What treaty took the place of constitutional treaty?	the Lisbon Treaty	3
1 The European Commission is the main executive body of the European Union.
2 Article 171 of the Treaty on European Union states the Commission should promote the general interest of the Union while Article 173 adds that Commissioners should be completely independent and not take instructions from any Government.
3 Under article 172 Union legislative acts may only be adopted on the basis of a Commission proposal except where the Treaties provide otherwise.
4 This means that the Commission has a monopoly on initiating the legislative procedure although the Council is the de facto catalyst of many legislative initiatives.
5 The Parliament can also formally request the Commission to submit a legislative proposal but the Commission can reject such a suggestion giving reasons.
6 The Commissions President currently an exLuxembourg Prime Minister JeanClaude Juncker sets the agenda for the EUs work.
7 Decisions are taken by a simple majority vote usually through a written procedure of circulating the proposals and adopting if there are no objections.
8 citation needed Since Ireland refused to consent to changes in the Treaty of Lisbon 2007 there remains one Commissioner for each of the 28 member states including the President and the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy currently Federica Mogherini.
9 The Commissioners and most importantly the portfolios they will hold are bargained over intensively by the member states.
10 The Commissioners as a block are then subject to a qualified majority vote of the Council to approve and majority approval of the Parliament.
11 The proposal to make the Commissioners be drawn from the elected Parliament was not adopted in the Treaty of Lisbon.
12 This means Commissioners are through the appointment process the unelected subordinates of member state governments.
13 What is the main executive body of the EU?	The European Commission	1
14 Who is the sole governing authority capable of initiating legislative proposals?	the Commission	4
15 Which authority figure is designated to schedule and set the work of the EU?	The Commissions President	6
16 For each of the 28 member states how many Commissioners are represented for each one?	one Commissioner for each of the 28 member states	8
17 Who is the current President and the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy?	Federica Mogherini	8
18 Which article of the Treaty on European Union states that Commissioners should be completely independent and not take instructions from any Government?	Article 173	2
19 Who sets the agenda for the EUs work?	The Commissions President	6
20 How are decisions made on behave of the EU made?	simple majority vote	7
21 Which country refused to content to changes in the Treaty of Lisbon 2007?	Ireland	8
22 Who are the unelected subordinates of member state governments?	Commissioners	12
1 Commissioners have various privileges such as being exempt from member state taxes but not EU taxes and having immunity from prosecution for doing official acts.
2 Commissioners have sometimes been found to have abused their offices particularly since the Santer Commission was censured by Parliament in 1999 and it eventually resigned due to corruption allegations.
3 This resulted in one main case Commission v Edith Cresson where the European Court of Justice held that a Commissioner giving her dentist a job for which he was clearly unqualified did in fact not break any law.
4 By contrast to the ECJs relaxed approach a Committee of Independent Experts found that a culture had developed where few Commissioners had ‘even the slightest sense of responsibility’.
5 This led to the creation of the European Antifraud Office.
6 In 2012 it investigated the Maltese Commissioner for Health John Dalli who quickly resigned after allegations that he received a €60m bribe in connection with a Tobacco Products Directive.
7 Beyond the Commission the European Central Bank has relative executive autonomy in its conduct of monetary policy for the purpose of managing the euro.
8 It has a sixperson board appointed by the European Council on the Councils recommendation.
9 The President of the Council and a Commissioner can sit in on ECB meetings but do not have voting rights.
10 What commission was censured in 1999 and paved the way for Commissioners to abuse their power?	the Santer Commission	2
11 Did the European Court of Justice rule the defendant in the case of Commission v Edith Cresson broke any laws?	did in fact not break any law	3
12 Who found that there was a developed culture of Commissioners who lacked responsibility?	Committee of Independent Experts	4
13 Who appoints the board of the European Central Bank?	European Council	8
14 Can the President of the Council vote on important matters related to the European Central Bank?	do not have voting rights	9
15 When was the Santer Commission censured by Parliament?	1999	2
16 The censuring of the Santer Commission  resulted in which main case?	Commission v Edith Cresson	3
17 Who found that a culture had developed where few Commissioners had any sense of responsibility?	a Committee of Independent Experts	4
18 The corruption found by the Committee of Independent Experts resulted to the creation of what office?	the European Antifraud Office	5
19 When did the European AntiFraud Office investigate John Dalli?	2012	6
1 While the Commission has a monopoly on initiating legislation the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union have powers of amendment and veto during the legislative process.
2 According to the Treaty on European Union articles 9 and 10 the EU observes the principle of equality of its citizens and is meant to be founded on representative democracy.
3 In practice equality and democracy are deficient because the elected representatives in the Parliament cannot initiate legislation against the Commissions wishes citizens of smallest countries have ten times the voting weight in Parliament as citizens of the largest countries and qualified majorities or consensus of the Council are required to legislate.
4 The justification for this democratic deficit under the Treaties is usually thought to be that completion integration of the European economy and political institutions required the technical coordination of experts while popular understanding of the EU developed and nationalist sentiments declined postwar.
5 Over time this has meant the Parliament gradually assumed more voice from being an unelected assembly to its first direct elections in 1979 to having increasingly more rights in the legislative process.
6 Citizens rights are therefore limited compared to the democratic polities within all European member states under TEU article 11 citizens and associations have the rights such as publicising their views and submit an initiative that must be considered by the Commission with one million signatures.
7 TFEU article 227 contains a further right for citizens to petition the Parliament on issues which affect them.
8 Parliament elections take place every five years and votes for Members of the European Parliament in member states must be organised by proportional representation or a single transferable vote.
9 There are 750 MEPs and their numbers are degressively proportional according to member state size.
10 This means  although the Council is meant to be the body representing member states  in the Parliament citizens of smaller member states have more voice than citizens in larger member states.
11 MEPs divide as they do in national Parliaments along political party lines the conservative European Peoples Party is currently the largest and the Party of European Socialists leads the opposition.
12 Parties do not receive public funds from the EU as the Court of Justice held in Parti écologiste Les Verts v Parliament that this was entirely an issue to be regulated by the member states.
13 The Parliaments powers include calling inquiries into maladministration or appoint an Ombudsman pending any court proceedings.
14 It can require the Commission respond to questions and by a twothirds majority can censure the whole Commission as happened to the Santer Commission in 1999.
15 In some cases the Parliament has explicit consultation rights which the Commission must genuinely follow.
16 However its role participation in the legislative process still remains limited because no member can actually or pass legislation without the Commission and Council meaning power kratia is not in the hands of directly elected representatives of the people demos in the EU it is not yet true that the administration is in the hands of the many and not of the few.
17 Which two governing bodies have legislative veto power?	the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union	1
18 What cant Parliament do that causes equality and democracy to be deficient?	cannot initiate legislation against the Commissions wishes	3
19 How often do Parliament elections take place?	every five years	8
20 How much of a voting majority must there be to effectively censure the Commission?	twothirds majority	14
21 What two bodies must the Parliament go through first to pass legislation?	the Commission and Council	16
22 Which entity has a monopoly on initiating legislation?	the Commission	1
23 Which entities have powers of amendment and veto during the legislative process?	the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union	1
24 When did the first direct elections take place?	1979	5
25 How often do Parliament elections take place?	every five years	8
26 Which party is currently the largest among political party lines?	the conservative European Peoples Party	11
1 The second main legislative body is the Council which is composed of different ministers of the member states.
2 The heads of government of member states also convene a European Council a distinct body that the TEU article 15 defines as providing the necessary impetus for its development and shall define the general political directions and priorities.
3 It meets each six months and its President currently former Poland Prime Minister Donald Tusk is meant to drive forward its work but it does not itself legislative functions.
4 The Council does this in effect this is the governments of the member states but there will be a different minister at each meeting depending on the topic discussed eg.
5 for environmental issues the member states environment ministers attend and vote for foreign affairs the foreign ministers etc.
6 The minister must have the authority to represent and bin the member states in decisions.
7 When voting takes place it is weighted inversely to member state size so smaller member states are not dominated by larger member states.
8 In total there are 352 votes but for most acts there must be a qualified majority vote if not consensus.
9 TEU article 164 and TFEU article 2383 define this to mean at least 55 per cent of the Council members not votes representing 65 per cent of the population of the EU currently this means around 74 per cent or 260 of the 352 votes.
10 This is critical during the legislative process.
11 The legislative body the Council are made up of what type of individuals?	different ministers of the member states	1
12 Who is currently the President of the Council?	Donald Tusk	3
13 How are the votes weighted to ensure that smaller states arent dominated by larger ones?	inversely	7
14 What are the total number of votes to be counted during the voting process?	352	8
15 Currently how many votes out of the 352 total votes are needed for a majority?	260	9
16 Which entity is the secondary legislative body?	the Council	1
17 How often does the European Council meet?	each six months	3
18 How many votes in total does the Council have?	352	8
19 What is defined as the majority vote?	at least 55 per cent of the Council members not votes representing 65 per cent of the population of the EU	9
1 To make new legislation TFEU article 294 defines the ordinary legislative procedure that applies for most EU acts.
2 The essence is there are three readings starting with a Commission proposal where the Parliament must vote by a majority of all MEPs not just those present to block or suggest changes and the Council must vote by qualified majority to approve changes but by unanimity to block Commission amendment.
3 Where the different institutions cannot agree at any stage a Conciliation Committee is convened representing MEPs ministers and the Commission to try and get agreement on a joint text if this works it will be sent back to the Parliament and Council to approve by absolute and qualified majority.
4 This means legislation can be blocked by a majority in Parliament a minority in the Council and a majority in the Commission it is harder to change EU law than stay the same.
5 A different procedure exists for budgets.
6 For enhanced cooperation among a subset of at least member states authorisation must be given by the Council.
7 Member state governments should be informed by the Commission at the outset before any proposals start the legislative procedure.
8 The EU as a whole can only act within its power set out in the Treaties.
9 TEU articles 4 and 5 state that powers remain with the member states unless they have been conferred although there is a debate about the KompetenzKompetenz question who ultimately has the competence to define the EUs competence.
10 Many member state courts believe they decide other member state Parliaments believe they decide while within the EU the Court of Justice believes it has the final say.
11 What type of vote must the Parliament have to either block or suggest changes to the Commissions proposals?	a majority	2
12 What type of vote must the Council pass in order to approve of any changes recommended by Parliament?	qualified majority	2
13 Is it easier or harder to change EU law than stay the same?	harder	4
14 What articles state that unless conferred powers remain with member states?	TEU articles 4 and 5	9
15 Within the EU which court believes they have the final word deciding on EUs competence?	Court of Justice	10
16 Which TFEU article defines the ordinary legislative procedure that applies for majority of EU acts?	TFEU article 294	1
17 What can block a legislation?	legislation can be blocked by a majority in Parliament  a minority in the Council  and a majority in the Commission	4
18 Which articles state that powers stay with member states unless theyve been conferred?	TEU articles 4 and 5	9
19 What entity is created if the three different institutions cannot come to a consensus at any stage?	Conciliation Committee	3
1 The judicial branch of the EU has played an important role in the development of EU law by assuming the task of interpreting the treaties and accelerating economic and political integration.
2 Today the Court of Justice of the European Union CJEU is the main judicial body within which there is a higher European Court of Justice commonly abbreviated as ECJ that deals with cases that contain more public importance and a General Court that deals with issues of detail but without general importance.
3 There is also a Civil Service Tribunal to deal with EU staff issues and then a separate Court of Auditors.
4 Under the Treaty on European Union article 192 there is one judge from each member state 28 at present who are supposed to possess the qualifications required for appointment to the highest judicial offices or for the General Court the ability required for appointment to high judicial office.
5 A president is elected by the judges for three years.
6 Under TEU article 193 is to be the ultimate court to interpret questions of EU law.
7 In fact most EU law is applied by member state courts the English Court of Appeal the German Bundesgerichtshof the Belgian Cour du travail etc.
8 but they can refer questions to the EU court for a preliminary ruling.
9 The CJEUs duty is to ensure that in the interpretation and application of the Treaties the law is observed although realistically it has the ability to expand and develop the law according to the principles it deems to be appropriate.
10 Arguably this has been done through both seminal and controversial judgments including Van Gend en Loos Mangold v Helm and Kadi v Commission.
11 Which branch of the EU has had the most influence on the development of EU law?	judicial branch	1
12 What is the main judicial body of the EU?	Court of Justice of the European Union CJEU	2
13 How many total judges are there in the EU?	28	4
14 Under which courts is most EU law applied?	member state courts	7
15 What is the CJEUs duty?	ensure that in the interpretation and application of the Treaties the law is observed	9
16 How is the judicial branch of the EU an important factor in the development of EU law?	by assuming the task of interpreting the treaties  and accelerating economic and political integration	1
17 What is the current main judicial body of the EU?	the Court of Justice of the European Union	2
18 What entity deals with EU staff issues?	Civil Service Tribunal	3
19 How long is one term for an elected president of the CJEU?	three years	5
20 What is the CJEUs duty?	to ensure that in the interpretation and application of the Treaties the law is observed	9
1 Since its founding the EU has operated among an increasing plurality of national and globalising legal systems.
2 This has meant both the European Court of Justice and the highest national courts have had to develop principles to resolve conflicts of laws between different systems.
3 Within the EU itself the Court of Justices view is that if EU law conflicts with a provision of national law then EU law has primacy.
4 In the first major case in 1964 Costa v ENEL a Milanese lawyer and former shareholder of an energy company named Mr Costa refused to pay his electricity bill to Enel as a protest against the nationalisation of the Italian energy corporations.
5 He claimed the Italian nationalisation law conflicted with the Treaty of Rome and requested a reference be made to both the Italian Constitutional Court and the Court of Justice under TFEU article 267.
6 The Italian Constitutional Court gave an opinion that because the nationalisation law was from 1962 and the treaty was in force from 1958 Costa had no claim.
7 By contrast the Court of Justice held that ultimately the Treaty of Rome in no way prevented energy nationalisation and in any case under the Treaty provisions only the Commission could have brought a claim not Mr Costa.
8 However in principle Mr Costa was entitled to plead that the Treaty conflicted with national law and the court would have a duty to consider his claim to make a reference if there would be no appeal against its decision.
9 The Court of Justice repeating its view in Van Gend en Loos said member states albeit within limited spheres have restricted their sovereign rights and created a body of law applicable both to their nationals and to themselves on the basis of reciprocity.
10 EU law would not be overridden by domestic legal provisions however framed without the legal basis of the community itself being called into question.
11 This meant any subsequent unilateral act of the member state inapplicable.
12 Similarly in Amministrazione delle Finanze v Simmenthal SpA a company Simmenthal SpA claimed that a public health inspection fee under an Italian law of 1970 for importing beef from France to Italy was contrary to two Regulations from 1964 and 1968.
13 In accordance with the principle of the precedence of Community law said the Court of Justice the directly applicable measures of the institutions such as the Regulations in the case render automatically inapplicable any conflicting provision of current national law.
14 This was necessary to prevent a corresponding denial of Treaty obligations undertaken unconditionally and irrevocably by member states that could imperil the very foundations of the EU.
15 But despite the views of the Court of Justice the national courts of member states have not accepted the same analysis.
16 If there is a conflict between EU law and national law which law take precedence?	EU law	3
17 What was the reason the Italian Constitutional court gave that resulted in Mr Costa losing his his claim against ENEL?	nationalisation law was from 1962  and the treaty was in force from 1958	6
18 What were the years two Regulations that conflicted with an Italian law originate in the Simmenthal SpA case?	1964 and 1968	12
19 Which entities have had to develop principles dedicated to conflict resolution between laws of different systems?	the European Court of Justice and the highest national courts	2
20 When did Costa v ENEL take place?	1964	4
21 Which court argued that the Treaty of Rome did not prevent energy nationalism?	the Court of Justice	7
1 Generally speaking while all member states recognise that EU law takes primacy over national law where this agreed in the Treaties they do not accept that the Court of Justice has the final say on foundational constitutional questions affecting democracy and human rights.
2 In the United Kingdom the basic principle is that Parliament as the sovereign expression of democratic legitimacy can decide whether it wishes to expressly legislate against EU law.
3 This however would only happen in the case of an express wish of the people to withdraw from the EU.
4 It was held in R Factortame Ltd v Secretary of State for Transport that whatever limitation of its sovereignty Parliament accepted when it enacted the European Communities Act 1972 was entirely voluntary and so it has always been clear that UK courts have a duty to override any rule of national law found to be in conflict with any directly enforceable rule of Community law.
5 More recently the UK Supreme Court noted that in R HS2 Action Alliance Ltd v Secretary of State for Transport although the UK constitution is uncodified there could be fundamental principles of common law and Parliament did not either contemplate or authorise the abrogation of those principles when it enacted the European Communities Act 1972.
6 The view of the German Constitutional Court from the Solange I and Solange II decisions is that if the EU does not comply with its basic constitutional rights and principles particularly democracy the rule of law and the social state principles then it cannot override German law.
7 However as the nicknames of the judgments go so long as the EU works towards the democratisation of its institutions and has a framework that protects fundamental human rights it would not review EU legislation for compatibility with German constitutional principles.
8 Most other member states have expressed similar reservations.
9 This suggests the EUs legitimacy rests on the ultimate authority of member states its factual commitment to human rights and the democratic will of the people.
10 What do all member states agree takes precedence over national law?	EU law	1
11 What issues do member states say the Court of Justice does not have the final say on?	foundational constitutional questions affecting democracy and human rights	1
12 When was the European Communities Act created?	1972	5
13 What does the EUs legitimacy rest on?	the ultimate authority of member states  its factual commitment to human rights  and the democratic will of the people	9
14 In what cases can the EU not override German law?	if the EU does not comply with its basic constitutional rights and principles	6
1 While constitutional law concerns the European Unions governance structure administrative law binds EU institutions and member states to follow the law.
2 Both member states and the Commission have a general legal right or standing locus standi to bring claims against EU institutions and other member states for breach of the treaties.
3 From the EUs foundation the Court of Justice also held that the Treaties allowed citizens or corporations to bring claims against EU and member state institutions for violation of the Treaties and Regulations if they were properly interpreted as creating rights and obligations.
4 However under Directives citizens or corporations were said in 1986 to not be allowed to bring claims against other nonstate parties.
5 This meant courts of member states were not bound to apply an EU law where a national rule conflicted even though the member state government could be sued if it would impose an obligation on another citizen or corporation.
6 These rules on direct effect limit the extent to which member state courts are bound to administer EU law.
7 All actions by EU institutions can be subject to judicial review and judged by standards of proportionality particularly where general principles of law or fundamental rights are engaged.
8 The remedy for a claimant where there has been a breach of the law is often monetary damages but courts can also require specific performance or will grant an injunction in order to ensure the law is effective as possible.
9 Which type of law makes EU institutions and its member states follow the law?	administrative law	1
10 During what year were citizens or corporations said to not be able to bring claims against other non state parties?	1986	4
11 Which actions by EU institutions can be subject to judicial review?	All actions	7
12 Which type of law concerns the EUs governance structure?	constitutional law	1
1 Although it is generally accepted that EU law has primacy not all EU laws give citizens standing to bring claims that is not all EU laws have direct effect.
2 In Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen it was held that the provisions of the Treaties and EU Regulations are directly effective if they are 1 clear and unambiguous 2 unconditional and 3 did not require EU or national authorities to take further action to implement them.
