10 What fish living in the Amazon river is known to bit humans?	piranha	3
11 What are dart frogs are known to secrete?	lipophilic alkaloid toxins	4
12 What type of bat that lives in the Amazon rainforest can spread rabies?	Vampire bats	6
1 Deforestation is the conversion of forested areas to nonforested areas.
2 The main sources of deforestation in the Amazon are human settlement and development of the land.
3 Prior to the early 1960s access to the forests interior was highly restricted and the forest remained basically intact.
4 Farms established during the 1960s were based on crop cultivation and the slash and burn method.
5 However the colonists were unable to manage their fields and the crops because of the loss of soil fertility and weed invasion.
6 The soils in the Amazon are productive for just a short period of time so farmers are constantly moving to new areas and clearing more land.
7 These farming practices led to deforestation and caused extensive environmental damage.
8 Deforestation is considerable and areas cleared of forest are visible to the naked eye from outer space.
9 What is the process of removing trees from a forest known as?	Deforestation	1
10 Acessing the Amazon rainforest was restricted before what era?	the early 1960s	3
11 What method was used to clear forest for crop cultivation in the amazon forest?	slash and burn method	4
12 What are two factors that made it difficult for colonists to the Amazon forest to survive?	loss of soil fertility and weed invasion	5
13 What is notable about the Amazon forest when it is seen from space?	areas cleared of forest are visible to the naked eye	8
1 Between 1991 and 2000 the total area of forest lost in the Amazon rose from 415000 to 587000 square kilometres 160000 to 227000 sq mi with most of the lost forest becoming pasture for cattle.
2 Seventy percent of formerly forested land in the Amazon and 91 of land deforested since 1970 is used for livestock pasture.
3 Currently Brazil is the secondlargest global producer of soybeans after the United States.
4 New research however conducted by Leydimere Oliveira et al has shown that the more rainforest is logged in the Amazon the less precipitation reaches the area and so the lower the yield per hectare becomes.
5 So despite the popular perception there has been no economical advantage for Brazil from logging rainforest zones and converting these to pastoral fields.
6 How many square kilometres of the Amazon forest was lost by 1991?	415 000	1
7 In the year 2000 how many square kilometres of the Amazon forest had been lost?	587 000	1
8 What is most of the cleared land in the Amazon region used for?	pasture for cattle	1
9 Where is Brazil ranked globally in soybean production?	secondlargest global producer	3
10 What percentage of the land cleared in the Amazon is used for growing livestock?	91	2
1 The needs of soy farmers have been used to justify many of the controversial transportation projects that are currently developing in the Amazon.
2 The first two highways successfully opened up the rainforest and led to increased settlement and deforestation.
3 The mean annual deforestation rate from 2000 to 2005 22392 km2 or 8646 sq mi per year was 18 higher than in the previous five years 19018 km2 or 7343 sq mi per year.
4 Although deforestation has declined significantly in the Brazilian Amazon between 2004 and 2014 there has been an increase to the present day.
5 Highways built in the Amazon rainforest were built primarily for what kind of farmers?	soy farmers	1
6 What did creating highways in the Amazon rainforest lead to?	increased settlement and deforestation	2
7 The rate of clearing of forest from 2000 to 2005 was how many square miles per year?	8 646 sq mi	3
8 What happened to the rate of deforestation in the Amazon region of Brazil between 2004 and 2014?	deforestation has declined	4
9 How much higher was the rate of deforestation in 2000 to 2005 compared to 1995 to 2000?	18 higher	3
1 Environmentalists are concerned about loss of biodiversity that will result from destruction of the forest and also about the release of the carbon contained within the vegetation which could accelerate global warming.
2 Amazonian evergreen forests account for about 10 of the worlds terrestrial primary productivity and 10 of the carbon stores in ecosystems—of the order of 11 × 1011 metric tonnes of carbon.
3 Amazonian forests are estimated to have accumulated 062 ± 037 tons of carbon per hectare per year between 1975 and 1996.
4 What are environmentalists concerned about losing in the Amazon forest?	loss of biodiversity	1
5 The loss of biodiversity may be the result of what according to environmentalists?	destruction of the forest	1
6 What are environmentalists concerned about having released from the Amazon region?	carbon contained within the vegetation	1
7 What amount of the worlds carbon is stored in the Amazon forest?	10 of the carbon stores	2
8 How many metric tons of carbon are believed to be stored in the Amazon forest?	11 × 1011 metric tonnes	2
1 One computer model of future climate change caused by greenhouse gas emissions shows that the Amazon rainforest could become unsustainable under conditions of severely reduced rainfall and increased temperatures leading to an almost complete loss of rainforest cover in the basin by 2100.
2 However simulations of Amazon basin climate change across many different models are not consistent in their estimation of any rainfall response ranging from weak increases to strong decreases.
3 The result indicates that the rainforest could be threatened though the 21st century by climate change in addition to deforestation.
4 What change in conditions may make the Amazon rainforest unsustainable?	reduced rainfall and increased temperatures	1
5 A complete loss of rainforest cover may be caused by what type of emissions?	greenhouse gas emissions	1
6 If one computer model turns out correct by what year would there be a nearly complete loss of rainforest in the Amazon basin?	2100	1
7 How long may the Amazon rainforest be threatened according to some computer models?	though the 21st century	3
8 What are the main threats facing the Amazon rainforest in the current century?	climate change in addition to deforestation	3
1 As indigenous territories continue to be destroyed by deforestation and ecocide such as in the Peruvian Amazon indigenous peoples rainforest communities continue to disappear while others like the Urarina continue to struggle to fight for their cultural survival and the fate of their forested territories.
2 Meanwhile the relationship between nonhuman primates in the subsistence and symbolism of indigenous lowland South American peoples has gained increased attention as have ethnobiology and communitybased conservation efforts.
3 What kind of territories are being destroyed by ecocide in the Amazon?	indigenous territories	1
4 What type of conservation effort is gaining attention in the Amazon?	communitybased conservation	2
5 Indigenous territories are largely being destroyed in what two ways?	deforestation and ecocide	1
6 The Peruvian Amazon indigienous people are one group struggling in the Amazon what is another group?	Urarina	1
7 There is growing interest in what indigenous group in the Amazon?	lowland South American	2
1 The use of remote sensing for the conservation of the Amazon is also being used by the indigenous tribes of the basin to protect their tribal lands from commercial interests.
2 Using handheld GPS devices and programs like Google Earth members of the Trio Tribe who live in the rainforests of southern Suriname map out their ancestral lands to help strengthen their territorial claims.
3 Currently most tribes in the Amazon do not have clearly defined boundaries making it easier for commercial ventures to target their territories.

1 To accurately map the Amazons biomass and subsequent carbon related emissions the classification of tree growth stages within different parts of the forest is crucial.
2 In 2006 Tatiana Kuplich organized the trees of the Amazon into four categories 1 mature forest 2 regenerating forest less than three years 3 regenerating forest between three and five years of regrowth and 4 regenerating forest eleven to eighteen years of continued development.
3 The researcher used a combination of Synthetic aperture radar SAR and Thematic Mapper TM to accurately place the different portions of the Amazon into one of the four classifications.
4 Classifying the stages of what is important to mapping aspects of the Amazon?	tree growth	1
5 The classification of aspects of the Amazon forest is important for mapping what type of emission?	carbon related emissions	1
6 Who organized the trees of the Amazon into four categories?	Tatiana Kuplich	2
7 In what year did one individual suggest classifying the trees of the Amazon into four categories?	2006	2
8 What type of radar was used to classify trees into four categories?	Synthetic aperture radar SAR	3
1 In 2005 parts of the Amazon basin experienced the worst drought in one hundred years and there were indications that 2006 could have been a second successive year of drought.
2 A July 23 2006 article in the UK newspaper The Independent reported Woods Hole Research Center results showing that the forest in its present form could survive only three years of drought.
3 Scientists at the Brazilian National Institute of Amazonian Research argue in the article that this drought response coupled with the effects of deforestation on regional climate are pushing the rainforest towards a tipping point where it would irreversibly start to die.
4 It concludes that the forest is on the brink of being turned into savanna or desert with catastrophic consequences for the worlds climate.
5 In what year did the Amazon experience its worst drought of recent history?	2005	1
6 What organization argued that drought among other effects could cause the Amazon forest to reach a tipping point?	Brazilian National Institute of Amazonian Research	3
7 Along with drought what is one other factor that is pushing the Amazon rainforest towards a tipping point?	deforestation	3
8 What might the Amazon forest become if it passes the tipping point and starts to die?	savanna or desert	4
9 What organization predicted that the Amazon forest could survive only three years of drought?	Woods Hole Research Center	2
1 In 2010 the Amazon rainforest experienced another severe drought in some ways more extreme than the 2005 drought.
2 The affected region was approximate 1160000 square miles 3000000 km2 of rainforest compared to 734000 square miles 1900000 km2 in 2005.
3 The 2010 drought had three epicenters where vegetation died off whereas in 2005 the drought was focused on the southwestern part.
4 The findings were published in the journal Science.
5 In a typical year the Amazon absorbs 15 gigatons of carbon dioxide during 2005 instead 5 gigatons were released and in 2010 8 gigatons were released.
6 In what year did the Amazon experience a drought that may have been more extreme than in 2005?	2010	1
7 How many square miles large was the region impacted by the 2010 drought?	1 160 000	2
8 How many areas were impacted by the the death of vegetation in the 2010 drought?	three epicenters	3
9 The southern part of the Amazon forest was mainly impacted by drought in what year?	2005	3
10 How many tons of carbon are absorbed the Amazon in a typical year?	15 gigatons	5
1 Ctenophora tᵻˈnɒfərə singular ctenophore ˈtɛnəfɔːr or ˈtiːnəfɔːr from the Greek κτείς kteis comb and φέρω pherō carry commonly known as comb jellies is a phylum of animals that live in marine waters worldwide.
2 Their most distinctive feature is the ‘combs’ – groups of cilia which they use for swimming – they are the largest animals that swim by means of cilia.
3 Adults of various species range from a few millimeters to 15 m 4 ft 11 in in size.
4 Like cnidarians their bodies consist of a mass of jelly with one layer of cells on the outside and another lining the internal cavity.
5 In ctenophores these layers are two cells deep while those in cnidarians are only one cell deep.
6 Some authors combined ctenophores and cnidarians in one phylum Coelenterata as both groups rely on water flow through the body cavity for both digestion and respiration.
7 Increasing awareness of the differences persuaded more recent authors to classify them as separate phyla.
8 What are Ctenophora commonly known as?	comb jellies	1
9 Where do Ctenophora live?	marine waters worldwide	1
10 What size are adult Ctenophora?	a few millimeters to 15 m 4 ft 11 in in size	3
11 What is a ctenophora?	phylum of animals that live in marine waters	1
12 What does the ctenophora use to swim?	‘combs’ – groups of cilia	2
13 What does ctenophora use for digestion and respiration?	water flow through the body cavity	6
14 How large can ctenophora grow?	15 m 4 ft 11 in	3
15 What is the most distinctive feature of ctenophora?	‘combs’ – groups of cilia	2
16 What are ctenophora commonly known as?	comb jellies	1
17 How big can ctenophora grow?	15 m 4 ft 11 in	3
18 What does ctenophora rely on for digestion and respiration?	water flow through the body cavity	6
19 What does ctenophora mean in Greek?	κτείς kteis comb and φέρω pherō carry	1
20 Where do ctenophora live?	marine waters	1
1 Almost all ctenophores are predators taking prey ranging from microscopic larvae and rotifers to the adults of small crustaceans the exceptions are juveniles of two species which live as parasites on the salps on which adults of their species feed.
2 In favorable circumstances ctenophores can eat ten times their own weight in a day.
3 Only 100–150 species have been validated and possibly another 25 have not been fully described and named.
4 The textbook examples are cydippids with eggshaped bodies and a pair of retractable tentacles fringed with tentilla little tentacles that are covered with colloblasts sticky cells that capture prey.
5 The phylum has a wide range of body forms including the flattened deepsea platyctenids in which the adults of most species lack combs and the coastal beroids which lack tentacles and prey on other ctenophores by using huge mouths armed with groups of large stiffened cilia that act as teeth.
6 These variations enable different species to build huge populations in the same area because they specialize in different types of prey which they capture by as wide a range of methods as spiders use.
7 How much can Ctenophores eat in one day?	ten times their own weight	2
8 How many species of Ctenophores have been validated?	100–150	3
9 How many species of Ctenophores have not been fully described or named?	possibly another 25	3
10 How many species of Ctenophora have been validated?	100–150 species	3
11 What are the little tentacles that cydippids have called?	tentilla	4
12 How much food does a ctenophora eat in a day?	ten times their own weight	2
13 What do coastal beroids not have that other ctenophora have?	tentacles	5
14 What does coastal beriods use as teeth?	groups of large  stiffened cilia	5
15 How much do ctenophore eat in a day?	ten times their own weight	2
16 What are the small tentacles on Cydippids called?	tentilla	4
17 What do Beriods use as teeth?	groups of large  stiffened cilia	5
18 What do Cydippids use to capture their prey?	colloblasts	4
19 How many different species of ctenohore are there?	100–150 species	3
1 Most species are hermaphrodites—a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm meaning it can fertilize its own egg not needing a mate.
2 Some are simultaneous hermaphrodites which can produce both eggs and sperm at the same time.
3 Others are sequential hermaphrodites in which the eggs and sperm mature at different times.
4 Fertilization is generally external although platyctenids eggs are fertilized inside their parents bodies and kept there until they hatch.
5 The young are generally planktonic and in most species look like miniature cydippids gradually changing into their adult shapes as they grow.
6 The exceptions are the beroids whose young are miniature beroids with large mouths and no tentacles and the platyctenids whose young live as cydippidlike plankton until they reach nearadult size but then sink to the bottom and rapidly metamorphose into the adult form.
7 In at least some species juveniles are capable of reproduction before reaching the adult size and shape.
8 The combination of hermaphroditism and early reproduction enables small populations to grow at an explosive rate.
9 What gender are most species of Ctenophores?	Most species are hermaphrodites	1
10 What do young Ctenophores generaly look like?	miniature cydippids	5
11 Are juiveniles capable of reproduction?	In at least some species  juveniles are capable of reproduction before reaching the adult size	7
12 What is unique about  a hermaphrodite?	can produce both eggs and sperm  meaning it can fertilize its own egg	1
13 What can a simultaneous hermaphrodite do?	can produce both eggs and sperm at the same time	2
14 What type of hermaphrodite produces egg and sperm at different times?	sequential	3
15 Which species eggs are fertilized and kept inside the parents body until hatched?	platyctenids	4
16 What causes the population of ctenophora to grow at an explosive rate?	hermaphroditism and early reproduction	8
17 What is a hermaphrodite?	a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm	1
18 What is unique about  simultaneous hermaphrodites?	can produce both eggs and sperm at the same time	2
19 What is a trait of sequential hermaphrodites?	the eggs and sperm mature at different times	3
20 Which group keep the eggs are fertilized and kept inside the parents body until they hatch?	platyctenids	4
21 Which group has young that are born with no tentacles and a large mouth?	beroids	6
1 Ctenophores may be abundant during the summer months in some coastal locations but in other places they are uncommon and difficult to find.
2 In bays where they occur in very high numbers predation by ctenophores may control the populations of small zooplanktonic organisms such as copepods which might otherwise wipe out the phytoplankton planktonic plants which are a vital part of marine food chains.
3 One ctenophore Mnemiopsis has accidentally been introduced into the Black Sea where it is blamed for causing fish stocks to collapse by eating both fish larvae and organisms that would otherwise have fed the fish.
4 The situation was aggravated by other factors such as overfishing and longterm environmental changes that promoted the growth of the Mnemiopsis population.
5 The later accidental introduction of Beroe helped to mitigate the problem as Beroe preys on other ctenophores.
6 What sea were Ctenophores accidently introduced?	the Black Sea	3
7 What specific type of Ctenophore was introduced into the Black Sea?	Mnemiopsis	3
8 What promoted the growrth of Mnemiposis in the Black Sea?	overfishing and longterm environmental changes	4
9 What does the Beroe eat?	other ctenophores	5
10 What was introduces into the Black Sea?	Mnemiopsis	3
11 What does  mnemiopsis eat?	fish larvae and organisms	3
12 Where do ctenophores be found in large numbers?	In bays	2
13 Where can ctenophores be found in large amounts?	In bays	2
14 What are phytoplankton?	planktonic plants	2
15 What ctenophore was accidentally introduced into The Black Sea?	Mnemiopsis	3
16 What event was blamed on the introduction of mnemiopsis into The Black Sea?	causing fish stocks to collapse	3
17 What was done to counteract the overpopulation of mnemiopsis in The Black Sea?	introduction of Beroe	5
1 Despite their soft gelatinous bodies fossils thought to represent ctenophores apparently with no tentacles but many more combrows than modern forms have been found in lagerstätten as far back as the early Cambrian about 515 million years ago.
2 The position of the ctenophores in the evolutionary family tree of animals has long been debated and the majority view at present based on molecular phylogenetics is that cnidarians and bilaterians are more closely related to each other than either is to ctenophores.
3 A recent molecular phylogenetics analysis concluded that the common ancestor of all modern ctenophores was cydippidlike and that all the modern groups appeared relatively recently probably after the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 66 million years ago.
4 Evidence accumulating since the 1980s indicates that the cydippids are not monophyletic in other words do not include all and only the descendants of a single common ancestor because all the other traditional ctenophore groups are descendants of various cydippids.
5 When did the CretaceousPaleogene extinction happen?	66 million years ago	3
6 Evidence indicates that Cydippids are not what?	monophyletic	4
7 How old are the fossils found that represent ctenophhores ?	515 million years	1
8 What were the fossils that were found to represent ctenphores missing that current ctenphora have?	tentacles	1
9 Fossils found that were believed to be ctenophores were how old?	515 million years	1
10 What event happened 66 million years ago?	Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction	3
11 Cypiddids are not what?	monophyletic	4
12 What do current ctenophores have that fossils found did not have?	tentacles	1
1 Ctenophores form an animal phylum that is more complex than sponges about as complex as cnidarians jellyfish sea anemones etc.
2  and less complex than bilaterians which include almost all other animals.
3 Unlike sponges both ctenophores and cnidarians have cells bound by intercell connections and carpetlike basement membranes muscles nervous systems and some have sensory organs.
4 Ctenophores are distinguished from all other animals by having colloblasts which are sticky and adhere to prey although a few ctenophore species lack them.
5 Jellyfish ans sea anemones belong to what phylum?	cnidarians	1
6 What makes ctenophores different from all other animals?	by having colloblasts	4
7 Ctenophora are less complex than which other phylum?	bilaterians	2
8 Which phylum is more complex than sponges?	Ctenophores	1
9 What does ctenophore use to capture prey?	colloblasts	4
10 Jellyfish and sea anemones belong to which group	cnidarians 	1.
11 What do ctenophores have that no other animals have?	colloblasts	4
12 What do ctenophore use to capture their prey?	colloblasts	4
13 Which two groups have cells bound by intercell connections and membranes muscles a nervous system and sensory organs?	ctenophores and cnidarians	3
14 Ctenophores are less complex than what other group?	bilaterians	2
1 Like sponges and cnidarians ctenophores have two main layers of cells that sandwich a middle layer of jellylike material which is called the mesoglea in cnidarians and ctenophores more complex animals have three main cell layers and no intermediate jellylike layer.
2 Hence ctenophores and cnidarians have traditionally been labelled diploblastic along with sponges.
3 Both ctenophores and cnidarians have a type of muscle that in more complex animals arises from the middle cell layer and as a result some recent text books classify ctenophores as triploblastic while others still regard them as diploblastic.
4 What is the jellylike susbtance called?	mesoglea	1
5 Ctenophores and cnidarians are classified as what?	diploblastic	2
6 Which group has two layers of cells with a middle layer of mesoglea?	sponges and cnidarians  ctenophores	1
7 Ctenophores cnidarians and what other group are labelled diploblastic?	sponges	2
1 Ranging from about 1 millimeter 0039 in to 15 meters 49 ft in size ctenophores are the largest noncolonial animals that use cilia hairs as their main method of locomotion.
2 Most species have eight strips called comb rows that run the length of their bodies and bear comblike bands of cilia called ctenes stacked along the comb rows so that when the cilia beat those of each comb touch the comb below.
3 The name ctenophora means combbearing from the Greek κτείς stemform κτεν meaning comb and the Greek suffix φορος meaning carrying.
4 What are the hairs on ctenophores called?	cilia	1
5 What are cilia used for?	method of locomotion	1
6 Comb like bands of cilia are called what?	ctenes	2
7 What does ctenophore mean in Greek?	combbearing	3
1 For a phylum with relatively few species ctenophores have a wide range of body plans.
2 Coastal species need to be tough enough to withstand waves and swirling sediment particles while some oceanic species are so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study.
3 In addition oceanic species do not preserve well and are known mainly from photographs and from observers notes.
4 Hence most attention has until recently concentrated on three coastal genera – Pleurobrachia Beroe and Mnemiopsis.
5 At least two textbooks base their descriptions of ctenophores on the cydippid Pleurobrachia.
6 Which cidippid is used as a description on ctenophores in most textbooks?	Pleurobrachia	5
7 Which group of ctenophore are are hardest to study?	oceanic species	2
8 Why are coastal species tough?	to withstand waves and swirling sediment particles	2
9 Which ctenophora have been studies the most?	Pleurobrachia  Beroe and Mnemiopsis	4
1 The internal cavity forms a mouth that can usually be closed by muscles a pharynx throat a wider area in the center that acts as a stomach and a system of internal canals.
2 These branch through the mesoglea to the most active parts of the animal the mouth and pharynx the roots of the tentacles if present all along the underside of each comb row and four branches round the sensory complex at the far end from the mouth – two of these four branches terminate in anal pores.
3 The inner surface of the cavity is lined with an epithelium the gastrodermis.
4 The mouth and pharynx have both cilia and welldeveloped muscles.
5 In other parts of the canal system the gastrodermis is different on the sides nearest to and furthest from the organ that it supplies.
6 The nearer side is composed of tall nutritive cells that store nutrients in vacuoles internal compartments germ cells that produce eggs or sperm and photocytes that produce bioluminescence.
7 The side furthest from the organ is covered with ciliated cells that circulate water through the canals punctuated by ciliary rosettes pores that are surrounded by double whorls of cilia and connect to the mesoglea.
8 The inside of a ctenophore is lined with what?	epithelium	3
9 What do photocytes produce?	bioluminescence	6
10 What is the throat called?	pharynx	1
11 What does the internal cavity contain?	a mouth that can usually be closed by muscles a pharynx throat a wider area in the center that acts as a stomach and a system of internal canals	1
12 What are the most active parts of ctenophora?	the mouth and pharynx	2
1 The outer surface bears usually eight comb rows called swimmingplates which are used for swimming.
2 The rows are oriented to run from near the mouth the oral pole to the opposite end the aboral pole and are spaced more or less evenly around the body although spacing patterns vary by species and in most species the comb rows extend only part of the distance from the aboral pole towards the mouth.
3 The combs also called ctenes or comb plates run across each row and each consists of thousands of unusually long cilia up to 2 millimeters 0079 in.
4 Unlike conventional cilia and flagella which has a filament structure arranged in a 9  2 pattern these cilia are arranged in a 9  3 pattern where the extra compact filament is suspected to have a supporting function.
5 These normally beat so that the propulsion stroke is away from the mouth although they can also reverse direction.
6 Hence ctenophores usually swim in the direction in which the mouth is pointing unlike jellyfish.
7 When trying to escape predators one species can accelerate to six times its normal speed some other species reverse direction as part of their escape behavior by reversing the power stroke of the comb plate cilia.
8 What are the eight comb rows on the outer surface called?	swimmingplates	1
9 Combs are called what?	also called ctenes or comb plates	3
10 What does the 9 3 pattern of cilia thought to do?	supporting function	4
11 What direction do ctenophore swim?	in the direction in which the mouth is pointing 	6
12 Cilia can g ow up too what length?	2 millimeters 0079 in	3
1 It is uncertain how ctenophores control their buoyancy but experiments have shown that some species rely on osmotic pressure to adapt to water of different densities.
2 Their body fluids are normally as concentrated as seawater.
3 If they enter less dense brackish water the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and decrease its density to avoid sinking.
4 Conversely if they move from brackish to fullstrength seawater the rosettes may pump water out of the mesoglea to reduce its volume and increase its density.
5 How do ctenophores control buoyancy?	osmotic pressure	1
6 Ciliary rosettes pump water into what to control buoyancy?	the mesoglea	3
7 What does pumping water into the mesoglea do?	increase its bulk and decrease its density	3
8 What does the ciliary rosettes do to decease bulk and increase density?	pump water out of the mesoglea	4
1 The largest single sensory feature is the aboral organ at the opposite end from the mouth.
2 Its main component is a statocyst a balance sensor consisting of a statolith a solid particle supported on four bundles of cilia called balancers that sense its orientation.
3 The statocyst is protected by a transparent dome made of long immobile cilia.
4 A ctenophore does not automatically try to keep the statolith resting equally on all the balancers.
5 Instead its response is determined by the animals mood in other words the overall state of the nervous system.
6 For example if a ctenophore with trailing tentacles captures prey it will often put some comb rows into reverse spinning the mouth towards the prey.
7 What is the largest sensory feature of the ctenophora?	aboral organ	1
8 Where is the aboral organ located?	at the opposite end from the mouth	1
9 What protects the statocyst?	a transparent dome made of long  immobile cilia	3
10 What is the main component of the aboral organ?	a statocyst	2
11 What is a statocyst?	a balance sensor	2
1 Cydippid ctenophores have bodies that are more or less rounded sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or eggshaped the common coastal sea gooseberry Pleurobrachia sometimes has an eggshaped body with the mouth at the narrow end although some individuals are more uniformly round.
2 From opposite sides of the body extends a pair of long slender tentacles each housed in a sheath into which it can be withdrawn.
3 Some species of cydippids have bodies that are flattened to various extents so that they are wider in the plane of the tentacles.
4 What is the common coastal pleurobrachia called?	sea gooseberry	1
5 What does the pleurobrachia have on opposite sides of its body?	a pair of long  slender tentacles	2
6 Cydippid are typically what shape?	more or less rounded	1
7 The long tentacles on the pleurbrachia are protected by what?	a sheath	2
8 Where is the mouth located on the pleuobrachia located?	at the narrow end	1
1 The tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are typically fringed with tentilla little tentacles although a few genera have simple tentacles without these sidebranches.
2 The tentacles and tentilla are densely covered with microscopic colloblasts that capture prey by sticking to it.
3 Colloblasts are specialized mushroomshaped cells in the outer layer of the epidermis and have three main components a domed head with vesicles chambers that contain adhesive a stalk that anchors the cell in the lower layer of the epidermis or in the mesoglea and a spiral thread that coils round the stalk and is attached to the head and to the root of the stalk.
4 The function of the spiral thread is uncertain but it may absorb stress when prey tries to escape and thus prevent the collobast from being torn apart.
5 In addition to colloblasts members of the genus Haeckelia which feed mainly on jellyfish incorporate their victims stinging nematocytes into their own tentacles – some cnidariaeating nudibranchs similarly incorporate nematocytes into their bodies for defense.
6 The tentilla of Euplokamis differ significantly from those of other cydippids they contain striated muscle a cell type otherwise unknown in the phylum Ctenophora and they are coiled when relaxed while the tentilla of all other known ctenophores elongate when relaxed.
7 Euplokamis tentilla have three types of movement that are used in capturing prey they may flick out very quickly in 40 to 60 milliseconds they can wriggle which may lure prey by behaving like small planktonic worms and they coil round prey.
8 The unique flicking is an uncoiling movement powered by contraction of the striated muscle.
9 The wriggling motion is produced by smooth muscles but of a highly specialized type.
10 Coiling around prey is accomplished largely by the return of the tentilla to their inactive state but the coils may be tightened by smooth muscle.
11 What are the tentacles of cydipped ctenophores are usually fringed with?	tentilla	1
12 What are colloblasts?	specialized mushroomshaped cells in the outer layer of the epidermis	3
13 What makes the tentilla of euplokamis different from other cysippids?	they contain striated muscle 	6
14 How many types of movements do euplokamis tentilla have?	three types of movement	7
15 What does the euplokamis use the three types of movement for?	capturing prey	7
1 There are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end and are spaced evenly round the body.
2 The combs beat in a metachronal rhythm rather like that of a Mexican wave.
3 From each balancer in the statocyst a ciliary groove runs out under the dome and then splits to connect with two adjacent comb rows and in some species runs all the way along the comb rows.
4 This forms a mechanical system for transmitting the beat rhythm from the combs to the balancers via water disturbances created by the cilia.
5 How many rows of combs are there?	eight rows	1
6 Where are the rows of combs located?	from near the mouth to the opposite end	1
7 How are the combs spaced?	evenly round the body	1
8 What runs from the balancer in the statocyst to the comb rows?	ciliary groove	3
1 The Lobata have a pair of lobes which are muscular cuplike extensions of the body that project beyond the mouth.
2 Their inconspicuous tentacles originate from the corners of the mouth running in convoluted grooves and spreading out over the inner surface of the lobes rather than trailing far behind as in the Cydippida.
3 Between the lobes on either side of the mouth many species of lobates have four auricles gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth.
4 This combination of structures enables lobates to feed continuously on suspended planktonic prey.
5 What does the lobata have pair of?	lobes	1
6 What are auricles?	gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents	3
7 How many auricles do most species have?	four	3
8 What do the auricles do?	help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth	3
9 What do lobates feed on?	suspended planktonic prey	4
1 Lobates have eight combrows originating at the aboral pole and usually not extending beyond the body to the lobes in species with four auricles the cilia edging the auricles are extensions of cilia in four of the comb rows.
2 Most lobates are quite passive when moving through the water using the cilia on their comb rows for propulsion although Leucothea has long and active auricles whose movements also contribute to propulsion.
3 Members of the lobate genera Bathocyroe and Ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes so that the jet of expelled water drives them backwards very quickly.
4 Unlike cydippids the movements of lobates combs are coordinated by nerves rather than by water disturbances created by the cilia yet combs on the same row beat in the same Mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids.
5 This may have enabled lobates to grow larger than cydippids and to have shapes that are less egglike.
6 What does the bathocyroe and ocyropsis do to escape danger?	by clapping their lobes	3
7 What happens when bathocyroe and ocyropsis clap their lobes together?	jet of expelled water drives them backwards very quickly	3
8 The movements of the lobates combs are controlled by what?	nerves	4
9 Cydippids combs are controlled by what?	water disturbances created by the cilia	4
1 The Beroida also known as Nuda have no feeding appendages but their large pharynx just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body bears macrocilia at the oral end.
2 These fused bundles of several thousand large cilia are able to bite off pieces of prey that are too large to swallow whole – almost always other ctenophores.
3 In front of the field of macrocilia on the mouth lips in some species of Beroe is a pair of narrow strips of adhesive epithelial cells on the stomach wall that zip the mouth shut when the animal is not feeding by forming intercellular connections with the opposite adhesive strip.
4 This tight closure streamlines the front of the animal when it is pursuing prey.
5 Beroida are known by what other name?	Nuda	1
6 What group has no feeding appendages?	The Beroida	1
7 Some species of beroe have a pair of strips of adhesive cells on the stomach wall What does it do?	zip the mouth shut when the animal is not feeding 	3
8 What does the beroe do when pursuing prey?	zip the mouth shut	3
9 What does the beroida have instead of feeding appendages?	large pharynx	1
1 The Cestida belt animals are ribbonshaped planktonic animals with the mouth and aboral organ aligned in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon.
2 There is a pair of combrows along each aboral edge and tentilla emerging from a groove all along the oral edge which stream back across most of the winglike body surface.
3 Cestids can swim by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their combrows.
4 There are two known species with worldwide distribution in warm and warmtemperate waters Cestum veneris Venus girdle is among the largest ctenophores – up to 15 meters 49 ft long and can undulate slowly or quite rapidly.
5 Velamen parallelum which is typically less than 20 centimeters 066 ft long can move much faster in what has been described as a darting motion.
6 Which species are ribbonshaped planktonic animals?	The Cestida	1
7 What is the largest ctenophore?	Cestum veneris	4
8 What are cestida called?	belt animals	1
9 How do cestids swim?	by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their combrows	3
10 Which species moves by a darting motion?	Velamen parallelum	5
1 Most Platyctenida have oval bodies that are flattened in the oralaboral direction with a pair of tentillabearing tentacles on the aboral surface.
2 They cling to and creep on surfaces by everting the pharynx and using it as a muscular foot.
3 All but one of the known platyctenid species lack combrows.
4 Platyctenids are usually cryptically colored live on rocks algae or the body surfaces of other invertebrates and are often revealed by their long tentacles with many sidebranches seen streaming off the back of the ctenophore into the current.
5 What do most platyctenida have on their aboral surface?	a pair of tentillabearing tentacles	1
6 What do platyctenida use their pharynx for?	cling to and creep on surfaces	2
7 What do all but one platycenida species lack?	combrows	3
8 Where do platycenida live?	on rocks  algae  or the body surfaces of other invertebrates	4
1 Almost all species are hermaphrodites in other words they function as both males and females at the same time – except that in two species of the genus Ocryopsis individuals remain of the same single sex all their lives.
2 The gonads are located in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows and eggs and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis.
3 Fertilization is external in most species but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch.
4 Selffertilization has occasionally been seen in species of the genus Mnemiopsis and it is thought that most of the hermaphroditic species are selffertile.
5 How are eggs and sperm released?	via pores in the epidermis	2
6 How do platyctenids reproduce?	internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch	3
7 What genus has selffertilization been seen?	Mnemiopsis	4
8 Where are the gonads located?	in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows	2
9 Is fertilization  internal or exeternal in most species?	external	3
1 Development of the fertilized eggs is direct in other words there is no distinctive larval form and juveniles of all groups generally resemble miniature cydippid adults.
2 In the genus Beroe the juveniles like the adults lack tentacles and tentacle sheaths.
3 In most species the juveniles gradually develop the body forms of their parents.
4 In some groups such as the flat bottomdwelling platyctenids the juveniles behave more like true larvae as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis after dropping to the seafloor.
5 Juvenile and adult  beroe lack what?	tentacles and tentacle sheaths	2
6 Where do juvenile platyctenids live?	among the plankton	4
7 When do juvenile develop into adults?	after dropping to the seafloor	4
8 Juvenile platyctenids act like what?	more like true larvae	4
9 Which genus lack tentacles and sheaths?	Beroe	2
1 When some species including Bathyctena chuni Euplokamis stationis and Eurhamphaea vexilligera are disturbed they produce secretions ink that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies.
2 Juveniles will luminesce more brightly in relation to their body size than adults whose luminescence is diffused over their bodies.
3 Detailed statistical investigation has not suggested the function of ctenophores bioluminescence nor produced any correlation between its exact color and any aspect of the animals environments such as depth or whether they live in coastal or midocean waters.
4 What do bathyctena chuni euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera have in common?	they produce secretions ink that luminesce	1
5 When do bathyctena chuni euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera  excrete secretions?	are disturbed 	1
6 What are the secretions commonly called?	ink	1
7 Do adults or juveniles secretions luminesce brighter?	Juveniles will luminesce more brightly	2
1 Almost all ctenophores are predators – there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic.
2 If food is plentiful they can eat 10 times their own weight per day.
3 While Beroe preys mainly on other ctenophores other surfacewater species prey on zooplankton planktonic animals ranging in size from the microscopic including mollusc and fish larvae to small adult crustaceans such as copepods amphipods and even krill.
4 Members of the genus Haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their preys nematocysts stinging cells into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts.
5 Ctenophores have been compared to spiders in their wide range of techniques from capturing prey – some hang motionless in the water using their tentacles as webs some are ambush predators like Salticid jumping spiders and some dangle a sticky droplet at the end of a fine thread as bolas spiders do.
6 This variety explains the wide range of body forms in a phylum with rather few species.
7 The twotentacled cydippid Lampea feeds exclusively on salps close relatives of seasquirts that form large chainlike floating colonies and juveniles of Lampea attach themselves like parasites to salps that are too large for them to swallow.
8 Members of the cydippid genus Pleurobrachia and the lobate Bolinopsis often reach high population densities at the same place and time because they specialize in different types of prey Pleurobrachias long tentacles mainly capture relatively strong swimmers such as adult copepods while Bolinopsis generally feeds on smaller weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae.
9 Are ctenophores predators vegetarian or parasitic?	Almost all ctenophores are predators	1
10 Haeckelia prey mostly on what animal?	jellyfish	4
11 What happens to the jellyfish nematocysts when they are eaten by the haeckelia?	incorporate their preys nematocysts stinging cells into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts	4
12 What does the bolinopsis generally eat?	smaller  weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae	8
13 What is the name of the twotentacled cydippid that feedsentirely on salps called?	Lampea	7
1 Ctenophores used to be regarded as dead ends in marine food chains because it was thought their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water made them a poor diet for other animals.
2 It is also often difficult to identify the remains of ctenophores in the guts of possible predators although the combs sometimes remain intact long enough to provide a clue.
3 Detailed investigation of chum salmon Oncorhynchus keta showed that these fish digest ctenophores 20 times as fast as an equal weight of shrimps and that ctenophores can provide a good diet if there are enough of them around.
4 Beroids prey mainly on other ctenophores.
5 Some jellyfish and turtles eat large quantities of ctenophores and jellyfish may temporarily wipe out ctenophore populations.
6 Since ctenophores and jellyfish often have large seasonal variations in population most fish that prey on them are generalists and may have a greater effect on populations than the specialist jellyeaters.
7 This is underlined by an observation of herbivorous fishes deliberately feeding on gelatinous zooplankton during blooms in the Red Sea.
8 The larvae of some sea anemones are parasites on ctenophores as are the larvae of some flatworms that parasitize fish when they reach adulthood.
9 Why was it thought that  ctenophores were a poor diet for other animals?	their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water	1
10 What is the oncorhynchus also called?	chum salmon	3
11 What do beroids typically eat?	ctenophores	4
12 Where have herbivorous fishes been seen feeding on gelatinous zooplankton?	the Red Sea	7
13 Turtles and jellyfish can eat large quantities of what?	ctenophores 	5
1 On the other hand in the late 1980s the Western Atlantic ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the Black Sea and Sea of Azov via the ballast tanks of ships and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that would otherwise feed the adult fish.
2 Mnemiopsis is well equipped to invade new territories although this was not predicted until after it so successfully colonized the Black Sea as it can breed very rapidly and tolerate a wide range of water temperatures and salinities.
3 The impact was increased by chronic overfishing and by eutrophication that gave the entire ecosystem a shortterm boost causing the Mnemiopsis population to increase even faster than normal – and above all by the absence of efficient predators on these introduced ctenophores.
4 Mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the Mnemiopsiseating North American ctenophore Beroe ovata and by a cooling of the local climate from 1991 to 1993 which significantly slowed the animals metabolism.
5 However the abundance of plankton in the area seems unlikely to be restored to preMnemiopsis levels.
6 What is blamed for causing the sharp drop in fish catches in the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov?	ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi	1
7 How was the ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi introduced into The Black Sea and the Sea of Azov?	via the ballast tanks of ships	1
8 How was the population of mnemiopsis in The black Sea and the Sea of Azov brought under control?	by the accidental introduction of the Mnemiopsiseating North American ctenophore Beroe ovata 	4
9 When was ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi introduced into The Black Sea and the Sea of Azov?	in the late 1980s	1
10 How does cooling of the local environment affect the mnemiopsis?	significantly slowed the animals metabolism	4
1 Because of their soft gelatinous bodies ctenophores are extremely rare as fossils and fossils that have been interpreted as ctenophores have been found only in lagerstätten places where the environment was exceptionally suited to preservation of soft tissue.
2 Until the mid1990s only two specimens good enough for analysis were known both members of the crown group from the early Devonian Emsian period.
3 Three additional putative species were then found in the Burgess Shale and other Canadian rocks of similar age about 505 million years ago in the midCambrian period.
4 All three apparently lacked tentacles but had between 24 and 80 comb rows far more than the 8 typical of living species.
5 They also appear to have had internal organlike structures unlike anything found in living ctenophores.
6 One of the fossil species first reported in 1996 had a large mouth apparently surrounded by a folded edge that may have been muscular.
7 Evidence from China a year later suggests that such ctenophores were widespread in the Cambrian but perhaps very different from modern species – for example one fossils combrows were mounted on prominent vanes.
8 The Ediacaran Eoandromeda could putatively represent a comb jelly.
9 Why are ctenophores extremely rare as fossils?	Because of their soft  gelatinous bodies	1
10 Ediacaran eoandromeda can be regarded to represent what?	comb jelly	8
11 What was the period called that was 505 million years ago?	Cambrian period	3
12 How many species were found in the Burgess Shale?	Three additional putative species	3
13 What did the  fossils found in the Burgess Shale lack?	lacked tentacles	4
1 The early Cambrian sessile frondlike fossil Stromatoveris from Chinas Chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago is very similar to Vendobionta of the preceding Ediacaran period.
2 DeGan Shu Simon Conway Morris et al.
3 found on its branches what they considered rows of cilia used for filter feeding.
4 They suggested that Stromatoveris was an evolutionary aunt of ctenophores and that ctenophores originated from sessile animals whose descendants became swimmers and changed the cilia from a feeding mechanism to a propulsion system.
5 How old were the fossils found in China?	515 million years	1
6 What type of fossils were found in China?	Cambrian sessile frondlike fossil Stromatoveris	1
7 Which genus is considered the aunt of ctenophores?	Stromatoveris	4
8 Stromatoveris is similair to which genus?	Vendobionta	1
9 Vendobionta lived during which period?	Ediacaran period	1
1 The relationship of ctenophores to the rest of Metazoa is very important to our understanding of the early evolution of animals and the origin of multicellularity.
2 It has been the focus of debate for many years.
3 Ctenophores have been purported to be the sister lineage to the Bilateria sister to the Cnidaria sister to Cnidaria Placozoa and Bilateria and sister to all other animal phyla.
4 A series of studies that looked at the presence and absence of members of gene families and signalling pathways eg homeoboxes nuclear receptors the Wnt signaling pathway and sodium channels showed evidence congruent with the latter two scenarios that ctenophores are either sister to Cnidaria Placozoa and Bilateria or sister to all other animal phyla.
5 Several more recent studies comparing complete sequenced genomes of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as the sister lineage to all other animals.
6 This position would suggest that neural and muscle cell types were either lost in major animal lineages eg Porifera or that they evolved independently in the ctenophore lineage.
7 However other researchers have argued that the placement of Ctenophora as sister to all other animals is a statistical anomaly caused by the high rate of evolution in ctenophore genomes and that Porifera sponges is the earliestdiverging animal phylum instead.
8 Ctenophores and sponges are also the only known animal phyla that lack any true hox genes.
9 Recent studies believe  that ctenophores are the sister lineage to what?	all other animals	5
10 What do some researchers believe is the earliestdiverging animal phylum is?	Porifera	7
1 Since all modern ctenophores except the beroids have cydippidlike larvae it has widely been assumed that their last common ancestor also resembled cydippids having an eggshaped body and a pair of retractable tentacles.
2 Richard Harbisons purely morphological analysis in 1985 concluded that the cydippids are not monophyletic in other words do not contain all and only the descendants of a single common ancestor that was itself a cydippid.
3 Instead he found that various cydippid families were more similar to members of other ctenophore orders than to other cydippids.
4 He also suggested that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was either cydippidlike or beroidlike.
5 A molecular phylogeny analysis in 2001 using 26 species including 4 recently discovered ones confirmed that the cydippids are not monophyletic and concluded that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippidlike.
6 It also found that the genetic differences between these species were very small – so small that the relationships between the Lobata Cestida and Thalassocalycida remained uncertain.
7 This suggests that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was relatively recent and perhaps was lucky enough to survive the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 655 million years ago while other lineages perished.
8 When the analysis was broadened to include representatives of other phyla it concluded that cnidarians are probably more closely related to bilaterians than either group is to ctenophores but that this diagnosis is uncertain.
9 Which genus of ctenophores does not have cydippedlike larvae?	beroids	1
10 A molecular phylogeny analysis confirmed that cydippid are not what?	monophyletic	5
11 When was the CretaceousPaleogen extinction occur?	655 million years ago	7
12 Who did a morphologically analysis in 1985 that concluded cydippids are not monophyletic?	Richard Harbison	2
1 Fresno ˈfrɛznoʊ FREZnoh the county seat of Fresno County is a city in the US state of California.
2 As of 2015 the citys population was 520159 making it the fifthlargest city in California the largest inland city in California and the 34thlargest in the nation.
3 Fresno is in the center of the San Joaquin Valley and is the largest city in the Central Valley which contains the San Joaquin Valley.
4 It is approximately 220 miles 350 km northwest of Los Angeles 170 miles 270 km south of the state capital Sacramento or 185 miles 300 km south of San Francisco.
5 The name Fresno means ash tree in Spanish and an ash leaf is featured on the citys flag.
6 Which city is the fifthlargest city in California?	Fresno	1
7 How far is Fresno from Los Angeles?	220 miles 350 km	4
8 What does the name Fresno mean in Spanish?	ash tree	5
9 What is featured on the city of Fresnos city flag?	ash leaf	5
10 How do you pronounce Fresno?	ˈfrɛznoʊ FREZnoh	1
1 In 1872 the Central Pacific Railroad established a station near Easterbys—by now a hugely productive wheat farm—for its new Southern Pacific line.
2 Soon there was a store around the station and the store grew the town of Fresno Station later called Fresno.
3 Many Millerton residents drawn by the convenience of the railroad and worried about flooding moved to the new community.
4 Fresno became an incorporated city in 1885.
5 By 1931 the Fresno Traction Company operated 47 streetcars over 49 miles of track.
6 The Central Pacific Railroad established a station for its new line in what year?	1872	1
7 What were the reasons why residents moved to the town of Fresno Station?	the convenience of the railroad and worried about flooding	3
8 In what year did Fresno become an incorporated city?	1885	4
9 How many streetcars did the Fresno Traction Company operate in 1931?	47 streetcars	5
10 What entity sparked the growth of Fresno Station?	store	2
1 Before World War II Fresno had many ethnic neighborhoods including Little Armenia German Town Little Italy and Chinatown.
2 In 1940 the Census Bureau reported Fresnos population as 940 white 33 black and 27 Asian.
3 Incongruously Chinatown was primarily a Japanese neighborhood and today JapaneseAmerican businesses still remain.
4 During 1942 Pinedale in what is now North Fresno was the site of the Pinedale Assembly Center an interim facility for the relocation of Fresno area Japanese Americans to internment camps.
5 The Fresno Fairgrounds was also utilized as an assembly center.
6 In 1940 what percentage of the population in Fresno was Asian?	27	2
7 What ethnic neighborhood in Fresno had primarily Japanese residents in 1940?	Chinatown	3
8 In 1942 what was North Fresno previously called?	Pinedale	4
9 What was the Pinedale Assembly Center?	an interim facility for the relocation of Fresno area Japanese Americans to internment camps	4
10 What was the Fresno Fairgrounds used as?	an assembly center	5
1 In September 1958 Bank of America launched a new product called BankAmericard in Fresno.
2 After a troubled gestation during which its creator resigned BankAmericard went on to become the first successful credit card that is a financial instrument that was usable across a large number of merchants and also allowed cardholders to revolve a balance earlier financial products could do one or the other but not both.
3 In 1976 BankAmericard was renamed and spun off into a separate company known today as Visa Inc.
4 What new product did Bank of America introduce in 1958?	BankAmericard	1
5 What was the name of the first successful credit card?	BankAmericard	1
6 What did the BankAmericard allow customers do to that they couldnt do with previous financial instruments?	to revolve a balance	2
7 In what year did BankAmericard change its name?	1976	3
8 What presentday company did BankAmericard turn into?	Visa Inc	3
1 In the 1970s the city was the subject of a song Walking Into Fresno written by Hall Of Fame guitarist Bill Aken and recorded by Bob Gallion of the worldfamous WWVA Jamboree radio and television show in Wheeling West Virginia.
2 Aken adopted by Mexican movie actress Lupe Mayorga grew up in the neighboring town of Madera and his song chronicled the hardships faced by the migrant farm workers he saw as a child.
3 Aken also made his first TV appearance playing guitar on the old countrywestern show at The Fresno Barn.
4 Who wrote Walking in Fresno?	Bill Aken	1
5 Who recorded Walking in Fresno?	Bob Gallion	1
6 In what town did Bill Aiken grow up?	Madera	2
7 On what show did Bill Aiken make is television debut?	The Fresno Barn	3
8 Who was Bill Aikens adopted mother?	Lupe Mayorga	2
1 Fresno has three large public parks two in the city limits and one in county land to the southwest.
2 Woodward Park which features the Shinzen Japanese Gardens numerous picnic areas and several miles of trails is in North Fresno and is adjacent to the San Joaquin River Parkway.
3 Roeding Park near Downtown Fresno is home to the Fresno Chaffee Zoo and Rotary Storyland and Playland.
4 Kearney Park is the largest of the Fresno regions park system and is home to historic Kearney Mansion and plays host to the annual Civil War Revisited the largest reenactment of the Civil War in the west coast of the US.
5 How many large public parks does Fresno have?	three	1
6 Which park is home to the Fresno Chafffee Zoo?	Roeding Park	3
7 Which park is home to the Kearney Mansion?	Kearney Park	4
8 Which is one of the park features located in North Fresno?	Shinzen Japanese Gardens	2
9 Which park hosts the largest Civil War reenactment on the west coast?	Kearney Park	4
1 Between the 1880s and World War II Downtown Fresno flourished filled with electric Street Cars and contained some of the San Joaquin Valleys most beautiful architectural buildings.
2 Among them the original Fresno County Courthouse demolished the Fresno Carnegie Public Library demolished the Fresno Water Tower the Bank of Italy Building the Pacific Southwest Building the San Joaquin Light  Power Building currently known as the Grand 1401 and the Hughes Hotel burned down to name a few.
3 During what period did downtown Fresno thrive?	Between the 1880s and World War II	1
4 What were two of Fresnos most beautiful architectural buildings that are now demolished?	Fresno County Courthouse demolished  the Fresno Carnegie Public Library	2
5 What former building is currently known as Grand 1401?	San Joaquin Light  Power Building	2
6 Which one of Fresnos hotels burned down?	Hughes Hotel	2
1 Fulton Street in Downtown Fresno was Fresnos main financial and commercial district before being converted into one of the nations first pedestrian malls in 1964.
2 Renamed the Fulton Mall the area contains the densest collection of historic buildings in Fresno.
3 While the Fulton Mall corridor has suffered a sharp decline from its heyday the Mall includes some of the finest public art pieces in the country including the only PierreAuguste Renoir piece in the world that one can walk up to and touch.
4 Current plans call for the reopening of the Fulton Mall to automobile traffic.
5 The public art pieces will be restored and placed near their current locations and will feature wide sidewalks up to 28 on the east side of the street to continue with the pedestrian friendly environment of the district.
6 In what year did Fresno get its first pedestrian mall?	1964	1
7 What was the pedestrian mall renamed?	Fulton Mall	2
8 Which artist has a piece of his artwork located at the Fulton Mall?	PierreAuguste Renoir	3
9 After reopening where will the art pieces be located after restoration?	near their current locations	5
10 What feature will enrich the the pedestrian friendly environment after restoration?	wide sidewalks	5
1 The neighborhood of Sunnyside is on Fresnos far southeast side bounded by Chestnut Avenue to the West.
2 Its major thoroughfares are Kings Canyon Avenue and Clovis Avenue.
3 Although parts of Sunnyside are within the City of Fresno much of the neighborhood is a county island within Fresno County.
4 Largely developed in the 1950s through the 1970s it has recently experienced a surge in new home construction.
5 It is also the home of the Sunnyside Country Club which maintains a golf course designed by William P Bell.
6 Where is the neighborhood of Sunnyside located in Fresno?	Fresnos far southeast side	1
7 What are the two major thoroughfares of Sunnyside?	Kings Canyon Avenue and Clovis Avenue	2
8 When was most of Sunnside developed?	1950s through the 1970s	4
9 Where is the home of the Sunnyside Country Club?	Sunnyside	5
10 Who designed the golf course located at the Sunnyside Country Club?	William P Bell	5
1 The popular neighborhood known as the Tower District is centered around the historic Tower Theatre which is included on the National List of Historic Places.
2 The theater was built in 1939 and is at Olive and Wishon Avenues in the heart of the Tower District.
3 The name of the theater refers to a wellknown landmark water tower which is actually in another nearby area.
4 The Tower District neighborhood is just north of downtown Fresno proper and onehalf mile south of Fresno City College.
5 Although the neighborhood was known as a residential area prior the early commercial establishments of the Tower District began with small shops and services that flocked to the area shortly after World War II.
6 The character of small local businesses largely remains today.
7 To some extent the businesses of the Tower District were developed due to the proximity of the original Fresno Normal School later renamed California State University at Fresno.
8 In 1916 the college moved to what is now the site of Fresno City College onehalf mile north of the Tower District.
9 The Tower District is centered around which historic theatre?	Tower Theatre	1
10 When was the Tower Theatre built?	1939	2
11 From what landmark within Fresno does the Tower Theatre get its name?	water tower	3
12 What was the original name of California State University at Fresno?	Fresno Normal School	7
13 How far is Fresno City College from the Tower District?	onehalf mile	8
1 This vibrant and culturally diverse area of retail businesses and residences experienced a renewal after a significant decline in the late 1960s and 1970s.
2 citation needed After decades of neglect and suburban flight the neighborhood revival followed the reopening of the Tower Theatre in the late 1970s which at that time showed second and third run movies along with classic films.
3 Roger Rockas Dinner Theater  Good Company Players also opened nearby in 1978citation needed at Olive and Wishon Avenues.
4 Fresno native Audra McDonald performed in the leading roles of Evita and The Wiz at the theater while she was a high school student.
5 McDonald subsequently became a leading performer on Broadway in New York City and a Tony award winning actress.
6 Also in the Tower District is Good Company Players 2nd Space Theatre.
7 During what period did the Tower Theatre reopen?	late 1970s	2
8 After its reopening which types of movies did the Tower Theatre show?	second and third run movies  along with classic films	2
9 In what year did Roger Rockas Dinner Theater  Good Company Players open?	1978	3
10 Where is Audra McDonald from?	Fresno	4
11 Which two leading roles did Audra McDonald perform when she was in high school?	Evita and The Wiz	4
1 The neighborhood features restaurants live theater and nightclubs as well as several independent shops and bookstores currently operating on or near Olive Avenue and all within a few hundred feet of each other.
2 Since renewal the Tower District has become an attractive area for restaurant and other local businesses.
3 Today the Tower District is also known as the center of Fresnos LGBT and hipster Communities.
4  Additionally Tower District is also known as the center of Fresnos local punkgothdeathrock and heavy metal community.

1 The area is also known for its early twentieth century homes many of which have been restored in recent decades.
2 The area includes many California Bungalow and American Craftsman style homes Spanish Colonial Revival Style architecture Mediterranean Revival Style architecture Mission Revival Style architecture and many Storybook houses designed by Fresno architects Hilliard Taylor  Wheeler.

1 Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract.
2 The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large stately homes.
3 The original development of this area began circa 1910 on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field.
4 The Alta Vista Tract as the land would become known was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation and was officially platted in 1911.
5 The tracts boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south Cedar Avenue on the east the rear property line of Platt Avenue east of Sixth Street and Platt Avenue west of Sixth Street on the north and First Street on the west.
6 The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912 in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community.
7 At the time of its admission to the City the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon.
8 In 1914 developers Billings  Meyering acquired the tract completed street development provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service and began marketing the property with fervor.
9 A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes.
10 This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company rightofway along Huntington Boulevard which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.
11 Which boulevard can you find many majestic homes in the area?	Huntington Boulevard	2
12 Who mapped the Alta Vista Tract?	William Stranahan	4
13 In what year did developers Billings  Meyering acquire the Alta Vista Tract?	1914	8
14 How many homes did the Alta Vista Tract have five years after Billings  Meyering acquired it?	267	9
15 Which company provided streetcar connections between downtown and the hospital?	Fresno Traction Company	10
1 The West Side of Fresno also often called Southwest Fresno is one of the oldest neighborhoods in the city.
2 The neighborhood lies southwest of the 99 freeway which divides it from Downtown Fresno west of the 41 freeway and south of Nielsen Ave or the newly constructed 180 Freeway and extends to the city limits to the west and south.
3 The neighborhood is traditionally considered to be the center of Fresnos AfricanAmerican community.
4 It is culturally diverse and also includes significant MexicanAmerican and AsianAmerican principally Hmong or Laotian populations.
5 What is another name for the west side of Fresno?	Southwest Fresno	1
6 In which direction does the west side of Fresno neighborhood lie to the 99 freeway?	southwest	2
7 The west side of Fresno is the center of which ethnic community?	AfricanAmerican	3
8 What are the two principal AsianAmerican groups living in the west side neighborhood of Fresno?	Hmong or Laotian	4
9 Which neighborhood lies west of the 41 freeway?	West Side	1
1 The neighborhood includes Kearney Boulevard named after early 20th century entrepreneur and millionaire M Theo Kearney which extends from Fresno Street in Southwest Fresno about 20 mi 32 km west to Kerman California.
2 A small twolane rural road for most of its length Kearney Boulevard is lined with tall palm trees.
3 The roughly halfmile stretch of Kearney Boulevard between Fresno Street and Thorne Ave was at one time the preferred neighborhood for Fresnos elite AfricanAmerican families.
4 Another section Brookhaven on the southern edge of the West Side south of Jensen and west of Elm was given the name by the Fresno City Council in an effort to revitalize the neighborhoods image.
5 The isolated subdivision was for years known as the Dogg Pound in reference to a local gang and as of late 2008 was still known for high levels of violent crime.
6 Who is Kearney Boulevard named after?	M Theo Kearney	1
7 What kinds of trees is Kearney Boulevard lined with?	tall palm trees	2
8 Between which two streets along Kearney Boulevard were wealthy AfricanAmericans at one time residing?	Fresno Street and Thorne Ave	3
9 What was the name given to a section of Kearney Boulevard in efforts to change the areas image?	Brookhaven	4
10 What area of Brookhaven is still known for its high levels of crime?	The isolated subdivision	5
1 While many homes in the neighborhood date back to the 1930s or before the neighborhood is also home to several public housing developments built between the 1960s and 1990s by the Fresno Housing Authority.
2 The US Department of Housing and Urban Development has also built small subdivisions of singlefamily homes in the area for purchase by lowincome working families.
3 There have been numerous attempts to revitalize the neighborhood including the construction of a modern shopping center on the corner of Fresno and B streets an aborted attempt to build luxury homes and a golf course on the western edge of the neighborhood and some new section 8 apartments have been built along Church Ave west of Elm St Cargill Meat Solutions and Foster Farms both have large processing facilities in the neighborhood and the stench from these and other small industrial facilities has long plagued area residents.
4 The Fresno Chandler Executive Airport is also on the West Side.
5 Due to its position on the edge of the city and years of neglect by developers is not a true innercity neighborhood and there are many vacant lots strawberry fields and vineyards throughout the neighborhood.
6 The neighborhood has very little retail activity aside from the area near Fresno Street and State Route 99 Freeway Kearney Palm Shopping Center built in the late 1990s and small corner markets scattered throughout.
7 When were the public housing developments built in the neighborhood?	between the 1960s and 1990s	1
8 On which corner is the shopping center located?	Fresno and B streets	3
9 What are the two processing facilities in the neighborhood?	Cargill Meat Solutions and Foster Farms	3
10 Where is the airport located?	the West Side	4
11 How much retail activity does the neighborhood have?	very little	6
1 In the north eastern part of Fresno Woodward Park was founded by the late Ralph Woodward a longtime Fresno resident.
2 He bequeathed a major portion of his estate in 1968 to provide a regional park and bird sanctuary in Northeast Fresno.
3 The park lies on the South bank of the San Joaquin River between Highway 41 and Friant Road.
4 The initial 235 acres 095 km2 combined with additional acres acquired later by the City brings the park to a sizable 300 acres 12 km2.
5 Now packed with amenities Woodward Park is the only Regional Park of its size in the Central Valley.
6 The Southeast corner of the park harbors numerous bird species offering bird enthusiasts an excellent opportunity for viewing.
7 The park has a multiuse amphitheatre that seats up to 2500 people authentic Japanese Garden fenced dog park twomile 3 km equestrian trail exercise par course three childrens playgrounds a lake 3 small ponds 7 picnic areas and five miles 8 km of multipurpose trails that are part of the San Joaquin River Parkways Lewis S Eaton Trail.
8 When complete the Lewis S Eaton trail system will cover 22 miles 35 km between Highway 99 and Friant Dam.
9 The parks numerous picnic tables make for a great picnic destination and a convenient escape from city life.
10 The parks amphetheatre was renovated in 2010 and has hosted performances by acts such as Deftones Tech N9ne and Sevendust as well as numerous others.
11 The park is open April through October 6am to 10pm and November through March 6am to 7pm.
12 Woodward Park is home to the annual CIFCalifornia Interscholastic Federation State Championship cross country meet which takes place in late November.
13 It is also the home of the Woodward Shakespeare Festival which began performances in the park in 2005.
14 Who founded Woodward Park?	Ralph Woodward	1
15 How many total acres is Woodward Park?	300 acres	4
16 How many seats does the amphitheatre at Woodward park have?	2 500	7
17 How many miles once completed will the the Lewis S Eaton trail cover?	22 miles	8
18 What months out of the year is Woodward Park open?	April through October	11
1 Formed in 1946 Sierra Sky Park Airport is a residential airport community born of a unique agreement in transportation law to allow personal aircraft and automobiles to share certain roads.
2 Sierra Sky Park was the first aviation community to be builtcitation needed and there are now numerous such communities across the United States and around the world.
3 Developer William Smilie created the nations first planned aviation community.
4 Still in operation today the public use airport provides a unique neighborhood that spawned interest and similar communities nationwide.
5 When was the Sierra Sky Park Airport formed?	1946	1
6 Who created the nations first aviation community?	William Smilie	3
7 What is the name of the first aviation community built?	Sierra Sky Park	2
8 The transportation law allows personal aircraft to share the roadways with what?	automobiles	1
9 Are there any other aviation communities such as Sierra Sky Park in the United States?	there are now numerous such communities across the United States	2
1 Fresno is marked by a semiarid climate Köppen BSh with mild moist winters and hot and dry summers thus displaying Mediterranean characteristics.
2 December and January are the coldest months and average around 465 °F 81 °C and there are 14 nights with freezing lows annually with the coldest night of the year typically bottoming out below 30 °F −11 °C.
3 July is the warmest month averaging 830 °F 283 °C normally there are 32 days of 100 °F 378 °C highs and 106 days of 90 °F 322 °C highs and in July and August there are only three or four days where the high does not reach 90 °F 322 °C.
4 Summers provide considerable sunshine with July peaking at 97 percent of the total possible sunlight hours conversely January is the lowest with only 46 percent of the daylight time in sunlight because of thick tule fog.
5 However the year averages 81 of possible sunshine for a total of 3550 hours.
6 Average annual precipitation is around 115 inches 2921 mm which by definition would classify the area as a semidesert.
7 Most of the wind rose direction occurrences derive from the northwest as winds are driven downward along the axis of the California Central Valley in December January and February there is an increased presence of southeastern wind directions in the wind rose statistics.
8 Fresno meteorology was selected in a national US Environmental Protection Agency study for analysis of equilibrium temperature for use of tenyear meteorological data to represent a warm dry western United States locale.
9 How would one describe the summers in Fresno?	hot and dry	1
10 What month is the warmest in Fresno?	July	3
11 How much rain per year does Fresno get on average?	around 115 inches	6
12 In which direction does most of the wind in Fresno originate from?	northwest	7
13 In which months does Fresno experience increased wind coming from the southeastern direction?	December  January and February	7
1 The official record high temperature for Fresno is 115 °F 461 °C set on July 8 1905 while the official record low is 17 °F −8 °C set on January 6 1913.
2 The average windows for 100 °F 378 °C 90 °F 322 °C and freezing temperatures are June 1 thru September 13 April 26 thru October 9 and December 10 thru January 28 respectively and no freeze occurred between in the 19831984 season.
3 Annual rainfall has ranged from 2357 inches 5987 mm in the “rain year” from July 1982 to June 1983 down to 443 inches 1125 mm from July 1933 to June 1934.
4 The most rainfall in one month was 954 inches 2423 mm in November 1885 and the most rainfall in 24 hours 355 inches 902 mm on November 18 1885.
5 Measurable precipitation falls on an average of 48 days annually.
6 Snow is a rarity the heaviest snowfall at the airport was 22 inches 006 m on January 21 1962.
7 What is the hottest temperature record for Fresno?	115 °F	1
8 On what date was the record low temperature in Fresno?	January 6  1913	1
9 In what year did Fresno experience the most rainfall?	1885	4
10 What is the most snow Fresno has ever had?	22 inches	6
11 What is the most rainfall recorded in a 24 hour period in Fresno?	355 inches	4
