1 To avoid interference with existing VHF television stations in the San Francisco Bay Area and those planned for Chico Sacramento Salinas and Stockton the Federal Communications Commission decided that Fresno would only have UHF television stations.
2 The very first Fresno television station to begin broadcasting was KMJTV which debuted on June 1 1953.
3 KMJ is now known as NBC affiliate KSEE.
4 Other Fresno stations include ABC OO KFSN CBS affiliate KGPE CW affiliate KFRE FOX affiliate KMPH MNTV affiliate KAIL PBS affiliate KVPT Telemundo OO KNSO Univision OO KFTV and MundoFox and Azteca affiliate KGMCDT.
5 Why does Fresno only have UHF television stations?	To avoid interference with existing VHF television stations	1
6 What was the very first television station to broadcast in Fresno?	KMJTV	2
7 When did the KMJTV first broadcast?	June 1  1953	2
8 What is KMJ now referred to?	NBC affiliate KSEE	3
9 What is the name of the CBS affiliate in Fresno?	KGPE	4
1 Fresno is served by State Route 99 the main northsouth freeway that connects the major population centers of the California Central Valley.
2 State Route 168 the Sierra Freeway heads east to the city of Clovis and Huntington Lake.
3 State Route 41 Yosemite FreewayEisenhower Freeway comes into Fresno from Atascadero in the south and then heads north to Yosemite.
4 State Route 180 Kings Canyon Freeway comes from the west via Mendota and from the east in Kings Canyon National Park going towards the city of Reedley.
5 What route connects Fresno with the California Central Valley?	State Route 99	1
6 What is another name for State Route 168?	the Sierra Freeway	2
7 What is another name for the Yosemite Freeway?	State Route 41	3
8 State Route 180 comes from which direction via Mendota?	west	4
1 Fresno is the largest US city not directly linked to an Interstate highway.
2 When the Interstate Highway System was created in the 1950s the decision was made to build what is now Interstate 5 on the west side of the Central Valley and thus bypass many of the population centers in the region instead of upgrading what is now State Route 99.
3 Due to rapidly raising population and traffic in cities along SR 99 as well as the desirability of Federal funding much discussion has been made to upgrade it to interstate standards and eventually incorporate it into the interstate system most likely as Interstate 9.
4 Major improvements to signage lane width median separation vertical clearance and other concerns are currently underway.
5 Which is the largest city not connected to an interstate highway?	Fresno	1
6 In what year was the Interstate Highway System created?	1950s	2
7 Which State Route has been in discussion to upgrade to interstate standards?	99	3
8 What are the factors that are contributing to the desire to have SR 99 improved to be of interstate standards?	rapidly raising population and traffic in cities along SR 99	3
1 Passenger rail service is provided by Amtrak San Joaquins.
2 The main passenger rail station is the recently renovated historic Santa Fe Railroad Depot in Downtown Fresno.
3 The BakersfieldStockton mainlines of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway and Union Pacific Railroad railroads cross in Fresno and both railroads maintain railyards within the city the San Joaquin Valley Railroad also operates former Southern Pacific branchlines heading west and south out of the city.
4 The city of Fresno is planned to serve the future California High Speed Rail.
5 Which company provides train service in Fresno?	Amtrak San Joaquins	1
6 Where is the Santa Fe Railroad Depot located?	Downtown Fresno	2
7 What two railroads have railyards in the city of Fresno?	Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway and Union Pacific Railroad	3
8 If you were to take a train west or south out of the city of Fresno which railroad would you take?	San Joaquin Valley Railroad	3
9 Which city is planned to be a part of the California High Speed Rail?	Fresno	4
1 Starting in the late 1950s American computer scientist Paul Baran developed the concept Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching with the goal to provide a faulttolerant efficient routing method for telecommunication messages as part of a research program at the RAND Corporation funded by the US Department of Defense.
2 This concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore established principles of preallocation of network bandwidth largely fortified by the development of telecommunications in the Bell System.
3 The new concept found little resonance among network implementers until the independent work of Donald Davies at the National Physical Laboratory United Kingdom NPL in the late 1960s.
4 Davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in Europe in the decade following including the incorporation of the concept in the early ARPANET in the United States.
5 What did Paul Baran develop 	Paul Baran developed the concept Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching 	1.
6 What did Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching do	provide a faulttolerant efficient routing method for telecommunication messages 	1.
7 What did this concept contradict 	This concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore established principles of preallocation of network bandwidth 	2.
8 What is Donald Davies credited with 	Davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in Europe 	4.
9 What did Paul Baran develop in the late 1950s	the concept Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching 	1.
10 What was the goal of the system 	to provide a faulttolerant efficient routing method for telecommunication messages 	1.
11 Who is credited with the modern name for this system 	Davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in Europe 	4.
1 Packet switching contrasts with another principal networking paradigm circuit switching a method which preallocates dedicated network bandwidth specifically for each communication session each having a constant bit rate and latency between nodes.
2 In cases of billable services such as cellular communication services circuit switching is characterized by a fee per unit of connection time even when no data is transferred while packet switching may be characterized by a fee per unit of information transmitted such as characters packets or messages.
3 Packet Switching contrast with what other principal 	circuit switching 	1.
4 What is circuit switching characterized by	circuit switching is characterized by a fee per unit of connection time 	2.
5 How is packet switching charecterized	by a fee per unit of information transmitted 	2.
6 What does Packet switching contrast with 	circuit switching 	1.
7 How is circuit switching allocated 	a method which preallocates dedicated network bandwidth 	1.
8 How is circuit switching charecterized 	by a fee per unit of connection time even when no data is transferred 	2.
9 How is packet switching characterized 	by a fee per unit of information transmitted such as characters packets or messages 	2.
1 Packet mode communication may be implemented with or without intermediate forwarding nodes packet switches or routers.
2 Packets are normally forwarded by intermediate network nodes asynchronously using firstin firstout buffering but may be forwarded according to some scheduling discipline for fair queuing traffic shaping or for differentiated or guaranteed quality of service such as weighted fair queuing or leaky bucket.
3 In case of a shared physical medium such as radio or 10BASE5 the packets may be delivered according to a multiple access scheme.
4 How is packet mode communication implemented 	with or without intermediate forwarding nodes 	1.
5 How are packets normally forwarded	asynchronously using firstin firstout buffering but may be forwarded according to some scheduling discipline for fair queuing 	2.
6 In cases of shared physical medium how are they delivered 	the packets may be delivered according to a multiple access scheme 	3.
7 How is packet mode communication implemented 	with or without intermediate forwarding nodes 	1.
8 How are packets normally forwarded	by intermediate network nodes asynchronously using firstin firstout buffering but may be forwarded according to some scheduling discipline for fair queuing 	2.
9 In cases with shared medium how is it delivered 	the packets may be delivered according to a multiple access scheme 	3.
1 Baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the RAND Corporation for the US Air Force into survivable communications networks first presented to the Air Force in the summer of 1961 as briefing B265 later published as RAND report P2626 in 1962 and finally in report RM 3420 in 1964.
2 Report P2626 described a general architecture for a largescale distributed survivable communications network.
3 The work focuses on three key ideas use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points dividing user messages into message blocks later called packets and delivery of these messages by store and forward switching.
4 What did Baran develop during research at RAND 	the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching 	1.
5 What was developed for the Air Force 	survivable communications networks 	1.
6 What 3 things does the Air Force work key on 	use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points dividing user messages into message blocks 	3.
7 How are Air force messages delivered 	delivery of these messages by store and forward switching 	3.
8 What was report P2626	a general architecture for a largescale distributed survivable communications network 	2.
9 What delivery message was used 	by store and forward switching 	3.
10 What concept was developed by Baran while researching at RAND	distributed adaptive message block switching 	1.
11 What  things did the network concentrate on 	use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points dividing user messages into message blocks later called packets 	3.
1 Starting in 1965 Donald Davies at the National Physical Laboratory UK independently developed the same message routing methodology as developed by Baran.
2 He called it packet switching a more accessible name than Barans and proposed to build a nationwide network in the UK.
3 He gave a talk on the proposal in 1966 after which a person from the Ministry of Defence MoD told him about Barans work.
4 A member of Davies team Roger Scantlebury met Lawrence Roberts at the 1967 ACM Symposium on Operating System Principles and suggested it for use in the ARPANET.
5 What did Donald Davies Develop	independently developed the same message routing methodology as developed by Baran 	1.
6 What did Davies call his system 	packet switching 	2.
7 What did Davies want to build 	proposed to build a nationwide network in the UK 	2.
8 What use was suggested for the system 	use in the ARPANET 	4.
9 Who developed the same technology as Baran 	Donald Davies 	1.
10 What did Davies call the System 	packet switching 	2.
11 What was suggested at the Symposium in 1967	suggested it for use in the ARPANET 	4.
1 In connectionless mode each packet includes complete addressing information.
2 The packets are routed individually sometimes resulting in different paths and outoforder delivery.
3 Each packet is labeled with a destination address source address and port numbers.
4 It may also be labeled with the sequence number of the packet.
5 This precludes the need for a dedicated path to help the packet find its way to its destination but means that much more information is needed in the packet header which is therefore larger and this information needs to be looked up in powerhungry contentaddressable memory.
6 Each packet is dispatched and may go via different routes potentially the system has to do as much work for every packet as the connectionoriented system has to do in connection setup but with less information as to the applications requirements.
7 At the destination the original messagedata is reassembled in the correct order based on the packet sequence number.
8 Thus a virtual connection also known as a virtual circuit or byte stream is provided to the enduser by a transport layer protocol although intermediate network nodes only provides a connectionless network layer service.
9 What does each packet includ in connectionless mode 	each packet includes complete addressing information 	1.
10 How are the packets routed 	individually sometimes resulting in different paths and outoforder delivery 	2.
11 What is included with each packet label	Each packet is labeled with a destination address source address and port numbers It may also be labeled with the sequence number of the packet 	3.
12 What happens to the packet at the destination	the original messagedata is reassembled in the correct order based on the packet sequence number 	7.
1 Connectionoriented transmission requires a setup phase in each involved node before any packet is transferred to establish the parameters of communication.
2 The packets include a connection identifier rather than address information and are negotiated between endpoints so that they are delivered in order and with error checking.
3 Address information is only transferred to each node during the connection setup phase when the route to the destination is discovered and an entry is added to the switching table in each network node through which the connection passes.
4 The signaling protocols used allow the application to specify its requirements and discover link parameters.
5 Acceptable values for service parameters may be negotiated.
6 Routing a packet requires the node to look up the connection id in a table.
7 The packet header can be small as it only needs to contain this code and any information such as length timestamp or sequence number which is different for different packets.
8 Is the packet header long 	The packet header can be small as it only needs to contain this code and any information such as length timestamp or sequence number 	7.
9 Why is the node requiered to look up 	Routing a packet requires the node to look up the connection id in a table 	6.
10 What is a connection identifier 	a connection identifier rather than address information and are negotiated between endpoints so that they are delivered in order and with error checking 	2.
11 What does connection orientation require	a setup phase in each involved node before any packet is transferred to establish the parameters of communication 	1.
1 Both X25 and Frame Relay provide connectionoriented operations.
2 But X25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model.
3 Frame Relay does it at level two the data link layer.
4 Another major difference between X25 and Frame Relay is that X25 requires a handshake between the communicating parties before any user packets are transmitted.
5 Frame Relay does not define any such handshakes.
6 X25 does not define any operations inside the packet network.
7 It only operates at the usernetworkinterface UNI.
8 Thus the network provider is free to use any procedure it wishes inside the network.
9 X25 does specify some limited retransmission procedures at the UNI and its link layer protocol LAPB provides conventional HDLCtype link management procedures.
10 Frame Relay is a modified version of ISDNs layer two protocol LAPD and LAPB.
11 As such its integrity operations pertain only between nodes on a link not endtoend.
12 Any retransmissions must be carried out by higher layer protocols.
13 The X25 UNI protocol is part of the X25 protocol suite which consists of the lower three layers of the OSI Model.
14 It was widely used at the UNI for packet switching networks during the 1980s and early 1990s to provide a standardized interface into and out of packet networks.
15 Some implementations used X25 within the network as well but its connectionoriented features made this setup cumbersome and inefficient.
16 Frame relay operates principally at layer two of the OSI Model.
17 However its address field the Data Link Connection ID or DLCI can be used at the OSI network layer with a minimum set of procedures.
18 Thus it rids itself of many X25 layer 3 encumbrances but still has the DLCI as an ID beyond a nodetonode layer two link protocol.
19 The simplicity of Frame Relay makes it faster and more efficient than X25.
20 Because Frame relay is a data link layer protocol like X25 it does not define internal network routing operations.
21 For X25 its packet IDsthe virtual circuit and virtual channel numbers have to be correlated to network addresses.
22 The same is true for Frame Relays DLCI.
23 How this is done is up to the network provider.
24 Frame Relay by virtue of having no network layer procedures is connectionoriented at layer two by using the HDLCLAPDLAPB Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode SABM.
25 X25 connections are typically established for each communication session but it does have a feature allowing a limited amount of traffic to be passed across the UNI without the connectionoriented handshake.
26 For a while Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks.
27 However X25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted by the Internet Protocol IP at the network layer and the Asynchronous Transfer Mode ATM and or versions of MultiProtocol Label Switching MPLS at layer two.
28 A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS.
29 Uyless Black X25 and Related Protocols IEEE Computer Society 1991 Uyless Black Frame Relay Networks McGrawHill 1998 Uyless Black MPLS and Label Switching Networks Prentice Hall 2001  Uyless Black ATM Volume I Prentice Hall 1995.
30 WHat do x25 and Frame Relay both require	connectionoriented operations But X25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model Frame Relay does it at level two the data link layer 	1.
31 What supplanted Frame Relay and X25 	supplanted by the Internet Protocol IP at the network layer and the Asynchronous Transfer Mode ATM and or versions of MultiProtocol Label Switching 	27.
32 What were X25 and Frame relay used for 	Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks However X25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted 	26.
33 What is a typical configuration	A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS 	28.
1 ARPANET and SITA HLN became operational in 1969.
2 Before the introduction of X25 in 1973 about twenty different network technologies had been developed.
3 Two fundamental differences involved the division of functions and tasks between the hosts at the edge of the network and the network core.
4 In the datagram system the hosts have the responsibility to ensure orderly delivery of packets.
5 The User Datagram Protocol UDP is an example of a datagram protocol.
6 In the virtual call system the network guarantees sequenced delivery of data to the host.
7 This results in a simpler host interface with less functionality than in the datagram model.
8 The X25 protocol suite uses this network type.
9 WHen did ARPNET and SITA become operational	1969 	1.
10 2 differences betwen X25 and ARPNET CITA technologies 	Two fundamental differences involved the division of functions and tasks between the hosts at the edge of the network and the network core 	3.
11 WHat does UserDatagram Protocol gaurentee	In the virtual call system the network guarantees sequenced delivery of data to the host 	6.
12 X25 uses what type network type 	User Datagram Protocol 	5.
1 AppleTalk was a proprietary suite of networking protocols developed by Apple Inc in 1985 for Apple Macintosh computers.
2 It was the primary protocol used by Apple devices through the 1980s and 90s.
3 AppleTalk included features that allowed local area networks to be established ad hoc without the requirement for a centralized router or server.
4 The AppleTalk system automatically assigned addresses updated the distributed namespace and configured any required internetwork routing.
5 It was a plugnplay system.
6 What was Apple Talk 	a proprietary suite of networking protocols developed by Apple Inc in 1985 	1.
7 WHat were features of Apple Talk 	that allowed local area networks to be established ad hoc without the requirement for a centralized router or server 	3.
8 What did the Apple system assign automatically 	automatically assigned addresses updated the distributed namespace and configured any required internetwork routing 	4.
9 This type of system is known as 	a plugnplay system 	5.
1 The CYCLADES packet switching network was a French research network designed and directed by Louis Pouzin.
2 First demonstrated in 1973 it was developed to explore alternatives to the early ARPANET design and to support network research generally.
3 It was the first network to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data rather than the network itself using unreliable datagrams and associated endtoend protocol mechanisms.
4 Concepts of this network influenced later ARPANET architecture.
5 What network was designed by the french 	CYCLADES packet switching network 	1.
6 What was a first for this network 	to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data rather than the network itself 	3.
7 How was this possible 	using unreliable datagrams and associated endtoend protocol mechanisms 	3.
8 This network influenced  later models of 	later ARPANET architecture 	4.
1 DECnet is a suite of network protocols created by Digital Equipment Corporation originally released in 1975 in order to connect two PDP11 minicomputers.
2 It evolved into one of the first peertopeer network architectures thus transforming DEC into a networking powerhouse in the 1980s.
3 Initially built with three layers it later 1982 evolved into a sevenlayer OSIcompliant networking protocol.
4 The DECnet protocols were designed entirely by Digital Equipment Corporation.
5 However DECnet Phase II and later were open standards with published specifications and several implementations were developed outside DEC including one for Linux.
6 What is  DECnet	a suite of network protocols created by Digital Equipment Corporation 	1.
7 What did DECnet originally do 	connect two PDP11 minicomputers 	1.
8 DEC originally had 3 layers but evolved into how many layers 	Initially built with three layers it later 1982 evolved into a sevenlayer OSIcompliant networking protocol 	3.
9 What did DECnet phase 2 become 	were open standards with published specifications and several implementations were developed outside DEC including one for Linux 	5.
1 In 1965 at the instigation of Warner Sinback a data network based on this voicephone network was designed to connect GEs four computer sales and service centers Schenectady Phoenix Chicago and Phoenix to facilitate a computer timesharing service apparently the worlds first commercial online service.
2 In addition to selling GE computers the centers were computer service bureaus offering batch processing services.
3 They lost money from the beginning and Sinback a highlevel marketing manager was given the job of turning the business around.
4 He decided that a timesharing system based on Kemneys work at Dartmouth—which used a computer on loan from GE—could be profitable.
5 Warner was right.
6 What was Warner Sinback	a data network based on this voicephone network was designed to connect GEs four computer sales and service centers 	1.
7 The 4 sales and service centers are viewed as 	the worlds first commercial online service 	1.
8 Were the centers profitable	They lost money from the beginning and Sinback a highlevel marketing manager was given the job of turning the business around 	3.
9 What did Warner Sinback decide 	that a timesharing system based on Kemneys work at Dartmouth—which used a computer on loan from GE—could be profitable 	4.
1 Merit Network Inc an independent nonprofit 501c3 corporation governed by Michigans public universities was formed in 1966 as the Michigan Educational Research Information Triad to explore computer networking between three of Michigans public universities as a means to help the states educational and economic development.
2 With initial support from the State of Michigan and the National Science Foundation NSF the packetswitched network was first demonstrated in December 1971 when an interactive host to host connection was made between the IBM mainframe computer systems at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and Wayne State University in Detroit.
3 In October 1972 connections to the CDC mainframe at Michigan State University in East Lansing completed the triad.
4 Over the next several years in addition to host to host interactive connections the network was enhanced to support terminal to host connections host to host batch connections remote job submission remote printing batch file transfer interactive file transfer gateways to the Tymnet and Telenet public data networks X25 host attachments gateways to X25 data networks Ethernet attached hosts and eventually TCPIP and additional public universities in Michigan join the network.
5 All of this set the stage for Merits role in the NSFNET project starting in the mid1980s.
6 WHy was the Merit network formed in Michigan 	as a means to help the states educational and economic development 	1.
7 What completed the triad 	an interactive host to host connection was made between the IBM mainframe computer systems at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and Wayne State 	2.
8 What set the stage for Merits role in NSFNET	Ethernet attached hosts and eventually TCPIP and additional public universities in Michigan join the network 	4.
1 Telenet was the first FCClicensed public data network in the United States.
2 It was founded by former ARPA IPTO director Larry Roberts as a means of making ARPANET technology public.
3 He had tried to interest ATT in buying the technology but the monopolys reaction was that this was incompatible with their future.
4 Bolt Beranack and Newman BBN provided the financing.
5 It initially used ARPANET technology but changed the host interface to X25 and the terminal interface to X29.
6 Telenet designed these protocols and helped standardize them in the CCITT.
7 Telenet was incorporated in 1973 and started operations in 1975.
8 It went public in 1979 and was then sold to GTE.
9 What was telenet 	the first FCClicensed public data network in the United States 	1.
10 Who founded Telnet 	Larry Roberts 	2.
11 Purpose of Telnet 	making ARPANET technology public 	2.
12 Telnet Used what  Interface technology	host interface to X25 and the terminal interface to X29 	5.
13 Telnet was sold to 	Telenet was incorporated in 1973 and started operations in 1975 It went public in 1979 and was then sold to GTE 	7.
1 Tymnet was an international data communications network headquartered in San Jose CA that utilized virtual call packet switched technology and used X25 SNASDLC BSC and ASCII interfaces to connect host computers serversat thousands of large companies educational institutions and government agencies.
2 Users typically connected via dialup connections or dedicated async connections.
3 The business consisted of a large public network that supported dialup users and a private network business that allowed government agencies and large companies mostly banks and airlines to build their own dedicated networks.
4 The private networks were often connected via gateways to the public network to reach locations not on the private network.
5 Tymnet was also connected to dozens of other public networks in the US and internationally via X25X75 gateways.
6 Interesting note Tymnet was not named after Mr Tyme.
7 Another employee suggested the name.
8 What was Tymnet	an international data communications network headquartered in San Jose CA 	1.
9 What did Tymnet connect 	connect host computers serversat thousands of large companies educational institutions and government agencies 	1.
10 How did user of Tymnet connect 	connected via dialup connections or dedicated async connections 	2.
11 The business allowed for private companies to do what 	government agencies and large companies mostly banks and airlines to build their own dedicated networks 	3.
12 Gateways allowed private companies to do what 	private networks were often connected via gateways to the public network to reach locations not on the private network 	4.
1 There were two kinds of X25 networks.
2 Some such as DATAPAC and TRANSPAC were initially implemented with an X25 external interface.
3 Some older networks such as TELENET and TYMNET were modified to provide a X25 host interface in addition to older host connection schemes.
4 DATAPAC was developed by Bell Northern Research which was a joint venture of Bell Canada a common carrier and Northern Telecom a telecommunications equipment supplier.
5 Northern Telecom sold several DATAPAC clones to foreign PTTs including the Deutsche Bundespost.
6 X75 and X121 allowed the interconnection of national X25 networks.
7 A user or host could call a host on a foreign network by including the DNIC of the remote network as part of the destination address.
8 citation needed.
9 How many types of X25 networks were there originally 	There were two kinds of X25 networks Some such as DATAPAC and TRANSPAC 	1.
10 Who developed DATAPAC	DATAPAC was developed by Bell Northern Research 	4.
11 WHat did foreign clones of DATAPAC allow for 	A user or host could call a host on a foreign network by including the DNIC of the remote network as part of the destination address 	7.
1 AUSTPAC was an Australian public X25 network operated by Telstra.
2 Started by Telecom Australia in the early 1980s AUSTPAC was Australias first public packetswitched data network supporting applications such as online betting financial applications — the Australian Tax Office made use of AUSTPAC — and remote terminal access to academic institutions who maintained their connections to AUSTPAC up until the midlate 1990s in some cases.
3 Access can be via a dialup terminal to a PAD or by linking a permanent X25 node to the network.

1 The Computer Science Network CSNET was a computer network funded by the US National Science Foundation NSF that began operation in 1981.
2 Its purpose was to extend networking benefits for computer science departments at academic and research institutions that could not be directly connected to ARPANET due to funding or authorization limitations.
3 It played a significant role in spreading awareness of and access to national networking and was a major milestone on the path to development of the global Internet.
4 What is CSNET	The Computer Science Network 	1.
5 What was the purpose of CSNET	to extend networking benefits for computer science departments at academic and research institutions that could not be directly connected to ARPANET 	2.
6 Funding limitations allowed CSNET to be what 	role in spreading awareness of and access to national networking and was a major milestone on the path to development of the global Internet 	3.
1 Internet2 is a notforprofit United States computer networking consortium led by members from the research and education communities industry and government.
2 The Internet2 community in partnership with Qwest built the first Internet2 Network called Abilene in 1998 and was a prime investor in the National LambdaRail NLR project.
3 In 2006 Internet2 announced a partnership with Level 3 Communications to launch a brand new nationwide network boosting its capacity from 10 Gbits to 100 Gbits.
4 In October 2007 Internet2 officially retired Abilene and now refers to its new higher capacity network as the Internet2 Network.

1 The National Science Foundation Network NSFNET was a program of coordinated evolving projects sponsored by the National Science Foundation NSF beginning in 1985 to promote advanced research and education networking in the United States.
2 NSFNET was also the name given to several nationwide backbone networks operating at speeds of 56 kbits 15 Mbits T1 and 45 Mbits T3 that were constructed to support NSFs networking initiatives from 19851995.
3 Initially created to link researchers to the nations NSFfunded supercomputing centers through further public funding and private industry partnerships it developed into a major part of the Internet backbone.
4 What is NSFNET	The National Science Foundation Network 	1.
5 What did NSFNET promote	advanced research and education networking in the United States 	1.
6 What did NSFNET eventually provide	it developed into a major part of the Internet backbone 	3.
1 The Very highspeed Backbone Network Service vBNS came on line in April 1995 as part of a National Science Foundation NSF sponsored project to provide highspeed interconnection between NSFsponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the United States.
2 The network was engineered and operated by MCI Telecommunications under a cooperative agreement with the NSF.
3 By 1998 the vBNS had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via 12 national points of presence with DS3 45 Mbits OC3c 155 Mbits and OC12c 622 Mbits links on an all OC12c backbone a substantial engineering feat for that time.
4 The vBNS installed one of the first ever production OC48c 25 Gbits IP links in February 1999 and went on to upgrade the entire backbone to OC48c.
5 what does vBNS stand for 	The Very highspeed Backbone Network Service 	1.
6 What did vBNS do 	provide highspeed interconnection between NSFsponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the United States 	1.
7 Who operated the vBSN network 	The network was engineered and operated by MCI Telecommunications under a cooperative agreement with the NSF 	2.
8 By 199 how many universities were connected 	By 1998 the vBNS had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via 12 national points of presence with DS3 	3.

1 The Black Death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of Central Asia where it then travelled along the Silk Road reaching Crimea by 1343.
2 From there it was most likely carried by Oriental rat fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on merchant ships.
3 Spreading throughout the Mediterranean and Europe the Black Death is estimated to have killed 30–60 of Europes total population.
4 In total the plague reduced the world population from an estimated 450 million down to 350–375 million in the 14th century.
5 The world population as a whole did not recover to preplague levels until the 17th century.
6 The plague recurred occasionally in Europe until the 19th century.
7 Where did the black death originate?	the arid plains of Central Asia	1
8 How did the black death make it to the Mediterranean and Europe?	merchant ships	2
9 How much of the European population did the black death kill?	30–60 of Europes total population	3
10 When did the worlds population finally recover from the black death?	the 17th century	5
11 For how long did the plague stick around?	until the 19th century	6
1 The plague disease caused by Yersinia pestis is enzootic commonly present in populations of fleas carried by ground rodents including marmots in various areas including Central Asia Kurdistan Western Asia Northern India and Uganda.
2 Nestorian graves dating to 1338–39 near Lake Issyk Kul in Kyrgyzstan have inscriptions referring to plague and are thought by many epidemiologists to mark the outbreak of the epidemic from which it could easily have spread to China and India.
3 In October 2010 medical geneticists suggested that all three of the great waves of the plague originated in China.
4 In China the 13th century Mongol conquest caused a decline in farming and trading.
5 However economic recovery had been observed at the beginning of the 14th century.
6 In the 1330s a large number of natural disasters and plagues led to widespread famine starting in 1331 with a deadly plague arriving soon after.
7 Epidemics that may have included plague killed an estimated 25 million Chinese and other Asians during the 15 years before it reached Constantinople in 1347.
8 What does it mean for a disease to be enzootic?	commonly present	1
9 How old are the gravestones that reference the plague?	dating to 1338–39	2
10 Where do scientists think all of the plagues originated from?	China	3
11 When did the Chinese famine begin?	1331	6
12 How many did this epidemic in China kill?	an estimated 25 million	7
1 Plague was reportedly first introduced to Europe via Genoese traders at the port city of Kaffa in the Crimea in 1347.
2 After a protracted siege during which the Mongol army under Jani Beg was suffering from the disease the army catapulted the infected corpses over the city walls of Kaffa to infect the inhabitants.
3 The Genoese traders fled taking the plague by ship into Sicily and the south of Europe whence it spread north.
4 Whether or not this hypothesis is accurate it is clear that several existing conditions such as war famine and weather contributed to the severity of the Black Death.
5 Who introduced plague to Europe?	Genoese traders	1
6 Who did the army siege belong to?	Jani Beg	2
7 What did the Mongol army throw in their catapults?	infected corpses	2
8 Where did the genoese traders bring the plague?	Sicily	3
9 What contributed to the severity of the plague?	war  famine  and weather	4
1 From Italy the disease spread northwest across Europe striking France Spain Portugal and England by June 1348 then turned and spread east through Germany and Scandinavia from 1348 to 1350.
2 It was introduced in Norway in 1349 when a ship landed at Askøy then spread to Bjørgvin modern Bergen and Iceland.
3 Finally it spread to northwestern Russia in 1351.
4 The plague was somewhat less common in parts of Europe that had smaller trade relations with their neighbours including the Kingdom of Poland the majority of the Basque Country isolated parts of Belgium and the Netherlands and isolated alpine villages throughout the continent.
5 Which direction did the disease first move in?	northwest across Europe	1
6 Which country was the last to receive the disease?	northwestern Russia	3
7 What types of European groups were able to avoid the plague?	parts of Europe that had smaller trade relations with their neighbours	4
8 Where was the disease spreading between 1348 and 1350?	Germany and Scandinavia	1
9 When did a plagueridden ship land in Norway?	1349	2
1 The plague struck various countries in the Middle East during the pandemic leading to serious depopulation and permanent change in both economic and social structures.
2 As it spread to western Europe the disease entered the region from southern Russia also.
3 By autumn 1347 the plague reached Alexandria in Egypt probably through the ports trade with Constantinople and ports on the Black Sea.
4 During 1347 the disease travelled eastward to Gaza and north along the eastern coast to cities in Lebanon Syria and Palestine including Ashkelon Acre Jerusalem Sidon Damascus Homs and Aleppo.
5 In 1348–49 the disease reached Antioch.
6 The citys residents fled to the north most of them dying during the journey but the infection had been spread to the people of Asia Minor.
7 citation needed.

10 How did the plague infiltrate Alexandria?	y through the ports trade with Constantinople  and ports on the Black Sea	3
11 Where did the residents of Antioch flee to?	The citys residents fled to the north	6
1 Gasquet 1908 claimed that the Latin name atra mors Black Death for the 14thcentury epidemic first appeared in modern times in 1631 in a book on Danish history by JI.
2 Pontanus Vulgo  ab effectu atram mortem vocatibant.
3 Commonly and from its effects they called it the black death.
4 The name spread through Scandinavia and then Germany gradually becoming attached to the mid 14thcentury epidemic as a proper name.
5 In England it was not until 1823 that the medieval epidemic was first called the Black Death.
6 Who claimed that the name Black Death first appeared in 1631?	Gasquet	1

1 Medical knowledge had stagnated during the Middle Ages.
2 The most authoritative account at the time came from the medical faculty in Paris in a report to the king of France that blamed the heavens in the form of a conjunction of three planets in 1345 that caused a great pestilence in the air.
3 This report became the first and most widely circulated of a series of plague tracts that sought to give advice to sufferers.
4 That the plague was caused by bad air became the most widely accepted theory.
5 Today this is known as the Miasma theory.
6 The word plague had no special significance at this time and only the recurrence of outbreaks during the Middle Ages gave it the name that has become the medical term.
7 What was the black death originally blamed on?	the heavens	2
8 Who was the medical report written for?	the king of France	2
9 What is the newer more widely accepted theory behind the spread of the plague?	That the plague was caused by bad air	4
10 What is the bad air theory officially known as?	Miasma theory	5
1 The dominant explanation for the Black Death is the plague theory which attributes the outbreak to Yersinia pestis also responsible for an epidemic that began in southern China in 1865 eventually spreading to India.
2 The investigation of the pathogen that caused the 19thcentury plague was begun by teams of scientists who visited Hong Kong in 1894 among whom was the FrenchSwiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin after whom the pathogen was named Yersinia pestis.
3 The mechanism by which Y pestis was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by PaulLouis Simond and was found to involve the bites of fleas whose midguts had become obstructed by replicating Y pestis several days after feeding on an infected host.
4 This blockage results in starvation and aggressive feeding behaviour by the fleas which repeatedly attempt to clear their blockage by regurgitation resulting in thousands of plague bacteria being flushed into the feeding site infecting the host.
5 The bubonic plague mechanism was also dependent on two populations of rodents one resistant to the disease which act as hosts keeping the disease endemic and a second that lack resistance.
6 When the second population dies the fleas move on to other hosts including people thus creating a human epidemic.
7 What was considered responsible for the black death as well as the epidemic in southern China?	Yersinia pestis	1
8 Where and when did the investigation of the plague pathogen begin?	Hong Kong in 1894	2
9 Who was yersinia pestis named for?	FrenchSwiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin	2
10 What did PaulLouis Simond establish in 1898?	The mechanism by which Y pestis was usually transmitted	3
11 What was the bubonic plague mechanism reliant on?	two populations of rodents	5
1 The historian Francis Aidan Gasquet wrote about the Great Pestilence in 1893 and suggested that it would appear to be some form of the ordinary Eastern or bubonic plague.
2 He was able to adopt the epidemiology of the bubonic plague for the Black Death for the second edition in 1908 implicating rats and fleas in the process and his interpretation was widely accepted for other ancient and medieval epidemics such as the Justinian plague that was prevalent in the Eastern Roman Empire from 541 to 700 CE.
3 Who wrote about the great pestilence in 1893?	Francis Aidan Gasquet	1
4 What did Gasquet think the plague was?	some form of the ordinary Eastern or bubonic plague	1
5 When did the second edition of Gasquets book come out?	1908	2
6 What did Gasquets book blame the plague on?	rats and fleas	2
7 What is another plague thought to have spread the same way?	the Justinian plague that was prevalent in the Eastern Roman Empire from 541 to 700 CE	2
1 Other forms of plague have been implicated by modern scientists.
2 The modern bubonic plague has a mortality rate of 30–75 and symptoms including fever of 38–41 °C 100–106 °F headaches painful aching joints nausea and vomiting and a general feeling of malaise.
3 Left untreated of those that contract the bubonic plague 80 percent die within eight days.
4 Pneumonic plague has a mortality rate of 90 to 95 percent.
5 Symptoms include fever cough and bloodtinged sputum.
6 As the disease progresses sputum becomes free flowing and bright red.
7 Septicemic plague is the least common of the three forms with a mortality rate near 100.
8 Symptoms are high fevers and purple skin patches purpura due to disseminated intravascular coagulation.
9 In cases of pneumonic and particularly septicemic plague the progress of the disease is so rapid that there would often be no time for the development of the enlarged lymph nodes that were noted as buboes.
10 What is the mortality rate of the modern bubonic plague?	30–75	2
11 How high do plague fevers run?	100–106 °F	2
12 What percent of untreated victims of the plague die within 8 days?	80 percent	3
13 What is the mortality rate of pneumonic plague?	90 to 95 percent	4
14 What skinrelated symptom appears from the pneumonic plague?	purple skin patches	8
1 In October 2010 the openaccess scientific journal PLoS Pathogens published a paper by a multinational team who undertook a new investigation into the role of Yersinia pestis in the Black Death following the disputed identification by Drancourt and Raoult in 1998.
2 They assessed the presence of DNARNA with Polymerase Chain Reaction PCR techniques for Y pestis from the tooth sockets in human skeletons from mass graves in northern central and southern Europe that were associated archaeologically with the Black Death and subsequent resurgences.
3 The authors concluded that this new research together with prior analyses from the south of France and Germany .
4 .
5 .
6 ends the debate about the etiology of the Black Death and unambiguously demonstrates that Y pestis was the causative agent of the epidemic plague that devastated Europe during the Middle Ages.
7 When did the Plos Pathogens paper come out?	In October 2010	1
8 What was the Plos Pathogens paper about?	a new investigation into the role of Yersinia pestis in the Black Death	1
9 How did scientists assess the DNARNA of yersinia pestis?	with Polymerase Chain Reaction PCR	2
10 Where did scientists find their Y pestis sample?	from the tooth sockets in human skeletons	2
11 What does the plos pathogen paper claim?	unambiguously demonstrates that Y pestis was the causative agent of the epidemic plague	6
1 The study also found that there were two previously unknown but related clades genetic branches of the Y pestis genome associated with medieval mass graves.
2 These clades which are thought to be extinct were found to be ancestral to modern isolates of the modern Y pestis strains Y p orientalis and Y p medievalis suggesting the plague may have entered Europe in two waves.
3 Surveys of plague pit remains in France and England indicate the first variant entered Europe through the port of Marseille around November 1347 and spread through France over the next two years eventually reaching England in the spring of 1349 where it spread through the country in three epidemics.
4 Surveys of plague pit remains from the Dutch town of Bergen op Zoom showed the Y pestis genotype responsible for the pandemic that spread through the Low Countries from 1350 differed from that found in Britain and France implying Bergen op Zoom and possibly other parts of the southern Netherlands was not directly infected from England or France in 1349 and suggesting a second wave of plague different from those in Britain and France may have been carried to the Low Countries from Norway the Hanseatic cities or another site.
5 What are clades?	genetic branches	1
6 What strains of y pestis were found in the mass graves?	Y p orientalis and Y p medievalis	2
7 What do the strains of y pestis suggest abut the plague?	the plague may have entered Europe in two waves	2
8 How and when did the first variant of y pestis enter Europe?	through the port of Marseille around November 1347	3
9 When did the y pestis reach England?	spring of 1349	3
1 The results of the Haensch study have since been confirmed and amended.
2 Based on genetic evidence derived from Black Death victims in the East Smithfield burial site in England Schuenemann et al.
3 concluded in 2011 that the Black Death in medieval Europe was caused by a variant of Y pestis that may no longer exist.
4 A study published in Nature in October 2011 sequenced the genome of Y pestis from plague victims and indicated that the strain that caused the Black Death is ancestral to most modern strains of the disease.
5 What is the current status of the Haensch study?	confirmed and amended	1
6 Where was the burial site used for testing located?	East Smithfield	2
7 What is thought to have happened to the y pestis that caused the black death?	may no longer exist	3
8 When was the study on sequenced Y genomes published?	October 2011	4
1 The plague theory was first significantly challenged by the work of British bacteriologist J F D Shrewsbury in 1970 who noted that the reported rates of mortality in rural areas during the 14thcentury pandemic were inconsistent with the modern bubonic plague leading him to conclude that contemporary accounts were exaggerations.
2 In 1984 zoologist Graham Twigg produced the first major work to challenge the bubonic plague theory directly and his doubts about the identity of the Black Death have been taken up by a number of authors including Samuel K Cohn Jr 2002 David Herlihy 1997 and Susan Scott and Christopher Duncan 2001.
3 Who challenged the plague theory first?	British bacteriologist J F D Shrewsbury	1
4 What did Shrewsbury note about the plague?	rates of mortality in rural areas during the 14thcentury pandemic were inconsistent with the modern bubonic plague	1
5 What was Shrewsburys conclusion?	contemporary accounts were exaggerations	1
6 What did Graham Twigg publish in 1984?	the first major work to challenge the bubonic plague theory directly	2
7 Who discussed Twiggs study in 2002?	Samuel K Cohn  Jr	2
1 It is recognised that an epidemiological account of the plague is as important as an identification of symptoms but researchers are hampered by the lack of reliable statistics from this period.
2 Most work has been done on the spread of the plague in England and even estimates of overall population at the start vary by over 100 as no census was undertaken between the time of publication of the Domesday Book and the year 1377.
3 Estimates of plague victims are usually extrapolated from figures from the clergy.
4 What is as important as identifying plague symptoms?	epidemiological account of the plague	1
5 Why are researchers struggling to identify the history of the plague?	the lack of reliable statistics from this period	1
6 How much do estimations of the population during the plague vary?	by over 100	2
7 Where can population estimates be extrapolated from?	the clergy	3
8 During which years was no census taken?	between the time of publication of the Domesday Book and the year 1377	2
1 In addition to arguing that the rat population was insufficient to account for a bubonic plague pandemic sceptics of the bubonic plague theory point out that the symptoms of the Black Death are not unique and arguably in some accounts may differ from bubonic plague that transference via fleas in goods was likely to be of marginal significance and that the DNA results may be flawed and might not have been repeated elsewhere despite extensive samples from other mass graves.
2 Other arguments include the lack of accounts of the death of rats before outbreaks of plague between the 14th and 17th centuries temperatures that are too cold in northern Europe for the survival of fleas that despite primitive transport systems the spread of the Black Death was much faster than that of modern bubonic plague that mortality rates of the Black Death appear to be very high that while modern bubonic plague is largely endemic as a rural disease the Black Death indiscriminately struck urban and rural areas and that the pattern of the Black Death with major outbreaks in the same areas separated by 5 to 15 years differs from modern bubonic plague—which often becomes endemic for decades with annual flareups.
3 Why might rats not be responsible for the plague?	the rat population was insufficient	1
4 How significant was the transfer of disease through fleas?	of marginal significance	1
5 Why  might the temperature affect the theory of plague spreading?	temperatures that are too cold in northern Europe for the survival of fleas	2
6 Was the bubonic plague spread faster or slower than modern bubonic plague?	the Black Death was much faster than that of modern bubonic plague	2
7 How many years could separate outbreaks of the black death?	5 to 15 years	2
1 A variety of alternatives to the Y pestis have been put forward.
2 Twigg suggested that the cause was a form of anthrax and Norman Cantor 2001 thought it may have been a combination of anthrax and other pandemics.
3 Scott and Duncan have argued that the pandemic was a form of infectious disease that characterise as hemorrhagic plague similar to Ebola.
4 Archaeologist Barney Sloane has argued that there is insufficient evidence of the extinction of a large number of rats in the archaeological record of the medieval waterfront in London and that the plague spread too quickly to support the thesis that the Y pestis was spread from fleas on rats he argues that transmission must have been person to person.
5 However no single alternative solution has achieved widespread acceptance.
6 Many scholars arguing for the Y pestis as the major agent of the pandemic suggest that its extent and symptoms can be explained by a combination of bubonic plague with other diseases including typhus smallpox and respiratory infections.
7 In addition to the bubonic infection others point to additional septicemic a type of blood poisoning and pneumonic an airborne plague that attacks the lungs before the rest of the body forms of the plague which lengthen the duration of outbreaks throughout the seasons and help account for its high mortality rate and additional recorded symptoms.
8 In 2014 scientists with Public Health England announced the results of an examination of 25 bodies exhumed from the Clerkenwell area of London as well as of wills registered in London during the period which supported the pneumonic hypothesis.
9 What does Graham Twigg propose about the spread of disease?	a form of anthrax	2
10 What was Norman Cantors theory about the plague?	a combination of anthrax and other pandemics	2
11 Which diseases do many scientists believe contributed to plague pandemic?	typhus  smallpox and respiratory infections	6
12 What is septicemia?	a type of blood poisoning	7
13 How many bodies did Public Health England exhume?	25	8
1 The most widely accepted estimate for the Middle East including Iraq Iran and Syria during this time is for a death rate of about a third.
2 The Black Death killed about 40 of Egypts population.
3 Half of Pariss population of 100000 people died.
4 In Italy the population of Florence was reduced from 110–120 thousand inhabitants in 1338 down to 50 thousand in 1351.
5 At least 60 of the population of Hamburg and Bremen perished and a similar percentage of Londoners may have died from the disease as well.
6 Interestingly while contemporary reports account of mass burial pits being created in response to the large numbers of dead recent scientific investigations of a burial pit in Central London found wellpreserved individuals to be buried in isolated evenly spaced graves suggesting at least some preplanning and Christian burials at this time.
7 Before 1350 there were about 170000 settlements in Germany and this was reduced by nearly 40000 by 1450.
8 In 1348 the plague spread so rapidly that before any physicians or government authorities had time to reflect upon its origins about a third of the European population had already perished.
9 In crowded cities it was not uncommon for as much as 50 of the population to die.
10 The disease bypassed some areas and the most isolated areas were less vulnerable to contagion.
11 Monks and priests were especially hard hit since they cared for victims of the Black Death.

1 In England in the absence of census figures historians propose a range of preincident population figures from as high as 7 million to as low as 4 million in 1300 and a postincident population figure as low as 2 million.
2 By the end of 1350 the Black Death subsided but it never really died out in England.
3 Over the next few hundred years further outbreaks occurred in 1361–62 1369 1379–83 1389–93 and throughout the first half of the 15th century.
4 An outbreak in 1471 took as much as 10–15 of the population while the death rate of the plague of 1479–80 could have been as high as 20.
5 The most general outbreaks in Tudor and Stuart England seem to have begun in 1498 1535 1543 1563 1589 1603 1625 and 1636 and ended with the Great Plague of London in 1665.
