1 The Black Death ravaged much of the Islamic world.
2 Plague was present in at least one location in the Islamic world virtually every year between 1500 and 1850.
3 Plague repeatedly struck the cities of North Africa.
4 Algiers lost 30 to 50 thousand inhabitants to it in 1620–21 and again in 1654–57 1665 1691 and 1740–42.
5 Plague remained a major event in Ottoman society until the second quarter of the 19th century.
6 Between 1701 and 1750 thirtyseven larger and smaller epidemics were recorded in Constantinople and an additional thirtyone between 1751 and 1800.
7 Baghdad has suffered severely from visitations of the plague and sometimes twothirds of its population has been wiped out.
8 During which years was the plague present in Islamic countries?	between 1500 and 1850	2
9 How many people were lost in Algiers during 162021?	30 to 50 thousand inhabitants	4
10 How long did plague last in the Ottoman empire?	until the second quarter of the 19th century	5
11 How many people at most have died of plague in Baghdad?	twothirds of its population	7
1 There are three major types of rock igneous sedimentary and metamorphic.
2 The rock cycle is an important concept in geology which illustrates the relationships between these three types of rock and magma.
3 When a rock crystallizes from melt magma andor lava it is an igneous rock.
4 This rock can be weathered and eroded and then redeposited and lithified into a sedimentary rock or be turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure that change the mineral content of the rock which gives it a characteristic fabric.
5 The sedimentary rock can then be subsequently turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure and is then weathered eroded deposited and lithified ultimately becoming a sedimentary rock.
6 Sedimentary rock may also be reeroded and redeposited and metamorphic rock may also undergo additional metamorphism.
7 All three types of rocks may be remelted when this happens a new magma is formed from which an igneous rock may once again crystallize.
8 An igneous rock is a rock that crystallizes from what?	melt magma andor lava	3
9 Sedimentary rock can be turned into which of the three types of rock?	metamorphic rock	5
10 When the three types of rock are remelted what is formed?	new magma	7
11 What are the three major types of rock?	igneous  sedimentary  and metamorphic	1
12 What changes the mineral content of a rock?	heat and pressure	4
1 In the 1960s a series of discoveries the most important of which was seafloor spreading showed that the Earths lithosphere which includes the crust and rigid uppermost portion of the upper mantle is separated into a number of tectonic plates that move across the plastically deforming solid upper mantle which is called the asthenosphere.
2 There is an intimate coupling between the movement of the plates on the surface and the convection of the mantle oceanic plate motions and mantle convection currents always move in the same direction because the oceanic lithosphere is the rigid upper thermal boundary layer of the convecting mantle.
3 This coupling between rigid plates moving on the surface of the Earth and the convecting mantle is called plate tectonics.
4 What was the most important discovery that led to the understanding that Earths lithosphere is separated into tectonic plates?	seafloor spreading	1
5 Which parts of the Earth are included in the lithosphere?	the crust and rigid uppermost portion of the upper mantle	1
6 What is another word for the Earths upper mantle?	asthenosphere	1
7 Plate tectonics can be seen as the intimate coupling between rigid plates on the surface of the Earth and what?	the convecting mantle	3
8 In what decade was seafloor spreading discovered?	the 1960s	1
1 The development of plate tectonics provided a physical basis for many observations of the solid Earth.
2 Long linear regions of geologic features could be explained as plate boundaries.
3 Midocean ridges high regions on the seafloor where hydrothermal vents and volcanoes exist were explained as divergent boundaries where two plates move apart.
4 Arcs of volcanoes and earthquakes were explained as convergent boundaries where one plate subducts under another.
5 Transform boundaries such as the San Andreas fault system resulted in widespread powerful earthquakes.
6 Plate tectonics also provided a mechanism for Alfred Wegeners theory of continental drift in which the continents move across the surface of the Earth over geologic time.
7 They also provided a driving force for crustal deformation and a new setting for the observations of structural geology.
8 The power of the theory of plate tectonics lies in its ability to combine all of these observations into a single theory of how the lithosphere moves over the convecting mantle.
9 What is the area called where two plates move apart?	divergent boundaries	3
10 What is the area called where one plate subducts under another?	convergent boundaries	4
11 What type of fault boundary is defined by having widespread powerful earthquakes as in the state of California?	Transform boundaries	5
12 Whose theory was the theory of continental drift?	Alfred Wegener	6
13 The lithosphere moves over which mantle n the theory of plate tectonics?	the convecting mantle	8
1 Seismologists can use the arrival times of seismic waves in reverse to image the interior of the Earth.
2 Early advances in this field showed the existence of a liquid outer core where shear waves were not able to propagate and a dense solid inner core.
3 These advances led to the development of a layered model of the Earth with a crust and lithosphere on top the mantle below separated within itself by seismic discontinuities at 410 and 660 kilometers and the outer core and inner core below that.
4 More recently seismologists have been able to create detailed images of wave speeds inside the earth in the same way a doctor images a body in a CT scan.
5 These images have led to a much more detailed view of the interior of the Earth and have replaced the simplified layered model with a much more dynamic model.
6 What types of waves do seismologists use to image the interior of the Earth?	seismic waves	1
7 In the layered model of the Earth the outermost layer is what?	crust	3
8 In the layered model of the Earth there are seismic discontinuities in which layer?	the mantle	3
9 Recently a more detailed model of the Earth was developed Seismologists were able to create this using images of what from the interior of the Earth?	wave speeds	4
10 In the layered model of the Earth the mantle has two layers below it What are they?	the outer core and inner core	3
1 The following four timelines show the geologic time scale.
2 The first shows the entire time from the formation of the Earth to the present but this compresses the most recent eon.
3 Therefore the second scale shows the most recent eon with an expanded scale.
4 The second scale compresses the most recent era so the most recent era is expanded in the third scale.
5 Since the Quaternary is a very short period with short epochs it is further expanded in the fourth scale.
6 The second third and fourth timelines are therefore each subsections of their preceding timeline as indicated by asterisks.
7 The Holocene the latest epoch is too small to be shown clearly on the third timeline on the right another reason for expanding the fourth scale.
8 The Pleistocene P epoch.
9 Q stands for the Quaternary period.
10 Why is the second timeline needed?	second scale shows the most recent eon with an expanded scale	3
11 Which timeline is further expanded in the fourth scale?	Quaternary	5
12 What is the name of the latest epoch?	The Holocene	7
13 The Pleistocene epoch takes place during which period?	the Quaternary period	9
1 The principle of crosscutting relationships pertains to the formation of faults and the age of the sequences through which they cut.
2 Faults are younger than the rocks they cut accordingly if a fault is found that penetrates some formations but not those on top of it then the formations that were cut are older than the fault and the ones that are not cut must be younger than the fault.
3 Finding the key bed in these situations may help determine whether the fault is a normal fault or a thrust fault.
4 What principle relates to the formation of faults and the age of the sequences through which they cut?	The principle of crosscutting relationships	1
5 When rock formations are found on top of a fault that have not been cut then they must be older or younger than the fault?	younger than the fault	2
6 Finding what helps to determine if a fault is a normal fault or a thrust fault?	the key bed	3
7 Rocks on top of a fault that are cut are always older or younger than the fault itself?	older than the fault	2
1 The principle of inclusions and components states that with sedimentary rocks if inclusions or clasts are found in a formation then the inclusions must be older than the formation that contains them.
2 For example in sedimentary rocks it is common for gravel from an older formation to be ripped up and included in a newer layer.
3 A similar situation with igneous rocks occurs when xenoliths are found.
4 These foreign bodies are picked up as magma or lava flows and are incorporated later to cool in the matrix.
5 As a result xenoliths are older than the rock which contains them.
6 What foreign bodies which are older than the rocks themselves occur igneous rocks?	xenoliths	5
7 Xenoliths are picked up by what and deposited into the matrix of igneous rocks?	magma or lava flows	4
8 What is another word for inclusions in sedimentary rocks?	clasts	1
9 What is the principle that states that with sedimentary rocks inclusions must be older than the formation that contains them?	The principle of inclusions and components	1
10 What is something that is often torn up and included in sedimentary rock?	gravel	2
1 The principle of faunal succession is based on the appearance of fossils in sedimentary rocks.
2 As organisms exist at the same time period throughout the world their presence or sometimes absence may be used to provide a relative age of the formations in which they are found.
3 Based on principles laid out by William Smith almost a hundred years before the publication of Charles Darwins theory of evolution the principles of succession were developed independently of evolutionary thought.
4 The principle becomes quite complex however given the uncertainties of fossilization the localization of fossil types due to lateral changes in habitat facies change in sedimentary strata and that not all fossils may be found globally at the same time.
5 Which principle is based on the appearance of fossils in sedimentary rocks?	The principle of faunal succession	1
6 Whose principles were the principle of faunal succession built upon?	William Smith	3
7 The fact that not all fossils may be found globally at the same time causes the principle to become what?	complex	4
8 The presence or absence of what can be used to determine the relative age of the formations in which they are found?	organisms	2
9 The principle of faunal succession was developed 100 years before whose theory of evolution?	Charles Darwin	3
1 At the beginning of the 20th century important advancement in geological science was facilitated by the ability to obtain accurate absolute dates to geologic events using radioactive isotopes and other methods.
2 This changed the understanding of geologic time.
3 Previously geologists could only use fossils and stratigraphic correlation to date sections of rock relative to one another.
4 With isotopic dates it became possible to assign absolute ages to rock units and these absolute dates could be applied to fossil sequences in which there was datable material converting the old relative ages into new absolute ages.
5 When was the ability to use radioactive isotopes to date rock formations developed?	At the beginning of the 20th century	1
6 What type of correlation was used previously to help date rock formations?	stratigraphic correlation	3
7 It is now possible to convert old relative ages into what type of ages using isotopic dating?	absolute ages	4
8 Previous to isotopic dating sections of rocks had to be dated using fossils and stratigraphic correlation relative to what?	to one another	3
9 When dating rocks what is the absolute isotopic date applied to?	fossil sequences	4
1 For many geologic applications isotope ratios of radioactive elements are measured in minerals that give the amount of time that has passed since a rock passed through its particular closure temperature the point at which different radiometric isotopes stop diffusing into and out of the crystal lattice.
2 These are used in geochronologic and thermochronologic studies.
3 Common methods include uraniumlead dating potassiumargon dating argonargon dating and uraniumthorium dating.
4 These methods are used for a variety of applications.
5 Dating of lava and volcanic ash layers found within a stratigraphic sequence can provide absolute age data for sedimentary rock units which do not contain radioactive isotopes and calibrate relative dating techniques.
6 These methods can also be used to determine ages of pluton emplacement.
7 Thermochemical techniques can be used to determine temperature profiles within the crust the uplift of mountain ranges and paleotopography.
8 What techniques can be used to determine paleotopography?	Thermochemical techniques	7
9 The point at which different radiometric isotopes stop diffusing into and out of the crystal lattice is called what?	particular closure temperature	1
10 What type of ratios are used in geochronologic and thermochronologic studies?	isotope ratios of radioactive elements	1
11 How can you find the absolute age of sedimentary rock units which do not contain radioactive isotopes?	Dating of lava and volcanic ash layers found within a stratigraphic sequence	5
1 When rock units are placed under horizontal compression they shorten and become thicker.
2 Because rock units other than muds do not significantly change in volume this is accomplished in two primary ways through faulting and folding.
3 In the shallow crust where brittle deformation can occur thrust faults form which cause deeper rock to move on top of shallower rock.
4 Because deeper rock is often older as noted by the principle of superposition this can result in older rocks moving on top of younger ones.
5 Movement along faults can result in folding either because the faults are not planar or because rock layers are dragged along forming drag folds as slip occurs along the fault.
6 Deeper in the Earth rocks behave plastically and fold instead of faulting.
7 These folds can either be those where the material in the center of the fold buckles upwards creating antiforms or where it buckles downwards creating synforms.
8 If the tops of the rock units within the folds remain pointing upwards they are called anticlines and synclines respectively.
9 If some of the units in the fold are facing downward the structure is called an overturned anticline or syncline and if all of the rock units are overturned or the correct updirection is unknown they are simply called by the most general terms antiforms and synforms.
10 Rock units become thicker and shorten when placed under this type of compression 	horizontal compression 	1.
11 Where do thrust faults form?	In the shallow crust	3
12 When rock folds deep in the Earth it can fold one of two ways when it buckles upwards it creates what?	antiforms	7
13 When rock folds deep in the Earth it can fold one of two ways when it buckles downwards it creates what?	synforms	7
14 If the tops of the rock units within the folds remain pointing upwards they are called what?	anticlines and synclines	8
1 Extension causes the rock units as a whole to become longer and thinner.
2 This is primarily accomplished through normal faulting and through the ductile stretching and thinning.
3 Normal faults drop rock units that are higher below those that are lower.
4 This typically results in younger units being placed below older units.
5 Stretching of units can result in their thinning in fact there is a location within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt in which the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon can be seen over a length of less than a meter.
6 Rocks at the depth to be ductilely stretched are often also metamorphosed.
7 These stretched rocks can also pinch into lenses known as boudins after the French word for sausage because of their visual similarity.
8 This causes the rock unit as a whole to become longer and thinner 	Extension 	1.
9 Stretched rocks that pinch into lenses are known by what word?	boudins	7
10 Where can the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon be seen in less than the length of a meter?	within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt	5
11 Rocks that are a depth where they are ductilely stretched are also often what?	metamorphosed	6
12 What causes rock extension?	normal faulting and through the ductile stretching and thinning	2
1 The addition of new rock units both depositionally and intrusively often occurs during deformation.
2 Faulting and other deformational processes result in the creation of topographic gradients causing material on the rock unit that is increasing in elevation to be eroded by hillslopes and channels.
3 These sediments are deposited on the rock unit that is going down.
4 Continual motion along the fault maintains the topographic gradient in spite of the movement of sediment and continues to create accommodation space for the material to deposit.
5 Deformational events are often also associated with volcanism and igneous activity.
6 Volcanic ashes and lavas accumulate on the surface and igneous intrusions enter from below.
7 Dikes long planar igneous intrusions enter along cracks and therefore often form in large numbers in areas that are being actively deformed.
8 This can result in the emplacement of dike swarms such as those that are observable across the Canadian shield or rings of dikes around the lava tube of a volcano.
9 What is another word for long planar igneous intrusions?	Dikes	7
10 Where do dikes form?	in areas that are being actively deformed	7
11 What type of gradients are formed by faulting and other deformational processes?	topographic gradients	2
12 What activity maintains topographic gradients?	Continual motion along the fault	4
13 What events are often associated with volcanism and igneous activity?	Deformational events	5
1 All of these processes do not necessarily occur in a single environment and do not necessarily occur in a single order.
2 The Hawaiian Islands for example consist almost entirely of layered basaltic lava flows.
3 The sedimentary sequences of the midcontinental United States and the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States contain almostundeformed stacks of sedimentary rocks that have remained in place since Cambrian time.
4 Other areas are much more geologically complex.
5 In the southwestern United States sedimentary volcanic and intrusive rocks have been metamorphosed faulted foliated and folded.
6 Even older rocks such as the Acasta gneiss of the Slave craton in northwestern Canada the oldest known rock in the world have been metamorphosed to the point where their origin is undiscernable without laboratory analysis.
7 In addition these processes can occur in stages.
8 In many places the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States being a very visible example the lower rock units were metamorphosed and deformed and then deformation ended and the upper undeformed units were deposited.
9 Although any amount of rock emplacement and rock deformation can occur and they can occur any number of times these concepts provide a guide to understanding the geological history of an area.
10 The Hawaiian Islands are made up almost entirely of what?	layered basaltic lava flows	2
11 What is the oldest known rock in the world?	Acasta gneiss	6
12 What type of rock is found at the Grand Canyon?	sedimentary rocks	3
13 The rocks at the Grand Canyon have been in place since when?	Cambrian time	3
14 Where is the oldest known rock in the world located?	Slave craton in northwestern Canada	6
1 Geologists use a number of field laboratory and numerical modeling methods to decipher Earth history and understand the processes that occur on and inside the Earth.
2 In typical geological investigations geologists use primary information related to petrology the study of rocks stratigraphy the study of sedimentary layers and structural geology the study of positions of rock units and their deformation.
3 In many cases geologists also study modern soils rivers landscapes and glaciers investigate past and current life and biogeochemical pathways and use geophysical methods to investigate the subsurface.
4 What is petrology?	the study of rocks	2
5 What is stratigraphy?	the study of sedimentary layers	2
6 What is structural geology?	the study of positions of rock units and their deformation	2
7  What modern formations do geologists study?	modern soils	3
1 In addition to identifying rocks in the field petrologists identify rock samples in the laboratory.
2 Two of the primary methods for identifying rocks in the laboratory are through optical microscopy and by using an electron microprobe.
3 In an optical mineralogy analysis thin sections of rock samples are analyzed through a petrographic microscope where the minerals can be identified through their different properties in planepolarized and crosspolarized light including their birefringence pleochroism twinning and interference properties with a conoscopic lens.
4 In the electron microprobe individual locations are analyzed for their exact chemical compositions and variation in composition within individual crystals.
5 Stable and radioactive isotope studies provide insight into the geochemical evolution of rock units.
6 What do petrologists use electron microprobes in the laboratory for?	identifying rocks	1
7 What properties are analyzed with a conoscopic lens by petrologists?	birefringence  pleochroism  twinning  and interference properties	3
8 Stable and radioactive isotope studies provide insight into what?	geochemical evolution of rock units	5
9 Petrologists identify rock samples in the field and where else?	the laboratory	1
10 What type of microscope is used by petrologists?	petrographic microscope	3
1 Petrologists can also use fluid inclusion data and perform high temperature and pressure physical experiments to understand the temperatures and pressures at which different mineral phases appear and how they change through igneous and metamorphic processes.
2 This research can be extrapolated to the field to understand metamorphic processes and the conditions of crystallization of igneous rocks.
3 This work can also help to explain processes that occur within the Earth such as subduction and magma chamber evolution.
4 How else can petrologists understand the pressures at which different mineral phases appear?	pressure physical experiments	1
5 How else can petrologists understand the temperature at which different mineral phases appear?	physical experiments	1
6 Data from physical experiments can be extrapolated to the field to understand what processes?	metamorphic processes	2
1 Structural geologists use microscopic analysis of oriented thin sections of geologic samples to observe the fabric within the rocks which gives information about strain within the crystalline structure of the rocks.
2 They also plot and combine measurements of geological structures in order to better understand the orientations of faults and folds in order to reconstruct the history of rock deformation in the area.
3 In addition they perform analog and numerical experiments of rock deformation in large and small settings.
4 What type of geologists give information about strain within the crystalline structure of the rocks?	Structural geologists	1
5 How do structural geologists observe the fabric within the rocks?	microscopic analysis of oriented thin sections	1
6 In order to better understand the orientations of faults and folds structural geologists do what with measurements of geological structures?	plot and combine	2
7 What kind of experiments of rock deformation do structural geologists perform?	analog and numerical experiments	3
1 Among the most wellknown experiments in structural geology are those involving orogenic wedges which are zones in which mountains are built along convergent tectonic plate boundaries.
2 In the analog versions of these experiments horizontal layers of sand are pulled along a lower surface into a back stop which results in realisticlooking patterns of faulting and the growth of a critically tapered all angles remain the same orogenic wedge.
3 Numerical models work in the same way as these analog models though they are often more sophisticated and can include patterns of erosion and uplift in the mountain belt.
4 This helps to show the relationship between erosion and the shape of the mountain range.
5 These studies can also give useful information about pathways for metamorphism through pressure temperature space and time.
6 Zones in which mountains are built along convergent tectonic plate boundaries are called what?	orogenic wedges	1
7 What are among the most well known experiments in structural geology?	those involving orogenic wedges	1
8 Horizontal layers of what are pulled along a surface into a back stop in analog versions of orogenic wedge experiments?	sand	2
9 What does critically tapered mean?	all angles remain the same	2
10 Which is more sophisticated numericals model or an analog models of orogenic wedges?	Numerical models	3
1 In the laboratory stratigraphers analyze samples of stratigraphic sections that can be returned from the field such as those from drill cores.
2 Stratigraphers also analyze data from geophysical surveys that show the locations of stratigraphic units in the subsurface.
3 Geophysical data and well logs can be combined to produce a better view of the subsurface and stratigraphers often use computer programs to do this in three dimensions.
4 Stratigraphers can then use these data to reconstruct ancient processes occurring on the surface of the Earth interpret past environments and locate areas for water coal and hydrocarbon extraction.
5 The analysis of stratigraphic sections such as drill cores is done by who?	stratigraphers	1
6 What type of surveys show the location of stratigraphic units in the subsurface?	geophysical surveys	2
7 What can be combined with geophysical data to produce a better view of the subsurface?	well logs	3
8 What tool do stratigraphers use to see their data in three dimensions?	computer programs	3
9 Stratigraphers try to locate areas for what types of extraction?	water  coal  and hydrocarbon extraction	4
1 In the laboratory biostratigraphers analyze rock samples from outcrop and drill cores for the fossils found in them.
2 These fossils help scientists to date the core and to understand the depositional environment in which the rock units formed.
3 Geochronologists precisely date rocks within the stratigraphic section in order to provide better absolute bounds on the timing and rates of deposition.
4 Magnetic stratigraphers look for signs of magnetic reversals in igneous rock units within the drill cores.
5 Other scientists perform stable isotope studies on the rocks to gain information about past climate.
6 Why is it important to precisely date rocks within the stratigraphic section?	provide better absolute bounds on the timing and rates of deposition	3
7 Who analyzes rock samples from drill cores in the lab?	biostratigraphers	1
8 What types of scientists looks for signs of magnetic reversals in igneous rocks within the drill cores?	Magnetic stratigraphers	4
9 Who dates rocks precisely within the stratigraphic section?	Geochronologists	3
1 Some modern scholars such as Fielding H Garrison are of the opinion that the origin of the science of geology can be traced to Persia after the Muslim conquests had come to an end.
2 Abu alRayhan alBiruni 973–1048 CE was one of the earliest Persian geologists whose works included the earliest writings on the geology of India hypothesizing that the Indian subcontinent was once a sea.
3 Drawing from Greek and Indian scientific literature that were not destroyed by the Muslim conquests the Persian scholar Ibn Sina Avicenna 981–1037 proposed detailed explanations for the formation of mountains the origin of earthquakes and other topics central to modern geology which provided an essential foundation for the later development of the science.
4 In China the polymath Shen Kuo 1031–1095 formulated a hypothesis for the process of land formation based on his observation of fossil animal shells in a geological stratum in a mountain hundreds of miles from the ocean he inferred that the land was formed by erosion of the mountains and by deposition of silt.
5 Fielding H Garrison believes that the science of geology can be traced to where?	Persia	1
6 Living from 973–1048 CE he was one of the earliest Persian geologists what was his name?	Abu alRayhan alBiruni	2
7 In China this person inferred that the land was formed by erosion of the mountains and by silt deposition what was his name?	Shen Kuo	4
8 This person proposed explanations for the origins of earthquakes and the formation of mountains what was his name?	Ibn Sina	3
9 What prompted Shen Kuo to believe the land was formed by erosion of the mountains?	his observation of fossil animal shells	4
1 James Hutton is often viewed as the first modern geologist.
2 In 1785 he presented a paper entitled Theory of the Earth to the Royal Society of Edinburgh.
3 In his paper he explained his theory that the Earth must be much older than had previously been supposed in order to allow enough time for mountains to be eroded and for sediments to form new rocks at the bottom of the sea which in turn were raised up to become dry land.
4 Hutton published a twovolume version of his ideas in 1795 Vol.
5 1 Vol.
6 2.
7 Who is viewed as the first modern geologist?	James Hutton	1
8 In 1785 James Hutton presented what paper to the Royal Society of Edinburgh?	Theory of the Earth	2
9 James Hutton published a 2 volume version of his theories in what year?	1795	4
10 What was the main idea of James Huttons paper?	Earth must be much older than had previously been supposed	3
1 The first geological map of the US was produced in 1809 by William Maclure.
2 In 1807 Maclure commenced the selfimposed task of making a geological survey of the United States.
3 Almost every state in the Union was traversed and mapped by him the Allegheny Mountains being crossed and recrossed some 50 times.
4 The results of his unaided labours were submitted to the American Philosophical Society in a memoir entitled Observations on the Geology of the United States explanatory of a Geological Map and published in the Societys Transactions together with the nations first geological map.
5 This antedates William Smiths geological map of England by six years although it was constructed using a different classification of rocks.
6 Who produced the first geological map of the US?	William Maclure	1
7 In what year was the first geological map of the US produced?	1809	1
8 In what year did William Maclure begin the process of creating the first geological map of the US?	1807	2
9 What was the memoir entitled which was submitted to the American Philosophical Society?	Observations on the Geology of the United States explanatory of a Geological Map	4
10 To whom did William Maclure submit the map?	the American Philosophical Society	4
1 Sir Charles Lyell first published his famous book Principles of Geology in 1830.
2 This book which influenced the thought of Charles Darwin successfully promoted the doctrine of uniformitarianism.
3 This theory states that slow geological processes have occurred throughout the Earths history and are still occurring today.
4 In contrast catastrophism is the theory that Earths features formed in single catastrophic events and remained unchanged thereafter.
5 Though Hutton believed in uniformitarianism the idea was not widely accepted at the time.
6 First published by Sir Charles Lyell in 1830 this book was called what?	Principles of Geology	1
7 What doctrine did the doctrine of the Principles of Geology successfully promote?	uniformitarianism	2
8 Which theory states that slow geological processes are still occurring today and have occurred throughout Earths history?	uniformitarianism	2
9 Which theory states that Earths features remained unchanged after forming in one single catastrophic event?	catastrophism	4
10 Which famous evolutionist was influenced by the book Principles of Geology?	Charles Darwin	2
1 Newcastle upon Tyne RP iˌnjuːkɑːsəl əˌpɒn ˈtaɪn Locally injuːˌkæsəl əˌpən ˈtaɪn commonly known as Newcastle is a city in Tyne and Wear North East England 103 miles 166 km south of Edinburgh and 277 miles 446 km north of London on the northern bank of the River Tyne 85 mi 137 km from the North Sea.
2 Newcastle is the most populous city in the North East and Tyneside the eighth most populous conurbation in the United Kingdom.
3 Newcastle is a member of the English Core Cities Group and is a member of the Eurocities network of European cities.
4 Newcastle was part of the county of Northumberland until 1400 when it became a county itself a status it retained until becoming part of Tyne and Wear in 1974.
5 not in citation given The regional nickname and dialect for people from Newcastle and the surrounding area is Geordie.
6 How many miles south of Edinburgh is Newcastle?	103 miles	1
7 How many miles from the north Sea is Newcastle?	85 mi	1
8 What network is Newcastle a member of?	Eurocities	3
9 What county was Newcastle a part of until 1400?	Northumberland	4
10 Whats the regional nickname for Newcastle and its surrounding area?	Geordie	5
1 The city developed around the Roman settlement Pons Aelius and was named after the castle built in 1080 by Robert Curthose William the Conquerors eldest son.
2 The city grew as an important centre for the wool trade in the 14th century and later became a major coal mining area.
3 The port developed in the 16th century and along with the shipyards lower down the River Tyne was amongst the worlds largest shipbuilding and shiprepairing centres.
4 Newcastles economy includes corporate headquarters learning digital technology retail tourism and cultural centres from which the city contributes £13 billion towards the United Kingdoms GVA.
5 Among its icons are Newcastle Brown Ale Newcastle United football club and the Tyne Bridge.
6 It has hosted the worlds most popular half marathon the Great North Run since it began in 1981.
7 Who built a castle in Newcastle in 1080?	Robert Curthose	1
8 What trade was the city an important center of in the 14th century?	wool	2
9 What resource was mined in the Newcastle area?	coal	2
10 What century was Newcastles port developed in?	16th century	3
11 What globally popular half marathon began in 1981?	the Great North Run	6
1 The first recorded settlement in what is now Newcastle was Pons Aelius a Roman fort and bridge across the River Tyne.
2 It was given the family name of the Roman Emperor Hadrian who founded it in the 2nd century AD.
3 This rare honour suggests that Hadrian may have visited the site and instituted the bridge on his tour of Britain.
4 The population of Pons Aelius at this period was estimated at 2000.
5 Fragments of Hadrians Wall are still visible in parts of Newcastle particularly along the West Road.
6 The course of the Roman Wall can be traced eastwards to the Segedunum Roman fort in Wallsend—the walls end—and to the supply fort Arbeia in South Shields.
7 The extent of Hadrians Wall was 73 miles 117 km spanning the width of Britain the Wall incorporated the Vallum a large rearward ditch with parallel mounds and was constructed primarily for defence to prevent unwanted immigration and the incursion of Pictish tribes from the north not as a fighting line for a major invasion.
8 What was the first recorded settlement in what became Newcastle?	Pons Aelius	1
9 What river was there originally a bridge across in Roman times?	Tyne	1
10 What was the estimated population of Pons Aelius around the 2nd century?	2 000	4
11 Whose wall has fragments visible in places around Newcastle even today?	Hadrians	5
12 What tribes were the Romans fearful would invade from the North?	Pictish	7
1 Throughout the Middle Ages Newcastle was Englands northern fortress.
2 Incorporated first by Henry II the city had a new charter granted by Elizabeth in 1589.
3 A 25foot 76 m high stone wall was built around the town in the 13th century to defend it from invaders during the Border war against Scotland.
4 The Scots king William the Lion was imprisoned in Newcastle in 1174 and Edward I brought the Stone of Scone and William Wallace south through the town.
5 Newcastle was successfully defended against the Scots three times during the 14th century and was created a county corporate with its own sheriff by Henry IV in 1400.
6 Newcastle served as a northern fortress for which country during the Middle Ages?	Englands	1
7 Who granted Newcastle a new charter in 1589?	Elizabeth	2
8 How high was the stone wall built around Newcastle in the 13th century?	25foot	3
9 What was the name of the King of the Scots?	William the Lion	4
10 How many times did Newcastle fight off the Scots during the 14th century?	three times	5
1 From 1530 a royal act restricted all shipments of coal from Tyneside to Newcastle Quayside giving a monopoly in the coal trade to a cartel of Newcastle burgesses known as the Hostmen.
2 This monopoly which lasted for a considerable time helped Newcastle prosper and develop into a major town.
3 The phrase taking coals to Newcastle was first recorded contextually in 1538.
4 The phrase itself means a pointless pursuit.
5 In the 18th century American Timothy Dexter an entrepreneur widely regarded as an eccentric defied this idiom.
6 He was persuaded to sail a shipment of coal to Newcastle by merchants plotting to ruin him however his shipment arrived on the Tyne during a strike that had crippled local production unexpectedly he made a considerable profit.
7 What did a 1530 royal act restrict shipments of?	coal	1
8 What was the cartel of Newcastle burgesses known as?	the Hostmen	1
9 What does the phrase taking coals to Newcastle mean?	a pointless pursuit	4
10 What was the American Timothy Dexter widely regarded as?	an eccentric	5
11 What did the merchants of Newcastle plot to do to Timothy Dexter?	ruin him	6
1 In the Sandgate area to the east of the city and beside the river resided the closeknit community of keelmen and their families.
2 They were so called because they worked on the keels boats that were used to transfer coal from the river banks to the waiting colliers for export to London and elsewhere.
3 In the 1630s about 7000 out of 20000 inhabitants of Newcastle died of plague more than onethird of the population.
4 Specifically within the year 1636 it is roughly estimated with evidence held by the Society of Antiquaries that 47 of the then population of Newcastle died from the epidemic this may also have been the most devastating loss in any British City in this period.
5 Who did the keelmen live with in a tightknight community east of Newcastle?	their families	1
6 How was coal transferred from the river banks to colliers?	boats	2
7 How many folks died of plague in Newcastle in the 1630s?	7 000	3
8 What percentage of Newcastles population was culled by the plague?	47	4
9 The epidemic in Newcastle was the most what in any British city at the time?	devastating loss	4
1 During the English Civil War the North declared for the King.
2 In a bid to gain Newcastle and the Tyne Cromwells allies the Scots captured the town of Newburn.
3 In 1644 the Scots then captured the reinforced fortification on the Lawe in South Shields following a siege.
4 In 1644 the city was then besieged for many months and was eventually stormed with roaring drummes and sacked by Cromwells allies.
5 The grateful King bestowed the motto Fortiter Defendit Triumphans Triumphing by a brave defence upon the town.
6 Charles I was imprisoned in Newcastle by the Scots in 1646–7.
7 Who did the North declare for during the English civil war?	the King	1
8 Who was Cromwells allies?	the Scots	2
9 What was roaring as Newcastle was stormed?	drummes	4
10 What does Fortiter Defendit Triumphans mean?	Triumphing by a brave defence	5
11 Who was imprisoned in Newcastle by the Scots in 1646 through 1647?	Charles I	6
1 In the 19th century shipbuilding and heavy engineering were central to the citys prosperity and the city was a powerhouse of the Industrial Revolution.
2 This revolution resulted in the urbanization of the city.
3 In 1817 the Maling company at one time the largest pottery company in the world moved to the city.
4 The Victorian industrial revolution brought industrial structures that included the 2 1⁄2mile 40 km Victoria Tunnelling built in 1842 which provided underground wagon ways to the staithes.
5 On 3 February 1879 Mosley Street in the city was the first public road in the world to be lit up by the incandescent lightbulb.
6 Newcastle was one of the first cities in the world to be lit up by electric lighting.
7 Innovations in Newcastle and surrounding areas included the development of safety lamps Stephensons Rocket Lord Armstrongs artillery BeRo flour Joseph Swans electric light bulbs and Charles Parsons invention of the steam turbine which led to the revolution of marine propulsion and the production of cheap electricity.
8 In 1882 Newcastle became the seat of an Anglican diocese with St Nicholas Church becoming its cathedral.
9 What did the Industrial Revolution cause to happen to Newcastle?	urbanization	2
10 What was the largest pottery company in the world in 1817?	the Maling company	3
11 Newcastle was one of the first cities in the world to have what innovation?	electric lighting	6
12 What were shipbuilding and engineering important to Newcastle for in the 19th century?	prosperity	1
13 What did Charles Parsons invent?	the steam turbine	7
1 In large parts Newcastle still retains a medieval street layout.
2 Narrow alleys or chares most of which can only be traversed by foot still exist in abundance particularly around the riverside.
3 Stairs from the riverside to higher parts of the city centre and the extant Castle Keep originally recorded in the 14th century remain intact in places.
4 Close Sandhill and Quayside contain modern buildings as well as structures dating from the 15th–18th centuries including Bessie Surtees House the Cooperage and Lloyds Quayside Bars Derwentwater House and House of Tides a restaurant situated at a Grade Ilisted 16th century merchants house at 28–30 Close.
5 What type of layout does Newcastles streets have in many parts?	medieval	1
6 What are chares?	Narrow alleys	2
7 What runs from the riverside to higher parts of the city center?	Stairs	3
8 What kind of buildings are in the towns of Close Sandhill and Quayside?	modern	4
9 What is the House of Tides?	a restaurant	4
1 The city has an extensive neoclassical centre referred to as Tyneside Classical largely developed in the 1830s by Richard Grainger and John Dobson and recently extensively restored.
2 Broadcaster and writer Stuart Maconie described Newcastle as Englands bestlooking city and the late Germanborn British scholar of architecture Nikolaus Pevsner describes Grey Street as one of the finest streets in England.
3 The street curves down from Greys Monument towards the valley of the River Tyne and was voted Englands finest street in 2005 in a survey of BBC Radio 4 listeners.
4 In the Google Street View awards of 2010 Grey Street came 3rd in the British picturesque category.
5 Osborne Road came 4th in the foodie street category.
6 A portion of Grainger Town was demolished in the 1960s to make way for the Eldon Square Shopping Centre including all but one side of the original Eldon Square itself.
7 What has recently undergone extensive restoration?	Tyneside Classical	1
8 What did John Dobson describe Newcastle as?	Englands bestlooking city	2
9 What street does Nikolaus Pevsner think is one of the finest in England?	Grey Street	2
10 When was a part of Grainger Town destroyed?	in the 1960s	6
11 What is in Eldon Square?	Shopping Centre	6
1 Another green space in Newcastle is the Town Moor lying immediately north of the city centre.
2 It is larger than Londons famous Hyde Park and Hampstead Heath put together and the freemen of the city have the right to graze cattle on it.
3 The right incidentally extends to the pitch of St James Park Newcastle United Football Clubs ground though this is not exercised although the Freemen do collect rent for the loss of privilege.
4 Honorary freemen include Bob Geldof King Harald V of Norway Bobby Robson Alan Shearer the late Nelson Mandela and the Royal Shakespeare Company.
5 The Hoppings funfair said to be the largest travelling funfair in Europe is held here annually in June.
6 Whats the name of the green space north of the center of Newcastle?	Town Moor	1
7 What an the freeman of Newcastle do with their cows on the Town Moor?	graze	2
8 What is said to be the largest travelling funfair in Europe?	The Hoppings funfair	5
9 When is the funfair held in Newcastle?	June	5
10 What honorary title does Bob Geldof hold?	freemen	4
1 Largescale regeneration has replaced former shipping premises with imposing new office developments an innovative tilting bridge the Gateshead Millennium Bridge was commissioned by Gateshead Council and has integrated the older Newcastle Quayside more closely with major cultural developments in Gateshead including the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art the venue for the Turner Prize 2011 and the Norman Fosterdesigned The Sage Gateshead music centre.
2 The Newcastle and Gateshead Quaysides are now a thriving cosmopolitan area with bars restaurants and public spaces.
3 As a tourist promotion Newcastle and Gateshead have linked together under the banner NewcastleGateshead to spearhead the regeneration of the NorthEast.
4 The River Tyne had the temporary Bambuco Bridge in 2008 for ten days it was not made for walking road or cycling but was just a sculpture.
5 What has replaced the former shipping premises?	Largescale regeneration	1
6 Who commissioned the Gateshead Milennium Bridge?	Gateshead Council	1
7 Who designed the Sage Gateshead music center?	Norman Foster	1
8 Why have Newcastle and Gateshead linked together under a common banner?	tourist promotion	3
9 How many days did the River Tyne have the Bambuco Bridge?	ten	4
1 The historic heart of Newcastle is the Grainger Town area.
2 Established on classical streets built by Richard Grainger a builder and developer between 1835 and 1842 some of Newcastle upon Tynes finest buildings and streets lie within this area of the city centre including Grainger Market Theatre Royal Grey Street Grainger Street and Clayton Street.
3 These buildings are predominantly four stories high with vertical dormers domes turrets and spikes.
4 Richard Grainger was said to have found Newcastle of bricks and timber and left it in stone.
5 Of Grainger Towns 450 buildings 244 are listed of which 29 are grade I and 49 are grade II.
6 What is the historic heart of Newcastle?	the Grainger Town area	1
7 When was Richard Grainger actively building and developing?	between 1835 and 1842	2
8 How high are many of the buildings with turrets?	four stories	3
9 How man of Grainger Towns 450 buildings are listed?	244	5
1 The Grainger Market replaced an earlier market originally built in 1808 called the Butcher Market.
2 The Grainger Market itself was opened in 1835 and was Newcastles first indoor market.
3 At the time of its opening in 1835 it was said to be one of the largest and most beautiful markets in Europe.
4 The opening was celebrated with a grand dinner attended by 2000 guests and the Laing Art Gallery has a painting of this event.
5 With the exception of the timber roof which was destroyed by a fire in 1901 and replaced by latticedsteel arches the Market is largely in its original condition.
6 The Grainger Market architecture like most in Grainger Town which are either grade I or II listed was listed grade I in 1954 by English Heritage.
7 What earlier market did the Grainger Market replace?	the Butcher Market	1
8 When did Newcastles first indoor market open?	1835	2
9 How many guests attended the dinner celebrating the opening of the Grainger Market?	2000	4
10 How is the opening of the Grainger Market documented in the Laing Art Gallery?	a painting	4
11 Who listed the Grainger Market architecture as grade 1 in 1954?	English Heritage	6
1 The climate in Newcastle is oceanic Köppen Cfb and significantly milder than some other locations in the world at a similar latitude due to the warming influence of the Gulf Stream via the North Atlantic Drift.
2 Being in the rain shadow of the North Pennines it is among the driest cities in the UK.
3 Temperature extremes recorded at Newcastle Weather Centre include 325 °C 905 °F during August 1990 down to −126 °C 93 °F during January 1982.
4 In contrast to other areas influenced by the Gulf Stream such as inland Scandinavia Newcastle has milder winters and cooler summers similar to the remainder of the British Isles.
5 Whats the climate like in Newcastle?	oceanic	1
6 What kind of influence does the Gulf Stream exert on Newcastle?	warming	1
7 What type of shadow does the North Pennines cast?	rain	2
8 When was the coldest temperature in Newcastle recorded?	January 1982	3
9 What area is Newcastles milder winters and cooler summers most similar to?	the British Isles	4
1 In 2010 Newcastle was positioned ninth in the retail centre expenditure league of the UK.
2 There are several major shopping areas in Newcastle City Centre.
3 The largest of these is the Eldon Square Shopping Centre one of the largest city centre shopping complexes in the UK.
4 It incorporates a flagship Debenhams store as well as one of the largest John Lewis stores in the UK.
5 John Lewis is still known to many in Newcastle as Bainbridges.
6 Newcastle store Bainbridges opened in 1838 is often cited as the world’s first department store.
7 Emerson Bainbridge 1817–1892 a pioneer and the founder of Bainbridges sold goods via department a new for merchant custom for that time.
8 The Bainbridge’s official ledgers reported revenue by department giving birth to the name department store.
9 Eldon Square is currently undergoing a full redevelopment.
10 A new bus station replacing the old underground bus station was officially opened in March 2007.
11 The wing of the centre including the undercover Green Market near Grainger Street was demolished in 2007 so that the area could be redeveloped.
12 This was completed in February 2010 with the opening of a flagship Debenhams department store as well as other major stores including Apple Hollister and Guess.
13 What year was Newcastle ninth in retail expenditures?	2010	1
14 What is one of the largest city center shopping complexes in the UK?	Eldon Square Shopping Centre 	3
15 What department store is thought to be the first in the world?	Bainbridges	6
16 How did Brainbridges official ledgers report revenue?	by department	8
17 What year was the new bus station in Newcastle officially opened?	2007	11
1 Other shopping destinations in Newcastle include Grainger Street and the area around Greys Monument the relatively modern Eldon Garden and Monument Mall complexes the Newgate Centre Central Arcade and the traditional Grainger Market.
2 Outside the city centre the largest suburban shopping areas are Gosforth and Byker.
3 The largest Tesco store in the United Kingdom is located in Kingston Park on the edge of Newcastle.
4 Close to Newcastle the largest indoor shopping centre in Europe the MetroCentre is located in Gateshead.

1 The Tyneside flat was the dominant housing form constructed at the time when the industrial centres on Tyneside were growing most rapidly.
2 They can still be found in areas such as South Heaton in Newcastle but once dominated the streetscape on both sides of the Tyne.
3 Tyneside flats were built as terraces one of each pair of doors led to an upstairs flat while the other led into the groundfloor flat each of two or three rooms.
4 A new development in the Ouseburn valley has recreated them Architects Cany Ash and Robert Sakula were attracted by the possibilities of high density without building high and getting rid of common areas.
5 What was the dominant housing template when industrial centres were growing the fastest?	The Tyneside flat	1
6 What were Tyneside flats built as?	terraces	3
7 Where is this housing style being developed recently?	the Ouseburn valley	4
8 What profession are Cany Ash and Robert Sakula?	Architects	4
9 What can be achieved without building high or getting rid of common areas?	high density	4
1 In terms of housing stock the authority is one of few authorities to see the proportion of detached homes rise in the 2010 Census to 78 in this instance this was coupled with a similar rise in flats and waterside apartments to 256 and the proportion of converted or shared houses in 2011 renders this dwelling type within the highest of the five colourcoded brackets at 59 and on a par with Oxford and Reading greater than Manchester and Liverpool and below a handful of historic densely occupied arguably overinflated markets in the local authorities Harrogate Cheltenham Bath inner London Hastings Brighton and Tunbridge Wells.

1 According to the UK Governments returned 2001 census information the city of Newcastle had a population of 189863 whereas the metropolitan borough of Newcastle had a population of around 259000.
2 Newcastle has a population of 282442 according to the Office for National Statistics.
3 The metropolitan boroughs of North Tyneside population circa 201000 South Tyneside population circa 148000 and Gateshead population circa 201000 are along with Newcastle all part of the Tyneside conurbation population circa 880000.
4 The metropolitan county of Tyne and Wear which consists of the four aforementioned boroughs as well as the City of Sunderland population circa 275000 had a population of around 1076000 and the Tyne and Wear City Region which also includes North Durham South East Northumberland and the Tyne Valley has a population of 1650000.
5 Newcastle is also home to a large student population with Newcastle and Northumbria Universities in the local area.
6 Areas with predominant student populations include Jesmond and Heaton.

1 According to the same statistics the average age of people living in Newcastle is 378 the national average being 386.
2 Many people in the city have Scottish or Irish ancestors.
3 There is a strong presence of Border Reiver surnames such as Armstrong Charlton Elliot Johnstone Kerr Hall Nixon Little and Robson.
4 There are also small but significant Chinese Jewish and Eastern European Polish Czech Roma populations.
5 There are also estimated to be between 500 and 2000 Bolivians in Newcastle forming up to 1 of the population—the largest such percentage of any UK city.
6 What is the average age of people who live in Newcastle?	378	1
7 Scottish or Irish describe the type of what people in Newcastle have?	ancestors	2
8 What type of surnames is their a strong presence of?	Border Reiver	3
9 What is the smallest number of Bolivians its estimated live in Newcastle?	500	5
10 What percentage of Newcastles population is it believed the Bolivians account for?	1	5
1 The dialect of Newcastle is known as Geordie and contains a large amount of vocabulary and distinctive word pronunciations not used in other parts of the United Kingdom.
2 The Geordie dialect has much of its origins in the language spoken by the AngloSaxon populations who migrated to and conquered much of England after the end of Roman Imperial rule.
3 This language was the forerunner of Modern English but while the dialects of other English regions have been heavily altered by the influences of other foreign languages—particularly Latin and Norman French—the Geordie dialect retains many elements of the old language.
4 An example of this is the pronunciation of certain words dead cow house and strong are pronounced deed coo hoos and strang—which is how they were pronounced in the AngloSaxon language.
5 Other Geordie words with AngloSaxon origins include larn from the AngloSaxon laeran meaning teach burn stream and gan go.
6 What is the dialect of Newcastle known as?	Geordie	1
7 Who conquered much of England after the end of Roman imperial rule?	AngloSaxon populations	2
8 What does the Geordie dialect keep of the older language which came before it?	many elements	3
9 Strang is an AngloSaxon word which means what in modern English?	strong	4
10 Would word means burn in the AngloSaxon language?	stream	5
1 Bairn and hyem meaning child and home respectively are examples of Geordie words with origins in Scandinavia barn and hjem are the corresponding modern Norwegian and Danish words.
2 Some words used in the Geordie dialect are used elsewhere in the Northern United Kingdom.
3 The words bonny meaning pretty howay come on stot bounce and hadaway go away or youre kidding all appear to be used in Scots aye yes and nowt IPAnaʊt rhymes with outnothing are used elsewhere in Northern England.
4 Many words however appear to be used exclusively in Newcastle and the surrounding area such as Canny a versatile word meaning good nice or very hacky dirty netty toilet hoy throw from the Dutch gooien via West Frisian hockle spit.
5 Bairn and hyem have origins from what culture?	Scandinavia	1
6 Where are some words from the Geordia dialect used?	Northern United Kingdom	2
7 What folks are likely to use words like howay and hadaway?	Scots	3
8 What appears to be used exclusively in Newcastle and surrounding areas?	Many words	4
9 What language does hoy originate from?	Dutch	4
1 In a report published in early February 2007 by the Ear Institute at the University College London and Widex a Danish hearing aid manufacturer Newcastle was named as the noisiest city in the whole of the UK with an average level of 804 decibels.
2 The report claimed that these noise levels would have a negative longterm impact on the health of the citys residents.
3 The report was criticized however for attaching too much weight to readings at arbitrarily selected locations which in Newcastles case included a motorway underpass without pedestrian access.
4 What was published in February of 2007?	a report	1
5 What was Newcastle named as the most type of city in the UK?	noisiest	1
6 Whats the average decibel level of noise in Newcastle?	804	1
7 What type of impact can the residents of Newcastle expect the citys noise to have on them?	negative	2
8 What was one location the noise readings in Newcastle were taken at?	a motorway underpass	3
1 There are concentrations of pubs bars and nightclubs around the Bigg Market and the Quayside area of the city centre.
2 There are many bars on the Bigg Market and other popular areas for nightlife are Collingwood Street popularly referred to as the Diamond Strip due to its concentration of highend bars Neville Street the Central Station area and Osborne Road in the Jesmond area of the city.
3 In recent years The Gate has opened in the city centre a new indoor complex consisting of bars upmarket clubs restaurants and a 12screen Empire multiplex cinema.
4 Newcastles gay scene  The Pink Triangle  is centred on the Times Square area near the Centre for Life and has a range of bars cafés and clubs.

1 The city has a proud history of theatre.
2 Stephen Kemble of the famous Kemble family successfully managed the original Theatre Royal Newcastle for fifteen years 1791–1806.
3 He brought members of his famous acting family such as Sarah Siddons and John Kemble out of London to Newcastle.
4 Stephen Kemble guided the theatre through many celebrated seasons.
5 The original Theatre Royal in Newcastle was opened on 21 January 1788 and was located on Mosley Street.
6 It was demolished to make way for Grey Street where its replacement was built.
7 What does Newcastle have a proud history of?	theatre	1
8 Who managed the original Theatre Royal in Newcastle?	Stephen Kemble	2
9 What did Stephen Kemble guide the Theatre Royal through?	many celebrated seasons	4
10 When did the theater in Newcastle originally open?	1788	5
11 On what street was the Theatre Royals replacement built?	Grey Street	6
1 The city still contains many theatres.
2 The largest the Theatre Royal on Grey Street first opened in 1837 designed by John and Benjamin Green.
3 It has hosted a season of performances from the Royal Shakespeare Company for over 25 years as well as touring productions of West End musicals.
4 The Mill Volvo Tyne Theatre hosts smaller touring productions whilst other venues feature local talent.
5 Northern Stage formally known as the Newcastle Playhouse and Gulbenkian Studio hosts various local national and international productions in addition to those produced by the Northern Stage company.
6 Other theatres in the city include the Live Theatre the Peoples Theatre and the Jubilee Theatre.
7 NewcastleGateshead was voted in 2006 as the arts capital of the UK in a survey conducted by the Artsworld TV channel.
8 What does Newcastle still contain many of?	theatres	1
9 What first opened in 1837?	the Theatre Royal	2
10 What company has been hosted at the Theatre Royal for over 25 years?	Royal Shakespeare	3
11 What do other smaller venues of Newcastle tend to feature?	local talent	4
12 What was NewcastleGateshead voted in 2006?	arts capital of the UK	7
1 The Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne popularly known as the Lit  Phil is the largest independent library outside London housing more than 150000 books.
2 Its music library contains 8000 CDs and 10000 LPs.
3 The current Lit and Phil premises were built in 1825 and the building was designed by John and Benjamin Green.
4 Operating since 1793 and founded as a ‘conversation club’ its lecture theatre was the first public building to be lit by electric light during a lecture by Joseph Swan on 20 October 1880.
5 What is the largest independent library outside of London?	The Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle	1

8 What was the first public building to be lit by electric light in Newcastle?	lecture theatre	4
9 Who lectured at the Newcastle library on the 20th of October in 1880?	Joseph Swan	4

4 The North East Art Expo a festival of art and design from the regions professional artists is held in late May.

1 The Hoppings reputedly the largest travelling fair in Europe takes place on Newcastle Town Moor every June.
2 The event has its origins in the Temperance Movement during the early 1880s and coincides with the annual race week at High Gosforth Park.
3 Newcastle Community Green Festival which claims to be the UKs biggest free community environmental festival also takes place every June in Leazes Park.
4 The Northern Rock Cyclone a cycling festival takes place within or starting from Newcastle in June.
5 The Northern Pride Festival and Parade is held in Leazes Park and in the citys Gay Community in mid July.
6 The Ouseburn Festival a family oriented weekend festival near the city centre incorporating a Family Fun Day and Carnival Day is held in late July.

8 When does the largest traveling fair in Europe take place?	every June	1

10 What type of festival is The Northern Rock Cyclone?	a cycling festival	4
11 Which festival is held in Newcastles Gay Community in midJuly?	The Northern Pride Festival	5
1 Newcastle Mela held on the late August bank holiday weekend is an annual twoday multicultural event blending drama music and food from Punjabi Pakistani Bengali and Hindu cultures.
2 NewcastleGateshead also holds an annual International Arts Fair.
3 The 2009 event will be in the Norman Foster designed Sage Gateshead Music and Arts Centre in September.
4 In October there is the Design Event festival—an annual festival providing the public with an opportunity to see work by regional national and international designers.
5 The SAMA Festival an East Asian cultural festival is also held in early October.

1 Lindisfarne are a folkrock group with a strong Tyneside connection.
2 Their most famous song Fog on the Tyne 1971 was covered by Geordie exfootballer Paul Gascoigne in 1990.
3 Venom reckoned by many to be the originators of black metal and extremely influential to the extreme metal scene as a whole formed in Newcastle in 1979.
4 Folk metal band Skyclad often regarded as the first folk metal band also formed in Newcastle after the breakup of Martin Walkyier thrash metal band Sabbat.
5 Andy Taylor former lead guitarist of Duran Duran was born here in 1961.
6 Brian Johnson was a member of local rock band Geordie before becoming the lead vocalist of ACDC.

1 The Pilgrim Street building was refurbished between November 2006 and May 2008 during the refurbishment works the cinema relocated to the Old Town Hall Gateshead.

1 The earliest known movie featuring some exterior scenes filmed in the city is On the Night of the Fire 1939 though by and large the action is studiobound.
2 Later came The Clouded Yellow 1951 and Payroll 1961 both of which feature more extensive scenes filmed in the city.
3 The 1971 film Get Carter was shot on location in and around Newcastle and offers an opportunity to see what Newcastle looked like in the 1960s and early 1970s.
4 The city was also backdrop to another gangster film the 1988 film noir thriller Stormy Monday directed by Mike Figgis and starring Tommy Lee Jones Melanie Griffith Sting and Sean Bean.
5 What is the earliest known movie featuring scenes filmed outdoors in Newcastle?	On the Night of the Fire	1
6 What 1971 film was shot on location in Newcastle?	Get Carter	3
7 What genre of film was the 1988 film Stormy Monday?	gangster	4
8 Who directed Stormy Monday?	Mike Figgis	4
9 What famous musician starred in Stormy Monday?	Sting	4
1 Newcastle has a horse racing course at Gosforth Park.
2 The city is also home to the Newcastle Eagles basketball team who play their home games at the new Sport Central complex at Northumbria University.
3 The Eagles are the most successful team in the history of the British Basketball League BBL.
4 The citys speedway team Newcastle Diamonds are based at Brough Park in Byker a venue that is also home to greyhound racing.
5 Newcastle also hosts the start of the annual Great North Run the worlds largest halfmarathon in which participants race over the Tyne Bridge into Gateshead and then towards the finish line 131 miles 211 km away on the coast at South Shields.
6 Another famous athletic event is the 59mile 95 km Blaydon Race a road race from Newcastle to Blaydon which has taken place on 9 June annually since 1981 to commemorate the celebrated Blaydon Races horse racing.
7 Where is Newcastles horse racing course located?	Gosforth Park	1
8 What is the name of Newcastles basketball team?	the Newcastle Eagles	2
9 Whats the name of Newcastles speedway team?	Newcastle Diamonds	4
10 Where can you see greyhound racing in Newcastle?	Brough Park	4
11 What famous 59mile athletic event takes place annually in Newcastle in June?	Blaydon Race	6
1 Newcastle International Airport is located approximately 6 miles 97 km from the city centre on the northern outskirts of the city near Ponteland and is the larger of the two main airports serving the North East.
2 It is connected to the city via the Metro Light Rail system and a journey into Newcastle city centre takes approximately 20 minutes.
3 The airport handles over five million passengers per year and is the tenth largest and the fastest growing regional airport in the UK expecting to reach 10 million passengers by 2016 and 15 million by 2030.
4 As of 2007update over 90 destinations are available worldwide.
5 How far is Newcastles airport from the center of town?	6 miles	1
6 How is Newports airport connected to the city?	Metro Light Rail system	2
7 How long does it take to get to the middle of Newcastle from its outskirts when riding the rails?	20 minutes	2
8 How many passengers per year does Newcastles airport handle?	over five million	3
9 How many destinations are available worldwide from Newcastles airport?	over 90	4
1 In 2014 work was completed on the stations historic entrance.
2 Glazing was placed over the historic arches and the Victorian architecture was enhanced transforming the 19th century public portico.
3 The station is one of only six Grade One listed railway stations in the UK.
4 Opened in 1850 by Queen Victoria it was the first covered railway station in the world and was much copied across the UK.
5 It has a neoclassical façade originally designed by the architect John Dobson and was constructed in collaboration with Robert Stephenson.
6 The station sightlines towards the Castle Keep whilst showcasing the curvature of the station’s arched roof.
7 The first services were operated by the North Eastern Railway company.
8 The citys other mainline station Manors is to the east of the city centre.
9 What was enhanced in 2014?	Victorian architecture	2
10 How many Grade One listed railway stations are in the UK?	six	3
11 What Queen opened the first covered railway station in the world?	Victoria	4
12 Who constructed Newcastles station?	Robert Stephenson	5
13 What mainline station is to the east of the city center?	Manors	8
1 Train operator Virgin Trains East Coast provides a halfhourly frequency of trains to London Kings Cross with a journey time of about three hours these services call at Durham Darlington York Doncaster Newark North Gate and Peterborough and north to Scotland with all trains calling at Edinburgh and a small number of trains extended to Glasgow Aberdeen and Inverness.
2 CrossCountry trains serve destinations in Yorkshire the Midlands and the South West.
3 First TransPennine Express operates services to Manchester and Liverpool.
4 Northern Rail provides local and regional services.
5 How often do trains journey to Kings Cross?	halfhourly	1
6 How many hours can one expect to ride the train from Newcastle to Kings Cross?	about three	1
7 Where do all trains going to Scotland stop at?	Edinburgh	1
8 Whose trains serve destinations in Yorkshire?	CrossCountry	2
9 Which train company provides local and regional services?	Northern Rail	4
1 The city is served by the Tyne and Wear Metro a system of suburban and underground railways covering much of Tyne and Wear.
2 It was opened in five phases between 1980 and 1984 and was Britains first urban light rail transit system two extensions were opened in 1991 and 2002.
3 It was developed from a combination of existing and newly built tracks and stations with deeplevel tunnels constructed through Newcastle city centre.
4 A bridge was built across the Tyne between Newcastle and Gateshead and opened by Queen Elizabeth II in 1981.
5 The network is operated by DB Regio on behalf of Nexus and carries over 37 million passengers a year extending as far as Newcastle Airport Tynemouth South Shields and South Hylton in Sunderland.
6 In 2004 the company Marconi designed and constructed the mobile radio system to the underground Metro system.
7 The Metro system was the first in the UK to have mobile phone antennae installed in the tunnels.
8 What underground railways cover much of Tyne and Wear?	Tyne and Wear Metro	1
9 How many phases was the Metro opened in between 1980 and 1984?	five	2
10 What type of tunnels are constructed through Newcastles city center?	deeplevel	3
11 What did Queen Elizabeth II open in Newcastle in 1981?	A bridge	4
12 How many passengers a year does the rail network in Newcastle carry?	over 37 million	5
1 The system is currently undergoing a period of refurbishment and modernization entitled Metro All Change.
2 The programme has replaced all ticket machines and introduced ticket gates at the busiest stations  part of the transition to smart ticketing.
3 All Metro trains are being completely refurbished and most stations are undergoing improvement works or in some cases complete reconstruction for example North Shields.
4 In addition tracks signalling and overhead wires are also being overhauled.
5 Longer term plans include the procurement of an entirely new fleet of trains and further extensions to the system.
6 Proposed routes include to Newcastles west end to the Cobalt business park in North Tyneside to the Metrocentre in Gateshead and to additional locations in Gateshead South Tyneside and Sunderland.
7 Several of the proposed routes would require trams as opposed to the current light rail trains.
8 What is the name of the current refurbishment the system is undergoing?	Metro All Change	1
9 What does the replacement of the ticket machines and introduction of ticket gates herald the transition to?	smart ticketing	2
10 What is being overhauled as part of the improvement works?	tracks  signalling and overhead wires	4
11 What will be obtained as part of longer term plans for improvements to Newcastles train system?	an entirely new fleet of trains	5
12 What type of train would some of the proposed new routes require?	trams	7
1 Major roads in the area include the A1 Gateshead Newcastle Western Bypass stretching north to Edinburgh and south to London the A19 heading south past Sunderland and Middlesbrough to York and Doncaster the A69 heading west to Carlisle the A696 which becomes the A68 heads past Newcastle Airport and up through central Northumberland and central Scottish Borders the A167 the old Great North Road heading south to Gateshead ChesterleStreet Durham and Darlington and the A1058 Coast Road which runs from Jesmond to the east coast between Tynemouth and Cullercoats.
2 Many of these designations are recent—upon completion of the Western Bypass and its designation as the new line of the A1 the roads between this and the A1s former alignment through the Tyne Tunnel were renumbered with many city centre roads changing from a 6prefix to their present 1prefix numbers.
3 In November 2011 the capacity of the Tyne Tunnel was increased when a project to build a second road tunnel and refurbish the first tunnel was completed.
4 What major Newcastle road stretches from Edinburgh to London?	the A1	1
5 What Newcastle road heads west to Carlisle?	the A696	1
6 Whats the nickname for Newcastles A167?	the old Great North Road	1
7 What was renumbered in Newcastle upon completion of the Western Bypass?	the roads	2
8 What was increased in November 2011?	the capacity of the Tyne Tunnel	3
1 There are 3 main bus companies providing services in the city Arriva North East Go North East and Stagecoach North East.
2 There are two major bus stations in the city Haymarket bus station and Eldon Square bus station.
3 Arriva mainly operates from Haymarket Bus Station providing the majority of services to the north of Newcastle Northumberland and North Tyneside.
4 GoAhead operates from Eldon Square Bus Station providing the majority of services south of the river in Gateshead South Tyneside Sunderland and County Durham.
5 Stagecoach is the primary operator in the city proper with crosscity services mainly between both the West and East ends via the city centre with some services extending out to the MetroCentre Killingworth Wallsend and Ponteland.
6 Bus Services in Newcastle upon Tyne and the surrounding boroughs part of the Tyne and Wear area are coordinated by Nexus the Tyne and Wear Passenger Transport Executive.
7 How many bus companies provide service to the city of Newcastle?	3	1
8 How many major bus stations are in the city of Newcastle?	two	2
9 Who is Newcastles primary bus operator in the city proper?	Stagecoach	5
10 What is Nexus?	the Tyne and Wear Passenger Transport Executive	6
11 What bus company in Newcastle provides the majority of services south of the river?	GoAhead	4
1 Following guidelines set in the National Cycling strategy Newcastle first developed its cycling strategy in 1998.
2 As of 2012 the local council social aims and objectives for cycling include highlighting the usage of cycling to cut city congestion educating that cycling promotes healthy living… The authority also has infrastructure aims and objectives which include developing on road cycle networks on quieter streets making safer routes on busier streets innovating and implementing contraflows on one way streets developing the existing off road cycle route networks and improve signage joining up routes that are partially or completely isolated Increase the number of cycle parking facilities working with employers to integrate cycling into workplace travel plans link the local networks to national networks.
3 What year did Newcastle first develop its cycling strategy?	1998	1
4 What does the local council hope will help cut down traffic congestion in Newcastle?	highlighting the usage of cycling	2
5 What type of living does cycling promote?	healthy	2
6 What streets are contraflows to be implemented on in Newcastle?	one way	2
7 What would the local council of Newcastle like to link their local bike networks to?	national networks	2
1 From Newcastle International Ferry Terminal at North Shields Danish DFDS Seaways run a service to IJmuiden near Amsterdam.
2 The DFDS ferry service to Gothenburg Sweden ceased at the end of October 2006 – the company cited high fuel prices and new competition from lowcost air services as the cause – and their service to Bergen and Stavanger Norway was terminated late 2008.
3 Since summer 2007 Thomson cruise lines have included Newcastle as a departure port on its Norwegian and Fjords cruise.
