1 By 1954 all US networks had regained control of their programming with higher advertising revenues ABCs revenue increased by 67 earning 26 million NBCs went up by 30 100 million and CBSs rose by 44 117 million.
2 However that year ABC had only 14 primary affiliates compared to the 74 that carried the majority of CBS programs and the 71 that were primarily affiliated with NBC.
3 Most markets outside the largest ones were not large enough to support three fulltime network affiliates.
4 In some markets that were large enough for a third fulltime affiliate the only available commercial allocation was on the lessdesirable UHF band.
5 Until the AllChannel Receiver Act passed by Congress in 1961 mandated the inclusion of UHF tuning most viewers needed to purchase a converter to be able to watch UHF stations and the signal quality was marginal at best even with a converter.
6 Additionally during the analog television era UHF stations were not adequately receivable in rugged terrain.
7 These factors made many prospective station owners skittish about investing in a UHF station especially one that would have had to take on an affiliation with a weaker network.
8 How many primary affiliates did ABC have in 1954?	14	2
9 How many primary affiliates did CBS have in 1954?	74	2
10 What important legislation was passed by Congress for the television industry in 1961?	AllChannel Receiver Act	5
11 The AllChannel Receiver Act mandated the support of what kind of tuning?	UHF tuning	5
1 As a result with the exception of the largest markets ABC was relegated to secondary status on one or both of the existing stations usually via offhours clearances a notable exception during this time was WKSTTV in Youngstown Ohio now WYTV despite the small size of the surrounding market and its close proximity to Cleveland and Pittsburgh even decades before the citys economic collapse.
2 According to Goldenson this meant that an hour of ABC programming reported five times lower viewership than its competitors.
3 However the networks intake of money at the time would allow it to accelerate its content production.
4 Still ABCs limited reach would continue to hobble it for the next two decades several smaller markets would not grow large enough to support a fulltime ABC affiliate until the 1960s with some very small markets having to wait as late as the 1980s or even the advent of digital television in the 2000s which allowed stations like WTRFTV in Wheeling West Virginia to begin airing ABC programming on a digital subchannel after airing the networks programs outside of recommended timeslots decades before.
5 ABC had secondary status on the existing stations in what Ohio town?	Youngstown	1
6 Relegation to secondary status for ABC resulted in viewership how much lower than their competitors according to Goldenson?	five times lower viewership	2
7 The beginnings of digital television allowed what affiliate in Wheeling West Virginia to begin airing ABC programs digitally?	WTRFTV	4
8 Very small markets had to wait until what decade to support an ABC affiliate?	1980s	4
1 On September 3 1958 the Disneyland anthology series was retitled Walt Disney Presents as it became disassociated with the theme park of the same name.
2 The movement in westerns which ABC is credited for having started represented a fifth of all primetime series on American television in January 1959 at which point detective shows were beginning to rise in popularity as well.
3 ABC requested additional productions from Disney.
4 In late 1958 Desilu Productions pitched its detective series The Untouchables to CBS after that network rejected the show because of its use of violence Desilu then presented it to ABC which agreed to pick up the show and debuted The Untouchables in April 1959.
5 The series went on to quickly become immensely popular.
6 What was the Disneyland anthology series retitled in 1958?	Walt Disney Presents	1
7 What production company pitched The Untouchables to CBS in 1958?	Desilu Productions	4
8 Why did CBS turn down the pitch for The Untouchables?	its use of violence	4
9 When did the Untouchables debut on ABC?	April 1959	4
1 Due to pressure from film studios wanting to increase their production as the major networks began airing theatrically released films ABC joined CBS and NBC in broadcasting films on Sunday nights in 1962 with the launch of the ABC Sunday Night Movie which debuted a year behind its competitors and was initially presented in blackandwhite.
2 Despite a significant increase in viewership with its audience share having increased to 33 from the 15 share it had in 1953 ABC remained in third place the company had a total revenue of 155 million a third of the revenue pulled in by CBS at the same period.
3 To catch up ABC followed up The Flintstones with another animated series from HannaBarbera The Jetsons which debuted on September 23 1962 as the first television series to be broadcast in color on the network.
4 On April 1 1963 ABC debuted the soap opera General Hospital which would go on to become the television networks longrunning entertainment program.
5 That year also saw the premiere of The Fugitive on September 17 a drama series centering on a man on the run after being accused of committing a murder he did not commit.
6 What was the title of ABCs broadcast film program that debuted on Sundays in 1962?	ABC Sunday Night Movie	1
7 What was ABCs revenue in 1962?	155 million	2
8 What production company produced the animated series The Flintstones for ABC?	HannaBarbera	3
9 What was the first series to be televised in color on ABC?	The Jetsons	3
10 When did General Hospital first debut on ABC?	April 1  1963	4
1 On December 7 1965 Goldenson announced a merger proposal with ITT to ABC management the two companies agreed to the deal on April 27 1966.
2 The FCC approved the merger on December 21 1966 however the previous day December 20 Donald F Turner head antitrust regulator for the United States Department of Justice expressed doubts related to such issues as the emerging cable television market and concerns over the journalistic integrity of ABC and how it could be influenced by the overseas ownership of ITT.
3 ITT management promised that the company would allow ABC to retain autonomy in the publishing business.
4 The merger was suspended and a complaint was filed by the Department of Justice in July 1967 with ITT going to trial in October 1967 the merger was officially canceled after the trials conclusion on January 1 1968.
5 Leonard Goldenson announced a merger proposal with what company in December 1965?	ITT	1
6 What anitrust regulator had doubts about the ITT and ABC merger?	Donald F Turner	2
7 The merger between ITT and ABC was suspended after a complaint was filed by whom in July 1967?	Department of Justice	4
8 When was the merger between ITT and ABC officially canceled?	January 1  1968	4
1 In December 1984 Thomas S Murphy chief executive officer of Capital Cities Communications contacted Leonard Goldenson about a proposal to merge their respective companies.
2 On March 16 1985 ABCs executive committee accepted the merger offer which was formally announced on March 18 1985 with Capital Cities purchasing ABC and its related properties for 35 billion and 118 for each of ABCs shares as well as a guarantee of 10 or 3 for a total of 121 per share.
3 To finance the purchase Capital Cities borrowed 21 billion from a consortium of banks which sold certain assets that Capital Cites could not acquire or retain due to FCC ownership rules for a combined 900 million and sold off several cable television systems which were sold to The Washington Post Company forming the presentday Cable One.
4 The remaining 500 million was loaned by Warren Buffett who promised that his company Berkshire Hathaway would purchase 3 million in shares at 17250 apiece.
5 Due to an FCC ban on samemarket ownership of television and radio stations by a single company although the deal would have otherwise complied with new ownership rules implemented by the FCC in January 1985 that allowed broadcasters to own a maximum of 12 television stations ABC and Capital Cities respectively decided to sell WXYZTV and Tampa independent station WFTSTV to the E W Scripps Company although Capital CitiesABC originally intended to seek a crossownership waiver to retain WXYZ and Capital Citiesowned radio stations WJR and WHYT.
6 In 1984 Thomas Murphy contacted Leonard Goldenson about merging ABC with what company?	Capital Cities Communications	1
7 How much did Capital Cities Communications purchase ABC and its properties for?	35 billion	2
8 500 Million was supplied for the Capital City  ABC merger by what investor?	Warren Buffett	4
9 Capital City and ABC sold the WXYZTV and WFTSTV stations to what company?	E W Scripps Company	5
10 New ownership rules by the FCC in 1985 allowed broadcasters to own a maximum of how many stations?	12 television stations	5
1 The merger between ABC and Capital Cities received federal approval on September 5 1985.
2 After the ABCCapital Cities merger was finalized on January 3 1986 the combined company – which became known as Capital CitiesABC Inc – added four television stations WPVITVPhiladelphia KTRKTVHouston KFSNTVFresno and WTVDRaleigh and several radio stations to ABCs broadcasting portfolio and also included Fairchild Publications and four newspapers including The Kansas City Star and Fort Worth StarTelegram.
3 It also initiated several changes in its management Frederick S Pierce was named president of ABCs broadcasting division Michael P Millardi became vice president of ABC Broadcasting and president of ABC Owned Stations and ABC Video Enterprises John B Sias was appointed president of the ABC Television Network Brandon Stoddard became president of ABC Entertainment a position to which he had been appointed in November 1985 and Roone Arledge became president of ABC News and ABC Sports.
4 In February 1986 Thomas S Murphy who had been serving as CEO of Capital Cities since 1964 was appointed chairman and CEO emeritus of ABC.
5 Jim Duffy stepped down as ABC Television president for a management position at ABC Communications a subsidiary that specialized in community service programming including shows related to literary education.
6 When did the merger between ABC and Capital Cities gain federal approval?	September 5  1985	1
7 After the merger between ABC and Capital Cities was completed what was the resulting company known as?	Capital CitiesABC  Inc	2
8 After the Capital Cities  ABC merger Frederick Pierce was named to what position?	president of ABCs broadcasting division	3
9 After the merger between ABC and Capital Cities who became the vice president of ABC broadcasting?	Michael P Millardi	3
10 In the wake of the ABC and Capital Cities merger who was the president of ABC News and ABC Sports?	Roone Arledge	3
1 As far as programming is concerned four of ABCs marquee shows of the 1970s ended their runs during the mid1980s Laverne  Shirley ended its run in 1983 Happy Days and Threes Company ended in 1984 with the latter producing a shortlived spinoff that year while The Love Boat ended its run in 1986.
2 After nearly a decade of ratings trouble NBC had regained the ratings lead among the Big Three networks in 1984 on the success of series such as The Cosby Show Cheers and Miami Vice.
3 To counteract NBC ABC decided to refocus itself on comedies and familyoriented series beginning in the mid1980s including Mr Belvedere Roseanne Whos the Boss Just the Ten of Us The Wonder Years Full House and Perfect Strangers.
4 Which sitcom ended its broadcast run for ABC in 1983?	Laverne  Shirley	1

6 Which network regained the ratings lead in America in 1984?	NBC	2
7 What comedy for ABC ended its broadcast run in 1986?	The Love Boat	1
8 ABC began to focus on what kind of series after NBCs success in 1984?	comedies and familyoriented series	3

1 In 1968 ABC took advantage of new FCC ownership regulations that allowed broadcasting companies to own a maximum of seven radio stations nationwide in order to purchase Houston radio stations KXYZ and KXYZFM for 1 million in shares and 15 million in bonds.
2 That year Roone Arledge was named president of ABC Sports the company also founded ABC Pictures a film production company which released its first picture that year the Ralph Nelsondirected Charly.
3 It was renamed ABC Motion Pictures in 1979 the unit was dissolved in 1985.
4 The studio also operated two subsidiaries Palomar Pictures International and Selmur Pictures.
5 In July 1968 ABC continued its acquisitions in the amusement parks sector with the opening of ABC Marine World in Redwood City California that park was sold in 1972 and demolished in 1986 with the land that occupied the park later becoming home to the headquarters of Oracle Corporation.
6 New broadcast regulations from the FCC in 1968 allowed companies to own a maximum of how many radio stations?	seven radio stations	1
7 What was the first picture released by ABC Pictures?	Charly	2
8 Who was the film Charly produced by?	Ralph Nelson	2
9 When was the ABC Pictures division eventually dissolved?	1985	3
10 Where was ABC Marine World opened?	Redwood City  California	5
1 It was not until the late 1950s that the ABC network became a serious contender to NBC and CBS and this was in large part due to the diverse range of programming that met the expectations of the public such as westerns and detective series.
2 Despite an almost 500 increase in advertising revenues between 1953 and 1958 the network only had a national reach of between 10 and 18 of the total US population as it still had relatively fewer affiliates than NBC and CBS.
3 In 1957 ABC Entertainment president Ollie Treiz discovered that the locally produced variety show Bandstand had pulled very strong ratings in the Philadelphia market on WFILTV Treiz ultimately negotiated a deal to take the show national under the revised title American Bandstand the show quickly became a social phenomenon by presenting new musical talent and dances to Americas youth and helped make a star out of its host Dick Clark.
4 What kind of programs can be credited for ABCs success in the late 1950s?	westerns and detective series	1
5 How much did advertising revenue increase for ABC between 1953 and 1958?	500	2
6 What was the national viewership reach of ABC in 1958?	between 10 and 18	2
7 Who was the ABC Entertainment president in 1957?	Ollie Treiz	3
8 Who hosted the bandstand show debuted on ABC in 1957?	Dick Clark	3
1 These kinds of programs presented ABC with an image of the philosophy of counterprogramming against its competitors offering a strong lineup of programs that contrasted with those seen on its rival networks which helped Goldenson give the network a continuum between film and television.
2 ABCs western series as well as series such as the actioner Zorro went up against and defeated the variety shows aired by NBC and CBS in the fall of 1957 and its detective shows did the same in the fall of 1959.
3 To captivate the networks audiences short 66minute series were scheduled a halfhour before their hourlong competition.
4 In May 1961 Life criticized the public enthusiasm and sponsorship for these types of shows at the expense of news programming and denounced an unofficial law replacing the good programs with the bad ones.
5 What was the programming philosophy pioneered by ABC and Goldenson?	counterprogramming	1
6 What ABC action series went up against NBCs variety shows in Fall 1957?	Zorro	2
7 What magazine criticized ABCs programming strategy in May 1961?	Life	4
8 What kind of shows were used as counterprogramming by ABC in the Fall of 1959?	detective shows	2
1 In May 2013 ABC launched WATCH ABC a revamp of its traditional multiplatform streaming services encompassing the networks existing streaming portal at ABCcom and a mobile app for smartphones and tablet computers in addition to providing fulllength episodes of ABC programs the service allows live programming streams of local ABC affiliates in select markets the first such offering by a US broadcast network.
2 Similar to sister network ESPNs WatchESPN service which originated the WATCH brand used by the streaming services of Disneys television networks live streams of ABC stations are only available to authenticated subscribers of participating pay television providers in certain markets.
3 New York City OO WABCTV and Philadelphia OO WPVITV were the first stations to offer streams of their programming on the service with a free preview for nonsubscribers through June 2013 with the six remaining ABC OOs offering streams by the start of the 2013–14 season.
4 Hearst Television also reached a deal to offer streams of its ABC affiliates including stations in Boston Kansas City Milwaukee and West Palm Beach on the service.
5 What service did ABC launch in May 2013?	WATCH ABC	1
6 What were the first local stations to offer streams of their programming on WATCH ABC?	New York City OO WABCTV and Philadelphia OO WPVITV	3
7 What company reached a deal to also stream its ABC affiliates?	Hearst Television	4
8 What is the name of ESPNs streaming service that is analogous to WATCH ABC?	WatchESPN	2
1 The Sinclair Broadcast Group is the largest operator of ABC stations by numerical total owning or providing services to 28 ABC affiliates and two additional subchannelonly affiliates Sinclair owns the largest ABC subchannel affiliate by market size WABMDT2WDBBDT2 in the Birmingham market which serve as repeaters of WBMALD the largest lowpower Big Four affiliate by market size which itself is also simulcast on a subchannel of former WBMA satellite WGWW owned by Sinclair partner company Howard Stirk Holdings.
2 The E W Scripps Company is the largest operator of ABC stations in terms of overall market reach owning 15 ABCaffiliated stations including affiliates in larger markets such as Cleveland Phoenix Detroit and Denver and through its ownership of Phoenix affiliate KNXV Las Vegas affiliate KTNVTV and Tucson affiliate KGUNTV the only provider of ABC programming for the majority of Arizona outside of the YumaEl Centro market and Southern Nevada.

1 The network has the unusual distinction of having separately owned and operated affiliates which serve the same market in Tampa Florida WFTSTV and WWSB and Grand Rapids Michigan WZZM and WOTV with an analogous situation arising in Kansas City Missouri KMBCTV and KQTV.
2 KQTV is licensed to St Joseph Missouri which is designated by Nielsen as a separate market from Kansas City despite being located within 55 miles 89 km of one another while WWSB and WOTV serve areas that do not receive an adequate signal from their markets primary ABC affiliate in the case of WWSB this dates back to when WTSP was Tampas primary ABC affiliate prior to 1994 with the former being necessitated to serve the southern part of the Tampa market including the stations city of license Sarasota due to WTSPs transmitter being shortspaced to avoid interfering with the analog signal of Miami affiliate WPLG – which like WTSP broadcast on VHF channel 10.
3 What are the two ABC affiliates for Tampa Florida?	WFTSTV and WWSB	1

5 What are the two ABC affiliates for Grand Rapids Michigan?	WZZM and WOTV	1
6 What was Tampas primary ABC affiliate prior to 1994?	WTSP	2
1 He came to power by uniting many of the nomadic tribes of Northeast Asia.
2 After founding the Mongol Empire and being proclaimed Genghis Khan he started the Mongol invasions that resulted in the conquest of most of Eurasia.
3 These included raids or invasions of the Qara Khitai Caucasus Khwarezmid Empire Western Xia and Jin dynasties.
4 These campaigns were often accompanied by wholesale massacres of the civilian populations – especially in the Khwarezmian and Xia controlled lands.
5 By the end of his life the Mongol Empire occupied a substantial portion of Central Asia and China.
6 What do we call the empire that Genghis Khan founded?	the Mongol Empire	2
7 Who did Genghis Khan unite before he began conquering the rest of Eurasia?	many of the nomadic tribes of Northeast Asia	1
8 In which regions in particular did Genghis Khans armies massacre civilians?	Khwarezmian and Xia controlled lands	4
9 What areas did Genghis Khan control at the end of his life?	a substantial portion of Central Asia and China	5
10 Which other empires or dynasties did Genghis Khan conquer?	the Qara Khitai  Caucasus  Khwarezmid Empire  Western Xia and Jin dynasties	3
1 Before Genghis Khan died he assigned Ögedei Khan as his successor and split his empire into khanates among his sons and grandsons.
2 He died in 1227 after defeating the Western Xia.
3 He was buried in an unmarked grave somewhere in Mongolia at an unknown location.
4 His descendants extended the Mongol Empire across most of Eurasia by conquering or creating vassal states out of all of modernday China Korea the Caucasus Central Asia and substantial portions of modern Eastern Europe Russia and Southwest Asia.
5 Many of these invasions repeated the earlier largescale slaughters of local populations.
6 As a result Genghis Khan and his empire have a fearsome reputation in local histories.
7 Who did Genghis Khan assign as his successor?	Ögedei Khan	1
8 What year did Genghis Khan die?	1227	2
9 Which empire was the last one Genghis Khan conquered before he died?	Western Xia	2
10 Among whom was Genghis Khans empire split after his death?	his sons and grandsons	1
11 Where was Genghis Khan buried?	somewhere in Mongolia at an unknown location	3
1 Temüjin was probably born in 1162 in Delüün Boldog near Burkhan Khaldun mountain and the Onon and Kherlen rivers in modernday northern Mongolia not far from the current capital Ulaanbaatar.
2 The Secret History of the Mongols reports that Temüjin was born with a blood clot grasped in his fist a traditional sign that he was destined to become a great leader.
3 He was the secondoldest son of his father Yesügei a Khamag Mongols major chief of the Kiyad and an ally of Toghrul Khan of the Keraite tribe and the oldest son of his mother Hoelun.
4 According to the Secret History Temüjin was named after a Tatar chieftain Temüjinüge whom his father had just captured.
5 Where was Genghis Khan likely born?	Delüün Boldog	1
6 Who was Genghis Khans father?	Yesügei  a Khamag Mongols major chief of the Kiyad	3
7 What year was Temüjin who became Genghis Khan likely born?	1162	1
8 Who might Temüjin have been named after?	a Tatar chieftain  Temüjinüge  whom his father had just captured	4
1 Temüjin had three brothers named Hasar Hachiun and Temüge and one sister named Temülen as well as two halfbrothers named Begter and Belgutei.
2 Like many of the nomads of Mongolia Temüjins early life was difficult.
3 His father arranged a marriage for him and at nine years of age he was delivered by his father to the family of his future wife Börte who was a member of the tribe Khongirad.
4 Temüjin was to live there in service to Dai Setsen the head of the new household until he reached the marriageable age of 12.
5 What was Temüjin sisters name?	Temülen	1
6 Who were Temüjins three full brothers?	Hasar  Hachiun  and Temüge	1
7 What was the name of the wife arranged for Temüjin by his father?	Börte	3
8 Which tribe did Temüjin move in with at nine years of age?	Khongirad	3
9 Who was the head of the household that Temüjin joined when he was nine years old?	Dai Setsen	4
1 For the next several years Hoelun and her children lived in poverty surviving primarily on wild fruits and ox carcasses marmots and other small game killed by Temüjin and his brothers.
2 Begter Temujins older halfbrother began to exercise the power of the eldest male in the family and eventually Temujins mother Hoelun not Begters mother would have to accept him as her husband if and when he became an adult.
3 Temujins resentment erupted during one hunting excursion that Temüjin and his brother Khasar killed their halfbrother Begter.
4 Which of Temüjins brothers took up the role of male leader of the family?	Begter	2
5 Who would Begter have married when he came of age?	Hoelun	2
6 Who killed Begter Temüjins halfbrother?	Temüjin and his brother Khasar	3
7 When was Temüjins halfbrother Begter killed?	during one hunting excursion	3
1 In another incident around 1177 he was captured in a raid and held prisoner by his fathers former allies the Tayichiud.
2 The Tayichiud enslaved Temüjin reportedly with a cangue a sort of portable stocks but with the help of a sympathetic guard the father of Chilaun who later became a general of Genghis Khan he was able to escape from the ger yurt in the middle of the night by hiding in a river crevice.
3 citation needed It was around this time that Jelme and Boorchu two of Genghis Khans future generals joined forces with him.
4 Temüjins reputation also became widespread after his escape from the Tayichiud.
5 Who captured and held Temüjin prisoner around 1177?	the Tayichiud	1
6 How was Temüjin kept imprisoned by the Tayichiud?	with a cangue  a sort of portable stocks	2
7 Which of his future generals fathers helped Temüjin escape the Tayichiud?	Chilaun	2
8 Which of his future generals joined forces with Temüjin around the time of his escape from the Tayichiud?	Jelme and Boorchu	3
9 Where did Temüjin hide during his escape from the Tayichiud?	a river crevice	2
1 At this time none of the tribal confederations of Mongolia were united politically and arranged marriages were often used to solidify temporary alliances.
2 Temüjin grew up observing the tough political climate of Mongolia which included tribal warfare thievery raids corruption and continual acts of revenge carried out between the various confederations all compounded by interference from foreign forces such as the Chinese dynasties to the south.
3 Temüjins mother Hoelun taught him many lessons about the unstable political climate of Mongolia especially the need for alliances.
4 What was used to from political alliances among the Mongolian tribal confederations?	arranged marriages	1
5 Who taught Temüjin early lessons about politics in Mongolia?	Temüjins mother Hoelun	3
6 Which foreign forces often meddled in the Mongolian political scene?	the Chinese dynasties to the south	2
7 What did Temüjins mother emphasize in his lessons about Mongolias volatile political climate?	the need for alliances	3
1 As previously arranged by his father Temüjin married Börte of the Onggirat tribe when he was around 16 in order to cement alliances between their respective tribes.
2 Soon after Börtes marriage to Temüjin she was kidnapped by the Merkits and reportedly given away as a wife.
3 Temüjin rescued her with the help of his friend and future rival Jamukha and his protector Toghrul Khan of the Keraite tribe.
4 She gave birth to a son Jochi 1185–1226 nine months later clouding the issue of his parentage.
5 Despite speculation over Jochi Börte would be Temüjins only empress though he did follow tradition by taking several morganatic wives.
6 What was the tribe of the woman Temüjin married when he was around 16 years old?	the Onggirat	1
7 Who kidnapped Temüjins first wife soon after they were married?	the Merkits	2
8 Who helped Temüjin rescue his wife from the Merkits?	Jamukha  and his protector  Toghrul Khan of the Keraite tribe	3
9 What was the name of Temüjins wife Börtes first son?	Jochi	4
10 What year did Börtes give birth to Jochi?	1185	4
1 Börte had three more sons Chagatai 1187—1241 Ögedei 1189—1241 and Tolui 1190–1232.
2 Genghis Khan also had many other children with his other wives but they were excluded from the succession.
3 While the names of sons were documented daughters were not.
4 The names of at least six daughters are known and while they played significant roles behind the scenes during his lifetime no documents have survived that definitively provide the number or names of daughters born to the consorts of Genghis Khan.
5 How many sons did Börte bear Genghis Khan after Jochi?	three	1
6 What was the name of Börtes second male child?	Chagatai	1
7 What year did two of Ghengis Khan and Börtes sons die?	1241	1
8 Which male child of Ghengis Khan and Börte was born last?	Tolui	1
9 How many names of Ghengis Khans daughters are known?	six	4
1 Temüjin began his ascent to power by offering himself as an ally or according to other sources a vassal to his fathers anda sworn brother or blood brother Toghrul who was Khan of the Keraites and is better known by the Chinese title Wang Khan which the Jurchen Jin dynasty granted him in 1197.
2 This relationship was first reinforced when Börte was captured by the Merkits.
3 Temüjin turned to Toghrul for support and in response Toghrul offered his vassal 20000 of his Keraite warriors and suggested that he also involve his childhood friend Jamukha who had himself become Khan ruler of his own tribe the Jadaran.
4 What is an anda?	sworn brother or blood brother	1
5 With whom was Temüjins first important alliance?	Toghrul	1
6 What tribe did Toghrul lead?	the Keraites	1
7 How many warriors did Toghrul provide Temüjin when his wife was captured?	20 000	3
8 Which of Temüjins childhood friends did Toghrul suggest he also enlist?	Jamukha	3
1 As Jamukha and Temüjin drifted apart in their friendship each began consolidating power and soon became rivals.
2 Jamukha supported the traditional Mongolian aristocracy while Temüjin followed a meritocratic method and attracted a broader though lower class range of followers.
3 Due to his earlier defeat of the Merkits and a proclamation by the shaman Kokochu that the Eternal Blue Sky had set aside the world for Temüjin Temüjin began rising to power.
4 In 1186 Temüjin was elected khan of the Mongols.
5 However Jamukha threatened by Temüjins rapid ascent quickly moved to stop Temüjins ambitions.
6 In 1187 he launched an attack against his former friend with an army of thirty thousand troops.
7 Temüjin hastily gathered together his followers to defend against the attack but he was decisively beaten in the Battle of Dalan Balzhut.
8 Jamukha horrified people greatly and harmed his image by boiling seventy young male captives alive in cauldrons alienating many of his potential followers and eliciting sympathy for Temüjin.
9 Toghrul as Temüjins patron was exiled to the Qara Khitai.
10 The life of Temüjin for the next ten years is very unclear as historical records are mostly silent on that period.
11 Who did Jamukha support that were not part of Temüjins power base?	the traditional Mongolian aristocracy	2
12 Which shamans proclamation aided Temüjins rise?	Kokochu	3
13 When was Temüjin elected khan of the Mongols?	1186	4
14 Which battle did Temüjin lose to Jamukha shortly after his election as khan?	Battle of Dalan Balzhut	7
15 Where was Temüjins patron Toghrul exiled?	Qara Khitai	9
1 As an incentive for absolute obedience and following his rule of law the Yassa code Temüjin promised civilians and soldiers wealth from future possible war spoils.
2 As he defeated rival tribes he did not drive away enemy soldiers and abandon the rest.
3 Instead he took the conquered tribe under his protection and integrated its members into his own tribe.
4 He would even have his mother adopt orphans from the conquered tribe bringing them into his family.
5 These political innovations inspired great loyalty among the conquered people making Temüjin stronger with each victory.
6 What was the name of Temüjins laws?	the Yassa code	1
7 What did Temüjin promise his followers in exchange for their obedience?	wealth from future possible war spoils	1
8 Who did Temüjins mother adopt to help integrate the tribes he conquered?	orphans from the conquered tribe	4
9 What did Temüjin offer the people he conquered in order earn their loyalty?	his protection	3
1 One of the later ruptures between Toghrul and Temüjin was Toghruls refusal to give his daughter in marriage to Jochi the eldest son of Temüjin a sign of disrespect in the Mongolian culture.
2 This act led to the split between both factions and was a prelude to war.
3 Toghrul allied himself with Jamukha who already opposed Temüjins forces however the internal dispute between Toghrul and Jamukha plus the desertion of a number of their allies to Temüjin led to Toghruls defeat.
4 Jamukha escaped during the conflict.
5 This defeat was a catalyst for the fall and eventual dissolution of the Keraite tribe.
6 To whom did Toghrul refuse to give his daughter in marriage angering Temüjin?	Jochi	1
7 Who did Toghrul join in a campaign against Temüjin?	Jamukha	3
8 Who escaped when Temüjin emerged victorious in his conflict with Toghrul?	Jamukha	4
9 What tribe fell apart after Temüjin defeated Toghrul?	the Keraite	5
1 The next direct threat to Temüjin was the Naimans Naiman Mongols with whom Jamukha and his followers took refuge.
2 The Naimans did not surrender although enough sectors again voluntarily sided with Temüjin.
3 In 1201 a khuruldai elected Jamukha as Gür Khan universal ruler a title used by the rulers of the Qara Khitai.
4 Jamukhas assumption of this title was the final breach with Temüjin and Jamukha formed a coalition of tribes to oppose him.
5 Before the conflict however several generals abandoned Jamukha including Subutai Jelmes wellknown younger brother.
6 After several battles Jamukha was finally turned over to Temüjin by his own men in 1206.
7 Who protected Jamukha after he escaped the conflict with Temüjin?	the Naimans	1
8 What year was Jamukha elected Gür Khan?	1201	3
9 What does the title Gür Khan mean?	universal ruler	3
10 Which wellknown general abandoned Jamukhas coalition against Temüjin?	Subutai	5
11 What year was Jamukha surrendered to Temüjin?	1206	657
1 According to the Secret History Temüjin again offered his friendship to Jamukha asking him to return to his side.
2 Temüjin had killed the men who betrayed Jamukha stating that he did not want disloyal men in his army.
3 Jamukha refused the offer of friendship and reunion saying that there can only be one sun in the sky and he asked for a noble death.
4 The custom is to die without spilling blood which is granted by breaking the back.
5 Jamukha requested this form of death despite the fact that in the past Jamukha had been known to have boiled his opponents generals alive.
6 What did Temüjin offer Jamukha after the latters defeat?	his friendship	1
7 Why did Temüjin kill those of Jamukhas followers that had betrayed their leader?	he did not want disloyal men in his army	2
8 What did Jamukha request from Temüjin instead of friendship?	a noble death	3
9 What form of death did Jamukha hope Temüjin would allow him?	breaking the back	4
1 Accounts of Genghis Khans life are marked by claims of a series of betrayals and conspiracies.
2 These include rifts with his early allies such as Jamukha who also wanted to be a ruler of Mongol tribes and Wang Khan his and his fathers ally his son Jochi and problems with the most important shaman who was allegedly trying to drive a wedge between him and his loyal brother Khasar.
3 His military strategies showed a deep interest in gathering good intelligence and understanding the motivations of his rivals exemplified by his extensive spy network and Yam route systems.
4 He seemed to be a quick student adopting new technologies and ideas that he encountered such as siege warfare from the Chinese.
5 He was also ruthless demonstrated by his tactic of measuring against the linchpin used against the tribes led by Jamukha.
6 From whom did Genghis Khan learn seige warfare?	the Chinese	4
7 Which rivals tribes did Genghis Khan famously measure against the linchpin?	Jamukha	5
8 An important shaman was alleged to be trying to distance Genghis Khan from which of his brothers?	Khasar	2
9 What aspect of the economy did Genghis Khan exploit for intelligence gathering?	Yam route systems	3
10 Who was the ally of his father that Genghis Khan fell out as time passed?	Wang Khan	2
1 As a result by 1206 Temüjin had managed to unite or subdue the Merkits Naimans Mongols Keraites Tatars Uyghurs and other disparate smaller tribes under his rule.
2 It was a monumental feat for the Mongols as they became known collectively.
3 At a Khuruldai a council of Mongol chiefs Temüjin was acknowledged as Khan of the consolidated tribes and took the new title Genghis Khan.
4 The title Khagan was not conferred on Genghis until after his death when his son and successor Ögedei took the title for himself and extended it posthumously to his father as he was also to be posthumously declared the founder of the Yuan dynasty.
5 This unification of all confederations by Genghis Khan established peace between previously warring tribes and a single political and military force under Genghis Khan.
6 By what year had Temüjin created a significant Mongol tribal alliance?	1206	1
7 What is the term for a meeting of Mongol chiefs?	Khuruldai	3
8 What title was given to Genghis Khan posthumously?	Khagan	4
9 Who gave Genghis Khan the title Khadan?	Ögedei	4
10 Who made Temüjin khan of the Mongols?	a council of Mongol chiefs	3
1 In 1211 after the conquest of Western Xia Genghis Khan planned again to conquer the Jin dynasty.
2 The commander of the Jin dynasty army made a tactical mistake in not attacking the Mongols at the first opportunity.
3 Instead the Jin commander sent a messenger MingTan to the Mongol side who defected and told the Mongols that the Jin army was waiting on the other side of the pass.
4 At this engagement fought at Badger Pass the Mongols massacred hundreds of thousands of Jin troops.
5 In 1215 Genghis besieged captured and sacked the Jin capital of Zhongdu modernday Beijing.
6 This forced the Emperor Xuanzong to move his capital south to Kaifeng abandoning the northern half of his kingdom to the Mongols.
7 Between 1232 and 1233 Kaifeng fell to the Mongols under the reign of Genghis third son Ögedei Khan.
8 The Jin dynasty collapsed in 1234 after the siege of Caizhou.
9 What dynasty did Genghis Khan plan to attack after conquering Western Xia?	the Jin dynasty	1
10 Who was the Jin dynasty defector who betrayed the location of the Jin army?	MingTan	3
11 When did Genghis Khan capture the Jin dynasty capital?	1215	5
12 Where did the Jin emporer relocate his capital after Genghis Khan overran the norther part of his empire?	Kaifeng	6
13 Which of Genghis Khans sons completed the conquest of the Jin dynasty?	Ögedei Khan	7
1 Kuchlug the deposed Khan of the Naiman confederation that Temüjin defeated and folded into his Mongol Empire fled west and usurped the khanate of Qara Khitai also known as the Western Liao as it was originally established as remnants of the Liao dynasty.
2 Genghis Khan decided to conquer the Qara Khitai and defeat Kuchlug possibly to take him out of power.
3 By this time the Mongol army was exhausted from ten years of continuous campaigning in China against the Western Xia and Jin dynasty.
4 Therefore Genghis sent only two tumen 20000 soldiers against Kuchlug under his younger general Jebe known as The Arrow.
5 Who took control of Qara Khitai after fleeing Temüjins Mongol Empire?	Kuchlug	1
6 What older dynasty was replaced by the Western Liao or Qara Khitai?	the Liao dynasty	1
7 How many soldiers did Genghis Khan send against Kuchlug and Qara Khitai?	20 000	4
8 Which young general did Genghis Khan send to conquer Qara Khitai?	Jebe	4
9 What other moniker was Genghis Khans general Jebe known by?	The Arrow	4
1 With such a small force the invading Mongols were forced to change strategies and resort to inciting internal revolt among Kuchlugs supporters leaving the Qara Khitai more vulnerable to Mongol conquest.
2 As a result Kuchlugs army was defeated west of Kashgar.
3 Kuchlug fled again but was soon hunted down by Jebes army and executed.
4 By 1218 as a result of defeat of Qara Khitai the Mongol Empire and its control extended as far west as Lake Balkhash which bordered the Khwarezmia Khwarezmid Empire a Muslim state that reached the Caspian Sea to the west and Persian Gulf and the Arabian Sea to the south.
5 What strategy did Jebes army use against Kuchlug and his supporters?	inciting internal revolt	1
6 Where did Jebes forces first defeat Kuchlug?	west of Kashgar	2
7 How far west did the Mongol Empire extend after Kuchlugs demise?	Lake Balkhash	4
8 Which empire bordered the Mongol Empire to the west in 1218?	Khwarezmid Empire	4
9 What kind of state was the Khwarezmia?	a Muslim state	4
1 In the early 13th century the Khwarazmian dynasty was governed by Shah Ala adDin Muhammad.
2 Genghis Khan saw the potential advantage in Khwarezmia as a commercial trading partner using the Silk Road and he initially sent a 500man caravan to establish official trade ties with the empire.
3 However Inalchuq the governor of the Khwarezmian city of Otrar attacked the caravan that came from Mongolia claiming that the caravan contained spies and therefore was a conspiracy against Khwarezmia.
4 The situation became further complicated because the governor later refused to make repayments for the looting of the caravans and handing over the perpetrators.
5 Genghis Khan then sent again a second group of three ambassadors two Mongols and a Muslim to meet the Shah himself instead of the governor Inalchuq.
6 The Shah had all the men shaved and the Muslim beheaded and sent his head back with the two remaining ambassadors.
7 This was seen as an affront and insult to Genghis Khan.
8 Outraged Genghis Khan planned one of his largest invasion campaigns by organizing together around 100000 soldiers 10 tumens his most capable generals and some of his sons.
9 He left a commander and number of troops in China designated his successors to be his family members and likely appointed Ögedei to be his immediate successor and then went out to Khwarezmia.
10 Who was the leader of the Khwarezmian dynasty in the early 1200s?	Shah Ala adDin Muhammad	1
11 Who ordered the attack on the caravan of traders Genghis Khan send to Khwarezmia?	Inalchuq	3
12 Which of Genghis Khans ambassadors did the Shah have beheaded?	the Muslim	6
13 How many soldiers did Genghis Khan take with him to Khwarezmia?	100 000	8
14 What trading route joined Khwarezmia and the Mongol Empire?	the Silk Road	2
1 The Mongol army under Genghis Khan generals and his sons crossed the Tien Shan mountains by entering the area controlled by the Khwarezmian Empire.
2 After compiling intelligence from many sources Genghis Khan carefully prepared his army which was divided into three groups.
3 His son Jochi led the first division into the northeast of Khwarezmia.
4 The second division under Jebe marched secretly to the southeast part of Khwarzemia to form with the first division a pincer attack on Samarkand.
5 The third division under Genghis Khan and Tolui marched to the northwest and attacked Khwarzemia from that direction.
6 What mountain range did Genghis Khan cross to enter the Khwarezmian Empire?	Tien Shan	1
7 How many divisions comprised Genghis Khans army in Khwarezmia?	three	2
8 Where did Jebes division of Genghis Khans army campaign in Khwarezmia?	the southeast	4
9 Who led the third division in Khwarezmia alongside Genghis Khan himself?	Tolui	5
10 Which area of Khwarezmia did the first and second divisions of the Mongol army target in a pincer attack?	Samarkand	4
1 The Shahs army was split by diverse internecine feuds and by the Shahs decision to divide his army into small groups concentrated in various cities.
2 This fragmentation was decisive in Khwarezmias defeats as it allowed the Mongols although exhausted from the long journey to immediately set about defeating small fractions of the Khwarzemi forces instead of facing a unified defense.
3 The Mongol army quickly seized the town of Otrar relying on superior strategy and tactics.
4 Genghis Khan ordered the wholesale massacre of many of the civilians enslaved the rest of the population and executed Inalchuq by pouring molten silver into his ears and eyes as retribution for his actions.
5 Near the end of the battle the Shah fled rather than surrender.
6 Genghis Khan ordered Subutai and Jebe to hunt him down giving them 20000 men and two years to do this.
7 The Shah died under mysterious circumstances on a small island within his empire.
8 What feature of the Shahs army enable the weary Mongol forces easy early victories?	fragmentation	2
9 Which towns massacre did Genghis Khan order in retribution for the treatment of his envoys?	Otrar	3
10 What metal was used in Inalchuqs execution?	silver	4
11 What did the Shah do when faced with defeat by Genghis Khans forces?	fled	5
12 Who did Genghis Khan charge with finding and punishing the Shah?	Subutai and Jebe	6
1 The Mongols conquest even by their own standards was brutal.
2 After the capital Samarkand fell the capital was moved to Bukhara by the remaining men while Genghis Khan ordered two of his generals and their forces to completely destroy the remnants of the Khwarezmid Empire including not only royal buildings but entire towns populations and even vast swaths of farmland.
3 According to legend Genghis Khan even went so far as to divert a river through the Khwarezmid emperors birthplace erasing it from the map.
4 citation needed.
5 What was the capital of Khwarezmia before the Mongol invasion?	Samarkand	2
6 Where was the Khwarezmid capital moved after Genghis Khans forces prevailed in Samarkand?	Bukhara	2
7 What does legend say Genghis Khan used to obliterate the Kharezmid emporers place of birth?	a river	3
1 The Mongols attacked Samarkand using captured enemies as body shields.
2 After several days only a few remaining soldiers loyal supporters of the Shah held out in the citadel.
3 After the fortress fell Genghis supposedly reneged on his surrender terms and executed every soldier that had taken arms against him at Samarkand.
4 The people of Samarkand were ordered to evacuate and assemble in a plain outside the city where they were killed and pyramids of severed heads raised as a symbol of victory.
5 AtaMalik Juvayni a high official in the service of the Mongol empire wrote that in Termez on the Oxus all the people both men and women were driven out onto the plain and divided in accordance with their usual custom then they were all slain.
6 What did the Mongols shield themselves with while attacking Samarkand?	captured enemies	1
7 How did Genghis Khan observed the surrender terms after Samarkand fell?	reneged	3
8 What victory symbols did the Mongols build on the plains outside Samarkand?	pyramids of severed heads	4
1 The city of Bukhara was not heavily fortified with a moat and a single wall and the citadel typical of Khwarezmi cities.
2 The city leaders opened the gates to the Mongols though a unit of Turkish defenders held the citys citadel for another twelve days.
3 Survivors from the citadel were executed artisans and craftsmen were sent back to Mongolia young men who had not fought were drafted into the Mongolian army and the rest of the population was sent into slavery.
4 As the Mongol soldiers looted the city a fire broke out razing most of the city to the ground.
5 Genghis Khan had the citys surviving population assemble in the main mosque of the town where he declared that he was the flail of God sent to punish them for their sins.
6 How did the leaders of the city of Bukhara respond to the Mongol attack?	opened the gates	2
7 Who continued to hold the citadel of Bukhara after the Mongols took the rest of the city?	a unit of Turkish defenders	2
8 Which residents of Bukhara were spared and sent back to Mongolia?	artisans and craftsmen	3
9 How did Genghis Khan describe himself to the people of Bukhara?	the flail of God	5
10 Who among the population of Bukhara became part of the Mongolian army?	young men who had not fought	3
1 After the defeat of the Khwarezmian Empire in 1220 Genghis Khan gathered his forces in Persia and Armenia to return to the Mongolian steppes.
2 Under the suggestion of Subutai the Mongol army was split into two forces.
3 Genghis Khan led the main army on a raid through Afghanistan and northern India towards Mongolia while another 20000 two tumen contingent marched through the Caucasus and into Russia under generals Jebe and Subutai.
4 They pushed deep into Armenia and Azerbaijan.
5 The Mongols destroyed the kingdom of Georgia sacked the Genoese tradefortress of Caffa in Crimea and overwintered near the Black Sea.
6 Heading home Subutais forces attacked the allied forces of the Cuman–Kipchaks and the poorly coordinated 80000 Kievan Rus troops led by Mstislav the Bold of Halych and Mstislav III of Kiev who went out to stop the Mongols actions in the area.
7 Subutai sent emissaries to the Slavic princes calling for a separate peace but the emissaries were executed.
8 At the Battle of Kalka River in 1223 Subutais forces defeated the larger Kievan force.
9 They also may have fought against the neighboring Volga Bulgars.
10 There is no historical record except a short account by the Arab historian Ibn alAthir writing in Mosul some 1100 miles away from the event.
11 Various historical secondary sources  Morgan Chambers Grousset  state that the Mongols actually defeated the Bulgars Chambers even going so far as to say that the Bulgars had made up stories to tell the recently crushed Russians that they had beaten the Mongols and driven them from their territory.
12 The Russian princes then sued for peace.
13 Subutai agreed but was in no mood to pardon the princes.
14 As was customary in Mongol society for nobility the Russian princes were given a bloodless death.
15 Subutai had a large wooden platform constructed on which he ate his meals along with his other generals.
16 Six Russian princes including Mstislav III of Kiev were put under this platform and crushed to death.
17 What year did the Khwarezmian Empire fall to Genghis Khan?	1220	1
18 Whose plan called for the Mongolian army to split in two after the Khwarezmian conquest?	Subutai	2
19 Where did Jebe and Subutai spend the winter following the split of the Mongol army?	near the Black Sea	5
20 Where was the Kievian force that confronted Subutais army defeated in 1223?	Kalka River	8
21 Who led the Kievian Rus troops against Subutais Mongol army?	Mstislav the Bold of Halych and Mstislav III of Kiev	6
1 The Mongols learned from captives of the abundant green pastures beyond the Bulgar territory allowing for the planning for conquest of Hungary and Europe.
2 Genghis Khan recalled Subutai back to Mongolia soon afterwards and Jebe died on the road back to Samarkand.
3 The famous cavalry expedition led by Subutai and Jebe in which they encircled the entire Caspian Sea defeating all armies in their path remains unparalleled to this day and word of the Mongol triumphs began to trickle to other nations particularly Europe.
4 These two campaigns are generally regarded as reconnaissance campaigns that tried to get the feel of the political and cultural elements of the regions.
5 In 1225 both divisions returned to Mongolia.
6 These invasions added Transoxiana and Persia to an already formidable empire while destroying any resistance along the way.
7 Later under Genghis Khans grandson Batu and the Golden Horde the Mongols returned to conquer Volga Bulgaria and Kievan Rus in 1237 concluding the campaign in 1240.
8 Which Mongol leader completed the conquest of Kievan Rus?	Batu	7
9 By what name was the Mongol army that finally conquered Bulgaria known?	the Golden Horde	7
10 Which two Mongol leaders added Persia to the Mongol Empire?	Subutai and Jebe	3
11 When did Subutais army return to Mongolia?	1225	5
12 Where did Jebe die?	on the road back to Samarkand	2
1 In 1226 immediately after returning from the west Genghis Khan began a retaliatory attack on the Tanguts.
2 His armies quickly took Heisui Ganzhou and Suzhou not the Suzhou in Jiangsu province and in the autumn he took Xiliangfudisambiguation needed.
3 One of the Tangut generals challenged the Mongols to a battle near Helan Mountains but was defeated.
4 In November Genghis laid siege to the Tangut city Lingzhou and crossed the Yellow River defeating the Tangut relief army.
5 According to legend it was here that Genghis Khan reportedly saw a line of five stars arranged in the sky and interpreted it as an omen of his victory.
6 In which year did Genghis Khan strike against the Tanguts?	1226	1
7 What season was it when Genghis Khan took Xiliangfu from the Tanguts?	autumn	2
8 Who won the battle near the Helan mountains?	the Mongols	3
9 What river did Genghis Khan cross before defeating the main Tangut army?	the Yellow River	4
10 What omen was Genghis Khan reported to have seen assuring his coming victory against the Tanguts?	a line of five stars arranged in the sky	5
1 In 1227 Genghis Khans army attacked and destroyed the Tangut capital of Ning Hia and continued to advance seizing Lintiaofu Xining province Xindufu and Deshun province in quick succession in the spring.
2 At Deshun the Tangut general Ma Jianlong put up a fierce resistance for several days and personally led charges against the invaders outside the city gate.
3 Ma Jianlong later died from wounds received from arrows in battle.
4 Genghis Khan after conquering Deshun went to Liupanshan Qingshui County Gansu Province to escape the severe summer.
5 The new Tangut emperor quickly surrendered to the Mongols and the rest of the Tanguts officially surrendered soon after.
6 Not happy with their betrayal and resistance Genghis Khan ordered the entire imperial family to be executed effectively ending the Tangut lineage.
7 What was the name of the Tangut capital?	Ning Hia	1
8 Who was the Tangut general who fought Genghis Khan at Deshun?	Ma Jianlong	2
9 What weapon caused the wounds that killed Tangut general Ma Jianlong?	arrows	3
10 Where did Genghis Khan spend the summer after taking Deshun?	Liupanshan	4
11 What did Genghis Khan do to the Tangut imperial family after their surrender?	executed	6
1 The succession of Genghis Khan was already a significant topic during the later years of his reign as he reached old age.
2 The long running paternity discussion about Genghis oldest son Jochi was particularly contentious because of the seniority of Jochi among the brothers.
3 According to traditional historical accounts the issue over Jochis paternity was voiced most strongly by Chagatai.
4 In The Secret History of the Mongols just before the invasion of the Khwarezmid Empire by Genghis Khan Chagatai declared before his father and brothers that he would never accept Jochi as Genghis Khans successor.
5 In response to this tension and possibly for other reasons Ögedei was appointed as successor.
6 The paternity of which of Genghis Khans sons was disputed?	Jochi	2
7 Which Mongol leader was most opposed to Jochi as Genghis Khans successor?	Chagatai	4
8 Before which military campaign did Chagatai publicly dispute Jochis paternity?	invasion of the Khwarezmid Empire	4
9 Who was appointed Genghis Khans successor?	Ögedei	5
1 Genghis Khan was aware of the friction between his sons particularly between Chagatai and Jochi and worried of possible conflict between them if he died.
2 He therefore decided to divide his empire among his sons and make all of them Khan in their own right while appointing one of his sons as his successor.
3 Chagatai was considered unstable due to his temper and rash behavior because of statements he made that he would not follow Jochi if he were to become his fathers successor.
4 Tolui Genghis Khans youngest son was not to be his successor because he was the youngest and in the Mongol culture youngest sons were not given much responsibility due to their age.
5 If Jochi were to become successor it was likely that Chagatai would engage in warfare with him and collapse the empire.
6 Therefore Genghis Khan decided to give the throne to Ögedei.
7 Ögedei was seen by Genghis Khan as dependable in character and relatively stable and down to earth and would be a neutral candidate and might defuse the situation between his brothers.
8 Which pair of Genghis Khans sons were most rivalrous?	Chagatai and Jochi	1
9 Which of Genghis Khans sons was disqualified from being successor because of his unstable behavior?	Chagatai	3
10 Whichs of Genghis Khans successors could not be successor because of his age?	Tolui	4
11 Which son did Genghis Khan view as his most dependable one?	Ögedei	7
1 Jochi died in 1226 during his fathers lifetime.
2 Some scholars notably Ratchnevsky have commented on the possibility that Jochi was secretly poisoned by an order from Genghis Khan.
3 Rashid alDin reports that the great Khan sent for his sons in the spring of 1223 and while his brothers heeded the order Jochi remained in Khorasan.
4 Juzjani suggests that the disagreement arose from a quarrel between Jochi and his brothers in the siege of Urgench.
5 Jochi had attempted to protect Urgench from destruction as it belonged to territory allocated to him as a fief.
6 He concludes his story with the clearly apocryphal statement by Jochi Genghis Khan is mad to have massacred so many people and laid waste so many lands.
7 I would be doing a service if I killed my father when he is hunting made an alliance with Sultan Muhammad brought this land to life and gave assistance and support to the Muslims.
8 Juzjani claims that it was in response to hearing of these plans that Genghis Khan ordered his son secretly poisoned however as Sultan Muhammad was already dead in 1223 the accuracy of this story is questionable.
9 Jochis death occurred in what year?	1226	1
10 Where did Jochi remain after Genghis Khan sent for his sons in the spring of 1223?	Khorasan	3
11 Which territory did Jochi try to protect that may have led to a dispute with his brothers?	Urgench	4
12 Who did Jochi reportedly enlist to help him stop his fathers massacres?	Sultan Muhammad	7
13 Why is Jochis reported alliance with the Muslims historically suspect?	Sultan Muhammad was already dead in 1223	8
1 In August 1227 during the fall of Yinchuan the capital of Western Xia Genghis Khan died.
2 The exact cause of his death remains a mystery and is variously attributed to being killed in action against the Western Xia illness falling from his horse or wounds sustained in hunting or battle.
3 According to The Secret History of the Mongols Genghis Khan fell from his horse while hunting and died because of the injury.
4 He was already old and tired from his journeys.
5 The Galician–Volhynian Chronicle alleges he was killed by the Western Xia in battle while Marco Polo wrote that he died after the infection of an arrow wound he received during his final campaign.
6 Later Mongol chronicles connect Genghis death with a Western Xia princess taken as war booty.
7 One chronicle from the early 17th century even relates the legend that the princess hid a small dagger and stabbed him though some Mongol authors have doubted this version and suspected it to be an invention by the rival Oirads.
8 Genghis Khan was in the process of taking what capital city when he died?	Yinchuan	1
9 What does the Secret History say Genghis Khan was doing when he sustained his mortal injuries?	hunting	3
10 What weapon did Marco Pole report as the cause of Genghis Khans death?	arrow	5
11 Later chronicles of Genghis Khans death implicate a princess from what empire in his death?	Western Xia	6
12 Which rival of the Mongols is suspected of inventing the story that Genghis Khan was murdered by a captured princess?	Oirads	7
1 Years before his death Genghis Khan asked to be buried without markings according to the customs of his tribe.
2 After he died his body was returned to Mongolia and presumably to his birthplace in Khentii Aimag where many assume he is buried somewhere close to the Onon River and the Burkhan Khaldun mountain part of the Kentii mountain range.
3 According to legend the funeral escort killed anyone and anything across their path to conceal where he was finally buried.
4 The Genghis Khan Mausoleum constructed many years after his death is his memorial but not his burial site.
5 What was Genghis Khans tribes burial custom?	without markings	1
6 Where is Genghis Khans presumed to have been delivered?	Khentii Aimag	2
7 What river is near Genghis Khans likely place of burial?	Onon River	2
8 What memorial was built years after Genghis Khans death and burial?	The Genghis Khan Mausoleum	4
1 In 1939 Chinese Nationalist soldiers took the mausoleum from its position at the Lords Enclosure Mongolian Edsen Khoroo in Mongolia to protect it from Japanese troops.
2 It was taken through Communistheld territory in Yanan some 900 km on carts to safety at a Buddhist monastery the Dongshan Dafo Dian where it remained for ten years.
3 In 1949 as Communist troops advanced the Nationalist soldiers moved it another 200 km farther west to the famous Tibetan monastery of Kumbum Monastery or Taer Shi near Xining which soon fell under Communist control.
4 In early 1954 Genghis Khans bier and relics were returned to the Lords Enclosure in Mongolia.
5 By 1956 a new temple was erected there to house them.
6 In 1968 during the Cultural Revolution Red Guards destroyed almost everything of value.
7 The relics were remade in the 1970s and a great marble statue of Genghis was completed in 1989.
8 What is the Mongolian name for the original place of the Genghis Khan mausoleum?	Edsen Khoroo	1
9 Which Buddhist monastery hosted the Genghis Khan mausoleum during the Japanese occupation?	Dongshan Dafo Dian	2
10 Where did the Chinese Nationalists move the mausoleum away from advancing Chinese Communist forces?	Kumbum Monastery or Taer Shi near Xining	3
11 When was the mausoleum returned to the Lords Enclosure in Mongolia?	1954	4
12 Who destroyed the most valuable relics in the mausoleum during the Cultural Revolution?	Red Guards	6
1 On October 6 2004 a joint JapaneseMongolian archaeological dig uncovered what is believed to be Genghis Khans palace in rural Mongolia which raises the possibility of actually locating the rulers longlost burial site.
2 Folklore says that a river was diverted over his grave to make it impossible to find the same manner of burial as the Sumerian King Gilgamesh of Uruk and Atilla the Hun.
3 Other tales state that his grave was stampeded over by many horses and that trees were then planted over the site and the permafrost also did its part in hiding the burial site.
4 On which date was Genghis Khans palace rediscovered by archeaologists?	October 6  2004	1
5 What kind of water body is rumored to be obscuring Genghis Khans burial site?	a river	2
6 What two other rulers had their graves hidden under a river?	Sumerian King Gilgamesh of Uruk and Atilla the Hun	2
7 What animals may have been stampeded over Genghis Khans grave site?	horses	3
1 The Mongol Empire was governed by a civilian and military code called the Yassa created by Genghis Khan.
2 The Mongol Empire did not emphasize the importance of ethnicity and race in the administrative realm instead adopting an approach grounded in meritocracy.
3 The exception was the role of Genghis Khan and his family.
4 The Mongol Empire was one of the most ethnically and culturally diverse empires in history as befitted its size.
5 Many of the empires nomadic inhabitants considered themselves Mongols in military and civilian life including Mongols Turks and others and included many diverse Khans of various ethnicities as part of the Mongol Empire such as Muhammad Khan.
6 Who created the code that governed military and civilian conduct in the Mongol Empire?	Genghis Khan	1
7 What was the name of the Mongol Empires legal code?	Yassa	1
8 What was the guiding principle of the Mongol Empire code of conduct?	meritocracy	2
9 Who was exempt from the meritocratic principles of the Mongol Empire?	Genghis Khan and his family	3
10 Who is an example of the diversity of leadership in the Mongol Empire?	Muhammad Khan	5
1 There were tax exemptions for religious figures and to some extent teachers and doctors.
2 The Mongol Empire practiced religious tolerance because Mongol tradition had long held that religion was a personal concept and not subject to law or interference.
3 citation needed Sometime before the rise of Genghis Khan Ong Khan his mentor and eventual rival had converted to Nestorian Christianity.
4 Various Mongol tribes were Shamanist Buddhist or Christian.
5 Religious tolerance was thus a well established concept on the Asian steppe.
6 What perk did religious leaders teachers and doctors get in the Mongol Empire?	tax exemptions	1
7 Which of Genghis Khans mentors practiced Christianity?	Ong Khan	3
8 How was religion handled in the Mongol Empire?	a personal concept	2
9 What are examples of the various religions of Mongol tribes?	Shamanist  Buddhist or Christian	4
1 Modern Mongolian historians say that towards the end of his life Genghis Khan attempted to create a civil state under the Great Yassa that would have established the legal equality of all individuals including women.
2 However there is no evidence of this or of the lifting of discriminatory policies towards sedentary peoples such as the Chinese.
3 Women played a relatively important role in Mongol Empire and in family for example Töregene Khatun was briefly in charge of the Mongol Empire when next male Khagan was being chosen.
4 Modern scholars refer to the alleged policy of encouraging trade and communication as the Pax Mongolica Mongol Peace.
5 Which woman took a leadership role in the Mongol Empire while succession was being determined?	Töregene Khatun	3
6 What is the modern term for the Mongolian policies supporting trade and communication?	the Pax Mongolica Mongol Peace	4
7 Who is an example of a sedentary people who were not favored by the laws of the Mongol Empire?	the Chinese	2
8 What do some modern historians claim Genghis Khan sought to add his legal code at the end of his reign?	legal equality of all individuals  including women	1
1 Genghis Khan realised that he needed people who could govern cities and states conquered by him.
2 He also realised that such administrators could not be found among his Mongol people because they were nomads and thus had no experience governing cities.
3 For this purpose Genghis Khan invited a Khitan prince ChuTsai who worked for the Jin and had been captured by the Mongol army after the Jin dynasty was defeated.
4 Jin had captured power by displacing Khitan.
5 Genghis told ChuTsai who was a lineal descendant of Khitan rulers that he had avenged ChuTsais forefathers.
6 ChuTsai responded that his father served the Jin dynasty honestly and so did he also he did not consider his own father his enemy so the question of revenge did not apply.
7 This reply impressed Genghis Khan.
8 ChuTsai administered parts of the Mongol Empire and became a confidant of the successive Mongol Khans.
9 Which Khitan prince became an important administrator in the Mongol Empire?	ChuTsai	3
10 Why would Mongols have too little experience to govern cities they conquered?	they were nomads	2
11 Khitan had been overthrown by which dynasty that Genghis Khan later defeated?	Jin	4
12 Who were ChuTsais forefathers?	Khitan rulers	5
1 Genghis Khan put absolute trust in his generals such as Muqali Jebe and Subutai and regarded them as close advisors often extending them the same privileges and trust normally reserved for close family members.
2 He allowed them to make decisions on their own when they embarked on campaigns far from the Mongol Empire capital Karakorum.
3 Muqali a trusted lieutenant was given command of the Mongol forces against the Jin dynasty while Genghis Khan was fighting in Central Asia and Subutai and Jebe were allowed to pursue the Great Raid into the Caucasus and Kievan Rus an idea they had presented to the Khagan on their own initiative.
4 While granting his generals a great deal of autonomy in making command decisions Genghis Khan also expected unwavering loyalty from them.
5 Who among Genghis Khans subjects shared similar privileges to his close family members?	his generals	1
6 What was the capital of the Mongol Empire?	Karakorum	2
7 Who was delegated command of the Mongol forces against the Jin dynasty?	Muqali	3
8 Which two generals raided the Caucasas and Kievan Rus for Genghis Khan?	Subutai and Jebe	3
9 What did Genghis Khan expect from his generals alongside the autonomy he granted them?	unwavering loyalty	4
1 The Mongol military was also successful in siege warfare cutting off resources for cities and towns by diverting certain rivers taking enemy prisoners and driving them in front of the army and adopting new ideas techniques and tools from the people they conquered particularly in employing Muslim and Chinese siege engines and engineers to aid the Mongol cavalry in capturing cities.
2 Another standard tactic of the Mongol military was the commonly practiced feigned retreat to break enemy formations and to lure small enemy groups away from the larger group and defended position for ambush and counterattack.
3 What would Mongol armies divert in order to cut off the resources of cities they were attacking?	rivers	1
4 What were the cultural origins of the engineers and technology adopted by the Mongol military?	Muslim and Chinese	1
5 How did Mongol armies lure enemy groups out of their defensive positions?	feigned retreat	2
6 How were enemy prisoners used tactically by Mongol armies?	driving them in front of the army	1
1 Contrary to popular belief Genghis Khan did not conquer all the areas ultimately part of the Mongol Empire.
2 At the time of his death the Mongol Empire stretched from the Caspian Sea to the Sea of Japan.
3 The empires expansion continued for a generation or more after Genghiss death in 1227.
4 Under Genghiss successor Ögedei Khan the speed of expansion reached its peak.
5 Mongol armies pushed into Persia finished off the Western Xia and the remnants of the Khwarezmids and came into conflict with the imperial Song dynasty of China starting a war that lasted until 1279 and that concluded with the Mongols gaining control of all of China.
6 They also pushed further into Russia and eastern Europe.
7 What sea bordered Genghis Khans empire to the east when he died?	Sea of Japan	2
8 What body of water sat to the west of the Mongol Empire when Genghis Khan died?	Caspian Sea	2
9 Who led the most rapid expansion of the Mongol Empire?	Ögedei Khan	4
10 What year was the conflict with the Song dynasty concluded?	1279	5
1 Genghis Khan is credited with bringing the Silk Road under one cohesive political environment.
2 This allowed increased communication and trade between the West Middle East and Asia thus expanding the horizons of all three cultural areas.
3 Some historians have noted that Genghis Khan instituted certain levels of meritocracy in his rule was tolerant of religions and explained his policies clearly to all his soldiers.
4 In Turkey Genghis Khan is looked on as a great military leader and it is popular for male children to carry his title as name.
5 To which trading route did Genghis Khan bring a stable political climate?	the Silk Road	1
6 In which Middle Eastern country is Genghis Khans title a popular name for male children?	Turkey	4
7 What was the Genghis Khans characteristic approach to religious diversity?	tolerant	3
8 What effect did Genghis Khans career have on communication and trade across Asia?	increased	2
1 In the early 1990s the memory of Genghis Khan with the Mongolian national identity has had a powerful revival partly because of his perception during the Mongolian Peoples Republic period.
2 Genghis Khan became one of the central figures of the national identity.
3 He is looked upon positively by Mongolians for his role in uniting warring tribes.
4 For example it is not uncommon for Mongolians to refer to their country as Genghis Khans Mongolia to themselves as Genghis Khans children and to Genghis Khan as the father of the Mongols especially among the younger generation.
5 However there is a chasm in the perception of his brutality.
6 Mongolians maintain that the historical records written by nonMongolians are unfairly biased against Genghis Khan and that his butchery is exaggerated while his positive role is underrated.
7 What recent decade saw brightening of the perception of Genghis Khan in Mongolia?	1990s	1
8 What is the key accomplishment of Genghis Khan that modern Mongolians celebrate?	uniting warring tribes	3
9 How do Mongolians sometime describe their relationship to Genghis Khan?	Genghis Khans children	4
10 What do some Mongolians feel nonMongolian historians exaggerate about Genghis Khan?	his brutality	5
11 What is the general perception of nonMongolian histories of Genghis Khan by Mongolians themselves?	unfairly biased	6
1 In Mongolia today Genghis Khans name and likeness are endorsed on products streets buildings and other places.
2 His face can be found on everyday commodities from liquor bottles to candy products and on the largest denominations of 500 1000 5000 10000 and 20000 Mongolian tögrög ₮.
3 Mongolias main international airport in Ulaanbaatar is named Chinggis Khaan International Airport.
4 Major Genghis Khan statues have been erected before the parliament and near Ulaanbaatar.
5 There have been repeated discussions about regulating the use of his name and image to avoid trivialization.
6 What is the name of contemporary Mongolian currency?	tögrög	2
7 Whose likeness is on the larger denominations of Mongolian currency?	Genghis Khan	1
8 What is the name of Mongolias largest airport?	Chinggis Khaan International Airport	3
9 Why have Mongolian politicians considered regulating the use of Genghis Khans name?	to avoid trivialization	5
10 What city is near a major statue of Genghis Khan?	Ulaanbaatar	4
1 Genghis Khan is regarded as one of the prominent leaders in Mongolias history.
2 He is responsible for the emergence of the Mongols as a political and ethnic identity because there was no unified identity between the tribes that had cultural similarity.
3 He reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during a time of almost endemic warfare between tribes.
4 He is also given credit for the introduction of the traditional Mongolian script and the creation of the Ikh Zasag Great Administration the first written Mongolian law.
5 Ikh Zasag law adopted during Genghis Khan’s time in Mongolia had points to punish illegal matters related to corruption and bribery very heavily Mongolian President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj noted.
6 President Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as a leader from whom to learn for anticorruption efforts as Genghis Khan sought equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth.
7 Chinggis Genghis Khanwas a man who deeply realized that the justice begins and consolidates with the equality of law and not with the distinctions between people.
8 He was a man who knew that the good laws and rules lived longer than fancy palaces Elbegdorj said in his speech on the 850th anniversary of Chinggis Khaans birth.
9 In summary Mongolians see him as the fundamental figure in the founding of the Mongol Empire and therefore the basis for Mongolia as a country.
10 What is the Mongolian name of the first Mongolian laws codified in writing?	Ikh Zasag	4
11 What did Mongolian President Tsakhiagian Elbegdorj note was significantly punished by Genghis Khans laws?	corruption and bribery	5
12 Which Mongolian president lauded Genghis Khan on the 850th anniversary of the conquerors birth?	Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj	5
13 What innovation in Mongolian language is credited to Genghis Khan?	traditional Mongolian script	4
1 There are conflicting views of Genghis Khan in the Peoples Republic of China with some viewing him positively in the Inner Mongolia region where there are a monument and buildings about him and where there is a considerable number of Mongols in the area with a population of around 5 million almost twice the population of Mongolia.
2 While Genghis Khan never conquered all of China his grandson Kublai Khan completed that conquest and established the Yuan dynasty that is often credited with reuniting China.
3 There has been much artwork and literature praising Genghis as a great military leader and political genius.
4 The years of the Mongolestablished Yuan dynasty left an indelible imprint on Chinese political and social structures for subsequent generations with literature during the Jin dynasty relatively fewer.
5 In general the legacy of Genghis Khan and his successors who completed the conquest of China after 65 years of struggle remains a mixed topic.
6 citation needed.
7 Where in China is Genghis Khan most favorably viewed today?	Inner Mongolia region	1
8 What is the population of the Inner Mongolia region of China?	5 million	1
9 Which descendant of Genghis Khan is remembered as having reunified China?	Kublai Khan	2
10 What Chinese dynasty did the Mongols found?	Yuan	2
11 What was Kublai Khans relation to Genghis Khan?	grandson	2
1 In the Middle East and particularly in Iran Genghis Khan is almost universally condemned as a destructive and genocidal warlord who caused enormous damage and destruction to the population of these areas.
2 Steven R Ward wrote that Overall the Mongol violence and depredations killed up to threefourths of the population of the Iranian Plateau possibly 10 to 15 million people.
3 Some historians have estimated that Irans population did not again reach its preMongol levels until the mid20th century.
4 Which Middle Eastern nation in particular views Genghis Khan as a contemptible perpetrator of genocide?	Iran	1
5 What proportion of the general population in the area than became Iran did Genghis Khan kill?	threefourths	2
6 How many people do historians estimate Genghis Khan killed in the Iranian Plateau?	10 to 15 million	2
1 The invasions of Baghdad Samarkand Urgench Kiev Vladimir among others caused mass murders such as when portions of southern Khuzestan were completely destroyed.
2 His descendant Hulagu Khan destroyed much of Irans northern part and sacked Baghdad although his forces were halted by the Mamluks of Egypt but Hulagus descendant Ghazan Khan would return to beat the Egyptian Mamluks right out of Levant Palestine and even Gaza.
3 According to the works of the Persian historian RashidalDin Hamadani the Mongols killed more than 70000 people in Merv and more than 190000 in Nishapur.
4 In 1237 Batu Khan a grandson of Genghis Khan launched an invasion into Kievan Rus.
5 Over the course of three years the Mongols destroyed and annihilated all of the major cities of Eastern Europe with the exceptions of Novgorod and Pskov.

1 Although the famous Mughal emperors were proud descendants of Genghis Khan and particularly Timur they clearly distanced themselves from the Mongol atrocities committed against the Khwarizim Shahs Turks Persians the citizens of Baghdad and Damascus Nishapur Bukhara and historical figures such as Attar of Nishapur and many other notable Muslims.
2 However Mughal Emperors directly patronized the legacies of Genghis Khan and Timur together their names were synonymous with the names of other distinguished personalities particularly among the Muslim populations of South Asia.

1 One theory suggests the name stems from a palatalised version of the Mongolian and Turkic word tenggis meaning ocean oceanic or widespreading.
2 Lake Baikal and ocean were called tenggis by the Mongols.
3 However it seems that if they had meant to call Genghis tenggis they could have said and written Tenggis Khan which they did not.
4 Zhèng Chinese 正 meaning right just or true would have received the Mongolian adjectival modifier s creating Jenggis which in medieval romanization would be written Genghis.
5 It is likely that the 13th century Mongolian pronunciation would have closely matched Chinggis.
6 Which Mongolian word meaning widespreading may have contributed to the appellation Genghis?	tenggis	1
7 Which massive lake did the Mongolians call tenggis?	Lake Baikal	2
8 What does zhèng mean?	right  just  or true	4
9 Jenggis is the adjectival form of what word?	Zhèng	4
10 What spelling of Genghis most closely matches its probable pronunciation?	Chinggis	5
