1 The word pharmacy is derived from its root word pharma which was a term used since the 15th–17th centuries.
2 However the original Greek roots from pharmakos imply sorcery or even poison.
3 In addition to pharma responsibilities the pharma offered general medical advice and a range of services that are now performed solely by other specialist practitioners such as surgery and midwifery.
4 The pharma as it was referred to often operated through a retail shop which in addition to ingredients for medicines sold tobacco and patent medicines.
5 Often the place that did this was called an apothecary and several languages have this as the dominant term though their practices are more akin to a modern pharmacy in English the term apothecary would today be seen as outdated or only approproriate if herbal remedies were on offer to a large extent.
6 The pharmas also used many other herbs not listed.
7 The Greek word Pharmakeia Greek φαρμακεία derives from pharmakon φάρμακον meaning drug medicine or poison.
8 n 1.
9 What word is the word pharmacy taken from?	its root word pharma	1
10 What goods were sold in a pharma?	ingredients for medicines  sold tobacco and patent medicines	4
11 What did the Greek root pharmakos imply?	sorcery or even poison	2
12 How would the word apothecary be viewed by contemporary English speakers?	outdated or only approproriate if herbal remedies were on offer to a large extent	5
13 What else was used by pharmas?	many other herbs not listed	6
1 Pharmacists are healthcare professionals with specialised education and training who perform various roles to ensure optimal health outcomes for their patients through the quality use of medicines.
2 Pharmacists may also be smallbusiness proprietors owning the pharmacy in which they practice.
3 Since pharmacists know about the mode of action of a particular drug and its metabolism and physiological effects on the human body in great detail they play an important role in optimisation of a drug treatment for an individual.
4 What type of professionals are pharmacists?	healthcare professionals	1
5 What types of health outcomes do pharmacists aim for with their patients?	optimal health outcomes	1
6 What type of treatment are pharmacists important for?	optimisation of a drug treatment for an individual	3
7 What other role do many pharmacists play?	smallbusiness proprietors	2
8 What types of preparation do pharmacists have?	specialised education and training	1
1 A Pharmacy Technician in the UK is considered a health care professional and often does not work under the direct supervision of a pharmacist if employed in a hospital pharmacy but instead is supervised and managed by other senior pharmacy technicians.
2 In the UK the role of a PhT has grown and responsibility has been passed on to them to manage the pharmacy department and specialised areas in pharmacy practice allowing pharmacists the time to specialise in their expert field as medication consultants spending more time working with patients and in research.
3 A pharmacy technician once qualified has to register as a professional on the General Pharmaceutical Council GPhC register.
4 The GPhC is the governing body for pharmacy health care professionals and this is who regulates the practice of pharmacists and pharmacy technicians.
5 Who oversees a Pharmacy Technician in the UK?	other senior pharmacy technicians	1
6 With what body must a pharmacy technician register?	the General Pharmaceutical Council GPhC register	3
7 What is a main duty of the GPhC?	regulates the practice of pharmacists and pharmacy technicians	4
8 What type of professional is a Pharmacy Technician considered to be?	health care professional	1
9 What types of responsibilities might a pharmacy technician have?	manage the pharmacy department and specialised areas in pharmacy practice	2
1 In Ancient Greece Diocles of Carystus 4th century BC was one of several men studying the medicinal properties of plants.
2 He wrote several treatises on the topic.
3 The Greek physician Pedanius Dioscorides is famous for writing a five volume book in his native Greek Περί ύλης ιατρικής in the 1st century AD.
4 The Latin translation De Materia Medica Concerning medical substances was used a basis for many medieval texts and was built upon by many middle eastern scientists during the Islamic Golden Age.
5 The title coined the term materia medica.
6 What is Pedanius Dioscorides known for?	writing a five volume book in his native Greek	3
7 What is the name of the Latin translation of Dioscorides book?	De Materia Medica	4
8 What term resulted from Dioscorides book?	materia medica	5
9 Who was a man studying medicinal applicants of plants in Ancient Greece?	Diocles of Carystus	1
10 Who added to Dioscorides book in the Islamic Golden Age?	many middle eastern scientists	4
1 In Japan at the end of the Asuka period 538–710 and the early Nara period 710–794 the men who fulfilled roles similar to those of modern pharmacists were highly respected.
2 The place of pharmacists in society was expressly defined in the Taihō Code 701 and restated in the Yōrō Code 718.
3 Ranked positions in the preHeian Imperial court were established and this organizational structure remained largely intact until the Meiji Restoration 1868.
4 In this highly stable hierarchy the pharmacists—and even pharmacist assistants—were assigned status superior to all others in healthrelated fields such as physicians and acupuncturists.
5 In the Imperial household the pharmacist was even ranked above the two personal physicians of the Emperor.
6 How were the men who did tasks like those of todays pharmacists viewed in Japan in the Asuka and Nara periods?	highly respected	1
7 In which two codes were the roles of pharmacists codified?	the Taihō Code 701 and restated in the Yōrō Code 718	2
8 What put a hierarchical structure in place?	the preHeian Imperial court	3
9 What stature did pharmacists have in the preHeian Imperial court?	status superior to all others in healthrelated fields such as physicians and acupuncturists	4
10 Where did the pharmacist stand in relation to the Emperors personal physicians?	ranked above	5
1 The advances made in the Middle East in botany and chemistry led medicine in medieval Islam substantially to develop pharmacology.
2 Muhammad ibn Zakarīya Rāzi Rhazes 865–915 for instance acted to promote the medical uses of chemical compounds.
3 Abu alQasim alZahrawi Abulcasis 936–1013 pioneered the preparation of medicines by sublimation and distillation.
4 His Liber servitoris is of particular interest as it provides the reader with recipes and explains how to prepare the simples’ from which were compounded the complex drugs then generally used.
5 Sabur Ibn Sahl d 869 was however the first physician to initiate pharmacopoedia describing a large variety of drugs and remedies for ailments.
6 AlBiruni 973–1050 wrote one of the most valuable Islamic works on pharmacology entitled Kitab alSaydalah The Book of Drugs in which he detailed the properties of drugs and outlined the role of pharmacy and the functions and duties of the pharmacist.
7 Avicenna too described no less than 700 preparations their properties modes of action and their indications.
8 He devoted in fact a whole volume to simple drugs in The Canon of Medicine.
9 Of great impact were also the works by alMaridini of Baghdad and Cairo and Ibn alWafid 1008–1074 both of which were printed in Latin more than fifty times appearing as De Medicinis universalibus et particularibus by Mesue the younger and the Medicamentis simplicibus by Abenguefit.
10 Peter of Abano 1250–1316 translated and added a supplement to the work of alMaridini under the title De Veneris.
11 AlMuwaffaq’s contributions in the field are also pioneering.
12 Living in the 10th century he wrote The foundations of the true properties of Remedies amongst others describing arsenious oxide and being acquainted with silicic acid.
13 He made clear distinction between sodium carbonate and potassium carbonate and drew attention to the poisonous nature of copper compounds especially copper vitriol and also lead compounds.
14 He also describes the distillation of seawater for drinking.
15 verification needed.
16 Developments in which scientists influenced the creation of pharmacology in medieval Islam?	botany and chemistry	1
17 Who was influential in promoting the use of chemical compounds as medicines?	Muhammad ibn Zakarīya Rāzi	2
18 Who authored the Liber servitoris?	Abu alQasim alZahrawi	3
19 Who wrote about the distillation of drinking water from sea water?	AlMuwaffaq	11
20 Which two compounds did AlMuwaffaq differentiate between?	sodium carbonate and potassium carbonate	13
1 In Europe there are old pharmacies still operating in Dubrovnik Croatia located inside the Franciscan monastery opened in 1317 and in the Town Hall Square of Tallinn Estonia dating from at least 1422.
2 The oldest is claimed to have been set up in 1221 in the Church of Santa Maria Novella in Florence Italy which now houses a perfume museum.
3 The medieval Esteve Pharmacy located in Llívia a Catalan enclave close to Puigcerdà also now a museum dates back to the 15th century keeping albarellos from the 16th and 17th centuries old prescription books and antique drugs.
4 How far does one pharmacy in Croatia date back to?	1317	1
5 Where is the oldest pharmacy stated to be located?	Church of Santa Maria Novella in Florence  Italy	2

7 What sorts of items are displayed in the Esteve Pharmacy museum?	albarellos from the 16th and 17th centuries  old prescription books and antique drugs	3
8 In what year is the oldest pharmacy said to have been established?	1221	2
1 In most countries the dispensary is subject to pharmacy legislation with requirements for storage conditions compulsory texts equipment etc specified in legislation.
2 Where it was once the case that pharmacists stayed within the dispensary compoundingdispensing medications there has been an increasing trend towards the use of trained pharmacy technicians while the pharmacist spends more time communicating with patients.
3 Pharmacy technicians are now more dependent upon automation to assist them in their new role dealing with patients prescriptions and patient safety issues.
4 What is the dispensary subject to in a majority of countries?	pharmacy legislation	1
5 What responsibilities were pharmacy technicians formerly limited to?	within the dispensary compoundingdispensing medications	2
6 What do pharmacy technicians depend on more and more?	automation	3
7 What are new responsibilities pharmacy technicians now deal with?	patients prescriptions and patient safety issues	3
8 What does pharmacy legislation mandate?	storage conditions  compulsory texts  equipment  etc	1
1 Because of the complexity of medications including specific indications effectiveness of treatment regimens safety of medications ie drug interactions and patient compliance issues in the hospital and at home many pharmacists practicing in hospitals gain more education and training after pharmacy school through a pharmacy practice residency and sometimes followed by another residency in a specific area.
2 Those pharmacists are often referred to as clinical pharmacists and they often specialize in various disciplines of pharmacy.
3 For example there are pharmacists who specialize in hematologyoncology HIVAIDS infectious disease critical care emergency medicine toxicology nuclear pharmacy pain management psychiatry anticoagulation clinics herbal medicine neurologyepilepsy management pediatrics neonatal pharmacists and more.
4 Where do pharmacists acquire more preparation following pharmacy school?	a pharmacy practice residency	1
5 What do clinical pharmacists specialize in?	various disciplines of pharmacy	2
6 What is one issue that adds to the complexity of a pharmacists job?	effectiveness of treatment regimens	1
7 Which pharmacists are likely to seek additional education following pharmacy school?	pharmacists practicing in hospitals	1
1 Hospital pharmacies can often be found within the premises of the hospital.
2 Hospital pharmacies usually stock a larger range of medications including more specialized medications than would be feasible in the community setting.
3 Most hospital medications are unitdose or a single dose of medicine.
4 Hospital pharmacists and trained pharmacy technicians compound sterile products for patients including total parenteral nutrition TPN and other medications given intravenously.
5 This is a complex process that requires adequate training of personnel quality assurance of products and adequate facilities.
6 Several hospital pharmacies have decided to outsource high risk preparations and some other compounding functions to companies who specialize in compounding.
7 The high cost of medications and drugrelated technology combined with the potential impact of medications and pharmacy services on patientcare outcomes and patient safety make it imperative that hospital pharmacies perform at the highest level possible.
8 Where are many hospital pharmacies located?	within the premises of the hospital	1
9 In what form are most hospital medications?	unitdose  or a single dose of medicine	3
10 What types of pharmacy functions have begun to be outsourced?	high risk preparations and some other compounding functions	6
11 What is one factor that increases the importance of the pharmacy performing at a high level?	The high cost of medications and drugrelated technology	7
12 What are some advantages of hospital pharmacies?	Hospital pharmacies usually stock a larger range of medications  including more specialized medications	2
1 Pharmacists provide direct patient care services that optimizes the use of medication and promotes health wellness and disease prevention.
2 Clinical pharmacists care for patients in all health care settings but the clinical pharmacy movement initially began inside hospitals and clinics.
3 Clinical pharmacists often collaborate with physicians and other healthcare professionals to improve pharmaceutical care.
4 Clinical pharmacists are now an integral part of the interdisciplinary approach to patient care.
5 They often participate in patient care rounds drug product selection.
6 What do the services given by pharmacists provide?	optimizes the use of medication and promotes health  wellness  and disease prevention	1
7 What is the origin of clinical pharmacy?	inside hospitals and clinics	2
8 Who do clinical pharmacists work with much of the time?	physicians and other healthcare professionals	3
9 What do clinical pharmacists often participate in?	patient care rounds drug product selection	5
10 Where do clinical pharmacists work with patients?	all health care settings	2
1 The clinical pharmacists role involves creating a comprehensive drug therapy plan for patientspecific problems identifying goals of therapy and reviewing all prescribed medications prior to dispensing and administration to the patient.
2 The review process often involves an evaluation of the appropriateness of the drug therapy eg drug choice dose route frequency and duration of therapy and its efficacy.
3 The pharmacist must also monitor for potential drug interactions adverse drug reactions and assess patient drug allergies while designing and initiating a drug therapy plan.
4 What is one example of what a clinical pharmacists duties entail?	creating a comprehensive drug therapy plan for patientspecific problems	1
5 What is involved in a review of prescribed medications?	an evaluation of the appropriateness of the drug therapy	2
6 What are the components of drug therapy?	drug choice  dose  route  frequency  and duration of therapy	2
7 What are some other factors a pharmacist must monitor?	potential drug interactions  adverse drug reactions	3
1 In the US federal health care system including the VA the Indian Health Service and NIH ambulatory care pharmacists are given full independent prescribing authority.
2 In some states such North Carolina and New Mexico these pharmacist clinicians are given collaborative prescriptive and diagnostic authority.
3 In 2011 the board of Pharmaceutical Specialties approved ambulatory care pharmacy practice as a separate board certification.
4 The official designation for pharmacists who pass the ambulatory care pharmacy specialty certification exam will be Board Certified Ambulatory Care Pharmacist and these pharmacists will carry the initials BCACP.
5 What type of authority are ambulatory care pharmacists given in the US federal health care system?	full independent prescribing authority	1
6 In what states are pharmacist clinicians given prescriptive and diagnostic authority?	North Carolina and New Mexico	2
7 When was ambulatory care pharmacy approved as its own certification?	2011	3
8 What will a pharmacist who passes the ambulatory pharmacist exam be called?	Board Certified Ambulatory Care Pharmacist	4
9 What entities are included in the federal health care system?	the VA  the Indian Health Service  and NIH	1
1 Consultant pharmacy practice focuses more on medication regimen review ie.
2 cognitive services than on actual dispensing of drugs.
3 Consultant pharmacists most typically work in nursing homes but are increasingly branching into other institutions and noninstitutional settings.
4 Traditionally consultant pharmacists were usually independent business owners though in the United States many now work for several large pharmacy management companies primarily Omnicare Kindred Healthcare and PharMerica.
5 This trend may be gradually reversing as consultant pharmacists begin to work directly with patients primarily because many elderly people are now taking numerous medications but continue to live outside of institutional settings.
6 Some community pharmacies employ consultant pharmacists andor provide consulting services.

8 Where do a majority of consultant pharmacists tend to work?	nursing homes	3
9 What are some large pharmacy management companies?	Omnicare  Kindred Healthcare and PharMerica	4
10 What is the main reason consulting pharmacists are increasingly working directly with patients?	because many elderly people are now taking numerous medications but continue to live outside of institutional settings	5
11 What do some community pharmacies do?	employ consultant pharmacists andor provide consulting services	6
1 Since about the year 2000 a growing number of Internet pharmacies have been established worldwide.
2 Many of these pharmacies are similar to community pharmacies and in fact many of them are actually operated by brickandmortar community pharmacies that serve consumers online and those that walk in their door.
3 The primary difference is the method by which the medications are requested and received.
4 Some customers consider this to be more convenient and private method rather than traveling to a community drugstore where another customer might overhear about the drugs that they take.
5 Internet pharmacies also known as online pharmacies are also recommended to some patients by their physicians if they are homebound.
6 When did internet pharmacies begin to come into being?	about the year 2000	1
7 Who often operates internet pharmacies?	brickandmortar community pharmacies that serve consumers online and those that walk in their door	2
8 What are internet pharmacies also called?	online pharmacies	5
9 What is one reason a patient might choose an internet pharmacy?	another customer might overhear about the drugs that they take	4
10 What is the main difference between online pharmacies and community pharmacies?	the method by which the medications are requested and received	3
1 While most Internet pharmacies sell prescription drugs and require a valid prescription some Internet pharmacies sell prescription drugs without requiring a prescription.
2 Many customers order drugs from such pharmacies to avoid the inconvenience of visiting a doctor or to obtain medications which their doctors were unwilling to prescribe.
3 However this practice has been criticized as potentially dangerous especially by those who feel that only doctors can reliably assess contraindications riskbenefit ratios and an individuals overall suitability for use of a medication.
4 There also have been reports of such pharmacies dispensing substandard products.
5 Why might customers order from internet pharmacies?	to avoid the inconvenience of visiting a doctor or to obtain medications which their doctors were unwilling to prescribe	2
6 Who has criticized ordering from online pharmacies that dont require prescriptions?	those who feel that only doctors can reliably assess contraindications  riskbenefit ratios  and an individuals overall suitability for use of a medication	3
7 What is a criticism of online pharmacies that issue drugs without a prescription?	dispensing substandard products	4
8 What practice do some internet pharmacies engage in?	sell prescription drugs without requiring a prescription	1
9 What do most online pharmacies do?	sell prescription drugs and require a valid prescription	1
1 Of particular concern with Internet pharmacies is the ease with which people youth in particular can obtain controlled substances eg Vicodin generically known as hydrocodone via the Internet without a prescription issued by a doctorpractitioner who has an established doctorpatient relationship.
2 There are many instances where a practitioner issues a prescription brokered by an Internet server for a controlled substance to a patient she has never met.
3 citation needed In the United States in order for a prescription for a controlled substance to be valid it must be issued for a legitimate medical purpose by a licensed practitioner acting in the course of legitimate doctorpatient relationship.
4 The filling pharmacy has a corresponding responsibility to ensure that the prescription is valid.
5 Often individual state laws outline what defines a valid patientdoctor relationship.
6 What is one problem with internet pharmacies?	the ease with which people  youth in particular  can obtain controlled substances	1
7 What conditions must be met for a prescription for a controlled substance to be valid?	it must be issued for a legitimate medical purpose by a licensed practitioner acting in the course of legitimate doctorpatient relationship	3
8 What is one problem with internet pharmacies?	the ease with which people  youth in particular  can obtain controlled substances	1
9 What conditions must be met to prescribe a controlled substance?	it must be issued for a legitimate medical purpose by a licensed practitioner acting in the course of legitimate doctorpatient relationship	3
10 What is the obligation of a pharmacy filling a prescription?	to ensure that the prescription is valid	4
11 Who defines what constitutes a patientdoctor relationship?	individual state laws	5
12 What is an example of a controlled substance?	Vicodin  generically known as hydrocodone	1
1 In the United States there has been a push to legalize importation of medications from Canada and other countries in order to reduce consumer costs.
2 While in most cases importation of prescription medications violates Food and Drug Administration FDA regulations and federal laws enforcement is generally targeted at international drug suppliers rather than consumers.
3 There is no known case of any US citizens buying Canadian drugs for personal use with a prescription who has ever been charged by authorities.

1 Pharmacy informatics is the combination of pharmacy practice science and applied information science.
2 Pharmacy informaticists work in many practice areas of pharmacy however they may also work in information technology departments or for healthcare information technology vendor companies.
3 As a practice area and specialist domain pharmacy informatics is growing quickly to meet the needs of major national and international patient information projects and health system interoperability goals.
4 Pharmacists in this area are trained to participate in medication management system development deployment and optimization.
5 What two things does pharmacy informatics bring together?	pharmacy practice science and applied information science	1
6 What fields may pharmacy informatics also work in?	information technology departments or for healthcare information technology vendor companies	2
7 Whose needs will the growth in pharmacy informatics meet?	major national and international patient information projects and health system interoperability goals	3
8 What areas are pharmacy informatics prepared to work in?	medication management system development  deployment and optimization	4
9 How fast is pharmacy informatics growing?	quickly	3
1 Specialty pharmacies supply high cost injectable oral infused or inhaled medications that are used for chronic and complex disease states such as cancer hepatitis and rheumatoid arthritis.
2 Unlike a traditional community pharmacy where prescriptions for any common medication can be brought in and filled specialty pharmacies carry novel medications that need to be properly stored administered carefully monitored and clinically managed.
3 In addition to supplying these drugs specialty pharmacies also provide lab monitoring adherence counseling and assist patients with costcontainment strategies needed to obtain their expensive specialty drugs.
4 It is currently the fastest growing sector of the pharmaceutical industry with 19 of 28 newly FDA approved medications in 2013 being specialty drugs.
5 What is the fastest growing area in the pharmaceutical industry?	specialty pharmacies	3
6 How many drugs approved by the FDA in 2013 were specialty drugs?	19	4
7 What types of diseases are specialty drugs often used against?	cancer  hepatitis  and rheumatoid arthritis	1
8 What types of medications do specialty pharmacies stock?	novel medications that need to be properly stored  administered  carefully monitored  and clinically managed	2
9 Besides drugs what else do specialty pharmacies provide?	lab monitoring  adherence counseling  and assist patients with costcontainment strategies needed to obtain their expensive specialty drugs	3
1 In most jurisdictions such as the United States pharmacists are regulated separately from physicians.
2 These jurisdictions also usually specify that only pharmacists may supply scheduled pharmaceuticals to the public and that pharmacists cannot form business partnerships with physicians or give them kickback payments.
3 However the American Medical Association AMA Code of Ethics provides that physicians may dispense drugs within their office practices as long as there is no patient exploitation and patients have the right to a written prescription that can be filled elsewhere.
4 7 to 10 percent of American physicians practices reportedly dispense drugs on their own.
5 How are pharmacists regulated in most jurisdictions?	separately from physicians	1
6 Who do most jurisdictions say can give scheduled drugs to the public?	only pharmacists	2
7 What body has stated that physicians can also dispense drugs under specific conditions?	the American Medical Association AMA	3
8 What is the estimate of how many physicians give out drugs on their own?	7 to 10 percent	4
9 What are pharmacists forbidden to do?	form business partnerships with physicians or give them kickback payments	2
1 In some rural areas in the United Kingdom there are dispensing physicians who are allowed to both prescribe and dispense prescriptiononly medicines to their patients from within their practices.
2 The law requires that the GP practice be located in a designated rural area and that there is also a specified minimum distance currently 16 kilometres between a patients home and the nearest retail pharmacy.
3 This law also exists in Austria for general physicians if the nearest pharmacy is more than 4 kilometers away or where none is registered in the city.
4 What is another country that permits physicians to give out drugs from within their practice?	Austria	3
5 Where are some physicians permitted to prescribe and give out medications within their practices?	In some rural areas in the United Kingdom	1
6 What is the minimum distance between a patients home and the nearest pharmacy that allows a physician to give out medication?	16 kilometres	2
7 What is the minimum distance between a patients home and the nearest pharmacy that allows a physician in Austria to give out medicine?	more than 4 kilometers	3
1 The reason for the majority rule is the high risk of a conflict of interest andor the avoidance of absolute powers.
2 Otherwise the physician has a financial selfinterest in diagnosing as many conditions as possible and in exaggerating their seriousness because he or she can then sell more medications to the patient.
3 Such selfinterest directly conflicts with the patients interest in obtaining costeffective medication and avoiding the unnecessary use of medication that may have sideeffects.
4 This system reflects much similarity to the checks and balances system of the US and many other governments.
5 citation needed.
6 Why is majority rule used?	the high risk of a conflict of interest andor the avoidance of absolute powers	1
7 Why might a physician diagnose a large number of conditions?	because he or she can then sell more medications to the patient	2
8 What do rules about conflict of interest involving doctors diagnosing patients resemble?	the checks and balances system of the US and many other governments	4
9 How else might a physician take advantage of selfinterest?	exaggerating their seriousness	2
10 Where might the doctors selfinterest be at odds with the patients selfinterest?	in obtaining costeffective medication and avoiding the unnecessary use of medication that may have sideeffects	3
1 In the coming decades pharmacists are expected to become more integral within the health care system.
2 Rather than simply dispensing medication pharmacists are increasingly expected to be compensated for their patient care skills.
3 In particular Medication Therapy Management MTM includes the clinical services that pharmacists can provide for their patients.
4 Such services include the thorough analysis of all medication prescription nonprescription and herbals currently being taken by an individual.
5 The result is a reconciliation of medication and patient education resulting in increased patient health outcomes and decreased costs to the health care system.
6 What will be the importance of the pharmacist in coming decades?	expected to become more integral within the health care system	1
7 What responsibilities are pharmacists believed to be taking on more in the future?	increasingly expected to be compensated for their patient care skills	2
8 What is included in Medication Therapy Management?	clinical services that pharmacists can provide for their patients	3
9 What are examples of clinical services that pharmacists can provide?	thorough analysis of all medication prescription  nonprescription  and herbals currently being taken by an individual	4
10 What are outcomes expected with Medication Therapy Management?	a reconciliation of medication and patient education resulting in increased patient health outcomes and decreased costs to the health care system	5
1 This shift has already commenced in some countries for instance pharmacists in Australia receive remuneration from the Australian Government for conducting comprehensive Home Medicines Reviews.
2 In Canada pharmacists in certain provinces have limited prescribing rights as in Alberta and British Columbia or are remunerated by their provincial government for expanded services such as medications reviews Medschecks in Ontario.
3 In the United Kingdom pharmacists who undertake additional training are obtaining prescribing rights and this is because of pharmacy education.
4 They are also being paid for by the government for medicine use reviews.
5 In Scotland the pharmacist can write prescriptions for Scottish registered patients of their regular medications for the majority of drugs except for controlled drugs when the patient is unable to see their doctor as could happen if they are away from home or the doctor is unavailable.
6 In the United States pharmaceutical care or clinical pharmacy has had an evolving influence on the practice of pharmacy.
7 Moreover the Doctor of Pharmacy Pharm.
8 D degree is now required before entering practice and some pharmacists now complete one or two years of residency or fellowship training following graduation.
9 In addition consultant pharmacists who traditionally operated primarily in nursing homes are now expanding into direct consultation with patients under the banner of senior care pharmacy.
10 Which provinces in Canada limit the rights of pharmacists in prescribing?	Alberta and British Columbia	2
11 Who pays Australian pharmacists for doing Home Medicines Reviews?	the Australian Government	1
12 What are pharmacists in the United Kingdom being increasingly paid for?	medicine use reviews	4
13 What fields have increased in influence on pharmacy in the United States?	pharmaceutical care or clinical pharmacy	6
14 What degree is now mandatory in the US in order to be a licensed pharmacist?	Doctor of Pharmacy Pharm D	7
1 The two symbols most commonly associated with pharmacy in Englishspeaking countries are the mortar and pestle and the ℞ recipere character which is often written as Rx in typed text.
2 The show globe was also used until the early 20th century.
3 Pharmacy organizations often use other symbols such as the Bowl of Hygieia which is often used in the Netherlands conical measures and caduceuses in their logos.
4 Other symbols are common in different countries the green Greek cross in France Argentina the United Kingdom Belgium Ireland Italy Spain and India the increasingly rare Gaper in the Netherlands and a red stylized letter A in Germany and Austria from Apotheke the German word for pharmacy from the same Greek root as the English word apothecary.
5 What are the two symbols that signify pharmacy in Englishspeaking countries?	the mortar and pestle and the ℞ recipere character	1
6 What symbol was employed until early in the 20th century?	The show globe	2
7 What country uses the Bowl of Hygieia as a symbol of pharmacy?	the Netherlands	3
8 What countries use a red stylized A to signify pharmacy?	Germany and Austria	4
9 Which countries use the green Greek cross as a symbol of pharmacy?	France  Argentina  the United Kingdom  Belgium  Ireland  Italy  Spain  and India	4
1 The immune system is a system of many biological structures and processes within an organism that protects against disease.
2 To function properly an immune system must detect a wide variety of agents known as pathogens from viruses to parasitic worms and distinguish them from the organisms own healthy tissue.
3 In many species the immune system can be classified into subsystems such as the innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system or humoral immunity versus cellmediated immunity.
4 In humans the blood–brain barrier blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier and similar fluid–brain barriers separate the peripheral immune system from the neuroimmune system which protects the brain.
5 What is the immune system?	a system of many biological structures and processes within an organism that protects against disease	1
6 What does the immune system protect against?	a wide variety of agents  known as pathogens  from viruses to parasitic worms	2
7 What are two of its subsystems?	the innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system	3
8 What is the subsystem that protects the human brain?	the neuroimmune system	4
9 What is the immune system?	biological structures and processes within an organism	1
10 What does the immune system protect against?	pathogens  from viruses to parasitic worms	2
11 What are two of its subsystems?	innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system	3
12 The immune system protects organisms against what?	disease	1
13 What are the agents the immune system detects known as?	pathogens	2
14 Which part of the immune system protects the brain?	neuroimmune system	4
15 What separates the neuroimmune system and peripheral immune system in humans?	blood–brain barrier  blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier	4
16 What are the agents detected by the immune system called?	pathogens	2
17 What are the two major subsystems of the immune system?	innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system	3
18 What are the two different types of immunity?	humoral immunity versus cellmediated immunity	3
19 What is the immune system of the brained known as?	neuroimmune system	4
1 Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt and thereby avoid detection and neutralization by the immune system however multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens.
2 Even simple unicellular organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary immune system in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections.
3 Other basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes and remain in their modern descendants such as plants and invertebrates.
4 These mechanisms include phagocytosis antimicrobial peptides called defensins and the complement system.
5 Jawed vertebrates including humans have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms including the ability to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently.
6 Adaptive or acquired immunity creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen.
7 This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination.
8 How do pathogens avoid detection?	Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt	1
9 What kind of immune system do bacteria have?	enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections	2
10 Which other ancient organism formed basic immune mechanisms?	eukaryotes	3
11 How does adaptiveacquired immunity help in the future?	creates immunological memory	6
12 The immune systems of bacteria have enzymes that protect against infection by what kind of cells?	bacteriophage	2
13 What are antimicrobial peptides that evolved as immune defense in eukaryotes called?	defensins	4
14 The idea of acquired immunity in jawed vertebrates is the basis of what medical treatment?	vaccination	7
15 What is the ability to recognize and adapt to new specific pathogens called?	Adaptive or acquired immunity	6
1 Disorders of the immune system can result in autoimmune diseases inflammatory diseases and cancer.
2 Immunodeficiency occurs when the immune system is less active than normal resulting in recurring and lifethreatening infections.
3 In humans immunodeficiency can either be the result of a genetic disease such as severe combined immunodeficiency acquired conditions such as HIVAIDS or the use of immunosuppressive medication.
4 In contrast autoimmunity results from a hyperactive immune system attacking normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms.
5 Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimotos thyroiditis rheumatoid arthritis diabetes mellitus type 1 and systemic lupus erythematosus.
6 Immunology covers the study of all aspects of the immune system.
7 What can result from disorders of the immune system?	autoimmune diseases  inflammatory diseases and cancer	1
8 When does immunodeficiency occur?	when the immune system is less active than normal	2
9 What does immunodeficiency cause?	recurring and lifethreatening infections	2
10 Name one of the causes of immunodeficiency	genetic disease 	3.
11 Name a common autoimmune disease	rheumatoid arthritis 	5.
12 What happens when the immune system less active than normal?	Immunodeficiency	2
13 What is the term for a hyperactive immune system that attacks normal tissues?	autoimmunity	4
14 What field involves the study of the immune system?	Immunology	6
15 What acquired condition results in immunodeficiency in humans?	HIVAIDS	3
1 Immunology is a science that examines the structure and function of the immune system.
2 It originates from medicine and early studies on the causes of immunity to disease.
3 The earliest known reference to immunity was during the plague of Athens in 430 BC.
4 Thucydides noted that people who had recovered from a previous bout of the disease could nurse the sick without contracting the illness a second time.
5 In the 18th century PierreLouis Moreau de Maupertuis made experiments with scorpion venom and observed that certain dogs and mice were immune to this venom.
6 This and other observations of acquired immunity were later exploited by Louis Pasteur in his development of vaccination and his proposed germ theory of disease.
7 Pasteurs theory was in direct opposition to contemporary theories of disease such as the miasma theory.
8 It was not until Robert Kochs 1891 proofs for which he was awarded a Nobel Prize in 1905 that microorganisms were confirmed as the cause of infectious disease.
9 Viruses were confirmed as human pathogens in 1901 with the discovery of the yellow fever virus by Walter Reed.
10 What even is the earliest known reference to immunity?	plague of Athens in 430 BC	3
11 Which animals venom did PierreLouis Moreau de Maupertuis work with?	scorpion	5
12 Who came up with germ theory?	Louis Pasteur	6
13 Who discovered the Yellow Fever virus?	Walter Reed	9
14 Who won the Nobel Prize in 1905?	Robert Koch	8
15 What did Robert Koch prove was the cause of infectious disease?	microorganisms	8
16 What virus did Walter Reed discover?	yellow fever virus	9
17 When was the first known historical reference to immunity?	Athens in 430 BC	3
1 The immune system protects organisms from infection with layered defenses of increasing specificity.
2 In simple terms physical barriers prevent pathogens such as bacteria and viruses from entering the organism.
3 If a pathogen breaches these barriers the innate immune system provides an immediate but nonspecific response.
4 Innate immune systems are found in all plants and animals.
5 If pathogens successfully evade the innate response vertebrates possess a second layer of protection the adaptive immune system which is activated by the innate response.
6 Here the immune system adapts its response during an infection to improve its recognition of the pathogen.
7 This improved response is then retained after the pathogen has been eliminated in the form of an immunological memory and allows the adaptive immune system to mount faster and stronger attacks each time this pathogen is encountered.
8 What is another name for an immune systems improved response?	immunological memory	7
9 Which system comes after an organisms physical barriers?	the innate immune system	3
10 What protection comes after the innate response?	the adaptive immune system	5
11 What type of immune systems are found in all plants and animals?	Innate immune systems	4
12 What immune system is activated by the innate response?	adaptive immune system	5
13 What allows the adaptive immune system to react faster and more strongly each subsequent time a pathogen is encountered?	immunological memory	7
14 What is the first line of defense against pathogens that prevents them from entering an organism?	physical barriers	2
1 Both innate and adaptive immunity depend on the ability of the immune system to distinguish between self and nonself molecules.
2 In immunology self molecules are those components of an organisms body that can be distinguished from foreign substances by the immune system.
3 Conversely nonself molecules are those recognized as foreign molecules.
4 One class of nonself molecules are called antigens short for antibody generators and are defined as substances that bind to specific immune receptors and elicit an immune response.
5 The adaptive immune system must distinguish between what types of molecules?	self and nonself	1
6 What molecules are parts of the body of an organism in immunology?	self molecules	2
7 What molecules are recognized as foreign by the immune system?	nonself molecules	3
8 What term is shorthand for antibody generators?	antigens	4
9 Antigens bind to what in order to elicit a response of the immune system?	specific immune receptors	4
1 Microorganisms or toxins that successfully enter an organism encounter the cells and mechanisms of the innate immune system.
2 The innate response is usually triggered when microbes are identified by pattern recognition receptors which recognize components that are conserved among broad groups of microorganisms or when damaged injured or stressed cells send out alarm signals many of which but not all are recognized by the same receptors as those that recognize pathogens.
3 Innate immune defenses are nonspecific meaning these systems respond to pathogens in a generic way.
4 This system does not confer longlasting immunity against a pathogen.
5 The innate immune system is the dominant system of host defense in most organisms.
6 What part of the innate immune system identifies microbes and triggers immune response?	pattern recognition receptors	2
7 For most organisms what is the dominant system of defense?	innate immune system	5
8 Pattern recognition receptors recognize components present in broad groups of what?	microorganisms	2
9 The innate immune system responds in a generic way meaning it is what?	nonspecific	3
1 Several barriers protect organisms from infection including mechanical chemical and biological barriers.
2 The waxy cuticle of many leaves the exoskeleton of insects the shells and membranes of externally deposited eggs and skin are examples of mechanical barriers that are the first line of defense against infection.
3 However as organisms cannot be completely sealed from their environments other systems act to protect body openings such as the lungs intestines and the genitourinary tract.
4 In the lungs coughing and sneezing mechanically eject pathogens and other irritants from the respiratory tract.
5 The flushing action of tears and urine also mechanically expels pathogens while mucus secreted by the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract serves to trap and entangle microorganisms.
6 What is a mechanical barrier in insects that protects the insect?	exoskeleton	2
7 What is an example of a mechanical barrier on leaves?	The waxy cuticle	2
8 What responses protect the lungs by mechanically ejecting pathogens from the respiratory system?	coughing and sneezing	4
9 What is secreted by the respiratory tract to trap microorganisms?	mucus	5
10 The flushing action of what expels pathogens from the eyes?	tears	5
1 Chemical barriers also protect against infection.
2 The skin and respiratory tract secrete antimicrobial peptides such as the βdefensins.
3 Enzymes such as lysozyme and phospholipase A2 in saliva tears and breast milk are also antibacterials.
4 Vaginal secretions serve as a chemical barrier following menarche when they become slightly acidic while semen contains defensins and zinc to kill pathogens.
5 In the stomach gastric acid and proteases serve as powerful chemical defenses against ingested pathogens.
6 What are the anitmicrobial peptides secreted by the skin called?	βdefensins	2
7 What enzymes in saliva are antibacterial in nature?	lysozyme and phospholipase A2	3
8 Semen contains what in order to kill pathogens?	defensins and zinc	4
9 What compounds in the stomach protect against ingested pathogens?	gastric acid and proteases	5
10 Vaginal secretions serve as a chemical protective barrier following what?	menarche	4
1 Within the genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts commensal flora serve as biological barriers by competing with pathogenic bacteria for food and space and in some cases by changing the conditions in their environment such as pH or available iron.
2 This reduces the probability that pathogens will reach sufficient numbers to cause illness.
3 However since most antibiotics nonspecifically target bacteria and do not affect fungi oral antibiotics can lead to an overgrowth of fungi and cause conditions such as a vaginal candidiasis a yeast infection.
4 There is good evidence that reintroduction of probiotic flora such as pure cultures of the lactobacilli normally found in unpasteurized yogurt helps restore a healthy balance of microbial populations in intestinal infections in children and encouraging preliminary data in studies on bacterial gastroenteritis inflammatory bowel diseases urinary tract infection and postsurgical infections.
5 What serves as a biological barrier by competing for space and food in the GI tract?	commensal flora	1
6 Most antibiotics target bacteria and dont affect what class of organisms?	fungi	3
7 What probiotic flora is found in unpasteurized yogurt?	lactobacilli	4
8 Commensal flora can change what specific conditions of their environment in the gastrointestinal tract?	pH or available iron	1
1 Inflammation is one of the first responses of the immune system to infection.
2 The symptoms of inflammation are redness swelling heat and pain which are caused by increased blood flow into tissue.
3 Inflammation is produced by eicosanoids and cytokines which are released by injured or infected cells.
4 Eicosanoids include prostaglandins that produce fever and the dilation of blood vessels associated with inflammation and leukotrienes that attract certain white blood cells leukocytes.
5 Common cytokines include interleukins that are responsible for communication between white blood cells chemokines that promote chemotaxis and interferons that have antiviral effects such as shutting down protein synthesis in the host cell.
6 Growth factors and cytotoxic factors may also be released.
7 These cytokines and other chemicals recruit immune cells to the site of infection and promote healing of any damaged tissue following the removal of pathogens.
8 What is one of the first responses the immune system has to infection?	Inflammation	1
9 What causes the symptoms of inflammation?	increased blood flow into tissue	2
10 What compounds are released by injured or infected cells triggering inflammation?	eicosanoids and cytokines	3
11 Eicosanoids include what compounds that result in fever and blood vessel dilation?	prostaglandins	4
12 What cytokines are responsible for communication between white blood cells?	interleukins	5
1 Phagocytosis is an important feature of cellular innate immunity performed by cells called phagocytes that engulf or eat pathogens or particles.
2 Phagocytes generally patrol the body searching for pathogens but can be called to specific locations by cytokines.
3 Once a pathogen has been engulfed by a phagocyte it becomes trapped in an intracellular vesicle called a phagosome which subsequently fuses with another vesicle called a lysosome to form a phagolysosome.
4 The pathogen is killed by the activity of digestive enzymes or following a respiratory burst that releases free radicals into the phagolysosome.
5 Phagocytosis evolved as a means of acquiring nutrients but this role was extended in phagocytes to include engulfment of pathogens as a defense mechanism.
6 Phagocytosis probably represents the oldest form of host defense as phagocytes have been identified in both vertebrate and invertebrate animals.
7 What type of cells engulf or eat pathogens and foreign particles?	phagocytes	1
8 Phagocytes can be called to a specific location by what?	cytokines	2
9 When a pathogen has been eaten by a phagocyte it becomes trapped in what vesicle?	phagosome	3
10 What is formed when a phagosome fuses with a lysosome?	phagolysosome	4
11 Phagocytosis first evolved as means of doing what?	acquiring nutrients	5
1 Neutrophils and macrophages are phagocytes that travel throughout the body in pursuit of invading pathogens.
2 Neutrophils are normally found in the bloodstream and are the most abundant type of phagocyte normally representing 50 to 60 of the total circulating leukocytes.
3 During the acute phase of inflammation particularly as a result of bacterial infection neutrophils migrate toward the site of inflammation in a process called chemotaxis and are usually the first cells to arrive at the scene of infection.
4 Macrophages are versatile cells that reside within tissues and produce a wide array of chemicals including enzymes complement proteins and regulatory factors such as interleukin 1.
5 Macrophages also act as scavengers ridding the body of wornout cells and other debris and as antigenpresenting cells that activate the adaptive immune system.
6 What are two types of phagocytes that travel through the body to find invading pathogens?	Neutrophils and macrophages	1
7 What are the most abundant kind of phagocyte?	Neutrophils	2
8 What percentage of leukocytes do neutrophils represent?	50 to 60	2
9 What is the process in which neutrophils move towards the site of inflammation called?	chemotaxis	3
10 What is a regulatory factor produced by macrophages?	interleukin 1	4
1 Leukocytes white blood cells act like independent singlecelled organisms and are the second arm of the innate immune system.
2 The innate leukocytes include the phagocytes macrophages neutrophils and dendritic cells mast cells eosinophils basophils and natural killer cells.
3 These cells identify and eliminate pathogens either by attacking larger pathogens through contact or by engulfing and then killing microorganisms.
4 Innate cells are also important mediators in the activation of the adaptive immune system.
5 What are white blood cells known as?	Leukocytes	1
6 What cells are the second arm of the innate immune system?	Leukocytes white blood cells	1
7 Innate cells can act as mediators in the activation of what branch of the immune system?	adaptive immune system	4
8 What are three kinds of phagocytes?	macrophages  neutrophils  and dendritic cells	2
1 Dendritic cells DC are phagocytes in tissues that are in contact with the external environment therefore they are located mainly in the skin nose lungs stomach and intestines.
2 They are named for their resemblance to neuronal dendrites as both have many spinelike projections but dendritic cells are in no way connected to the nervous system.
3 Dendritic cells serve as a link between the bodily tissues and the innate and adaptive immune systems as they present antigens to T cells one of the key cell types of the adaptive immune system.
4 What are the phagocytes that are located in tissues in contact with the external environment called?	Dendritic cells	1
5 Dendritic cells are named that because they resemble what?	neuronal dendrites	2
6 What are one of the key cell types of the adaptive immune system?	T cells	3
7 Dendritic cells present antigens to what cells of the adaptive nervous system?	T cells	3
1 Natural killer cells or NK cells are a component of the innate immune system which does not directly attack invading microbes.
2 Rather NK cells destroy compromised host cells such as tumor cells or virusinfected cells recognizing such cells by a condition known as missing self.
3 This term describes cells with low levels of a cellsurface marker called MHC I major histocompatibility complex – a situation that can arise in viral infections of host cells.
4 They were named natural killer because of the initial notion that they do not require activation in order to kill cells that are missing self.
5 For many years it was unclear how NK cells recognize tumor cells and infected cells.
6 It is now known that the MHC makeup on the surface of those cells is altered and the NK cells become activated through recognition of missing self.
7 Normal body cells are not recognized and attacked by NK cells because they express intact self MHC antigens.
8 Those MHC antigens are recognized by killer cell immunoglobulin receptors KIR which essentially put the brakes on NK cells.
9 Natural killer cells recognize cells that should be targeted by a condition known as what?	missing self	2
10 What is one part of the innate immune system that doesnt attack microbes directly?	Natural killer cells	1
11 Missing self desribes cells that only have small amounts of what cellsurface marker?	MHC I major histocompatibility complex	3
12 MHC antigens on normal body cells are recognized by what receptor on NK cells?	killer cell immunoglobulin receptors KIR	8
1 The adaptive immune system evolved in early vertebrates and allows for a stronger immune response as well as immunological memory where each pathogen is remembered by a signature antigen.
2 The adaptive immune response is antigenspecific and requires the recognition of specific nonself antigens during a process called antigen presentation.
3 Antigen specificity allows for the generation of responses that are tailored to specific pathogens or pathogeninfected cells.
4 The ability to mount these tailored responses is maintained in the body by memory cells.
5 Should a pathogen infect the body more than once these specific memory cells are used to quickly eliminate it.
6 In what types of organisms did the adaptive immune system first evolve?	vertebrates	1
7 The adaptive immune system recognizes nonself antigens during a process called what?	antigen presentation	2
8 Antigen specificity  allows responses that are specific to certain types of what?	pathogens or pathogeninfected cells	3
1 Both B cells and T cells carry receptor molecules that recognize specific targets.
2 T cells recognize a nonself target such as a pathogen only after antigens small fragments of the pathogen have been processed and presented in combination with a self receptor called a major histocompatibility complex MHC molecule.
3 There are two major subtypes of T cells the killer T cell and the helper T cell.
4 In addition there are regulatory T cells which have a role in modulating immune response.
5 Killer T cells only recognize antigens coupled to Class I MHC molecules while helper T cells and regulatory T cells only recognize antigens coupled to Class II MHC molecules.
6 These two mechanisms of antigen presentation reflect the different roles of the two types of T cell.
7 A third minor subtype are the γδ T cells that recognize intact antigens that are not bound to MHC receptors.
8 What are the two major subtypes of T cells?	killer T cell and the helper T cell	3
9 What kind of T cells have the purpose of modulating the immune response?	regulatory T cells	4
10 Killer T cells can only recognize antigens coupled to what kind of molecules?	Class I MHC molecules	5
11 Helper and regulatory T cells can only recognize antigens coupled to what kind of molecules?	Class II MHC molecules	5
12 What class of T cells recognizes intact antigens that are not associated with MHC receptors?	γδ T cells	7
1 Killer T cells are a subgroup of T cells that kill cells that are infected with viruses and other pathogens or are otherwise damaged or dysfunctional.
2 As with B cells each type of T cell recognizes a different antigen.
3 Killer T cells are activated when their T cell receptor TCR binds to this specific antigen in a complex with the MHC Class I receptor of another cell.
4 Recognition of this MHCantigen complex is aided by a coreceptor on the T cell called CD8.
5 The T cell then travels throughout the body in search of cells where the MHC I receptors bear this antigen.
6 When an activated T cell contacts such cells it releases cytotoxins such as perforin which form pores in the target cells plasma membrane allowing ions water and toxins to enter.
7 The entry of another toxin called granulysin a protease induces the target cell to undergo apoptosis.
8 T cell killing of host cells is particularly important in preventing the replication of viruses.
9 T cell activation is tightly controlled and generally requires a very strong MHCantigen activation signal or additional activation signals provided by helper T cells see below.
10 What kind of T cells kill cells that are infected with pathogens?	Killer T cells	1
11 What coreceptor on the T cell helps in recognizing the MHCantigen complex?	CD8	4
12 What is the receptor that killer T cells use to bind to specific antigens that are complexed with the MHC Class 1 receptor of another cell?	T cell receptor TCR	3
13 What toxin induces apoptosis in the target cell?	granulysin	7
14 When an activated killer T cell finds cells where the MHC 1 receptor has specific antigens it releases cytotoxins such as what?	perforin	6
1 Helper T cells express T cell receptors TCR that recognize antigen bound to Class II MHC molecules.
2 The MHCantigen complex is also recognized by the helper cells CD4 coreceptor which recruits molecules inside the T cell eg Lck that are responsible for the T cells activation.
3 Helper T cells have a weaker association with the MHCantigen complex than observed for killer T cells meaning many receptors around 200–300 on the helper T cell must be bound by an MHCantigen in order to activate the helper cell while killer T cells can be activated by engagement of a single MHCantigen molecule.
4 Helper T cell activation also requires longer duration of engagement with an antigenpresenting cell.
5 The activation of a resting helper T cell causes it to release cytokines that influence the activity of many cell types.
6 Cytokine signals produced by helper T cells enhance the microbicidal function of macrophages and the activity of killer T cells.
7 In addition helper T cell activation causes an upregulation of molecules expressed on the T cells surface such as CD40 ligand also called CD154 which provide extra stimulatory signals typically required to activate antibodyproducing B cells.
8 What coreceptor recruits molecules inside the T cell that are responsible for cell activation?	CD4 coreceptor	2
9 How many receptors on a helper T cell must be bound to a MHCantigen complex in order for the cell to be activated?	around 200–300	3
10 The receptors on a killer T cell must bind to how many MHC antigen complexes in order to activate the cell?	a single MHCantigen molecule	3
11 Activation of a helper T cell causes it to release what chemicals that influence cell activity?	cytokines	5
12 What is a ligand on the cell surface that is upregulated after helper T cell activation?	CD40 ligand	7
1 Gamma delta T cells γδ T cells possess an alternative T cell receptor TCR as opposed to CD4 and CD8 αβ T cells and share the characteristics of helper T cells cytotoxic T cells and NK cells.
2 The conditions that produce responses from γδ T cells are not fully understood.
3 Like other unconventional T cell subsets bearing invariant TCRs such as CD1drestricted Natural Killer T cells γδ T cells straddle the border between innate and adaptive immunity.
4 On one hand γδ T cells are a component of adaptive immunity as they rearrange TCR genes to produce receptor diversity and can also develop a memory phenotype.
5 On the other hand the various subsets are also part of the innate immune system as restricted TCR or NK receptors may be used as pattern recognition receptors.
6 For example large numbers of human Vγ9Vδ2 T cells respond within hours to common molecules produced by microbes and highly restricted Vδ1 T cells in epithelia respond to stressed epithelial cells.
7 Gamma delta T cells share the characteristics of what other types of T cells?	helper T cells  cytotoxic T cells and NK cells	1
8 Gamma delta T cells have a different version of what receptor?	alternative T cell receptor TCR	1
9 What type of T cells help with both innnate and adaptive immunity?	γδ T cells	3
10 Gamma delta T cells rearrange TCR genes to produce what?	receptor diversity	4
11 What kind of human T cells respond to common molecules produced by microbes?	Vγ9Vδ2 T cells	6
1 A B cell identifies pathogens when antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign antigen.
2 This antigenantibody complex is taken up by the B cell and processed by proteolysis into peptides.
3 The B cell then displays these antigenic peptides on its surface MHC class II molecules.
4 This combination of MHC and antigen attracts a matching helper T cell which releases lymphokines and activates the B cell.
5 As the activated B cell then begins to divide its offspring plasma cells secrete millions of copies of the antibody that recognizes this antigen.
6 These antibodies circulate in blood plasma and lymph bind to pathogens expressing the antigen and mark them for destruction by complement activation or for uptake and destruction by phagocytes.
7 Antibodies can also neutralize challenges directly by binding to bacterial toxins or by interfering with the receptors that viruses and bacteria use to infect cells.
8 What kind of cell identifies pathogens when the antibodies on its surface complex with a specific foreign antigen?	B cell	1
9 What is the process by which the antigenantibody complex is processed in to peptides?	proteolysis	2
10 What does the matching helper T cell release when it binds with the MHCantigen complex of the B cell?	lymphokines	4
1 When B cells and T cells are activated and begin to replicate some of their offspring become longlived memory cells.
2 Throughout the lifetime of an animal these memory cells remember each specific pathogen encountered and can mount a strong response if the pathogen is detected again.
3 This is adaptive because it occurs during the lifetime of an individual as an adaptation to infection with that pathogen and prepares the immune system for future challenges.
4 Immunological memory can be in the form of either passive shortterm memory or active longterm memory.
5 When B cells and T cells begin to replicate what do some of their offspring cells become?	longlived memory cells	1
6 The function of longlived memory cells is an example of what kind of immune response?	adaptive	3
7 Immunological memory can take what two forms?	passive shortterm memory or active longterm memory	4
8 Longlived memory cells can remember previous encounters with what?	specific pathogen	2
1 Newborn infants have no prior exposure to microbes and are particularly vulnerable to infection.
2 Several layers of passive protection are provided by the mother.
3 During pregnancy a particular type of antibody called IgG is transported from mother to baby directly across the placenta so human babies have high levels of antibodies even at birth with the same range of antigen specificities as their mother.
4 Breast milk or colostrum also contains antibodies that are transferred to the gut of the infant and protect against bacterial infections until the newborn can synthesize its own antibodies.
5 This is passive immunity because the fetus does not actually make any memory cells or antibodies—it only borrows them.
6 This passive immunity is usually shortterm lasting from a few days up to several months.
7 In medicine protective passive immunity can also be transferred artificially from one individual to another via antibodyrich serum.
8 Newborns are vulnerable to infection because they have no previous exposure to what?	microbes	1
9 What antibody is transported from the mother to baby across the placenta?	IgG	3
10 Antibodies are transferred to the gut of the infant through what means?	Breast milk or colostrum	4
11 Antibodies transported from the mother to an infant via the placenta is an example of what type of shortlived immunity?	passive immunity	6
1 Hormones can act as immunomodulators altering the sensitivity of the immune system.
2 For example female sex hormones are known immunostimulators of both adaptive and innate immune responses.
3 Some autoimmune diseases such as lupus erythematosus strike women preferentially and their onset often coincides with puberty.
4 By contrast male sex hormones such as testosterone seem to be immunosuppressive.
5 Other hormones appear to regulate the immune system as well most notably prolactin growth hormone and vitamin D.
6 Hormones can alter the sensitivity of the immune system so they can be referred to as what?	immunomodulators	1
7 Female sex hormones are immunostimulators of which immune responses?	adaptive and innate immune responses	2
8 What is an autoimmune disease that affects women preferentially?	lupus erythematosus	3
9 What is the effect of testosterone on the male immune system?	immunosuppressive	4
1 When suffering from sleep deprivation active immunizations may have a diminished effect and may result in lower antibody production and a lower immune response than would be noted in a wellrested individual.
2 Additionally proteins such as NFIL3 which have been shown to be closely intertwined with both Tcell differentiation and our circadian rhythms can be affected through the disturbance of natural light and dark cycles through instances of sleep deprivation shift work etc.
3 As a result these disruptions can lead to an increase in chronic conditions such as heart disease chronic pain and asthma.
4 What is a protein that is closely intertwined with circadian rhythms?	NFIL3	2
5 Disruptions in sleep can lead to increase in what chronic conditions?	heart disease  chronic pain  and asthma	3
6 What kind of deprivation results in diminished immune response and lower antibody production?	sleep deprivation	1
1 It is conjectured that a progressive decline in hormone levels with age is partially responsible for weakened immune responses in aging individuals.
2 Conversely some hormones are regulated by the immune system notably thyroid hormone activity.
3 The agerelated decline in immune function is also related to decreasing vitamin D levels in the elderly.
4 As people age two things happen that negatively affect their vitamin D levels.
5 First they stay indoors more due to decreased activity levels.
6 This means that they get less sun and therefore produce less cholecalciferol via UVB radiation.
7 Second as a person ages the skin becomes less adept at producing vitamin D.
8 What is partially responsible for weakened immune response in older individuals?	decline in hormone levels with age	1
9 As a person gets older what does the skin produce less of?	vitamin D	7
10 The production of what signalling molecules is regulated by the immune system?	hormones	2
11 Older people get less sun and produce less of what chemical via UVB radiation?	cholecalciferol	6
1 The main response of the immune system to tumors is to destroy the abnormal cells using killer T cells sometimes with the assistance of helper T cells.
2 Tumor antigens are presented on MHC class I molecules in a similar way to viral antigens.
3 This allows killer T cells to recognize the tumor cell as abnormal.
4 NK cells also kill tumorous cells in a similar way especially if the tumor cells have fewer MHC class I molecules on their surface than normal this is a common phenomenon with tumors.
5 Sometimes antibodies are generated against tumor cells allowing for their destruction by the complement system.
6 What type of immune cells help to destroy abnormal cells in tumors?	killer T cells	1
7 Lots of tumor cells have fewer of what type of molecule on their surface?	MHC class I molecules	4
8 Tumor antigens are complexed with MHC class I molecules in the same way as what antigens?	viral antigens	2
9 The immune system also produces what molecules in order to allow for tumor destruction by the complement system?	antibodies	5
1 Unlike animals plants lack phagocytic cells but many plant immune responses involve systemic chemical signals that are sent through a plant.
2 Individual plant cells respond to molecules associated with pathogens known as Pathogenassociated molecular patterns or PAMPs.
3 When a part of a plant becomes infected the plant produces a localized hypersensitive response whereby cells at the site of infection undergo rapid apoptosis to prevent the spread of the disease to other parts of the plant.
4 Systemic acquired resistance SAR is a type of defensive response used by plants that renders the entire plant resistant to a particular infectious agent.
5 RNA silencing mechanisms are particularly important in this systemic response as they can block virus replication.
6 Plants lack what kind of immune cells?	phagocytic cells	1
7 Plant cells respond to the molecules associated with pathogens known as what?	Pathogenassociated molecular patterns	2
8 Cells of the site of an infection in a plant undergo what process to prevent spread of the disease?	apoptosis	3
9 What is a kind of defense response that makes the entire plant resistant to a particular agent?	Systemic acquired resistance SAR	4
10 What is a mechanism that can help plants block virus replication?	RNA silencing mechanisms	5
1 Overactive immune responses comprise the other end of immune dysfunction particularly the autoimmune disorders.
2 Here the immune system fails to properly distinguish between self and nonself and attacks part of the body.
3 Under normal circumstances many T cells and antibodies react with self peptides.
4 One of the functions of specialized cells located in the thymus and bone marrow is to present young lymphocytes with self antigens produced throughout the body and to eliminate those cells that recognize selfantigens preventing autoimmunity.
5 What kind of disorders are the result of an overactive immune response?	autoimmune disorders	1
6 In autoimmune disorders the immune system doesnt distinguish between what types of cells?	self and nonself	2
7 Where are the specialized cells that eliminate cells that recognize selfantigens located?	thymus and bone marrow	4
8 Under normal conditions T cells and antibodies produce what kind of peptides?	self peptides	3
1 Immunodeficiencies occur when one or more of the components of the immune system are inactive.
2 The ability of the immune system to respond to pathogens is diminished in both the young and the elderly with immune responses beginning to decline at around 50 years of age due to immunosenescence.
3 In developed countries obesity alcoholism and drug use are common causes of poor immune function.
4 However malnutrition is the most common cause of immunodeficiency in developing countries.
5 Diets lacking sufficient protein are associated with impaired cellmediated immunity complement activity phagocyte function IgA antibody concentrations and cytokine production.
6 Additionally the loss of the thymus at an early age through genetic mutation or surgical removal results in severe immunodeficiency and a high susceptibility to infection.
7 What kind of disorders occur when part of the immune system isnt active?	Immunodeficiencies	1
8 In what two age groups is the strength of the immune system reduced?	the young and the elderly	2
9 At what age do immune responses typically begin to decline?	around 50 years of age	2
10 What are some causes of reduced immune function in developed countries?	obesity  alcoholism  and drug use	3
11 What is the most common cause of immunodeficiency in developing nations?	malnutrition	4
1 Longterm active memory is acquired following infection by activation of B and T cells.
2 Active immunity can also be generated artificially through vaccination.
3 The principle behind vaccination also called immunization is to introduce an antigen from a pathogen in order to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that particular pathogen without causing disease associated with that organism.
4 This deliberate induction of an immune response is successful because it exploits the natural specificity of the immune system as well as its inducibility.
5 With infectious disease remaining one of the leading causes of death in the human population vaccination represents the most effective manipulation of the immune system mankind has developed.
6 By what process can active immunity be generated in an artificial manner?	vaccination	2
7 What is the process of vaccination also known as?	immunization	3
8 In the process of vaccination what is introduced in order to develop a specific immunity?	an antigen from a pathogen	3
9 Vaccination exploits what feature of the human immune system in order to be successful?	natural specificity of the immune system	4
1 The success of any pathogen depends on its ability to elude host immune responses.
2 Therefore pathogens evolved several methods that allow them to successfully infect a host while evading detection or destruction by the immune system.
3 Bacteria often overcome physical barriers by secreting enzymes that digest the barrier for example by using a type II secretion system.
4 Alternatively using a type III secretion system they may insert a hollow tube into the host cell providing a direct route for proteins to move from the pathogen to the host.
5 These proteins are often used to shut down host defenses.
6 Bacteria often secrete what kind of proteins to ingest a physical barrier?	enzymes	3
7 What kind of system of infection involves inserting a hollow tube into a host cell?	type III secretion system	4
8 In a type III secretion system proteins are transported to the host cell in order to do what?	shut down host defenses	5
9 The success of pathogens is predicated on their ability to do what?	elude host immune responses	1
1 In the mid1950s Frank Burnet inspired by a suggestion made by Niels Jerne formulated the clonal selection theory CST of immunity.
2 On the basis of CST Burnet developed a theory of how an immune response is triggered according to the selfnonself distinction self constituents constituents of the body do not trigger destructive immune responses while nonself entities pathogens an allograft trigger a destructive immune response.
3 The theory was later modified to reflect new discoveries regarding histocompatibility or the complex twosignal activation of T cells.
4 The selfnonself theory of immunity and the selfnonself vocabulary have been criticized but remain very influential.
5 Who formulated the idea of clonal selection theory of immunity?	Frank Burnet	1
6 What are two examples of nonself entities in accordance with Frank Burnets theory?	pathogens  an allograft	2
7 What is the complex twosignal activation of T cells referred to?	histocompatibility	3
8 What other scientist influence Frank Burnet when he was formulating his theory of immunity?	Niels Jerne	1
1 Antiinflammatory drugs are often used to control the effects of inflammation.
2 Glucocorticoids are the most powerful of these drugs however these drugs can have many undesirable side effects such as central obesity hyperglycemia osteoporosis and their use must be tightly controlled.
3 Lower doses of antiinflammatory drugs are often used in conjunction with cytotoxic or immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate or azathioprine.
4 Cytotoxic drugs inhibit the immune response by killing dividing cells such as activated T cells.
5 However the killing is indiscriminate and other constantly dividing cells and their organs are affected which causes toxic side effects.
6 Immunosuppressive drugs such as cyclosporin prevent T cells from responding to signals correctly by inhibiting signal transduction pathways.
7 What are the most powerful class of antiinflammatory drugs?	Glucocorticoids	2
8 Low doses of antiinflammatories are sometimes used with what classes of drugs?	cytotoxic or immunosuppressive drugs	3
9 What are two examples of cytotoxic or immunosuppressive drugs?	methotrexate or azathioprine	3
10 What is an example of an immunosuppressive drug that prevents T cell activity by altering signal transduction pathways?	cyclosporin	6
1 In contrast during wake periods differentiated effector cells such as cytotoxic natural killer cells and CTLs cytotoxic T lymphocytes peak in order to elicit an effective response against any intruding pathogens.
2 As well during awake active times antiinflammatory molecules such as cortisol and catecholamines peak.
3 There are two theories as to why the proinflammatory state is reserved for sleep time.
4 First inflammation would cause serious cognitive and physical impairments if it were to occur during wake times.
5 Second inflammation may occur during sleep times due to the presence of melatonin.
