6 Inflammation causes a great deal of oxidative stress and the presence of melatonin during sleep times could actively counteract free radical production during this time.
7 What are examples of differentiated effector cells that peak during wake periods?	cytotoxic natural killer cells and CTLs cytotoxic T lymphocytes	1
8 What are two antiinflammatory molecules that peak during awake hours?	cortisol and catecholamines	2
9 Inflammation occurs during sleep times because of the presence of what molecule?	melatonin	5
10 Melatonin during sleep can actively counteract the production of what?	free radical production	6
1 When a Tcell encounters a foreign pathogen it extends a vitamin D receptor.
2 This is essentially a signaling device that allows the Tcell to bind to the active form of vitamin D the steroid hormone calcitriol.
3 Tcells have a symbiotic relationship with vitamin D Not only does the Tcell extend a vitamin D receptor in essence asking to bind to the steroid hormone version of vitamin D calcitriol but the Tcell expresses the gene CYP27B1 which is the gene responsible for converting the prehormone version of vitamin D calcidiol into the steroid hormone version calcitriol.
4 Only after binding to calcitriol can Tcells perform their intended function.
5 Other immune system cells that are known to express CYP27B1 and thus activate vitamin D calcidiol are dendritic cells keratinocytes and macrophages.
6 What does a T cell extend when it encounters a foreign pathogen?	a vitamin D receptor	1
7 What is the active form of vitamin D known as?	calcitriol	2
8 What is the nature of the relationship between Tcells and vitamin D?	symbiotic relationship	3
9 What gene is responsible for converting calcidiol into calcitriol?	gene CYP27B1	3
10 Other than T cells what other immune cells express CYP27B1?	dendritic cells  keratinocytes and macrophages	5
1 Pattern recognition receptors are proteins used by nearly all organisms to identify molecules associated with pathogens.
2 Antimicrobial peptides called defensins are an evolutionarily conserved component of the innate immune response found in all animals and plants and represent the main form of invertebrate systemic immunity.
3 The complement system and phagocytic cells are also used by most forms of invertebrate life.
4 Ribonucleases and the RNA interference pathway are conserved across all eukaryotes and are thought to play a role in the immune response to viruses.
5 What are the proteins that organisms use to identify molecules associated with pathogens?	Pattern recognition receptors	1
6 What are the antimicrobial peptides that are the main form of invertebrate systemic immunity called?	defensins	2
7 What cell type is also used for immune response in most types of invertebrate life?	phagocytic cells	3
8 What pathway that plays a role in immune response to viruses is present in all eukaryotes?	RNA interference pathway	4
1 Evolution of the adaptive immune system occurred in an ancestor of the jawed vertebrates.
2 Many of the classical molecules of the adaptive immune system eg immunoglobulins and T cell receptors exist only in jawed vertebrates.
3 However a distinct lymphocytederived molecule has been discovered in primitive jawless vertebrates such as the lamprey and hagfish.
4 These animals possess a large array of molecules called Variable lymphocyte receptors VLRs that like the antigen receptors of jawed vertebrates are produced from only a small number one or two of genes.
5 These molecules are believed to bind pathogenic antigens in a similar way to antibodies and with the same degree of specificity.
6 What molecules of the adaptive immune system only exist in jawed vertebrates?	immunoglobulins and T cell receptors	2
7 What are two examples of primitive jawless vertebrates?	the lamprey and hagfish	3
8 Primitive jawless vertebrates possess an array of receptors referred to as what?	Variable lymphocyte receptors VLRs	4
9 Evolution of what part of the immune system occurred in the evolutionary ancestor of jawed vertebrates?	adaptive immune system	1
1 It is likely that a multicomponent adaptive immune system arose with the first vertebrates as invertebrates do not generate lymphocytes or an antibodybased humoral response.
2 Many species however utilize mechanisms that appear to be precursors of these aspects of vertebrate immunity.
3 Immune systems appear even in the structurally most simple forms of life with bacteria using a unique defense mechanism called the restriction modification system to protect themselves from viral pathogens called bacteriophages.
4 Prokaryotes also possess acquired immunity through a system that uses CRISPR sequences to retain fragments of the genomes of phage that they have come into contact with in the past which allows them to block virus replication through a form of RNA interference.
5 Offensive elements of the immune systems are also present in unicellular eukaryotes but studies of their roles in defense are few.
6 Invertebrates do not generate what type of cells that are a part of the vertebrate adaptive immune system?	lymphocytes	1
7 What is the main defense mechanism of bacteria known as?	the restriction modification system	3
8 The restriction modification system is used by bacteria for protection from what pathogens?	bacteriophages	3
9 What is the system by which prokaryotes retain phage gene fragments that they have previously come in contact with?	CRISPR	4
1 Immunology is strongly experimental in everyday practice but is also characterized by an ongoing theoretical attitude.
2 Many theories have been suggested in immunology from the end of the nineteenth century up to the present time.
3 The end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century saw a battle between cellular and humoral theories of immunity.
4 According to the cellular theory of immunity represented in particular by Elie Metchnikoff it was cells – more precisely phagocytes – that were responsible for immune responses.
5 In contrast the humoral theory of immunity held among others by Robert Koch and Emil von Behring stated that the active immune agents were soluble components molecules found in the organism’s “humors” rather than its cells.
6 What were the two main theories of immunity at the end of the 19th century?	cellular and humoral theories of immunity	3
7 Who was the main proponent of the cellular theory of immunity?	Elie Metchnikoff	4
8 Under Elie Metchnikoffs cellular theory what cells were responsible for immune response?	phagocytes	4
9 What two scientists were proponents of the humoral theory of immunity?	Robert Koch and Emil von Behring	5
10 According to the humoral theory of immunity what were the bodies immune agents?	soluble components molecules	5
1 Clearly some tumors evade the immune system and go on to become cancers.
2 Tumor cells often have a reduced number of MHC class I molecules on their surface thus avoiding detection by killer T cells.
3 Some tumor cells also release products that inhibit the immune response for example by secreting the cytokine TGFβ which suppresses the activity of macrophages and lymphocytes.
4 In addition immunological tolerance may develop against tumor antigens so the immune system no longer attacks the tumor cells.
5 Tumors that are able to evade the bodys immune response can become what?	cancers	1
6 What receptors do tumor cells often have reduced concentrations of?	MHC class I molecules	2
7 What is a chemical secreted by tumors that suppresses the immune response?	cytokine TGFβ	3
8 Cytokine TBFB suppresses the activity of what cell types?	macrophages and lymphocytes	3
1 Hypersensitivity is an immune response that damages the bodys own tissues.
2 They are divided into four classes Type I – IV based on the mechanisms involved and the time course of the hypersensitive reaction.
3 Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate or anaphylactic reaction often associated with allergy.
4 Symptoms can range from mild discomfort to death.
5 Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE which triggers degranulation of mast cells and basophils when crosslinked by antigen.
6 Type II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to antigens on the patients own cells marking them for destruction.
7 This is also called antibodydependent or cytotoxic hypersensitivity and is mediated by IgG and IgM antibodies.
8 Immune complexes aggregations of antigens complement proteins and IgG and IgM antibodies deposited in various tissues trigger Type III hypersensitivity reactions.
9 Type IV hypersensitivity also known as cellmediated or delayed type hypersensitivity usually takes between two and three days to develop.
10 Type IV reactions are involved in many autoimmune and infectious diseases but may also involve contact dermatitis poison ivy.
11 These reactions are mediated by T cells monocytes and macrophages.
12 What is the name for a response of the immune system that damages the bodys native tissues?	Hypersensitivity	1
13 How many classes of immune hypersensitivity are there?	four classes Type I – IV	2
14 What type of hypersensitivity is associated with allergies?	Type I	3
15 What is the chemical that mediates Type 1 hypersensitivity?	IgE	5
16 Antibodydependent hypersensitivity belongs to what class of hypersensitivity?	Type II hypersensitivity	6
1 An evasion strategy used by several pathogens to avoid the innate immune system is to hide within the cells of their host also called intracellular pathogenesis.
2 Here a pathogen spends most of its lifecycle inside host cells where it is shielded from direct contact with immune cells antibodies and complement.
3 Some examples of intracellular pathogens include viruses the food poisoning bacterium Salmonella and the eukaryotic parasites that cause malaria Plasmodium falciparum and leishmaniasis Leishmania spp.
4 Other bacteria such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis live inside a protective capsule that prevents lysis by complement.
5 Many pathogens secrete compounds that diminish or misdirect the hosts immune response.
6 Some bacteria form biofilms to protect themselves from the cells and proteins of the immune system.
7 Such biofilms are present in many successful infections eg the chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Burkholderia cenocepacia infections characteristic of cystic fibrosis.
8 Other bacteria generate surface proteins that bind to antibodies rendering them ineffective examples include Streptococcus protein G Staphylococcus aureus protein A and Peptostreptococcus magnus protein L.
9 What is the process by which pathogens evade the immune system by hiding inside the host cells called?	intracellular pathogenesis	1
10 What food bacteria is an example of intracellular pathogenesis?	Salmonella	3
11 What is the eukaryotic parasite responsible for malaria known as?	Plasmodium falciparum	3
12 What bacteria lives inside a protective capsule that serves to prevent cell lysis?	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	4
13 What protein does Staphylococcus aureus produce to make antibodies ineffective?	protein A	8
1 The mechanisms used to evade the adaptive immune system are more complicated.
2 The simplest approach is to rapidly change nonessential epitopes amino acids andor sugars on the surface of the pathogen while keeping essential epitopes concealed.
3 This is called antigenic variation.
4 An example is HIV which mutates rapidly so the proteins on its viral envelope that are essential for entry into its host target cell are constantly changing.
5 These frequent changes in antigens may explain the failures of vaccines directed at this virus.
6 The parasite Trypanosoma brucei uses a similar strategy constantly switching one type of surface protein for another allowing it to stay one step ahead of the antibody response.
7 Masking antigens with host molecules is another common strategy for avoiding detection by the immune system.
8 In HIV the envelope that covers the virion is formed from the outermost membrane of the host cell such selfcloaked viruses make it difficult for the immune system to identify them as nonself structures.
9 What is the process by which the adaptive immune system is evaded by the chainging of nonessential epitopes called?	antigenic variation	3
10 What is an example of a virus that uses antigenic variation?	HIV	4
11 What is an example of a parasite that used the antigenic variation strategy to evade destruction?	Trypanosoma brucei	6
12 What compounds can be masked with the molecules of the host cell in order for a virus to evade detection?	antigens	7
1 Another important role of the immune system is to identify and eliminate tumors.
2 This is called immune surveillance.
3 The transformed cells of tumors express antigens that are not found on normal cells.
4 To the immune system these antigens appear foreign and their presence causes immune cells to attack the transformed tumor cells.
5 The antigens expressed by tumors have several sources some are derived from oncogenic viruses like human papillomavirus which causes cervical cancer while others are the organisms own proteins that occur at low levels in normal cells but reach high levels in tumor cells.
6 One example is an enzyme called tyrosinase that when expressed at high levels transforms certain skin cells eg.
7 melanocytes into tumors called melanomas.
8 A third possible source of tumor antigens are proteins normally important for regulating cell growth and survival that commonly mutate into cancer inducing molecules called oncogenes.
9 What is the process by which the immune system identifies tumors called?	immune surveillance	2
10 What is the virus in humans that causes cervical cancer?	human papillomavirus	5
11 What is an example of an enzyme that can transform skin cells into tumors when expressed at high levels?	tyrosinase	6
12 What are cancerous tumors of the skin known as?	melanomas	7
13 What are the skin cells that can be transformed into tumors known as?	melanocytes	7
1 Larger drugs 500 Da can provoke a neutralizing immune response particularly if the drugs are administered repeatedly or in larger doses.
2 This limits the effectiveness of drugs based on larger peptides and proteins which are typically larger than 6000 Da.
3 In some cases the drug itself is not immunogenic but may be coadministered with an immunogenic compound as is sometimes the case for Taxol.
4 Computational methods have been developed to predict the immunogenicity of peptides and proteins which are particularly useful in designing therapeutic antibodies assessing likely virulence of mutations in viral coat particles and validation of proposed peptidebased drug treatments.
5 Early techniques relied mainly on the observation that hydrophilic amino acids are overrepresented in epitope regions than hydrophobic amino acids however more recent developments rely on machine learning techniques using databases of existing known epitopes usually on wellstudied virus proteins as a training set.
6 A publicly accessible database has been established for the cataloguing of epitopes from pathogens known to be recognizable by B cells.
7 The emerging field of bioinformaticsbased studies of immunogenicity is referred to as immunoinformatics.
8 Immunoproteomics is the study of large sets of proteins proteomics involved in the immune response.
9 At what size and larger can drugs elicit a neutralizing immune response?	500 Da	1
10 What kind of amino acids are overrepresented in epitope regions?	hydrophilic amino acids	5
11 What is the study of proteins involved in immune response known as?	Immunoproteomics	8
12 There is a public database of epitopes for pathogens known to be recognizable by what cells?	B cells	6
13 What is the field of studying immunogenicity through bioinformatics known as?	immunoinformatics	7
1 In addition to the negative consequences of sleep deprivation sleep and the intertwined circadian system have been shown to have strong regulatory effects on immunological functions affecting both the innate and the adaptive immunity.
2 First during the early slowwavesleep stage a sudden drop in blood levels of cortisol epinephrine and norepinephrine induce increased blood levels of the hormones leptin pituitary growth hormone and prolactin.
3 These signals induce a proinflammatory state through the production of the proinflammatory cytokines interleukin1 interleukin12 TNFalpha and IFNgamma.
4 These cytokines then stimulate immune functions such as immune cells activation proliferation and differentiation.
5 It is during this time that undifferentiated or less differentiated like naïve and central memory T cells peak ie.
6 during a time of a slowly evolving adaptive immune response.
7 In addition to these effects the milieu of hormones produced at this time leptin pituitary growth hormone and prolactin support the interactions between APCs and Tcells a shift of the Th1Th2 cytokine balance towards one that supports Th1 an increase in overall Th cell proliferation and naïve T cell migration to lymph nodes.
8 This milieu is also thought to support the formation of longlasting immune memory through the initiation of Th1 immune responses.
9 Drop in the blood levels of cortisol and epinephrine results in increase levels of what hormones?	leptin  pituitary growth hormone  and prolactin	2
10 Hormones released during sleep support the interaction of Tcells and what species?	APCs	7
11 Sleep hormones shift the cytokine balance to which cytokine?	Th1	7
12 Sleep hormone release supports formation of immune memory by initiating what immune response?	Th1 immune responses	8
1 In humans this response is activated by complement binding to antibodies that have attached to these microbes or the binding of complement proteins to carbohydrates on the surfaces of microbes.
2 This recognition signal triggers a rapid killing response.
3 The speed of the response is a result of signal amplification that occurs following sequential proteolytic activation of complement molecules which are also proteases.
4 After complement proteins initially bind to the microbe they activate their protease activity which in turn activates other complement proteases and so on.
5 This produces a catalytic cascade that amplifies the initial signal by controlled positive feedback.
6 The cascade results in the production of peptides that attract immune cells increase vascular permeability and opsonize coat the surface of a pathogen marking it for destruction.
7 This deposition of complement can also kill cells directly by disrupting their plasma membrane.
8 Complement proteins bind to what kind of molecules on the surface of microbes in order to elicit an immune response?	carbohydrates	1
9 How can the deposition of compliment kill invader cells directly?	disrupting their plasma membrane	7
10 The speed of the killing response of the human immune system is a product of what process?	signal amplification	3
11 What type of cascade results when complement proteins bind to microbes and activate their protease activity?	catalytic cascade	5
1 One of its earliest massive implementations was brought about by Egyptians against the British occupation in the 1919 Revolution.
2 Civil disobedience is one of the many ways people have rebelled against what they deem to be unfair laws.
3 It has been used in many nonviolent resistance movements in India Gandhis campaigns for independence from the British Empire in Czechoslovakias Velvet Revolution and in East Germany to oust their communist governments In South Africa in the fight against apartheid in the American Civil Rights Movement in the Singing Revolution to bring independence to the Baltic countries from the Soviet Union recently with the 2003 Rose Revolution in Georgia and the 2004 Orange Revolution in Ukraine among other various movements worldwide.
4 What is it called when people in society rebel against laws they think are unfair?	Civil disobedience	2
5 What is an example of major civil disobedience in South Africa?	apartheid	3
6 What was the the movement called that brought Baltic countries independence from the Soviet Union?	Singing Revolution	3
7 In 2004 the Orange revolution occurred in what country?	Ukraine	3
8 Where was the location of the 2003 Rose revolution?	Georgia	3
9 Which people brought forward one of the earliest examples of Civil Disobedience?	Egyptians	1
10 Who was one of the earliest examples of Civil Disobedience against?	the British	1
11 Why do people chose civil disobedience to protest?	nonviolent resistance	3
12 What does civil disobedience protest against?	unfair laws	2
13 What civil rights movement in the US was known for its disobedience?	American Civil Rights Movement	3
1 One of the oldest depictions of civil disobedience is in Sophocles play Antigone in which Antigone one of the daughters of former King of Thebes Oedipus defies Creon the current King of Thebes who is trying to stop her from giving her brother Polynices a proper burial.
2 She gives a stirring speech in which she tells him that she must obey her conscience rather than human law.
3 She is not at all afraid of the death he threatens her with and eventually carries out but she is afraid of how her conscience will smite her if she does not do this.
4 Sophocles demonstrated civil disobedience in a play that was called?	Antigone	1
5 Who is Antigones father in the play?	former King of Thebes	1
6 What is the name of the current King of Thebes in the play?	Creon	1
7 What character in the play portrays civil disobedience?	Oedipus	1
8 What is Creon trying to stop Antigone from doing in the play?	giving her brother Polynices a proper burial	1
9 What play showed an early depiction of civil disobedience?	Antigone	1
10 Antigone was a play made by whom?	Sophocles	1
11 In Antigone who was the target of civil disobedience?	Creon  the current King of Thebes	1
12 What was the protest in Antigone about?	giving her brother Polynices a proper burial	1
13 How was the civil disobedience shown in Antigone?	obey her conscience rather than human law	2
1 Following the Peterloo massacre of 1819 poet Percy Shelley wrote the political poem The Mask of Anarchy later that year that begins with the images of what he thought to be the unjust forms of authority of his time—and then imagines the stirrings of a new form of social action.
2 It is perhaps the first modernvague statement of the principle of nonviolent protest.
3 A version was taken up by the author Henry David Thoreau in his essay Civil Disobedience and later by Gandhi in his doctrine of Satyagraha.
4 Gandhis Satyagraha was partially influenced and inspired by Shelleys nonviolence in protest and political action.
5 In particular it is known that Gandhi would often quote Shelleys Masque of Anarchy to vast audiences during the campaign for a free India.
6 After the Peterloo massacre what poet wrote The Massacre of Anarchy?	Percy Shelley	1
7 His poem is considered the first kind of what type of protest?	nonviolent	2
8 Inspired by Shelley what was the name of Gandhis doctrine?	Satyagraha	4
9 Gandhi often referenced Shelleys poem in his efforts to do what?	free India	5
10 What famous author used similarity and likeness of Percy Shelly in his writing?	Henry David Thoreau	3
11 Who wrote the poem The Mark of Anarchy?	Percy Shelley	1
12 The Mark of Anarchy was written to protest against what?	unjust forms of authority	1
13 What was the principle shown in The Mark of Anarchy?	principle of nonviolent protest	2
14 What was Ghandis work called?	doctrine of Satyagraha	3
15 Which famous Indian practiced civil disobedience?	Gandhi	3
1 It has been argued that the term civil disobedience has always suffered from ambiguity and in modern times become utterly debased.
2 Marshall Cohen notes It has been used to describe everything from bringing a testcase in the federal courts to taking aim at a federal official.
3 Indeed for Vice President Agnew it has become a codeword describing the activities of muggers arsonists draft evaders campaign hecklers campus militants antiwar demonstrators juvenile delinquents and political assassins.
4 Vice President Agnew describes Civil disobedience in what activities?	muggers  arsonists  draft evaders  campaign hecklers  campus militants  antiwar demonstrators  juvenile delinquents and political assassins	3
5 What person argues that civil disobedience is used to describe everything?	Marshall Cohen	2
6 Civil disobedience has been argued in more recent times to have suffered from what?	ambiguity	1
7 More in the present prevalence of civil disobedience has turned and said to be?	utterly debased	1
8 In modern times what is said about civil disobedience?	become utterly debased	1
9 Who noted the different current uses of civil disobedience?	Marshall Cohen	2
10 How has civil disobedience evolved in current times?	codeword describing the activities of muggers  arsonists  draft evaders	3
11 Who gave a negative connotation to civil disobedience in recent history?	Vice President Agnew	3
12 What issue has been plaguing the civil disobedience movement	ambiguity 	1.
1 LeGrande writes that the formulation of a single allencompassing definition of the term is extremely difficult if not impossible.
2 In reviewing the voluminous literature on the subject the student of civil disobedience rapidly finds himself surrounded by a maze of semantical problems and grammatical niceties.
3 Like Alice in Wonderland he often finds that specific terminology has no more or no less meaning than the individual orator intends it to have.
4 He encourages a distinction between lawful protest demonstration nonviolent civil disobedience and violent civil disobedience.
5 Who wrote that it is difficult to produce an all inclusive definition of civil disobedience?	LeGrande	1
6 Le Grande also wrote that defining the term civil disobedience so difficult it could be described as?	impossible	1
7 Le grand asks for a variance of what three terms?	lawful protest demonstration  nonviolent civil disobedience  and violent civil disobedience	4
8 Le grand states that students studying civil disobedience will often run into grammatical niceties and what other problem?	semantical	2
9 Le grand concludes that an authors words offer only what they intended for them to imply regarding this type of terminology?	specific	3
10 Who said that writing a good description of civil disobedience is hard?	LeGrande	1
11 How much literature has been written regarding civil disobedience?	voluminous literature	2
12 What issue plagues the literature about civil disobedience?	semantical problems and grammatical niceties	2
13 What type of protest falls under civil disobedience without aggression?	nonviolent civil disobedience	4
14 What type of civil disobedience is accompanied by aggression?	violent civil disobedience	4
1 Civil disobedience is usually defined as pertaining to a citizens relation to the state and its laws as distinguished from a constitutional impasse in which two public agencies especially two equally sovereign branches of government conflict.
2 For instance if the head of government of a country were to refuse to enforce a decision of that countrys highest court it would not be civil disobedience since the head of government would be acting in her or his capacity as public official rather than private citizen.
3 If the head of government refuses to enforce a decision of the highest court what terminology could be used?	constitutional impasse	1
4 Constitutional impasse is different from civil disobedience because does not include what type of person?	citizens	1
5 How is civil disobedience typically defined in connection of the citizens?	to the state and its laws	1
6 When would a person be considered to be excising a constitutional impasse?	the head of government would be acting in her or his capacity as public official	2
7 Constitutional impasse is distinct from what key term?	Civil disobedience	1
8 What does civil disobedience relate to?	the state and its laws	1
9 What does not constitute as civil disobedience?	refuse to enforce a decision	2
10 What type of person can not be attributed civil disobedience?	head of government	2
11 Civil Disobedience is mainly performed by what population group?	private citizen	2
12 What group of people cannot be part of civil disobedience?	sovereign branches of government	1
1 However this definition is disputed by Thoreaus political philosophy pitching the conscience vs the collective.
2 The individual is the final judge of right and wrong.
3 More than this since only individuals act only individuals can act unjustly.
4 When the government knocks on the door it is an individual in the form of a postman or tax collector whose hand hits the wood.
5 Before Thoreau’s imprisonment when a confused taxman had wondered aloud about how to handle his refusal to pay Thoreau had advised “Resign” If a man chose to be an agent of injustice then Thoreau insisted on confronting him with the fact that he was making a choice.
6 But if government is “the voice of the people” as it is often called shouldn’t that voice be heeded.
7 Thoreau admits that government may express the will of the majority but it may also express nothing more than the will of elite politicians.
8 Even a good form of government is “liable to be abused and perverted before the people can act through it” Moreover even if a government did express the voice of the people this fact would not compel the obedience of individuals who disagree with what is being said.
9 The majority may be powerful but it is not necessarily right.
10 What then is the proper relationship between the individual and the government.

1 Some theories of civil disobedience hold that civil disobedience is only justified against governmental entities.
2 Brownlee argues that disobedience in opposition to the decisions of nongovernmental agencies such as trade unions banks and private universities can be justified if it reflects a larger challenge to the legal system that permits those decisions to be taken.
3 The same principle she argues applies to breaches of law in protest against international organizations and foreign governments.
4 Some theories argue that civil disobedience is justified in regard to?	governmental entities	1
5 Brownlee argues disobedience can be justified toward what institutions?	trade unions  banks  and private universities	2
6 Brownlee justifies civil disobedience toward what branch of the government?	legal system	2
7 Browlee also applies that civil disobedience is okay regarding?	international organizations and foreign governments	3
8 Who claims that public companies can also be part of civil disobedience?	Brownlee	2

11 What public entity of learning is often target of civil disobedience?	universities	2
1 It is usually recognized that lawbreaking if it is not done publicly at least must be publicly announced in order to constitute civil disobedience.
2 But Stephen Eilmann argues that if it is necessary to disobey rules that conflict with morality we might ask why disobedience should take the form of public civil disobedience rather than simply covert lawbreaking.
3 If a lawyer wishes to help a client overcome legal obstacles to securing her or his natural rights he might for instance find that assisting in fabricating evidence or committing perjury is more effective than open disobedience.
4 This assumes that common morality does not have a prohibition on deceit in such situations.
5 The Fully Informed Jury Associations publication A Primer for Prospective Jurors notes Think of the dilemma faced by German citizens when Hitlers secret police demanded to know if they were hiding a Jew in their house.
6 By this definition civil disobedience could be traced back to the Book of Exodus where Shiphrah and Puah refused a direct order of Pharaoh but misrepresented how they did it.
7 Exodus 1 1519.
8 If law breaking is not done in a public manor it is not considered what term?	civil disobedience	1
9 Stephen Eilmann asks why show public civil disobedience instead what is a better idea?	covert lawbreaking	2
10 Stephen Eilmann demonstrates covert law breaking in Nazi Germany   Citizens illegally had been doing what?	hiding a Jew in their house	5
11 Stephen Eildmann cites the oldest known example of civil disobedience in what part of the bible?	Exodus 1 1519	7
12 What two women were defying the pharaoh in the story from the book of Exodus?	Shiphrah and Puah	6
13 What must be done to make non public lawbreaking acknowledged as civil disobedience?	must be publicly announced	1
14 What is necessary to disobey?	rules that conflict with morality	2
15 What is sometimes more effective than civil disobedience at times?	fabricating evidence or committing perjury	3
16 What dilemma is a good example of moral civil disobedience?	the dilemma faced by German citizens	5
17 What book of the Bible discusses civil disobedience?	Book of Exodus	6
1 There have been debates as to whether civil disobedience must necessarily be nonviolent.
2 Blacks Law Dictionary includes nonviolence in its definition of civil disobedience.
3 Christian Bays encyclopedia article states that civil disobedience requires carefully chosen and legitimate means but holds that they do not have to be nonviolent.
4 It has been argued that while both civil disobedience and civil rebellion are justified by appeal to constitutional defects rebellion is much more destructive therefore the defects justifying rebellion must be much more serious than those justifying disobedience and if one cannot justify civil rebellion then one cannot justify a civil disobedients use of force and violence and refusal to submit to arrest.
5 Civil disobedients refraining from violence is also said to help preserve societys tolerance of civil disobedience.
6 Cristian Bays encyclopedia concludes that civil disobedience does not only include what behavior?	nonviolence	2
7 What dictionary contains a non violent definition?	Blacks Law	2
8 What other terminology is considered much more destructive?	civil rebellion	4
9 People behaving with civil disobedience that is notviolent is said to make society have more of what?	tolerance	5
10 Debates about civil disobedience include or exclude what major practice?	violence	2
11 What type of civil disobedience is commonly accepted?	nonviolent	1
12 When violence is used what is civil disobedience sometimes called?	civil rebellion	4
13 What is one result of civil rebellion?	destructive	4
14 Why is it preferred that civil disobedience is non violent?	help preserve societys tolerance of civil disobedience	5
1 Nonrevolutionary civil disobedience is a simple disobedience of laws on the grounds that they are judged wrong by an individual conscience or as part of an effort to render certain laws ineffective to cause their repeal or to exert pressure to get ones political wishes on some other issue.
2 Revolutionary civil disobedience is more of an active attempt to overthrow a government or to change cultural traditions social customs religious beliefs etcrevolution doesnt have to be political ie.
3 cultural revolution it simply implies sweeping and widespread change to a section of the social fabric.
4 Gandhis acts have been described as revolutionary civil disobedience.
5 It has been claimed that the Hungarians under Ferenc Deák directed revolutionary civil disobedience against the Austrian government.
6 Thoreau also wrote of civil disobedience accomplishing peaceable revolution.
7 Howard Zinn Harvey Wheeler and others have identified the right espoused in The Declaration of Independence to alter or abolish an unjust government to be a principle of civil disobedience.
8 What is it called when there is an active attempt to overthrow a government or belief system?	Revolutionary civil disobedience	2
9 What group of people performed revolutionary civil disobedience toward the Austrian government?	Hungarians	5
10 The Hungarians performed this civil disobedience under the direction of what person?	Ferenc Deák	5
11 Revolutionary civil disobedience towards culture is highlighted by example of who?	Gandhis	4
12 What other topics can Civil disobedience pertain to?	cultural traditions  social customs  religious beliefs	2
13 What is a simple form of civil disobedience?	disobedience of laws	1
14 Why would a person chose civil disobedience against specific laws?	judged wrong by an individual conscience	1
15 What is the goal of individual civil disobedience?	render certain laws ineffective	1
16 What type of civil disobedience is larger scale?	Revolutionary civil disobedience	2
17 What famous Indians actions were considered civil disobedience?	Gandhi	4
1 The earliest recorded incidents of collective civil disobedience took place during the Roman Empirecitation needed.
2 Unarmed Jews gathered in the streets to prevent the installation of pagan images in the Temple in Jerusalem.
3 citation neededoriginal research.
4 In modern times some activists who commit civil disobedience as a group collectively refuse to sign bail until certain demands are met such as favorable bail conditions or the release of all the activists.
5 This is a form of jail solidarity.
6 page needed There have also been many instances of solitary civil disobedience such as that committed by Thoreau but these sometimes go unnoticed.
7 Thoreau at the time of his arrest was not yet a wellknown author and his arrest was not covered in any newspapers in the days weeks and months after it happened.
8 The tax collector who arrested him rose to higher political office and Thoreaus essay was not published until after the end of the Mexican War.

17 What is the civil disobedience called where people refuse to be released?	jail solidarity	5
18 How long did it take for Thoreaus disobedience to be known?	until after the end of the Mexican War	8
1 Civil disobedients have chosen a variety of different illegal acts.
2 Bedau writes There is a whole class of acts undertaken in the name of civil disobedience which even if they were widely practiced would in themselves constitute hardly more than a nuisance eg.
3 trespassing at a nuclearmissile installationSuch acts are often just a harassment and at least to the bystander somewhat inaneThe remoteness of the connection between the disobedient act and the objectionable law lays such acts open to the charge of ineffectiveness and absurdity.
4 Bedau also notes though that the very harmlessness of such entirely symbolic illegal protests toward public policy goals may serve a propaganda purpose.
5 Some civil disobedients such as the proprietors of illegal medical cannabis dispensaries and Voice in the Wilderness which brought medicine to Iraq without the permission of the US Government directly achieve a desired social goal such as the provision of medication to the sick while openly breaking the law.
6 Julia Butterfly Hill lived in Luna a 180foot 55 mtall 600yearold California Redwood tree for 738 days successfully preventing it from being cut down.

15 What type of goals are usually done skirting the law?	social goal	5
16 Who lived in a tree to prevent it from being cut down as a form of civil disobedience?	Julia Butterfly Hill	6
1 In cases where the criminalized behavior is pure speech civil disobedience can consist simply of engaging in the forbidden speech.
2 An example would be WBAIs broadcasting the track Filthy Words from a George Carlin comedy album which eventually led to the 1978 Supreme Court case of FCC v Pacifica Foundation.
3 Threatening government officials is another classic way of expressing defiance toward the government and unwillingness to stand for its policies.
4 For example Joseph Haas was arrested for allegedly sending an email to the Lebanon New Hampshire city councilors stating Wise up or die.

1 Some forms of civil disobedience such as illegal boycotts refusals to pay taxes draft dodging distributed denialofservice attacks and sitins make it more difficult for a system to function.
2 In this way they might be considered coercive.
3 Brownlee notes that although civil disobedients are constrained in their use of coercion by their conscientious aim to engage in moral dialogue nevertheless they may find it necessary to employ limited coercion in order to get their issue onto the table.
4 The Plowshares organization temporarily closed GCSB Waihopai by padlocking the gates and using sickles to deflate one of the large domes covering two satellite dishes.
5 Boycotting refusing to pay taxes sit ins and draft dodging all make what harder?	system to function	1
