11 What side effect of these type of protests is unfortunate?	coercion	3
12 What goal do many of these protests have?	engage in moral dialogue	3
13 How can you protest against big companies in a non violent way?	padlocking the gates	4
1 Many of the same decisions and principles that apply in other criminal investigations and arrests arise also in civil disobedience cases.
2 For example the suspect may need to decide whether or not to grant a consent search of his property and whether or not to talk to police officers.
3 It is generally agreed within the legal community and is often believed within the activist community that a suspects talking to criminal investigators can serve no useful purpose and may be harmful.
4 However some civil disobedients have nonetheless found it hard to resist responding to investigators questions sometimes due to a lack of understanding of the legal ramifications or due to a fear of seeming rude.
5 Also some civil disobedients seek to use the arrest as an opportunity to make an impression on the officers.
6 Thoreau wrote My civil neighbor the taxgatherer is the very man I have to deal withfor it is after all with men and not with parchment that I quarreland he has voluntarily chosen to be an agent of the government.
7 How shall he ever know well that he is and does as an officer of the government or as a man until he is obliged to consider whether he will treat me his neighbor for whom he has respect as a neighbor and welldisposed man or as a maniac and disturber of the peace and see if he can get over this obstruction to his neighborliness without a ruder and more impetuous thought or speech corresponding with his action.
8 What type of government investigations apply to civil disobedience?	criminal investigations	1
9 What is a way you can show police officers civil disobedience ?	not to grant a consent search	2
10 What should be avoided when talking to authorities?	suspects talking to criminal investigators	3
11 What reasons cause failure of the disobedience with authorities?	lack of understanding of the legal ramifications 	4
12 Why do some people purposely resist officers of the law?	use the arrest as an opportunity	5
1 Some civil disobedients feel it is incumbent upon them to accept punishment because of their belief in the validity of the social contract which is held to bind all to obey the laws that a government meeting certain standards of legitimacy has established or else suffer the penalties set out in the law.
2 Other civil disobedients who favor the existence of government still dont believe in the legitimacy of their particular government or dont believe in the legitimacy of a particular law it has enacted.
3 And still other civil disobedients being anarchists dont believe in the legitimacy of any government and therefore see no need to accept punishment for a violation of criminal law that does not infringe the rights of others.
4 What do some civil disobedient people feel the need to acknowledge	accept punishment 	1.
5 Why is the need for acceptance of punishment needed?	validity of the social contract	1
6 What do some people protest against?	legitimacy of a particular law	2
7 What is the group called that does not agree with government at all?	anarchists	3
8 Anarchists do not want to accept punishment for what reason?	does not infringe the rights of others	3
1 An important decision for civil disobedients is whether or not to plead guilty.
2 There is much debate on this point as some believe that it is a civil disobedients duty to submit to the punishment prescribed by law while others believe that defending oneself in court will increase the possibility of changing the unjust law.
3 It has also been argued that either choice is compatible with the spirit of civil disobedience.
4 ACTUPs Civil Disobedience Training handbook states that a civil disobedient who pleads guilty is essentially stating Yes I committed the act of which you accuse me.
5 I dont deny it in fact I am proud of it.
6 I feel I did the right thing by violating this particular law I am guilty as charged but that pleading not guilty sends a message of Guilt implies wrongdoing.
7 I feel I have done no wrong.
8 I may have violated some specific laws but I am guilty of doing no wrong.
9 I therefore plead not guilty.
10 A plea of no contest is sometimes regarded as a compromise between the two.
11 One defendant accused of illegally protesting nuclear power when asked to enter his plea stated I plead for the beauty that surrounds us this is known as a creative plea and will usually be interpreted as a plea of not guilty.
12 What is an important personal decision for civil disobedients?	whether or not to plead guilty	1
13 Which duty do some people believe civil disobedients have?	submit to the punishment prescribed by law	2
14 Why would one plead guilty to a crime involving civil disobedience?	I feel I did the right thing by violating this particular law	6
15 Which reason is given sometimes to plead not guilty involving these matters?	Guilt implies wrongdoing	6
16 What third type of plea uses creative words?	creative plea	11
1 When the Committee for NonViolent Action sponsored a protest in August 1957 at the Camp Mercury nuclear test site near Las Vegas Nevada 13 of the protesters attempted to enter the test site knowing that they faced arrest.
2 At a prearranged announced time one at a time they stepped across the line and were immediately arrested.
3 They were put on a bus and taken to the Nye County seat of Tonopah Nevada and arraigned for trial before the local Justice of the Peace that afternoon.
4 A well known civil rights attorney Francis Heisler had volunteered to defend the arrested persons advising them to plead nolo contendere as an alternative to pleading either guilty or notguilty.
5 The arrested persons were found guilty nevertheless and given suspended sentences conditional on their not reentering the test site grounds.
6 citation needed.
7 Where in Las Vegas did a famous protest take place?	Camp Mercury nuclear test site	1
8 What was the civil disobedience performed at the test site?	tempted to enter the test site	1
9 What was the result of the disobedience protesting the nuclear site?	arrested	2
10 How did their lawyer suggest they would plea?	nolo contendere	4
11 What type of sentences were the protesters given?	suspended sentences	5
1 Howard Zinn writes There may be many times when protesters choose to go to jail as a way of continuing their protest as a way of reminding their countrymen of injustice.
2 But that is different than the notion that they must go to jail as part of a rule connected with civil disobedience.
3 The key point is that the spirit of protest should be maintained all the way whether it is done by remaining in jail or by evading it.
4 To accept jail penitently as an accession to the rules is to switch suddenly to a spirit of subservience to demean the seriousness of the protestIn particular the neoconservative insistence on a guilty plea should be eliminated.
5 Why do some people chose to go to jail for their disobedience?	a way of continuing their protest	1
6 Going to jail accomplished what goal of civil disobedience?	reminding their countrymen of injustice	1
7 What is the most important item for civil disobedience to follow through?	protest should be maintained all the way	3
8 Why should one not go to jail?	accept jail penitently	4
1 Sometimes the prosecution proposes a plea bargain to civil disobedients as in the case of the Camden 28 in which the defendants were offered an opportunity to plead guilty to one misdemeanor count and receive no jail time.
2 In some mass arrest situations the activists decide to use solidarity tactics to secure the same plea bargain for everyone.
3 But some activists have opted to enter a blind plea pleading guilty without any plea agreement in place.
4 Mohandas Gandhi pleaded guilty and told the court I am here to .
5 .
6 .
7 submit cheerfully to the highest penalty that can be inflicted upon me for what in law is a deliberate crime and what appears to me to be the highest duty of a citizen.
8 What type of punishment is sometimes offered to civil disobedients?	plea bargain	1
9 What is usually the goal of taking a plea bargain?	no jail time	1
10 When many people are arrested what is a common tactic negotiating?	solidarity tactics	2
11 What type of plea is sometimes taken as an act of disobedience?	blind plea	3
12 Which famous Indian took a plea and put himself at the mercy of the courts?	Mohandas Gandhi	4
1 Some civil disobedience defendants choose to make a defiant speech or a speech explaining their actions in allocution.
2 In US v BurgosAndujar a defendant who was involved in a movement to stop military exercises by trespassing on US Navy property argued to the court in allocution that the ones who are violating the greater law are the members of the Navy.
3 As a result the judge increased her sentence from 40 to 60 days.
4 This action was upheld because according to the US Court of Appeals for the First Circuit her statement suggested a lack of remorse an attempt to avoid responsibility for her actions and even a likelihood of repeating her illegal actions.
5 Some of the other allocution speeches given by the protesters complained about mistreatment from government officials.
6 What way do some people perform civil disobedience in a constructive way?	defiant speech	1
7 Why would one want to give a speech?	explaining their actions	1
8 Why is giving a defiant speech sometimes more harmful for the individual?	lack of remorse	4
9 Why would one want to give more punishment?	likelihood of repeating	4
10 What type of treatment do civil disobedients usually receive?	mistreatment from government officials	5
1 Steven Barkan writes that if defendants plead not guilty they must decide whether their primary goal will be to win an acquittal and avoid imprisonment or a fine or to use the proceedings as a forum to inform the jury and the public of the political circumstances surrounding the case and their reasons for breaking the law via civil disobedience.
2 A technical defense may enhance the chances for acquittal but make for more boring proceedings and reduced press coverage.
3 During the Vietnam War era the Chicago Eight used a political defense while Benjamin Spock used a technical defense.
4 In countries such as the United States whose laws guarantee the right to a jury trial but do not excuse lawbreaking for political purposes some civil disobedients seek jury nullification.
5 Over the years this has been made more difficult by court decisions such as Sparf v United States which held that the judge need not inform jurors of their nullification prerogative and United States v Dougherty which held that the judge need not allow defendants to openly seek jury nullification.
6 What is the primary goal of pleading not guilty when arrested for Civil Disobedience?	acquittal and avoid imprisonment	1
7 What is a secondary goal of pleading not guilty?	use the proceedings as a forum	1
8 What would someone who is civilly disobedient do in court?	inform the jury and the public of the political circumstances	1
9 What US war has a large amount of Civil Disobedients?	Vietnam War	3
10 What can sympathetic Jurors in cases with civil disobedients?	jury nullification	5
1 One theory is that while disobedience may be helpful any great amount of it would undermine the law by encouraging general disobedience which is neither conscientious nor of social benefit.
2 Therefore conscientious lawbreakers must be punished.
3 Michael Bayles argues that if a person violates a law in order to create a test case as to the constitutionality of a law and then wins his case then that act did not constitute civil disobedience.
4 It has also been argued that breaking the law for selfgratification as in the case of a homosexual or cannabis user who does not direct his act at securing the repeal of amendment of the law is not civil disobedience.
5 Likewise a protestor who attempts to escape punishment by committing the crime covertly and avoiding attribution or by denying having committed the crime or by fleeing the jurisdiction is generally viewed as not being a civil disobedient.
6 What needs to be avoided with civil disobedience?	general disobedience	1
7 Why should disobedience by the general public be avoided?	neither conscientious nor of social benefit	1
8 What is one main reason that civil disobedience is not recognized?	breaking the law for selfgratification	4
9 Why should someone not commit a crime when they are protesting?	not being a civil disobedient	5
10 For what reason would someone avoid crimes while protesting?	avoiding attribution	5
1 Courts have distinguished between two types of civil disobedience Indirect civil disobedience involves violating a law which is not itself the object of protest whereas direct civil disobedience involves protesting the existence of a particular law by breaking that law.
2 During the Vietnam War courts typically refused to excuse the perpetrators of illegal protests from punishment on the basis of their challenging the legality of the Vietnam War the courts ruled it was a political question.
3 The necessity defense has sometimes been used as a shadow defense by civil disobedients to deny guilt without denouncing their politically motivated acts and to present their political beliefs in the courtroom.
4 However court cases such as US v Schoon have greatly curtailed the availability of the political necessity defense.
5 Likewise when Carter Wentworth was charged for his role in the Clamshell Alliances 1977 illegal occupation of the Seabrook Station Nuclear Power Plant the judge instructed the jury to disregard his competing harms defense and he was found guilty.
6 Fully Informed Jury Association activists have sometimes handed out educational leaflets inside courthouses despite admonitions not to according to FIJA many of them have escaped prosecution because prosecutors have reasoned correctly that if they arrest fully informed jury leafleters the leaflets will have to be given to the leafleters own jury as evidence.
7 What is violating a law which is not the goal of the protest called?	Indirect civil disobedience	1
8 When the law is a direct target of the protest what is this called?	direct civil disobedience	1
9 What US war caused a high amount of civil disobedience?	Vietnam War	2
10 What type of defense is sometimes used in court by protestors?	competing harms defense	5
11 Why are people who distribute leaflets inside courthouses not been arrested?	the leaflets will have to be given to the leafleters own jury as evidence	6
1 Along with giving the offender his just deserts achieving crime control via incapacitation and deterrence is a major goal of criminal punishment.
2 Brownlee argues Bringing in deterrence at the level of justification detracts from the law’s engagement in a moral dialogue with the offender as a rational person because it focuses attention on the threat of punishment and not the moral reasons to follow this law.
3 Leonard Hubert Hoffmann writes In deciding whether or not to impose punishment the most important consideration would be whether it would do more harm than good.
4 This means that the objector has no right not to be punished.
5 It is a matter for the state including the judges to decide on utilitarian grounds whether to do so or not.
6 What is the main goal of criminal punishment of civil disobedients?	incapacitation	1
7 What should be the main goal of not using punishment in a just system?	would do more harm than good	3
8 Who decides the fate of protesters most of the time?	the state	5
9 What should the punishment rely on instead in a just society?	moral reasons to follow this law	2
1 Construction is the process of constructing a building or infrastructure.
2 Construction differs from manufacturing in that manufacturing typically involves mass production of similar items without a designated purchaser while construction typically takes place on location for a known client.
3 Construction as an industry comprises six to nine percent of the gross domestic product of developed countries.
4 Construction starts with planningcitation needed design and financing and continues until the project is built and ready for use.
5 What is the process of constructing a building or infrastructure?	Construction	1
6 What typically involves mass production of similar items without a designated purchaser?	manufacturing	2
7 What percentile of gross domestic product is construction comprised of?	six to nine percent	3
8 What three things are needed for construction to take place?	planning citation needed design  and financing	4
9 Construction takes place on location for who?	a known client	2
1 Largescale construction requires collaboration across multiple disciplines.
2 An architect normally manages the job and a construction manager design engineer construction engineer or project manager supervises it.
3 For the successful execution of a project effective planning is essential.
4 Those involved with the design and execution of the infrastructure in question must consider zoning requirements the environmental impact of the job the successful scheduling budgeting constructionsite safety availability and transportation of building materials logistics inconvenience to the public caused by construction delays and bidding etc.
5 The largest construction projects are referred to as megaprojects.
6 Who normally manages a construction job?	An architect	2
7 Who normally supervises a construction job?	a construction manager  design engineer  construction engineer or project manager	2
8 What is essential for the successful execution of a project?	effective planning	3
9 The largest construction projects are known as what?	megaprojects	5
10 Zoning requirements environmental impact budgeting and logistics are things who should consider?	Those involved with the design and execution of the infrastructure	4
1 In general there are three sectors of construction buildings infrastructure and industrial.
2 Building construction is usually further divided into residential and nonresidential commercialinstitutional.
3 Infrastructure is often called heavyhighway heavy civil or heavy engineering.
4 It includes large public works dams bridges highways waterwastewater and utility distribution.
5 Industrial includes refineries process chemical power generation mills and manufacturing plants.
6 There are other ways to break the industry into sectors or markets.
7 What are the three sectors of construction?	buildings  infrastructure and industrial	1
8 Building construction is usually further divided into what categories?	residential and nonresidential	2
9 Infrastructure is often called what?	heavyhighway  heavy civil or heavy engineering	3
10 Large public works dams bridges highways waterwastewater and utility distribution are under what construction sector?	Infrastructure	3
11 Refineries process chemical power generation mills and manufacturing plants are under what sector of construction?	Industrial	5
1 Engineering NewsRecord ENR is a trade magazine for the construction industry.
2 Each year ENR compiles and reports on data about the size of design and construction companies.
3 They publish a list of the largest companies in the United States Top40 and also a list the largest global firms Top250 by amount of work they are doing outside their home country.
4 In 2014 ENR compiled the data in nine market segments.
5 It was divided as transportation petroleum buildings power industrial water manufacturing sewerwaste telecom hazardous waste plus a tenth category for other projects.
6 In their reporting on the Top 400 they used data on transportation sewer hazardous waste and water to rank firms as heavy contractors.
7 What is Engineering NewsRecord?	a trade magazine for the construction industry	1
8 What compiles and reports on data about the size of design and construction companies?	ENR	2
9 In what year did ENR compile data in nine market segments?	2014	4
10 ENR used data on what to rank Top 400 firms as heavy contractors?	transportation  sewer  hazardous waste and water	6
1 The Standard Industrial Classification and the newer North American Industry Classification System have a classification system for companies that perform or otherwise engage in construction.
2 To recognize the differences of companies in this sector it is divided into three subsectors building construction heavy and civil engineering construction and specialty trade contractors.
3 There are also categories for construction service firms eg engineering architecture and construction managers firms engaged in managing construction projects without assuming direct financial responsibility for completion of the construction project.
4 What are the three construction subsectors?	building construction  heavy and civil engineering construction  and specialty trade contractors	2
5 There are other categories for what?	construction service firms eg  engineering  architecture and construction managers	3
6 What has a classification system for construction companies?	The Standard Industrial Classification and the newer North American Industry Classification System	1
7 What are construction managers?	firms engaged in managing construction projects without assuming direct financial responsibility for completion of the construction project	3
1 Building construction is the process of adding structure to real property or construction of buildings.
2 The majority of building construction jobs are small renovations such as addition of a room or renovation of a bathroom.
3 Often the owner of the property acts as laborer paymaster and design team for the entire project.
4 Although building construction projects typically include various common elements such as design financial estimating and legal considerations many projects of varying sizes reach undesirable end results such as structural collapse cost overruns andor litigation.
5 For this reason those with experience in the field make detailed plans and maintain careful oversight during the project to ensure a positive outcome.
6 What is the process of adding structure to real property or construction of buildings?	Building construction	1
7 The majority of building construction jobs are what?	small renovations	2
8 Who acts as laborer paymaster and design team for a renovation project?	the owner of the property	3
9 What are some examples of undesirable end results of a project?	structural collapse  cost overruns  andor litigation	4
10 What do those in the field do to ensure a positive outcome?	make detailed plans and maintain careful oversight	5
1 Residential construction practices technologies and resources must conform to local building authority regulations and codes of practice.
2 Materials readily available in the area generally dictate the construction materials used eg.
3 brick versus stone versus timber.
4 Cost of construction on a per square meter or per square foot basis for houses can vary dramatically based on site conditions local regulations economies of scale custom designed homes are often more expensive to build and the availability of skilled tradespeople.
5 As residential construction as well as all other types of construction can generate a lot of waste careful planning again is needed here.
6 Residential construction practices technologies and resources must conform to what?	local building authority regulations and codes of practice	1
7 What generally dictates the construction materials used?	Materials readily available in the area	2
8 Residential construction can generate what is not carefully planned?	a lot of waste	5
9 Site conditions local regulations economies of scale and the availability of skilled tradespeople all affect what?	Cost of construction	4
1 New techniques of building construction are being researched made possible by advances in 3D printing technology.
2 In a form of additive building construction similar to the additive manufacturing techniques for manufactured parts building printing is making it possible to flexibly construct small commercial buildings and private habitations in around 20 hours with builtin plumbing and electrical facilities in one continuous build using large 3D printers.
3 Working versions of 3Dprinting building technology are already printing 2 metres 6 ft 7 in of building material per hour as of January 2013update with the nextgeneration printers capable of 35 metres 11 ft per hour sufficient to complete a building in a week.
4 Dutch architect Janjaap Ruijssenaarss performative architecture 3Dprinted building is scheduled to be built in 2014.
5 New techniques of building construction are being researched made possible by advances in what?	3D printing technology	1
6 Building printing is making it possible to flexibly construct small commercial buildings and private habitations in what amount of time?	around 20 hours	2
7 Dutch architect Janjaap Ruijssenaarss performative architecture 3Dprinted building is scheduled to be built when?	Working versions of 3Dprinting building technology are already printing	3
8 Working versions of 3Dprinting building technology are already printing how much building material per hour?	2 metres 6 ft 7 in	3
1 In the modern industrialized world construction usually involves the translation of designs into reality.
2 A formal design team may be assembled to plan the physical proceedings and to integrate those proceedings with the other parts.
3 The design usually consists of drawings and specifications usually prepared by a design team including Architect civil engineers mechanical engineers electrical engineers structural engineers fire protection engineers planning consultants architectural consultants and archaeological consultants.
4 The design team is most commonly employed by ie.
5 in contract with the property owner.
6 Under this system once the design is completed by the design team a number of construction companies or construction management companies may then be asked to make a bid for the work either based directly on the design or on the basis of drawings and a bill of quantities provided by a quantity surveyor.
7 Following evaluation of bids the owner typically awards a contract to the most cost efficient bidder.
8 A formal design team may be assembled to do what?	plan the physical proceedings  and to integrate those proceedings with the other parts	2
9 Construction involves the translation of what?	designs into reality	1
10 The design team is most commonly employed by who?	the property owner	5
11 Who provides the bill of quantities?	a quantity surveyor	6
12 The owner typically awards a contract to who?	the most cost efficient bidder	7
1 The modern trend in design is toward integration of previously separated specialties especially among large firms.
2 In the past architects interior designers engineers developers construction managers and general contractors were more likely to be entirely separate companies even in the larger firms.
3 Presently a firm that is nominally an architecture or construction management firm may have experts from all related fields as employees or to have an associated company that provides each necessary skill.
4 Thus each such firm may offer itself as onestop shopping for a construction project from beginning to end.
5 This is designated as a design build contract where the contractor is given a performance specification and must undertake the project from design to construction while adhering to the performance specifications.
6 The modern trend in design is toward integration of what?	previously separated specialties	1
7 Even in large firms architects interior designers engineers developers construction managers and general contractors were more likely to be what?	entirely separate companies	2
8 In modern times firms may offer themselves as what for a construction project?	onestop shopping	4
9 What kind of contract is given when the contractor is given a performance specification and must undertake the project from design to construction while adhering to the performance specifications?	design build contract	5
1 Several project structures can assist the owner in this integration including designbuild partnering and construction management.
2 In general each of these project structures allows the owner to integrate the services of architects interior designers engineers and constructors throughout design and construction.
3 In response many companies are growing beyond traditional offerings of design or construction services alone and are placing more emphasis on establishing relationships with other necessary participants through the designbuild process.
4 What project structures assist the owner in integration?	designbuild  partnering and construction management	1
5 These project structures allow the owner to integrate the services of who throughout the design and construction?	architects  interior designers  engineers and constructors	2
6 Many construction companies are now placing more emphasis on what?	establishing relationships with other necessary participants through the designbuild process	3
1 Construction projects can suffer from preventable financial problems.
2 Underbids happen when builders ask for too little money to complete the project.
3 Cash flow problems exist when the present amount of funding cannot cover the current costs for labour and materials and because they are a matter of having sufficient funds at a specific time can arise even when the overall total is enough.
4 Fraud is a problem in many fields but is notoriously prevalent in the construction field.
5 Financial planning for the project is intended to ensure that a solid plan with adequate safeguards and contingency plans are in place before the project is started and is required to ensure that the plan is properly executed over the life of the project.
6 What can construction projects suffer from?	preventable financial problems	1
7 What is an underbid?	when builders ask for too little money to complete the project	2
8 When do cash flow problems exist?	when the present amount of funding cannot cover the current costs for labour and materials	3
9 What financial issue is notoriously prevalent in the construction field?	Fraud	4
1 Mortgage bankers accountants and cost engineers are likely participants in creating an overall plan for the financial management of the building construction project.
2 The presence of the mortgage banker is highly likely even in relatively small projects since the owners equity in the property is the most obvious source of funding for a building project.
3 Accountants act to study the expected monetary flow over the life of the project and to monitor the payouts throughout the process.
4 Cost engineers and estimators apply expertise to relate the work and materials involved to a proper valuation.
5 Cost overruns with government projects have occurred when the contractor identified change orders or project changes that increased costs which are not subject to competition from other firms as they have already been eliminated from consideration after the initial bid.
6 Who are likely participants in creating an overall plan for the financial management of the building construction project?	Mortgage bankers  accountants  and cost engineers	1
7 The presence of who is highly likely even in small projects?	the mortgage banker	2
8 Who studies the expected monetary flow over the life of the project and to monitor the payouts throughout the process?	Accountants	3
9 Cost overruns with government projects have occurred when the contractor did what?	identified change orders or project changes that increased costs	5
10 Who applies expertise to relate the work and materials involved to a proper valuation?	Cost engineers and estimators	4
1 The project must adhere to zoning and building code requirements.
2 Constructing a project that fails to adhere to codes does not benefit the owner.
3 Some legal requirements come from malum in se considerations or the desire to prevent things that are indisputably bad – bridge collapses or explosions.
4 Other legal requirements come from malum prohibitum considerations or things that are a matter of custom or expectation such as isolating businesses to a business district and residences to a residential district.
5 An attorney may seek changes or exemptions in the law that governs the land where the building will be built either by arguing that a rule is inapplicable the bridge design will not cause a collapse or that the custom is no longer needed acceptance of livework spaces has grown in the community.
6 What must a project adhere to?	zoning and building code requirements	1
7 Constructing a project that fails to adhere to codes does not benefit whom?	the owner	2
8 What is malum in se considerations?	the desire to prevent things that are indisputably bad	3
9 What are malum prohibitum considerations?	things that are a matter of custom or expectation	4
10 Who may seek changes or exemptions in the law that governs the land where the building will be built?	An attorney	5
1 A construction project is a complex net of contracts and other legal obligations each of which all parties must carefully consider.
2 A contract is the exchange of a set of obligations between two or more parties but it is not so simple a matter as trying to get the other side to agree to as much as possible in exchange for as little as possible.
3 The time element in construction means that a delay costs money and in cases of bottlenecks the delay can be extremely expensive.
4 Thus the contracts must be designed to ensure that each side is capable of performing the obligations set out.
5 Contracts that set out clear expectations and clear paths to accomplishing those expectations are far more likely to result in the project flowing smoothly whereas poorly drafted contracts lead to confusion and collapse.
6 What is a complex net of contracts and other legal obligations?	A construction project	1
7 What is the exchange of a set of obligations between two or more parties?	A contract	2
8 What does the time element in construction mean?	that a delay costs money  and in cases of bottlenecks  the delay can be extremely expensive	3
9 Contracts must be designed to ensure what?	that each side is capable of performing the obligations set out	4
10 What leads to confusion and collapse?	poorly drafted contracts	5
1 There is also a growing number of new forms of procurement that involve relationship contracting where the emphasis is on a cooperative relationship between the principal and contractor and other stakeholders within a construction project.
2 New forms include partnering such as PublicPrivate Partnering PPPs aka private finance initiatives PFIs and alliances such as pure or project alliances and impure or strategic alliances.
3 The focus on cooperation is to ameliorate the many problems that arise from the often highly competitive and adversarial practices within the construction industry.
4 A growing number of new forms of procurement involves what?	relationship contracting where the emphasis is on a cooperative relationship	1
5 What is PPP?	PublicPrivate Partnering	2
6 What is a PPP also known as?	private finance initiatives PFIs	2
7 Focus on what is to ameliorate the many problems that arise from the often highly competitive and adversarial practices within the construction industry	cooperation 	3.
1 This is the most common method of construction procurement and is well established and recognized.
2 In this arrangement the architect or engineer acts as the project coordinator.
3 His or her role is to design the works prepare the specifications and produce construction drawings administer the contract tender the works and manage the works from inception to completion.
4 There are direct contractual links between the architects client and the main contractor.
5 Any subcontractor has a direct contractual relationship with the main contractor.
6 The procedure continues until the building is ready to occupy.
7 In the most common construction procurement who acts as the project coordinator?	the architect or engineer	2
8 Whose role is to design the works prepare the specifications and produce construction drawings administer the contract tender the works and manage the works from inception to completion	the project coordinator 	2.
9 There are direct contractual links between who?	the architects client and the main contractor	4
10 Any subcontractor has a direct contractual relationship with who?	the main contractor	4
11 The procedure continues until what?	the building is ready to occupy	6
1 The owner produces a list of requirements for a project giving an overall view of the projects goals.
2 Several DB contractors present different ideas about how to accomplish these goals.
3 The owner selects the ideas he or she likes best and hires the appropriate contractor.
4 Often it is not just one contractor but a consortium of several contractors working together.
5 Once these have been hired they begin building the first phase of the project.
6 As they build phase 1 they design phase 2.
7 This is in contrast to a designbidbuild contract where the project is completely designed by the owner then bid on then completed.
8 Who produces a list of requirements for a project giving an overall view of the projects goals?	The owner	1
9 Who presents different ideas about how to accomplish goals?	DB contractors	2
10 Who selects and hires the best ideas and appropriate contractors?	The owner	3
11 Who is usually working together?	a consortium of several contractors	4
12 What happens as they build phase 1?	they design phase 2	6
1 Before the foundation can be dug contractors are typically required to verify and have existing utility lines marked either by the utilities themselves or through a company specializing in such services.
2 This lessens the likelihood of damage to the existing electrical water sewage phone and cable facilities which could cause outages and potentially hazardous situations.
3 During the construction of a building the municipal building inspector inspects the building periodically to ensure that the construction adheres to the approved plans and the local building code.
4 Once construction is complete and a final inspection has been passed an occupancy permit may be issued.
5 Who is required to verify and have existing utility lines marked?	contractors	1
6 Having existing utility lines marked lessens the likelihood of what?	damage	2
7 What are some existing facilities?	electrical  water  sewage  phone  and cable facilities	2
8 Who inspects the building periodically to ensure that the construction adheres to the approved plans and the local building code?	the municipal building inspector	3
9 What is issued once construction is complete and a final inspection has been passed?	an occupancy permit	4
1 In the United States the industry in 2014 has around 960 billion in annual revenue according to statistics tracked by the Census Bureau of which 680 billion is private split evenly between residential and nonresidential and the remainder is government.
2 As of 2005 there were about 667000 firms employing 1 million contractors 200000 general contractors 38000 heavy and 432000 specialty the average contractor employed fewer than 10 employees.
3 As a whole the industry employed an estimated 58 million as of April 2013 with a 132 unemployment rate.
4 In the United States approximately 828000 women were employed in the construction industry as of 2011.
5 What is the annual construction industry revenue in 2014?	960 billion	1
6 How much revenue is private?	680 billion	1
7 How many firms were existing in 2005?	667 000 firms	2
8 The average contractor hired how many employees?	fewer than 10 employees	2
9 How many women were employed in construction in 2011?	828 000	4
1 In 2010 a salary survey revealed the differences in remuneration between different roles sectors and locations in the construction and built environment industry.
2 The results showed that areas of particularly strong growth in the construction industry such as the Middle East yield higher average salaries than in the UK for example.
3 The average earning for a professional in the construction industry in the Middle East across all sectors job types and levels of experience is £42090 compared to £26719 in the UK.
4 This trend is not necessarily due to the fact that more affluent roles are available however as architects with 14 or more years experience working in the Middle East earn on average £43389 per annum compared to £40000 in the UK.
5 Some construction workers in the USCanada have made more than 100000 annually depending on their trade.
6 What is the average construction salary in the Middle East?	£42 090	3
7 What is the average construction salary in the UK?	£26 719	3
8 Where have some workers made more than 100000?	USCanada	5
1 Construction is one of the most dangerous occupations in the world incurring more occupational fatalities than any other sector in both the United States and in the European Union.
2 In 2009 the fatal occupational injury rate among construction workers in the United States was nearly three times that for all workers.
3 Falls are one of the most common causes of fatal and nonfatal injuries among construction workers.
4 Proper safety equipment such as harnesses and guardrails and procedures such as securing ladders and inspecting scaffolding can curtail the risk of occupational injuries in the construction industry.
5 Other major causes of fatalities in the construction industry include electrocution transportation accidents and trench caveins.
6 What is one of the most dangerous occupations in the world?	Construction	1
7 What is the most common cause of injury on site?	Falls	3
8 What are other major fatality causes?	electrocution  transportation accidents  and trench caveins	5
9 What can curtail the risk of occupational injuries in the construction industry?	Proper safety equipment such as harnesses and guardrails and procedures such as securing ladders and inspecting scaffolding	4
1 Private schools also known as independent schools nongovernmental or nonstate schools are not administered by local state or national governments thus they retain the right to select their students and are funded in whole or in part by charging their students tuition rather than relying on mandatory taxation through public government funding at some private schools students may be able to get a scholarship which makes the cost cheaper depending on a talent the student may have eg.
2 sport scholarship art scholarship academic scholarship financial need or tax credit scholarships that might be available.
3 Along with nongovernmental and nonstate schools what is another name for private schools?	independent	1
4 Along with sport and art what is a type of talent scholarship?	academic	2
5 Rather than taxation what are private schools largely funded by?	tuition	1
6 What right do private schools have that public schools dont?	to select their students	1
1 In the United Kingdom and several other Commonwealth countries including Australia and Canada the use of the term is generally restricted to primary and secondary educational levels it is almost never used of universities and other tertiary institutions.
2 Private education in North America covers the whole gamut of educational activity ranging from preschool to tertiary level institutions.
3 Annual tuition fees at K12 schools range from nothing at so called tuitionfree schools to more than 45000 at several New England preparatory schools.
4 What is the yearly cost of some notable prep schools in New England?	45 000	3
5 What are private schools that charge no tuition called?	tuitionfree	3
6 Along with Canada and the United Kingdom what country generally doesnt refer to universities as private schools?	Australia	1

1 The secondary level includes schools offering years 7 through 12 year twelve is known as lower sixth and year 13 upper sixth.
2 This category includes universitypreparatory schools or prep schools boarding schools and day schools.
3 Tuition at private secondary schools varies from school to school and depends on many factors including the location of the school the willingness of parents to pay peer tuitions and the schools financial endowment.
4 High tuition schools claim is used to pay higher salaries for the best teachers and also used to provide enriched learning environments including a low student to teacher ratio small class sizes and services such as libraries science laboratories and computers.
5 Some private schools are boarding schools and many military academies are privately owned or operated as well.
6 What is another term for year 12 of education?	lower sixth	1
7 What is another term used for year 13?	upper sixth	1
8 What is another term for universitypreparatory schools?	prep schools	2
9 Along with location endowment and the willingness of parents to pay what factor influences private school tuition?	peer tuitions	3
10 Who receives higher salaries at private schools that charge higher tuition?	teachers	4
1 Religiously affiliated and denominational schools form a subcategory of private schools.
2 Some such schools teach religious education together with the usual academic subjects to impress their particular faiths beliefs and traditions in the students who attend.
3 Others use the denomination as more of a general label to describe on what the founders based their belief while still maintaining a fine distinction between academics and religion.
4 They include parochial schools a term which is often used to denote Roman Catholic schools.
5 Other religious groups represented in the K12 private education sector include Protestants Jews Muslims and the Orthodox Christians.

1 The right to create private schools in Germany is in Article 7 Paragraph 4 of the Grundgesetz and cannot be suspended even in a state of emergency.
2 It is also not possible to abolish these rights.
3 This unusual protection of private schools was implemented to protect these schools from a second Gleichschaltung or similar event in the future.
4 Still they are less common than in many other countries.
5 Overall between 1992 and 2008 the percent of pupils in such schools in Germany increased from 61 to 78 including rise from 05 to 61 in the former GDR.
6 Percent of students in private high schools reached 111.
7 What article of the Grundgesetz grants the right to make private schools?	7	1
8 The prospect of what event compelled the protection of German private schools?	second Gleichschaltung	3
9 What percentage of German students attended private schools in 2008?	78	5
10 What was the percentage of Germans attending private high schools in 2008?	111	6
11 In 1992 what percentage of East German students attended private schools?	05	5
1 Ersatzschulen are ordinary primary or secondary schools which are run by private individuals private organizations or religious groups.
2 These schools offer the same types of diplomas as public schools.
3 Ersatzschulen lack the freedom to operate completely outside of government regulation.
4 Teachers at Ersatzschulen must have at least the same education and at least the same wages as teachers at public schools an Ersatzschule must have at least the same academic standards as a public school and Article 7 Paragraph 4 of the Grundgesetz also forbids segregation of pupils according to the means of their parents the socalled Sonderungsverbot.
5 Therefore most Ersatzschulen have very low tuition fees andor offer scholarships compared to most other Western European countries.
6 However it is not possible to finance these schools with such low tuition fees which is why all German Ersatzschulen are additionally financed with public funds.
7 The percentages of public money could reach 100 of the personnel expenditures.
8 Nevertheless Private Schools became insolvent in the past in Germany.
9 What is the German term for segregating students based on their parents wealth?	Sonderungsverbot	4
10 What do Germans call private schools?	Ersatzschulen	1
11 How does the level of tuition in German private schools compare to private schools in other Western European countries?	very low	5
1 Ergänzungsschulen are secondary or postsecondary nontertiary schools which are run by private individuals private organizations or rarely religious groups and offer a type of education which is not available at public schools.
2 Most of these schools are vocational schools.
3 However these vocational schools are not part of the German dual education system.
4 Ergänzungsschulen have the freedom to operate outside of government regulation and are funded in whole by charging their students tuition fees.
5 What are private secondary schools in Germany called?	Ergänzungsschulen	1
6 What types of schools are most ergänzungsschulen?	vocational	2
7 How are ergänzungsschulen funded?	tuition	4
8 Along with private individuals and organizations what groups sometimes runs ergänzungsschulen?	religious	1
1 In India private schools are called independent schools but since some private schools receive financial aid from the government it can be an aided or an unaided school.
2 So in a strict sense a private school is an unaided independent school.
3 For the purpose of this definition only receipt of financial aid is considered not land purchased from the government at a subsidized rate.
4 It is within the power of both the union government and the state governments to govern schools since Education appears in the Concurrent list of legislative subjects in the constitution.
5 The practice has been for the union government to provide the broad policy directions while the states create their own rules and regulations for the administration of the sector.
6 Among other things this has also resulted in 30 different Examination Boards or academic authorities that conduct examinations for school leaving certificates.
7 Prominent Examination Boards that are present in multiple states are the CBSE and the CISCE NENBSE.
8 What is the term for an Indian private school?	independent	1
9 Along with the CISCE and NENBSE what is a notable Examination Board in multiple Indian states?	CBSE	7
10 How many Examination Boards exist in India?	30	6
11 What body in India provides policy directions to schools?	union government	5
1 Legally only nonprofit trusts and societies can run schools in India.
2 They will have to satisfy a number of infrastructure and human resource related criteria to get Recognition a form of license from the government.
3 Critics of this system point out that this leads to corruption by school inspectors who check compliance and to fewer schools in a country that has the largest adult illiterate population in the world.
4 While official data does not capture the real extent of private schooling in the country various studies have reported unpopularity of government schools and an increasing number of private schools.
5 The Annual Status of Education Report ASER which evaluates learning levels in rural India has been reporting poorer academic achievement in government schools than in private schools.
6 A key difference between the government and private schools is that the medium of education in private schools is English while it is the local language in government schools.
7 Along with trusts what other nonprofits are allowed to run schools in India?	societies	1
8 What country has the most illiterate adults in the world?	India	1
9 What is the full name of the ASER?	Annual Status of Education Report	5
10 What is the purpose of the ASER?	evaluates learning levels in rural India	5
11 In private schools what language are classes taught in?	English	6
1 In Ireland private schools Irish scoil phríobháideach are unusual because a certain number of teachers salaries are paid by the State.
2 If the school wishes to employ extra teachers they are paid for with school fees which tend to be relatively low in Ireland compared to the rest of the world.
3 There is however a limited element of state assessment of private schools because of the requirement that the state ensure that children receive a certain minimum education Irish private schools must still work towards the Junior Certificate and the Leaving Certificate for example.
4 Many private schools in Ireland also double as boarding schools.
5 The average fee is around €5000 annually for most schools but some of these schools also provide boarding and the fees may then rise up to €25000 per year.
6 The feepaying schools are usually run by a religious order ie the Society of Jesus or Congregation of Christian Brothers etc.
7 What is the Irish term for private schools?	scoil phríobháideach	1
8 How do private schools in Ireland differ from most?	teachers salaries are paid by the State	1
9 What is the typical annual cost for an Irish private school?	€5 000	5
10 Along with the Congregation of Christian Brothers what is a notable religious group that runs feepaying schools in Ireland?	Society of Jesus	6
11 What might the fees to attend an Irish boarding school rise to?	€25 000 per year	5
1 After Malaysias independence in 1957 the government instructed all schools to surrender their properties and be assimilated into the National School system.
2 This caused an uproar among the Chinese and a compromise was achieved in that the schools would instead become National Type schools.
3 Under such a system the government is only in charge of the school curriculum and teaching personnel while the lands still belonged to the schools.
4 While Chinese primary schools were allowed to retain Chinese as the medium of instruction Chinese secondary schools are required to change into Englishmedium schools.
5 Over 60 schools converted to become National Type schools.
6 In what year did Malaysia receive its independence?	1957	1
7 What language is used in Chinese primary schools in Malaysia?	Chinese	4
8 What language is used in Chinese secondary schools in Malaysia?	English	4
9 What is the name of the postindependence government school system in Malaysia?	National School	1

1 As of April 2014 there are 88 private schools in New Zealand catering for around 28000 students or 37 of the entire student population.
2 Private school numbers have been in decline since the mid1970s as a result of many private schools opting to become stateintegrated schools mostly due of financial difficulties stemming from changes in student numbers andor the economy.
3 Stateintegrated schools keep their private school special character and receives state funds in return for having to operate like a state school eg.
4 they must teach the state curriculum they must employ registered teachers and they cant charge tuition fees they can charge attendance dues for the upkeep on the stillprivate school land and buildings.
5 The largest decline in private school numbers occurred between 1979 and 1984 when the nations thenprivate Catholic school system integrated.
6 As a result private schools in New Zealand are now largely restricted to the largest cities Auckland Hamilton Wellington and Christchurch and niche markets.

8 In April 2014 how many New Zealand students attended private schools?	28 000	1
9 What percentage of New Zealand students attended private schools in April 2014?	37	1
10 What religions schools were integrated into New Zealand public schools between 1979 and 1984?	Catholic	5

1 In the Philippines the private sector has been a major provider of educational services accounting for about 75 of primary enrollment 32 of secondary enrollment and about 80 of tertiary enrollment.
2 Private schools have proven to be efficient in resource utilization.
3 Per unit costs in private schools are generally lower when compared to public schools.
4 This situation is more evident at the tertiary level.
5 Government regulations have given private education more flexibility and autonomy in recent years notably by lifting the moratorium on applications for new courses new schools and conversions by liberalizing tuition fee policy for private schools by replacing values education for third and fourth years with English mathematics and natural science at the option of the school and by issuing the revised Manual of Regulations for Private Schools in August 1992.

3 The Private Education Student Financial Assistance is made available to underprivileged but deserving high school graduates who wish to pursue collegetechnical education in private colleges and universities.

1 In the final years of the apartheid era parents at white government schools were given the option to convert to a semiprivate form called Model C and many of these schools changed their admissions policies to accept children of other races.
2 Following the transition to democracy the legal form of Model C was abolished however the term continues to be used to describe government schools formerly reserved for white children.
3 These schools tend to produce better academic results than government schools formerly reserved for other race groups .
4 Former Model C schools are not private schools as they are statecontrolled.
5 All schools in South Africa including both independent schools and public schools have the right to set compulsory school fees and formerly model C schools tend to set much higher school fees than other public schools.
6 After apartheid what types of schools are referred to as Model C schools?	government schools formerly reserved for white children	2
7 How do academic results in former Model C schools compare to other schools?	better	3
8 How do the fees at former Model C schools compare to those at other schools?	higher	5

1 In many parts of the United States after the 1954 decision in the landmark court case Brown v Board of Education of Topeka that demanded United States schools desegregate with all deliberate speed local families organized a wave of private Christian academies.

3 The academic content of the academies was usually College Preparatory.

1 Established originally by the Massachusetts legislature and soon thereafter named for John Harvard its first benefactor Harvard is the United States oldest institution of higher learning and the Harvard Corporation formally the President and Fellows of Harvard College is its first chartered corporation.
2 Although never formally affiliated with any denomination the early College primarily trained Congregationalist and Unitarian clergy.
3 Its curriculum and student body were gradually secularized during the 18th century and by the 19th century Harvard had emerged as the central cultural establishment among Boston elites.
4 Following the American Civil War President Charles W Eliots long tenure 1869–1909 transformed the college and affiliated professional schools into a modern research university Harvard was a founding member of the Association of American Universities in 1900.
5 James Bryant Conant led the university through the Great Depression and World War II and began to reform the curriculum and liberalize admissions after the war.
6 The undergraduate college became coeducational after its 1977 merger with Radcliffe College.
7 What individual is the school named after?	John Harvard	1
8 When did the undergraduate program become coeducational?	1977	6
9 What was the name of the leader through the Great Depression and World War II?	James Bryant Conant	5
10 What organization did Harvard found in 1900?	Association of American Universities	4
11 What president of the university transformed it into a modern research university?	Charles W Eliot	4
1 Harvard is a large highly residential research university.
2 The nominal cost of attendance is high but the Universitys large endowment allows it to offer generous financial aid packages.
3 It operates several arts cultural and scientific museums alongside the Harvard Library which is the worlds largest academic and private library system comprising 79 individual libraries with over 18 million volumes.
4 Harvards alumni include eight US presidents several foreign heads of state 62 living billionaires 335 Rhodes Scholars and 242 Marshall Scholars.
5 To date some 150 Nobel laureates 18 Fields Medalists and 13 Turing Award winners have been affiliated as students faculty or staff.

8 How many volumes are contained in the library?	18 million volumes	3
9 How many US presidents are alumni of the school?	eight US presidents	4

1 The University is organized into eleven separate academic units—ten faculties and the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study—with campuses throughout the Boston metropolitan area its 209acre 85 ha main campus is centered on Harvard Yard in Cambridge approximately 3 miles 5 km northwest of Boston the business school and athletics facilities including Harvard Stadium are located across the Charles River in the Allston neighborhood of Boston and the medical dental and public health schools are in the Longwood Medical Area.
2 Harvards 376 billion financial endowment is the largest of any academic institution.

1 Harvard was formed in 1636 by vote of the Great and General Court of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.
2 It was initially called New College or the college at New Towne.
3 In 1638 the college became home for North Americas first known printing press carried by the ship John of London.
4 In 1639 the college was renamed Harvard College after deceased clergyman John Harvard who was an alumnus of the University of Cambridge.
5 He had left the school £779 and his library of some 400 books.
6 The charter creating the Harvard Corporation was granted in 1650.
7 In what year was the school formed?	1636	1
8 What organization arranged to founding of school?	Massachusetts Bay Colony	1
9 What year was North Americas first printing press started?	1638	3
10 In what year was the school renamed as Harvard College?	1639	4
11 In what year was the charter granted for Harvard Corporation?	1650	547
1 In the early years the College trained many Puritan ministers.
2 citation needed A 1643 publication said the schools purpose was to advance learning and perpetuate it to posterity dreading to leave an illiterate ministry to the churches when our present ministers shall lie in the dust.
3 It offered a classic curriculum on the English university model—​​many leaders in the colony had attended the University of Cambridge—​​but conformed Puritanism.
4 It was never affiliated with any particular denomination but many of its earliest graduates went on to become clergymen in Congregational and Unitarian churches.
5 Ministers of what faith were trained by the university in early years?	Puritan ministers	1
6 After what higher learning model was the school designed?	English university model	3
7 Was the school officially associated with any denomination?	It was never affiliated with any particular denomination	4
1 Throughout the 18th century Enlightenment ideas of the power of reason and free will became widespread among Congregationalist ministers putting those ministers and their congregations in tension with more traditionalist Calvinist parties.
2 1–4 When the Hollis Professor of Divinity David Tappan died in 1803 and the president of Harvard Joseph Willard died a year later in 1804 a struggle broke out over their replacements.
3 Henry Ware was elected to the chair in 1805 and the liberal Samuel Webber was appointed to the presidency of Harvard two years later which signaled the changing of the tide from the dominance of traditional ideas at Harvard to the dominance of liberal Arminian ideas defined by traditionalists as Unitarian ideas.
4 4–524.
5 In what year did Harvard President Joseph Willard die?	1804	2
6 What liberal succeeded Joseph Willard as president?	Samuel Webber	3
7 In what year was Henry Ware elected to chair?	1805	3
1 In 1846 the natural history lectures of Louis Agassiz were acclaimed both in New York and on the campus at Harvard College.
2 Agassizs approach was distinctly idealist and posited Americans participation in the Divine Nature and the possibility of understanding intellectual existences.
3 Agassizs perspective on science combined observation with intuition and the assumption that a person can grasp the divine plan in all phenomena.
4 When it came to explaining lifeforms Agassiz resorted to matters of shape based on a presumed archetype for his evidence.
5 This dual view of knowledge was in concert with the teachings of Common Sense Realism derived from Scottish philosophers Thomas Reid and Dugald Stewart whose works were part of the Harvard curriculum at the time.
6 The popularity of Agassizs efforts to soar with Plato probably also derived from other writings to which Harvard students were exposed including Platonic treatises by Ralph Cudworth John Norrisand in a Romantic vein Samuel Coleridge.
7 The library records at Harvard reveal that the writings of Plato and his early modern and Romantic followers were almost as regularly read during the 19th century as those of the official philosophy of the more empirical and more deistic Scottish school.
8 in 1846 whos natural history lectures were acclaimed in New York and Harvard?	Louis Agassiz	1
9 Agassizs approach to science combined observation and what?	intuition	3
10 Common Sense Realism of what Scottish philosophers did Agassiz incorporate in his dual view of knowedge?	Thomas Reid and Dugald Stewart	5
1 Charles W Eliot president 1869–1909 eliminated the favored position of Christianity from the curriculum while opening it to student selfdirection.
2 While Eliot was the most crucial figure in the secularization of American higher education he was motivated not by a desire to secularize education but by Transcendentalist Unitarian convictions.
3 Derived from William Ellery Channing and Ralph Waldo Emerson these convictions were focused on the dignity and worth of human nature the right and ability of each person to perceive truth and the indwelling God in each person.
4 What president eliminated the Christian position in the curriculum?	Charles W Eliot	1
5 What conviction motivated Eliot to move towards secularization?	Transcendentalist Unitarian	2
6 From whom were the movement that Eliot followed derived?	William Ellery Channing and Ralph Waldo Emerson	3
1 James Bryant Conant president 1933–1953 reinvigorated creative scholarship to guarantee its preeminence among research institutions.
2 He saw higher education as a vehicle of opportunity for the talented rather than an entitlement for the wealthy so Conant devised programs to identify recruit and support talented youth.
3 In 1943 he asked the faculty make a definitive statement about what general education ought to be at the secondary as well as the college level.
4 The resulting Report published in 1945 was one of the most influential manifestos in the history of American education in the 20th century.
5 Who lead the school back to leading research institution in 2oth century?	James Bryant Conant	1
6 How was the school able to bring aboard the best talented students?	identify  recruit	2
7 In what year of 20th century did Harvard release an important document about education in America?	1945	4
1 Women remained segregated at Radcliffe though more and more took Harvard classes.
2 Nonetheless Harvards undergraduate population remained predominantly male with about four men attending Harvard College for every woman studying at Radcliffe.
3 Following the merger of Harvard and Radcliffe admissions in 1977 the proportion of female undergraduates steadily increased mirroring a trend throughout higher education in the United States.
4 Harvards graduate schools which had accepted females and other groups in greater numbers even before the college also became more diverse in the postWorld War II period.
5 What was the ratio of men to women at HarvardRadcliffe?	about four men attending Harvard College for every woman studying at Radcliffe	2
6 In what year did Harvard and Radcliffe admissions merge?	1977	3
7 What was the trend of female student population from 1970s and deyond?	the proportion of female undergraduates steadily increased  mirroring a trend throughout higher education in the United States	3
1 Harvards 209acre 85 ha main campus is centered on Harvard Yard in Cambridge about 3 miles 5 km westnorthwest of the State House in downtown Boston and extends into the surrounding Harvard Square neighborhood.
2 Harvard Yard itself contains the central administrative offices and main libraries of the university academic buildings including Sever Hall and University Hall Memorial Church and the majority of the freshman dormitories.
3 Sophomore junior and senior undergraduates live in twelve residential Houses nine of which are south of Harvard Yard along or near the Charles River.
4 The other three are located in a residential neighborhood half a mile northwest of the Yard at the Quadrangle commonly referred to as the Quad which formerly housed Radcliffe College students until Radcliffe merged its residential system with Harvard.
5 Each residential house contains rooms for undergraduates House masters and resident tutors as well as a dining hall and library.
6 The facilities were made possible by a gift from Yale University alumnus Edward Harkness.

10 How far from the Yard is the Quad located?	half a mile northwest of the Yard	4

1 Harvard has purchased tracts of land in Allston a walk across the Charles River from Cambridge with the intent of major expansion southward.
2 The university now owns approximately fifty percent more land in Allston than in Cambridge.
3 Proposals to connect the Cambridge campus with the new Allston campus include new and enlarged bridges a shuttle service andor a tram.
4 Plans also call for sinking part of Storrow Drive at Harvards expense for replacement with park land and pedestrian access to the Charles River as well as the construction of bike paths and buildings throughout the Allston campus.
5 The institution asserts that such expansion will benefit not only the school but surrounding community pointing to such features as the enhanced transit infrastructure possible shuttles open to the public and park space which will also be publicly accessible.

2 As of September 2011update it had nearly regained the loss suffered during the 2008 recession.

1 The fouryear fulltime undergraduate program comprises a minority of enrollments at the university and emphasizes instruction with an arts and sciences focus.
2 Between 1978 and 2008 entering students were required to complete a core curriculum of seven classes outside of their concentration.
3 Since 2008 undergraduate students have been required to complete courses in eight General Education categories Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding Culture and Belief Empirical and Mathematical Reasoning Ethical Reasoning Science of Living Systems Science of the Physical Universe Societies of the World and United States in the World.
4 Harvard offers a comprehensive doctoral graduate program and there is a high level of coexistence between graduate and undergraduate degrees.

1 Harvards academic programs operate on a semester calendar beginning in early September and ending in midMay.
2 Undergraduates typically take four halfcourses per term and must maintain a fourcourse rate average to be considered fulltime.
3 In many concentrations students can elect to pursue a basic program or an honorseligible program requiring a senior thesis andor advanced course work.
4 Students graduating in the top 4–5 of the class are awarded degrees summa cum laude students in the next 15 of the class are awarded magna cum laude and the next 30 of the class are awarded cum laude.
5 Harvard has chapters of academic honor societies such as Phi Beta Kappa and various committees and departments also award several hundred named prizes annually.
6 Harvard along with other universities has been accused of grade inflation although there is evidence that the quality of the student body and its motivation have also increased.
7 Harvard College reduced the number of students who receive Latin honors from 90 in 2004 to 60 in 2005.
8 Moreover the honors of John Harvard Scholar and Harvard College Scholar will now be given only to the top 5 percent and the next 5 percent of each class.
