1 The Harvard University Library System is centered in Widener Library in Harvard Yard and comprises nearly 80 individual libraries holding over 18 million volumes.
2 According to the American Library Association this makes it the largest academic library in the United States and one of the largest in the world.
3 Cabot Science Library Lamont Library and Widener Library are three of the most popular libraries for undergraduates to use with easy access and central locations.
4 There are rare books manuscripts and other special collections throughout Harvards libraries Houghton Library the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America and the Harvard University Archives consist principally of rare and unique materials.
5 Americas oldest collection of maps gazetteers and atlases both old and new is stored in Pusey Library and open to the public.
6 The largest collection of EastAsian language material outside of East Asia is held in the HarvardYenching Library.
7 What is the center library in the Harvard library system?	Widener Library	1
8 What are the 3 post popular libraries for undergraduates in the Harvard system?	Cabot Science Library  Lamont Library  and Widener Library	3
9 Where are Americas oldest collection of maps gazettes and atlases housed?	Pusey Library	5
10 How many total volumes are in the Harvard library system?	18 million volumes	1
1 Harvard operates several arts cultural and scientific museums.
2 The Harvard Art Museums comprises three museums.
3 The Arthur M Sackler Museum includes collections of ancient Asian Islamic and later Indian art the BuschReisinger Museum formerly the Germanic Museum covers central and northern European art and the Fogg Museum of Art covers Western art from the Middle Ages to the present emphasizing Italian early Renaissance British preRaphaelite and 19thcentury French art.
4 The Harvard Museum of Natural History includes the Harvard Mineralogical Museum Harvard University Herbaria featuring the Blaschka Glass Flowers exhibit and the Museum of Comparative Zoology.
5 Other museums include the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts designed by Le Corbusier housing the film archive the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology specializing in the cultural history and civilizations of the Western Hemisphere and the Semitic Museum featuring artifacts from excavations in the Middle East.
6 How many museums comprise Harvard Art Museums?	three museums	2
7 What does the Fogg Museum of Art cover?	Western art from the Middle Ages to the present	3
8 What museum specializes in cultural history and civilizations of the Western Hemisphere?	Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology	5
1 Harvard has been highly ranked by many university rankings.
2 In particular it has consistently topped the Academic Ranking of World Universities ARWU since 2003 and the THE World Reputation Rankings since 2011 when the first time such league tables were published.
3 When the QS and Times were published in partnership as the THEQS World University Rankings during 20042009 Harvard had also been regarded the first in every year.
4 The Universitys undergraduate program has been continuously among the top two in the US News  World Report.
5 In 2014 Harvard topped the University Ranking by Academic Performance URAP.
6 It was ranked 8th on the 20132014 PayScale College Salary Report and 14th on the 2013 PayScale College Education Value Rankings.
7 From a poll done by The Princeton Review Harvard is the second most commonly named dream college both for students and parents in 2013 and was the first nominated by parents in 2009.
8 In 2011 the Mines ParisTech  Professional Ranking World Universities ranked Harvard 1st university in the world in terms of number of alumni holding CEO position in Fortune Global 500 companies.
9 Starting in what year has Harvard topped the Academic Rankings of World Universities?	2003	2
10 Beginning in what year was Harvard on top of the World Reputation Rankings?	2011	2
11 According to the Princeton Review where has Harvard ranked as a Dream College in 2013	second most commonly 	7.
1 The Harvard Crimson competes in 42 intercollegiate sports in the NCAA Division I Ivy League.
2 Harvard has an intense athletic rivalry with Yale University culminating in The Game although the Harvard–Yale Regatta predates the football game.
3 This rivalry though is put aside every two years when the Harvard and Yale Track and Field teams come together to compete against a combined Oxford University and Cambridge University team a competition that is the oldest continuous international amateur competition in the world.
4 How many intercollegiate sports does Harvard compete in NCAA division I	42 	1.
5 What is Harvards most intense rival?	Yale University	2
6 At what time is the HarvardYale rivalry set aside?	every two years when the Harvard and Yale Track and Field teams come together to compete against a combined Oxford University and Cambridge University team	3
1 Harvards athletic rivalry with Yale is intense in every sport in which they meet coming to a climax each fall in the annual football meeting which dates back to 1875 and is usually called simply The Game.
2 While Harvards football team is no longer one of the countrys best as it often was a century ago during footballs early days it won the Rose Bowl in 1920 both it and Yale have influenced the way the game is played.
3 In 1903 Harvard Stadium introduced a new era into football with the firstever permanent reinforced concrete stadium of its kind in the country.
4 The stadiums structure actually played a role in the evolution of the college game.
5 Seeking to reduce the alarming number of deaths and serious injuries in the sport Walter Camp former captain of the Yale football team suggested widening the field to open up the game.
6 But the stadium was too narrow to accommodate a wider playing surface.
7 So other steps had to be taken.
8 Camp would instead support revolutionary new rules for the 1906 season.
9 These included legalizing the forward pass perhaps the most significant rule change in the sports history.
10 What was the first year that Yale and Harvard played football?	1875	1
11 In what year did Harvard Stadium become the first ever concrete reinforced stadium in the country?	1903	3
12 In what year was a set of significant rule changes introduced including the forward pass?	1906	8
13 What school was Walter Camp a captain for the football team?	former captain of the Yale football team	5
1 Harvard has several athletic facilities such as the Lavietes Pavilion a multipurpose arena and home to the Harvard basketball teams.
2 The Malkin Athletic Center known as the MAC serves both as the universitys primary recreation facility and as a satellite location for several varsity sports.
3 The fivestory building includes two cardio rooms an Olympicsize swimming pool a smaller pool for aquaerobics and other activities a mezzanine where all types of classes are held an indoor cycling studio three weight rooms and a threecourt gym floor to play basketball.
4 The MAC offers personal trainers and specialty classes.
5 It is home to Harvard volleyball fencing and wrestling.
6 The offices of several of the schools varsity coaches are also in the MAC.
7 What is the name of Harvards basketball facility?	Lavietes Pavilion	1
8 What is the name of Harvards primary recreational sports facility?	Malkin Athletic Center	2
9 How many weight rooms are in the Malkin Athletic Center	three weight rooms 	3.
1 Older than The Game by 23 years the HarvardYale Regatta was the original source of the athletic rivalry between the two schools.
2 It is held annually in June on the Thames River in eastern Connecticut.
3 The Harvard crew is typically considered to be one of the top teams in the country in rowing.
4 Today Harvard fields top teams in several other sports such as the Harvard Crimson mens ice hockey team with a strong rivalry against Cornell squash and even recently won NCAA titles in Mens and Womens Fencing.
5 Harvard also won the Intercollegiate Sailing Association National Championships in 2003.
6 Harvard  Yale Regatta predates The Game by how many years?	23 years	1
7 In what body of water is the Harvard  Yale Regatta held?	Thames River	2
8 Who is the primary rival of the Harvard Crimson hockey team?	strong rivalry against Cornell	4
9 In what year did Harvard win an Intercolleiate Sailing Association National Championship?	2003	5

1 Harvards faculty includes scholars such as biologist E O Wilson cognitive scientist Steven Pinker physicists Lisa Randall and Roy Glauber chemists Elias Corey Dudley R Herschbach and George M Whitesides computer scientists Michael O Rabin and Leslie Valiant Shakespeare scholar Stephen Greenblatt writer Louis Menand critic Helen Vendler historians Henry Louis Gates Jr and Niall Ferguson economists Amartya Sen N Gregory Mankiw Robert Barro Stephen A Marglin Don M Wilson III and Martin Feldstein political philosophers Harvey Mansfield Baroness Shirley Williams and Michael Sandel Fields Medalist mathematician ShingTung Yau political scientists Robert Putnam Joseph Nye and Stanley Hoffmann scholarcomposers Robert Levin and Bernard Rands astrophysicist Alyssa A Goodman and legal scholars Alan Dershowitz and Lawrence Lessig.

1 Jacksonville is the largest city by population in the US state of Florida and the largest city by area in the contiguous United States.
2 It is the county seat of Duval County with which the city government consolidated in 1968.
3 Consolidation gave Jacksonville its great size and placed most of its metropolitan population within the city limits with an estimated population of 853382 in 2014 it is the most populous city proper in Florida and the Southeast and the 12th most populous in the United States.
4 Jacksonville is the principal city in the Jacksonville metropolitan area with a population of 1345596 in 2010.
5 Which Florida city has the biggest population?	Jacksonville	1
6 What was the population Jacksonville city as of 2010?	1 345 596	4
7 Based on population alone what is Jacksonvilles ranking in the United States?	12th	3
8 In which county does Jacksonville reside?	Duval	2
9 What year did consolidation cause Jacksonville to become part of Duval County?	1968	2
1 Jacksonville is in the First Coast region of northeast Florida and is centered on the banks of the St Johns River about 25 miles 40 km south of the Georgia state line and about 340 miles 550 km north of Miami.
2 The Jacksonville Beaches communities are along the adjacent Atlantic coast.
3 The area was originally inhabited by the Timucua people and in 1564 was the site of the French colony of Fort Caroline one of the earliest European settlements in what is now the continental United States.
4 Under British rule settlement grew at the narrow point in the river where cattle crossed known as Wacca Pilatka to the Seminole and the Cow Ford to the British.
5 A platted town was established there in 1822 a year after the United States gained Florida from Spain it was named after Andrew Jackson the first military governor of the Florida Territory and seventh President of the United States.
6 What river runs alongside Jacksonville?	St Johns	1
7 How far is Jacksonville from Miami?	340 miles	1
8 What is the name of the French colony established in 1564?	Fort Caroline	3
9 Prior to the arrival of the French the area now known as Jacksonville was previously inhabited by what people?	the Timucua	3
10 What historical figure was Jacksonville named after?	Andrew Jackson	5
1 Harbor improvements since the late 19th century have made Jacksonville a major military and civilian deepwater port.
2 Its riverine location facilitates two United States Navy bases and the Port of Jacksonville Floridas third largest seaport.
3 The two US Navy bases Blount Island Command and the nearby Naval Submarine Base Kings Bay form the third largest military presence in the United States.
4 Significant factors in the local economy include services such as banking insurance healthcare and logistics.
5 As with much of Florida tourism is also important to the Jacksonville area particularly tourism related to golf.
6 People from Jacksonville may be called Jacksonvillians or Jaxsons also spelled Jaxons.
7 What is the ranking of the military forces in Jacksonville?	third largest	3
8 What sport attracts most tourists to Jacksonville?	golf	5
9 How many naval bases are located in Jacksonville?	two	3
10 What are those from Jacksonville sometimes called?	Jacksonvillians or Jaxsons	6
1 The area of the modern city of Jacksonville has been inhabited for thousands of years.
2 On Black Hammock Island in the national Timucuan Ecological and Historic Preserve a University of North Florida team discovered some of the oldest remnants of pottery in the United States dating to 2500 BC.
3 In the 16th century the beginning of the historical era the region was inhabited by the Mocama a coastal subgroup of the Timucua people.
4 At the time of contact with Europeans all Mocama villages in presentday Jacksonville were part of the powerful chiefdom known as the Saturiwa centered around the mouth of the St Johns River.
5 One early map shows a village called Ossachite at the site of what is now downtown Jacksonville this may be the earliest recorded name for that area.
6 The area where Jacksonville currently sits has been inhabited for how many years?	thousands	1
7 Who discovered pottery found on Black Hammock Island?	a University of North Florida team	2
8 What civilization did the pottery belong to?	Timucua	3
9 What is the 16th century known as the start of?	the historical era	3
10 What is the name of the village that once existed in what is now downtown Jacksonville?	Ossachite	5
1 French Huguenot explorer Jean Ribault charted the St Johns River in 1562 calling it the River of May because he discovered it in May.
2 Ribault erected a stone column near presentday Jacksonville claiming the newly discovered land for France.
3 In 1564 René Goulaine de Laudonnière established the first European settlement Fort Caroline on the St Johns near the main village of the Saturiwa.
4 Philip II of Spain ordered Pedro Menéndez de Avilés to protect the interest of Spain by attacking the French presence at Fort Caroline.
5 On September 20 1565 a Spanish force from the nearby Spanish settlement of St Augustine attacked Fort Caroline and killed nearly all the French soldiers defending it.
6 The Spanish renamed the fort San Mateo and following the ejection of the French St Augustines position as the most important settlement in Florida was solidified.
7 The location of Fort Caroline is subject to debate but a reconstruction of the fort was established on the St Johns River in 1964.
8 Who mapped the St Johns River in 1562?	Jean Ribault	1
9 For what nation did Ribault initially claim what is now Jacksonville?	France	2
10 Who led the attack of the French colony in 1565?	Pedro Menéndez de Avilés	4
11 What was Fort Caroline renamed to after the Spanish attack?	San Mateo	6
12 Which fort was rebuilt in 1964?	Fort Caroline	7
1 Spain ceded Florida to the British in 1763 after the French and Indian War and the British soon constructed the Kings Road connecting St Augustine to Georgia.
2 The road crossed the St Johns River at a narrow point which the Seminole called Wacca Pilatka and the British called the Cow Ford or Cowford these names ostensibly reflect the fact that cattle were brought across the river there.
3 The British introduced the cultivation of sugar cane indigo and fruits as well the export of lumber.
4 As a result the northeastern Florida area prospered economically more than it had under the Spanish.
5 Britain ceded control of the territory back to Spain in 1783 after its defeat in the American Revolutionary War and the settlement at the Cow Ford continued to grow.
6 After Spain ceded the Florida Territory to the United States in 1821 American settlers on the north side of the Cow Ford decided to plan a town laying out the streets and plats.
7 They soon named the town Jacksonville after Andrew Jackson.
8 Led by Isaiah D Hart residents wrote a charter for a town government which was approved by the Florida Legislative Council on February 9 1832.
9 After what event did the Spanish concede Florida to Britain?	French and Indian War	1
10 Soon after gaining Florida what did the English do?	constructed the Kings Road	1
11 Why the narrow part of St Johns River called Cowford?	cattle were brought across the river there	2
12 Who gained control of Florida after the conclusion of the Revolutionary War?	Spain	6
13 When was the Jacksonville town charter approved?	February 9  1832	8
1 During the American Civil War Jacksonville was a key supply point for hogs and cattle being shipped from Florida to aid the Confederate cause.
2 The city was blockaded by Union forces who gained control of the nearby Fort Clinch.
3 Though no battles were fought in Jacksonville proper the city changed hands several times between Union and Confederate forces.
4 The Skirmish of the Brick Church in 1862 just outside Jacksonville proper resulted in the first Confederate victory in Florida.
5 In February 1864 Union forces left Jacksonville and confronted a Confederate Army at the Battle of Olustee resulting in a Confederate victory.
6 Union forces then retreated to Jacksonville and held the city for the remainder of the war.
7 In March 1864 a Confederate cavalry confronted a Union expedition resulting in the Battle of Cedar Creek.
8 Warfare and the long occupation left the city disrupted after the war.
9 Supplies from Jacksonville were in support of which faction in the Civil War?	Confederate	1
10 What was the name of the battle that marked the first Confederate win in Florida?	The Skirmish of the Brick Church	4
11 After what battle did Union forces return to and occupy Jacksonville for the rest of the war?	Battle of Olustee	5
12 What factors negatively impacted Jacksonville following the war?	Warfare and the long occupation	8
13 In what year was the battle that resulted from a Confederate cavalry unit attacking a Union expedition?	Battle of Cedar Creek	7
1 During Reconstruction and the Gilded Age Jacksonville and nearby St Augustine became popular winter resorts for the rich and famous.
2 Visitors arrived by steamboat and later by railroad.
3 President Grover Cleveland attended the SubTropical Exposition in the city on February 22 1888 during his trip to Florida.
4 This highlighted the visibility of the state as a worthy place for tourism.
5 The citys tourism however was dealt major blows in the late 19th century by yellow fever outbreaks.
6 In addition extension of the Florida East Coast Railway further south drew visitors to other areas.
7 From 1893 to 1938 Jacksonville was the site of the Florida Old Confederate Soldiers and Sailors Home with a nearby cemetery.
8 During which period did Jacksonville become a popular destination for the rich?	Gilded Age	1
9 Which US President visited Jacksonville in 1888?	Grover Cleveland	3
10 What caused Jacksonvilles tourism to become less desirable at the latter half of the 19th century?	yellow fever outbreaks	5
11 What drew wouldbe Jacksonville tourists to other Florida destinations?	extension of the Florida East Coast Railway further south	6
12 Other than the steamboat what modern form of travel brought visitors to Florida?	railroad	2
1 On May 3 1901 downtown Jacksonville was ravaged by a fire that started as a kitchen fire.
2 Spanish moss at a nearby mattress factory was quickly engulfed in flames and enabling the fire to spread rapidly.
3 In just eight hours it swept through 146 city blocks destroyed over 2000 buildings left about 10000 homeless and killed 7 residents.
4 The Confederate Monument in Hemming Park was one of the only landmarks to survive the fire.
5 Governor Jennings declare martial law and sent the state militia to maintain order.
6 On May 17 municipal authority resumed in Jacksonville.
7 It is said the glow from the flames could be seen in Savannah Georgia and the smoke plumes seen in Raleigh North Carolina.
8 Known as the Great Fire of 1901 it was one of the worst disasters in Florida history and the largest urban fire in the southeastern United States.
9 Architect Henry John Klutho was a primary figure in the reconstruction of the city.
10 The first multistory structure built by Klutho was the DyalUpchurch Building in 1902.
11 The St James Building built on the previous site of the St James Hotel that burned down was built in 1912 as Kluthos crowning achievement.
12 What caused the spread of the Jacksonville fire in 1901?	Spanish moss	2
13 How many buildings were razed by the Jacksonville fire?	over 2 000	3
14 In the wake of the Jacksonville fire what did the Florida Governor do?	declare martial law	5
15 What was the Jacksonville fire later known as?	Great Fire of 1901	8
1 In the 1910s New York–based filmmakers were attracted to Jacksonvilles warm climate exotic locations excellent rail access and cheap labor.
2 Over the course of the decade more than 30 silent film studios were established earning Jacksonville the title of Winter Film Capital of the World.
3 However the emergence of Hollywood as a major film production center ended the citys film industry.
4 One converted movie studio site Norman Studios remains in Arlington It has been converted to the Jacksonville Silent Film Museum at Norman Studios.
5 Who was drawn to Jacksonville in the 1910s?	New York–based filmmakers	1
6 What type of movies were produced in Jacksonvilles 30 studios?	silent film	2
7 Jacksonvilles popularity for films earned it what title?	Winter Film Capital of the World	2
8 What brought the downfall of Jacksonville filmmaking?	Hollywood	3
1 Jacksonville like most large cities in the United States suffered from negative effects of rapid urban sprawl after World War II.
2 The construction of highways led residents to move to newer housing in the suburbs.
3 After World War II the government of the city of Jacksonville began to increase spending to fund new public building projects in the boom that occurred after the war.
4 Mayor W Haydon Burns Jacksonville Story resulted in the construction of a new city hall civic auditorium public library and other projects that created a dynamic sense of civic pride.
5 However the development of suburbs and a subsequent wave of middle class white flight left Jacksonville with a much poorer population than before.
6 The citys most populous ethnic group nonHispanic white declined from 758 in 1970 to 551 by 2010.
7 What drove residents to quieter suburban housing?	highways	2
8 What was the white population of Jacksonville as of 2010?	551	6
9 What term referred to middle class citizens leaving the suburbs?	white flight	5
10 Who was responsible for the new building projects in Jacksonville?	Mayor W Haydon Burns	4
11 Jacksonville began to suffer and decline after what major world event?	World War II	1
1 Much of the citys tax base dissipated leading to problems with funding education sanitation and traffic control within the city limits.
2 In addition residents in unincorporated suburbs had difficulty obtaining municipal services such as sewage and building code enforcement.
3 In 1958 a study recommended that the city of Jacksonville begin annexing outlying communities in order to create the needed tax base to improve services throughout the county.
4 Voters outside the city limits rejected annexation plans in six referendums between 1960 and 1965.
5 What was the cause for the issues with city funding?	Much of the citys tax base dissipated	1
6 In what part of the city did residents suffer from a lack of city services?	unincorporated suburbs	2
7 What was the proposed solution to Jacksonvilles tax issues?	annexing outlying communities	3
8 Who voted against Jacksonvilles annexation?	Voters outside the city limits	4
1 In the mid1960s corruption scandals began to arise among many of the citys officials who were mainly elected through the traditional old boy network.
2 After a grand jury was convened to investigate 11 officials were indicted and more were forced to resign.
3 Jacksonville Consolidation led by J J Daniel and Claude Yates began to win more support during this period from both inner city blacks who wanted more involvement in government and whites in the suburbs who wanted more services and more control over the central city.
4 In 1964 all 15 of Duval Countys public high schools lost their accreditation.
5 This added momentum to proposals for government reform.
6 Lower taxes increased economic development unification of the community better public spending and effective administration by a more central authority were all cited as reasons for a new consolidated government.
7 How were most city officials elected in the 1960s?	old boy network	1
8 How many city officials were indicted due to corruption?	11	2
9 What political group began to gain support following the corruption scandal?	Jacksonville Consolidation	3
10 What spurred increased support for government reform?	public high schools lost their accreditation	4
1 When a consolidation referendum was held in 1967 voters approved the plan.
2 On October 1 1968 the governments merged to create the Consolidated City of Jacksonville.
3 Fire police health  welfare recreation public works and housing  urban development were all combined under the new government.
4 In honor of the occasion thenMayor Hans Tanzler posed with actress Lee Meredith behind a sign marking the new border of the Bold New City of the South at Florida 13 and Julington Creek.
5 The Better Jacksonville Plan promoted as a blueprint for Jacksonvilles future and approved by Jacksonville voters in 2000 authorized a halfpenny sales tax.
6 This would generate most of the revenue required for the 225 billion package of major projects that included road  infrastructure improvements environmental preservation targeted economic development and new or improved public facilities.
7 What was the result of the 1967 referendum?	voters approved the plan	1
8 Who was Jacksonvilles mayor at the time of the consolidation?	Hans Tanzler	4
9 What was Jacksonville referred to as after the consolidation?	Bold New City of the South	4
10 What was the name of the approved measure that helped cover the cost of major city projects?	Better Jacksonville Plan	5
11 How did the Better Jacksonville Plan generate money?	authorized a halfpenny sales tax	5
1 According to the United States Census Bureau the city has a total area of 8743 square miles 2264 km2 making Jacksonville the largest city in land area in the contiguous United States of this 8666 7577 sq mi or 1962 km2 is land and  1334 1167 sq mi or 302 km2 is water.
2 Jacksonville surrounds the town of Baldwin.
3 Nassau County lies to the north Baker County lies to the west and Clay and St Johns County lie to the south the Atlantic Ocean lies to the east along with the Jacksonville Beaches.
4 The St Johns River divides the city.
5 The Trout River a major tributary of the St Johns River is located entirely within Jacksonville.
6 What is the land area of Jacksonville?	8743 square miles	1
7 What river separates Jacksonville?	The St Johns River	4
8 What is the name of the river that is completely contained inside Jacksonville?	The Trout River	5
9 How much of Jacksonville is made up of water?	1334	1
10 What town is surrounded by Jacksonville?	Baldwin	2
1 The tallest building in Downtown Jacksonvilles skyline is the Bank of America Tower constructed in 1990 as the Barnett Center.
2 It has a height of 617 ft 188 m and includes 42 floors.
3 Other notable structures include the 37story Wells Fargo Center with its distinctive flared base making it the defining building in the Jacksonville skyline originally built in 197274 by the Independent Life and Accident Insurance Company and the 28 floor Riverplace Tower which when completed in 1967 was the tallest precast posttensioned concrete structure in the world.
4 What distinction does the Bank of America Tower hold?	tallest building in Downtown Jacksonville	1
5 The Bank of America Tower was previously known as what?	Barnett Center	1
6 How tall is the Bank of America Tower?	617 ft	2
7 How many floors are there in the building that was completed in 1967?	28	3
8 What makes the Wells Fargo Center stand out?	its distinctive flared base	3
1 Like much of the south Atlantic region of the United States Jacksonville has a humid subtropical climate Köppen Cfa with mild weather during winters and hot and humid weather during summers.
2 Seasonal rainfall is concentrated in the warmest months from May through September while the driest months are from November through April.
3 Due to Jacksonvilles low latitude and coastal location the city sees very little cold weather and winters are typically mild and sunny.
4 Summers can be hot and wet and summer thunderstorms with torrential but brief downpours are common.
5 What type of climate does Jacksonville have?	subtropical	1
6 When does rain typically fall in Jacksonville?	May through September	2
7 How is winter weather in Jacksonville described as?	mild	1
8 Aside from being located on the coast what contributes to Jacksonvilles lack of cold weather?	low latitude	3
1 Mean monthly temperatures range from around 53 F in January to 82 F in July.
2 High temperatures average 64 to 92 °F 18 to 33 °C throughout the year.
3 High heat indices are common for the summer months in the area with indices above 110 °F 433 °C possible.
4 The highest temperature recorded was 104 °F 40 °C on July 11 1879 and July 28 1872.
5 It is common for thunderstorms to erupt during a typical summer afternoon.
6 These are caused by the rapid heating of the land relative to the water combined with extremely high humidity.
7 What is Jacksonvilles hottest recorded temperature?	104 °F	4
8 What is a common occurrence during summer days?	thunderstorms	5
9 What else contributes to Jacksonvilles summer storms other than land heating beside the water?	high humidity	6
10 What is Jacksonvilles hottest month on average?	July	1
1 Jacksonville has suffered less damage from hurricanes than most other east coast cities although the threat does exist for a direct hit by a major hurricane.
2 The city has only received one direct hit from a hurricane since 1871 however Jacksonville has experienced hurricane or nearhurricane conditions more than a dozen times due to storms crossing the state from the Gulf of Mexico to the Atlantic Ocean or passing to the north or south in the Atlantic and brushing past the area.
3 The strongest effect on Jacksonville was from Hurricane Dora in 1964 the only recorded storm to hit the First Coast with sustained hurricaneforce winds.
4 The eye crossed St Augustine with winds that had just barely diminished to 110 mph 180 kmh making it a strong Category 2 on the SaffirSimpson Scale.
5 Jacksonville also suffered damage from 2008s Tropical Storm Fay which crisscrossed the state bringing parts of Jacksonville under darkness for four days.
6 Similarly four years prior to this Jacksonville was inundated by Hurricane Frances and Hurricane Jeanne which made landfall south of the area.
7 These tropical cyclones were the costliest indirect hits to Jacksonville.
8 Hurricane Floyd in 1999 caused damage mainly to Jacksonville Beach.
9 During Floyd the Jacksonville Beach pier was severely damaged and later demolished.
10 The rebuilt pier was later damaged by Fay but not destroyed.
11 Tropical Storm Bonnie would cause minor damage in 2004 spawning a minor tornado in the process.
12 On May 28 2012 Jacksonville was hit by Tropical Storm Beryl packing winds up to 70 miles per hour 113 kmh which made landfall near Jacksonville Beach.
13 What storm had the most significant impact on Jacksonville?	Hurricane Dora	3
14 How fast were the winds around St Augustine in the 1964 hurricane?	110 mph	4
15 What was the name of the storm that hit Jacksonville in May of 2012?	Tropical Storm Beryl	12
16 What is the scale used to measure the strength of hurricanes called?	SaffirSimpson Scale	4
17 In what year did a tropical storm cause a four day loss of power to Jacksonville?	2008	5
1 Jacksonville is the most populous city in Florida and the twelfth most populous city in the United States.
2 As of 2010update there were 821784 people and 366273 households in the city.
3 Jacksonville has the countrys tenthlargest Arab population with a total population of 5751 according to the 2000 United States Census.
4 Jacksonville has Floridas largest Filipino American community with 25033 in the metropolitan area as of the 2010 Census.
5 Much of Jacksonvilles Filipino community served in or has ties to the United States Navy.
6 What ethnic group located in Jacksonville is ranked tenth largest?	Arab	3
7 How many residents were recorded in the 2010 census of Jacksonville?	821 784	2
8 Compared to the rest of Florida how does Jacksonvilles Filipino population rank?	largest	4
9 What Jacksonville community is known for having heavy ties to the Navy?	Filipino	5
1 As of 2010update there were 366273 households out of which 118 were vacant.
2 239 of households had children under the age of 18 living with them 438 were married couples 152 had a female householder with no husband present and 364 were nonfamilies.
3 297 of all households were made up of individuals and 79 had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.
4 The average household size was 255 and the average family size was 321.
5 In the city the population was spread out with 239 under the age of 18 105 from 18 to 24 285 from 25 to 44 262 from 45 to 64 and 109 who were 65 years of age or older.
6 The median age was 355 years.
7 For every 100 females there were 941 males.
8 For every 100 females age 18 and over there were 913 males.
9 What portion of households in Jacksonville have only one person?	297	3
10 How many of Jacksonvilles city residents are younger than 18?	239	5
11 Which gender is more populous across all groups in Jacksonville?	females	7
12 How many men older than 18 are there for every 100 women?	913	8
1 A study by the World Institute for Development Economics Research at United Nations University reports that the richest 1 of adults alone owned 40 of global assets in the year 2000.
2 The three richest people in the world possess more financial assets than the lowest 48 nations combined.
3 The combined wealth of the 10 million dollar millionaires grew to nearly 41 trillion in 2008.
4 A January 2014 report by Oxfam claims that the 85 wealthiest individuals in the world have a combined wealth equal to that of the bottom 50 of the worlds population or about 35 billion people.
5 According to a Los Angeles Times analysis of the report the wealthiest 1 owns 46 of the worlds wealth the 85 richest people a small part of the wealthiest 1 own about 07 of the human populations wealth which is the same as the bottom half of the population.
6 More recently in January 2015 Oxfam reported that the wealthiest 1 percent will own more than half of the global wealth by 2016.
7 An October 2014 study by Credit Suisse also claims that the top 1 now own nearly half of the worlds wealth and that the accelerating disparity could trigger a recession.
8 In October 2015 Credit Suisse published a study which shows global inequality continues to increase and that half of the worlds wealth is now in the hands of those in the top percentile whose assets each exceed 759900.
9 A 2016 report by Oxfam claims that the 62 wealthiest individuals own as much wealth as the poorer half of the global population combined.
10 Oxfams claims have however been questioned on the basis of the methodology used by using net wealth adding up assets and subtracting debts the Oxfam report for instance finds that there are more poor people in the United States and Western Europe than in China due to a greater tendency to take on debts.
11 unreliable source.
12 unreliable source.
13 Anthony Shorrocks the lead author of the Credit Suisse report which is one of the sources of Oxfams data considers the criticism about debt to be a silly argument and a nonissue .
14 .
15 .
16 a diversion.

1 Neoclassical economics views inequalities in the distribution of income as arising from differences in value added by labor capital and land.
2 Within labor income distribution is due to differences in value added by different classifications of workers.
3 In this perspective wages and profits are determined by the marginal value added of each economic actor worker capitalistbusiness owner landlord.
4 Thus in a market economy inequality is a reflection of the productivity gap between highlypaid professions and lowerpaid professions.
5 What philosophy of thought  addresses wealth inequality?	Neoclassical economics	1
6 What is income inequality attributed to?	differences in value added by labor  capital and land	1
7 What impacts distribution of wealth when evaluating labor?	different classifications of workers	2
8 What is the term that describes the difference between what higher paid and lower paid professionals earn?	productivity gap	4
9 How is income determined in a market with variously skilled workers?	marginal value added of each economic actor	3
10 What did Neoclassical economics view the inequality in the distribution of income as being from?	differences in value added by labor  capital and land	1
11 What is distribution of income from labor due to the differences of?	value added by different classifications of workers	2
12 What does the marginal value added by an economic actor determine?	wages and profits	3
13 What are examples of economic actors?	worker  capitalistbusiness owner  landlord	3
14 In a market economy what is inequality a reflection of?	productivity gap between highlypaid professions and lowerpaid professions	4
1 In Marxian analysis capitalist firms increasingly substitute capital equipment for labor inputs workers under competitive pressure to reduce costs and maximize profits.
2 Over the longterm this trend increases the organic composition of capital meaning that less workers are required in proportion to capital inputs increasing unemployment the reserve army of labour.
3 This process exerts a downward pressure on wages.
4 The substitution of capital equipment for labor mechanization and automation raises the productivity of each worker resulting in a situation of relatively stagnant wages for the working class amidst rising levels of property income for the capitalist class.
5 What pushes businesses to increase pressures on workers?	reduce costs and maximize profits	1
6 What impact does workers working harder have on productivity of a business?	less workers are required	2
7 When less workers are required what happens to the job market?	increasing unemployment	2
8 What impact does higher worker productivity and leveled pay have on higher earners?	rising levels of property income	4
9 What do capitalist firms substitute equipment for in a Marxian analysis?	labor inputs	1
10 Why do firms substitute equipment for workers?	reduce costs and maximize profits	1
11 What trend increases the organic composition of capital over the long term?	substitute capital equipment	1
12 What does the substitution of equipment for labor raise for workers?	productivity	4
13 What type of wages does mechanization and automation lead to?	stagnant	4
1 In a purely capitalist mode of production ie.
2 where professional and labor organizations cannot limit the number of workers the workers wages will not be controlled by these organizations or by the employer but rather by the market.
3 Wages work in the same way as prices for any other good.
4 Thus wages can be considered as a function of market price of skill.
5 And therefore inequality is driven by this price.
6 Under the law of supply and demand the price of skill is determined by a race between the demand for the skilled worker and the supply of the skilled worker.
7 On the other hand markets can also concentrate wealth pass environmental costs on to society and abuse workers and consumers.
8 Markets by themselves even when they are stable often lead to high levels of inequality outcomes that are widely viewed as unfair.
9 Employers who offer a below market wage will find that their business is chronically understaffed.
10 Their competitors will take advantage of the situation by offering a higher wage the best of their labor.
11 For a businessman who has the profit motive as the prime interest it is a losing proposition to offer below or above market wages to workers.
12 What is controled by the market and economy?	workers wages	2
13 Under what law is value of a worker determined?	supply and demand	6
14 What happens when business underpays their workers?	business is chronically understaffed	9
15 How do competing businesses attract workers?	offering a higher wage	10
16 How is income inequality generally viewed by workers?	unfair	8
17 What controls wages in a purely capitalist mode of production?	the market	2
18 What do wages work in the same way as for any other good?	prices	3
19 What can be considered as a function of market price of skill?	wages	4
20 What can concentrate wealth pass environmental costs on to society and abuse both workers and consumers?	markets	7
21 What type of outcomes can even stable markets lead to?	unfair	8
1 A job where there are many workers willing to work a large amount of time high supply competing for a job that few require low demand will result in a low wage for that job.
2 This is because competition between workers drives down the wage.
3 An example of this would be jobs such as dishwashing or customer service.
4 Competition amongst workers tends to drive down wages due to the expendable nature of the worker in relation to his or her particular job.
5 A job where there are few able or willing workers low supply but a large need for the positions high demand will result in high wages for that job.
6 This is because competition between employers for employees will drive up the wage.
7 Examples of this would include jobs that require highly developed skills rare abilities or a high level of risk.
8 Competition amongst employers tends to drive up wages due to the nature of the job since there is a relative shortage of workers for the particular position.
9 Professional and labor organizations may limit the supply of workers which results in higher demand and greater incomes for members.
10 Members may also receive higher wages through collective bargaining political influence or corruption.
11 What has the tendency to increase wages in a field or job position?	Competition amongst workers	4
12 When there are many workers competing for a few jobs its considered as what?	low demand	1
13 What is the potential earnings for a job where there are few skilled workers but many available positions?	high wages	5
14 What can lead to higher wages for members of labor organizations?	collective bargaining  political influence  or corruption	10
15 Who works to get workers higher compensation?	Professional and labor organizations	9
16 What does many workers willing to work for a lot of time competing for a job that only requires a few workers result in?	low wage	1
17 What drives down wages in a job with many workers willing to work a lot?	competition between workers	2
18 Why does competition among workers drive down wages?	expendable nature of the worker	4
19 What type of wages result from jobs where there is low supply but high demand?	high	5
20 While competition between workers drives down wages for jobs with a high supply of worker whose competition drives wages up for the inverse?	employers	8
1 On the other hand higher economic inequality tends to increase entrepreneurship rates at the individual level selfemployment.
2 However most of it is often based on necessity rather than opportunity.
3 Necessitybased entrepreneurship is motivated by survival needs such as income for food and shelter push motivations whereas opportunitybased entrepreneurship is driven by achievementoriented motivations pull such as vocation and more likely to involve the pursue of new products services or underserved market needs.
4 The economic impact of the former type of entrepreneurialism tends to be redistributive while the latter is expected to foster technological progress and thus have a more positive impact on economic growth.
5 What increases with the increase of income inequality?	entrepreneurship rates	1
6 Survivial is at the heart of what concept for workers?	Necessitybased entrepreneurship	3
7 What type of motivators are food and shelter considered?	push	3
8 What type of motivators are achievement and self determination considered?	pull	3
9 What type of entrepreneurship leads to advancements in technology?	opportunitybased entrepreneurship	3
10 What increases entrepreneurship rates at the individual level?	higher economic inequality	1
11 What is the increased rates of selfemployment based on?	necessity	2
12 Survival needs such as income for food and shelter motivates what type of entrepreneurship?	Necessitybased	3
13 What motivation is opportunitybased entrepreneurship driven by?	achievementoriented	3
14 What type of impact does opportunitybased entrepreneurship tend to have on economic growth?	positive	4
1 Another cause is the rate at which income is taxed coupled with the progressivity of the tax system.
2 A progressive tax is a tax by which the tax rate increases as the taxable base amount increases.
3 In a progressive tax system the level of the top tax rate will often have a direct impact on the level of inequality within a society either increasing it or decreasing it provided that income does not change as a result of the change in tax regime.
4 Additionally steeper tax progressivity applied to social spending can result in a more equal distribution of income across the board.
5 The difference between the Gini index for an income distribution before taxation and the Gini index after taxation is an indicator for the effects of such taxation.
6 What is it called when the tax rate and base amount increase simultaneously?	progressive tax	2
7 What tax rate has a direct relationship with income inequality?	top tax rate	3
8 What can work to even the distribution of wealth?	social spending	4
9 What system has an impact on income inequality?	tax system	1
10 In a progressive tax what increases as the taxable base amount increases?	the tax rate	2
11 What will have a direct impact of inequality in a system that uses a progressive tax?	level of the top tax rate	3
12 What can result in more equal distribution of income?	steeper tax	4
13 What index is an indicator of the effects of taxes applied to social spending?	the Gini index	5
1 An important factor in the creation of inequality is variation in individuals access to education.
2 Education especially in an area where there is a high demand for workers creates high wages for those with this education however increases in education first increase and then decrease growth as well as income inequality.
3 As a result those who are unable to afford an education or choose not to pursue optional education generally receive much lower wages.
4 The justification for this is that a lack of education leads directly to lower incomes and thus lower aggregate savings and investment.
5 Conversely education raises incomes and promotes growth because it helps to unleash the productive potential of the poor.
6 What is key to getting the skills needed for high demand jobs?	access to education	1
7 What do people with lower income have less access to?	optional education	3
8 What does less education lead to when working?	lower wages	3
9 Who has limited productive potential when faced with less access to education?	poor	5
10 What are those with lower incomes less likely to have in order to prepare for the future?	savings and investment	4
11 What is an important factor contributing to inequality for individuals?	access to education	1
12 What does education in an area where there is high demand for workers tend to create?	high wages	2
13 What type of wages do people unable to afford an education receive?	lower	3
14 What does lack of education lead directly to?	lower incomes	4
15 What helps to unleash the productivity ability of the poor?	education	5
1 In 2014 economists with the Standard  Poors rating agency concluded that the widening disparity between the USs wealthiest citizens and the rest of the nation had slowed its recovery from the 20082009 recession and made it more prone to boomandbust cycles.
2 To partially remedy the wealth gap and the resulting slow growth SP recommended increasing access to education.
3 It estimated that if the average United States worker had completed just one more year of school it would add an additional 105 billion in growth to the countrys economy over five years.
4 What did Standard  Poor recommend to speed economy recovery?	increasing access to education	2
5 How much potential economic growth could the United States amass if everyone went through more schooling?	105 billion	3
6 What is the United States at risk for because of the recession of 2008?	boomandbust cycles	1
7 Who concluded that the rising income inequality gap was not getting better?	Standard  Poor	1
8 When did economists reach a conclusion with the SPs rating agency?	2014	1
9 When the recovery between the widening gap between the richest citizens and rest of the nation slow?	20082009	1
10 What did SP recommend to somewhat remedy the wealth gap?	increasing access to education	2
11 If the average US worker were to complete an additional year of school what amount of growth would be generated over 5 years?	105 billion	3
12 What does wealth disparity make the economy more prone to?	boomandbust cycles	1
1 During the mass high school education movement from 1910–1940 there was an increase in skilled workers which led to a decrease in the price of skilled labor.
2 High school education during the period was designed to equip students with necessary skill sets to be able to perform at work.
3 In fact it differs from the present high school education which is regarded as a steppingstone to acquire college and advanced degrees.
4 This decrease in wages caused a period of compression and decreased inequality between skilled and unskilled workers.
5 Education is very important for the growth of the economy however educational inequality in gender also influence towards the economy.
6 Lagerlof and Galor stated that gender inequality in education can result to low economic growth and continued gender inequality in education thus creating a poverty trap.
7 It is suggested that a large gap in male and female education may indicate backwardness and so may be associated with lower economic growth which can explain why there is economic inequality between countries.
8 When did the high school education movement occur?	1910–1940	1
9 What impact did the high school education movement have on the presence of skilled workers?	increase	1
10 What impact did the high school education movement have on the wages of skilled workers?	decrease	1
11 What impacts gender inequality in wages?	gender inequality in education	6
12 What contributed to the decreased inequality between trained and untrained workers?	period of compression	4
13 When was the mass high school education movement?	from 1910–1940	1
14 What did the increase in skilled workers lead to?	a decrease in the price of skilled labor	1
15 How did the education during the high school education movement differ from the subsequent high school education?	designed to equip students with necessary skill sets to be able to perform at work	2
16 What is very important for the growth of the economy?	Education	5
17 What can result in creating a poverty trap?	gender inequality in education	6
1 John Schmitt and Ben Zipperer 2006 of the CEPR point to economic liberalism and the reduction of business regulation along with the decline of union membership as one of the causes of economic inequality.
2 In an analysis of the effects of intensive AngloAmerican liberal policies in comparison to continental European liberalism where unions have remained strong they concluded The US economic and social model is associated with substantial levels of social exclusion including high levels of income inequality high relative and absolute poverty rates poor and unequal educational outcomes poor health outcomes and high rates of crime and incarceration.
3 At the same time the available evidence provides little support for the view that USstyle labormarket flexibility dramatically improves labormarket outcomes.
4 Despite popular prejudices to the contrary the US economy consistently affords a lower level of economic mobility than all the continental European countries for which data is available.
5 What types of organizations are on a decline in the US which adversely effects economic mobility?	unions	2
6 Which set of countries have higher economic mobility than the United States?	continental European countries	4
7 How much support is there for the US approach to economic development?	little	3
8 Under which policy are labor unions encouraged?	continental European liberalism	2
9 What is economic liberalism one of the causes of?	economic inequality	1
10 What does the US economic and social model have substantial levels of?	social exclusion	2
11 What organization is John Schmitt and Ben Zipperer members of?	CEPR	1
12 How much support does evidence provide for the view that labormarket flexibility improves labormarket outcomes?	little	3
13 What level of economic mobility does the US economy have compared to European countries?	lower	4
1 Sociologist Jake Rosenfield of the University of Washington asserts that the decline of organized labor in the United States has played a more significant role in expanding the income gap than technological changes and globalization which were also experienced by other industrialized nations that didnt experience steep surges in inequality.
2 He points out that nations with high rates of unionization particularly in Scandinavia have very low levels of inequality and concludes the historical pattern is clear the crossnational pattern is clear high inequality goes handinhand with weak labor movements and viceversa.
3 What country has low income inequality and high presence of unions?	Scandinavia	2
4 What do weak labor movement correlate with?	high inequality	2
5 What has had a negative impact on the labor markets in the US?	decline of organized labor	1
6 What has presented problems to the US economy more than other nations?	technological changes and globalization	1
7 What is the profession of Jake Rosenfield?	Sociologist	1
8 What college is Jake Rosenfield associated with?	University of Washington	1
9 What does Rosenfield feel plays the most significant role in expanding the income gap?	decline of organized labor	1
10 What rate of unionization do Scandinavian nations have?	high	2
11 What does high inequality go handinhand with?	weak labor movements	2
1 Trade liberalization may shift economic inequality from a global to a domestic scale.
2 When rich countries trade with poor countries the lowskilled workers in the rich countries may see reduced wages as a result of the competition while lowskilled workers in the poor countries may see increased wages.
3 Trade economist Paul Krugman estimates that trade liberalisation has had a measurable effect on the rising inequality in the United States.
4 He attributes this trend to increased trade with poor countries and the fragmentation of the means of production resulting in low skilled jobs becoming more tradeable.
5 However he concedes that the effect of trade on inequality in America is minor when compared to other causes such as technological innovation a view shared by other experts.
6 Empirical economists Max Roser and Jesus CrespoCuaresma find support in the data that international trade is increasing income inequality.
7 They empirically confirm the predictions of the Stolper–Samuelson theorem regarding the effects of international trade on the distribution of incomes.
8 Lawrence Katz estimates that trade has only accounted for 515 of rising income inequality.
9 Robert Lawrence argues that technological innovation and automation has meant that lowskilled jobs have been replaced by machine labor in wealthier nations and that wealthier countries no longer have significant numbers of lowskilled manufacturing workers that could be affected by competition from poor countries.
10 What effect does trade with poorer countries have on the workers in richer countries?	reduced wages	2
11 What effect does trade with richer countries have on the workers in poorer countries?	increased wages	2
12 What has a bigger impact on the United States economy more than trade?	technological innovation	5
13 What has replaced lower skilled workers in the United States?	machine labor	9
14 What scale does trade liberalization shift economic inequality from?	global	1
15 When rich countries trade with poor countries whose wages increase?	workers in the poor countries	2
16 What does Paul Krugmen think has had an observable effect on inequality in the US?	trade liberalisation	3
17 Compared to other causes the effect of trade on inequality in America is what?	minor	5
18 What has technological innovation and automation replaced lowskilled jobs with?	machine labor	9
1 In many countries there is a Gender pay gap in favor of males in the labor market.
2 Several factors other than discrimination may contribute to this gap.
3 On average women are more likely than men to consider factors other than pay when looking for work and may be less willing to travel or relocate.
4 Thomas Sowell in his book Knowledge and Decisions claims that this difference is due to women not taking jobs due to marriage or pregnancy but income studies show that that does not explain the entire difference.
5 A US Censuss report stated that in US once other factors are accounted for there is still a difference in earnings between women and men.
6 The income gap in other countries ranges from 53 in Botswana to 40 in Bahrain.
7 What is the income inequality gap between genders in Botswana?	53	6
8 What is the gender income inequality in Bahrain?	40	6
