1 Economist Simon Kuznets argued that levels of economic inequality are in large part the result of stages of development.
2 According to Kuznets countries with low levels of development have relatively equal distributions of wealth.
3 As a country develops it acquires more capital which leads to the owners of this capital having more wealth and income and introducing inequality.
4 Eventually through various possible redistribution mechanisms such as social welfare programs more developed countries move back to lower levels of inequality.
5 What types of programs help to redistribute wealth?	social welfare	4
6 What is the level of inequality in underdeveloped countries?	relatively equal	2
7 What introduces inequality to a country?	more capital	3
8 What leads to lower income inequality?	redistribution mechanisms	4
9 What profession does Simon Kuznets have?	Economist	1
10 What did Kuznets argue resulted from stages of development?	levels of economic inequality	1
11 What does a country acquire as it develops?	more capital	3
12 What do the owners of more capital end up having?	more wealth	3
13 What do redistribution mechanisms lead to?	lower levels of inequality	4
1 Plotting the relationship between level of income and inequality Kuznets saw middleincome developing economies level of inequality bulging out to form what is now known as the Kuznets curve.
2 Kuznets demonstrated this relationship using crosssectional data.
3 However more recent testing of this theory with superior panel data has shown it to be very weak.
4 Kuznets curve predicts that income inequality will eventually decrease given time.
5 As an example income inequality did fall in the United States during its High school movement from 1910 to 1940 and thereafter.
6 citation needed However recent data shows that the level of income inequality began to rise after the 1970s.
7 This does not necessarily disprove Kuznets theory.
8 citation needed It may be possible that another Kuznets cycle is occurring specifically the move from the manufacturing sector to the service sector.
9 citation needed This implies that it may be possible for multiple Kuznets cycles to be in effect at any given time.
10 During what time period did income inequality decrease in the United States?	1910 to 1940	5
11 When did income inequality begin to increase in the US?	1970s	6
12 In what sector are jobs beginning to increase?	service	8
13 In what sector are jobs beginning to decrease?	manufacturing	8
14 Who plotted the relationships between levels of income and inequality?	Kuznets	1
15 What is a a developing economys level of inequality bulging out called?	Kuznets curve	1
16 What has recent testing of Kuznets theory with superior data show it to be?	very weak	3
17 What does Kuznets curve predict about income inequality given time?	eventually decrease	4
18 What may be possible for multiple Kuznets cycles to be in at any given time?	effect	9
1 Wealth concentration is a theoreticalaccording to whom.
2 process by which under certain conditions newly created wealth concentrates in the possession of alreadywealthy individuals or entities.
3 According to this theory those who already hold wealth have the means to invest in new sources of creating wealth or to otherwise leverage the accumulation of wealth thus are the beneficiaries of the new wealth.
4 Over time wealth condensation can significantly contribute to the persistence of inequality within society.
5 Thomas Piketty in his book Capital in the TwentyFirst Century argues that the fundamental force for divergence is the usually greater return of capital r than economic growth g and that larger fortunes generate higher returns pp.
6 384 Table 122 US university endowment size vs real annual rate of return.
7 What process attributes new wealth to those that already have it?	Wealth concentration	1
8 According to the wealth concentration theory what advantage do the wealthy have in accumulating new wealth?	means to invest	3
9 What has the highest impact on wealth accumulation and the resulting income inequality?	greater return of capital	5
10 What tends to lead to more money?	larger fortunes	5
11 Where does newly created wealth concentrate?	the possession of alreadywealthy individuals	2
12 Who is best able to leverage the accumulation of wealth?	those who already hold wealth	3
13 What can significantly contribute to the continuing inequality in a society over time?	wealth condensation	4
14 Who wrote the book Capital in the TwentyFirst Century?	Thomas Piketty	5
15 What do larger fortunes generate?	higher returns	5
1 Economist Joseph Stiglitz argues that rather than explaining concentrations of wealth and income market forces should serve as a brake on such concentration which may better be explained by the nonmarket force known as rentseeking.
2 While the market will bid up compensation for rare and desired skills to reward wealth creation greater productivity etc it will also prevent successful entrepreneurs from earning excess profits by fostering competition to cut prices profits and large compensation.
3 A better explainer of growing inequality according to Stiglitz is the use of political power generated by wealth by certain groups to shape government policies financially beneficial to them.
4 This process known to economists as rentseeking brings income not from creation of wealth but from grabbing a larger share of the wealth that would otherwise have been produced without their effort.
5 What forces should serve as a brake on wealth concentration?	market	1
6 What career does Joseph Stiglitz have?	Economist	1
7 What type of skills does the market bid up compensation for?	rare and desired	2
8 What is used by certain wealthy groups to obtain policies financially beneficial for them?	political power generated by wealth	3
9 Income not from the creation of wealth but by grabbing a larger share of it is know to economists by what term?	rentseeking	4
1 Effects of inequality researchers have found include higher rates of health and social problems and lower rates of social goods a lower level of economic utility in society from resources devoted on highend consumption and even a lower level of economic growth when human capital is neglected for highend consumption.
2 For the top 21 industrialised countries counting each person equally life expectancy is lower in more unequal countries r  907.
3 A similar relationship exists among US states r  620.
4 Higher rates of health and social problems are just two of examples of effects from what?	inequality	1
5 Why does a lower level of economic growth occur due to highend consumption?	human capital is neglected	1
6 What is lower in countries with more inequality for the top 21 industrialized countries?	life expectancy	2
7 What is a lower rate of social goods an effect of?	inequality	1
8 In US states what happens to the life expectancy in less economically equal ones?	life expectancy is lower	2
1 2013 Economics Nobel prize winner Robert J Shiller said that rising inequality in the United States and elsewhere is the most important problem.
2 Increasing inequality harms economic growth.
3 High and persistent unemployment in which inequality increases has a negative effect on subsequent longrun economic growth.
4 Unemployment can harm growth not only because it is a waste of resources but also because it generates redistributive pressures and subsequent distortions drives people to poverty constrains liquidity limiting labor mobility and erodes selfesteem promoting social dislocation unrest and conflict.
5 Policies aiming at controlling unemployment and in particular at reducing its inequalityassociated effects support economic growth.
6 What year did Robert J Shiller win an Economics Nobel prize?	2013	1
7 What is the most important problem in the United States and elsewhere?	rising inequality	1
8 Persistent unemployment has what effect on longterm economic growth?	negative	3
9 Whats one factor in eroding selfesteem?	Unemployment	4
10 Policies which reduce the inequality associated effects of unemployment support what type of growth?	economic	5
1 British researchers Richard G Wilkinson and Kate Pickett have found higher rates of health and social problems obesity mental illness homicides teenage births incarceration child conflict drug use and lower rates of social goods life expectancy by country educational performance trust among strangers womens status social mobility even numbers of patents issued in countries and states with higher inequality.
2 Using statistics from 23 developed countries and the 50 states of the US they found socialhealth problems lower in countries like Japan and Finland and states like Utah and New Hampshire with high levels of equality than in countries US and UK and states Mississippi and New York with large differences in household income.
3 What nationality are researchers Richard G Wilkinson and Kate Pickett?	British	1
4 What rates of health and social problems are in countries with high inequality?	higher	1
5 How are the rates of social goods in countries with higher inequality?	lower	1
6 How many developed countries did British researchers use to gather statistics from?	23	2
7 Health problems were lower in places with higher levels of what?	equality	2
1 For most of human history higher material living standards – full stomachs access to clean water and warmth from fuel – led to better health and longer lives.
2 This pattern of higher incomeslonger lives still holds among poorer countries where life expectancy increases rapidly as per capita income increases but in recent decades it has slowed down among middle income countries and plateaued among the richest thirty or so countries in the world.
3 Americans live no longer on average about 77 years in 2004 than Greeks 78 years or New Zealanders 78 though the USA has a higher GDP per capita.
4 Life expectancy in Sweden 80 years and Japan 82 – where income was more equally distributed – was longer.
5 What did higher material living standards lead to for most of human history?	better health and longer lives	1
6 Where does the pattern of higher incomelonger lives still hold true?	poorer countries	2
7 What increases rapidly as per capita income increases?	life expectancy	2
8 Who lives no longer on average than Greeks and New Zealanders?	Americans	3
9 How are incomes distributed in Sweden?	more equally	4
1 In recent years the characteristic that has strongly correlated with health in developed countries is income inequality.
2 Creating an index of Health and Social Problems from nine factors authors Richard Wilkinson and Kate Pickett found health and social problems more common in countries with bigger income inequalities and more common among states in the US with larger income inequalities.
3 Other studies have confirmed this relationship.
4 The UNICEF index of child wellbeing in rich countries studying 40 indicators in 22 countries correlates with greater equality but not per capita income.
5 What characteristic in recent years has been strongly tied with health in developed countries?	income inequality	1
6 Who created an index of health and social problems?	authors Richard Wilkinson and Kate Pickett	2
7 How many factors of health and social problems did Wilkinson and PIckett identify?	nine	2
8 Where are health and social problems most common?	among states in the US with larger income inequalities	2
9 What does child wellbeing in rich countries correlate most to?	greater equality	4
1 Crime rate has also been shown to be correlated with inequality in society.
2 Most studies looking into the relationship have concentrated on homicides – since homicides are almost identically defined across all nations and jurisdictions.
3 There have been over fifty studies showing tendencies for violence to be more common in societies where income differences are larger.
4 Research has been conducted comparing developed countries with undeveloped countries as well as studying areas within countries.
5 Daly et al.
6 2001 found that among US States and Canadian Provinces there is a tenfold difference in homicide rates related to inequality.
7 They estimated that about half of all variation in homicide rates can be accounted for by differences in the amount of inequality in each province or state.
8 Fajnzylber et al.
9 2002 found a similar relationship worldwide.
10 Among comments in academic literature on the relationship between homicides and inequality are.
11 What has crime rate been show to be correlated with in a society?	inequality	1
12 What is almost identical across all nations and jurisdictions?	homicides	2
13 Over how many studies have shown that violence is more common in societies with income differences?	fifty	3
14 What is it estimated that about half of all variation in homicide rates can be accounted for by?	differences in the amount of inequality	7
15 How much of a difference in homicide rates are related to inequality?	tenfold	6
1 Following the utilitarian principle of seeking the greatest good for the greatest number – economic inequality is problematic.
2 A house that provides less utility to a millionaire as a summer home than it would to a homeless family of five is an example of reduced distributive efficiency within society that decreases marginal utility of wealth and thus the sum total of personal utility.
3 An additional dollar spent by a poor person will go to things providing a great deal of utility to that person such as basic necessities like food water and healthcare while an additional dollar spent by a much richer person will very likely go to luxury items providing relatively less utility to that person.
4 Thus the marginal utility of wealth per person the additional dollar decreases as a person becomes richer.
5 From this standpoint for any given amount of wealth in society a society with more equality will have higher aggregate utility.
6 Some studies have found evidence for this theory noting that in societies where inequality is lower populationwide satisfaction and happiness tend to be higher.
7 What does the utilitarian principle seek for the greatest number of people?	the greatest good	1
8 An adobe that provides less utility to one person than another is an example of reduced what?	distributive efficiency	2
9 A dollar spent by a poor person is likely to provide what for them?	a great deal of utility	3
10 What the marginal utility of wealth per income per person do as that person becomes richer?	decreases	4
11 What will a society with more equality have?	higher aggregate utility	5
1 Conservative researchers have argued that income inequality is not significant because consumption rather than income should be the measure of inequality and inequality of consumption is less extreme than inequality of income in the US.
2 Will Wilkinson of the libertarian Cato Institute states that the weight of the evidence shows that the runup in consumption inequality has been considerably less dramatic than the rise in income inequality and consumption is more important than income.
3 According to Johnson Smeeding and Tory consumption inequality was actually lower in 2001 than it was in 1986.
4 The debate is summarized in The Hidden Prosperity of the Poor by journalist Thomas B Edsall.
5 Other studies have not found consumption inequality less dramatic than household income inequality and the CBOs study found consumption data not adequately capturing consumption by highincome households as it does their income though it did agree that household consumption numbers show more equal distribution than household income.
6 What do conservative researchers fell should be a measure of inequality?	consumption	1
7 What political leaning does the Cato Institute have?	libertarian	2
8 When was consumption inequality lower than it had been in 1986?	2001	3
9 Who wrote The Hidden Prosperity of the Poor?	Thomas B Edsall	4
10 What is Thomas B Edsalls profession?	journalist	4
1 Central Banking economist Raghuram Rajan argues that systematic economic inequalities within the United States and around the world have created deep financial fault lines that have made financial crises more likely to happen than in the past – the Financial crisis of 2007–08 being the most recent example.
2 To compensate for stagnating and declining purchasing power political pressure has developed to extend easier credit to the lower and middle income earners – particularly to buy homes – and easier credit in general to keep unemployment rates low.
3 This has given the American economy a tendency to go from bubble to bubble fueled by unsustainable monetary stimulation.
4 What is Raghuram Rajans career?	economist	1
5 What does Rajan feel has created deep financial fault lines?	systematic economic inequalities	1
6 What is the most recent example of financial fault lines?	the Financial crisis of 2007–08	1
7 What does political pressure push to extend to compensate for stagnating purchasing power?	easier credit	2
8 What has given the American economy a tendency to go from bubble to bubble?	easier credit	2
1 According to International Monetary Fund economists inequality in wealth and income is negatively correlated with the duration of economic growth spells not the rate of growth.
2 High levels of inequality prevent not just economic prosperity but also the quality of a countrys institutions and high levels of education.
3 According to IMF staff economists if the income share of the top 20 percent the rich increases then GDP growth actually declines over the medium term suggesting that the benefits do not trickle down.
4 In contrast an increase in the income share of the bottom 20 percent the poor is associated with higher GDP growth.
5 The poor and the middle class matter the most for growth via a number of interrelated economic social and political channels.
6 What is negatively correlated to the duration of economic growth?	inequality in wealth and income	1
7 What do high levels of inequality  prevent beyond economic prosperity?	quality of a countrys institutions	2
8 What happens to the GDP growth of a country if the income share of the top 20 percent increases according to IMF staff economists?	declines	3
9 What does an increase in the income share of the bottom 20 percent of people of a society result in?	higher GDP growth	4
10 Who matters the most for economic growth?	The poor and the middle class	5
1 According to economists David CastellsQuintana and Vicente Royuela increasing inequality harms economic growth.
2 High and persistent unemployment in which inequality increases has a negative effect on subsequent longrun economic growth.
3 Unemployment can harm growth not only because it is a waste of resources but also because it generates redistributive pressures and subsequent distortions drives people to poverty constrains liquidity limiting labor mobility and erodes selfesteem promoting social dislocation unrest and conflict.
4 Policies aiming at controlling unemployment and in particular at reducing its inequalityassociated effects support economic growth.
5 What do David CastllesQuintana and Vicente Royuela do for a living?	economists	1
6 What does increasing inequality harm?	economic growth	1
7 What was persistent unemployment have a negative effect on?	subsequent longrun economic growth	2
8 Why does unemployment harm growth?	because it is a waste of resources	3
9 Policies which try to control unemployment support economic growth because they reduce what?	inequalityassociated effects	4
1 Economist Joseph Stiglitz presented evidence in 2009 that both global inequality and inequality within countries prevent growth by limiting aggregate demand.
2 Economist Branko Milanovic wrote in 2001 that The view that income inequality harms growth – or that improved equality can help sustain growth – has become more widely held in recent years.
3 .
4 The main reason for this shift is the increasing importance of human capital in development.
5 When physical capital mattered most savings and investments were key.
6 Then it was important to have a large contingent of rich people who could save a greater proportion of their income than the poor and invest it in physical capital.
7 But now that human capital is scarcer than machines widespread education has become the secret to growth.
8 What did Stiglitz present in 2009 regarding global inequality?	evidence	1
9 How does inequality prevent growth?	by limiting aggregate demand	1
10 What are both Branko Milanovic and Joseph Stiglitz?	Economist	2
11 What has been the main reason for the shift to the view that income inequality harms growth?	increasing importance of human capital in development	4
12 What has become the secret to economic growth?	widespread education	7
1 In 1993 Galor and Zeira showed that inequality in the presence of credit market imperfections has a long lasting detrimental effect on human capital formation and economic development.
2 A 1996 study by Perotti examined the channels through which inequality may affect economic growth.
3 He showed that in accordance with the credit market imperfection approach inequality is associated with lower level of human capital formation education experience and apprenticeship and higher level of fertility and thereby lower levels of growth.
4 He found that inequality is associated with higher levels of redistributive taxation which is associated with lower levels of growth from reductions in private savings and investment.
5 Perotti concluded that more equal societies have lower fertility rates and higher rates of investment in education.
6 Both are reflected in higher rates of growth.
7 Also very unequal societies tend to be politically and socially unstable which is reflected in lower rates of investment and therefore growth.
8 When did Galor and Zeria show new information about inequality?	1993	1
9 Inequality in the presence of credit market imperfections has what kind of effect on human capital formation?	detrimental	1
10 What did a 1996 study by Perotti examine?	channels through which inequality may affect economic growth	2
11 What is inequality associated with higher levels of?	redistributive taxation	4
12 What do extremely unequal societies tend to be?	politically and socially unstable	7
1 Research by Harvard economist Robert Barro found that there is little overall relation between income inequality and rates of growth and investment.
2 According to work by Barro in 1999 and 2000 high levels of inequality reduce growth in relatively poor countries but encourage growth in richer countries.
3 A study of Swedish counties between 1960 and 2000 found a positive impact of inequality on growth with lead times of five years or less but no correlation after ten years.
4 Studies of larger data sets have found no correlations for any fixed lead time and a negative impact on the duration of growth.
5 What does high levels of inequality do to growth in poor countries?	reduce	2
6 What does high levels of inequality do for economic growth in richer countries?	encourage	2
7 Barro found there is little relation between income inequality and rates of what?	growth and investment	1
8 What institution does Robert Barro hail from?	Harvard	1
9 When was a study conducted of Swedish counties?	between 1960 and 2000	3
1 Studies on income inequality and growth have sometimes found evidence confirming the Kuznets curve hypothesis which states that with economic development inequality first increases then decreases.
2 Economist Thomas Piketty challenges this notion claiming that from 1914 to 1945 wars and violent economic and political shocks reduced inequality.
3 Moreover Piketty argues that the magical Kuznets curve hypothesis with its emphasis on the balancing of economic growth in the long run cannot account for the significant increase in economic inequality throughout the developed world since the 1970s.
4 What have studies on income inequality sometimes found evidence confirming?	Kuznets curve hypothesis	1
5 The Kuznets curve says with economic development inequality will decrease after what?	first increases	1
6 Who challenges the notion of the Kuznets curve hypothesis?	Thomas Piketty	2
7 Whats Thomas Pikettys job?	Economist	2
8 What does Piketty feel was the biggest factors in reducing inequality between 1914 to 1945?	wars and violent economic and political shocks	2
1 Some theories developed in the 1970s established possible avenues through which inequality may have a positive effect on economic development.
2 According to a 1955 review savings by the wealthy if these increase with inequality were thought to offset reduced consumer demand.
3 A 2013 report on Nigeria suggests that growth has risen with increased income inequality.
4 Some theories popular from the 1950s to 2011 incorrectly stated that inequality had a positive effect on economic development.
5 Analyses based on comparing yearly equality figures to yearly growth rates were misleading because it takes several years for effects to manifest as changes to economic growth.
6 IMF economists found a strong association between lower levels of inequality in developing countries and sustained periods of economic growth.
7 Developing countries with high inequality have succeeded in initiating growth at high rates for a few years but longer growth spells are robustly associated with more equality in the income distribution.
8 When were theories developed suggesting inequality may have some positive effect on economic development?	the 1970s	1
9 According to a 1955 review what were savings by the wealthy thought to offset?	reduced consumer demand	2
10 What does a 2013 report on Nigeria suggest its growth has done?	risen with increased income inequality	3
11 How long does it take for the effects to manifest as changes to economic growth?	several years	5
12 What are longer growth spells associated with?	more equality in the income distribution	7
1 While acknowledging the central role economic growth can potentially play in human development poverty reduction and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals it is becoming widely understood amongst the development community that special efforts must be made to ensure poorer sections of society are able to participate in economic growth.
2 The effect of economic growth on poverty reduction – the growth elasticity of poverty – can depend on the existing level of inequality.
3 For instance with low inequality a country with a growth rate of 2 per head and 40 of its population living in poverty can halve poverty in ten years but a country with high inequality would take nearly 60 years to achieve the same reduction.
4 In the words of the Secretary General of the United Nations Ban KiMoon While economic growth is necessary it is not sufficient for progress on reducing poverty.
5 What needs to be made to ensure poorer members of society can participate in economic growth?	special efforts	1
6 What can the growth elasticity of poverty depend on?	existing level of inequality	2
7 What does it take a country with high inequality longer to achieve?	reduction	3
8 What was Ban KiMoon the Secretary General of?	the United Nations	4
9 What isnt economic growth sufficient for progress on?	reducing poverty	4
1 In many poor and developing countries much land and housing is held outside the formal or legal property ownership registration system.
2 Much unregistered property is held in informal form through various associations and other arrangements.
3 Reasons for extralegal ownership include excessive bureaucratic red tape in buying property and building In some countries it can take over 200 steps and up to 14 years to build on government land.
4 Other causes of extralegal property are failures to notarize transaction documents or having documents notarized but failing to have them recorded with the official agency.
5 What is held outside the formal legal ownership registration system in many developing countries?	much land and housing	1
6 How is unregistered property held in informal form?	through various associations and other arrangements	2
7 Excessive bureaucratic red tape is one of the reasons for what type of ownership?	extralegal	3
8 In some countries over how many steps can it take to build on government land?	200	3
9 What can it sometimes take up to 14 years to get permission to build on?	government land	3
1 A number of researchers David Rodda Jacob Vigdor and Janna Matlack argue that a shortage of affordable housing – at least in the US – is caused in part by income inequality.
2 David Rodda noted that from 1984 and 1991 the number of quality rental units decreased as the demand for higher quality housing increased Rhoda 1994148.
3 Through gentrification of older neighbourhoods for example in East New York rental prices increased rapidly as landlords found new residents willing to pay higher market rate for housing and left lower income families without rental units.
4 The ad valorem property tax policy combined with rising prices made it difficult or impossible for low income residents to keep pace.
5 What do a number of researchers think a shortage of is caused in part by income inequality?	a shortage of affordable housing	1
6 What decreased in number between 1984 and 1991?	quality rental units	2
7 Why did the demand for rentals decrease?	demand for higher quality housing increased	2
8 What drove increased rental prices in East New York?	residents willing to pay higher market rate for housing	3
9 What combined with ricing prices to make it difficult or impossible for poor people to keep pace?	ad valorem property tax policy	4
1 Firstly certain costs are difficult to avoid and are shared by everyone such as the costs of housing pensions education and health care.
2 If the state does not provide these services then for those on lower incomes the costs must be borrowed and often those on lower incomes are those who are worse equipped to manage their finances.
3 Secondly aspirational consumption describes the process of middle income earners aspiring to achieve the standards of living enjoyed by their wealthier counterparts and one method of achieving this aspiration is by taking on debt.
4 The result leads to even greater inequality and potential economic instability.
5 How are the certain costs which are difficult to avoid shared?	by everyone	1
6 What are those with lower incomes often unable to manage?	their finances	2
7 What is the term when middle income earners aspire to obtain the same standards of living as people wealthier than themselves?	aspirational consumption	3
8 What is one method of achieving aspirational consumption?	taking on debt	3
9 When people take on debt it leads potentially to what?	economic instability	4
1 The smaller the economic inequality the more waste and pollution is created resulting in many cases in more environmental degradation.
2 This can be explained by the fact that as the poor people in the society become more wealthy it increases their yearly carbon emissions.
3 This relation is expressed by the Environmental Kuznets Curve EKC.
4 not in citation given It should be noted here however that in certain cases with great economic inequality there is nonetheless not more waste and pollution created as the wastepollution is cleaned up better afterwards water treatment filtering  Also note that the whole of the increase in environmental degradation is the result of the increase of emissions per person being multiplied by a multiplier.
5 If there were fewer people however this multiplier would be lower and thus the amount of environmental degradation would be lower as well.
6 As such the current high level of population has a large impact on this as well.
7 If as WWF argued population levels would start to drop to a sustainable level 13 of current levels so about 2 billion people human inequality can be addressedcorrected while still not resulting in an increase of environmental damage.
8 When economic inequality is smaller more waste and pollution is?	created	1
9 What would be lower if there were fewer people?	emissions per person	4
10 What does the current high level of population have a large impact on?	environmental degradation	4
11 How could human inequality be addressed without resulting in an increase of environmental damage?	If as WWF argued  population levels would start to drop to a sustainable level	7
1 Socialists attribute the vast disparities in wealth to the private ownership of the means of production by a class of owners creating a situation where a small portion of the population lives off unearned property income by virtue of ownership titles in capital equipment financial assets and corporate stock.
2 By contrast the vast majority of the population is dependent on income in the form of a wage or salary.
3 In order to rectify this situation socialists argue that the means of production should be socially owned so that income differentials would be reflective of individual contributions to the social product.
4 What is the vast disparities in wealth attributed to by Socialists?	private ownership of the means of production	1
5 What does private ownership create a situation of?	a small portion of the population lives off unearned property income	1
6 What type of income is the vast majority of the population dependent on?	wage or salary	2
7 How do socialists think the means of production should be owned?	socially	3
8 What would income differentials be if individual contributions were relevant to the social product?	reflective	3
1 Robert Nozick argued that government redistributes wealth by force usually in the form of taxation and that the ideal moral society would be one where all individuals are free from force.
2 However Nozick recognized that some modern economic inequalities were the result of forceful taking of property and a certain amount of redistribution would be justified to compensate for this force but not because of the inequalities themselves.
3 John Rawls argued in A Theory of Justice that inequalities in the distribution of wealth are only justified when they improve society as a whole including the poorest members.
4 Rawls does not discuss the full implications of his theory of justice.
5 Some see Rawlss argument as a justification for capitalism since even the poorest members of society theoretically benefit from increased innovations under capitalism others believe only a strong welfare state can satisfy Rawlss theory of justice.
6 Who argues that the government redistributes wealth by force?	Robert Nozick	1
7 What is the usual form of the governments wealth redistribution?	taxation	1
8 In an ideal moral society what would all citizens be free from?	force	1
9 How were some modern economic inequalities created?	forceful taking of property	2
10 When are inequalities in wealth justified according to John Rawls?	when they improve society as a whole	3
1 The capabilities approach – sometimes called the human development approach – looks at income inequality and poverty as form of “capability deprivation”.
2 Unlike neoliberalism which “defines wellbeing as utility maximization” economic growth and income are considered a means to an end rather than the end itself.
3 Its goal is to “widen people’s choices and the level of their achieved wellbeing” through increasing functionings the things a person values doing capabilities the freedom to enjoy functionings and agency the ability to pursue valued goals.
4 What does the capabilities approach look at poverty as a form of?	capability deprivation	1
5 In the capabilities approach grow and income are considered a means to an end rather than what?	the end itself	2
6 What is the goal of the capabilities approach?	to “widen people’s choices and the level of their achieved wellbeing”	3
7 How would the capabilities approach achieve its goal?	through increasing functionings	3
8 What is the definition of agency as it relates to capabilities?	the ability to pursue valued goals	3
1 When a person’s capabilities are lowered they are in some way deprived of earning as much income as they would otherwise.
2 An old ill man cannot earn as much as a healthy young man gender roles and customs may prevent a woman from receiving an education or working outside the home.
3 There may be an epidemic that causes widespread panic or there could be rampant violence in the area that prevents people from going to work for fear of their lives.
4 As a result income and economic inequality increases and it becomes more difficult to reduce the gap without additional aid.
5 To prevent such inequality this approach believes it’s important to have political freedom economic facilities social opportunities transparency guarantees and protective security to ensure that people aren’t denied their functionings capabilities and agency and can thus work towards a better relevant income.
6 What happens when a persons capabilities aer lowered as it relates to their income?	deprived of earning as much	1
7 What can and old ill man not do?	earn as much as a healthy young man	2
8 What issues may prevent women from working outside the home or receiving education?	gender roles and customs	2
9 Why would rampant violence prevent people from going to work?	for fear of their lives	3
10 What can people work towards if they arent denied their functionings capabilities and agency?	a better relevant income	5
1 Doctor Who is a British sciencefiction television programme produced by the BBC since 1963.
2 The programme depicts the adventures of the Doctor a Time Lord—a space and timetravelling humanoid alien.
3 He explores the universe in his TARDIS a sentient timetravelling space ship.
4 Its exterior appears as a blue British police box which was a common sight in Britain in 1963 when the series first aired.
5 Accompanied by companions the Doctor combats a variety of foes while working to save civilisations and help people in need.
6 Who is the producer of Doctor Who?	BBC	1
7 What year did Doctor Who first show on TV?	1963	1
8 What is Doctor Whos space ship called?	TARDIS	3
9 What does the outside of the Tardis resemble?	a blue British police box	4
10 What typegenre of TV show is Doctor Who?	sciencefiction	1
1 The show is a significant part of British popular culture and elsewhere it has become a cult television favourite.
2 The show has influenced generations of British television professionals many of whom grew up watching the series.
3 The programme originally ran from 1963 to 1989.
4 There was an unsuccessful attempt to revive regular production in 1996 with a backdoor pilot in the form of a television film.
5 The programme was relaunched in 2005 by Russell T Davies who was showrunner and head writer for the first five years of its revival produced inhouse by BBC Wales in Cardiff.
6 The first series of the 21st century featured Christopher Eccleston in the title role and was produced by the BBC.
7 Doctor Who also spawned spinoffs in multiple media including Torchwood 2006–2011 and The Sarah Jane Adventures 2007–2011 both created by Russell T Davies K9 2009–2010 and a single pilot episode of K9 and Company 1981.
8 There also have been many spoofs and cultural references to the character in other media.
9 In what years did Doctor Who originally show on TV?	1963 to 1989	3
10 Who relaunched Doctor Who in 2005?	Russell T Davies	5
11 What Doctor Who spinoff only made it as far as a pilot episode?	K9 and Company	7
12 Who produced the Doctor Who revival series?	BBC Wales	5
13 Who played Doctor Who in the revival series?	Christopher Eccleston	6
1 Twelve actors have headlined the series as the Doctor.
2 The transition from one actor to another is written into the plot of the show as well as the differing approach to the role that each brings under the concept of regeneration into a new incarnation.
3 The shows premise is that this is a life process of Time Lords through which the character of the Doctor takes on a new body and to some extent new personality which occurs after sustaining an injury which would be fatal to most other species.
4 Each actors portrayal differs but they are all intended to be aspects of the same character and form part of the same storyline.
5 The timetravelling nature of the plot means that on occasion different Doctors have met each other.
6 Peter Capaldi took on the role after Matt Smiths exit in the 2013 Christmas special The Time of the Doctor.
7 How many actors have played Doctor Who?	Twelve	1
8 Who followed Matt Smith in the role of Doctor Who?	Peter Capaldi	6
9 Which episode was Matt Smiths final one as Doctor Who?	The Time of the Doctor	6
10 When does Doctor Who transition to a new body?	after sustaining an injury	3
11 In addition to a new body what else changes about the Doctor?	new personality	3
1 Doctor Who follows the adventures of the primary character a rogue Time Lord from the planet Gallifrey who simply goes by the name The Doctor.
2 He fled from Gallifrey in a stolen Mark I Type 40 TARDIS – Time and Relative Dimension in Space – time machine which allows him to travel across time and space.
3 The TARDIS has a chameleon circuit which normally allows the machine to take on the appearance of local objects as a disguise.
4 However the Doctors TARDIS remains fixed as a blue British Police box due to a malfunction in the chameleon circuit.
5 What planet is Doctor Who from?	Gallifrey	1
6 What vehicle did Doctor Who use for his escape from Gallifrey?	Mark I Type 40 TARDIS	2
7 That does TARDIS stand for?	Time and Relative Dimension in Space	2
8 What feature normally allows the TARDIS to disguise itself?	chameleon circuit	3
9 Why does Doctor Whos TARDIS always look the same?	due to a malfunction in the chameleon circuit	4
1 The Doctor rarely travels alone and often brings one or more companions to share these adventures.
2 His companions are usually humans as he has found a fascination with planet Earth.
3 He often finds events that pique his curiosity as he tries to prevent evil forces from harming innocent people or changing history using only his ingenuity and minimal resources such as his versatile sonic screwdriver.
4 As a Time Lord the Doctor has the ability to regenerate when his body is mortally damaged taking on a new appearance and personality.
5 The Doctor has gained numerous reoccurring enemies during his travels including the Daleks the Cybermen and the Master another renegade Time Lord.
6 How often does Doctor Who travel by himself?	rarely	1
7 What enemy of Doctor Who is also a Time Lord?	the Master	5
8 What does Doctor Who do when his body is mortally damaged?	regenerate	4
9 What type of beings does Doctor Who usually take with him on his travels?	humans	2
10 What type of Lord is Doctor Who?	Time Lord	4
1 Doctor Who first appeared on BBC TV at 171620 GMT eighty seconds after the scheduled programme time 515 pm on Saturday 23 November 1963.
2 It was to be a regular weekly programme each episode 25 minutes of transmission length.
3 Discussions and plans for the programme had been in progress for a year.
4 The head of drama Canadian Sydney Newman was mainly responsible for developing the programme with the first format document for the series being written by Newman along with the head of the script department later head of serials Donald Wilson and staff writer C E Webber.
5 Writer Anthony Coburn story editor David Whitaker and initial producer Verity Lambert also heavily contributed to the development of the series.
6 note 1 The programme was originally intended to appeal to a family audience as an educational programme using time travel as a means to explore scientific ideas and famous moments in history.
7 On 31 July 1963 Whitaker commissioned Terry Nation to write a story under the title The Mutants.
8 As originally written the Daleks and Thals were the victims of an alien neutron bomb attack but Nation later dropped the aliens and made the Daleks the aggressors.
9 When the script was presented to Newman and Wilson it was immediately rejected as the programme was not permitted to contain any bugeyed monsters.
10 The first serial had been completed and the BBC believed it was crucial that the next one be a success but The Mutants was the only script ready to go so the show had little choice but to use it.
11 According to producer Verity Lambert We didnt have a lot of choice — we only had the Dalek serial to go  We had a bit of a crisis of confidence because Donald Wilson was so adamant that we shouldnt make it.
12 Had we had anything else ready we would have made that.
13 Nations script became the second Doctor Who serial – The Daleks aka.
14 The Mutants.
15 The serial introduced the eponymous aliens that would become the series most popular monsters and was responsible for the BBCs first merchandising boom.
16 What was the date of the very first episode of Doctor Who?	23 November 1963	1
17 What creatures were the most popular monsters in the series?	The Daleks aka The Mutants	13
18 Why was the Dalek script rejected at first?	the programme was not permitted to contain any bugeyed monsters	9
19 Who wrote The Mutants?	Terry Nation	7
20 How long was each episode of Doctor Who?	25 minutes of transmission length	2
1 The BBC drama departments serials division produced the programme for 26 seasons broadcast on BBC 1.
2 Falling viewing numbers a decline in the public perception of the show and a lessprominent transmission slot saw production suspended in 1989 by Jonathan Powell controller of BBC 1.
3 Although as series costar Sophie Aldred reported in the documentary Doctor Who More Than 30 Years in the TARDIS it was effectively if not formally cancelled with the decision not to commission a planned 27th series of the show for transmission in 1990 the BBC repeatedly affirmed that the series would return.
4 How many seasons did the BBC produce Doctor Who?	26	1
5 Who ended the series in 1989?	Jonathan Powell	2
6 What documentary was shown about Doctor Who?	Doctor Who More Than 30 Years in the TARDIS	3
7 After cancelling the show what did the BBC tell the public?	the series would return	3
8 What TV station showed the broadcasts of the original Doctor Who series?	BBC 1	1
1 While inhouse production had ceased the BBC hoped to find an independent production company to relaunch the show.
2 Philip Segal a British expatriate who worked for Columbia Pictures television arm in the United States had approached the BBC about such a venture as early as July 1989 while the 26th series was still in production.
3 Segals negotiations eventually led to a Doctor Who television film broadcast on the Fox Network in 1996 as a coproduction between Fox Universal Pictures the BBC and BBC Worldwide.
4 Although the film was successful in the UK with 91 million viewers it was less so in the United States and did not lead to a series.
5 What was the BBC hoping that an independent production firm would do for Doctor Who?	relaunch the show	1
6 Who approached the BBC in 1989 about relaunching the show?	Philip Segal	2

1 Doctor Who finally returned with the episode Rose on BBC One on 26 March 2005.
2 There have since been nine further series in 2006–2008 and 2010–2015 and Christmas Day specials every year since 2005.
3 No full series was filmed in 2009 although four additional specials starring David Tennant were made.
4 In 2010 Steven Moffat replaced Davies as head writer and executive producer.
5 In January 2016 Moffat announced that he would step down after the 2017 finale to be replaced by Chris Chibnall in 2018.
6 In addition Series 10 will debut in Spring 2017 with a Christmas special broadcast in 2016.

1 The 2005 version of Doctor Who is a direct plot continuation of the original 1963–1989 seriesnote 2 and the 1996 telefilm.
2 This is similar to the 1988 continuation of Mission Impossible but differs from most other series relaunches which have either been reboots for example Battlestar Galactica and Bionic Womancitation needed or set in the same universe as the original but in a different time period and with different characters for example Star Trek The Next Generation and spinoffscitation needed.
3 What years did the original Doctor Who series run?	1963–1989	1
4 What new series continues the plot of the original Doctor Who?	The 2005 version	1
5 What year was the only film version of Doctor Who shown?	1996	1
6 Name two series that have been reboots rather than plot continuations	Battlestar Galactica and Bionic Woman 	2.
7 What other series mentioned returned with a plot continuation?	Mission Impossible 	2
1 It has been claimed that the transmission of the first episode was delayed by ten minutes due to extended news coverage of the assassination of US President John F Kennedy the previous day whereas in fact it went out after a delay of eighty seconds.
2 The BBC believed that many viewers had missed this introduction to a new series due to the coverage of the assassination as well as a series of power blackouts across the country and they broadcast it again on 30 November 1963 just before episode two.
3 When did the BBC rebroadcast the first episode of Doctor Who?	30 November 1963	2
4 How long was the broadcast delay the first time the series premiered?	eighty seconds	1
5 Who long was the broadcast delay claimed to be the first time the series premiered?	ten minutes	1
6 What major event US occurred that made the BBC delay the broadcast?	the assassination of US President John F Kennedy	1
7 What other event made the BBC concerned that viewers had not seen the premier of Doctor Who?	a series of power blackouts across the country	2
1 The phrase Hiding behind or watching from behind the sofa entered British pop culture signifying in humour the stereotypical earlyseries behaviour of children who wanted to avoid seeing frightening parts of a television programme while remaining in the room to watch the remainder of it.
2 The phrase retains this association with Doctor Who to the point that in 1991 the Museum of the Moving Image in London named their exhibition celebrating the programme Behind the Sofa.
3 The electronic theme music too was perceived as eerie novel and frightening at the time.
4 A 2012 article placed this childhood juxtaposition of fear and thrill at the center of many peoples relationship with the show and a 2011 online vote at Digital Spy deemed the series the scariest TV show of all time.
5 What popular phrase is associated with the Doctor Who series?	Hiding behind or watching from behind the sofa	1
6 Who put on a Doctor Who exhibition in 1991?	the Museum of the Moving Image	2
7 What was the name of the 1991 Doctor Who exhibition?	Behind the Sofa	2
8 What did people vote the Doctor Who series as in a 2011 online vote?	scariest TV show of all time	4
9 Who conducted the 2011 online vote?	Digital Spy	4
1 A BBC audience research survey conducted in 1972 found that by their own definition of violence any acts which may cause physical andor psychological injury hurt or death to persons animals or property whether intentional or accidental Doctor Who was the most violent of the drama programmes the corporation produced at the time.
2 The same report found that 3 of the surveyed audience regarded the show as very unsuitable for family viewing.
3 Responding to the findings of the survey in The Times newspaper journalist Philip Howard maintained that to compare the violence of Dr Who sired by a horselaugh out of a nightmare with the more realistic violence of other television series where actors who look like human beings bleed paint that looks like blood is like comparing Monopoly with the property market in London both are fantasies but one is meant to be taken seriously.
4 Which show was voted most violent of the BBC shows in a 1972 survey?	Doctor Who	1
5 How many of the survey respondents considered Doctor Who very unsuitable for family viewing?	3	2
6 What journalist wrote an article defending Doctor Who?	Philip Howard	3
7 In his defense of Doctor Who what did Philip Howard compare to the London property market?	Monopoly	3
8 What publication did Philip Howard work for?	The Times newspaper	3
1 The image of the TARDIS has become firmly linked to the show in the publics consciousness BBC scriptwriter Anthony Coburn who lived in the resort of Herne Bay Kent was one of the people who conceived the idea of a police box as a time machine.
2 In 1996 the BBC applied for a trade mark to use the TARDIS blue police box design in merchandising associated with Doctor Who.
3 In 1998 the Metropolitan Police Authority filed an objection to the trade mark claim but in 2002 the Patent Office ruled in favour of the BBC.
4 What image has become linked to Doctor Who?	the TARDIS	1
5 What does the TARDIS look like?	blue police box	2
6 What is the function of the TARDIS?	time machine	1
7 Who filed an objection to the BBC using the blue police box in Doctor Who merchandise?	the Metropolitan Police Authority	3
8 When did the BBC receive a favorable ruling on the trade mark claim?	2002	3
1 Doctor Who originally ran for 26 seasons on BBC One from 23 November 1963 until 6 December 1989.
2 During the original run each weekly episode formed part of a story or serial — usually of four to six parts in earlier years and three to four in later years.
3 Notable exceptions were The Daleks Master Plan which aired in 12 episodes plus an earlier oneepisode teaser Mission to the Unknown featuring none of the regular cast almost an entire season of sevenepisode serials season 7 the 10episode serial The War Games and The Trial of a Time Lord which ran for 14 episodes albeit divided into three production codes and four narrative segments during season 23.
4 Occasionally serials were loosely connected by a storyline such as season 8 being devoted to the Doctor battling a rogue Time Lord called The Master season 16s quest for The Key to Time season 18s journey through ESpace and the theme of entropy and season 20s Black Guardian Trilogy.
5 How many seasons did the original Doctor Who run?	26	1
6 When was the last episode of the original series?	6 December 1989	1
7 How many episodes were in The Daleks Master Plan?	12	3
8 What is the name of a Time Lord that Doctor Who has fought?	The Master	4
9 What was the focus of Season 20 of Doctor Who?	Black Guardian Trilogy	4
1 The serial format changed for the 2005 revival with each series usually consisting of 13 45minute selfcontained episodes 60 minutes with adverts on overseas commercial channels and an extended episode broadcast on Christmas Day.
2 Each series includes several standalone and multipart stories linked with a loose story arc that resolves in the series finale.
3 As in the early classic era each episode whether standalone or part of a larger story has its own title.
4 Occasionally regularseries episodes will exceed the 45minute run time notably the episodes Journeys End from 2008 and The Eleventh Hour from 2010 exceeded an hour in length.
5 In what year did the serial format change for the Doctor Who series?	2005	1
6 How long was each Doctor Who episode in the 2005 revival series including ads?	60 minutes	1
7 When was an extended episode of Doctor Who shown?	Christmas Day	1
8 Which episode in 2008 was over an hour long?	Journeys End	4
9 In what year did The Eleventh Hour play?	2010	4
1 826 Doctor Who instalments have been televised since 1963 ranging between 25minute episodes the most common format 45minute episodes for Resurrection of the Daleks in the 1984 series a single season in 1985 and the revival two featurelength productions 1983s The Five Doctors and the 1996 television film eight Christmas specials most of 60 minutes duration one of 72 minutes and four additional specials ranging from 60 to 75 minutes in 2009 2010 and 2013.
2 Four miniepisodes running about eight minutes each were also produced for the 1993 2005 and 2007 Children in Need charity appeals while another miniepisode was produced in 2008 for a Doctor Whothemed edition of The Proms.
3 The 1993 2part story entitled Dimensions in Time was made in collaboration with the cast of the BBC soapopera EastEnders and was filmed partly on the EastEnders set.
4 A twopart miniepisode was also produced for the 2011 edition of Comic Relief.
5 Starting with the 2009 special Planet of the Dead the series was filmed in 1080i for HDTV and broadcast simultaneously on BBC One and BBC HD.

8 How many Doctor Who Christmas Specials have been shown?	eight	1
9 How long was the longest Doctor Who Christmas Special?	72 minutes	1
10 In what year did Doctor Who begin being shown in HDTV?	2009	5
1 Between about 1964 and 1973 large amounts of older material stored in the BBCs various video tape and film libraries were either destroyednote 3 wiped or suffered from poor storage which led to severe deterioration from broadcast quality.
2 This included many old episodes of Doctor Who mostly stories featuring the first two Doctors William Hartnell and Patrick Troughton.
3 In all 97 of 253 episodes produced during the first six years of the programme are not held in the BBCs archives most notably seasons 3 4  5 from which 79 episodes are missing.
4 In 1972 almost all episodes then made were known to exist at the BBC while by 1978 the practice of wiping tapes and destroying spare film copies had been brought to a stop.
5 Who were the first two actors that played Doctor Who?	William Hartnell and Patrick Troughton	2
6 How many of the episodes produced in the first six seasons are not in BBCs archives?	97	3
7 Which seasons is the BBC missing a total of 79 episodes?	3  4   5	3
8 When did the practice of wiping tapes stop?	1978	4
9 What years saw the most loss of old shows in the BBC archives?	Between about 1964 and 1973	1
1 Some episodes have been returned to the BBC from the archives of other countries who bought prints for broadcast or by private individuals who acquired them by various means.
2 Early colour videotape recordings made offair by fans have also been retrieved as well as excerpts filmed from the television screen onto 8 mm cine film and clips that were shown on other programmes.
3 Audio versions of all of the lost episodes exist from home viewers who made tape recordings of the show.
4 Short clips from every story with the exception of Marco Polo Mission to the Unknown and The Massacre of St Bartholomews Eve also exist.

1 Official reconstructions have also been released by the BBC on VHS on MP3 CDROM and as special features on DVD.
2 The BBC in conjunction with animation studio Cosgrove Hall reconstructed the missing episodes 1 and 4 of The Invasion 1968 using remastered audio tracks and the comprehensive stage notes for the original filming for the serials DVD release in November 2006.
3 The missing episodes of The Reign of Terror were animated by animation company ThetaSigma in collaboration with Big Finish and became available for purchase in May 2013 through Amazoncom.
4 Subsequent animations made in 2013 include The Tenth Planet The Ice Warriors and The Moonbase.

1 Producers introduced the concept of regeneration to permit the recasting of the main character.
2 This was first prompted by original star William Hartnells poor health.
3 The actual term regeneration was not initially conceived of until the Doctors third onscreen regeneration however Hartnells Doctor had merely described undergoing a renewal and the Second Doctor underwent a change of appearance.
4 citation needed The device has allowed for the recasting of the actor various times in the shows history as well as the depiction of alternative Doctors either from the Doctors relative past or future.
5 citation needed.
6 What term is used to explain a change in the appearance of Doctor Who?	regeneration	1
7 When was the term regeneration first used?	the Doctors third onscreen regeneration	3
8 What first prompted the regeneration concept?	William Hartnells poor health	2
9 What term was used for the first regeneration?	renewal	3
10 What term was used for the second regeneration?	change of appearance	3
1 The serials The Deadly Assassin and Mawdryn Undead and the 1996 TV film would later establish that a Time Lord can only regenerate 12 times for a total of 13 incarnations.
2 This line became stuck in the public consciousness despite not often being repeated and was recognised by producers of the show as a plot obstacle for when the show finally had to regenerate the Doctor a thirteenth time.
3 The episode The Time of the Doctor depicted the Doctor acquiring a new cycle of regenerations starting from the Twelfth Doctor due to the Eleventh Doctor being the product of the Doctors twelfth regeneration from his original set.
4 How many times can a Time Lord regenerate?	12	1
5 How many incarnations can a Time Lord have?	13	1
6 In what episode did Doctor Who get a new cycle of regenerations?	The Time of the Doctor	3
7 In what two serials was the number of regenerations set?	The Deadly Assassin and Mawdryn Undead	1
8 In what year did the film also mention the number of regenerations?	1996	1
1 In addition to those actors who have headlined the series others have portrayed versions of the Doctor in guest roles.
2 Notably in 2013 John Hurt gueststarred as a hitherto unknown incarnation of the Doctor known as the War Doctor in the runup to the shows 50th anniversary special The Day of the Doctor.
3 He is shown in miniepisode The Night of the Doctor to have been retroactively inserted into the shows fictional chronology between McGann and Ecclestons Doctors although his introduction was written so as not to disturb the established numerical naming of the Doctors.
4 Another example is from the 1986 serial The Trial of a Time Lord where Michael Jayston portrayed the Valeyard who is described as an amalgamation of the darker sides of the Doctors nature somewhere between his twelfth and final incarnation.

1 There have been instances of actors returning at later dates to reprise the role of their specific Doctor.
2 In 1973s The Three Doctors William Hartnell and Patrick Troughton returned alongside Jon Pertwee.
3 For 1983s The Five Doctors Troughton and Pertwee returned to star with Peter Davison and Tom Baker appeared in previously unseen footage from the uncompleted Shada episode.
4 For this episode Richard Hurndall replaced William Hartnell.
5 Patrick Troughton again returned in 1985s The Two Doctors with Colin Baker.
6 In 2007 Peter Davison returned in the Children in Need short Time Crash alongside David Tennant and most recently in 2013s 50th anniversary special episode The Day of the Doctor David Tennants Tenth Doctor appeared alongside Matt Smith as the Eleventh Doctor and John Hurt as the War Doctor as well as brief footage from all of the previous actors.
7 In addition the Doctor has occasionally encountered himself in the form of his own incarnation from the near future or past.
8 The First Doctor encounters himself in the story The Space Museum albeit frozen and as an exhibit the Third Doctor encounters and interacts with himself in the story Day of the Daleks the Fourth Doctor encounters and interacts with the future incarnation of himself the Watcher in the story Logopolis the Ninth Doctor observes a former version of his current incarnation in Fathers Day and the Eleventh Doctor briefly comes face to face with himself in The Big Bang.
9 In The Almost People the Doctor comes facetoface with himself although it is found out that this incarnation is in fact just a flesh replica.
10 In The Name of the Doctor the Eleventh Doctor meets an unknown incarnation of himself whom he refers to as his secret and who is subsequently revealed to be the War Doctor.

1 Throughout the programmes long history there have been revelations about the Doctor that have raised additional questions.
2 In The Brain of Morbius 1976 it was hinted that the First Doctor may not have been the first incarnation although the other faces depicted may have been incarnations of the Time Lord Morbius.
3 In subsequent stories the First Doctor was depicted as the earliest incarnation of the Doctor.
4 In Mawdryn Undead 1983 the Fifth Doctor explicitly confirmed that he was then currently in his fifth incarnation.
5 Later that same year during 1983s 20th Anniversary special The Five Doctors the First Doctor enquires as to the Fifth Doctors regeneration when the Fifth Doctor confirms Fourth the First Doctor excitedly replies Goodness me.
6 So there are five of me now.
7 In 2010 the Eleventh Doctor similarly calls himself the Eleventh in The Lodger.
8 In the 2013 episode The Time of the Doctor the Eleventh Doctor clarified he was the product of the twelfth regeneration due to a previous incarnation which he chose not to count and one other aborted regeneration.
9 The name Eleventh is still used for this incarnation the same episode depicts the prophesied Fall of the Eleventh which had been trailed throughout the series.

1 The programmes first serial An Unearthly Child shows that the Doctor has a granddaughter Susan Foreman.
2 In the 1967 serial Tomb of the Cybermen when Victoria Waterfield doubts the Doctor can remember his family because of being so ancient the Doctor says that he can when he really wants to—The rest of the time they sleep in my mind.
3 The 2005 series reveals that the Ninth Doctor thought he was the last surviving Time Lord and that his home planet had been destroyed in The Empty Child 2005 Dr Constantine states that Before the war even began I was a father and a grandfather.
4 Now I am neither.
5 The Doctor remarks in response Yeah I know the feeling.
6 In Smith and Jones 2007 when asked if he had a brother he replied No not any more.
7 In both Fear Her 2006 and The Doctors Daughter 2008 he states that he had in the past been a father.
8 What is the name of the first Doctor Who serial?	An Unearthly Child	1
9 What is the name of Doctor Who granddaughter?	Susan Foreman	1
10 In what year did Doctor Who state that he was the last Time Lord?	2005	3
11 In 2005 what did Doctor Who think the condition of his home planet was?	destroyed	3

1 The companion figure – generally a human – has been a constant feature in Doctor Who since the programmes inception in 1963.
2 One of the roles of the companion is to remind the Doctor of his moral duty.
3 The Doctors first companions seen on screen were his granddaughter Susan Foreman Carole Ann Ford and her teachers Barbara Wright Jacqueline Hill and Ian Chesterton William Russell.
4 These characters were intended to act as audience surrogates through which the audience would discover information about the Doctor who was to act as a mysterious father figure.
5 The only story from the original series in which the Doctor travels alone is The Deadly Assassin.
6 Notable companions from the earlier series included Romana Mary Tamm and Lalla Ward a Time Lady Sarah Jane Smith Elisabeth Sladen and Jo Grant Katy Manning.
7 Dramatically these characters provide a figure with whom the audience can identify and serve to further the story by requesting exposition from the Doctor and manufacturing peril for the Doctor to resolve.
8 The Doctor regularly gains new companions and loses old ones sometimes they return home or find new causes — or loves — on worlds they have visited.
9 Some have died during the course of the series.
10 Companions are usually human or humanoid aliens.
11 What type of creature is usually Doctor Whos companion?	a human	1
12 What is the only story of the original series where Doctor Who travels alone?	The Deadly Assassin	5
13 What relative of Doctor Who traveled with him in the early episodes?	his granddaughter Susan Foreman	3
14 What was the occupation of Doctor Whos other nonrelated companions?	teachers	3
15 What was the name of the character known as the Time Lady?	Romana	6
1 Since the 2005 revival the Doctor generally travels with a primary female companion who occupies a larger narrative role.
2 Steven Moffat described the companion as the main character of the show as the story begins anew with each companion and she undergoes more change than the Doctor.
3 The primary companions of the Ninth and Tenth Doctors were Rose Tyler Billie Piper Martha Jones Freema Agyeman and Donna Noble Catherine Tate with Mickey Smith Noel Clarke and Jack Harkness John Barrowman recurring as secondary companion figures.
4 The Eleventh Doctor became the first to travel with a married couple Amy Pond Karen Gillan and Rory Williams Arthur Darvill whilst outofsync meetings with River Song Alex Kingston and Clara Oswald Jenna Coleman provided ongoing story arcs.
5 The tenth series will introduce Pearl Mackie as Bill the Doctors newest traveling companion.
6 Since 2005 what is the gender of Doctor Whos primary traveling companion?	female	1

8 Who was the first Doctor to travel with a married couple?	The Eleventh	4

10 Who played the companion named Donna Noble?	Catherine Tate	3
1 With the shows 2005 revival executive producer Russell T Davies stated his intention to reintroduce classic icons of Doctor Who one step at a time the Autons with the Nestene Consciousness and Daleks in series 1 Cybermen in series 2 the Macra and the Master in series 3 the Sontarans and Davros in series 4 and the Time Lords Rassilon in the 2009–10 Specials.
2 Davies successor Steven Moffat has continued the trend by reviving the Silurians in series 5 Cybermats in series 6 the Great Intelligence and the Ice Warriors in Series 7 and Zygons in the 50th Anniversary Special.
3 Since its 2005 return the series has also introduced new recurring aliens Slitheen Raxacoricofallapatorian Ood Judoon Weeping Angels and the Silence.
4 Who was the executive producer of the 2005 Doctor Who revival series?	Russell T Davies	1
5 When were the Daleks reintroduced in the revival series?	series 1	1
6 What icons were reintroduced in series 2 of the revival show?	Cybermen	1
7 In what series was the Master reintroduced?	3	1
