1 The Dalek race which first appeared in the shows second serial in 1963 are Doctor Whos oldest villains.
2 The Daleks are Kaleds from the planet Skaro mutated by the scientist Davros and housed in mechanical armour shells for mobility.
3 The actual creatures resemble octopi with large pronounced brains.
4 Their armour shells have a single eyestalk a sinkplungerlike device that serves the purpose of a hand and a directedenergy weapon.
5 Their main weakness is their eyestalk attacks upon them using various weapons can blind a Dalek making it go mad.
6 Their chief role in the series plot as they frequently remark in their instantly recognisable metallic voices is to exterminate all nonDalek beings.
7 They even attack the Time Lords in the Time War as shown during the 50th Anniversary of the show.
8 They continue to be a recurring monster within the Doctor Who franchise their most recent appearances being in the 2015 episodes The Witchs Familiar and Hell Bent.
9 Davros has also been a recurring figure since his debut in Genesis of the Daleks although played by several different actors.
10 Who are the oldest villains from the Doctor Who series?	The Dalek race	1
11 What planet do the Daleks come from?	Skaro	2
12 What is the primary mission of the Daleks?	to exterminate all nonDalek beings	6
13 What scientist created the Daleks by mutation?	Davros	2
14 What is the Daleks main weakness?	their eyestalk	5
1 The Master is the Doctors archenemy a renegade Time Lord who desires to rule the universe.
2 Conceived as Professor Moriarty to the Doctors Sherlock Holmes the character first appeared in 1971.
3 As with the Doctor the role has been portrayed by several actors since the Master is a Time Lord as well and able to regenerate the first of these actors was Roger Delgado who continued in the role until his death in 1973.
4 The Master was briefly played by Peter Pratt and Geoffrey Beevers until Anthony Ainley took over and continued to play the character until Doctor Whos hiatus in 1989.
5 The Master returned in the 1996 television movie of Doctor Who and was played by American actor Eric Roberts.
6 Who is the archenemy of Doctor Who?	The Master	1
7 What title do both Doctor Who and the Master share?	Time Lord	1
8 Who played the Master in the 1996 TV movie?	Eric Roberts	5
9 What literary reference compares the Master to Doctor Who?	Professor Moriarty to the Doctors Sherlock Holmes	2
10 Who was the first person to play the Master?	Roger Delgado	3
1 Following the series revival in 2005 Derek Jacobi provided the characters reintroduction in the 2007 episode Utopia.
2 During that story the role was then assumed by John Simm who returned to the role multiple times through the Tenth Doctors tenure.
3 As of the 2014 episode Dark Water it was revealed that the Master had become a female incarnation or Time Lady going by the name of Missy short for Mistress the feminine equivalent of Master.
4 This incarnation is played by Michelle Gomez.
5 Who first played the Master in the 2007 series?	Derek Jacobi	1
6 What was the 2007 episode that featured the Masters return?	Utopia	1
7 In what year did the Master reincarnate into a female body?	2014	3
8 What is the nickname of the female Master?	Missy	3
9 What actress plays the female Master?	Michelle Gomez	4
1 The original theme was composed by Ron Grainer and realised by Delia Derbyshire of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop with assistance from Dick Mills.
2 The various parts were built up using musique concrète techniques by creating tape loops of an individually struck piano string and individual test oscillators and filters.
3 The Derbyshire arrangement served with minor edits as the theme tune up to the end of season 17 1979–80.
4 It is regarded as a significant and innovative piece of electronic music recorded well before the availability of commercial synthesisers or multitrack mixers.
5 Each note was individually created by cutting splicing speeding up and slowing down segments of analogue tape containing recordings of a single plucked string white noise and the simple harmonic waveforms of testtone oscillators intended for calibrating equipment and rooms not creating music.
6 New techniques were invented to allow mixing of the music as this was before the era of multitrack tape machines.
7 On hearing the finished result Grainer asked Did I write that.
8 citation needed.
9 Who composed the original Doctor Who theme?	Ron Grainer	1
10 What workshop helped with the creation of the Doctor Who theme?	the BBC Radiophonic Workshop	1
11 What kind of techniques were used to create the theme?	musique concrète	2
12 When was the last season that this original theme was used?	17	3
13 Upon hearing the final product what was the creator quoted as saying?	Did I write that	7
1 A different arrangement was recorded by Peter Howell for season 18 1980 which was in turn replaced by Dominic Glynns arrangement for the seasonlong serial The Trial of a Time Lord in season 23 1986.
2 Keff McCulloch provided the new arrangement for the Seventh Doctors era which lasted from season 24 1987 until the series suspension in 1989.
3 American composer John Debney created a new arrangement of Ron Grainers original theme for Doctor Who in 1996.
4 For the return of the series in 2005 Murray Gold provided a new arrangement which featured samples from the 1963 original with further elements added in the 2005 Christmas episode The Christmas Invasion Gold introduced a modified closing credits arrangement that was used up until the conclusion of the 2007 series.
5 citation needed.
6 Who recorded the theme played for season 18?	Peter Howell	1
7 Who created the theme used in 1986?	Dominic Glynn	1
8 For which Doctor did Keff McCulloch provide the theme?	Seventh	2
9 Who created the 2005 theme for Doctor Who?	Murray Gold	4
10 In what show did Murray Gold modify the closing credits theme?	The Christmas Invasion	4
1 A new arrangement of the theme once again by Gold was introduced in the 2007 Christmas special episode Voyage of the Damned Gold returned as composer for the 2010 series.
2 He was responsible for a new version of the theme which was reported to have had a hostile reception from some viewers.
3 In 2011 the theme tune charted at number 228 of radio station Classic FMs Hall of Fame a survey of classical music tastes.
4 A revised version of Golds 2010 arrangement had its debut over the opening titles of the 2012 Christmas special The Snowmen and a further revision of the arrangement was made for the 50th Anniversary special The Day of the Doctor in November 2013.
5 citation needed.
6 What was the name of the 2007 Christmas special?	Voyage of the Damned	1
7 What radio station did the Doctor Who theme reach the charts on in 2011?	Classic FMs Hall of Fame	3
8 Which series version had a negative reception from some Doctor Who viewers?	2010	1
9 How high did the Doctor Who theme go on the radio charts?	228	3
10 Who was the creator of the theme for the 50th Anniversary special?	Gold	4
1 Versions of the Doctor Who Theme have also been released as pop music over the years.
2 In the early 1970s Jon Pertwee who had played the Third Doctor recorded a version of the Doctor Who theme with spoken lyrics titled Who Is the Doctor.
3 note 6 In 1978 a disco version of the theme was released in the UK Denmark and Australia by the group Mankind which reached number 24 in the UK charts.
4 In 1988 the band The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu later known as The KLF released the single Doctorin the Tardis under the name The Timelords which reached No.
5 1 in the UK and No.
6 2 in Australia this version incorporated several other songs including Rock and Roll Part 2 by Gary Glitter who recorded vocals for some of the CDsingle remix versions of Doctorin the Tardis.
7 Others who have covered or reinterpreted the theme include Orbital Pink Floyd the Australian string ensemble Fourplay New Zealand punk band Blam Blam Blam The Pogues Thin Lizzy Dub Syndicate and the comedians Bill Bailey and Mitch Benn.
8 Both the theme and obsessive fans were satirised on The Chasers War on Everything.
9 The theme tune has also appeared on many compilation CDs and has made its way into mobilephone ringtones.
10 Fans have also produced and distributed their own remixes of the theme.
11 In January 2011 the Mankind version was released as a digital download on the album Gallifrey And Beyond.
12 Who recorded a version of the Doctor Who theme with spoken lyrics in the 1970s?	Jon Pertwee	2
13 Who released a disco version of the Doctor Who theme?	Mankind	3
14 How high on the charts did the Mankind version of the theme go?	number 24	3
15 What was the name of the Doctor Whorelated song released in 1988?	Doctorin the Tardis	4
16 Which Doctor Whorelated song reached Number One in the UK?	Doctorin the Tardis	4
1 The most frequent musical contributor during the first 15 years was Dudley Simpson who is also well known for his theme and incidental music for Blakes 7 and for his haunting theme music and score for the original 1970s version of The Tomorrow People.
2 Simpsons first Doctor Who score was Planet of Giants 1964 and he went on to write music for many adventures of the 1960s and 1970s including most of the stories of the Jon PertweeTom Baker periods ending with The Horns of Nimon 1979.
3 He also made a cameo appearance in The Talons of WengChiang as a Music hall conductor.
4 Who was the most frequent musical contributor to Doctor Who in the first 15 years of the show?	Dudley Simpson	1
5 What was the episode name of Simpsons first Doctor Who score?	Planet of Giants	2
6 In what decades was Dudley Simpson most active in contributing to Doctor Who?	the 1960s and 1970s	2
7 What was the last Doctor Who episode that Dudley Simpson wrote music for?	The Horns of Nimon	2
8 In what episode did Dudley Simpson play a music conductor?	The Talons of WengChiang	3
1 All the incidental music for the 2005 revived series has been composed by Murray Gold and Ben Foster and has been performed by the BBC National Orchestra of Wales from the 2005 Christmas episode The Christmas Invasion onwards.
2 A concert featuring the orchestra performing music from the first two series took place on 19 November 2006 to raise money for Children in Need.
3 David Tennant hosted the event introducing the different sections of the concert.
4 Murray Gold and Russell T Davies answered questions during the interval and Daleks and Cybermen appeared whilst music from their stories was played.
5 The concert aired on BBCi on Christmas Day 2006.
6 A Doctor Who Prom was celebrated on 27 July 2008 in the Royal Albert Hall as part of the annual BBC Proms.
7 The BBC Philharmonic and the London Philharmonic Choir performed Murray Golds compositions for the series conducted by Ben Foster as well as a selection of classics based on the theme of space and time.
8 The event was presented by Freema Agyeman and guestpresented by various other stars of the show with numerous monsters participating in the proceedings.
9 It also featured the specially filmed miniepisode Music of the Spheres written by Russell T Davies and starring David Tennant.
10 Who has performed all the Doctor Who music since the 2005 Christmas special?	the BBC National Orchestra of Wales	1
11 Who performed a benefit concert for the charity Children in Need?	the BBC National Orchestra of Wales	1
12 When was a Doctor Who Prom performed?	27 July 2008	6
13 What Doctor Who miniepisode was shown during the Prom?	Music of the Spheres	9
14 Who has composed the Doctor Who incidental music since 2005?	Murray Gold and Ben Foster	1
1 Six soundtrack releases have been released since 2005.
2 The first featured tracks from the first two series the second and third featured music from the third and fourth series respectively.
3 The fourth was released on 4 October 2010 as a two disc special edition and contained music from the 2008–2010 specials The Next Doctor to End of Time Part 2.
4 The soundtrack for Series 5 was released on 8 November 2010.
5 In February 2011 a soundtrack was released for the 2010 Christmas special A Christmas Carol and in December 2011 the soundtrack for Series 6 was released both by Silva Screen Records.
6 How many Doctor Who soundtracks have been released since 2005?	Six	1
7 Which series were featured on the first Doctor Who soundtrack?	the first two series	2
8 What music did the fourth soundtrack feature?	music from the 2008–2010 specials	3
9 What was the name of the 2010 Christmas special?	A Christmas Carol	5
10 When was the soundtrack for series 5 released?	8 November 2010	4
1 The original logo used for the First Doctor and briefly for the Second Doctor was reused in a slightly modified format for the 50th anniversary special The Day of the Doctor during the Eleventh Doctors run.
2 The logo used in the television movie featuring the Eighth Doctor was an updated version of the logo used for the Third Doctor.
3 The logo from 1973–80 was used for the Third Doctors final season and for the majority of the Fourth Doctors tenure.
4 The following logo while most associated with the Fifth Doctor was also used for the Fourth Doctors final season.
5 The logo used for the Ninth Doctor was slightly edited for the Tenth Doctor but it retained the same general appearance.
6 The logo used for the Eleventh Doctor had the DW TARDIS insignia placed to the right in 2012 but the same font remained albeit with a slight edit to the texture every episode with the texture relating to some aspect of the story.
7 The logo for the Twelfth Doctor had the DW TARDIS insignia removed and the font was subtly altered as well as made slightly larger.
8 As of 2014 the logo used for the Third and Eighth Doctors is the primary logo used on all media and merchandise relating to past Doctors and the current Doctor Who logo is used for all merchandise relating to the current Doctor.
9 What logo was modified and reused for the 50th Anniversary special?	The original logo	1
10 Which logo had the DW Tardis insignia removed?	The logo for the Twelfth Doctor	7
11 What logo is used for all merchandise that features past Doctors?	the logo used for the Third and Eighth Doctors	8
12 Which logo was used for the third Doctor Whos last season?	The logo from 1973–80	3
13 Which Doctor was the current Doctor during the 50th Anniversary special?	the Eleventh Doctor	1
1 Premiering the day after the assassination of John F Kennedy the first episode of Doctor Who was repeated with the second episode the following week.
2 Doctor Who has always appeared initially on the BBCs mainstream BBC One channel where it is regarded as a family show drawing audiences of many millions of viewers episodes are now repeated on BBC Three.
3 The programmes popularity has waxed and waned over the decades with three notable periods of high ratings.
4 The first of these was the Dalekmania period circa 1964–1965 when the popularity of the Daleks regularly brought Doctor Who ratings of between 9 and 14 million even for stories which did not feature them.
5 The second was the late 1970s when Tom Baker occasionally drew audiences of over 12 million.
6 The first episode of Doctor Who premiered the day after what famous event in history?	the assassination of John F Kennedy	1
7 Where have the first episodes of Doctor Who always appeared?	on the BBCs mainstream BBC One channel	2
8 In what years did the show see audiences as high as 12 million?	the late 1970s	5
9 When was the Dalekmania period?	circa 1964–1965	4
10 What channel shows repeats of the Doctor Who shows?	BBC Three	2
1 During the ITV network strike of 1979 viewership peaked at 16 million.
2 citation needed Figures remained respectable into the 1980s but fell noticeably after the programmes 23rd series was postponed in 1985 and the show was off the air for 18 months.
3 Its late 1980s performance of three to five million viewers was seen as poor at the time and was according to the BBC Board of Control a leading cause of the programmes 1989 suspension.
4 Some fans considered this disingenuous since the programme was scheduled against the soap opera Coronation Street the most popular show at the time.
5 After the series revival in 2005 the third notable period of high ratings it has consistently had high viewership levels for the evening on which the episode is broadcast.
6 When was Doctor Who viewing at its highest level?	During the ITV network strike of 1979	1
7 What was the main reason for the shows suspension in 1989?	Its late 1980s performance of three to five million viewers	3
8 Fans blame the poor viewership of the late 80s to competition from what show?	Coronation Street	4
9 How popular was Coronation Street in the late 80s?	the most popular show at the time	4
10 When was the third period of high viewership for the Doctor Who series?	After the series revival in 2005	5
1 Only four episodes have ever had their premiere showings on channels other than BBC One.
2 The 1983 20th anniversary special The Five Doctors had its début on 23 November the actual date of the anniversary on a number of PBS stations two days prior to its BBC One broadcast.
3 The 1988 story Silver Nemesis was broadcast with all three episodes airing back to back on TVNZ in New Zealand in November after the first episode had been shown in the UK but before the final two instalments had aired there.
4 Finally the 1996 television film premièred on 12 May 1996 on CITV in Edmonton Canada 15 days before the BBC One showing and two days before it aired on Fox in the United States.
5 citation needed.
6 What station did the 20th anniversary special show before being shown on BBC?	PBS	2
7 What country showed all three episodes of Silver Nemesis before the BBC did?	New Zealand	3
8 In what area did the 1996 television film premier?	Edmonton  Canada	4
9 How many days was the 1996 film shown ahead of the BBC showing?	15 days	4
10 When was the debut of the 1983 special called The Five Doctors?	23 November	2
1 In Australia the show has had a strong fan base since its inception having been exclusively first run by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation ABC since January 1965.
2 The ABC has periodically repeated episodes of note were the weekly screenings of all available classic episodes starting in 2003 for the shows 40th anniversary and the weekdaily screenings of all available revived episodes in 2013 for the shows 50th anniversary.
3 The ABC broadcasts the modern series first run on ABC1 with repeats on ABC2.
4 The ABC also provided partial funding for the 20th anniversary special The Five Doctors in 1983.
5 Repeats of both the classic and modern series have also been shown on subscription television channels BBC UKTV SF and later on SyFy upon SFs closure.
6 citation needed.

11 What Australian channel shows firstrun Doctor Who episodes?	ABC1	3
1 TVOntario picked up the show in 1976 beginning with The Three Doctors and aired each series several years late through to series 24 in 1991.
2 From 1979 to 1981 TVO airings were bookended by sciencefiction writer Judith Merril who would introduce the episode and then after the episode concluded try to place it in an educational context in keeping with TVOs status as an educational channel.
3 Its airing of The Talons of WengChiang was cancelled as a result of accusations that the story was racist the story was later broadcast in the 1990s on cable station YTV.
4 CBC began showing the series again in 2005.
5 The series moved to the Canadian cable channel Space in 2009.
6 citation needed.

1 Doctor Who has appeared on stage numerous times.
2 In the early 1970s Trevor Martin played the role in Doctor Who and the Daleks in the Seven Keys to Doomsday.
3 In the late 1980s Jon Pertwee and Colin Baker both played the Doctor at different times during the run of a play titled Doctor Who – The Ultimate Adventure.
4 For two performances while Pertwee was ill David Banks better known for playing Cybermen played the Doctor.
5 Other original plays have been staged as amateur productions with other actors playing the Doctor while Terry Nation wrote The Curse of the Daleks a stage play mounted in the late 1960s but without the Doctor.

10 Which actor was a replacement for Doctor Who due to the illness of the main actor?	David Banks	4
1 Following the success of the 2005 series produced by Russell T Davies the BBC commissioned Davies to produce a 13part spinoff series titled Torchwood an anagram of Doctor Who set in modernday Cardiff and investigating alien activities and crime.
2 The series debuted on BBC Three on 22 October 2006.
3 John Barrowman reprised his role of Jack Harkness from the 2005 series of Doctor Who.
4 Two other actresses who appeared in Doctor Who also star in the series Eve Myles as Gwen Cooper who also played the similarly named servant girl Gwyneth in the 2005 Doctor Who episode The Unquiet Dead and Naoko Mori who reprised her role as Toshiko Sato first seen in Aliens of London.
5 A second series of Torchwood aired in 2008 for three episodes the cast was joined by Freema Agyeman reprising her Doctor Who role of Martha Jones.
6 A third series was broadcast from 6 to 10 July 2009 and consisted of a single fivepart story called Children of Earth which was set largely in London.
7 A fourth series Torchwood Miracle Day jointly produced by BBC Wales BBC Worldwide and the American entertainment company Starz debuted in 2011.
8 The series was predominantly set in the United States though Wales remained part of the shows setting.
9 What Doctor Who spinoff series was commissioned by the BBC?	Torchwood	1
10 When did Torchwood premier?	22 October 2006	2
11 When did the second series of Torchwood play?	2008	5
12 What was the name of the story from the third Torchwood series?	Children of Earth	6
13 Was is the name of the Torchwood series that was mostly based in the US?	Torchwood Miracle Day	7
1 The Sarah Jane Adventures starring Elisabeth Sladen who reprised her role as investigative journalist Sarah Jane Smith was developed by CBBC a special aired on New Years Day 2007 and a full series began on 24 September 2007.
2 A second series followed in 2008 notable for as noted above featuring the return of Brigadier LethbridgeStewart.
3 A third in 2009 featured a crossover appearance from the main show by David Tennant as the Tenth Doctor.
4 In 2010 a further such appearance featured Matt Smith as the Eleventh Doctor alongside former companion actress Katy Manning reprising her role as Jo Grant.
5 A final threestory fifth series was transmitted in autumn 2011 – uncompleted due to the death of Elisabeth Sladen in early 2011.

1 In 1993 for the franchises 30th anniversary another charity special titled Dimensions in Time was produced for Children in Need featuring all of the surviving actors who played the Doctor and a number of previous companions.
2 It also featured a crossover with the soap opera EastEnders the action taking place in the latters Albert Square location and around Greenwich.
3 The special was one of several special 3D programmes the BBC produced at the time using a 3D system that made use of the Pulfrich effect requiring glasses with one darkened lens the picture would look normal to those viewers who watched without the glasses.
4 What special was created for the shows 30th anniversary?	Dimensions in Time	1
5 What charity benefited from the 30th anniversary show?	Children in Need	1
6 Dimensions in Time featured what prominent soap opera?	EastEnders	2
7 What type of lenses were needed to see the 3D effects in Dimension in Time?	glasses with one darkened lens	3
8 What was the name of the 3D system effect in Dimension in Time?	the Pulfrich effect	3
1 In 1999 another special Doctor Who and the Curse of Fatal Death was made for Comic Relief and later released on VHS.
2 An affectionate parody of the television series it was split into four segments mimicking the traditional serial format complete with cliffhangers and running down the same corridor several times when being chased the version released on video was split into only two episodes.
3 In the story the Doctor Rowan Atkinson encounters both the Master Jonathan Pryce and the Daleks.
4 During the special the Doctor is forced to regenerate several times with his subsequent incarnations played by in order Richard E Grant Jim Broadbent Hugh Grant and Joanna Lumley.
5 The script was written by Steven Moffat later to be head writer and executive producer to the revived series.
6 What was the name of the Doctor Who special created for Comic Relief?	Doctor Who and the Curse of Fatal Death	1
7 How many segments did the special originally have?	four	2
8 Who played the first incarnation of the Doctor in the special?	Rowan Atkinson	3
9 What actress played the last incarnation of the Doctor in the special?	Joanna Lumley	4
10 The script writer for the special went on to have what role in the revised Doctor Who series?	head writer and executive producer	5

3 In a similar manner the character of Oliver on Coupling created and written by current show runner Steven Moffat is portrayed as a Doctor Who collector and enthusiast.

1 The earliest Doctor Whorelated audio release was a 21minute narrated abridgement of the First Doctor television story The Chase released in 1966.
2 Ten years later the first original Doctor Who audio was released on LP record Doctor Who and the Pescatons featuring the Fourth Doctor.
3 The first commercially available audiobook was an abridged reading of the Fourth Doctor story State of Decay in 1981.
4 In 1988 during a hiatus in the television show Slipback the first radio drama was transmitted.
5 What story was the first Doctor Who audio release based on?	The Chase	1
6 How long was the first audio of a Doctor Who story?	21minute	1

8 In what year was the first Doctor Who audiobook released?	1981	3
9 What was the name of the first Doctor Who radio drama?	Slipback	4

4 Along with the main range adventures of the First Second and Third Doctors have been produced in both limited cast and full cast formats as well as audiobooks.

1 Doctor Who books have been published from the midsixties through to the present day.
2 From 1965 to 1991 the books published were primarily novelised adaptations of broadcast episodes beginning in 1991 an extensive line of original fiction was launched the Virgin New Adventures and Virgin Missing Adventures.
3 Since the relaunch of the programme in 2005 a new range of novels have been published by BBC Books.
4 Numerous nonfiction books about the series including guidebooks and critical studies have also been published and a dedicated Doctor Who Magazine with newsstand circulation has been published regularly since 1979.
5 This is published by Panini as is the Doctor Who Adventures magazine for younger fans.
6 In what year did original fiction featuring Doctor Who appear?	1991	2
7 When were the earliest Doctor Who books available?	the midsixties	1
8 How long has the Doctor Who Magazine been in circulation?	since 1979	4
9 Who is the publisher of the Doctor Who Adventures magazine?	Panini	5
10 Who began publishing Doctor Who novels in 2005?	BBC Books	3
1 Since the creation of the Doctor Who character by BBC Television in the early 1960s a myriad of stories have been published about Doctor Who in different media apart from the actual television episodes that continue to be produced by the BBC there have also been novels comics short stories audio books radio plays interactive video games game books webcasts DVD extras and even stage performances.
2 In this respect it is noteworthy that the BBC takes no position on the canonicity of any of such stories and producers of the show have expressed distaste for the idea.
3 When was Doctor Who created?	the early 1960s	1
4 What company created Doctor Who?	BBC Television	1
5 Who has expressed distaste for the canonicity of Doctor Who stories by other media?	producers of the show	2
6 Who does not take a position on the canonicity of Doctor Who stories by other media?	the BBC	2
1 The show has received recognition as one of Britains finest television programmes winning the 2006 British Academy Television Award for Best Drama Series and five consecutive 2005–2010 awards at the National Television Awards during Russell T Davies tenure as executive producer.
2 In 2011 Matt Smith became the first Doctor to be nominated for a BAFTA Television Award for Best Actor and in 2016 Michelle Gomez became the first female to receive a BAFTA nomination for the series getting a Best Supporting Actress nomination for her work as Missy.
3 When did Doctor Who win an award for Best Drama Series?	2006	1
4 What years did Doctor Who win five consecutive awards?	2005–2010	1
5 In what year did a Doctor first become nominated for a Best Actor award?	2011	2
6 What Doctor Who actress was nominated for an award in 2016?	Michelle Gomez	2
7 What award was Michelle Gomez nominated for?	Best Supporting Actress	2
1 In 2013 the Peabody Awards honoured Doctor Who with an Institutional Peabody for evolving with technology and the times like nothing else in the known television universe.
2 The programme is listed in Guinness World Records as the longestrunning science fiction television show in the world the most successful science fiction series of all time—based on its overall broadcast ratings DVD and book sales and iTunes traffic— and for the largest ever simulcast of a TV drama with its 50th anniversary special.
3 During its original run it was recognised for its imaginative stories creative lowbudget special effects and pioneering use of electronic music originally produced by the BBC Radiophonic Workshop.
4 Where is Doctor Who the record holder for most successful science fiction series of all time?	Guinness World Records	2
5 Who holds the record for largest simulcast of a TV drama?	Doctor Who	1
6 For what type of music was Doctor Who considered a pioneer?	electronic	3
7 What year did Doctor Who win a Peabody award?	2013	1
8 Which Doctor Who show was the largest simulcast of a TV drama?	50th anniversary special	2
1 In 1975 Season 11 of the series won a Writers Guild of Great Britain award for Best Writing in a Childrens Serial.
2 In 1996 BBC television held the Auntie Awards as the culmination of their TV60 series celebrating 60 years of BBC television broadcasting where Doctor Who was voted as the Best Popular Drama the corporation had ever produced ahead of such ratings heavyweights as EastEnders and Casualty.
3 In 2000 Doctor Who was ranked third in a list of the 100 Greatest British Television Programmes of the 20th century produced by the British Film Institute and voted on by industry professionals.
4 In 2005 the series came first in a survey by SFX magazine of The Greatest UK Science Fiction and Fantasy Television Series Ever.
5 Also in the 100 Greatest Kids TV shows a Channel 4 countdown in 2001 the 1963–1989 run was placed at number eight.
6 Which season of Doctor Who won an award for Best Writing in a Childrens Serial?	Season 11	1
7 What show is considered the best drama that the BBC has ever produced?	Doctor Who	2
8 What spot does Doctor Who hold in the 100 Greatest British TV Programs of the 20th Century?	third	3
9 What publication called Doctor Who The Greatest UK Science Fiction Series Ever?	SFX magazine	4
10 What rank does Doctor Who hold in a list of the 100 Greatest Kids TV Shows?	eight	5
1 The revived series has received recognition from critics and the public across various awards ceremonies.
2 It won five BAFTA TV Awards including Best Drama Series the highestprofile and most prestigious British television award for which the series has ever been nominated.
3 It was very popular at the BAFTA Cymru Awards with 25 wins overall including Best Drama Series twice Best ScreenplayScreenwriter thrice and Best Actor.
4 It was also nominated for 7 Saturn Awards winning the only Best International Series in the ceremonys history.
5 In 2009 Doctor Who was voted the 3rd greatest show of the 2000s by Channel 4 behind Top Gear and The Apprentice.
6 The episode Vincent and the Doctor was shortlisted for a Mind Award at the 2010 Mind Mental Health Media Awards for its touching portrayal of Vincent van Gogh.

10 In what year was Doctor Who rated the third greatest show of the 2000s?	2009	5

3 Doctor Who star Matt Smith won Best Actor in the 2012 National Television awards alongside Karen Gillan who won Best Actress.

1 Doctor Who has been satirised and spoofed on many occasions by comedians including Spike Milligan a Dalek invades his bathroom — Milligan naked hurls a soap sponge at it and Lenny Henry.

1 The University of Chicago UChicago Chicago or U of C is a private research university in Chicago.
2 The university established in 1890 consists of The College various graduate programs interdisciplinary committees organized into four academic research divisions and seven professional schools.
3 Beyond the arts and sciences Chicago is also well known for its professional schools which include the Pritzker School of Medicine the University of Chicago Booth School of Business the Law School the School of Social Service Administration the Harris School of Public Policy Studies the Graham School of Continuing Liberal and Professional Studies and the Divinity School.
4 The university currently enrolls approximately 5000 students in the College and around 15000 students overall.
5 What kind of university is the University of Chicago?	a private research university	1
6 When was the University of Chicago established?	1890	2
7 How many professional schools does the University of Chicago have?	seven	2
8 How many academic research divisions does the University of Chicago have?	four	2
9 How many students does the University of Chicago have enlisted?	5 000	4
1 University of Chicago scholars have played a major role in the development of various academic disciplines including the Chicago school of economics the Chicago school of sociology the law and economics movement in legal analysis the Chicago school of literary criticism the Chicago school of religion and the behavioralism school of political science.
2 Chicagos physics department helped develop the worlds first manmade selfsustaining nuclear reaction beneath the universitys Stagg Field.
3 Chicagos research pursuits have been aided by unique affiliations with worldrenowned institutions like the nearby Fermilab and Argonne National Laboratory as well as the Marine Biological Laboratory.
4 The university is also home to the University of Chicago Press the largest university press in the United States.
5 With an estimated completion date of 2020 the Barack Obama Presidential Center will be housed at the university and include both the Obama presidential library and offices of the Obama Foundation.
6 University of Chicago scholars played a major part in what development?	various academic disciplines	1
7 Who helped develop the first manmade selfsustaining nuclear reaction?	Chicagos physics department	2
8 Where is the first manmade selfsustaining nuclear reaction located?	beneath the universitys Stagg Field	2
9 What is the name of the largest university press in the US?	University of Chicago Press	4
10 In what year will the Barack Obama Presidential Center be finished?	2020	5
1 Founded by the American Baptist Education Society with a donation from oil magnate and wealthiest man in history John D Rockefeller the University of Chicago was incorporated in 1890 William Rainey Harper became the universitys first president in 1891 and the first classes were held in 1892.
2 Both Harper and future president Robert Maynard Hutchins advocated for Chicagos curriculum to be based upon theoretical and perennial issues rather than on applied sciences and commercial utility.
3 With Harpers vision in mind the University of Chicago also became one of the 14 founding members of the Association of American Universities an international organization of leading research universities in 1900.
4 What society founded the University of Chicago?	the American Baptist Education Society	1
5 What person helped establish the school with a donation?	John D Rockefeller	1
6 Who was the first president of the University of Chicago?	William Rainey Harper	1
7 What year was the universitys first president given his position?	1891	1
8 What year was the first class taught at the University of Chicago?	1892	1
1 The University of Chicago was created and incorporated as a coeducational secular institution in 1890 by the American Baptist Education Society and a donation from oil magnate and philanthropist John D Rockefeller on land donated by Marshall Field.
2 While the Rockefeller donation provided money for academic operations and longterm endowment it was stipulated that such money could not be used for buildings.
3 The original physical campus was financed by donations from wealthy Chicagoans like Silas B Cobb who provided the funds for the campus first building Cobb Lecture Hall and matched Marshall Fields pledge of 100000.
4 Other early benefactors included businessmen Charles L Hutchinson trustee treasurer and donor of Hutchinson Commons Martin A Ryerson president of the board of trustees and donor of the Ryerson Physical Laboratory Adolphus Clay Bartlett and Leon Mandel who funded the construction of the gymnasium and assembly hall and George C Walker of the Walker Museum a relative of Cobb who encouraged his inaugural donation for facilities.
5 Who donated property to the University of Chicago?	Marshall Field	1
6 Who helped pay for the universitys first building structure?	Silas B Cobb	3
7 What was the name of the first building built on campus grounds?	Cobb Lecture Hall	3
8 How much did Silas B Cobb pledge to the university?	100 000	3
9 What is the name of the donor who helped establish the Hutchinson Commons?	Charles L Hutchinson	4
1 In the 1890s the University of Chicago fearful that its vast resources would injure smaller schools by drawing away good students affiliated with several regional colleges and universities Des Moines College Kalamazoo College Butler University and Stetson University.
2 In 1896 the university affiliated with Shimer College in Mount Carroll Illinois.
3 Under the terms of the affiliation the schools were required to have courses of study comparable to those at the university to notify the university early of any contemplated faculty appointments or dismissals to make no faculty appointment without the universitys approval and to send copies of examinations for suggestions.
4 The University of Chicago agreed to confer a degree on any graduating senior from an affiliated school who made a grade of A for all four years and on any other graduate who took twelve weeks additional study at the University of Chicago.
5 A student or faculty member of an affiliated school was entitled to free tuition at the University of Chicago and Chicago students were eligible to attend an affiliated school on the same terms and receive credit for their work.
6 The University of Chicago also agreed to provide affiliated schools with books and scientific apparatus and supplies at cost special instructors and lecturers without cost except travel expenses and a copy of every book and journal published by the University of Chicago Press at no cost.
7 The agreement provided that either party could terminate the affiliation on proper notice.
8 Several University of Chicago professors disliked the program as it involved uncompensated additional labor on their part and they believed it cheapened the academic reputation of the university.
9 The program passed into history by 1910.
10 In 1890 who did the university decide to team up with?	several regional colleges and universities	1
11 What year did the university team up with Shimer College?	1896	2
12 The university agreed to grant a degree to any graduate of affiliate schoos that did what?	made a grade of A for all four years	4
13 Who disliked the affiliate program?	passed	9
14 In what year did the affiliate program end?	1910	1774
1 In 1929 the universitys fifth president Robert Maynard Hutchins took office the university underwent many changes during his 24year tenure.
2 Hutchins eliminated varsity football from the university in an attempt to emphasize academics over athletics instituted the undergraduate colleges liberalarts curriculum known as the Common Core and organized the universitys graduate work into its currentwhen.
3 four divisions.
4 In 1933 Hutchins proposed an unsuccessful plan to merge the University of Chicago and Northwestern University into a single university.
5 During his term the University of Chicago Hospitals now called the University of Chicago Medical Center finished construction and enrolled its first medical students.
6 Also the Committee on Social Thought an institution distinctive of the university was created.
7 Who was the universitys 5th president?	Robert Maynard Hutchins	1
8 What was the name given to the undergraduate colleges liberalarts curriculum?	the Common Core	2
9 Why did the 5th president of the university decide to get rid of the football program?	to emphasize academics over athletics	2
10 How long did the 5th presidents tenure last?	24year tenure	1
11 In what year was the universitys 5th president granted his position?	1929	1
1 In the early 1950s student applications declined as a result of increasing crime and poverty in the Hyde Park neighborhood.
2 In response the university became a major sponsor of a controversial urban renewal project for Hyde Park which profoundly affected both the neighborhoods architecture and street plan.
3 During this period the university like Shimer College and 10 others adopted an early entrant program that allowed very young students to attend college in addition students enrolled at Shimer were enabled to transfer automatically to the University of Chicago after their second year having taken comparable or identical examinations and courses.
4 In what year did the university first see a drop in applications?	1950s	1
5 Why did the university see a drop in applicants?	a result of increasing crime and poverty	1
6 When were Shimer College students allowed to transfer to the University of Chicago?	after their second year	3
7 The urban renewal project was intended to help the residents of what neighborhood?	Hyde Park	2
8 What did the early entrant program do for potential students?	allowed very young students to attend college	3
1 The university experienced its share of student unrest during the 1960s beginning in 1962 when students occupied President George Beadles office in a protest over the universitys offcampus rental policies.
2 After continued turmoil a university committee in 1967 issued what became known as the Kalven Report.
3 The report a twopage statement of the universitys policy in social and political action declared that To perform its mission in the society a university must sustain an extraordinary environment of freedom of inquiry and maintain an independence from political fashions passions and pressures.
4 The report has since been used to justify decisions such as the universitys refusal to divest from South Africa in the 1980s and Darfur in the late 2000s.
5 In what year did student decide to occupy the presidents office?	1962	1
6 What made the student decide to occupy the presidents office in protest?	the universitys offcampus rental policies	1
7 In what year was the Kalven Report issued?	1967	2
8 How many pages was the Kalven Report statement?	a twopage statement	3
9 What policy did the Kelven Report contain?	social and political action	3
1 From the mid2000s the university began a number of multimilliondollar expansion projects.
2 In 2008 the University of Chicago announced plans to establish the Milton Friedman Institute which attracted both support and controversy from faculty members and students.
3 The institute will cost around 200 million and occupy the buildings of the Chicago Theological Seminary.
4 During the same year investor David G Booth donated 300 million to the universitys Booth School of Business which is the largest gift in the universitys history and the largest gift ever to any business school.
5 In 2009 planning or construction on several new buildings half of which cost 100 million or more was underway.
6 Since 2011 major construction projects have included the Jules and Gwen Knapp Center for Biomedical Discovery a tenstory medical research center and further additions to the medical campus of the University of Chicago Medical Center.
7 In 2014 the University launched the public phase of a 45 billion fundraising campaign.
8 In September 2015 the University received 100 million from The Pearson Family Foundation to establish The Pearson Institute for the Study and Resolution of Global Conflicts and The Pearson Global Forum at the Harris School of Public Policy Studies.
9 When did the university decide to start multimilliondollar expansion projects?	mid2000s	1
10 What institute did the university announced to everyone in 2008?	Milton Friedman Institute	2
11 How much did the Milton Friedman Institute roughly cost?	around 200 million	3
12 What buildings held the Milton Friedman Institute?	the Chicago Theological Seminary	3
13 Who decide to make a very large donation to the universitys Booth School of Business?	David G Booth	4
1 The first buildings of the University of Chicago campus which make up what is now known as the Main Quadrangles were part of a master plan conceived by two University of Chicago trustees and plotted by Chicago architect Henry Ives Cobb.
2 The Main Quadrangles consist of six quadrangles each surrounded by buildings bordering one larger quadrangle.
3 The buildings of the Main Quadrangles were designed by Cobb Shepley Rutan and Coolidge Holabird  Roche and other architectural firms in a mixture of the Victorian Gothic and Collegiate Gothic styles patterned on the colleges of the University of Oxford.
4 Mitchell Tower for example is modeled after Oxfords Magdalen Tower and the university Commons Hutchinson Hall replicates Christ Church Hall.
5 What are the first buildings the university built knows as today?	the Main Quadrangles	1
6 How many quadrangles does the Main Quadrangles have?	six	2
7 Who helped designed the Main Quadrangles?	Cobb  Shepley  Rutan and Coolidge  Holabird  Roche 	3
8 The Mitchell Tower is designed to look like what Oxford tower?	Oxfords Magdalen Tower	4
9 Hutchinson Hall was designed to look like what Oxford hall?	Christ Church Hall	4
1 After the 1940s the Gothic style on campus began to give way to modern styles.
2 In 1955 Eero Saarinen was contracted to develop a second master plan which led to the construction of buildings both north and south of the Midway including the Laird Bell Law Quadrangle a complex designed by Saarinen a series of arts buildings a building designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe for the universitys School of Social Service Administration a building which is to become the home of the Harris School of Public Policy Studies by Edward Durrell Stone and the Regenstein Library the largest building on campus a brutalist structure designed by Walter Netsch of the Chicago firm Skidmore Owings  Merrill.
3 Another master plan designed in 1999 and updated in 2004 produced the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center 2003 the Max Palevsky Residential Commons 2001 South Campus Residence Hall and dining commons 2009 a new childrens hospital and other construction expansions and restorations.
4 In 2011 the university completed the glass domeshaped Joe and Rika Mansueto Library which provides a grand reading room for the university library and prevents the need for an offcampus book depository.
5 During what decade did the campus start to look more modern?	the 1940s	1
6 Who was assigned to design a second master plan?	Eero Saarinen	2
7 What administration did Ludwig Mies van der Rohe designa buiding?	School of Social Service Administration	2
8 What public policy school found its home in the building that Ludwig Mies van der Rohe designed?	Harris School of Public Policy Studies	2
9 When was the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center constructed?	2003	3
1 The University of Chicago also maintains facilities apart from its main campus.
2 The universitys Booth School of Business maintains campuses in Singapore London and the downtown Streeterville neighborhood of Chicago.
3 The Center in Paris a campus located on the left bank of the Seine in Paris hosts various undergraduate and graduate study programs.
4 In fall 2010 the University of Chicago also opened a center in Beijing near Renmin Universitys campus in Haidian District.
5 The most recent additions are a center in New Delhi India which opened in 2014 and a center in Hong Kong which opened in 2015.
6 What other locations can the Booth School of Business be found?	Singapore  London  and the downtown Streeterville neighborhood of Chicago	2
7 The Center in Paris is located near what river?	Seine	3
8 The university established a center in Beijing in what year?	2010	4
9 The universitys center in Beijing is located next to what schools campus?	Renmin University	4
10 What year did the university open a center in Hong Kong?	2015	5
1 The University of Chicago is governed by a board of trustees.
2 The Board of Trustees oversees the longterm development and plans of the university and manages fundraising efforts and is composed of 50 members including the university President.
3 Directly beneath the President are the Provost fourteen Vice Presidents including the Chief Financial Officer Chief Investment Officer and Dean of Students of the university the Directors of Argonne National Laboratory and Fermilab the Secretary of the university and the Student Ombudsperson.
4 As of August 2009update the Chairman of the Board of Trustees is Andrew Alper and the President of the university is Robert Zimmer.
5 In December 2013 it was announced that the Director of Argonne National Laboratory Eric Isaacs would become Provost.
6 Isaacs was replaced as Provost in March 2016 by Daniel Diermeier.
7 Who runs the University of Chicago?	a board of trustees	1
8 How many people belong to the universitys Board of Trustees?	50	2
9 How many Vice Presidents are in the Board of Trustees?	fourteen	3
10 What is the name of the Chairman of the Board of Trustees?	Andrew Alper	4
11 Who took Isaacs place as Provost in 2016?	Robert Zimmer	4
1 The academic bodies of the University of Chicago consist of the College four divisions of graduate research and seven professional schools.
2 The university also contains a library system the University of Chicago Press the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools and the University of Chicago Medical Center and holds ties with a number of independent academic institutions including Fermilab Argonne National Laboratory and the Marine Biological Laboratory.
3 The university is accredited by The Higher Learning Commission.
4 Who is the university accredited by?	The Higher Learning Commission	3
5 The academic body of the university is made up of how many divisions of graduate?	four	1
6 The academic body of the university is made up of how many professional schools?	seven	1
1 The College of the University of Chicago grants Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science degrees in 50 academic majors and 28 minors.
2 The colleges academics are divided into five divisions the Biological Sciences Collegiate Division the Physical Sciences Collegiate Division the Social Sciences Collegiate Division the Humanities Collegiate Division and the New Collegiate Division.
3 The first four are sections within their corresponding graduate divisions while the New Collegiate Division administers interdisciplinary majors and studies which do not fit in one of the other four divisions.
4 How many academic majors does the university grant in total?	50	1
5 How many academic minors does the university grant in total?	28	1
6 How many divisions make up the academics of the university?	five	2
7 What division offers more then one branch of studies that dont fit in with the other four?	the New Collegiate Division	3
1 Undergraduate students are required to take a distribution of courses to satisfy the universitys core curriculum known as the Common Core.
2 In 20122013 the Core classes at Chicago were limited to 17 students and are generally led by a fulltime professor as opposed to a teaching assistant.
3 As of the 2013–2014 school year 15 courses and demonstrated proficiency in a foreign language are required under the Core.
4 Undergraduate courses at the University of Chicago are known for their demanding standards heavy workload and academic difficulty according to Uni in the USA Among the academic cream of American universities – Harvard Yale Princeton MIT and the University of Chicago – it is UChicago that can most convincingly claim to provide the most rigorous intense learning experience.
5 What is the name of the universitys core curriculum?	the Common Core	1
6 During 20122013 how many student were able to take the Core classes at a single time?	17	2
7 UChicago claims to have what kind of learning experience compared to other universities?	the most rigorous  intense	4
8 What guide states the Univeristy of Chicago is known for their heavy workload and academic difficulty?	Uni in the USA	4
1 The university runs a number of academic institutions and programs apart from its undergraduate and postgraduate schools.
2 It operates the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools a private day school for K12 students and day care the Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School a residential treatment program for those with behavioral and emotional problems and four public charter schools on the South Side of Chicago administered by the universitys Urban Education Institute.
3 In addition the Hyde Park Day School a school for students with learning disabilities maintains a location on the University of Chicago campus.
4 Since 1983 the University of Chicago has maintained the University of Chicago School Mathematics Project a mathematics program used in urban primary and secondary schools.
5 The university runs a program called the Council on Advanced Studies in the Social Sciences and Humanities which administers interdisciplinary workshops to provide a forum for graduate students faculty and visiting scholars to present scholarly work in progress.
6 The university also operates the University of Chicago Press the largest university press in the United States.
7 What is the name of the private day school for K12 students the university runs?	University of Chicago Laboratory Schools	2
8 What is the name of the residential treatment program the university runs?	the Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School	2
9 How many public charter schools does the university run?	four	2
10 What does the Urban Education Institute help run?	four public charter schools	2
11 Where is the Hyde Park Day School located?	the University of Chicago campus	3
1 The University of Chicago Library system encompasses six libraries that contain a total of 98 million volumes the 11th most among library systems in the United States.
2 The universitys main library is the Regenstein Library which contains one of the largest collections of print volumes in the United States.
3 The Joe and Rika Mansueto Library built in 2011 houses a large study space and an automatic book storage and retrieval system.
4 The John Crerar Library contains more than 13 million volumes in the biological medical and physical sciences and collections in general science and the philosophy and history of science medicine and technology.
5 The university also operates a number of special libraries including the DAngelo Law Library the Social Service Administration Library and the Eckhart Library for mathematics and computer science which closed temporarily for renovation on July 8 2013.
6 Harper Memorial Library no longer contains any volumes however it is in addition to the Regenstein Library a 24hour study space on campus.
7 The University of Chicago Library system has how many libraries in total?	six	1
8 How man volumes does the The University of Chicago Library system hold?	98 million	1
9 What is the name given to the universitys main library?	the Regenstein Library	2
10 In what year was the Joe and Rika Mansueto Library constructed?	2011	3
11 How many volumes does the John Crerar Library roughly hold?	more than 13 million	4
1 The university operates 12 research institutes and 113 research centers on campus.
2 Among these are the Oriental Institute—a museum and research center for Near Eastern studies owned and operated by the university—and a number of National Resource Centers including the Center for Middle Eastern Studies.
3 Chicago also operates or is affiliated with a number of research institutions apart from the university proper.
4 The university partially manages Argonne National Laboratory part of the United States Department of Energys national laboratory system and has a joint stake in Fermilab a nearby particle physics laboratory as well as a stake in the Apache Point Observatory in Sunspot New Mexico.
5 Faculty and students at the adjacent Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago collaborate with the university In 2013 the university announced that it was affiliating the formerly independent Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole Mass.
6 Although formally unrelated the National Opinion Research Center is located on Chicagos campus.
7 How many research institutes does the university run on campus?	12	1
8 How many research centers does the university run on campus?	113	1
9 What is the name of the museum and research center for Near Eastern studies that is owned by the university?	the Oriental Institute	2
10 What lab does the university have a joint stake in?	Fermilab	4
11 Where is the Apache Point Observatory located?	Sunspot  New Mexico	4
1 The University of Chicago has been the site of some important experiments and academic movements.
2 In economics the university has played an important role in shaping ideas about the free market and is the namesake of the Chicago school of economics the school of economic thought supported by Milton Friedman and other economists.
3 The universitys sociology department was the first independent sociology department in the United States and gave birth to the Chicago school of sociology.
4 In physics the university was the site of the Chicago Pile1 the first selfsustained manmade nuclear reaction part of the Manhattan Project of Robert Millikans oildrop experiment that calculated the charge of the electron and of the development of radiocarbon dating by Willard F Libby in 1947.
5 The chemical experiment that tested how life originated on early Earth the Miller–Urey experiment was conducted at the university.
6 REM sleep was discovered at the university in 1953 by Nathaniel Kleitman and Eugene Aserinsky.
7 What role in economics did the university play a major part in?	shaping ideas about the free market	2
8 What was the name of the first selfsustained manmade nuclear reaction?	Chicago Pile1	4
9 What was the name of the experiment that tested how life originated?	Miller–Urey experiment	5
10 When was REM sleep discovered?	1953	6
1 The UChicago Arts program joins academic departments and programs in the Division of the Humanities and the College as well as professional organizations including the Court Theatre the Oriental Institute the Smart Museum of Art the Renaissance Society University of Chicago Presents and student arts organizations.
2 The university has an artistinresidence program and scholars in performance studies contemporary art criticism and film history.
3 It has offered a doctorate in music composition since 1933 and in Cinema  Media studies since 2000 a master of fine arts in visual arts early 1970s and a master of arts in the humanities with a creative writing track 2000.
4 It has bachelors degree programs in visual arts music and art history and more recently Cinema  Media studies 1996 and theater  performance studies 2002.
5 The Colleges general education core includes a “dramatic music and visual arts” requirement requiring students to study the history of the arts stage desire or begin working with sculpture.
6 Several thousand major and nonmajor undergraduates enroll annually in creative and performing arts classes.
7 UChicago is often considered the birthplace of improvisational comedy as the Compass Players student comedy troupe evolved into The Second City improv theater troupe in 1959.
8 The Reva and David Logan Center for the Arts opened in October 2012 five years after a 35 million gift from alumnus David Logan and his wife Reva.
9 The center includes spaces for exhibitions performances classes and media production.
10 The Logan Center was designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien.
11 This building is actually entirely glass.
12 The brick is a facade designed to keep the glass safe from the wind.
13 The architects later removed sections of the bricks when pressure arose in the form of complaints that the views of the city were blocked.
14 Since what year did the university offer a doctorate in music composition?	1933	3
15 Since what year did the university offer a doctorate in Cinema  Media studies?	2000	3
16 When did the university start having a bachelors degree program in Cinema  Media studies?	1996	4
17 When did the university start having a bachelors degree program in theater  performance studies?	2002	4
18 Around roughly how many students enroll yearly in creative and performing arts classes?	Several thousand	6
1 In the fall quarter of 2014 the University of Chicago enrolled 5792 students in the College 3468 students in its four graduate divisions 5984 students in its professional schools and 15244 students overall.
2 In the 2012 Spring Quarter international students comprised almost 19 of the overall study body over 26 of students were domestic ethnic minorities and about 44 of enrolled students were female.
3 Admissions to the University of Chicago is highly selective.
4 The middle 50 band of SAT scores for the undergraduate class of 2015 excluding the writing section was 1420–1530 the average MCAT score for entering students in the Pritzker School of Medicine in 2011 was 36 and the median LSAT score for entering students in the Law School in 2011 was 171.
5 In 2015 the College of the University of Chicago had an acceptance rate of 78 for the Class of 2019 the lowest in the colleges history.
6 In the fall quarter of 2014 how many students signed up for the college?	5 792	1
7 In the fall quarter of 2014 how many students signed up for the universitys four graduate divisions?	3 468	1
8 In the fall quarter of 2014 how many students signed up for the universitys professional schools?	5 984	1
9 In the fall quarter of 2014 how many students signed up for the universitys  in total?	15 244	1
10 Who made up 19 of the student body in the 2012 Spring Quarter?	international students	2
1 The Maroons compete in the NCAAs Division III as members of the University Athletic Association UAA.
2 The university was a founding member of the Big Ten Conference and participated in the NCAA Division I Mens Basketball and Football and was a regular participant in the Mens Basketball tournament.
3 In 1935 the University of Chicago reached the Sweet Sixteen.
4 In 1935 Chicago Maroons football player Jay Berwanger became the first winner of the Heisman Trophy.
5 However the university chose to withdraw from the conference in 1946 after University President Robert Maynard Hutchins deemphasized varsity athletics in 1939 and dropped football.
6 In 1969 Chicago reinstated football as a Division III team resuming playing its home games at the new Stagg Field.
7 The Maroons are apart of what association?	the University Athletic Association	1
8 The Maroons compete in what league division?	NCAAs Division III	1
9 The university was a founding force behind what conference?	the Big Ten Conference	2
10 What player first won the Heisman Trophy for the university?	Jay Berwanger	4
11 Why did the university eventually leave the conference?	Robert Maynard Hutchins deemphasized varsity athletics	5
1 Students at the University of Chicago run over 400 clubs and organizations known as Recognized Student Organizations RSOs.
2 These include cultural and religious groups academic clubs and teams and commoninterest organizations.
3 Notable extracurricular groups include the University of Chicago College Bowl Team which has won 118 tournaments and 15 national championships leading both categories internationally.
4 The universitys competitive Model United Nations team was the top ranked team in North America in 201314 and 20142015.
5 Among notable RSOs are the nations longest continuously running student film society Doc Films organizing committee for the University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt the twiceweekly student newspaper The Chicago Maroon the alternative weekly student newspaper South Side Weekly the nations second oldest continuously running student improvisational theater troupe OffOff Campus and the universityowned radio station WHPK.
6 Roughly how many clubs are ran at the university?	over 400	1

8 What club won 118 tournaments and 15 national championships?	the University of Chicago College Bowl Team	3

1 All Recognized Student Organizations from the University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt to Model UN in addition to academic teams sports club arts groups and more are funded by The University of Chicago Student Government.
2 Student Government is made up of graduate and undergraduate students elected to represent members from their respective academic unit.
3 It is led by an Executive Committee chaired by a President with the assistance of two Vice Presidents one for Administration and the other for Student Life elected together as a slate by the student body each spring.
4 Its annual budget is greater than 2 million.
5 Who makes up the Student Government?	graduate and undergraduate students	2
6 Who leads the Student Government?	an Executive Committee	3
7 How many vice presidents are on the Student Board?	two	3
8 Roughly how much is the Student Governments budget?	greater than 2 million	4
1 There are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the University of Chicago as well as one coed community service fraternity Alpha Phi Omega.
2 Four of the sororities are members of the National Panhellenic Conference and ten of the fraternities form the University of Chicago Interfraternity Council.
3 In 2002 the Associate Director of Student Activities estimated that 8–10 percent of undergraduates were members of fraternities or sororities.
4 The student activities office has used similar figures stating that one in ten undergraduates participate in Greek life.

1 Every May since 1987 the University of Chicago has held the University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt in which large teams of students compete to obtain notoriously esoteric items from a list.
2 Since 1963 the Festival of the Arts FOTA takes over campus for 7–10 days of exhibitions and interactive artistic endeavors.
3 Every January the university holds a weeklong winter festival KuviasungnerkKangeiko which include early morning exercise routines and fitness workshops.
4 The university also annually holds a summer carnival and concert called Summer Breeze that hosts outside musicians and is home to Doc Films a student film society founded in 1932 that screens films nightly at the university.
5 Since 1946 the university has organized the LatkeHamantash Debate which involves humorous discussions about the relative merits and meanings of latkes and hamantashen.

10 What is the name of the universitys summer festival?	Summer Breeze	4

1 In science alumni include astronomers Carl Sagan a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life and Edwin Hubble known for Hubbles Law NASA astronaut John M Grunsfeld geneticist James Watson best known as one of the codiscoverers of the structure of DNA experimental physicist Luis Alvarez popular environmentalist David Suzuki balloonist Jeannette Piccard biologists Ernest Everett Just and Lynn Margulis computer scientist Richard Hamming the creator of the Hamming Code lithiumion battery developer John B Goodenough mathematician and Fields Medal recipient Paul Joseph Cohen and geochemist Clair Cameron Patterson who developed the uraniumlead dating method into leadlead dating.
