1 The Yuan dynasty Chinese 元朝 pinyin Yuán Cháo officially the Great Yuan Chinese 大元 pinyin Dà Yuán Mongolian Yehe Yuan Ulusa was the empire or ruling dynasty of China established by Kublai Khan leader of the Mongolian Borjigin clan.
2 Although the Mongols had ruled territories including todays North China for decades it was not until 1271 that Kublai Khan officially proclaimed the dynasty in the traditional Chinese style.
3 His realm was by this point isolated from the other khanates and controlled most of presentday China and its surrounding areas including modern Mongolia and Korea.
4 It was the first foreign dynasty to rule all of China and lasted until 1368 after which its Genghisid rulers returned to their Mongolian homeland and continued to rule the Northern Yuan dynasty.
5 Some of the Mongolian Emperors of the Yuan mastered the Chinese language while others only used their native language ie.
6 Mongolian and the Phagspa script.
7 What is the Chinese name for the Yuan dynasty?	Yuán Cháo	1
8 What is the Yuan dynastys official name?	the Great Yuan	1
9 Who started the Yuan dynasty?	Kublai Khan	1
10 Who led the Mongolian Borjigin clan?	Kublai Khan	1
11 When did Khan formally declare the Yuan dynasty?	1271	2
1 The Yuan dynasty is considered both a successor to the Mongol Empire and an imperial Chinese dynasty.
2 It was the khanate ruled by the successors of Möngke Khan after the division of the Mongol Empire.
3 In official Chinese histories the Yuan dynasty bore the Mandate of Heaven following the Song dynasty and preceding the Ming dynasty.
4 The dynasty was established by Kublai Khan yet he placed his grandfather Genghis Khan on the imperial records as the official founder of the dynasty as Taizu.
5 b In the Proclamation of the Dynastic Name 《建國號詔》 Kublai announced the name of the new dynasty as Great Yuan and claimed the succession of former Chinese dynasties from the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors to the Tang dynasty.
6 What nonChinese empire did the Yuan dynasty succeed?	Mongol Empire	1
7 What dynasty came before the Yuan?	Song dynasty	3
8 What dynasty came after the Yuan?	Ming dynasty	3
9 Who was Kublai Khans grandfather?	Genghis Khan	4
1 In 1271 Kublai Khan imposed the name Great Yuan Chinese 大元 pinyin Dà Yuán Wade–Giles TaYüan establishing the Yuan dynasty.
2 Dà Yuán 大元 is from the sentence 大哉乾元 dà zai Qián Yuán  Great is Qián the Primal in the Commentaries on the Classic of Changes I Ching section regarding Qián 乾.
3 The counterpart in Mongolian language was Dai Ön Ulus also rendered as Ikh Yuan Üls or Yekhe Yuan Ulus.
4 In Mongolian Dai Ön Great Yuan is often used in conjunction with the Yeke Mongghul Ulus lit.
5 Great Mongol State resulting in Dai Ön Yeke Mongghul Ulus Mongolian script  meaning Great Yuan Great Mongol State.
6 The Yuan dynasty is also known as the Mongol dynasty or Mongol Dynasty of China similar to the names Manchu dynasty or Manchu Dynasty of China for the Qing dynasty.
7 Furthermore the Yuan is sometimes known as the Empire of the Great Khan or Khanate of the Great Khan which particularly appeared on some Yuan maps since Yuan emperors held the nominal title of Great Khan.
8 Nevertheless both terms can also refer to the khanate within the Mongol Empire directly ruled by Great Khans before the actual establishment of the Yuan dynasty by Kublai Khan in 1271.
9 When did Khan establish the Great Yuan?	1271	1
10 What writing inspired the name Great Yuan?	the Commentaries on the Classic of Changes I Ching	2
11 What was the Yuan dynasty called in Mongolian?	Dai Ön Ulus  also rendered as Ikh Yuan Üls or Yekhe Yuan Ulus	3
12 What does Yeke Mongghul Ulus mean?	Great Mongol State	5
13 What nominal title did Yuan emperors have?	Great Khan	7
1 Genghis Khan united the Mongol and Turkic tribes of the steppes and became Great Khan in 1206.
2 He and his successors expanded the Mongol empire across Asia.
3 Under the reign of Genghis third son Ögedei Khan the Mongols destroyed the weakened Jin dynasty in 1234 conquering most of northern China.
4 Ögedei offered his nephew Kublai a position in Xingzhou Hebei.
5 Kublai was unable to read Chinese but had several Han Chinese teachers attached to him since his early years by his mother Sorghaghtani.
6 He sought the counsel of Chinese Buddhist and Confucian advisers.
7 Möngke Khan succeeded Ögedeis son Güyük as Great Khan in 1251.
8 He granted his brother Kublai control over Mongol held territories in China.
9 Kublai built schools for Confucian scholars issued paper money revived Chinese rituals and endorsed policies that stimulated agricultural and commercial growth.
10 He adopted as his capital city Kaiping in Inner Mongolia later renamed Shangdu.
11 Which tribes did Genghis Khan unite?	Mongol and Turkic tribes	1
12 When did Genghis Khan become Great Khan?	1206	1
13 Who was Genghiss 3rd son?	Ögedei Khan	3
14 When did Mongke Khan become Great Khan?	1251	8
15 What was Kublai Khans relation to Ogedei Khan?	nephew	4
1 Many Han Chinese and Khitan defected to the Mongols to fight against the Jin.
2 Two Han Chinese leaders Shi Tianze Liu Heima 劉黑馬 Liu Ni and the Khitan Xiao Zhala 蕭札剌 defected and commanded the 3 Tumens in the Mongol army.
3 Liu Heima and Shi Tianze served Ogödei Khan.
4 Liu Heima and Shi Tianxiang led armies against Western Xia for the Mongols.
5 There were 4 Han Tumens and 3 Khitan Tumens with each Tumen consisting of 10000 troops.
6 The three Khitan Generals Shimobeidier 石抹孛迭兒 Tabuyir 塔不已兒 and Xiaozhacizhizizhongxi 蕭札刺之子重喜 commanded the three Khitan Tumens and the four Han Generals Zhang Rou Yan Shi Shi Tianze and Liu Heima commanded the four Han tumens under Ogödei Khan.
7 Who did the Han Chinese want to help the Mongols fight?	the Jin	1
8 What Khitan leader defected to the Mongols?	Xiao Zhala	2
9 What Han Chinese leader defected to the Mongols?	Shi Tianze  Liu Heima	2
10 How many soldiers were in each Tumen?	10 000	5
11 How many Khitan Tumens were there?	3	5
1 Shi Tianze was a Han Chinese who lived in the Jin dynasty.
2 Interethnic marriage between Han and Jurchen became common at this time.
3 His father was Shi Bingzhi 史秉直 Shih Pingchih.
4 Shi Bingzhi was married to a Jurchen woman surname Naho and a Han Chinese woman surname Chang it is unknown which of them was Shi Tianzes mother.
5 Shi Tianze was married to two Jurchen women a Han Chinese woman and a Korean woman and his son Shi Gang was born to one of his Jurchen wives.
6 The surnames of his Jurchen wives were Monien and Naho the surname of his Korean wife was Li and the surname of his Han Chinese wife was Shi.
7 Shi Tianze defected to Mongol forces upon their invasion of the Jin dynasty.
8 His son Shi Gang married a Kerait woman the Kerait were Mongolified Turkic people and were considered part of the Mongol nation.
9 Shi Tianze Shih Tientse Zhang Rou Chang Jou 張柔 and Yan Shi Yen Shih 嚴實 and other high ranking Chinese who served in the Jin dynasty and defected to the Mongols helped build the structure for the administration of the new state.
10 Chagaan Tsagaan and Zhang Rou jointly launched an attack on the Song dynasty ordered by Töregene Khatun.
11 What ethnicity was Shi Tianze?	Han Chinese	1
12 In what dynasty did Tianze live?	Jin dynasty	1
13 What kind of interethnic marriage became common in the Jin dynasty?	between Han and Jurchen	2
14 Who was Shi Tianzes father?	Shi Bingzhi	3
15 What dynasty did Zhang Rhou help attack?	Song dynasty	10
1 Möngke Khan commenced a military campaign against the Chinese Song dynasty in southern China.
2 The Mongol force that invaded southern China was far greater than the force they sent to invade the Middle East in 1256.
3 He died in 1259 without a successor.
4 Kublai returned from fighting the Song in 1260 when he learned that his brother Ariq Böke was challenging his claim to the throne.
5 Kublai convened a kurultai in Kaiping that elected him Great Khan.
6 A rival kurultai in Mongolia proclaimed Ariq Böke Great Khan beginning a civil war.
7 Kublai depended on the cooperation of his Chinese subjects to ensure that his army received ample resources.
8 He bolstered his popularity among his subjects by modeling his government on the bureaucracy of traditional Chinese dynasties and adopting the Chinese era name of Zhongtong.
9 Ariq Böke was hampered by inadequate supplies and surrendered in 1264.
10 All of the three western khanates Golden Horde Chagatai Khanate and Ilkhanate became functionally autonomous although only the Ilkhans truly recognized Kublai as Great Khan.
11 Civil strife had permanently divided the Mongol Empire.
12 Who led a Mongol attack on the Song dynasty?	Möngke Khan	1
13 Where did Mongke Khan attack the Song dynasty?	southern China	1
14 When did Mongke Khan die?	1259	3
15 Who challenged Kublai Khans right to succeed Mongke Khan?	Ariq Böke	4
16 What Chinese era name did Kublai adopt?	Zhongtong	8
1 Instability troubled the early years of Kublai Khans reign.
2 Ogedeis grandson Kaidu refused to submit to Kublai and threatened the western frontier of Kublais domain.
3 The hostile but weakened Song dynasty remained an obstacle in the south.
4 Kublai secured the northeast border in 1259 by installing the hostage prince Wonjong as the ruler of Korea making it a Mongol tributary state.
5 Kublai was also threatened by domestic unrest.
6 Li Tan the soninlaw of a powerful official instigated a revolt against Mongol rule in 1262.
7 After successfully suppressing the revolt Kublai curbed the influence of the Han Chinese advisers in his court.
8 He feared that his dependence on Chinese officials left him vulnerable to future revolts and defections to the Song.
9 Who was Kaidus grandfather?	Ogedei	2
10 Where did the Song dynasty continue to cause problems for Kublai?	south	3
11 Who did Kublai make the ruler of Korea?	Wonjong	4
12 Where did Korea border Kublais territory?	northeast	4
13 When did Li Tan lead a revolt?	1262	7
1 Kublais government after 1262 was a compromise between preserving Mongol interests in China and satisfying the demands of his Chinese subjects.
2 He instituted the reforms proposed by his Chinese advisers by centralizing the bureaucracy expanding the circulation of paper money and maintaining the traditional monopolies on salt and iron.
3 He restored the Imperial Secretariat and left the local administrative structure of past Chinese dynasties unchanged.
4 However Kublai rejected plans to revive the Confucian imperial examinations and divided Yuan society into three later four classes with the Han Chinese occupying the lowest rank.
5 Kublais Chinese advisers still wielded significant power in the government but their official rank was nebulous.
6 What did Kublais government have to balance between?	preserving Mongol interests in China and satisfying the demands of his Chinese subjects	1
7 What administrative division did Kublai leave unmodified?	local administrative structure of past Chinese dynasties	3
8 Who would have been the lowestranked class?	Han Chinese	4
9 How many societal class divisions were in the plan Kublai rejected?	three  later four	4
10 What natural resources did the Chinese government have a monopoly on?	salt and iron	2
1 Kublai readied the move of the Mongol capital from Karakorum in Mongolia to Khanbaliq in 1264 constructing a new city near the former Jurchen capital Zhongdu now modern Beijing in 1266.
2 In 1271 Kublai formally claimed the Mandate of Heaven and declared that 1272 was the first year of the Great Yuan Chinese 大元 in the style of a traditional Chinese dynasty.
3 The name of the dynasty originated from the I Ching and describes the origin of the universe or a primal force.
4 Kublai proclaimed Khanbaliq the Great Capital or Daidu Dadu Chinese 大都 in Chinese of the dynasty.
5 The era name was changed to Zhiyuan to herald a new era of Chinese history.
6 The adoption of a dynastic name legitimized Mongol rule by integrating the government into the narrative of traditional Chinese political succession.
7 Khublai evoked his public image as a sage emperor by following the rituals of Confucian propriety and ancestor veneration while simultaneously retaining his roots as a leader from the steppes.
8 Where had the Mongol capital been before Kublai moved it?	Karakorum	1
9 Where did Kublai move the Mongol capital to?	Khanbaliq	1
10 When did Kublai move the Mongol capital?	1264	1
11 What city later became Beijing?	Zhongdu	1
12 What rituals did Kublai follow to help his image?	Confucian propriety and ancestor veneration	7
1 Kublai Khan promoted commercial scientific and cultural growth.
2 He supported the merchants of the Silk Road trade network by protecting the Mongol postal system constructing infrastructure providing loans that financed trade caravans and encouraging the circulation of paper banknotes 鈔 Chao.
3 Pax Mongolica Mongol peace enabled the spread of technologies commodities and culture between China and the West.
4 Kublai expanded the Grand Canal from southern China to Daidu in the north.
5 Mongol rule was cosmopolitan under Kublai Khan.
6 He welcomed foreign visitors to his court such as the Venetian merchant Marco Polo who wrote the most influential European account of Yuan China.
7 Marco Polos travels would later inspire many others like Christopher Columbus to chart a passage to the Far East in search of its legendary wealth.
8 What kinds of growth did Kublai encourage?	commercial  scientific  and cultural	1
9 What does Pax Mongolica mean?	Mongol peace	3
10 Where did the Grand Canal start?	southern China	4
11 Where did Kublai extend the Grand Canal to?	Daidu in the north	4
12 Who described Kublais China to Europe?	Marco Polo	6
1 During the Southern Song dynasty the descendant of Confucius at Qufu the Duke Yansheng Kong Duanyou fled south with the Song Emperor to Quzhou while the newly established Jin dynasty 1115–1234 in the north appointed Kong Duanyous brother Kong Duancao who remained in Qufu as Duke Yansheng.
2 From that time up until the Yuan dynasty there were two Duke Yanshengs once in the north in Qufu and the other in the south at Quzhou.
3 During the Yuan dynasty the Emperor Kublai Khan invited the southern Duke Yansheng Kong Zhu to return to Qufu.
4 Kong Zhu refused and gave up the title so the northern branch of the family kept the title of Duke Yansheng.
5 The southern branch still remained in Quzhou where they lived to this day.
6 Confuciuss descendants in Quzhou alone number 30000.
7 During the Yuan dynasty one of Confucius descendants moved from China to Goryeo era Korea and established a branch of the family there after marrying a Korean woman.
8 Who did Duke Yansheng Kong Duanyou flee with?	the Song Emperor	1
9 When did the Jin dynasty begin?	1115	1
10 When did the Jin dynasty end?	1234	1
11 Who was appointed as the replacement for Duke Yansheng Kong Duanyou?	Kong Duancao	1
12 How many people in Quzhou are descended from Confucius?	30 000	6
1 After strengthening his government in northern China Kublai pursued an expansionist policy in line with the tradition of Mongol and Chinese imperialism.
2 He renewed a massive drive against the Song dynasty to the south.
3 Kublai besieged Xiangyang between 1268 and 1273 the last obstacle in his way to capture the rich Yangzi River basin.
4 An unsuccessful naval expedition was undertaken against Japan in 1274.
5 Kublai captured the Song capital of Hangzhou in 1276 the wealthiest city of China.
6 Song loyalists escaped from the capital and enthroned a young child as Emperor Bing of Song.
7 The Mongols defeated the loyalists at the battle of Yamen in 1279.
8 The last Song emperor drowned bringing an end to the Song dynasty.
9 The conquest of the Song reunited northern and southern China for the first time in three hundred years.
10 Where did Kublai build his administrations strength?	northern China	1
11 When did Kublai attack Xiangyang?	between 1268 and 1273	3
12 What area was Kublai trying to capture by attacking Xiangyang?	Yangzi River basin	3
13 What was the Song dynastys capital?	Hangzhou	5
14 How did the final Song emperor die?	drowned	8
1 Kublais government faced financial difficulties after 1279.
2 Wars and construction projects had drained the Mongol treasury.
3 Efforts to raise and collect tax revenues were plagued by corruption and political scandals.
4 Mishandled military expeditions followed the financial problems.
5 Kublais second invasion of Japan in 1281 failed because of an inauspicious typhoon.
6 Kublai botched his campaigns against Annam Champa and Java but won a Pyrrhic victory against Burma.
7 The expeditions were hampered by disease an inhospitable climate and a tropical terrain unsuitable for the mounted warfare of the Mongols.
8 The Tran dynasty which ruled Annam Dai Viet crushed and defeated the Mongols at the Battle of Bạch Đằng 1288.
9 The Chinese region of Fujian was the original home of the Chinese Tran Chen clan before they migrated under Trần Kinh 陳京 Chén Jīng to Dai Viet and whose descendants established the Trần dynasty which ruled Vietnam Đại Việt and certain members of the clan could still speak Chinese such as when a Yuan dynasty envoy had a meeting with the Chinesespeaking Trần prince Trần Quốc Tuấn later King Trần Hưng Đạo in 1282.
10 Professor Liam Kelley noted that people from Song dynasty China like Zhao Zhong and Xu Zongdao fled to Tran dynasty ruled Vietnam after the Mongol invasion of the Song and they helped the Tran fight against the Mongol invasion.
11 The Tran dynasty originated from the Fujian region of China as did the Daoist cleric Xu Zongdao who recorded the Mongol invasion and referred to them as Northern bandits.
12 Annam Burma and Champa recognized Mongol hegemony and established tributary relations with the Yuan dynasty.
13 When was Kublais administration running out of money?	after 1279	1
14 What interfered with Kublais second invasion of Japan?	an inauspicious typhoon	5
15 Where did the Tran dynasty rule?	Annam Dai Viet	8
16 In what battle were the Mongols defeated by the Tran?	Battle of Bạch Đằng	8
17 When were the Mongols defeated by the Tran?	1288	9
1 Following the conquest of Dali in 1253 the former ruling Duan dynasty were appointed as governorsgeneral recognized as imperial officials by the Yuan Ming and Qingera governments principally in the province of Yunnan.
2 Succession for the Yuan dynasty however was an intractable problem later causing much strife and internal struggle.
3 This emerged as early as the end of Kublais reign.
4 Kublai originally named his eldest son Zhenjin as the Crown Prince but he died before Kublai in 1285.
5 Thus Zhenjins third son with the support of his mother Kökejin and the minister Bayan succeeded the throne and ruled as Temür Khan or Emperor Chengzong from 1294 to 1307.
6 Temür Khan decided to maintain and continue much of the work begun by his grandfather.
7 He also made peace with the western Mongol khanates as well as neighboring countries such as Vietnam which recognized his nominal suzerainty and paid tributes for a few decades.
8 However the corruption in the Yuan dynasty began during the reign of Temür Khan.
9 When was Dali conquered by the Yuan?	1253	1
10 Who had Kublai wanted to succeed him?	his eldest son  Zhenjin	4
11 When did Zhenjin die?	before Kublai in 1285	4
12 What was Temur Khans Chinesestyle name?	Emperor Chengzong	5
13 When did Temur rule?	1294 to 1307	5
1 The fourth Yuan emperor Buyantu Khan Ayurbarwada was a competent emperor.
2 He was the first Yuan emperor to actively support and adopt mainstream Chinese culture after the reign of Kublai to the discontent of some Mongol elite.
3 He had been mentored by Li Meng a Confucian academic.
4 He made many reforms including the liquidation of the Department of State Affairs Chinese 尚書省 which resulted in the execution of five of the highestranking officials.
5 Starting in 1313 the traditional imperial examinations were reintroduced for prospective officials testing their knowledge on significant historical works.
6 Also he codified much of the law as well as publishing or translating a number of Chinese books and works.
7 Who was the 4th to rule the Yuan dynasty?	Buyantu Khan	1
8 What did the Mongol elites wish Buyantu didnt do?	actively support and adopt mainstream Chinese culture	2
9 Who mentored Buyantu?	Li Meng	3
10 What government department did Buyantu shut down?	the Department of State Affairs	4
11 When did Buyantu resume testing potential government employees?	1313	5
1 Emperor Gegeen Khan Ayurbarwadas son and successor ruled for only two years from 1321 to 1323.
2 He continued his fathers policies to reform the government based on the Confucian principles with the help of his newly appointed grand chancellor Baiju.
3 During his reign the Da Yuan Tong Zhi Chinese 大元通制 the comprehensive institutions of the Great Yuan a huge collection of codes and regulations of the Yuan dynasty begun by his father was formally promulgated.
4 Gegeen was assassinated in a coup involving five princes from a rival faction perhaps steppe elite opposed to Confucian reforms.
5 They placed Yesün Temür or Taidingdi on the throne and after an unsuccessful attempt to calm the princes he also succumbed to regicide.
6 Who was Ayurbarwadas son?	Gegeen Khan	1
7 When was Geegen the emperor?	1321 to 1323	1
8 Who did Gegeen appoint as grand chancellor?	Baiju	2
9 What did Da Yuan Tong Zhi mean?	the comprehensive institutions of the Great Yuan	3
10 How many rival princes were involved in assassinating Gegeen?	five	4
1 When Yesün Temür died in Shangdu in 1328 Tugh Temür was recalled to Khanbaliq by the Qipchaq commander El Temür.
2 He was installed as the emperor Emperor Wenzong in Khanbaliq while Yesün Temürs son Ragibagh succeeded to the throne in Shangdu with the support of Yesün Temürs favorite retainer Dawlat Shah.
3 Gaining support from princes and officers in Northern China and some other parts of the dynasty Khanbaliqbased Tugh Temür eventually won the civil war against Ragibagh known as the War of the Two Capitals.
4 Afterwards Tugh Temür abdicated in favour of his brother Kusala who was backed by Chagatai Khan Eljigidey and announced Khanbaliqs intent to welcome him.
5 However Kusala suddenly died only four days after a banquet with Tugh Temür.
6 He was supposedly killed with poison by El Temür and Tugh Temür then remounted the throne.
7 Tugh Temür also managed to send delegates to the western Mongol khanates such as Golden Horde and Ilkhanate to be accepted as the suzerain of Mongol world.
8 However he was mainly a puppet of the powerful official El Temür during his latter threeyear reign.
9 El Temür purged proKusala officials and brought power to warlords whose despotic rule clearly marked the decline of the dynasty.
10 Where did Yesun Temur die?	Shangdu	1
11 What was the civil war against Ragibagh also called?	the War of the Two Capitals	3
12 How long after a banquet with Tugh Temur did Kusala die?	four days	5
13 Who was thought to have killed Tugh Temur?	El Temür	6
14 Who took the throne after Kusalas death?	Tugh Temür	6
1 Due to the fact that the bureaucracy was dominated by El Temür Tugh Temür is known for his cultural contribution instead.
2 He adopted many measures honoring Confucianism and promoting Chinese cultural values.
3 His most concrete effort to patronize Chinese learning was founding the Academy of the Pavilion of the Star of Literature Chinese 奎章閣學士院 first established in the spring of 1329 and designed to undertake a number of tasks relating to the transmission of Confucian high culture to the Mongolian imperial establishment.
4 The academy was responsible for compiling and publishing a number of books but its most important achievement was its compilation of a vast institutional compendium named Jingshi Dadian Chinese 經世大典.
5 Tugh Temür supported Zhu Xis NeoConfucianism and also devoted himself in Buddhism.
6 What was Tugh Temur known for?	his cultural contribution	1
7 What academy did Tugh Temur found?	Academy of the Pavilion of the Star of Literature	3
8 When did Tugh Temur found his academy?	spring of 1329	3
9 What was the most notable publication of Tughs academy?	Jingshi Dadian	4
10 What religions did Tugh Temur follow?	supported Zhu Xis NeoConfucianism and also devoted himself in Buddhism	5
1 After the death of Tugh Temür in 1332 and subsequent death of Rinchinbal Emperor Ningzong the same year the 13yearold Toghun Temür Emperor Huizong the last of the nine successors of Kublai Khan was summoned back from Guangxi and succeeded to the throne.
2 After El Temürs death Bayan became as powerful an official as El Temür had been in the beginning of his long reign.
3 As Toghun Temür grew he came to disapprove of Bayans autocratic rule.
4 In 1340 he allied himself with Bayans nephew Toqtoa who was in discord with Bayan and banished Bayan by coup.
5 With the dismissal of Bayan Toghtogha seized the power of the court.
6 His first administration clearly exhibited fresh new spirit.
7 He also gave a few early signs of a new and positive direction in central government.
8 One of his successful projects was to finish the longstalled official histories of the Liao Jin and Song dynasties which were eventually completed in 1345.
9 Yet Toghtogha resigned his office with the approval of Toghun Temür marking the end of his first administration and he was not called back until 1349.
10 When did Tugh Temur die?	1332	1
11 What Chinesestyle name did Rinchinbal use?	Emperor Ningzong	1
12 How old was Toghun Temur when he became emperor?	13	1
13 How many successors of Kublai was Toghun the last of?	nine	1
14 Which dynasties histories were officially documented during Toghuns reign?	Liao  Jin  and Song	8
1 The final years of the Yuan dynasty were marked by struggle famine and bitterness among the populace.
2 In time Kublai Khans successors lost all influence on other Mongol lands across Asia while the Mongols beyond the Middle Kingdom saw them as too Chinese.
3 Gradually they lost influence in China as well.
4 The reigns of the later Yuan emperors were short and marked by intrigues and rivalries.
5 Uninterested in administration they were separated from both the army and the populace and China was torn by dissension and unrest.
6 Outlaws ravaged the country without interference from the weakening Yuan armies.
7 What problems did the Yuan dynasty have near its end?	struggle  famine  and bitterness	1
8 Why did Kublais successors lose control of the rest of the Mongol empire?	Mongols beyond the Middle Kingdom saw them as too Chinese	2
9 Who were later Yuan emperors isolated from?	both the army and the populace	5
10 What were the Yuan armies too weak to stop?	Outlaws ravaged the country	6
11 What were later Yuan emperors disinterested in?	administration	5
1 From the late 1340s onwards people in the countryside suffered from frequent natural disasters such as droughts floods and the resulting famines and the governments lack of effective policy led to a loss of popular support.
2 In 1351 the Red Turban Rebellion started and grew into a nationwide uprising.
3 In 1354 when Toghtogha led a large army to crush the Red Turban rebels Toghun Temür suddenly dismissed him for fear of betrayal.
4 This resulted in Toghun Temürs restoration of power on the one hand and a rapid weakening of the central government on the other.
5 He had no choice but to rely on local warlords military power and gradually lost his interest in politics and ceased to intervene in political struggles.
6 He fled north to Shangdu from Khanbaliq presentday Beijing in 1368 after the approach of the forces of the Míng dynasty 1368–1644 founded by Zhu Yuanzhang in the south.
7 He had tried to regain Khanbaliq which eventually failed he died in Yingchang located in presentday Inner Mongolia two years later 1370.
8 Yingchang was seized by the Ming shortly after his death.
9 Some royal family members still lived in Henan today.
10 When did the Yuan people suffer a series of natural disasters?	From the late 1340s onwards	1
11 What uprising began in 1351?	the Red Turban Rebellion	2
12 Why did Toghun Temur dismiss Toghtogha?	fear of betrayal	3
13 Who had Toghtogha tried to defeat?	the Red Turban rebels	3
14 When was the Ming dynasty in power?	1368–1644	6
1 A rich cultural diversity developed during the Yuan dynasty.
2 The major cultural achievements were the development of drama and the novel and the increased use of the written vernacular.
3 The political unity of China and much of central Asia promoted trade between East and West.
4 The Mongols extensive West Asian and European contacts produced a fair amount of cultural exchange.
5 The other cultures and peoples in the Mongol World Empire also very much influenced China.
6 It had significantly eased trade and commerce across Asia until its decline the communications between Yuan dynasty and its ally and subordinate in Persia the Ilkhanate encouraged this development.
7 Buddhism had a great influence in the Yuan government and the Tibetanrite Tantric Buddhism had significantly influenced China during this period.
8 The Muslims of the Yuan dynasty introduced Middle Eastern cartography astronomy medicine clothing and diet in East Asia.
9 Eastern crops such as carrots turnips new varieties of lemons eggplants and melons highquality granulated sugar and cotton were all either introduced or successfully popularized during the Yuan dynasty.
10 What encouraged trade under the Yuan?	The political unity of China and much of central Asia	3
11 What encouraged cultural exchange under the Yuan?	The Mongols extensive West Asian and European contacts	4
12 What was the Yuans Persian ally?	the Ilkhanate	6
13 What crops were introduced or popularized in the Yuan?	carrots  turnips  new varieties of lemons  eggplants  and melons  highquality granulated sugar  and cotton	9
1 Western musical instruments were introduced to enrich Chinese performing arts.
2 From this period dates the conversion to Islam by Muslims of Central Asia of growing numbers of Chinese in the northwest and southwest.
3 Nestorianism and Roman Catholicism also enjoyed a period of toleration.
4 Buddhism especially Tibetan Buddhism flourished although Taoism endured certain persecutions in favor of Buddhism from the Yuan government.
5 Confucian governmental practices and examinations based on the Classics which had fallen into disuse in north China during the period of disunity were reinstated by the Yuan court probably in the hope of maintaining order over Han society.
6 Advances were realized in the fields of travel literature cartography geography and scientific education.
7 What type of musical instruments did the Yuan bring to China?	Western	1
8 Besides Confucianism Buddhism and Islam what religions were tolerated during the Yuan?	Nestorianism and Roman Catholicism	3
9 What religion did the Yuan discourage to support Buddhism?	Taoism	4
10 What type of practices did the Yuan reintroduce in government?	Confucian	5
11 What fields of study were advanced during the Yuan?	travel literature  cartography  geography  and scientific education	6
1 The first recorded travels by Europeans to China and back date from this time.
2 The most famous traveler of the period was the Venetian Marco Polo whose account of his trip to Cambaluc the capital of the Great Khan and of life there astounded the people of Europe.
3 The account of his travels Il milione or The Million known in English as the Travels of Marco Polo appeared about the year 1299.
4 Some argue over the accuracy of Marco Polos accounts due to the lack of mentioning the Great Wall of China tea houses which would have been a prominent sight since Europeans had yet to adopt a tea culture as well the practice of foot binding by the women in capital of the Great Khan.
5 Some suggest that Marco Polo acquired much of his knowledge through contact with Persian traders since many of the places he named were in Persian.
6 Who was the first known European to visit China and return?	Marco Polo	2
7 What did Polo call the Yuan capital?	Cambaluc	2
8 What was the English title of Polos book?	Travels of Marco Polo	3
9 What was the Italian title of Polos book?	Il milione	3
10 How did some suspect that Polo learned about China instead of by actually visiting it?	through contact with Persian traders	5
1 The Yuan undertook extensive public works.
2 Among Kublai Khans top engineers and scientists was the astronomer Guo Shoujing who was tasked with many public works projects and helped the Yuan reform the lunisolar calendar to provide an accuracy of 3652425 days of the year which was only 26 seconds off the modern Gregorian calendars measurement.
3 Road and water communications were reorganized and improved.
4 To provide against possible famines granaries were ordered built throughout the empire.
5 The city of Beijing was rebuilt with new palace grounds that included artificial lakes hills and mountains and parks.
6 During the Yuan period Beijing became the terminus of the Grand Canal of China which was completely renovated.
7 These commercially oriented improvements encouraged overland and maritime commerce throughout Asia and facilitated direct Chinese contacts with Europe.
8 Chinese travelers to the West were able to provide assistance in such areas as hydraulic engineering.
9 Contacts with the West also brought the introduction to China of a major food crop sorghum along with other foreign food products and methods of preparation.
10 What astronomer worked for Kublai?	Guo Shoujing	2
11 How accurate did Guo make the reformed lunisolar calendar?	26 seconds off the modern Gregorian calendar	2
12 What did Kublai do to prevent famines?	granaries were ordered built throughout the empire	4
13 What city did the Grand Canal reach during the Yuan?	Beijing	6
14 What major crop was brought to China from the west?	sorghum	9
1 The Yuan dynasty was the first time that nonnative Chinese people ruled all of China.
2 In the historiography of Mongolia it is generally considered to be the continuation of the Mongol Empire.
3 Mongols are widely known to worship the Eternal Heaven and according to the traditional Mongolian ideology Yuan is considered to be the beginning of an infinite number of beings the foundation of peace and happiness state power the dream of many peoples besides it there is nothing great or precious.
4 In traditional historiography of China on the other hand the Yuan dynasty is usually considered to be the legitimate dynasty between the Song dynasty and the Ming dynasty.
5 Note however Yuan dynasty is traditionally often extended to cover the Mongol Empire before Kublai Khans formal establishment of the Yuan in 1271 partly because Kublai had his grandfather Genghis Khan placed on the official record as the founder of the dynasty or Taizu Chinese 太祖.
6 Despite the traditional historiography as well as the official views including the government of the Ming dynasty which overthrew the Yuan dynasty there also exist Chinese peoplewho.
7 who did not consider the Yuan dynasty as a legitimate dynasty of China but rather as a period of foreign domination.
8 The latter believe that Han Chinese were treated as secondclass citizenscitation needed and that China stagnated economically and scientifically.
9 The Yuan was the first time all of China was ruled by whom?	nonnative Chinese people	1
10 What did Mongols worship?	the Eternal Heaven	3
11 What legitimate dynasty came before the Yuan?	Song	4
12 What legitimate dynasty came after the Yuan?	Ming	4
13 Some Chinese considered the Yuan a legitimate dynasty but what did other Chinese think it was?	a period of foreign domination	7
1 The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire including that of the Han Chinese Khitans Jurchens Mongols and Tibetan Buddhists.
2 While the official terminology of the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely that of native Chinese dynasties the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted of a mix of elements from different cultures.
3 The Chinesestyle elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang Song as well as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties.
4 Chinese advisers such as Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to Kublais early court and the central government administration was established within the first decade of Kublais reign.
5 This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil military and censorial offices including the Central Secretariat Zhongshu Sheng to manage civil affairs the Privy Council Chinese 樞密院 to manage military affairs and the Censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection.
6 The actual functions of both central and local government institutions however showed a major overlap between the civil and military jurisdictions due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance.
7 Nevertheless such a civilian bureaucracy with the Central Secretariat as the top institution that was directly or indirectly responsible for most other governmental agencies such as the traditional Chinesestyle Six Ministries was created in China.
8 At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs Shangshu Sheng that mainly dealt with finance was established such as during the reign of Külüg Khan or Emperor Wuzong but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.
9 What cultures were part of Kublais administration?	Han Chinese  Khitans  Jurchens  Mongols  and Tibetan Buddhists	1
10 What dynasties inspired the Chineselike elements of Kublais government?	Tang  Song  as well as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties	3
11 Who were two of Kublais Chinese advisers?	Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu	4
12 What kind of division of power did Kublais government have?	tripartite	5
13 What were the three parts of Kublais government?	civil  military  and censorial offices	5
1 While the existence of these central government departments and the Six Ministries which had been introduced since the Sui and Tang dynasties gave a Sinicized image in the Yuan administration the actual functions of these ministries also reflected how Mongolian priorities and policies reshaped and redirected those institutions.
2 For example the authority of the Yuan legal system the Ministry of Justice did not extend to legal cases involving Mongols and Semuren who had separate courts of justice.
3 Cases involving members of more than one ethnic group were decided by a mixed board consisting of Chinese and Mongols.
4 Another example was the insignificance of the Ministry of War compared with native Chinese dynasties as the real military authority in Yuan times resided in the Privy Council.
5 Who had military control during the Yuan?	the Privy Council	4
6 When had the Six Ministries existed?	since the Sui and Tang dynasties	1
7 Who were exempt from the Ministry of Justice?	Mongols and Semuren	2
8 Who had no real military power during the Yuan?	the Ministry of War	4
1 Since its invention in 1269 the Phagspa script a unified script for spelling Mongolian Tibetan and Chinese languages was preserved in the court until the end of the dynasty.
2 Most of the Emperors could not master written Chinese but they could generally converse well in the language.
3 The Mongol custom of long standing qudamarriage alliance with Mongol clans the Onggirat and the Ikeres kept the imperial blood purely Mongol until the reign of Tugh Temur whose mother was a Tangut concubine.
4 The Mongol Emperors had built large palaces and pavilions but some still continued to live as nomads at times.
5 Nevertheless a few other Yuan emperors actively sponsored cultural activities an example is Tugh Temur Emperor Wenzong who wrote poetry painted read Chinese classical texts and ordered the compilation of books.
6 When was Phagspa script invented?	1269	1
7 Which languages used the Phagspa script?	Mongolian  Tibetan  and Chinese	1
8 How well did the Mongol Emperors know Chinese?	could not master written Chinese  but they could generally converse well	2
9 The mother of which emperor was a concubine?	Tugh Temur	3
10 What was Tughs Chinesestyle name?	Emperor Wenzong	5
1 The average Mongol garrison family of the Yuan dynasty seems to have lived a life of decaying rural leisure with income from the harvests of their Chinese tenants eaten up by costs of equipping and dispatching men for their tours of duty.
2 The Mongols practiced debt slavery and by 1290 in all parts of the Mongol Empire commoners were selling their children into slavery.
3 Seeing this as damaging to the Mongol nation Kublai in 1291 forbade the sale abroad of Mongols.
4 Kublai wished to persuade the Chinese that he was becoming increasingly sinicized while maintaining his Mongolian credentials with his own people.
5 He set up a civilian administration to rule built a capital within China supported Chinese religions and culture and devised suitable economic and political institutions for the court.
6 But at the same time he never abandoned his Mongolian heritage.
7 By what year was selling children into slavery common among the Mongols?	1290	2
8 When did Kublai ban the international Mongol slave trade?	1291	3
9 How were the Mongol garrison families earning money?	income from the harvests of their Chinese tenants	1
1 In the China of the Yuan or Mongol era various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development including the areas of painting mathematics calligraphy poetry and theater with many great artists and writers being famous today.
2 Due to the coming together of painting poetry and calligraphy at this time many of the artists practicing these different pursuits were the same individuals though perhaps more famed for one area of their achievements than others.
3 Often in terms of the further development of landscape painting as well as the classical joining together of the arts of painting poetry and calligraphy the Song dynasty and the Yuan dynasty are linked together.
4 In the area of Chinese painting during the Yuan dynasty there were many famous painters.
5 In the area of calligraphy many of the great calligraphers were from the Yuan dynasty era.
6 In Yuan poetry the main development was the qu which was used among other poetic forms by most of the famous Yuan poets.
7 Many of the poets were also involved in the major developments in the theater during this time and the other way around with people important in the theater becoming famous through the development of the sanqu type of qu.
8 One of the key factors in the mix of the zaju variety show was the incorporation of poetry both classical and of the newer qu form.
9 One of the important cultural developments during the Yuan era was the consolidation of poetry painting and calligraphy into a unified piece of the type that tends to come to mind when people think of classical Chinese art.
10 Another important aspect of Yuan times is the increasing incorporation of the then current vernacular Chinese into both the qu form of poetry and the zaju variety show.
11 Another important consideration regarding Yuan dynasty arts and culture is that so much of it has survived in China relatively to works from the Tang dynasty and Song dynasty which have often been better preserved in places such as the Shōsōin in Japan.
12 What type of arts flourished in the Yuan?	painting  mathematics  calligraphy  poetry  and theater	1
13 Which arts were often practiced together by the same artists?	painting  poetry  and calligraphy	2
14 What dynasty shared artistic inspiration with the Yuan?	Song	3
15 What form of poetry was developed in the Yuan?	the qu	6
16 What was a popular type of variety show during the Yuan?	zaju	8
1 There were many religions practiced during the Yuan dynasty such as Buddhism Islam and Christianity.
2 The establishment of the Yuan dynasty had dramatically increased the number of Muslims in China.
3 However unlike the western khanates the Yuan dynasty never converted to Islam.
4 Instead Kublai Khan the founder of the Yuan dynasty favored Buddhism especially the Tibetan variants.
5 As a result Tibetan Buddhism was established as the de facto state religion.
6 The toplevel department and government agency known as the Bureau of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs Xuanzheng Yuan was set up in Khanbaliq modern Beijing to supervise Buddhist monks throughout the empire.
7 Since Kublai Khan only esteemed the Sakya sect of Tibetan Buddhism other religions became less important.
8 He and his successors kept a Sakya Imperial Preceptor Dishi at court.
9 Before the end of the Yuan dynasty 14 leaders of the Sakya sect had held the post of Imperial Preceptor thereby enjoying special power.
10 Furthermore Mongol patronage of Buddhism resulted in a number of monuments of Buddhist art.
11 Mongolian Buddhist translations almost all from Tibetan originals began on a large scale after 1300.
12 Many Mongols of the upper class such as the Jalayir and the Oronar nobles as well as the emperors also patronized Confucian scholars and institutions.
13 A considerable number of Confucian and Chinese historical works were translated into the Mongolian language.
14 Which khanates had converted to Islam?	western	3
15 Which religion did Kublai prefer?	Buddhism  especially the Tibetan variants	4
16 What was the Yuans unofficial state religion?	Tibetan Buddhism	5
17 What government agency supervised Buddhist monks?	Bureau of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs	6
18 What was Kublais favorite sect of Tibetan Buddhism?	Sakya	7
1 Advances in polynomial algebra were made by mathematicians during the Yuan era.
2 The mathematician Zhu Shijie 1249–1314 solved simultaneous equations with up to four unknowns using a rectangular array of coefficients equivalent to modern matrices.
3 Zhu used a method of elimination to reduce the simultaneous equations to a single equation with only one unknown.
4 His method is described in the Jade Mirror of the Four Unknowns written in 1303.
5 The opening pages contain a diagram of Pascals triangle.
6 The summation of a finite arithmetic series is also covered in the book.
7 When was Zhu Shijie born?	1249	2
8 When did Zhu Shijie die?	1314	2
9 What modern math concept did Zhu Shijie do work similar to?	matrices	2
10 What type of math was advanced during the Yuan?	polynomial algebra	1
11 When did Zhu publish Jade Mirror of the Four Unknowns?	1303	4
1 Guo Shoujing applied mathematics to the construction of calendars.
2 He was one of the first mathematicians in China to work on spherical trigonometry.
3 Gou derived a cubic interpolation formula for his astronomical calculations.
4 His calendar the Shoushi Li 授時暦 or Calendar for Fixing the Seasons was disseminated in 1281 as the official calendar of the Yuan dynasty.
5 The calendar may have been influenced solely by the work of Song dynasty astronomer Shen Kuo or possibly by the work of Arab astronomers.
6 There are no explicit signs of Muslim influences in the Shoushi calendar but Mongol rulers were known to be interested in Muslim calendars.
7 Mathematical knowledge from the Middle East was introduced to China under the Mongols and Muslim astronomers brought Arabic numerals to China in the 13th century.
8 What did Guo Shoujing do for calendars?	applied mathematics to the construction of calendars	1
9 What did Gou use for astronomy?	a cubic interpolation formula	3
10 What was the Chinese name of Gous calendar?	Shoushi Li	4
11 What was the English name of Gous calendar?	Calendar for Fixing the Seasons	4
12 When did Gous calendar become the official calendar of the Yuan?	1281	4
1 The physicians of the Yuan court came from diverse cultures.
2 Healers were divided into nonMongol physicians called otachi and traditional Mongol shamans.
3 The Mongols characterized otachi doctors by their use of herbal remedies which was distinguished from the spiritual cures of Mongol shamanism.
4 Physicians received official support from the Yuan government and were given special legal privileges.
5 Kublai created the Imperial Academy of Medicine to manage medical treatises and the education of new doctors.
6 Confucian scholars were attracted to the medical profession because it ensured a high income and medical ethics were compatible with Confucian virtues.
7 Who were otachi?	nonMongol physicians	2
8 What type of medicine did otachi focus on?	herbal remedies	3
9 What type of medicine did Mongol shamans use?	spiritual cures	3
10 What department did Kublai create to train doctors?	Imperial Academy of Medicine	5
11 Why did Confucians like the medical field?	it ensured a high income and medical ethics were compatible with Confucian virtues	6
1 The Chinese medical tradition of the Yuan had Four Great Schools that the Yuan inherited from the Jin dynasty.
2 All four schools were based on the same intellectual foundation but advocated different theoretical approaches toward medicine.
3 Under the Mongols the practice of Chinese medicine spread to other parts of the empire.
4 Chinese physicians were brought along military campaigns by the Mongols as they expanded towards the west.
5 Chinese medical techniques such as acupuncture moxibustion pulse diagnosis and various herbal drugs and elixirs were transmitted westward to the Middle East and the rest of the empire.
6 Several medical advances were made in the Yuan period.
7 The physician Wei Yilin 1277–1347 invented a suspension method for reducing dislocated joints which he performed using anesthetics.
8 The Mongol physician Hu Sihui described the importance of a healthy diet in a 1330 medical treatise.
9 How many schools of medicine were recognized in China?	four	2
10 How did the Yuan come to have the 4 schools of medicine?	inherited from the Jin dynasty	1
11 How did Chinese medicine spread?	Chinese physicians were brought along military campaigns by the Mongols	4
12 What techniques did Chinese medicine include?	acupuncture  moxibustion  pulse diagnosis  and various herbal drugs and elixirs	5
13 When did Wei Yilin die?	1347	7
1 Western medicine was also practiced in China by the Nestorian Christians of the Yuan court where it was sometimes labeled as huihui or Muslim medicine.
2 The Nestorian physician Jesus the Interpreter founded the Office of Western Medicine in 1263 during the reign of Kublai.
3 Huihui doctors staffed at two imperial hospitals were responsible for treating the imperial family and members of the court.
4 Chinese physicians opposed Western medicine because its humoral system contradicted the yinyang and wuxing philosophy underlying traditional Chinese medicine.
5 No Chinese translation of Western medical works is known but it is possible that the Chinese had access to Avicennas The Canon of Medicine.
6 What was huihui?	Muslim medicine	1
7 Who founded the Office of Western Medicine?	Jesus the Interpreter	2
8 When was the Office of Western Medicine founded?	1263	2
9 What aspect of Western medicine did the Chinese dislike?	its humoral system	4
10 What philosophies underlay Chinese medicine?	yinyang and wuxing	4
1 The Mongol rulers patronized the Yuan printing industry.
2 Chinese printing technology was transferred to the Mongols through Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries.
3 Some Yuan documents such as Wang Zhens Nong Shu were printed with earthenware movable type a technology invented in the 12th century.
4 However most published works were still produced through traditional block printing techniques.
5 The publication of a Taoist text inscribed with the name of Töregene Khatun Ögedeis wife is one of the first printed works sponsored by the Mongols.
6 In 1273 the Mongols created the Imperial Library Directorate a governmentsponsored printing office.
7 The Yuan government established centers for printing throughout China.
8 Local schools and government agencies were funded to support the publishing of books.
9 How did the Mongols acquire Chinese printing technology?	through Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries	2
10 Who wrote the Nong Shu?	Wang Zhen	3
11 When was earthenware movable type invented?	in the 12th century	3
12 Who was Ogedeis wife?	Töregene Khatun	5
13 When was the Imperial Library Directorate established?	1273	6
1 One of the more notable applications of printing technology was the chao the paper money of the Yuan.
2 Chao were made from the bark of mulberry trees.
3 The Yuan government used woodblocks to print paper money but switched to bronze plates in 1275.
4 The Mongols experimented with establishing the Chinesestyle paper monetary system in Mongolcontrolled territories outside of China.
5 The Yuan minister Bolad was sent to Iran where he explained Yuan paper money to the Ilkhanate court of Gaykhatu.
6 The Ilkhanate government issued paper money in 1294 but public distrust of the exotic new currency doomed the experiment.
7 What was the Yuans paper money called?	chao	1
8 What were chao made out of?	bark of mulberry trees	2
9 When did the Yuan begin using bronze printing plates for its money?	1275	3
10 What had the Yuan used to print its money before bronze plates?	woodblocks	3
11 When did the Ilkhanate experiment with paper money?	1294	6
1 Politically the system of government created by Kublai Khan was the product of a compromise between Mongolian patrimonial feudalism and the traditional Chinese autocraticbureaucratic system.
2 Nevertheless socially the educated Chinese elite were in general not given the degree of esteem that they had been accorded previously under native Chinese dynasties.
3 Although the traditional Chinese elite were not given their share of power the Mongols and the Semuren various allied groups from Central Asia and the western end of the empire largely remained strangers to the mainstream Chinese culture and this dichotomy gave the Yuan regime a somewhat strong colonial coloration.
4 The unequal treatment is possibly due to the fear of transferring power to the ethnic Chinese under their rule.
5 The Mongols and Semuren were given certain advantages in the dynasty and this would last even after the restoration of the imperial examination in the early 14th century.
6 In general there were very few North Chinese or Southerners reaching the highestpost in the government compared with the possibility that Persians did so in the Ilkhanate.
7 Later the Yongle Emperor of the Ming dynasty also mentioned the discrimination that existed during the Yuan dynasty.
8 In response to an objection against the use of barbarians in his government the Yongle Emperor answered .
9 Discrimination was used by the Mongols during the Yuan dynasty who employed only Mongols and Tartars and discarded northern and southern Chinese and this was precisely the cause that brought disaster upon them.
10 What Mongolian system did Kublais government compromise with?	patrimonial feudalism	1
11 What Chinese system did Kublais government compromise with?	traditional Chinese autocraticbureaucratic system	1
12 Who were the Semuren?	allied groups from Central Asia and the western end of the empire	3
13 How did the unequal treatment of Chinese versus Mongols in the Yuan make the dynasty seem?	colonial	3
14 Where were Persians more successful compared to Chinese in the Yuan?	Ilkhanate	6
1 At the same time the Mongols imported Central Asian Muslims to serve as administrators in China the Mongols also sent Han Chinese and Khitans from China to serve as administrators over the Muslim population in Bukhara in Central Asia using foreigners to curtail the power of the local peoples of both lands.
2 Han Chinese were moved to Central Asian areas like Besh Baliq Almaliq and Samarqand by the Mongols where they worked as artisans and farmers.
3 Alans were recruited into the Mongol forces with one unit called Right Alan Guard which was combined with recently surrendered soldiers Mongols and Chinese soldiers stationed in the area of the former Kingdom of Qocho and in Besh Balikh the Mongols established a Chinese military colony led by Chinese general Qi Kongzhi Chi Kungchih.
4 After the Mongol conquest of Central Asia by Genghis Khan foreigners were chosen as administrators and comanagement with Chinese and QaraKhitays Khitans of gardens and fields in Samarqand was put upon the Muslims as a requirement since Muslims were not allowed to manage without them.
5 The Mongol appointed Governor of Samarqand was a QaraKhitay Khitan held the title Taishi familiar with Chinese culture his name was Ahai.
6 Who did the Mongols bring to China as administrators?	Central Asian Muslims	1
7 Who did the Mongols send to Bukhara as administrators?	Han Chinese and Khitans	1
8 Where in Central Asia did the Han Chinese move?	Besh Baliq  Almaliq  and Samarqand	2
9 What types of work did the Han do in Central Asia?	artisans and farmers	2
10 Who was made Governor of Samarqand?	a QaraKhitay Khitan	5
1 Despite the high position given to Muslims some policies of the Yuan Emperors severely discriminated against them restricting Halal slaughter and other Islamic practices like circumcision as well as Kosher butchering for Jews forcing them to eat food the Mongol way.
2 Toward the end corruption and the persecution became so severe that Muslim generals joined Han Chinese in rebelling against the Mongols.
3 The Ming founder Zhu Yuanzhang had Muslim generals like Lan Yu who rebelled against the Mongols and defeated them in combat.
4 Some Muslim communities had a Chinese surname which meant barracks and could also mean thanks.
5 Many Hui Muslims claim this is because that they played an important role in overthrowing the Mongols and it was given in thanks by the Han Chinese for assisting them.
6 During the war fighting the Mongols among the Ming Emperor Zhu Yuanzhangs armies was the Hui Muslim Feng Sheng.
7 The Muslims in the semu class also revolted against the Yuan dynasty in the Ispah Rebellion but the rebellion was crushed and the Muslims were massacred by the Yuan loyalist commander Chen Youding.
8 What Yuan policies did Muslims dislike?	restricting Halal slaughter and other Islamic practices like circumcision	1
9 What Jewish practice did the Yuan ban?	Kosher butchering	1
10 Who founded the Ming dynasty?	Zhu Yuanzhang	3
11 What was the second meaning of a Chinese word for barracks?	thanks	4
12 Who revolted in the Ispah Rebellion?	Muslims in the semu class	7
1 The historian Frederick W Mote wrote that the usage of the term social classes for this system was misleading and that the position of people within the fourclass system was not an indication of their actual social power and wealth but just entailed degrees of privilege to which they were entitled institutionally and legally so a persons standing within the classes was not a guarantee of their standing since there were rich and well socially standing Chinese while there were less rich Mongol and Semu than there were Mongol and Semu who lived in poverty and were ill treated.
2 Who thought that the Yuans social class system shouldnt be called social classes?	Frederick W Mote	1
3 What did Mote think the Yuan class system really represented?	degrees of privilege	1
4 There were many Chinese with what unexpected status?	rich and well socially standing	1
5 There were many Mongols with what unexpected status?	lived in poverty and were ill treated	1
1 The reason for the order of the classes and the reason why people were placed in a certain class was the date they surrendered to the Mongols and had nothing to do with their ethnicity.
2 The earlier they surrendered to the Mongols the higher they were placed the more the held out the lower they were ranked.
3 The Northern Chinese were ranked higher and Southern Chinese were ranked lower because southern China withstood and fought to the last before caving in.
4 Major commerce during this era gave rise to favorable conditions for private southern Chinese manufacturers and merchants.
5 Which part of China had people ranked higher in the class system?	Northern	3
6 Which part of China had people ranked lower in the class system?	Southern	3
7 Why were Southern Chinese ranked lower?	southern China withstood and fought to the last	3
8 Why were Northern Chinese ranked higher?	The earlier they surrendered to the Mongols  the higher they were placed	2
9 Who did the Yuans increase in commerce help?	private southern Chinese manufacturers and merchants	4
1 When the Mongols placed the Uighurs of the Kingdom of Qocho over the Koreans at the court the Korean King objected then the Mongol Emperor Kublai Khan rebuked the Korean King saying that the Uighur King of Qocho was ranked higher than the Karluk KaraKhanid ruler who in turn was ranked higher than the Korean King who was ranked last because the Uighurs surrendered to the Mongols first the Karluks surrendered after the Uighurs and the Koreans surrendered last and that the Uighurs surrendered peacefully without violently resisting.
