1 The Central Region consisting of presentday Hebei Shandong Shanxi the southeastern part of presentday Inner Mongolia and the Henan areas to the north of the Yellow River was considered the most important region of the dynasty and directly governed by the Central Secretariat or Zhongshu Sheng at Khanbaliq modern Beijing similarly another toplevel administrative department called the Bureau of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs or Xuanzheng Yuan held administrative rule over the whole of modernday Tibet and a part of Sichuan Qinghai and Kashmir.
2 What region of China is Hebei part of?	The Central Region	1
3 Who governed the Central Region in the Yuan?	the Central Secretariat	1
4 Where was the Central Secretariat based?	Khanbaliq	1
5 What modern city did Khanbaliq become?	Beijing	1
6 What was the Chinese name for the Central Secretariat?	Zhongshu Sheng	1
1 Kenya ˈkɛnjə locally ˈkɛɲa  listen officially the Republic of Kenya is a country in Africa and a founding member of the East African Community EAC.
2 Its capital and largest city is Nairobi.
3 Kenyas territory lies on the equator and overlies the East African Rift covering a diverse and expansive terrain that extends roughly from Lake Victoria to Lake Turkana formerly called Lake Rudolf and further southeast to the Indian Ocean.
4 It is bordered by Tanzania to the south Uganda to the west South Sudan to the northwest Ethiopia to the north and Somalia to the northeast.
5 Kenya covers 581309 km2 224445 sq mi and had a population of approximately 45 million people in July 2014.
6 Where is Kenya located?	in Africa	1
7 What is Kenya a founding member of?	East African Community	1
8 What is the capitol of Kenya?	Nairobi	2
9 What country boarders the south of Kenya?	Tanzania	4
10 What was the population of Kenya in 2014?	45 million people	5
1 Kenya has a warm and humid tropical climate on its Indian Ocean coastline.
2 The climate is cooler in the savannah grasslands around the capital city Nairobi and especially closer to Mount Kenya which has snow permanently on its peaks.
3 Further inland in the Nyanza region there is a hot and dry climate which becomes humid around Lake Victoria the largest tropical freshwater lake in the world.
4 This gives way to temperate and forested hilly areas in the neighboring western region.
5 The northeastern regions along the border with Somalia and Ethiopia are arid and semiarid areas with neardesert landscapes.
6 Kenya is known for its safaris diverse climate and geography and expansive wildlife reserves and national parks such as the East and West Tsavo National Park the Maasai Mara Lake Nakuru National Park and Aberdares National Park.
7 Kenya has several world heritage sites such as Lamu and numerous beaches including in Diani Bamburi and Kilifi where international yachting competitions are held every year.
8 What type of climate does Kenya have?	a warm and humid tropical climate on its Indian Ocean coastline	1
9 How is the climate near the savannah grasslands?	The climate is cooler	2
10 What mountain has snow on it all year round?	Mount Kenya	2
11 What regions do the northeastern part of the country boarder?	Somalia and Ethiopia	5
12 What is Kenya known for?	its safaris  diverse climate and geography  and expansive wildlife reserves and national parks	6
1 The African Great Lakes region which Kenya is a part of has been inhabited by humans since the Lower Paleolithic period.
2 By the first millennium AD the Bantu expansion had reached the area from WestCentral Africa.
3 The borders of the modern state consequently comprise the crossroads of the NigerCongo NiloSaharan and Afroasiatic areas of the continent representing most major ethnolinguistic groups found in Africa.
4 Bantu and Nilotic populations together constitute around 97 of the nations residents.
5 European and Arab presence in coastal Mombasa dates to the Early Modern period European exploration of the interior began in the 19th century.
6 The British Empire established the East Africa Protectorate in 1895 which starting in 1920 gave way to the Kenya Colony.
7 Kenya obtained independence in December 1963.
8 Following a referendum in August 2010 and adoption of a new constitution Kenya is now divided into 47 semiautonomous counties governed by elected governors.
9 How long has the African Great Lakes region been inhabited?	Lower Paleolithic period	1
10 When did the Bantu expansion reach the area from WestCentral Africa?	By the first millennium AD	2
11 Where is 97 of the population located?	Bantu and Nilotic	4
12 When did the exploration of the interior begin?	19th century	5
13 When did Kenya obtain independence?	December 1963	7
1 The Republic of Kenya is named after Mount Kenya.
2 The origin of the name Kenya is not clear but perhaps linked to the Kikuyu Embu and Kamba words Kirinyaga Kirenyaa and Kiinyaa which mean Gods resting place in all three languages.
3 If so then the British may not so much have mispronounced it Keenya as misspelled it.
4 Prehistoric volcanic eruptions of Mount Kenya now extinct may have resulted in its association with divinity and creation among the indigenous Bantu ethnic groups who are the native inhabitants of the agricultural land surrounding Mount Kenya.
5 original research.
6 What is the Republic of Kenya named after?	Mount Kenya	1
7 What words to they think are linked to the work Kenya?	Kirinyaga  Kirenyaa and Kiinyaa	2
8 What do the words Kirinyaga Kirenyaa and Kiinyaa mean?	Gods resting place	2
1 Ludwig Krapf recorded the name as both Kenia and Kegnia believed by most to be a corruption of the Kamba version.
2 Others say that this was—on the contrary—a very precise notation of a correct African pronunciation ˈkɛnjə.
3 An 1882 map drawn by Joseph Thompsons a Scottish geologist and naturalist indicated Mt.
4 Kenya as Mt.
5 Kenia 1862.
6 Controversy over the actual meaning of the word Kenya notwithstanding it is clear that the mountains name became widely accepted pars pro toto as the name of the country.
7 Ludwig Krapf recorded the name was what?	both Kenia and Kegnia	1
8 What do some believe about this pronunciation?	a very precise notation of a correct African pronunciation	2
9 Who was the Scottish geologist that named Mt Kenya as Mt Kenia?	Joseph Thompsons	3
10 What year did Thompsons indicate Mt Kenya?	1862	5
1 The Big Five game animals of Africa that is the lion leopard buffalo rhinoceros and elephant can be found in Kenya and in the Masai Mara in particular.
2 A significant population of other wild animals reptiles and birds can be found in the national parks and game reserves in the country.
3 The annual animal migration occurs between June and September with millions of animals taking part attracting valuable foreign tourism.
4 Two million wildebeest migrate a distance of 2900 kilometres 1802 mi from the Serengeti in neighbouring Tanzania to the Masai Mara in Kenya in a constant clockwise fashion searching for food and water supplies.
5 This Serengeti Migration of the wildebeest is a curious spectacle listed among the 10 Natural Wonders of Africa.
6 What are the biggest game animals of Kenya called?	The Big Five	1
7 What are the Big Five animals in Kenya?	lion  leopard  buffalo  rhinoceros  and elephant	1
8 Where are these animals mostly located?	Masai Mara	1
9 When does the annual animal migration occur?	between June and September	3
10 How far do the wildebeest migrate searching for food and water?	2 900 kilometres 1 802 mi	4
1 Fossils found in Kenya suggest that primates roamed the area more than 20 million years ago.
2 Recent findings near Lake Turkana indicate that hominids such as Homo habilis 18 and 25 million years ago and Homo erectus 18 million to 350000 years ago are possible direct ancestors of modern Homo sapiens and lived in Kenya in the Pleistocene epoch.
3 During excavations at Lake Turkana in 1984 paleoanthropologist Richard Leakey assisted by Kamoya Kimeu discovered the Turkana Boy a 16millionyearold fossil belonging to Homo erectus.
4 Previous research on early hominids is particularly identified with Mary Leakey and Louis Leakey who were responsible for the preliminary archaeological research at Olorgesailie and Hyrax Hill.
5 Later work at the former site was undertaken by Glynn Isaac.
6 How long ago did primates inhabit Kenya?	more than 20 million years ago	1
7 When did the ancestors of modern Homo sapiens inhabit Kenya?	in the Pleistocene epoch	2
8 Who helped discover the Turkana Boy?	Richard Leakey	3
9 How old was Turkana Boy?	6millionyearold	3
10 Who was responsible for the preliminary archaeological research at Ologesailie and Hyrax Hill?	Mary Leakey and Louis Leakey	4
1 The Swahili built Mombasa into a major port city and established trade links with other nearby citystates as well as commercial centres in Persia Arabia and even India.
2 By the 15thcentury Portuguese voyager Duarte Barbosa claimed that Mombasa is a place of great traffic and has a good harbour in which there are always moored small craft of many kinds and also great ships both of which are bound from Sofala and others which come from Cambay and Melinde and others which sail to the island of Zanzibar.
3 Who build the major port city in Kenya?	The Swahili	1
4 What is the name of the port city that was created?	Mombasa	1
5 What voyager said that Mombasa was a great harbour and moored small crafts and great ships?	Duarte Barbosa	2
1 Throughout the centuries the Kenyan Coast has played host to many merchants and explorers.
2 Among the cities that line the Kenyan coast is the City of Malindi.
3 It has remained an important Swahili settlement since the 14th century and once rivalled Mombasa for dominance in the African Great Lakes region.
4 Malindi has traditionally been a friendly port city for foreign powers.
5 In 1414 the Chinese trader and explorer Zheng He representing the Ming Dynasty visited the East African coast on one of his last treasure voyages.
6 Malindi authorities welcomed the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama in 1498.
7 Where do many merchants and explorers go?	the Kenyan Coast	1
8 What is an important Swahili settlement along the coast?	City of Malindi	2
9 When was the City of Malindi established?	14th century	3
1 At the outbreak of World War I in August 1914 the governors of British East Africa as the Protectorate was generally known and German East Africa agreed a truce in an attempt to keep the young colonies out of direct hostilities.
2 Lt Col Paul von LettowVorbeck took command of the German military forces determined to tie down as many British resources as possible.
3 Completely cut off from Germany von Lettow conducted an effective guerrilla warfare campaign living off the land capturing British supplies and remaining undefeated.
4 He eventually surrendered in Northern Rhodesia today Zambia fourteen days after the Armistice was signed in 1918.
5 When was the outbreak of World War I?	August 1914	1
6 What two governors agreed to a truce to protect their young colonies?	governors of British East Africa as the Protectorate was generally known and German East Africa	1
7 Who was in command of the German military forces?	Lt Col Paul von LettowVorbeck	2
8 How did von Lettow conduct his group?	effective guerrilla warfare campaign  living off the land  capturing British supplies  and remaining undefeated	3
9 Where did von Lettow surrender at?	Northern Rhodesia	4
1 The central highlands were already home to over a million members of the Kikuyu people most of whom had no land claims in European terms and lived as itinerant farmers.
2 To protect their interests the settlers banned the growing of coffee introduced a hut tax and the landless were granted less and less land in exchange for their labour.
3 A massive exodus to the cities ensued as their ability to provide a living from the land dwindled.
4 There were 80000 white settlers living in Kenya in the 1950s.
5 Where were the Kikuyu people located?	The central highlands	1
6 How did the Kikuyu people live?	as itinerant farmers	1
7 How did the settlers protect their interests?	banned the growing of coffee  introduced a hut tax  and the landless were granted less and less land in exchange for their labour	2
8 How many white settlers were living in Kenya in the 1950s?	80 000	4
1 The capture of Warũhiũ Itote aka General China on 15 January 1954 and the subsequent interrogation led to a better understanding of the Mau Mau command structure.
2 Operation Anvil opened on 24 April 1954 after weeks of planning by the army with the approval of the War Council.
3 The operation effectively placed Nairobi under military siege and the occupants were screened and the Mau Mau supporters moved to detention camps.
4 The Home Guard formed the core of the governments strategy as it was composed of loyalist Africans not foreign forces like the British Army and Kings African Rifles.
5 By the end of the emergency the Home Guard had killed 4686 Mau Mau amounting to 42 of the total insurgents.
6 The capture of Dedan Kimathi on 21 October 1956 in Nyeri signified the ultimate defeat of the Mau Mau and essentially ended the military offensive.
7 During this period substantial governmental changes to land tenure occurred.
8 The most important of these was the Swynnerton Plan which was used to both reward loyalists and punish Mau Mau.
9 When was Waruhiu Itote captured?	15 January 1954	1
10 What did this help accomplish?	the subsequent interrogation led to a better understanding of the Mau Mau command structure	1
11 When did Operation Anvil open?	24 April 1954	2
12 How many of the Mau Mau did Home Gaurd kill?	4 686 Mau Mau	5
13 What was the most important governmental change to land tenure?	the Swynnerton Plan  which was used to both reward loyalists and punish Mau Mau	8
1 The first direct elections for native Kenyans to the Legislative Council took place in 1957.
2 Despite British hopes of handing power to moderate local rivals it was the Kenya African National Union KANU of Jomo Kenyatta that formed a government.
3 The Colony of Kenya and the Protectorate of Kenya each came to an end on 12 December 1963 with independence being conferred on all of Kenya.
4 The United Kingdom ceded sovereignty over the Colony of Kenya and under an agreement dated 8 October 1963 the Sultan of Zanzibar agreed that simultaneous with independence for the Colony of Kenya the Sultan would cease to have sovereignty over the Protectorate of Kenya so that all of Kenya would be one sovereign independent state.
5 In this way Kenya became an independent country under the Kenya Independence Act 1963 of the United Kingdom.
6 Exactly 12 months later on 12 December 1964 Kenya became a republic under the name Republic of Kenya.
7 When was the first direct elections for native Kenyans?	1957	1
8 Who formed the government in Kenya?	Kenya African National Union KANU of Jomo Kenyatta	2
9 When did the different colonies come together and form Kenya?	12 December 1963	3
10 When did Kenya become an independent country?	1963	5
11 What did Kenya name itself on December 12 1964?	Republic of Kenya	6
1 The election held in 1988 saw the advent of the mlolongo queuing system where voters were supposed to line up behind their favoured candidates instead of a secret ballot.
2 This was seen as the climax of a very undemocratic regime and it led to widespread agitation for constitutional reform.
3 Several contentious clauses including one that allowed for only one political party were changed in the following years.
4 In democratic multiparty elections in 1992 and 1997 Daniel arap Moi won reelection.
5 What is the mlolongo system?	where voters were supposed to line up behind their favoured candidates instead of a secret ballot	1
6 What did mlolongo system lead to?	agitation for constitutional reform	2
7 Who won the elections in 1992 and 1997?	Daniel arap Moi	4
1 Kenya is a presidential representative democratic republic.
2 The President is both the head of state and head of government and of a multiparty system.
3 Executive power is exercised by the government.
4 Legislative power is vested in both the government and the National Assembly and the Senate.
5 The Judiciary is independent of the executive and the legislature.
6 There was growing concern especially during former president Daniel arap Mois tenure that the executive was increasingly meddling with the affairs of the judiciary.
7 citation needed.
8 What kind of government does Kenya have?	a presidential representative democratic republic	1
9 What titles are the President given?	the head of state and head of government	2
10 Who is the executive power?	exercised by the government	3
11 Who is in control of legislative power?	both the government and the National Assembly and the Senate	4
12 What branch is independant of the other branches?	The Judiciary	5
1 Kenya ranks low on Transparency Internationals Corruption Perception Index CPI a metric which attempts to gauge the prevalence of public sector corruption in various countries.
2 In 2012 the nation placed 139th out of 176 total countries in the CPI with a score of 27100.
3 However there are several rather significant developments with regards to curbing corruption from the Kenyan government for instance the establishment of a new and independent Ethics and AntiCorruption Commission EACC.
4 Where does Kenya rang on the CPI scale?	low	1
5 What does the CPI scale measure?	gauge the prevalence of public sector corruption in various countries	1
6 Where is Kenya place on the scale in 2012?	139th out of 176 total countries	2
7 How does Kenya curb coruption?	the establishment of a new and independent Ethics and AntiCorruption Commission	3
1 In the Presidential elections President Kibaki under the Party of National Unity ran for reelection against the main opposition party the Orange Democratic Movement ODM.
2 The elections were seen to have been flawed with international observers saying that they were below international standards.
3 After a split which took a crucial 8 of the votes away from the ODM to the newly formed Orange Democratic MovementKenya ODMKs candidate Kalonzo Musyoka the race tightened between ODM candidate Raila Odinga and Kibaki.
4 As the count came into the Electoral Commission of Kenya ECK headquarters Odinga was shown to have a slight and then substantial lead as the results from his strongholds came in early.
5 As the ECK continued to count the votes Kibaki closed the gap and then overtook his opponent by a substantial margin after votes from his stronghold arrived later.
6 This led to protests and open discrediting of the ECK for complicity and to Odinga declaring himself the peoples president and calling for a recount.
7 What party is President Kibaki part of?	Party of National Unity	1
8 Who did President Kibaki run against?	the Orange Democratic Movement ODM	1
9 What led to protests and open discrediting of the ECK?	Kibaki closed the gap and then overtook his opponent by a substantial margin after votes from his stronghold arrived later	5
10 Who called themselves the Peoples President?	Odinga	6
1 Since the election riots the government and civil society organisations started programmes to avoid similar disasters in the future said Agnes R M Aboum – executive director of TAABCO Research and Development Consultants in Nairobi – in the magazine DC Development and Cooperation.
2 For example the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission initiated community dialogues the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Kenya started peace meetings and the Kenya National Dialogue and Reconciliation process was started.

5 What group started peace meetings?	Evangelical Lutheran Church	2
6 What was started after these new programs were in place?	Kenya National Dialogue and Reconciliation process	2
1 On 28 February 2008 Kibaki and Odinga signed an agreement on the formation of a coalition government in which Odinga would become Kenyas second Prime Minister.
2 Under the deal the president would appoint cabinet ministers from both PNU and ODM camps depending on each partys strength in Parliament.
3 The agreement stipulated that the cabinet would include a vicepresident and two deputy Prime Ministers.
4 After debates it was passed by Parliament the coalition would hold until the end of the current Parliament or if either of the parties withdraws from the deal before then.
5 When did Kibaki and Odinga sing an agreement on the formation of government?	28 February 2008	1
6 What would be Odingas role in the government?	Prime Minister	1

1 The new office of the PM will have power and authority to coordinate and supervise the functions of the Government and will be occupied by an elected MP who will be the leader of the party or coalition with majority members in Parliament.
2 The world watched Annan and his UNbacked panel and African Union chairman Jakaya Kikwete as they brought together the former rivals to the signing ceremony beamed live on national TV from the steps of Nairobis Harambee House.
3 On 29 February 2008 representatives of PNU and ODM began working on the finer details of the powersharing agreement.
4 Kenyan lawmakers unanimously approved a powersharing deal 18 March 2008 aimed at salvaging a country usually seen as one of the most stable and prosperous in Africa.
5 The deal brought Kibakis PNU and Odingas ODM together and heralded the formation of the grand coalition in which the two political parties would share power equally.
6 What will the Prime Minister have power over?	PM will have power and authority to coordinate and supervise the functions of the Government	1

10 What was the goal of the grand coalition?	the two political parties would share power equally	5
1 A constitutional change was considered that would eliminate the position of Prime Minister and simultaneously reduce the powers of the President.
2 A referendum to vote on the proposed constitution was held on 4 August 2010 and the new constitution passed by a wide margin.
3 Among other things the new constitution delegates more power to local governments and gives Kenyans a bill of rights.
4 It was promulgated on 27 August 2010 at a euphoric ceremony in Nairobis Uhuru Park accompanied by a 21gun salute.
5 The event was attended by various African leaders and praised by the international community.
6 As of that day the new constitution heralding the Second Republic came into force.
7 What constitutional change was considered?	eliminate the position of Prime Minister and simultaneously reduce the powers of the President	1

10 When was the new constitution promulgated?	27 August 2010	4
11 What came into force after the new constitution was herald?	the Second Republic	6
1 In December 2014 President Uhuru Kenyatta signed a Security Laws Amendment Bill which supporters of the law suggested was necessary to guard against armed groups.
2 Opposition politicians human rights groups and nine Western countries criticised the security bill arguing that it infringed on democratic freedoms.
3 The governments of the United States Britain Germany and France also collectively issued a press statement cautioning about the laws potential impact.
4 Through the Jubillee Coalition the Bill was later passed on 19 December in the National Assembly under acrimonious circumstances.

1 The armed forces are regularly deployed in peacekeeping missions around the world.
2 Further in the aftermath of the national elections of December 2007 and the violence that subsequently engulfed the country a commission of inquiry the Waki Commission commended its readiness and adjudged it to have performed its duty well.

1 Kenya’s armed forces like many government institutions in the country have been tainted by corruption allegations.
2 Because the operations of the armed forces have been traditionally cloaked by the ubiquitous blanket of “state security” the corruption has been less in public view and thus less subject to public scrutiny and notoriety.
3 This has changed recently.
4 In what are by Kenyan standards unprecedented revelations in 2010 credible claims of corruption were made with regard to recruitment  and procurement of Armoured Personnel Carriers.
5 Further the wisdom and prudence of certain decisions of procurement have been publicly questioned.
6 What other forces were tainted by corruption allegations?	Kenya’s armed forces	1
7 Why has the corruption not be in the public view?	Because the operations of the armed forces have been traditionally cloaked by the ubiquitous blanket of “state security”	2

1 Although Kenya is the biggest and most advanced economy in east and central Africa and has an affluent urban minority it has a Human Development Index HDI of 0519 ranked 145 out of 186 in the world.
2 As of 2005 177 of Kenyans lived on less than 125 a day.
3 The important agricultural sector is one of the least developed and largely inefficient employing 75 of the workforce compared to less than 3 in the food secure developed countries.
4 Kenya is usually classified as a frontier market or occasionally an emerging market but it is not one of the least developed countries.
5 What is Kenyas HDI?	0519  ranked 145 out of 186 in the world	1
6 Who is the biggest and most advanced economy in east and central Africa?	Kenya	1
7 How much does 177 of the population live on a day?	less than 125 a day	2
8 What kind of market is Kenya considered?	a frontier market or occasionally an emerging market	4
1 East and Central Africas biggest economy has posted tremendous growth in the service sector boosted by rapid expansion in telecommunication and financial activity over the last decade and nowwhen.
2 contributes 62 of GDP.
3 22 of GDP still comes from the unreliable agricultural sector which employs 75 of the labour force a consistent characteristic of underdeveloped economies that have not attained food security – an important catalyst of economic growth A small portion of the population relies on food aid.
4 citation needed Industry and manufacturing is the smallest sector accounting for 16 of GDP.
5 The service industry and manufacturing sectors only employ 25 of the labour force but contribute 75 of GDP.
6 What was East and Central Africas economy boosted by?	rapid expansion in telecommunication and financial activity	1
7 What is an important catalyst of economic growth?	food security	3
8 What is the smalled work force sector?	Industry and manufacturing	4
9 What percent of the labor force work in agriculture?	75 of the labour force	3
1 Kenyas services sector which contributes 61 of GDP is dominated by tourism.
2 The tourism sector has exhibited steady growth in most years since independence and by the late 1980s had become the countrys principal source of foreign exchange.
3 Tourists the largest number being from Germany and the United Kingdom are attracted mainly to the coastal beaches and the game reserves notably the expansive East and West Tsavo National Park 20808 square kilometres 8034 sq mi in the southeast.
4 Tourism has seen a substantial revival over the past several years and is the major contributor to the pickup in the countrys economic growth.
5 Tourism is now Kenyas largest foreign exchange earning sector followed by flowers tea and coffee.
6 In 2006 tourism generated US803 million up from US699 million the previous year.
7 Presently there are also numerous Shopping Malls in Kenya.
8 In addition there are four main hypermarket chains in Kenya.
9 How much does the services sector contribute to GDP?	61	1
10 What is the service sector dominated by?	tourism	1
11 Has the tourism sector had growth or reduction?	steady growth	2
12 What attracts the tourists to Kenya?	the coastal beaches and the game reserves	3
13 Where is the largest number of tourist coming from?	Germany and the United Kingdom	3
1 Agriculture is the second largest contributor to Kenyas gross domestic product GDP after the service sector.
2 In 2005 agriculture including forestry and fishing accounted for 24 of GDP as well as for 18 of wage employment and 50 of revenue from exports.
3 The principal cash crops are tea horticultural produce and coffee.
4 Horticultural produce and tea are the main growth sectors and the two most valuable of all of Kenyas exports.
5 The production of major food staples such as corn is subject to sharp weatherrelated fluctuations.
6 Production downturns periodically necessitate food aid—for example in 2004 aid for 18 million people because of one of Kenyas intermittent droughts.
7 citation needed.
8 How much of the GDP was agriculture in 2005?	24	2
9 What are the principal cash crops in Kenya?	tea  horticultural produce  and coffee	3
10 What is the second largest contrubtor to Kenyas GDP?	Agriculture	1
11 What can cause fluctuations in the production of corn?	weatherrelated fluctuations	5
1 A consortium led by the International Crops Research Institute for the SemiArid Tropics ICRISAT has had some success in helping farmers grow new pigeon pea varieties instead of maize in particularly dry areas.
2 Pigeon peas are very drought resistant so can be grown in areas with less than 650 mm annual rainfall.
3 Successive projects encouraged the commercialisation of legumes by stimulating the growth of local seed production and agrodealer networks for distribution and marketing.
4 This work which included linking producers to wholesalers helped to increase local producer prices by 20–25 in Nairobi and Mombasa.
5 The commercialisation of the pigeon pea is now enabling some farmers to buy assets ranging from mobile phones to productive land and livestock and is opening pathways for them to move out of poverty.
6 What institution has helped farmers grow new pigeon pea varieties?	International Crops Research Institute for the SemiArid Tropics ICRISAT	1
7 Why did they teach them to grow peas?	Pigeon peas are very drought resistant 	2
8 How did the project encourage the commercialisation of legumes?	by stimulating the growth of local seed production and agrodealer networks for distribution and marketing	3
9 How did this effect the producer prices?	  helped to increase local producer prices by 20–25	4
10 What has the increase of prices caused?	enabling some farmers to buy assets	5
1 Tea coffee sisal pyrethrum corn and wheat are grown in the fertile highlands one of the most successful agricultural production regions in Africa.
2 Livestock predominates in the semiarid savanna to the north and east.
3 Coconuts pineapples cashew nuts cotton sugarcane sisal and corn are grown in the lowerlying areas.
4 Unfortunately the country has not attained the level of investment and efficiency in agriculture that can guarantee food security and coupled with resulting poverty 53 of the population lives below the poverty line a significant portion of the population regularly starves and is heavily dependent on food aid.
5 Poor roads an inadequate railway network underused water transport and expensive air transport have isolated mostly arid and semiarid areas and farmers in other regions often leave food to rot in the fields because they cannot access markets.
6 This was last seen in August and September 2011 prompting the Kenyans for Kenya initiative by the Red Cross.
7 Where is the most successful agricultural prodcution regions?	the fertile highlands	1
8 What is grown in the fertile highlands?	Tea  coffee  sisal  pyrethrum  corn  and wheat	1
9 Where does the livestock of the country normally dominate?	the semiarid savanna to the north and east	2
10 What percent live below the povertly line?	53 of the population	4
11 What program did Red Cross put together in 2011?	Kenyans for Kenya	6
1 Although Kenya is the most industrially developed country in the African Great Lakes region manufacturing still accounts for only 14 of the GDP.
2 Industrial activity concentrated around the three largest urban centres Nairobi Mombasa and Kisumu is dominated by foodprocessing industries such as grain milling beer production and sugarcane crushing and the fabrication of consumer goods eg vehicles from kits.
3 There is a cement production industry.
4 citation needed Kenya has an oil refinery that processes imported crude petroleum into petroleum products mainly for the domestic market.
5 In addition a substantial and expanding informal sector commonly referred to as Jua Kali engages in smallscale manufacturing of household goods motorvehicle parts and farm implements.
6 citation needed.
7 What country is the most industrially developed country in the African Great Lakes Region?	Kenya	1
8 How much of GDP does manufactoriing account for?	14	1
9 What are the three largest urban areas in Kenya?	Nairobi  Mombasa and Kisumu	2
10 What does the sector known as Jua Kali engage in?	smallscale manufacturing of household goods  motorvehicle parts  and farm implements	5
1 Kenyas inclusion among the beneficiaries of the US Governments African Growth and Opportunity Act AGOA has given a boost to manufacturing in recent years.
2 Since AGOA took effect in 2000 Kenyas clothing sales to the United States increased from US44 million to US270 million 2006.
3 citation needed Other initiatives to strengthen manufacturing have been the new governments favourable tax measures including the removal of duty on capital equipment and other raw materials.
4 citation needed.
5 What has given a boost to manufacturing in recent years?	Kenyas inclusion among the beneficiaries of the US Governments African Growth and Opportunity Act AGOA	1
6 What year did AGOA take effect?	2000	2
1 The largest share of Kenyas electricity supply comes from hydroelectric stations at dams along the upper Tana River as well as the Turkwel Gorge Dam in the west.
2 A petroleumfired plant on the coast geothermal facilities at Olkaria near Nairobi and electricity imported from Uganda make up the rest of the supply.
3 Kenyas installed capacity stood at 1142 megawatts between 2001 and 2003.
4 The stateowned Kenya Electricity Generating Company KenGen established in 1997 under the name of Kenya Power Company handles the generation of electricity while Kenya Power handles the electricity transmission and distribution system in the country.
5 Shortfalls of electricity occur periodically when drought reduces water flow.
6 To become energy sufficient Kenya aims to build a nuclear power plant by 2017.
7 Where does the largest part of Kenyas power come from?	hydroelectric stations at dams	1
8 Where are these dams located?	Tana River  as well as the Turkwel Gorge Dam	1
9 When was Kenya Electricity Generating Company established?	1997	4
1 Kenya has proven deposits of oil in Turkana and the commercial viability was just discovered.
2 Tullow Oil estimates Kenyas oil reserves to be around 10 billion barrels.
3 Exploration is still continuing to determine if there are more reserves.
4 Kenya currently imports all crude petroleum requirements.
5 Kenya east Africas largest economy has no strategic reserves and relies solely on oil marketers 21day oil reserves required under industry regulations.
6 Petroleum accounts for 20 to 25 of the national import bill.
7 Where does Kenya have deposits of oil?	in Turkana	1
8 How many barrels of oil is it estimated Kenya has?	around 10 billion barrels	2
9 What is Kenya doing to determine if there are more reserves?	Exploration	3
10 How much does petroleum account for of the national import bill?	r 20 to 25	6
1 Published comments on Kenyas Capital FM website by Liu Guangyuan Chinas ambassador to Kenya at the time of President Kenyattas 2013 trip to Beijing said Chinese investment in Kenya  reached 474 million representing Kenyas largest source of foreign direct investment and  bilateral trade  reached 284 billion in 2012.
2 Kenyatta was accompanied by 60 Kenyan business people and hoped to  gain support from China for a planned 25 billion railway from the southern Kenyan port of Mombasa to neighboring Uganda as well as a nearly 18 billion dam according to a statement from the presidents office also at the time of the trip.
3 Base Titanium a subsidiary of Base resources of Australia shipped its first major consignment of minerals to China.
4 About 25000 tonnes of ilmenite was flagged off the Kenyan coastal town of Kilifi.
5 The first shipment was expected to earn Kenya about Shs15 – Shs20 Billion in earnings.
6 China has been causing environmental and social problems that include the recent suspension of the railway project.

10 Where did the first shipment of minerals ship from?	Base Titanium  a subsidiary of Base resources of Australia	3

1 In 2007 the Kenyan government unveiled Vision 2030 an economic development programme it hopes will put the country in the same league as the Asian Economic Tigers by the year 2030.
2 In 2013 it launched a National Climate Change Action Plan having acknowledged that omitting climate as a key development issue in Vision 2030 was an oversight.
3 The 200page Action Plan developed with support from the Climate  Development Knowledge Network sets out the Government of Kenyas vision for a low carbon climate resilient development pathway.
4 At the launch in March 2013 the Secretary of the Ministry of Planning National Development and Vision 2030 emphasised that climate will be a central issue in the renewed Medium Term Plan that will be launched in the coming months.
5 This will create a direct and robust delivery framework for the Action Plan and ensure climate change is treated as an economywide issue.
6 What did Kenya reveil in 2030?	Vision 2030	1
7 What is Vision 2030?	an economic development programme it hopes will put the country in the same league as the Asian Economic Tigers by the year 2030	1
8 What was their first plan that was launched?	National Climate Change Action Plan	2
9 Why did Vision 2030 add the NCCAP?	having acknowledged that omitting climate as a key development issue in Vision 2030 was an oversight	2
10 What will ensure and create the framework for the Action Plan to work?	climate will be a central issue in the renewed Medium Term Plan that will be launched in the coming months	4
1 Child labour is common in Kenya.
2 Most working children are active in agriculture.
3 In 2006 UNICEF estimated that up to 30 of girls in the coastal areas of Malindi Mombasa Kilifi and Diani were subject to prostitution.
4 Most of the prostitutes in Kenya are aged 9–18.
5 The Ministry of Gender and Child Affairs employed 400 child protection officers in 2009.
6 The causes of child labour include poverty the lack of access to education and weak government institutions.
7 Kenya has ratified Convention No.
8 81 on labour inspection in industries and Convention No.
9 129 on labour inspection in agriculture.
10 Where are most working children working?	in agriculture	2
11 What percent of girls are in prostution in Kenyas coastal areas?	up to 30	3
12 What is the age range of most prostitutes in Kenya?	9–18	4
13 What are some of the causes of child labor?	poverty  the lack of access to education and weak government institutions	6
1 Kenyas various ethnic groups typically speak their mother tongues within their own communities.
2 The two official languages English and Swahili are used in varying degrees of fluency for communication with other populations.
3 English is widely spoken in commerce schooling and government.
4 Periurban and rural dwellers are less multilingual with many in rural areas speaking only their native languages.
5 British English is primarily used in the country.
6 Additionally a distinct local dialect Kenyan English is used by some communities and individuals in the country and contains features unique to it that were derived from local Bantu languages such as Swahili and Kikuyu.
7 It has been developing since colonisation and also contains certain elements of American English.
8 Sheng is a Swahilibased cant spoken in some urban areas.
9 Primarily consisting of a mixture of Swahili and English it is an example of linguistic codeswitching.
10 What language is spoken in Kenya?	Kenyas various ethnic groups typically speak their mother tongues within their own communities	1
11 What are the two official languages?	English and Swahili	2
12 Where is English spoken the most?	in commerce  schooling and government	3
13 Where is British English usually used?	in the country	5
1 The vast majority of Kenyans are Christian 83 with 477 regarding themselves as Protestant and 235 as Roman Catholic of the Latin Rite.
2 The Presbyterian Church of East Africa has 3 million followers in Kenya and the surrounding countries.
3 There are smaller conservative Reformed churches the Africa Evangelical Presbyterian Church the Independent Presbyterian Church in Kenya and the Reformed Church of East Africa.
4 621200 of Kenyans are Orthodox Christians.
5 Notably Kenya has the highest number of Quakers in the world with around 133000 members.
6 The only Jewish synagogue in the country is located in the capital Nairobi.
7 What is the main religion in Kenya?	Christian	1
8 What is the main denomination of Christians in Kenya?	Protestant	1
9 How many followers does The Presbyterian Church of East Africa have?	3 million followers	2
10 Where is the only Jewish synagogue located?	Nairobi	6
1 Sizeable minorities of other faiths do exist Muslim 112 indigenous beliefs 17 and nonreligious 24.
2 Sixty percent of the Muslim population lives in Kenyas Coastal Region comprising 50 of the total population there.
3 Roughly 4 of Muslims are Ahmadiyya 8 Shia and another 8 are nondenominational Muslims while 73 are Sunni.
4 Western areas of the Coast Region are mostly Christian.
5 The upper part of Kenyas Eastern Region is home to 10 of the countrys Muslims where they constitute the majority religious group.
6 In addition there is a large Hindu population in Kenya around 300000 who have played a key role in the local economy they are mostly of Indian origin.
7 How many Kenyans are nonreligious?	24	1
8 What percent of the Muslim population lives in Kenyas Coastal Region?	Sixty percent	2
9 What religion is the western region mostly?	mostly Christian	4
10 How much of the population is Hindu?	around 300 000	6
1 Nurses treat 80 of the population who visit dispensaries health centres and private clinics in rural and underserved urban areas.
2 Complicated cases are referred to clinical officers medical officers and medical practitioners.
3 According to the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics in 2011 there were 65000 qualified nurses registered in the country 8600 clinical officers and 7000 doctors for the population of 43 million people These figures from official registers include those who have died or left the profession hence the actual number of these workers may be lower.
4 Who treats the majority of the population medically?	Nurses	1
5 Who sees a patient after a nurse can not help anymore?	clinical officers  medical officers and medical practitioners	2
6 How many registered nurses were in Kenya in 2011?	65 000	3
7 How many doctors were in Kenya in 2011?	7 000 doctors	3
1 Diseases of poverty directly correlate with a countrys economic performance and wealth distribution Half of Kenyans live below the poverty level.
2 Preventable diseases like malaria HIVAIDS pneumonia diarrhoea and malnutrition are the biggest burden major childkillers and responsible for much morbidity weak policies corruption inadequate health workers weak management and poor leadership in the public health sector are largely to blame.
3 According to 2009 estimates HIV prevalence is about 63 of the adult population.
4 However the 2011 UNAIDS Report suggests that the HIV epidemic may be improving in Kenya as HIV prevalence is declining among young people ages 15–24 and pregnant women.
5 Kenya had an estimated 15 million cases of malaria in 2006.
6 What directly correlates with the countrys economic performance and wealth distribution?	Diseases of poverty	1
7 How many Kenyans are living below the poverty level?	Half	1
8 What are the biggest burdens?	diseases like malaria  HIVAIDS  pneumonia  diarrhoea and malnutrition	2
9 What is to blame for the burdens in health care in Kenya?	weak policies  corruption  inadequate health workers  weak management and poor leadership in the public health sector	2
10 How many cases of malaria did Kenya report in 2006?	15 million	5
1 Kenyas first system of education was introduced by British colonists.
2 After Kenyas independence on 12 December 1963 an authority named the Ominde Commission was formed to introduce changes that would reflect the nations sovereignty.
3 The commission focused on identity and unity which were critical issues at the time.
4 Changes in the subject content of history and geography were made to reflect national cohesion.
5 Between 1964 and 1985 the 7–4–2–3 system was adopted – seven years of primary four years of lower secondary two years of upper secondary and three years of university.
6 All schools had a common curriculum.
7 Who introduced the first system of education?	British colonists	1
8 When did Kenya gain independance?	12 December 1963	2
9 What was formed to introduce changes that would reflect the nations sovereignty?	Ominde Commission	2
10 What did the Ominde Commission do?	focused on identity and unity  which were critical issues at the time	3
11 What system was adopted for education?	the 7–4–2–3 system was adopted	5
1 In 1981 the Presidential Working Party on the Second University was commissioned to look at both the possibilities of setting up a second university in Kenya as well as the reforming of the entire education system.
2 The committee recommended that the 7–4–2–3 system be changed to an 8–4–4 system eight years in primary four years in secondary and four years in university education.
3 The table under Presentday education in Kenya below shows the structure of the 8–4–4 system.
4 Although the 7–4–2–3 system theoretically ended with the introduction of the new 8–4–4 system in 1985 the last batch of students from the former system graduated from Kenyan Universities in 1992.
5 What was the Presidential Working Party on the Second University commissioned to do?	look at both the possibilities of setting up a second university in Kenya as well as the reforming of the entire education system	1
6 What did they want the educational system to be?	8–4–4 system	2
7 What is the edcuation system currently?	8–4–4 system	3
8 When did the last batch of students that followed the former system graudate?	1992	4
1 The current 8–4–4 system was launched in January 1985.
2 It put more emphasis on vocational subjects on the assumption that the new structure would enable school dropouts at all levels either to be selfemployed or to secure employment in the informal sector.
3 In January 2003 the Government of Kenya announced the introduction of free primary education.
4 As a result primary school enrolment increased by about 70.
5 Secondary and tertiary education enrolment has not increased proportionally because payment is still required for attendance.
6 In 2007 the government issued a statement declaring that from 2008 secondary education would be heavily subsidiszed with the government footing all tuition fees.
7 When was the 844 system launched?	January 1985	1
8 What was the emphasis focuses on?	vocational subjects	2
9 Why were vocational subjects most important?	the new structure would enable school dropouts at all levels either to be selfemployed or to secure employment in the informal sector	2
10 When was free primary school introduced?	January 2003	3
11 How much did enrollment increase?	increased by about 70	4
1 Basic formal education starts at age six years and lasts 12 years comprising eight years in primary school and four years in high school or secondary school.
2 Primary school is free in public schools and those who exit at this level can join a vocational youthvillage polytechnic or make their own arrangements for an apprenticeship program and learn a trade such as tailoring carpentry motor vehicle repair bricklaying and masonry for about two years.
3 Those who complete high school can join a polytechnic or other technical college and study for three years or proceed directly to the university and study for four years.
4 Graduates from the polytechnics and colleges can then join the workforce and later obtain a specialised higher diploma qualification after a further one to two years of training or join the university – usually in the second or third year of their respective course.
5 The higher diploma is accepted by many employers in place of a bachelors degree and direct or accelerated admission to postgraduate studies is possible in some universities.
6 What age does basic education start?	age six years	1
7 What is the break down of years at different level of education?	eight years in primary school and four years in high school or secondary school	1
8 What do students do after primary school?	join a vocational youthvillage polytechnic or make their own arrangements for an apprenticeship program	2
9 What can students that complete high school have opportunites to do?	join a polytechnic or other technical college and study for three years or proceed directly to the university and study for four years	3
1 The countrys literacy level stands at 85 of the whole population.
2 Preschool which targets children from age three to five is an integral component of the education system and is a key requirement for admission to Standard One First Grade.
3 At the end of primary education pupils sit the Kenya Certificate of Primary Education KCPE which determines those who proceed to secondary school or vocational training.
4 The result of this examination is needed for placement at secondary school.
5 Primary school age is 671314 years.
6 For those who proceed to secondary level there is a national examination at the end of Form Four – the Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education KCSE which determines those proceeding to the universities other professional training or employment.
7 Students sit examinations in eight subjects of their choosing.
8 However English Kiswahili languages and mathematics are compulsory subjects.
9 What is Kenyas literacy rate?	85	1
10 Preschool targest what age children?	age three to five	2
11 What is preschool required for?	a key requirement for admission to Standard One First Grade	2
12 What does the KCPE determine?	those who proceed to secondary school or vocational training	3
13 What is the exam at the end of Form Four?	the Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education	6
1 Other than the curriculum led learning there are also National and Public Library Services led by the Kenya National Library Service KNLS.
2 KNLS is the body mandated to establish equip manage and maintain national and public libraries in the country.
3 In addition some of the counties within the country have either established or taken over libraries within their regions.
4 Nairobi County operates four libraries within their network which included the McMillan Memorial Library located at the central business district of Nairobi.
5 A public library is seen as a peoples university since it is open to all irrespective of age literacy level and has materials relevant to people of all walks of life.
6 Who leads the National and Public Library Servies?	the Kenya National Library Service	1
7 What is the KNLS responsible for?	establish  equip  manage and maintain national and public libraries in the country	2
8 What is the public library seen as to Kenyans?	a peoples university	5
9 Why is the public library known as a peoples university?	it is open to all irrespective of age  literacy level and has materials relevant to people of all walks of life	5
1 Kenya is active in several sports among them cricket rallying football rugby union and boxing.
2 The country is known chiefly for its dominance in middledistance and longdistance athletics having consistently produced Olympic and Commonwealth Games champions in various distance events especially in 800 m 1500 m 3000 m steeplechase 5000 m 10000 m and the marathon.
3 Kenyan athletes particularly Kalenjin continue to dominate the world of distance running although competition from Morocco and Ethiopia has reduced this supremacy.
4 Kenyas bestknown athletes included the fourtime womens Boston Marathon winner and twotime world champion Catherine Ndereba 800m world record holder David Rudisha former Marathon world recordholder Paul Tergat and John Ngugi.
5 What sports are Kenyans active in?	cricket  rallying  football  rugby union and boxing	1
6 What is the country known for?	its dominance in middledistance and longdistance athletics	2
7 Who dominates the world of long distance running?	Kenyan athletes particularly Kalenjin	3
8 What countries does Kenya compete with for long distance running?	Morocco and Ethiopia	3
1 Kenya won several medals during the Beijing Olympics six gold four silver and four bronze making it Africas most successful nation in the 2008 Olympics.
2 New athletes gained attention such as Pamela Jelimo the womens 800m gold medalist who went ahead to win the IAAF Golden League jackpot and Samuel Wanjiru who won the mens marathon.
3 Retired Olympic and Commonwealth Games champion Kipchoge Keino helped usher in Kenyas ongoing distance dynasty in the 1970s and was followed by Commonwealth Champion Henry Ronos spectacular string of world record performances.
4 Lately there has been controversy in Kenyan athletics circles with the defection of a number of Kenyan athletes to represent other countries chiefly Bahrain and Qatar.
5 The Kenyan Ministry of Sports has tried to stop the defections but they have continued anyway with Bernard Lagat the latest choosing to represent the United States.
6 Most of these defections occur because of economic or financial factors.
7 Some elite Kenyan runners who cannot qualify for their countrys strong national team find it easier to qualify by running for other countries.
8 citation needed.
9 How many gold medals did Kenya win during the Beijing Olympics?	six gold	1
10 How well did Kenya do in the Beijing Olympics?	Africas most successful nation in the 2008 Olympics	1
11 What else did Pamela Jelimo win after the Olympics?	IAAF Golden League jackpot	2
12 Why has there been controversy in Kenyan athletics?	the defection of a number of Kenyan athletes to represent other countries	4
13 Why do these defections occur?	economic or financial factors	6
1 Kenya has been a dominant force in womens volleyball within Africa with both the clubs and the national team winning various continental championships in the past decade.
2 citation needed The womens team has competed at the Olympics and World Championships but without any notable success.
3 Cricket is another popular and the most successful team sport.
4 Kenya has competed in the Cricket World Cup since 1996.
5 They upset some of the Worlds best teams and reached semifinals of the 2003 tournament.
6 They won the inaugural World Cricket League Division 1 hosted in Nairobi and participated in the World T20.
7 Their current captain is Rakep Patel.
8 They participated in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2011.
9 Kenya is represented by Lucas Onyango as a professional rugby league player who plays with Oldham Roughyeds.
10 Besides the former European Super League team he has played for Widnes Vikings and rugby union with Sale Sharks.
11 Rugby union is increasing in popularity especially with the annual Safari Sevens tournament.
12 Kenya sevens team ranked 9th in IRB Sevens World Series for the 2006 season.
13 Kenya was also a regional powerhouse in soccer.
14 However its dominance has been eroded by wrangles within the now defunct Kenya Football Federation leading to a suspension by FIFA which was lifted in March 2007.
15 What sport has Kenyan women been a dominate force?	womens volleyball within Africa	1
16 What is the most successful team sport in Kenya?	Cricket	3
17 When did Kenya reach the semifinals?	2003	5
18 Who is the current captian of the cricket team?	Rakep Patel	7
19 When was the suspension by FIFA lifted?	March 2007	1296
1 In the motor rallying arena Kenya is home to the world famous Safari Rally commonly acknowledged as one of the toughest rallies in the world.
2 It was a part of the World Rally Championship for many years until its exclusion after the 2002 event owing to financial difficulties.
3 Some of the best rally drivers in the world have taken part in and won the rally such as Björn Waldegård Hannu Mikkola Tommi Mäkinen Shekhar Mehta Carlos Sainz and Colin McRae.
4 Although the rally still runs annually as part of the Africa rally championship the organisers are hoping to be allowed to rejoin the World Rally championship in the next couple of years.
5 What is Kenya the home of?	the world famous Safari Rally	1
6 What is the Safair Rally known as?	one of the toughest rallies in the world	1
7 Who are some of the best rally drivers that have won the rally?	Björn Waldegård  Hannu Mikkola  Tommi Mäkinen  Shekhar Mehta  Carlos Sainz and Colin McRae	3
1 Kenyans generally have three meals in a day – breakfast in the morning kiamsha kinywa lunch in the afternoon chakula cha mchana and supper in the evening chakula cha jioni or known simply as chajio.
2 In between they have the 10 oclock tea chai ya saa nne and 4 pm tea chai ya saa kumi.
3 Breakfast is usually tea or porridge with bread chapati mahamri boiled sweet potatoes or yams.
4 Ugali with vegetables sour milk meat fish or any other stew is generally eaten by much of the population for lunch or supper.
5 Regional variations and dishes also exist.
6 How many meals a day do normal Kenyans eat?	three meals in a day	1
7 What time do they normally have tea?	10 oclock tea chai ya saa nne and 4 pm tea	2
8 What are some normal breakfast foods?	tea or porridge with bread  chapati  mahamri  boiled sweet potatoes or yams	3
9 What is normally eaten for lunch and supper?	Ugali with vegetables  sour milk  meat  fish or any other stew	4
1 The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change IPCC is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the United Nations set up at the request of member governments.
2 It was first established in 1988 by two United Nations organizations the World Meteorological Organization WMO and the United Nations Environment Programme UNEP and later endorsed by the United Nations General Assembly through Resolution 4353.
3 Membership of the IPCC is open to all members of the WMO and UNEP.
4 The IPCC produces reports that support the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change UNFCCC which is the main international treaty on climate change.
5 The ultimate objective of the UNFCCC is to stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic ie humaninduced interference with the climate system.
6 IPCC reports cover the scientific technical and socioeconomic information relevant to understanding the scientific basis of risk of humaninduced climate change its potential impacts and options for adaptation and mitigation.
7 What organization is the IPCC a part of?	the United Nations	1
8 What UN organizations established the IPCC?	the World Meteorological Organization WMO and the United Nations Environment Programme UNEP	2
9 What does the UN want to stabilize?	greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere	5
10 What is the UNs climate change treaty?	United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change	4
11 What UN resolution endorsed the IPCC?	Resolution 4353	2
1 Korean economist Hoesung Lee is the chair of the IPCC since October 8 2015 following the election of the new IPCC Bureau.
2 Before this election the IPCC was led by his viceChair Ismail El Gizouli who was designated acting Chair after the resignation of Rajendra K Pachauri in February 2015.
3 The previous chairs were Rajendra K Pachauri elected in May 2002 Robert Watson in 1997 and Bert Bolin in 1988.
4 The chair is assisted by an elected bureau including vicechairs working group cochairs and a secretariat.
5 Who is the chair of the IPCC?	Hoesung Lee	1
6 What nationality is Hoesung Lee?	Korean	1
7 Who is the vicechair of the IPCC?	Ismail El Gizouli	2
8 Who was the first chair of the IPCC?	Bert Bolin	3
9 When did Pachauri resign as chair of the IPCC?	February 2015	2
1 The IPCC Panel is composed of representatives appointed by governments and organizations.
2 Participation of delegates with appropriate expertise is encouraged.
3 Plenary sessions of the IPCC and IPCC Working groups are held at the level of government representatives.
4 Non Governmental and Intergovernmental Organizations may be allowed to attend as observers.
5 Sessions of the IPCC Bureau workshops expert and lead authors meetings are by invitation only.
6 Attendance at the 2003 meeting included 350 government officials and climate change experts.
7 After the opening ceremonies closed plenary sessions were held.
8 The meeting report states there were 322 persons in attendance at Sessions with about seveneighths of participants being from governmental organizations.
9 Who is on the IPCC Panel?	representatives appointed by governments and organizations	1
10 How many people attended the 2003 IPCC meeting?	350	6
11 What kind of people attend the IPCC meetings?	government officials and climate change experts	6
12 How much of the IPCC attendees are government representatives?	about seveneighths	8
1 The IPCC receives funding through the IPCC Trust Fund established in 1989 by the United Nations Environment Programme UNEP and the World Meteorological Organization WMO Costs of the Secretary and of housing the secretariat are provided by the WMO while UNEP meets the cost of the Depute Secretary.
2 Annual cash contributions to the Trust Fund are made by the WMO by UNEP and by IPCC Members the scale of payments is determined by the IPCC Panel which is also responsible for considering and adopting by consensus the annual budget.
3 The organisation is required to comply with the Financial Regulations and Rules of the WMO.
4 When was the IPCC Trust Fund founded?	1989	1
5 Who started the IPCC Trust Fund?	the United Nations Environment Programme UNEP and the World Meteorological Organization WMO	1
6 Who funds the IPCCs Deputy Secretary?	United Nations Environment Programme	1
7 What rules does the IPCC have to follow?	the Financial Regulations and Rules of the WMO	3
8 Who funds the IPCCs Secretary?	World Meteorological Organization	1
1 The IPCC does not carry out research nor does it monitor climate related data.
2 Lead authors of IPCC reports assess the available information about climate change based on published sources.
3 According to IPCC guidelines authors should give priority to peerreviewed sources.
4 Authors may refer to nonpeerreviewed sources the grey literature provided that they are of sufficient quality.
5 Examples of nonpeerreviewed sources include model results reports from government agencies and nongovernmental organizations and industry journals.
6 Each subsequent IPCC report notes areas where the science has improved since the previous report and also notes areas where further research is required.
7 What does the IPCC not do?	does not carry out research nor does it monitor climate related data	1
8 Where do IPCC reports get their information?	available information about climate change based on published sources	2
9 What is grey literature?	nonpeerreviewed sources	4
10 What kind of nonpeerreviewed sources does the IPCC use?	model results  reports from government agencies and nongovernmental organizations  and industry journals	5
1 Each chapter has a number of authors who are responsible for writing and editing the material.
2 A chapter typically has two coordinating lead authors ten to fifteen lead authors and a somewhat larger number of contributing authors.
3 The coordinating lead authors are responsible for assembling the contributions of the other authors ensuring that they meet stylistic and formatting requirements and reporting to the Working Group chairs.
4 Lead authors are responsible for writing sections of chapters.
5 Contributing authors prepare text graphs or data for inclusion by the lead authors.
6 How many coordinating lead authors does an IPCC report chapter have?	two	2
7 How many lead authors does an IPCC report chapter have?	ten to fifteen	2
8 How many contributing authors does an IPCC report chapter have?	a somewhat larger number	2
9 Who assembles the authors contributions?	The coordinating lead authors	3
10 Who do coordinating lead authors report to?	the Working Group chairs	3
1 The executive summary of the WG I Summary for Policymakers report says they are certain that emissions resulting from human activities are substantially increasing the atmospheric concentrations of the greenhouse gases resulting on average in an additional warming of the Earths surface.
2 They calculate with confidence that CO2 has been responsible for over half the enhanced greenhouse effect.
3 They predict that under a business as usual BAU scenario global mean temperature will increase by about 03 °C per decade during the 21st century.
4 They judge that global mean surface air temperature has increased by 03 to 06 °C over the last 100 years broadly consistent with prediction of climate models but also of the same magnitude as natural climate variability.
5 The unequivocal detection of the enhanced greenhouse effect is not likely for a decade or more.
6 What does the WG I Summary for Policymakers report say human activities are doing to greenhouse gases?	substantially increasing the atmospheric concentrations	1
7 What do increased greenhouse gases cause?	additional warming of the Earths surface	1
8 How much of the greenhouse effect is due to carbon dioxide?	over half	2
9 What is the scenario called in which we dont change our greenhouse gas creation practices?	business as usual BAU	3
10 How much has global mean surface air temperature changed in the last century?	increased by 03 to 06 °C	4
1 In 2001 16 national science academies issued a joint statement on climate change.

3 The statement also published as an editorial in the journal Science stated we support the TARs conclusion that it is at least 90 certain that temperatures will continue to rise with average global surface temperature projected to increase by between 14 and 58 °C above 1990 levels by 2100.

1 The IPCC concentrates its activities on the tasks allotted to it by the relevant WMO Executive Council and UNEP Governing Council resolutions and decisions as well as on actions in support of the UNFCCC process.

1 Former IPCC chairman Robert Watson has said The mistakes all appear to have gone in the direction of making it seem like climate change is more serious by overstating the impact.

1 The third assessment report TAR prominently featured a graph labeled Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction based on a 1999 paper by Michael E Mann Raymond S Bradley and Malcolm K Hughes MBH99 which has been referred to as the hockey stick graph.
2 This graph extended the similar graph in Figure 320 from the IPCC Second Assessment Report of 1995 and differed from a schematic in the first assessment report that lacked temperature units but appeared to depict larger global temperature variations over the past 1000 years and higher temperatures during the Medieval Warm Period than the mid 20th century.
3 The schematic was not an actual plot of data and was based on a diagram of temperatures in central England with temperatures increased on the basis of documentary evidence of Medieval vineyards in England.
4 Even with this increase the maximum it showed for the Medieval Warm Period did not reach temperatures recorded in central England in 2007.
5 The MBH99 finding was supported by cited reconstructions by Jones et al.
6 1998 Pollack Huang  Shen 1998 Crowley  Lowery 2000 and Briffa 2000 using differing data and methods.
7 The Jones et al.
8 and Briffa reconstructions were overlaid with the MBH99 reconstruction in Figure 221 of the IPCC report.
9 When was the paper published that the Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction graph was based on?	1999	1
10 Who wrote the paper that the Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction graph was based on?	Michael E Mann  Raymond S Bradley and Malcolm K Hughes	1
11 What is the nickname for the Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction graph?	the hockey stick graph	1
12 What reconstructions supported the 1999 papers information?	Jones et al 1998  Pollack  Huang  Shen 1998  Crowley  Lowery 2000 and Briffa 2000	5
1 These studies were widely presented as demonstrating that the current warming period is exceptional in comparison to temperatures between 1000 and 1900 and the MBH99 based graph featured in publicity.
2 Even at the draft stage this finding was disputed by contrarians in May 2000 Fred Singers Science and Environmental Policy Project held a press event on Capitol Hill Washington DC featuring comments on the graph Wibjörn Karlén and Singer argued against the graph at a United States Senate Committee on Commerce Science and Transportation hearing on 18 July 2000.
3 Contrarian John Lawrence Daly featured a modified version of the IPCC 1990 schematic which he misidentified as appearing in the IPCC 1995 report and argued that Overturning its own previous view in the 1995 report the IPCC presented the Hockey Stick as the new orthodoxy with hardly an apology or explanation for the abrupt Uturn since its 1995 report.
4 Criticism of the MBH99 reconstruction in a review paper which was quickly discredited in the Soon and Baliunas controversy was picked up by the Bush administration and a Senate speech by US Republican senator James Inhofe alleged that manmade global warming is the greatest hoax ever perpetrated on the American people.
5 The data and methodology used to produce the hockey stick graph was criticized in papers by Stephen McIntyre and Ross McKitrick and in turn the criticisms in these papers were examined by other studies and comprehensively refuted by Wahl  Ammann 2007 which showed errors in the methods used by McIntyre and McKitrick.
6 What range of years was the current warming compared to?	between 1000 and 1900	1
7 Who led the Science and Environmental Policy Project?	Fred Singer	2
8 Where did Singer hold a press conference in May 2000?	Capitol Hill  Washington  DC	2
9 When did Singer dispute the graph at a Senate hearing?	18 July 2000	2
10 What Senate committee did Singer speak to in July 2000?	United States Senate Committee on Commerce  Science and Transportation	2
1 On 23 June 2005 Rep Joe Barton chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce wrote joint letters with Ed Whitfield Chairman of the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations demanding full records on climate research as well as personal information about their finances and careers from Mann Bradley and Hughes.
2 Sherwood Boehlert chairman of the House Science Committee said this was a misguided and illegitimate investigation apparently aimed at intimidating scientists and at his request the US National Academy of Sciences arranged for its National Research Council to set up a special investigation.
3 The National Research Councils report agreed that there were some statistical failings but these had little effect on the graph which was generally correct.
4 In a 2006 letter to Nature Mann Bradley and Hughes pointed out that their original article had said that more widespread highresolution data are needed before more confident conclusions can be reached and that the uncertainties were the point of the article.
5 Who was the chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce?	Rep Joe Barton	1
6 Who was Chairman of the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations?	Ed Whitfield	1
7 When did Barton and Whitfield demand climate research records?	23 June 2005	1
8 Who was chairman of the House Science Committee?	Sherwood Boehlert	2

1 The IPCC Fourth Assessment Report AR4 published in 2007 featured a graph showing 12 proxy based temperature reconstructions including the three highlighted in the 2001 Third Assessment Report TAR Mann Bradley  Hughes 1999 as before Jones et al.
2 1998 and Briffa 2000 had both been calibrated by newer studies.
3 In addition analysis of the Medieval Warm Period cited reconstructions by Crowley  Lowery 2000 as cited in the TAR and Osborn  Briffa 2006.
4 Ten of these 14 reconstructions covered 1000 years or longer.
5 Most reconstructions shared some data series particularly tree ring data but newer reconstructions used additional data and covered a wider area using a variety of statistical methods.
6 The section discussed the divergence problem affecting certain tree ring data.

10 What problem did some tree ring data have?	divergence	6

1 On 1 February 2007 the eve of the publication of IPCCs major report on climate a study was published suggesting that temperatures and sea levels have been rising at or above the maximum rates proposed during the last IPCC report in 2001.
2 The study compared IPCC 2001 projections on temperature and sea level change with observations.
3 Over the six years studied the actual temperature rise was near the top end of the range given by IPCCs 2001 projection and the actual sea level rise was above the top of the range of the IPCC projection.
4 When was a study published confirming the 2001 IPCC projections?	1 February 2007	1
5 How did the 2001 IPCC report compare to reality for 20012006?	temperatures and sea levels have been rising at or above the maximum rates	1
6 How did the 2001 IPCC report compare to reality on temperature levels?	actual temperature rise was near the top end of the range given	3
7 How did the 2001 IPCC report compare to reality on sea levels?	actual sea level rise was above the top of the range	3
1 Another example of scientific research which suggests that previous estimates by the IPCC far from overstating dangers and risks have actually understated them is a study on projected rises in sea levels.
2 When the researchers analysis was applied to the possible scenarios outlined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change IPCC the researchers found that in 2100 sea levels would be 05–14 m 50–140 cm above 1990 levels.
3 These values are much greater than the 9–88 cm as projected by the IPCC itself in its Third Assessment Report published in 2001.
4 This may have been due in part to the expanding human understanding of climate.
5 What danger did the IPCC understate?	projected rises in sea levels	1
6 How much did the IPCC Third Assessment Report say sea levels will rise from 1990 to 2100?	9–88 cm	3
7 How much do researchers now think sea levels will rise from 1990 to 2100?	50–140 cm	2
8 When was the Third Assessment Report published?	2001	3
1 Michael Oppenheimer a longtime participant in the IPCC and coordinating lead author of the Fifth Assessment Report conceded in Science Magazines State of the Planet 20082009 some limitations of the IPCC consensus approach and asks for concurring smaller assessments of special problems instead of the large scale approach as in the previous IPCC assessment reports.
2 It has become more important to provide a broader exploration of uncertainties.
3 Others see as well mixed blessings of the drive for consensus within the IPCC process and ask to include dissenting or minority positions or to improve statements about uncertainties.
4 What role did Michael Oppenheimer have in the IPCCs reports?	coordinating lead author of the Fifth Assessment Report	1

6 What approach did Oppenheimer advocate?	concurring  smaller assessments of special problems	1
1 The IPCC process on climate change and its efficiency and success has been compared with dealings with other environmental challenges compare Ozone depletion and global warming.
2 In case of the Ozone depletion global regulation based on the Montreal Protocol has been successful in case of Climate Change the Kyoto Protocol failed.
3 The Ozone case was used to assess the efficiency of the IPCC process.
4 The lockstep situation of the IPCC is having built a broad science consensus while states and governments still follow different if not opposing goals.
5 The underlying linear model of policymaking of more knowledge we have the better the political response will be is being doubted.
6 What has successfully dealt with ozone depletion?	the Montreal Protocol	2
7 What did the Kyoto Protocol try to address?	Climate Change	2
8 Whose goals often still oppose the IPCC?	states and governments	4
1 According to Sheldon Ungars comparison with global warming the actors in the ozone depletion case had a better understanding of scientific ignorance and uncertainties.
2 The ozone case communicated to lay persons with easytounderstand bridging metaphors derived from the popular culture and related to immediate risks with everyday relevance while the public opinion on climate change sees no imminent danger.
3 The stepwise mitigation of the ozone layer challenge was based as well on successfully reducing regional burden sharing conflicts.
4 In case of the IPCC conclusions and the failure of the Kyoto Protocol varying regional costbenefit analysis and burdensharing conflicts with regard to the distribution of emission reductions remain an unsolved problem.
5 In the UK a report for a House of Lords committee asked to urge the IPCC to involve better assessments of costs and benefits of climate change but the Stern Review ordered by the UK government made a stronger argument in favor to combat humanmade climate change.
6 Who said people involved in the ozone situation had a better understanding of scientific ignorance and uncertainties?	Sheldon Ungar	1
7 What remain unsolved problems with the Kyoto Protocol?	varying regional costbenefit analysis and burdensharing conflicts with regard to the distribution of emission reductions	4
8 What conflicts did the ozone mitigation reduce?	regional burden sharing conflicts	3
9 Who ordered the Stern Review?	the UK government	5
1 Since the IPCC does not carry out its own research it operates on the basis of scientific papers and independently documented results from other scientific bodies and its schedule for producing reports requires a deadline for submissions prior to the reports final release.
2 In principle this means that any significant new evidence or events that change our understanding of climate science between this deadline and publication of an IPCC report cannot be included.
3 In an area of science where our scientific understanding is rapidly changing this has been raised as a serious shortcoming in a body which is widely regarded as the ultimate authority on the science.
4 However there has generally been a steady evolution of key findings and levels of scientific confidence from one assessment report to the next.
5 citation needed.
6 What does the IPCC rely on for research?	other scientific bodies	1
7 What can the IPCCs report deadlines cause to be omitted?	significant new evidence or events that change our understanding of climate science	2
8 Who is seen as the ultimate climate change authority?	IPCC	2
1 In February 2010 in response to controversies regarding claims in the Fourth Assessment Report five climate scientists – all contributing or lead IPCC report authors – wrote in the journal Nature calling for changes to the IPCC.
2 They suggested a range of new organizational options from tightening the selection of lead authors and contributors to dumping it in favor of a small permanent body or even turning the whole climate science assessment process into a moderated living WikipediaIPCC.
3 Other recommendations included that the panel employ a fulltime staff and remove government oversight from its processes to avoid political interference.
4 How many scientists called to change the IPCC in Feb 2010?	five	1
5 Where was the Feb 2010 call for change published?	the journal Nature	1
6 What was one proposal to let the IPCC respond to new evidence faster?	turning the whole climate science assessment process into a moderated living WikipediaIPCC	2
