7 How was it suggested that the IPCC avoid political problems?	remove government oversight from its processes	3
1 Chloroplasts main role is to conduct photosynthesis where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energystorage molecules ATP and NADPH while freeing oxygen from water.
2 They then use the ATP and NADPH to make organic molecules from carbon dioxide in a process known as the Calvin cycle.
3 Chloroplasts carry out a number of other functions including fatty acid synthesis much amino acid synthesis and the immune response in plants.
4 The number of chloroplasts per cell varies from 1 in algae up to 100 in plants like Arabidopsis and wheat.
5 What is the primary purpose of chloroplasts?	to conduct photosynthesis	1
6 What does ATP store?	energy	1
7 What does NADPH store?	energy	1
8 What is the process of turning CO2 into organic molecules called?	the Calvin cycle	2
9 How many chloroplasts per cell does algae have?	1	4
1 Chloroplasts are highly dynamic—they circulate and are moved around within plant cells and occasionally pinch in two to reproduce.
2 Their behavior is strongly influenced by environmental factors like light color and intensity.
3 Chloroplasts like mitochondria contain their own DNA which is thought to be inherited from their ancestor—a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell.
4 Chloroplasts cannot be made by the plant cell and must be inherited by each daughter cell during cell division.
5 How do chloroplasts reproduce?	pinch in two	1
6 What influences chloroplasts behavior?	environmental factors like light color and intensity	2
7 How are chloroplasts similar to mitochondria?	contain their own DNA	3
8 What was the ancestor of chloroplasts?	a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell	3
9 How do plants get chloroplasts?	must be inherited by each daughter cell during cell division	4
1 Chloroplasts are one of many types of organelles in the plant cell.
2 They are considered to have originated from cyanobacteria through endosymbiosis—when a eukaryotic cell engulfed a photosynthesizing cyanobacterium that became a permanent resident in the cell.
3 Mitochondria are thought to have come from a similar event where an aerobic prokaryote was engulfed.
4 This origin of chloroplasts was first suggested by the Russian biologist Konstantin Mereschkowski in 1905 after Andreas Schimper observed in 1883 that chloroplasts closely resemble cyanobacteria.
5 Chloroplasts are only found in plants and algae.
6 Which organisms have chloroplasts?	plants and algae	5
7 What nationality was Konstantin Mereschkowski?	Russian	4
8 What was Konstantin Mereschkowskis career?	biologist	4
9 When did Konstantin Mereschkowski suggest the origin of chloroplasts?	1905	4
10 Who said chloroplasts are similar to cyanobacteria?	Andreas Schimper	4
1 Cyanobacteria are considered the ancestors of chloroplasts.
2 They are sometimes called bluegreen algae even though they are prokaryotes.
3 They are a diverse phylum of bacteria capable of carrying out photosynthesis and are gramnegative meaning that they have two cell membranes.
4 Cyanobacteria also contain a peptidoglycan cell wall which is thicker than in other gramnegative bacteria and which is located between their two cell membranes.
5 Like chloroplasts they have thylakoids within.
6 On the thylakoid membranes are photosynthetic pigments including chlorophyll a Phycobilins are also common cyanobacterial pigments usually organized into hemispherical phycobilisomes attached to the outside of the thylakoid membranes phycobilins are not shared with all chloroplasts though.
7 What are chloroplasts descended from?	Cyanobacteria	1
8 What type of organism are cyanobacteria?	prokaryotes	2
9 What does gramnegative mean?	they have two cell membranes	3
10 What kind of cell wall do cyanobacteria have?	peptidoglycan	4
11 How are cyanobacteria sometimes wrongly described?	bluegreen algae	2
1 Somewhere around a billion years ago a freeliving cyanobacterium entered an early eukaryotic cell either as food or as an internal parasite but managed to escape the phagocytic vacuole it was contained in.
2 The two innermost lipidbilayer membranes that surround all chloroplasts correspond to the outer and inner membranes of the ancestral cyanobacteriums gram negative cell wall and not the phagosomal membrane from the host which was probably lost.
3 The new cellular resident quickly became an advantage providing food for the eukaryotic host which allowed it to live within it.
4 Over time the cyanobacterium was assimilated and many of its genes were lost or transferred to the nucleus of the host.
5 Some of its proteins were then synthesized in the cytoplasm of the host cell and imported back into the chloroplast formerly the cyanobacterium.
6 What kind of cell did cynaobacteria enter long ago?	eukaryotic	1
7 How long ago did cyanobacteria enter a cell?	around a billion years ago	1
8 What surrounds chloroplasts?	two innermost lipidbilayer membranes	2
9 What kind of membrane came from the host?	phagosomal	2
10 What happened when cyanobacteria was assimilated?	many of its genes were lost or transferred to the nucleus of the host	4
1 These chloroplasts which can be traced back directly to a cyanobacterial ancestor are known as primary plastids plastid in this context means almost the same thing as chloroplast.
2 All primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages—the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage the rhodophyte or red algal chloroplast lineage or the chloroplastidan or green chloroplast lineage.
3 The second two are the largest and the green chloroplast lineage is the one that contains the land plants.
4 What does plastid mean?	almost the same thing as chloroplast	1
5 How many chloroplast lineages are there?	three	2
6 What does rhodophyte mean?	red algal chloroplast	2
7 What does chloroplastidan mean?	green chloroplast	2
8 Which lineage includes land plants?	the green chloroplast lineage	3
1 The alga Cyanophora a glaucophyte is thought to be one of the first organisms to contain a chloroplast.
2 The glaucophyte chloroplast group is the smallest of the three primary chloroplast lineages being found in only 13 species and is thought to be the one that branched off the earliest.
3 Glaucophytes have chloroplasts that retain a peptidoglycan wall between their double membranes like their cyanobacterial parent.
4 For this reason glaucophyte chloroplasts are also known as muroplasts.
5 Glaucophyte chloroplasts also contain concentric unstacked thylakoids which surround a carboxysome  an icosahedral structure that glaucophyte chloroplasts and cyanobacteria keep their carbon fixation enzyme rubisco in.
6 The starch that they synthesize collects outside the chloroplast.
7 Like cyanobacteria glaucophyte chloroplast thylakoids are studded with light collecting structures called phycobilisomes.
8 For these reasons glaucophyte chloroplasts are considered a primitive intermediate between cyanobacteria and the more evolved chloroplasts in red algae and plants.
9 What chloroplast lineage is Cyanophora in?	glaucophyte	1
10 What kind of organism is Cyanophora?	alga	1
11 What are muroplasts?	glaucophyte chloroplasts	4
12 What do concentric unstacked thylakoids surround?	a carboxysome	5
13 What kind of structure is a carboxysome?	icosahedral	5
1 Rhodoplasts have a double membrane with an intermembrane space and phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes on the thylakoid membranes preventing their thylakoids from stacking.
2 Some contain pyrenoids.
3 Rhodoplasts have chlorophyll a and phycobilins for photosynthetic pigments the phycobilin phycoerytherin is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive red color.
4 However since they also contain the bluegreen chlorophyll a and other pigments many are reddish to purple from the combination.
5 The red phycoerytherin pigment is an adaptation to help red algae catch more sunlight in deep water—as such some red algae that live in shallow water have less phycoerytherin in their rhodoplasts and can appear more greenish.
6 Rhodoplasts synthesize a form of starch called floridean which collects into granules outside the rhodoplast in the cytoplasm of the red alga.
7 What kinds of pigments do rhodoplasts have?	chlorophyll a and phycobilins	3
8 What are rhodoplasts phycobilin pigments combined into?	phycobilisomes	1
9 What makes red algae red?	the phycobilin phycoerytherin	3
10 What is the benefit of red algae being red?	catch more sunlight in deep water	5
11 What is floridean?	a form of starch	6
1 The chloroplastidan chloroplasts or green chloroplasts are another large highly diverse primary chloroplast lineage.
2 Their host organisms are commonly known as the green algae and land plants.
3 They differ from glaucophyte and red algal chloroplasts in that they have lost their phycobilisomes and contain chlorophyll b instead.
4 Most green chloroplasts are obviously green though some arent like some forms of Hæmatococcus pluvialis due to accessory pigments that override the chlorophylls green colors.
5 Chloroplastidan chloroplasts have lost the peptidoglycan wall between their double membrane and have replaced it with an intermembrane space.
6 Some plants seem to have kept the genes for the synthesis of the peptidoglycan layer though theyve been repurposed for use in chloroplast division instead.
7 What do red algal chloroplasts have that green chloroplasts dont?	phycobilisomes	3
8 Why arent some forms of Hæmatococcus pluvialis green?	accessory pigments that override the chlorophylls green colors	4
9 What dont chloroplastidan chloroplasts have?	the peptidoglycan wall	5
10 What have some plants repurposed the peptidoglycan layer genes for?	chloroplast division	6
11 What do green chloroplasts have instead of phycobilisomes?	chlorophyll b	3
1 While primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplastcontaining alga but failed to digest it—much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story.
2 The engulfed alga was broken down leaving only its chloroplast and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus forming a chloroplast with three or four membranes—the two cyanobacterial membranes sometimes the eaten algas cell membrane and the phagosomal vacuole from the hosts cell membrane.
3 What kind of membrane do primary chloroplasts have?	double	1
4 What differs about secondary chloroplasts membranes?	additional membranes outside of the original two	1
5 What was the secondary endosymbiotic event?	a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplastcontaining alga but failed to digest it	1
6 What additional membranes do secondary chloroplasts have?	sometimes the eaten algas cell membrane  and the phagosomal vacuole from the hosts cell membrane	2
7 What was left when engulfed algae was broken down?	its chloroplast  and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus	2
1 Euglenophytes are a group of common flagellated protists that contain chloroplasts derived from a green alga.
2 Euglenophyte chloroplasts have three membranes—it is thought that the membrane of the primary endosymbiont was lost leaving the cyanobacterial membranes and the secondary hosts phagosomal membrane.
3 Euglenophyte chloroplasts have a pyrenoid and thylakoids stacked in groups of three.
4 Starch is stored in the form of paramylon which is contained in membranebound granules in the cytoplasm of the euglenophyte.
5 What kind of chloroplasts do Euglenophytes have?	chloroplasts derived from a green alga	1
6 What kind of protists are Euglenophytes?	common flagellated	1
7 How are the pyrenoid and thylakoids arranged?	stacked in groups of three	3
8 What does paramylon store?	Starch	4
9 Which membrane was lost in euglenophyte chloroplasts?	the membrane of the primary endosymbiont	2
1 Cryptophytes or cryptomonads are a group of algae that contain a redalgal derived chloroplast.
2 Cryptophyte chloroplasts contain a nucleomorph that superficially resembles that of the chlorarachniophytes.
3 Cryptophyte chloroplasts have four membranes the outermost of which is continuous with the rough endoplasmic reticulum.
4 They synthesize ordinary starch which is stored in granules found in the periplastid space—outside the original double membrane in the place that corresponds to the red algas cytoplasm.
5 Inside cryptophyte chloroplasts is a pyrenoid and thylakoids in stacks of two.
6 What is another word for cryptophytes?	cryptomonads	1
7 What kind of chloroplasts do cryptophytes have?	redalgal derived chloroplast	1
8 What part of cryptophyte chloroplasts is similar to chlorarachniophytes?	nucleomorph	2
9 Where do cryptophyte chloroplasts store starch?	in granules found in the periplastid space	4
10 How do cryptophyte chloroplasts arrange their pyrenoid and thylakoids?	stacks of two	5
1 Apicomplexans are another group of chromalveolates.
2 Like the helicosproidia theyre parasitic and have a nonphotosynthetic chloroplast.
3 They were once thought to be related to the helicosproidia but it is now known that the helicosproida are green algae rather than chromalveolates.
4 The apicomplexans include Plasmodium the malaria parasite.
5 Many apicomplexans keep a vestigial red algal derived chloroplast called an apicoplast which they inherited from their ancestors.
6 Other apicomplexans like Cryptosporidium have lost the chloroplast completely.
7 Apicomplexans store their energy in amylopectin starch granules that are located in their cytoplasm even though they are nonphotosynthetic.
8 What are Apicomplexans similar to?	helicosproidia	2
9 What are Apicomplexans a type of?	chromalveolates	1
10 What is Plasmodium?	the malaria parasite	4
11 What is an apicoplast?	a vestigial red algal derived chloroplast	5
12 Where do Apicomplexans store energy?	in amylopectin starch granules that are located in their cytoplasm	7
1 Apicoplasts have lost all photosynthetic function and contain no photosynthetic pigments or true thylakoids.
2 They are bounded by four membranes but the membranes are not connected to the endoplasmic reticulum.
3 The fact that apicomplexans still keep their nonphotosynthetic chloroplast around demonstrates how the chloroplast carries out important functions other than photosynthesis.
4 Plant chloroplasts provide plant cells with many important things besides sugar and apicoplasts are no different—they synthesize fatty acids isopentenyl pyrophosphate ironsulfur clusters and carry out part of the heme pathway.
5 This makes the apicoplast an attractive target for drugs to cure apicomplexanrelated diseases.
6 The most important apicoplast function is isopentenyl pyrophosphate synthesis—in fact apicomplexans die when something interferes with this apicoplast function and when apicomplexans are grown in an isopentenyl pyrophosphaterich medium they dump the organelle.
7 What do apicoplasts synthesize?	fatty acids  isopentenyl pyrophosphate  ironsulfur clusters	4
8 What kind of diseases do drugs target apicoplasts for?	apicomplexanrelated diseases	5
9 What is the most important thing apicoplasts do?	isopentenyl pyrophosphate synthesis	6
10 What are apicoplasts missing?	photosynthetic pigments or true thylakoids	1
11 How many membranes do apicoplasts have?	four	2
1 The most common dinophyte chloroplast is the peridinintype chloroplast characterized by the carotenoid pigment peridinin in their chloroplasts along with chlorophyll a and chlorophyll c2.
2 Peridinin is not found in any other group of chloroplasts.
3 The peridinin chloroplast is bounded by three membranes occasionally two having lost the red algal endosymbionts original cell membrane.
4 The outermost membrane is not connected to the endoplasmic reticulum.
5 They contain a pyrenoid and have tripletstacked thylakoids.
6 Starch is found outside the chloroplast An important feature of these chloroplasts is that their chloroplast DNA is highly reduced and fragmented into many small circles.
7 Most of the genome has migrated to the nucleus and only critical photosynthesisrelated genes remain in the chloroplast.
8 What is only found in peridinintype chloroplasts?	Peridinin	2
9 Where is Peridinin found?	peridinintype chloroplast	1
10 How are peridinintype chloroplasts thylakoids arranged?	tripletstacked	5
11 What have peridinintype chloroplasts lost?	the red algal endosymbionts original cell membrane	3
1 The fucoxanthin dinophyte lineages including Karlodinium and Karenia lost their original red algal derived chloroplast and replaced it with a new chloroplast derived from a haptophyte endosymbiont.
2 Karlodinium and Karenia probably took up different heterokontophytes.
3 Because the haptophyte chloroplast has four membranes tertiary endosymbiosis would be expected to create a six membraned chloroplast adding the haptophytes cell membrane and the dinophytes phagosomal vacuole.
4 However the haptophyte was heavily reduced stripped of a few membranes and its nucleus leaving only its chloroplast with its original double membrane and possibly one or two additional membranes around it.
5 What lineage is Karlodinium in?	fucoxanthin dinophyte	1
6 What lineage is Karenia in?	fucoxanthin dinophyte	1
7 How many membranes does the haptophyte chloroplast have?	four	3
8 What is tertiary endosymbiosis of haptophyte chloroplasts expected to create?	a six membraned chloroplast	3
1 Members of the genus Dinophysis have a phycobilincontaining chloroplast taken from a cryptophyte.
2 However the cryptophyte is not an endosymbiont—only the chloroplast seems to have been taken and the chloroplast has been stripped of its nucleomorph and outermost two membranes leaving just a twomembraned chloroplast.
3 Cryptophyte chloroplasts require their nucleomorph to maintain themselves and Dinophysis species grown in cell culture alone cannot survive so it is possible but not confirmed that the Dinophysis chloroplast is a kleptoplast—if so Dinophysis chloroplasts wear out and Dinophysis species must continually engulf cryptophytes to obtain new chloroplasts to replace the old ones.
4 Where did Dinophysis get its chloroplasts from?	a cryptophyte	1
5 What have the Dinophysis chloroplasts lost?	its nucleomorph and outermost two membranes	2
6 What is the chloroplast of Dinophysis?	a phycobilincontaining chloroplast	1
7 What is left of the Dinophysis chloroplasts?	a twomembraned chloroplast	2
1 Some dinophytes like Kryptoperidinium and Durinskia have a diatom heterokontophyte derived chloroplast.
2 These chloroplasts are bounded by up to five membranes depending on whether you count the entire diatom endosymbiont as the chloroplast or just the red algal derived chloroplast inside it.
3 The diatom endosymbiont has been reduced relatively little—it still retains its original mitochondria and has endoplasmic reticulum ribosomes a nucleus and of course red algal derived chloroplasts—practically a complete cell all inside the hosts endoplasmic reticulum lumen.
4 However the diatom endosymbiont cant store its own food—its starch is found in granules in the dinophyte hosts cytoplasm instead.
5 The diatom endosymbionts nucleus is present but it probably cant be called a nucleomorph because it shows no sign of genome reduction and might have even been expanded.
6 Diatoms have been engulfed by dinoflagellates at least three times.
7 What is another word for diatom?	heterokontophyte	1
8 What is Durinskias chloroplast?	a diatom heterokontophyte derived chloroplast	1
9 How many membranes does Durinskias chloroplast have?	up to five	2
10 What is sometimes but not always counted regarding Durinskias chloroplast membranes?	the entire diatom endosymbiont as the chloroplast	2
11 Where does the diatom endosymbiont store starch?	granules in the dinophyte hosts cytoplasm	4
1 Lepidodinium viride and its close relatives are dinophytes that lost their original peridinin chloroplast and replaced it with a green algal derived chloroplast more specifically a prasinophyte.
2 Lepidodinium is the only dinophyte that has a chloroplast thats not from the rhodoplast lineage.
3 The chloroplast is surrounded by two membranes and has no nucleomorph—all the nucleomorph genes have been transferred to the dinophyte nucleus.
4 The endosymbiotic event that led to this chloroplast was serial secondary endosymbiosis rather than tertiary endosymbiosis—the endosymbiont was a green alga containing a primary chloroplast making a secondary chloroplast.
5 Where do nucleomorph genes transfer to?	the dinophyte nucleus	3
6 What is the only dinophyte that has a nonrhodoplast chloroplast?	Lepidodinium	2
7 What did Lepidodinium viride lose?	their original peridinin chloroplast	1
8 What did Lepidodinium viride replace their original chloroplast with?	a green algal derived chloroplast	1
9 What is a prasinophyte?	a green algal derived chloroplast	1
1 While most chloroplasts originate from that first set of endosymbiotic events Paulinella chromatophora is an exception that acquired a photosynthetic cyanobacterial endosymbiont more recently.
2 It is not clear whether that symbiont is closely related to the ancestral chloroplast of other eukaryotes.
3 Being in the early stages of endosymbiosis Paulinella chromatophora can offer some insights into how chloroplasts evolved.
4 Paulinella cells contain one or two sausage shaped bluegreen photosynthesizing structures called chromatophores descended from the cyanobacterium Synechococcus.
5 Chromatophores cannot survive outside their host.
6 Chromatophore DNA is about a million base pairs long containing around 850 protein encoding genes—far less than the three million base pair Synechococcus genome but much larger than the approximately 150000 base pair genome of the more assimilated chloroplast.
7 Chromatophores have transferred much less of their DNA to the nucleus of their host.
8 About 03–08 of the nuclear DNA in Paulinella is from the chromatophore compared with 11–14 from the chloroplast in plants.
9 Where did most chloroplasts come from?	first set of endosymbiotic events	1
10 What is different about Paulinella chromatophora?	acquired a photosynthetic cyanobacterial endosymbiont more recently	1
11 How many base pairs are there in Chromatophore DNA?	about a million	6
12 How many proteinencoding genes are there in Chromatophore DNA?	around 850	6
13 How many base pairs are there in Synechococcus DNA?	three million	6
1 Chloroplasts have their own DNA often abbreviated as ctDNA or cpDNA.
2 It is also known as the plastome.
3 Its existence was first proved in 1962 and first sequenced in 1986—when two Japanese research teams sequenced the chloroplast DNA of liverwort and tobacco.
4 Since then hundreds of chloroplast DNAs from various species have been sequenced but theyre mostly those of land plants and green algae—glaucophytes red algae and other algal groups are extremely underrepresented potentially introducing some bias in views of typical chloroplast DNA structure and content.
5 What is chloroplast DNA abbreviated as?	ctDNA  or cpDNA	1
6 What is a synonym for chloroplast DNA?	the plastome	2
7 When was the plastome discovered?	1962	3
8 When was the first plastome sequenced?	1986	3
9 Who sequenced the first plastome?	two Japanese research teams	3
1 The inverted repeat regions are highly conserved among land plants and accumulate few mutations.
2 Similar inverted repeats exist in the genomes of cyanobacteria and the other two chloroplast lineages glaucophyta and rhodophyceæ suggesting that they predate the chloroplast though some chloroplast DNAs have since lost or flipped the inverted repeats making them direct repeats.
3 It is possible that the inverted repeats help stabilize the rest of the chloroplast genome as chloroplast DNAs which have lost some of the inverted repeat segments tend to get rearranged more.
4 What seldom mutates?	The inverted repeat regions	1
5 What have some inverted repeats become?	direct repeats	2
6 What could inverted repeats help do?	stabilize the rest of the chloroplast genome	3
1 The mechanism for chloroplast DNA cpDNA replication has not been conclusively determined but two main models have been proposed.
2 Scientists have attempted to observe chloroplast replication via electron microscopy since the 1970s.
3 The results of the microscopy experiments led to the idea that chloroplast DNA replicates using a double displacement loop Dloop.
4 As the Dloop moves through the circular DNA it adopts a theta intermediary form also known as a Cairns replication intermediate and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism.
5 Transcription starts at specific points of origin.
6 Multiple replication forks open up allowing replication machinery to transcribe the DNA.
7 As replication continues the forks grow and eventually converge.
8 The new cpDNA structures separate creating daughter cpDNA chromosomes.
9 How is chloroplast replication observed?	electron microscopy	2
10 How many major chloroplast replication models have been suggested?	two	1
11 What is a Cairns replication intermediate?	a theta intermediary form	4
12 What is a Dloop?	a Cairns replication intermediate	4
13 How does the Dloop finish replicating?	with a rolling circle mechanism	4
1 In cpDNA there are several A → G deamination gradients.
2 DNA becomes susceptible to deamination events when it is single stranded.
3 When replication forks form the strand not being copied is single stranded and thus at risk for A → G deamination.
4 Therefore gradients in deamination indicate that replication forks were most likely present and the direction that they initially opened the highest gradient is most likely nearest the start site because it was single stranded for the longest amount of time.
5 This mechanism is still the leading theory today however a second theory suggests that most cpDNA is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination.
6 It further contends that only a minority of the genetic material is kept in circular chromosomes while the rest is in branched linear or other complex structures.
7 What kind of gradients does cpDNA have?	A → G deamination	1
8 What makes DNA vulnerable to deamination?	when it is single stranded	2
9 How does the secondary theory say most cpDNA is structured?	linear	5
10 How does the secondary theory say most cpDNA replicates?	homologous recombination	5
11 Where does the secondary theory say most genes are kept?	in branched  linear  or other complex structures	6
1 One of competing model for cpDNA replication asserts that most cpDNA is linear and participates in homologous recombination and replication structures similar to bacteriophage T4.
2 It has been established that some plants have linear cpDNA such as maize and that more species still contain complex structures that scientists do not yet understand.
3 When the original experiments on cpDNA were performed scientists did notice linear structures however they attributed these linear forms to broken circles.
4 If the branched and complex structures seen in cpDNA experiments are real and not artifacts of concatenated circular DNA or broken circles then a Dloop mechanism of replication is insufficient to explain how those structures would replicate.
5 At the same time homologous recombination does not expand the multiple A  G gradients seen in plastomes.
6 Because of the failure to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpDNA the predominant theory continues to hold that most cpDNA is circular and most likely replicates via a D loop mechanism.
7 What is cpDNAs replication similar to?	bacteriophage T4	1
8 What kind of cpDNA does maize have?	linear	2
9 How is most plants cpDNA arranged?	circular	6
10 How does most plants cpDNA replicate?	via a D loop mechanism	6
1 Endosymbiotic gene transfer is how we know about the lost chloroplasts in many chromalveolate lineages.
2 Even if a chloroplast is eventually lost the genes it donated to the former hosts nucleus persist providing evidence for the lost chloroplasts existence.
3 For example while diatoms a heterokontophyte now have a red algal derived chloroplast the presence of many green algal genes in the diatom nucleus provide evidence that the diatom ancestor probably the ancestor of all chromalveolates too had a green algal derived chloroplast at some point which was subsequently replaced by the red chloroplast.
4 What shows us lost chloroplasts?	Endosymbiotic gene transfer	1
5 What do donated genes give evidence of?	the lost chloroplasts existence	2
6 What kind of chloroplasts do diatoms have?	a red algal derived chloroplast	3
7 What kind of chloroplasts did diatoms have but lost?	green algal derived chloroplast	3
1 Curiously around half of the protein products of transferred genes arent even targeted back to the chloroplast.
2 Many became exaptations taking on new functions like participating in cell division protein routing and even disease resistance.
3 A few chloroplast genes found new homes in the mitochondrial genome—most became nonfunctional pseudogenes though a few tRNA genes still work in the mitochondrion.
4 Some transferred chloroplast DNA protein products get directed to the secretory pathway though it should be noted that many secondary plastids are bounded by an outermost membrane derived from the hosts cell membrane and therefore topologically outside of the cell because to reach the chloroplast from the cytosol you have to cross the cell membrane just like if you were headed for the extracellular space.
5 In those cases chloroplasttargeted proteins do initially travel along the secretory pathway.
6 What is the status of most chloroplast genes in the mitochondrion?	nonfunctional pseudogenes	3
7 How much of the protein products of transferred genes dont go back to chloroplasts?	around half	1
8 What new tasks do the protein products of transferred genes take on?	participating in cell division  protein routing  and even disease resistance	2
9 What do you have to cross to reach the chloroplast in many secondary plastids?	the cell membrane	4
1 After a chloroplast polypeptide is synthesized on a ribosome in the cytosol an enzyme specific to chloroplast proteins phosphorylates or adds a phosphate group to many but not all of them in their transit sequences.
2 Phosphorylation helps many proteins bind the polypeptide keeping it from folding prematurely.
3 This is important because it prevents chloroplast proteins from assuming their active form and carrying out their chloroplast functions in the wrong place—the cytosol.
4 At the same time they have to keep just enough shape so that they can be recognized by the chloroplast.
5 These proteins also help the polypeptide get imported into the chloroplast.
6 What is the chloroplast polypeptide synthesized on?	a ribosome	1
7 Where is the chloroplast polypeptide synthesized?	in the cytosol	1
8 What does Phosphorylation do?	helps many proteins bind the polypeptide	2
9 What is the benefit of polypeptide binding?	keeping it from folding prematurely	2
1 In land plants chloroplasts are generally lensshaped 5–8 μm in diameter and 1–3 μm thick.
2 Greater diversity in chloroplast shapes exists among the algae which often contain a single chloroplast that can be shaped like a net eg Oedogonium a cup eg Chlamydomonas a ribbonlike spiral around the edges of the cell eg Spirogyra or slightly twisted bands at the cell edges eg Sirogonium.
3 Some algae have two chloroplasts in each cell they are starshaped in Zygnema or may follow the shape of half the cell in order Desmidiales.
4 In some algae the chloroplast takes up most of the cell with pockets for the nucleus and other organelles for example some species of Chlorella have a cupshaped chloroplast that occupies much of the cell.
5 How are chloroplasts in land plants usually shaped?	lensshaped	1
6 How large across are chloroplasts in land plants?	5–8 μm in diameter	1
7 How thick are chloroplasts in land plants?	1–3 μm	1
8 What shape is Oedogoniums chloroplasts?	a net	2
9 What shape is Chlamydomonass chloroplasts?	a cup	2
1 There are some common misconceptions about the outer and inner chloroplast membranes.
2 The fact that chloroplasts are surrounded by a double membrane is often cited as evidence that they are the descendants of endosymbiotic cyanobacteria.
3 This is often interpreted as meaning the outer chloroplast membrane is the product of the hosts cell membrane infolding to form a vesicle to surround the ancestral cyanobacterium—which is not true—both chloroplast membranes are homologous to the cyanobacteriums original double membranes.
4 What is evidence chloroplasts descended from endosymbiotic cyanobacteria?	a double membrane	2
5 What is incorrectly thought about the outer chloroplast membrane?	the product of the hosts cell membrane infolding to form a vesicle to surround the ancestral cyanobacterium	3
6 How do both chloroplast membranes compare to cyanobacteriums original double membranes?	homologous	3
1 The chloroplast double membrane is also often compared to the mitochondrial double membrane.
2 This is not a valid comparison—the inner mitochondria membrane is used to run proton pumps and carry out oxidative phosphorylation across to generate ATP energy.
3 The only chloroplast structure that can considered analogous to it is the internal thylakoid system.
4 Even so in terms of inout the direction of chloroplast H ion flow is in the opposite direction compared to oxidative phosphorylation in mitochondria.
5 In addition in terms of function the inner chloroplast membrane which regulates metabolite passage and synthesizes some materials has no counterpart in the mitochondrion.
6 What is the chloroplast double membrane sometimes compared to?	the mitochondrial double membrane	1
7 What does the inner mitochondria membrane do?	run proton pumps and carry out oxidative phosphorylation	2
8 What does oxidative phosphorylation do?	generate ATP energy	2
9 What chloroplast structure is similar to the inner mitochondria membrane?	the internal thylakoid system	3
10 What part of chloroplasts isnt similar to mitochondria?	the inner chloroplast membrane	5
1 The chloroplast membranes sometimes protrude out into the cytoplasm forming a stromule or stromacontaining tubule.
2 Stromules are very rare in chloroplasts and are much more common in other plastids like chromoplasts and amyloplasts in petals and roots respectively.
3 They may exist to increase the chloroplasts surface area for crossmembrane transport because they are often branched and tangled with the endoplasmic reticulum.
4 When they were first observed in 1962 some plant biologists dismissed the structures as artifactual claiming that stromules were just oddly shaped chloroplasts with constricted regions or dividing chloroplasts.
5 However there is a growing body of evidence that stromules are functional integral features of plant cell plastids not merely artifacts.
6 What are more common in other plastids than chloroplasts?	Stromules	2
7 What is a stromule?	stromacontaining tubule	1
8 Why do stromules exist?	to increase the chloroplasts surface area for crossmembrane transport	3
9 When were stromules discovered?	1962	4
1 Some chloroplasts contain a structure called the chloroplast peripheral reticulum.
2 It is often found in the chloroplasts of C4 plants though it has also been found in some C3 angiosperms and even some gymnosperms.
3 The chloroplast peripheral reticulum consists of a maze of membranous tubes and vesicles continuous with the inner chloroplast membrane that extends into the internal stromal fluid of the chloroplast.
4 Its purpose is thought to be to increase the chloroplasts surface area for crossmembrane transport between its stroma and the cell cytoplasm.
5 The small vesicles sometimes observed may serve as transport vesicles to shuttle stuff between the thylakoids and intermembrane space.
6 Where is the chloroplast peripheral reticulum usually found?	in the chloroplasts of C4 plants	2
7 Where is the chloroplast peripheral reticulum less commonly found?	in some C3 angiosperms  and even some gymnosperms	2
8 What is a maze of membranous tubes?	The chloroplast peripheral reticulum	3
9 What does the chloroplast peripheral reticulum do?	increase the chloroplasts surface area for crossmembrane transport	4
10 Where do transport vesicles move between?	the thylakoids and intermembrane space	5
1 Chloroplasts have their own ribosomes which they use to synthesize a small fraction of their proteins.
2 Chloroplast ribosomes are about twothirds the size of cytoplasmic ribosomes around 17 nm vs 25 nm.
3 They take mRNAs transcribed from the chloroplast DNA and translate them into protein.
4 While similar to bacterial ribosomes chloroplast translation is more complex than in bacteria so chloroplast ribosomes include some chloroplastunique features.
5 Small subunit ribosomal RNAs in several Chlorophyta and euglenid chloroplasts lack motifs for shinedalgarno sequence recognition which is considered essential for translation initiation in most chloroplasts and prokaryotes.
6 Such loss is also rarely observed in other plastids and prokaryotes.
7 What do chloroplasts use their ribosomes for?	synthesize a small fraction of their proteins	1
8 How large are Chloroplast ribosomes?	17 nm	2
9 How large are Cytoplasmic ribosomes?	25 nm	2
10 What are some Chlorophyta and euglenid chloroplasts missing?	motifs for shinedalgarno sequence recognition	5
11 Why is shinedalgarno sequence recognition important?	is considered essential for translation initiation in most chloroplasts and prokaryotes	5
1 Plastoglobuli singular plastoglobulus sometimes spelled plastoglobules are spherical bubbles of lipids and proteins about 45–60 nanometers across.
2 They are surrounded by a lipid monolayer.
3 Plastoglobuli are found in all chloroplasts but become more common when the chloroplast is under oxidative stress or when it ages and transitions into a gerontoplast.
4 Plastoglobuli also exhibit a greater size variation under these conditions.
5 They are also common in etioplasts but decrease in number as the etioplasts mature into chloroplasts.
6 What is a single Plastoglobuli called?	plastoglobulus  sometimes spelled plastoglobules	1
7 What shape are Plastoglobuli?	spherical bubbles	1
8 What are Plastoglobuli made of?	lipids and proteins	1
9 How large are Plastoglobuli?	45–60 nanometers across	1
10 What surrounds Plastoglobuli?	a lipid monolayer	2
1 Plastoglobuli were once thought to be freefloating in the stroma but it is now thought that they are permanently attached either to a thylakoid or to another plastoglobulus attached to a thylakoid a configuration that allows a plastoglobulus to exchange its contents with the thylakoid network.
2 In normal green chloroplasts the vast majority of plastoglobuli occur singularly attached directly to their parent thylakoid.
3 In old or stressed chloroplasts plastoglobuli tend to occur in linked groups or chains still always anchored to a thylakoid.
4 What are Plastoglobuli attached to?	either to a thylakoid or to another plastoglobulus attached to a thylakoid	1
5 What do Plastoglobuli exchange contents with?	the thylakoid network	1
6 How are green chloroplasts Plastoglobuli arranged?	singularly  attached directly to their parent thylakoid	2
7 When do Plastoglobuli occur in linked groups?	In old or stressed chloroplasts	3
1 The chloroplasts of some hornworts and algae contain structures called pyrenoids.
2 They are not found in higher plants.
3 Pyrenoids are roughly spherical and highly refractive bodies which are a site of starch accumulation in plants that contain them.
4 They consist of a matrix opaque to electrons surrounded by two hemispherical starch plates.
5 The starch is accumulated as the pyrenoids mature.
6 In algae with carbon concentrating mechanisms the enzyme rubisco is found in the pyrenoids.
7 Starch can also accumulate around the pyrenoids when CO2 is scarce.
8 Pyrenoids can divide to form new pyrenoids or be produced de novo.
9 Where are pyrenoids found?	The chloroplasts of some hornworts and algae	1
10 What shape are pyrenoids?	roughly spherical	3
11 What do pyrenoids look like?	highly refractive	3
12 What do pyrenoids store?	starch	3
13 How can pyrenoids replicate?	divide to form new pyrenoids  or be produced de novo	8
1 In the helical thylakoid model grana consist of a stack of flattened circular granal thylakoids that resemble pancakes.
2 Each granum can contain anywhere from two to a hundred thylakoids though grana with 10–20 thylakoids are most common.
3 Wrapped around the grana are helicoid stromal thylakoids also known as frets or lamellar thylakoids.
4 The helices ascend at an angle of 20–25° connecting to each granal thylakoid at a bridgelike slit junction.
5 The helicoids may extend as large sheets that link multiple grana or narrow to tubelike bridges between grana.
6 While different parts of the thylakoid system contain different membrane proteins the thylakoid membranes are continuous and the thylakoid space they enclose form a single continuous labyrinth.
7 In what model do grana look like pancakes?	the helical thylakoid model	1
8 What shape are granal thylakoids?	flattened circular	1
9 How many granal thylakoids can be in each granum?	anywhere from two to a hundred	2
10 How many granal thylakoids are usually in each granum?	10–20	2
11 What are frets?	helicoid stromal thylakoids	3
1 Embedded in the thylakoid membranes are important protein complexes which carry out the light reactions of photosynthesis.
2 Photosystem II and photosystem I contain lightharvesting complexes with chlorophyll and carotenoids that absorb light energy and use it to energize electrons.
3 Molecules in the thylakoid membrane use the energized electrons to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space decreasing the pH and turning it acidic.
4 ATP synthase is a large protein complex that harnesses the concentration gradient of the hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space to generate ATP energy as the hydrogen ions flow back out into the stroma—much like a dam turbine.
5 What does chlorophyll absorb?	light energy	2
6 What do carotenoids absorb?	light energy	2
7 What does chlorophyll use light energy to do?	energize electrons	2
8 What does the thylakoid membrane use the energized electrons for?	pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space	3
9 What is ATP synthase similar to?	a dam turbine	4
1 There are two types of thylakoids—granal thylakoids which are arranged in grana and stromal thylakoids which are in contact with the stroma.
2 Granal thylakoids are pancakeshaped circular disks about 300–600 nanometers in diameter.
3 Stromal thylakoids are helicoid sheets that spiral around grana.
4 The flat tops and bottoms of granal thylakoids contain only the relatively flat photosystem II protein complex.
5 This allows them to stack tightly forming grana with many layers of tightly appressed membrane called granal membrane increasing stability and surface area for light capture.
6 How many types of thylakoids are there?	two	1
7 What distinguishes granal thylakoids?	are arranged in grana	1
8 What distinguishes stromal thylakoids?	are in contact with the stroma	1
9 What shape are granal thylakoids?	pancakeshaped circular disks	2
10 How large are granal thylakoids?	about 300–600 nanometers in diameter	2
1 In addition to chlorophylls another group of yellow–orange pigments called carotenoids are also found in the photosystems.
2 There are about thirty photosynthetic carotenoids.
3 They help transfer and dissipate excess energy and their bright colors sometimes override the chlorophyll green like during the fall when the leaves of some land plants change color.
4 βcarotene is a bright redorange carotenoid found in nearly all chloroplasts like chlorophyll a Xanthophylls especially the orangered zeaxanthin are also common.
5 Many other forms of carotenoids exist that are only found in certain groups of chloroplasts.
6 How many photosynthetic carotenoids are there?	about thirty	2
7 What do photosynthetic carotenoids do?	help transfer and dissipate excess energy	3
8 Why do carotenoids make leaves change color in the fall?	their bright colors sometimes override the chlorophyll green	3
9 What is beta carotene?	a bright redorange carotenoid	4
10 What is the most common Xanthophyll?	orangered zeaxanthin	4
1 Phycobilins are a third group of pigments found in cyanobacteria and glaucophyte red algal and cryptophyte chloroplasts.
2 Phycobilins come in all colors though phycoerytherin is one of the pigments that makes many red algae red.
3 Phycobilins often organize into relatively large protein complexes about 40 nanometers across called phycobilisomes.
4 Like photosystem I and ATP synthase phycobilisomes jut into the stroma preventing thylakoid stacking in red algal chloroplasts.
5 Cryptophyte chloroplasts and some cyanobacteria dont have their phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes and keep them in their thylakoid space instead.
6 What are Phycobilins?	e a third group of pigments found in cyanobacteria	1
7 What color is phycoerytherin?	red	2
8 What does phycoerytherin appear in?	red algae	2
9 What are phycobilisomes?	relatively large protein complexes	3
10 How big are phycobilisomes?	about 40 nanometers across	3
1 To fix carbon dioxide into sugar molecules in the process of photosynthesis chloroplasts use an enzyme called rubisco.
2 Rubisco has a problem—it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen so at high oxygen concentrations rubisco starts accidentally adding oxygen to sugar precursors.
3 This has the end result of ATP energy being wasted and CO2 being released all with no sugar being produced.
4 This is a big problem since O2 is produced by the initial light reactions of photosynthesis causing issues down the line in the Calvin cycle which uses rubisco.
5 What do chloroplasts use to fix carbon dioxide into sugar?	an enzyme called rubisco	1
6 What is rubiscos flaw?	it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen	2
7 What effect does rubiscos flaw have?	at high oxygen concentrations  rubisco starts accidentally adding oxygen to sugar precursors	2
8 What process down the line does rubiscos flaw interfere with?	the Calvin cycle	4
9 What is wasted by rubiscos flaw?	ATP energy	3
1 As a result chloroplasts in C4 mesophyll cells and bundle sheath cells are specialized for each stage of photosynthesis.
2 In mesophyll cells chloroplasts are specialized for the light reactions so they lack rubisco and have normal grana and thylakoids which they use to make ATP and NADPH as well as oxygen.
3 They store CO2 in a fourcarbon compound which is why the process is called C4 photosynthesis.
4 The fourcarbon compound is then transported to the bundle sheath chloroplasts where it drops off CO2 and returns to the mesophyll.
5 Bundle sheath chloroplasts do not carry out the light reactions preventing oxygen from building up in them and disrupting rubisco activity.
6 Because of this they lack thylakoids organized into grana stacks—though bundle sheath chloroplasts still have freefloating thylakoids in the stroma where they still carry out cyclic electron flow a lightdriven method of synthesizing ATP to power the Calvin cycle without generating oxygen.
7 They lack photosystem II and only have photosystem I—the only protein complex needed for cyclic electron flow.
8 Because the job of bundle sheath chloroplasts is to carry out the Calvin cycle and make sugar they often contain large starch grains.
9 What are chloroplasts in mesophyll cells specialized for?	light reactions	2
10 What do chloroplasts in mesophyll cells lack?	rubisco	2
11 What do chloroplasts in mesophyll cells specialized use to make ATP?	normal grana and thylakoids	2
12 What do chloroplasts in mesophyll cells store carbon dioxide in?	a fourcarbon compound	3
13 What do bundle sheath chloroplasts specialize in?	to carry out the Calvin cycle and make sugar	8
1 Not all cells in a multicellular plant contain chloroplasts.
2 All green parts of a plant contain chloroplasts—the chloroplasts or more specifically the chlorophyll in them are what make the photosynthetic parts of a plant green.
3 The plant cells which contain chloroplasts are usually parenchyma cells though chloroplasts can also be found in collenchyma tissue.
4 A plant cell which contains chloroplasts is known as a chlorenchyma cell.
5 A typical chlorenchyma cell of a land plant contains about 10 to 100 chloroplasts.
6 What parts of plants have chloroplasts?	All green parts	2
7 What makes plants green?	the chlorophyll in them	2
8 What plant cells have chloroplasts in them?	parenchyma cells	3
9 Where can chloroplasts sometimes be found?	collenchyma tissue	3
10 What is a chlorenchyma cell?	A plant cell which contains chloroplasts	4
1 In some plants such as cacti chloroplasts are found in the stems though in most plants chloroplasts are concentrated in the leaves.
2 One square millimeter of leaf tissue can contain half a million chloroplasts.
3 Within a leaf chloroplasts are mainly found in the mesophyll layers of a leaf and the guard cells of stomata.
4 Palisade mesophyll cells can contain 30–70 chloroplasts per cell while stomatal guard cells contain only around 8–15 per cell as well as much less chlorophyll.
5 Chloroplasts can also be found in the bundle sheath cells of a leaf especially in C4 plants which carry out the Calvin cycle in their bundle sheath cells.
6 They are often absent from the epidermis of a leaf.
7 Where do cacti have chloroplasts?	in the stems	1
8 Where do most plants have chloroplasts?	concentrated in the leaves	1
9 How many chloroplasts are in stomatal guard cells?	8–15 per cell	4
10 How many chloroplasts are in a square mm of a leaf?	half a million	2
11 What layers of a leaf have chloroplasts?	the mesophyll layers	3
1 The chloroplasts of plant and algal cells can orient themselves to best suit the available light.
2 In lowlight conditions they will spread out in a sheet—maximizing the surface area to absorb light.
3 Under intense light they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cells cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edgeon.
4 This reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage.
5 This ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones.
6 Chloroplast movement is considered one of the most closely regulated stimulusresponse systems that can be found in plants.
7 Mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move.
8 When do chloroplasts spread out flat?	lowlight conditions	2
9 When do chloroplasts arrange in vertical columns or turn sideways?	Under intense light	3
10 What does turning sideways protect chloroplasts from?	photooxidative damage	4
11 Why do land plants have more and smaller chloroplasts?	to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out	5
12 What sometimes follows moving chloroplasts?	Mitochondria	7
1 Plants have two main immune responses—the hypersensitive response in which infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death and systemic acquired resistance where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogens presence.
2 Chloroplasts stimulate both responses by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system producing reactive oxygen species.
3 High levels of reactive oxygen species will cause the hypersensitive response.
4 The reactive oxygen species also directly kill any pathogens within the cell.
5 Lower levels of reactive oxygen species initiate systemic acquired resistance triggering defensemolecule production in the rest of the plant.
6 How many major immune responses do plants have?	two	1
7 What is the hypersensitive response of a plant immune system?	infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death	1
8 What is the systemic acquired resistance response of a plant immune system?	infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogens presence	1
9 How do chloroplasts trigger the plants immune system?	by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system	2
10 What does damaging photosynthesis systems create?	reactive oxygen species	2
1 Chloroplasts can serve as cellular sensors.
2 After detecting stress in a cell which might be due to a pathogen chloroplasts begin producing molecules like salicylic acid jasmonic acid nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species which can serve as defensesignals.
3 As cellular signals reactive oxygen species are unstable molecules so they probably dont leave the chloroplast but instead pass on their signal to an unknown second messenger molecule.
4 All these molecules initiate retrograde signaling—signals from the chloroplast that regulate gene expression in the nucleus.
5 What molecules act as defense signals?	salicylic acid  jasmonic acid  nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species	2
6 When do chloroplasts produce defense signals?	After detecting stress in a cell	2
7 What happens to reactive oxygen species signals since they dont leave the chloroplast?	pass on their signal to an unknown second messenger molecule	3
8 What is retrograde signaling?	signals from the chloroplast that regulate gene expression in the nucleus	4
1 One of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy to subsequently produce food in the form of sugars.
2 Water H2O and carbon dioxide CO2 are used in photosynthesis and sugar and oxygen O2 is made using light energy.
3 Photosynthesis is divided into two stages—the light reactions where water is split to produce oxygen and the dark reactions or Calvin cycle which builds sugar molecules from carbon dioxide.
4 The two phases are linked by the energy carriers adenosine triphosphate ATP and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate NADP.
5 What is the most important role of chloroplasts?	photosynthesis	1
6 What is the process of changing light into chemical energy?	photosynthesis	1
7 What is chemical energy used to produce in plants?	food in the form of sugars	1
8 What are the molecular inputs for photosynthesis?	Water H2O and carbon dioxide CO2	2
9 What are the molecular outputs for photosynthesis?	sugar and oxygen O2	2
1 Like mitochondria chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy.
2 The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water and release them down an electron transport chain.
3 The molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space creating a concentration gradient with more hydrogen ions up to a thousand times as many inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma.
4 The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase.
5 ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate or ATP.
6 Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma the ATP is synthesized there in position to be used in the dark reactions.
7 What do chloroplasts do like mitochondria?	generate ATP energy	1
8 Where do chloroplasts pump hydrogen?	into the thylakoid space	3
9 How concentrated do the hydrogen ions get in the thylakoid space?	up to a thousand times	3
10 What does ATP synthase change into ATP?	phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate	5
11 What does ATP mean?	adenosine triphosphate	5
1 While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted electrons at the end of an electron transport chain.
2 Normally the reenergized electrons are taken by NADP though sometimes they can flow back down more Hpumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more ATP.
3 This is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled.
4 Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants which need more ATP than NADPH.
5 What usually takes reenergized electrons?	NADP	2
6 In what process are electrons recycled?	cyclic photophosphorylation	3
7 Where is cyclic photophosphorylation common?	in C4 plants	4
8 What do C4 plants need?	more ATP than NADPH	4
1 The Calvin cycle starts by using the enzyme Rubisco to fix CO2 into fivecarbon Ribulose bisphosphate RuBP molecules.
2 The result is unstable sixcarbon molecules that immediately break down into threecarbon molecules called 3phosphoglyceric acid or 3PGA.
3 The ATP and NADPH made in the light reactions is used to convert the 3PGA into glyceraldehyde3phosphate or G3P sugar molecules.
4 Most of the G3P molecules are recycled back into RuBP using energy from more ATP but one out of every six produced leaves the cycle—the end product of the dark reactions.
5 What cycle starts with rubisco?	The Calvin cycle	1
6 What is the result of the Calvin cycle?	unstable sixcarbon molecules that immediately break down	2
7 What do unstable 6carbon molecules become?	threecarbon molecules called 3phosphoglyceric acid	2
8 How many G3P molecules leave the cycle?	one out of every six	4
1 Alternatively glucose monomers in the chloroplast can be linked together to make starch which accumulates into the starch grains found in the chloroplast.
2 Under conditions such as high atmospheric CO2 concentrations these starch grains may grow very large distorting the grana and thylakoids.
3 The starch granules displace the thylakoids but leave them intact.
4 Waterlogged roots can also cause starch buildup in the chloroplasts possibly due to less sucrose being exported out of the chloroplast or more accurately the plant cell.
5 This depletes a plants free phosphate supply which indirectly stimulates chloroplast starch synthesis.
6 While linked to low photosynthesis rates the starch grains themselves may not necessarily interfere significantly with the efficiency of photosynthesis and might simply be a side effect of another photosynthesisdepressing factor.
7 What is an alternate way to make starch?	glucose monomers in the chloroplast can be linked together	1
8 When might starch grains become overly large?	Under conditions such as high atmospheric CO2 concentrations	2
9 What happens when starch grains become overly large?	distorting the grana and thylakoids	2
10 What root problem can cause starch buildup?	Waterlogged roots	4
11 What might starch grains be a side effect of?	another photosynthesisdepressing factor	6
1 Photorespiration can occur when the oxygen concentration is too high.
2 Rubisco cannot distinguish between oxygen and carbon dioxide very well so it can accidentally add O2 instead of CO2 to RuBP.
3 This process reduces the efficiency of photosynthesis—it consumes ATP and oxygen releases CO2 and produces no sugar.
4 It can waste up to half the carbon fixed by the Calvin cycle.
5 Several mechanisms have evolved in different lineages that raise the carbon dioxide concentration relative to oxygen within the chloroplast increasing the efficiency of photosynthesis.
6 These mechanisms are called carbon dioxide concentrating mechanisms or CCMs.
7 These include Crassulacean acid metabolism C4 carbon fixation and pyrenoids.
8 Chloroplasts in C4 plants are notable as they exhibit a distinct chloroplast dimorphism.
9 What can rubisco do by mistake?	add O2 instead of CO2 to RuBP	2
10 When does photorespiration happen?	when the oxygen concentration is too high	1
11 Why is using O2 instead of CO2 less efficient?	it consumes ATP and oxygen  releases CO2  and produces no sugar	3
12 How much carbon gets wasted by using O2 instead of CO2?	up to half the carbon fixed by the Calvin cycle	4
13 What is unusual about C4 plants chloroplasts?	they exhibit a distinct chloroplast dimorphism	8
1 Chloroplasts alone make almost all of a plant cells amino acids in their stroma except the sulfurcontaining ones like cysteine and methionine.
2 Cysteine is made in the chloroplast the proplastid too but it is also synthesized in the cytosol and mitochondria probably because it has trouble crossing membranes to get to where it is needed.
3 The chloroplast is known to make the precursors to methionine but it is unclear whether the organelle carries out the last leg of the pathway or if it happens in the cytosol.
4 Where do chloroplasts make amino acids?	in their stroma	1
5 Which amino acids contain sulfur?	cysteine and methionine	1
6 What is the problem with cysteine?	it has trouble crossing membranes to get to where it is needed	2
7 What are we unsure of about how chloroplasts make methionine precursors?	whether the organelle carries out the last leg of the pathway or if it happens in the cytosol	3
1 Chloroplasts are a special type of a plant cell organelle called a plastid though the two terms are sometimes used interchangeably.
2 There are many other types of plastids which carry out various functions.
3 All chloroplasts in a plant are descended from undifferentiated proplastids found in the zygote or fertilized egg.
4 Proplastids are commonly found in an adult plants apical meristems.
5 Chloroplasts do not normally develop from proplastids in root tip meristems—instead the formation of starchstoring amyloplasts is more common.
6 What is sometimes used interchangeably with plastids?	Chloroplasts	1
7 What do a plants chloroplasts descend from?	undifferentiated proplastids found in the zygote  or fertilized egg	3
8 Where are Proplastids usually found?	in an adult plants apical meristems	4
9 What is more often seen in root tip maristems?	the formation of starchstoring amyloplasts	5
1 If angiosperm shoots are not exposed to the required light for chloroplast formation proplastids may develop into an etioplast stage before becoming chloroplasts.
2 An etioplast is a plastid that lacks chlorophyll and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma called a prolamellar body.
3 While etioplasts lack chlorophyll they have a yellow chlorophyll precursor stocked.
4 Within a few minutes of light exposure the prolamellar body begins to reorganize into stacks of thylakoids and chlorophyll starts to be produced.
5 This process where the etioplast becomes a chloroplast takes several hours.
6 Gymnosperms do not require light to form chloroplasts.
7 What happens if angiosperm shoots dont get enough light?	proplastids may develop into an etioplast stage before becoming chloroplasts	1
8 What is an etioplast?	a plastid that lacks chlorophyll	2
9 What do etioplasts internal membranes have?	invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma	2
10 What do etioplasts have instead of chlorophyll?	a yellow chlorophyll precursor	3
11 What plants dont need light to make chloroplasts?	Gymnosperms	6
1 Plastid differentiation is not permanent in fact many interconversions are possible.
2 Chloroplasts may be converted to chromoplasts which are pigmentfilled plastids responsible for the bright colors seen in flowers and ripe fruit.
3 Starch storing amyloplasts can also be converted to chromoplasts and it is possible for proplastids to develop straight into chromoplasts.
4 Chromoplasts and amyloplasts can also become chloroplasts like what happens when a carrot or a potato is illuminated.
5 If a plant is injured or something else causes a plant cell to revert to a meristematic state chloroplasts and other plastids can turn back into proplastids.
6 Chloroplast amyloplast chromoplast proplast etc are not absolute states—intermediate forms are common.
7 What can chloroplasts change into?	chromoplasts	2
8 What are chromoplasts?	pigmentfilled plastids responsible for the bright colors seen in flowers and ripe fruit	2
9 What can amyloplasts become?	chromoplasts	3
10 What can proplastids become?	chromoplasts	3
11 When a plant is injured what can become proplastids?	chloroplasts and other plastids	5
1 The division process starts when the proteins FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 assemble into filaments and with the help of a protein ARC6 form a structure called a Zring within the chloroplasts stroma.
2 The Min system manages the placement of the Zring ensuring that the chloroplast is cleaved more or less evenly.
3 The protein MinD prevents FtsZ from linking up and forming filaments.
4 Another protein ARC3 may also be involved but it is not very well understood.
5 These proteins are active at the poles of the chloroplast preventing Zring formation there but near the center of the chloroplast MinE inhibits them allowing the Zring to form.
6 What do FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 combine into?	filaments	1
7 What are FtsZ1 and FtsZ2?	proteins	1
8 What do FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 plus ARC6 form?	a structure called a Zring	1
9 Where is the Zring?	within the chloroplasts stroma	1
10 What gets the Zring in the right place?	The Min system	2
1 Next the two plastiddividing rings or PD rings form.
2 The inner plastiddividing ring is located in the inner side of the chloroplasts inner membrane and is formed first.
3 The outer plastiddividing ring is found wrapped around the outer chloroplast membrane.
4 It consists of filaments about 5 nanometers across arranged in rows 64 nanometers apart and shrinks to squeeze the chloroplast.
5 This is when chloroplast constriction beginsIn a few species like Cyanidioschyzon merolæ chloroplasts have a third plastiddividing ring located in the chloroplasts intermembrane space.
6 What are PD rings?	plastiddividing rings	1
7 How many PD rings are there?	two	1
8 How large are the outer PD rings filaments?	about 5 nanometers across	4
9 How far apart are the outer PD rings filaments?	64 nanometers	4
10 What is different about Cyanidioschyzon merolæ?	chloroplasts have a third plastiddividing ring	5
1 Light has been shown to be a requirement for chloroplast division.
2 Chloroplasts can grow and progress through some of the constriction stages under poor quality green light but are slow to complete division—they require exposure to bright white light to complete division.
3 Spinach leaves grown under green light have been observed to contain many large dumbbellshaped chloroplasts.
4 Exposure to white light can stimulate these chloroplasts to divide and reduce the population of dumbbellshaped chloroplasts.
5 What is necessary for chloroplasts to replicate?	Light	1
6 What kind of light is important for chloroplasts to divide?	bright white light	2
7 What do chloroplasts look like in spinach grown in green light?	large dumbbellshaped	3
8 What kind of light is inadequate for chloroplasts to divide?	poor quality green light	2
1 Recently chloroplasts have caught attention by developers of genetically modified crops.
2 Since in most flowering plants chloroplasts are not inherited from the male parent transgenes in these plastids cannot be disseminated by pollen.
3 This makes plastid transformation a valuable tool for the creation and cultivation of genetically modified plants that are biologically contained thus posing significantly lower environmental risks.
4 This biological containment strategy is therefore suitable for establishing the coexistence of conventional and organic agriculture.
5 While the reliability of this mechanism has not yet been studied for all relevant crop species recent results in tobacco plants are promising showing a failed containment rate of transplastomic plants at 3 in 1000000.
6 Why are chloroplasts of interest in GMO crops?	transgenes in these plastids cannot be disseminated by pollen	2
7 What is reduced by using plastid transformation for gene modification?	environmental risks	3
8 What was the containment failure rate in a tobacco plant study using plastid transformation?	3 in 1 000 000	5
9 What are plants with plastid gene transformations called?	transplastomic	5
1 A prime number or a prime is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.
2 A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number.
3 For example 5 is prime because 1 and 5 are its only positive integer factors whereas 6 is composite because it has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 and 6.
4 The fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role of primes in number theory any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering.
5 The uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization eg 3 1 · 3 1 · 1 · 3 etc.
6 are all valid factorizations of 3.
7 What is the only divisor besides 1 that a prime number can have?	itself	1
8 What are numbers greater than 1 that can be divided by 3 or more numbers called?	composite number	2
9 What theorem defines the main role of primes in number theory?	The fundamental theorem of arithmetic	4
10 Any number larger than 1 can be represented as a product of what?	a product of primes	4
11 Why must one be excluded in order to preserve the uniqueness of the fundamental theorem?	because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization	5
1 The property of being prime or not is called primality.
2 A simple but slow method of verifying the primality of a given number n is known as trial division.
3 It consists of testing whether n is a multiple of any integer between 2 and .
4 Algorithms much more efficient than trial division have been devised to test the primality of large numbers.
5 These include the Miller–Rabin primality test which is fast but has a small probability of error and the AKS primality test which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical.
6 Particularly fast methods are available for numbers of special forms such as Mersenne numbers.
7 As of January 2016update the largest known prime number has 22338618 decimal digits.
8 What is the name of the property that designates a number as being prime or not?	primality	1
9 What is the name of the process which confirms the primality of a number n?	trial division	2
10 What is the name of one algorithm useful for conveniently testing the primality of large numbers?	the Miller–Rabin primality test	5
11 What is the name of another algorithm useful for conveniently testing the primality of large numbers?	the AKS primality test	5
12 As of January 2016 how many digits does the largest known prime consist of?	22 338 618 decimal digits	7
1 There are infinitely many primes as demonstrated by Euclid around 300 BC.
2 There is no known simple formula that separates prime numbers from composite numbers.
3 However the distribution of primes that is to say the statistical behaviour of primes in the large can be modelled.
4 The first result in that direction is the prime number theorem proven at the end of the 19th century which says that the probability that a given randomly chosen number n is prime is inversely proportional to its number of digits or to the logarithm of n.
5 How many prime numbers exist?	infinitely many	1
6 Who established the amount of prime numbers in existence?	Euclid	1
7 What type of behavior in primes is it possible to determine?	the statistical behaviour	3
8 What theorem states that the probability that a number n is prime is inversely proportional to its logarithm?	the prime number theorem	4
9 When was the prime number theorem proven?	at the end of the 19th century	4
1 Many questions regarding prime numbers remain open such as Goldbachs conjecture that every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes and the twin prime conjecture that there are infinitely many pairs of primes whose difference is 2.
2 Such questions spurred the development of various branches of number theory focusing on analytic or algebraic aspects of numbers.
3 Primes are used in several routines in information technology such as publickey cryptography which makes use of properties such as the difficulty of factoring large numbers into their prime factors.
4 Prime numbers give rise to various generalizations in other mathematical domains mainly algebra such as prime elements and prime ideals.
5 What is the name of the supposition that any number larger than 2 can be represented as the sum of two primes?	Goldbachs conjecture	1
6 What is the name of the supposition that there are infinite pairs of primes whose difference is 2?	the twin prime conjecture	1
7 Besides the analytic property of numbers what other property of numbers does number theory focus on?	algebraic aspects	2
8 What is the application of prime numbers used in information technology which utilizes the fact that factoring very large prime numbers is very challenging?	publickey cryptography	3
9 What is the name of one algebraic generalization prime numbers have inspired?	prime ideals	4
1 Hence 6 is not prime.
2 The image at the right illustrates that 12 is not prime 12  3 · 4.
3 No even number greater than 2 is prime because by definition any such number n has at least three distinct divisors namely 1 2 and n This implies that n is not prime.
4 Accordingly the term odd prime refers to any prime number greater than 2.
5 Similarly when written in the usual decimal system all prime numbers larger than 5 end in 1 3 7 or 9 since even numbers are multiples of 2 and numbers ending in 0 or 5 are multiples of 5.
6  Any even number larger than what cannot be considered prime?	2	3
7 What are the specific divisors of all even numbers larger than 2?	1  2  and n	3
8 What name is given to any prime number larger than 2?	odd prime	4
9 Besides 13 and 7 what other number must all primes greater than 5 end with?	9	5
10 What type of numbers are always multiples of 2?	even numbers	5
1 Most early Greeks did not even consider 1 to be a number so they could not consider it to be a prime.
2 By the Middle Ages and Renaissance many mathematicians included 1 as the first prime number.
3 In the mid18th century Christian Goldbach listed 1 as the first prime in his famous correspondence with Leonhard Euler  who did not agree.
4 In the 19th century many mathematicians still considered the number 1 to be a prime.
5 For example Derrick Norman Lehmers list of primes up to 10006721 reprinted as late as 1956 started with 1 as its first prime.
6 Henri Lebesgue is said to be the last professional mathematician to call 1 prime.
7 By the early 20th century mathematicians began to accept that 1 is not a prime number but rather forms its own special category as a unit.
8 What number did early Greeks not regard as a true number?	1	1
9 Who included 1 as the first prime number in the mid 18th century?	Christian Goldbach	3
10 In the mid 18th century who did not concur that 1 should be the first prime number?	Leonhard Euler	3
11 How many primes were included in Derrick Norman Lehmers list of prime numbers?	10 006 721	5
12 What type of number do modern mathematicians consider 1 to be?	its own special category as a unit	7
1 A large body of mathematical work would still be valid when calling 1 a prime but Euclids fundamental theorem of arithmetic mentioned above would not hold as stated.
2 For example the number 15 can be factored as 3 · 5 and 1 · 3 · 5 if 1 were admitted as a prime these two presentations would be considered different factorizations of 15 into prime numbers so the statement of that theorem would have to be modified.
3 Similarly the sieve of Eratosthenes would not work correctly if 1 were considered a prime a modified version of the sieve that considers 1 as prime would eliminate all multiples of 1 that is all other numbers and produce as output only the single number 1.
4 Furthermore the prime numbers have several properties that the number 1 lacks such as the relationship of the number to its corresponding value of Eulers totient function or the sum of divisors function.
5 Which theorem would be invalid if the number 1 were considered prime?	Euclids fundamental theorem of arithmetic	1
6 The sieve of Eratosthenes would not be valid if what were true?	if 1 were considered a prime	3
7 What is another function that primes have that the number 1 does not?	Eulers totient function	4
8 What is one function that prime numbers have that 1 does not?	the sum of divisors function	4
9 If 1 were to be considered as prime what would the sieve of Eratosthenes yield for all other numbers?	only the single number 1	3
1 There are hints in the surviving records of the ancient Egyptians that they had some knowledge of prime numbers the Egyptian fraction expansions in the Rhind papyrus for instance have quite different forms for primes and for composites.
2 However the earliest surviving records of the explicit study of prime numbers come from the Ancient Greeks.
3 Euclids Elements circa 300 BC contain important theorems about primes including the infinitude of primes and the fundamental theorem of arithmetic.
4 Euclid also showed how to construct a perfect number from a Mersenne prime.
5 The Sieve of Eratosthenes attributed to Eratosthenes is a simple method to compute primes although the large primes found today with computers are not generated this way.
6 What is the name of the Egyptian papyrus that suggests that they may have had knowledge of prime numbers?	the Rhind papyrus	1
7 What civilization was the first known to clearly study prime numbers?	the Ancient Greeks	2
8 What work from around 300 BC has significant theorems about prime numbers?	Euclids Elements	3
9 Who demonstrated how to create a perfect number from a Mersenne prime?	Euclid	4
10 What does the Sieve of Eratosthenes do?	compute primes	5
1 After the Greeks little happened with the study of prime numbers until the 17th century.
2 In 1640 Pierre de Fermat stated without proof Fermats little theorem later proved by Leibniz and Euler.
3 Fermat also conjectured that all numbers of the form 22n  1 are prime they are called Fermat numbers and he verified this up to n  4 or 216  1.
4 However the very next Fermat number 232  1 is composite one of its prime factors is 641 as Euler discovered later and in fact no further Fermat numbers are known to be prime.
5 The French monk Marin Mersenne looked at primes of the form 2p − 1 with p a prime.
6 They are called Mersenne primes in his honor.
7 In what year did Pierre de Fermat declare Fermats little theorem?	In 1640	2
8 Besides Leibniz what other mathematician proved the validity of Fermats little theorem?	Euler	2
9 Of what form do Fermat numbers take?	22n  1	3
10 Of what form do Mersenne primes take?	2p − 1	5
11 To what extent did Fermat confirm the validity of Fermat numbers?	up to n  4 or 216  1	3
1 The most basic method of checking the primality of a given integer n is called trial division.
2 This routine consists of dividing n by each integer m that is greater than 1 and less than or equal to the square root of n If the result of any of these divisions is an integer then n is not a prime otherwise it is a prime.
3 Indeed if  is composite with a and b ≠ 1 then one of the factors a or b is necessarily at most .
4 For example for  the trial divisions are by m  2 3 4 5 and 6.
5 None of these numbers divides 37 so 37 is prime.
6 This routine can be implemented more efficiently if a complete list of primes up to  is known—then trial divisions need to be checked only for those m that are prime.
7 For example to check the primality of 37 only three divisions are necessary m  2 3 and 5 given that 4 and 6 are composite.
8 What is the most elemental way to test the primality of any integer n?	trial division	1
9 What makes the method of trial division more efficient?	if a complete list of primes up to  is known	6
10 Trial division involves dividing n by every integer m greater than what?	greater than 1	2
