11 How many divisions are required to verify the primality of the number 37?	only three divisions	7
12 What must the integer m be less than or equal to when performing trial division?	less than or equal to the square root of n	2
1 Modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes probabilistic or Monte Carlo and deterministic algorithms.
2 Deterministic algorithms provide a way to tell for sure whether a given number is prime or not.
3 For example trial division is a deterministic algorithm because if performed correctly it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite.
4 Probabilistic algorithms are normally faster but do not completely prove that a number is prime.
5 These tests rely on testing a given number in a partly random way.
6 For example a given test might pass all the time if applied to a prime number but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number.
7 If we repeat the test n times and pass every time then the probability that our number is composite is 11pn which decreases exponentially with the number of tests so we can be as sure as we like though never perfectly sure that the number is prime.
8 On the other hand if the test ever fails then we know that the number is composite.
9 How many modern types of primality tests for general numbers n are there?	two main classes	1
10 What is the name of one type of modern primality test?	probabilistic or Monte Carlo	1
11 What is the name of another type of modern primality test?	deterministic	1
12 What type of algorithm is trial division?	deterministic	3
13 When using a probabilistic algorithm how is the probability that the number is composite expressed mathematically?	11pn	7
1 A particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the Fermat primality test which relies on the fact Fermats little theorem that np≡n mod p for any n if p is a prime number.
2 If we have a number b that we want to test for primality then we work out nb mod b for a random value of n as our test.
3 A flaw with this test is that there are some composite numbers the Carmichael numbers that satisfy the Fermat identity even though they are not prime so the test has no way of distinguishing between prime numbers and Carmichael numbers.
4 Carmichael numbers are substantially rarer than prime numbers though so this test can be useful for practical purposes.
5 More powerful extensions of the Fermat primality test such as the BailliePSW MillerRabin and SolovayStrassen tests are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time when applied to a composite number.
6 What is one straightforward case of a probabilistic test?	the Fermat primality test 	1
7 What does the Fermat primality test depend upon?	np≡n mod p	1
8 What type of numbers demonstrate a flaw with the Fermat primality test?	composite numbers the Carmichael numbers	3
9 What is the name of one impressive continuation of the Fermat primality test?	BailliePSW	5
10 What is the name of another compelling continuation of the Fermat primality test?	SolovayStrassen tests	5
1 are prime.
2 Prime numbers of this form are known as factorial primes.
3 Other primes where either p  1 or p − 1 is of a particular shape include the Sophie Germain primes primes of the form 2p  1 with p prime primorial primes Fermat primes and Mersenne primes that is prime numbers that are of the form 2p − 1 where p is an arbitrary prime.
4 The Lucas–Lehmer test is particularly fast for numbers of this form.
5 This is why the largest known prime has almost always been a Mersenne prime since the dawn of electronic computers.
6 Of what form are Sophie Germain primes?	2p  1	3
7 Of what form are Mersenne primes?	2p − 1	3
8 What test is especially useful for numbers of the form 2p  1?	The Lucas–Lehmer test	4
9 What is the name of one type of prime where p1 or p1 takes a certain shape?	primorial primes	3
10 What is the name of another type of prime here p1 or p1 takes a certain shape?	Fermat primes	3
1 The following table gives the largest known primes of the mentioned types.
2 Some of these primes have been found using distributed computing.
3 In 2009 the Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search project was awarded a US100000 prize for first discovering a prime with at least 10 million digits.
4 The Electronic Frontier Foundation also offers 150000 and 250000 for primes with at least 100 million digits and 1 billion digits respectively.
5 Some of the largest primes not known to have any particular form that is no simple formula such as that of Mersenne primes have been found by taking a piece of semirandom binary data converting it to a number n multiplying it by 256k for some positive integer k and searching for possible primes within the interval 256kn  1 256kn  1 − 1.
6 citation needed.

11 In what interval are some of the greatest primes without a distinct form discovered in?	256kn  1  256kn  1 − 1	5
1 are prime for any natural number n Here  represents the floor function ie largest integer not greater than the number in question.
2 The latter formula can be shown using Bertrands postulate proven first by Chebyshev which states that there always exists at least one prime number p with n  p  2n − 2 for any natural number n  3.
3 However computing A or μ requires the knowledge of infinitely many primes to begin with.
4 Another formula is based on Wilsons theorem and generates the number 2 many times and all other primes exactly once.
5 What is name of the function used for the largest integer not greater than the number in question?	the floor function	1
6 Who first proved Bertrands postulate?	Chebyshev	2
7 For what size natural number does Bertrands postulate hold?	any natural number n  3	2
8 How is the prime number p in Bertrands postulate expressed mathematically?	n  p  2n − 2	2
9 On what theorem is the formula that frequently generates the number 2 and all other primes precisely once based on?	Wilsons theorem	4
1 can have infinitely many primes only when a and q are coprime ie their greatest common divisor is one.
2 If this necessary condition is satisfied Dirichlets theorem on arithmetic progressions asserts that the progression contains infinitely many primes.
3 The picture below illustrates this with q  9 the numbers are wrapped around as soon as a multiple of 9 is passed.
4 Primes are highlighted in red.
5 The rows progressions starting with a  3 6 or 9 contain at most one prime number.
6 In all other rows a  1 2 4 5 7 and 8 there are infinitely many prime numbers.
7 What is more the primes are distributed equally among those rows in the long run—the density of all primes congruent a modulo 9 is 16.
8 What is another way to state the condition that infinitely many primes can exist only if a and q are coprime?	their greatest common divisor is one	1
9 If a and q are coprime which theorem holds that an arithmetic progression has an infinite number of primes?	Dirichlets theorem	2
10 What is the density of all primes compatible with a modulo 9?	16	713
11 If q9 and a36 or 9 how many primes would be in the progression?	at most one prime number	5
12 If q9 and a12457 or 8 how many primes would be in a progression?	infinitely many prime numbers	6
1 The zeta function is closely related to prime numbers.
2 For example the aforementioned fact that there are infinitely many primes can also be seen using the zeta function if there were only finitely many primes then ζ1 would have a finite value.
3 However the harmonic series 1  12  13  14   diverges ie exceeds any given number so there must be infinitely many primes.
4 Another example of the richness of the zeta function and a glimpse of modern algebraic number theory is the following identity Basel problem due to Euler.
5 What function is related to prime numbers?	The zeta function	1
6 What type of value would the zeta function have if there were finite primes?	a finite value	2
7 What property of the harmonic series 1  12  13  14   shows that there is an infinite number of primes?	diverges	3
8 What does it mean when a harmonic series diverges?	exceeds any given number	3
9 Of what mathematical nature is the Basel problem?	identity	4
1 The unproven Riemann hypothesis dating from 1859 states that except for s  −2 −4  all zeroes of the ζfunction have real part equal to 12.
2 The connection to prime numbers is that it essentially says that the primes are as regularly distributed as possible.
3 clarification needed From a physical viewpoint it roughly states that the irregularity in the distribution of primes only comes from random noise.
4 From a mathematical viewpoint it roughly states that the asymptotic distribution of primes about xlog x of numbers less than x are primes the prime number theorem also holds for much shorter intervals of length about the square root of x for intervals near x.
5 This hypothesis is generally believed to be correct.
6 In particular the simplest assumption is that primes should have no significant irregularities without good reason.
7 When was the Riemann hypothesis proposed?	1859	1
8 According to the Riemann hypothesis all zeroes of the ζfunction have real part equal to 12 except for what values of s?	s  −2  −4   	1
9 What does the Riemann hypothesis state the source of irregularity in the distribution of points comes from?	random noise	3
10 What type of prime distribution does the Riemann hypothesis propose is also true for short intervals near X?	asymptotic distribution	4
11 What type of prime distribution is characterized about xlog x of numbers less than x?	asymptotic distribution	4
1 In addition to the Riemann hypothesis many more conjectures revolving about primes have been posed.
2 Often having an elementary formulation many of these conjectures have withstood a proof for decades all four of Landaus problems from 1912 are still unsolved.
3 One of them is Goldbachs conjecture which asserts that every even integer n greater than 2 can be written as a sum of two primes.
4 As of February 2011update this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up to n  2 · 1017.
5 Weaker statements than this have been proven for example Vinogradovs theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer can be written as a sum of three primes.
6 Chens theorem says that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a semiprime the product of two primes.
7 Also any even integer can be written as the sum of six primes.
8 The branch of number theory studying such questions is called additive number theory.
9 Which conjecture holds that every even integer n greater than 2 can be expressed as a sum of two primes?	Goldbachs conjecture	3
10 When did Landau propose his four conjectural problems?	1912	2
11 As of February 2011 how many numbers has Goldbachs conjecture been proven to?	all numbers up to n  2 · 1017	4
12 Which theorem states that all large odd integers can be expressed as a sum of three primes?	Vinogradovs theorem	5
13 Which theorem states that every large even integer can be written as a prime summed with a semiprime?	Chens theorem	6
1 A third type of conjectures concerns aspects of the distribution of primes.
2 It is conjectured that there are infinitely many twin primes pairs of primes with difference 2 twin prime conjecture.
3 Polignacs conjecture is a strengthening of that conjecture it states that for every positive integer n there are infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes that differ by 2n.
4 It is conjectured there are infinitely many primes of the form n2  1.
5 These conjectures are special cases of the broad Schinzels hypothesis H Brocards conjecture says that there are always at least four primes between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2.
6 Legendres conjecture states that there is a prime number between n2 and n  12 for every positive integer n It is implied by the stronger Cramérs conjecture.
7 What conjecture holds that there is an infinite amount of twin primes?	twin prime conjecture	2
8 What is a twin prime?	pairs of primes with difference 2	2
9 Which conjecture holds that for any positive integer n there is an infinite amount of pairs of consecutive primes differing by 2n?	Polignacs conjecture	3
10 Of what form is the infinite amount of primes that comprise the special cases of Schinzels hypothesis?	n2  1	4
11 What conjecture holds that there are always a minimum of 4 primes  between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2?	Brocards conjecture	5
1 For a long time number theory in general and the study of prime numbers in particular was seen as the canonical example of pure mathematics with no applications outside of the selfinterest of studying the topic with the exception of use of prime numbered gear teeth to distribute wear evenly.
2 In particular number theorists such as British mathematician G H Hardy prided themselves on doing work that had absolutely no military significance.
3 However this vision was shattered in the 1970s when it was publicly announced that prime numbers could be used as the basis for the creation of public key cryptography algorithms.
4 Prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators.
5 Besides the study of prime numbers what general theory was considered the official example of pure mathematics?	number theory	1
6 What British mathematician took pride in doing work that he felt had no military benefit?	G H Hardy	2
7 When was it discovered that prime numbers could applied to the creation of public key cryptography algorithms?	the 1970s	3
8 Besides public key cryptography what is another application for prime numbers?	hash tables	4
9 What type of number generators make use of prime numbers?	pseudorandom number generators	4
1 Giugas conjecture says that this equation is also a sufficient condition for p to be prime.
2 Another consequence of Fermats little theorem is the following if p is a prime number other than 2 and 5 1p is always a recurring decimal whose period is p − 1 or a divisor of p − 1.
3 The fraction 1p expressed likewise in base q rather than base 10 has similar effect provided that p is not a prime factor of q Wilsons theorem says that an integer p  1 is prime if and only if the factorial p − 1.
4  1 is divisible by p Moreover an integer n  4 is composite if and only if n − 1.
5 is divisible by n.
6 Assuming p is a prime other than 2 or 5 then according to Fermats theorem what type of decimal will 1p always be?	a recurring decimal	2
7 According to Fermats theorem what period does 1p always have assuming p is prime that is not 2 or 5?	p − 1	2
8 According to Wilsons theorem what factorial must be divisible by p if some integer p  1 is to be considered prime?	p − 1  1	3
9 According to Wilsons theorem what factorial must be divisible by n if some integer n  4 is to be considered composite?	n − 1	4
10 What condition what must be satisfied in order for 1p to be expressed in base q instead of base 10 and still have a period of p  1?	p is not a prime factor of q	3
1 Several publickey cryptography algorithms such as RSA and the Diffie–Hellman key exchange are based on large prime numbers for example 512bit primes are frequently used for RSA and 1024bit primes are typical for Diffie–Hellman.
2 RSA relies on the assumption that it is much easier ie more efficient to perform the multiplication of two large numbers x and y than to calculate x and y assumed coprime if only the product xy is known.
3 The Diffie–Hellman key exchange relies on the fact that there are efficient algorithms for modular exponentiation while the reverse operation the discrete logarithm is thought to be a hard problem.
4 What is one type of public key cryptography algorithm?	RSA	1
5 What is another type of public key cryptography algorithm?	the Diffie–Hellman key exchange	1
6 How many bits are often in the primes used for RSA public key cryptography algorithms?	512bit	1
7 On what type of exponentiation does the Diffie–Hellman key exchange depend on?	modular exponentiation	3
8 How many bits are typically used in the primes for the Diffie–Hellman key exchange?	1024bit	1
1 The evolutionary strategy used by cicadas of the genus Magicicada make use of prime numbers.
2 These insects spend most of their lives as grubs underground.
3 They only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after 7 13 or 17 years at which point they fly about breed and then die after a few weeks at most.
4 The logic for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators on Magicicadas.
5 If Magicicadas appeared at a nonprime number intervals say every 12 years then predators appearing every 2 3 4 6 or 12 years would be sure to meet them.
6 Over a 200year period average predator populations during hypothetical outbreaks of 14 and 15year cicadas would be up to 2 higher than during outbreaks of 13 and 17year cicadas.
7 Though small this advantage appears to have been enough to drive natural selection in favour of a primenumbered lifecycle for these insects.
8 What type of insect employs the use of prime numbers in its evolutionary strategy?	cicadas	1
9 Where do cicadas spend the majority of their lives?	as grubs underground	2
10 Other than 7 and 13 what other year interval do cicadas pupate?	17 years	3
11 What is the logic behind the cicadas prime number evolutionary strategy?	make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators	4
12 How much larger would cicada predator populations be if cicada outbreaks occurred at 14 and 15 year intervals?	up to 2 higher	6
1 The concept of prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics.
2 Generally prime indicates minimality or indecomposability in an appropriate sense.
3 For example the prime field is the smallest subfield of a field F containing both 0 and 1.
4 It is either Q or the finite field with p elements whence the name.
5 Often a second additional meaning is intended by using the word prime namely that any object can be essentially uniquely decomposed into its prime components.
6 For example in knot theory a prime knot is a knot that is indecomposable in the sense that it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots.
7 Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots.
8 Prime models and prime 3manifolds are other examples of this type.
9 What does the word prime generally suggest?	indecomposability	2
10 For a field F containing 0 and 1 what would be the prime field?	the smallest subfield	3
11 How can any knot be distinctively indicated?	as a connected sum of prime knots	7
12 What is an additional meaning intended when the word prime is used?	any object can be  essentially uniquely  decomposed into its prime components	5
13 What does it mean for a knot to be considered indecomposable?	it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots	6
1 Prime numbers give rise to two more general concepts that apply to elements of any commutative ring R an algebraic structure where addition subtraction and multiplication are defined prime elements and irreducible elements.
2 An element p of R is called prime element if it is neither zero nor a unit ie does not have a multiplicative inverse and satisfies the following requirement given x and y in R such that p divides the product xy then p divides x or y.
3 An element is irreducible if it is not a unit and cannot be written as a product of two ring elements that are not units.
4 In the ring Z of integers the set of prime elements equals the set of irreducible elements which is.
5 What is the name of an algebraic structure in which addition subtraction and multiplication are defined?	commutative ring R	1
6 What is one general concept that applies to elements of commutative rings?	prime elements	1
7 What is another general concept that applies to elements of commutative rings?	irreducible elements	1
8 What is one condition that an element p of R must satisfy in order to be considered a prime element?	it is neither zero nor a unit	2
9 Under what condition is an element irreducible?	cannot be written as a product of two ring elements that are not units	3
1 The fundamental theorem of arithmetic continues to hold in unique factorization domains.
2 An example of such a domain is the Gaussian integers Zi that is the set of complex numbers of the form a  bi where i denotes the imaginary unit and a and b are arbitrary integers.
3 Its prime elements are known as Gaussian primes.
4 Not every prime in Z is a Gaussian prime in the bigger ring Zi 2 factors into the product of the two Gaussian primes 1  i and 1 − i.
5 Rational primes ie.
6 prime elements in Z of the form 4k  3 are Gaussian primes whereas rational primes of the form 4k  1 are not.
7 What theorem remains valid in unique factorization domains?	The fundamental theorem of arithmetic	1
8 What is one example of a unique factorization domain?	the Gaussian integers Zi	2
9 What form do complex Gaussian integers have?	a  bi	2
10 What do a and b represent in a Gaussian integer expression?	arbitrary integers	2
11 Of what form are rational primes?	4k  3	6
1 In ring theory the notion of number is generally replaced with that of ideal.
2 Prime ideals which generalize prime elements in the sense that the principal ideal generated by a prime element is a prime ideal are an important tool and object of study in commutative algebra algebraic number theory and algebraic geometry.
3 The prime ideals of the ring of integers are the ideals 0 2 3 5 7 11 … The fundamental theorem of arithmetic generalizes to the Lasker–Noether theorem which expresses every ideal in a Noetherian commutative ring as an intersection of primary ideals which are the appropriate generalizations of prime powers.
4 In what theory is the idea of a number exchanged with that of an ideal?	In ring theory	1
5 What type of ideals generalize prime elements?	Prime ideals	2
6 What type of number theory utilizes and studies prime ideals?	algebraic number theory	2
7 Which theorem can be simplified to the Lasker–Noether theorem?	The fundamental theorem of arithmetic	3
8 What type of commutative ring does the Lasker–Noether theorem express every ideal as an intersection of primary ideals in?	a Noetherian commutative ring	3
1 Prime ideals are the points of algebrogeometric objects via the notion of the spectrum of a ring.
2 Arithmetic geometry also benefits from this notion and many concepts exist in both geometry and number theory.
3 For example factorization or ramification of prime ideals when lifted to an extension field a basic problem of algebraic number theory bears some resemblance with ramification in geometry.
4 Such ramification questions occur even in numbertheoretic questions solely concerned with integers.
5 For example prime ideals in the ring of integers of quadratic number fields can be used in proving quadratic reciprocity a statement that concerns the solvability of quadratic equations.
6 What are the points of algebrogeometric objects?	Prime ideals	1
7 What does factorization of prime ideals approximate?	ramification in geometry	3
8 In what type of ring can prime ideals be used for validating quadratic reciprocity?	ring of integers of quadratic number fields	5
9 What does quadratic reciprocity seek to achieve?	the solvability of quadratic equations	5
1 In particular this norm gets smaller when a number is multiplied by p in sharp contrast to the usual absolute value also referred to as the infinite prime.
2 While completing Q roughly filling the gaps with respect to the absolute value yields the field of real numbers completing with respect to the padic norm −p yields the field of padic numbers.
3 These are essentially all possible ways to complete Q by Ostrowskis theorem.
4 Certain arithmetic questions related to Q or more general global fields may be transferred back and forth to the completed or local fields.
5 This localglobal principle again underlines the importance of primes to number theory.
6 What happens to the norm when a number is multiplied by p?	norm gets smaller	1
7 To what may general global fields be transferred to or from?	completed or local fields	4
8 Completing Q with respect to what will produce the field of real numbers?	the absolute value	2
9 What principle highlights the significance of primes in number theory	localglobal principle 	5.
1 Prime numbers have influenced many artists and writers.
2 The French composer Olivier Messiaen used prime numbers to create ametrical music through natural phenomena.
3 In works such as La Nativité du Seigneur 1935 and Quatre études de rythme 1949–50 he simultaneously employs motifs with lengths given by different prime numbers to create unpredictable rhythms the primes 41 43 47 and 53 appear in the third étude Neumes rythmiques.
4 According to Messiaen this way of composing was inspired by the movements of nature movements of free and unequal durations.
5 Which French composer wrote ametrical music using prime numbers?	Olivier Messiaen	2
6 What is one work by Olivier Messiaen?	La Nativité du Seigneur	3
7 What is another piece created by Olivier Messiaen?	Quatre études de rythme	3
8 In which etude of Neumes rythmiques do the primes 41 43 47 and 53 appear in?	the third étude	3
9 Messiaen says that composition with prime numbers was inspired by what?	the movements of nature	4
1 The Rhine Romansh Rein German Rhein French le Rhin Dutch Rijn is a European river that begins in the Swiss canton of Graubünden in the southeastern Swiss Alps forms part of the SwissAustrian SwissLiechtenstein border SwissGerman and then the FrancoGerman border then flows through the Rhineland and eventually empties into the North Sea in the Netherlands.
2 The biggest city on the river Rhine is Cologne Germany with a population of more than 1050000 people.
3 It is the secondlongest river in Central and Western Europe after the Danube at about 1230 km 760 minote 2note 1 with an average discharge of about 2900 m3s 100000 cu fts.
4 Where does the Rhine begin?	Swiss canton	1
5 Where does the Rhine empty?	North Sea	1

8 How long is the Rhine?	1 230 km 760 mi	3

10 What country does the Rhine empty?	Netherlands	1
11 How long is the Rhine?	1 230 km	3
1 The variant forms of the name of the Rhine in modern languages are all derived from the Gaulish name Rēnos which was adapted in Romanera geography 1st century BC as Greek Ῥῆνος Rhēnos Latin Rhenus.
2 note 3 The spelling with Rh in English Rhine as well as in German Rhein and French Rhin is due to the influence of Greek orthography while the vocalisation i is due to the ProtoGermanic adoption of the Gaulish name as Rīnaz via Old Frankish giving Old English Rín Old High German Rīn Dutch Rijn formerly also spelled Rhijn.
3 The diphthong in modern German Rhein also adopted in Romansh Rein Rain is a Central German development of the early modern period the Alemannic name Rīn retaining the older vocalismnote 4 as does Ripuarian Rhing while Palatine has diphthongized Rhei Rhoi.
4 Spanish is with French in adopting the Germanic vocalism Rin while Italian Occitan and Portuguese retain the Latin Ren.

1 The flow of cold gray mountain water continues for some distance into the lake.
2 The cold water flows near the surface and at first doesnt mix with the warmer green waters of Upper Lake.
3 But then at the socalled Rheinbrech the Rhine water abruptly falls into the depths because of the greater density of cold water.
4 The flow reappears on the surface at the northern German shore of the lake off the island of Lindau.
5 The water then follows the northern shore until Hagnau am Bodensee.
6 A small fraction of the flow is diverted off the island of Mainau into Lake Überlingen.
7 Most of the water flows via the Constance hopper into the Rheinrinne Rhine Gutter and Seerhein.
8 Depending on the water level this flow of the Rhine water is clearly visible along the entire length of the lake.
9 Why does the Rhine water fall into depths at the Rheinbrech?	greater density of cold water	3
10 What Lake in a German island Mainau receives a fraction of the Rhines flow?	Lake Überlingen	6
11 Where does the cold and warm water meet the warm water?	Rheinbrech	3
12 How much of the lake connecting with the Rhine can you see from the German islands?	entire length	8
13 What is the Island off of the German shore of the Rhine that this warm and cold water meet?	Lindau	4
14 Where does the cold water mix with Lake Constance?	Rheinbrech	3
15 What island does the cold water flow of the Rhine and Lake Constance flow to?	Lindau	4
16 A small fraction of the cold water flow from Lake Constance goes to what other lake?	Lake Überlingen	6
17 What does the word Rheinrinne translate to?	Rhine Gutter	7
18 What does the flow of the Rhine being visible depend on?	water level	8
1 The Rhine emerges from Lake Constance flows generally westward as the Hochrhein passes the Rhine Falls and is joined by its major tributary the river Aare.
2 The Aare more than doubles the Rhines water discharge to an average of nearly 1000 m3s 35000 cu fts and provides more than a fifth of the discharge at the Dutch border.
3 The Aare also contains the waters from the 4274 m 14022 ft summit of Finsteraarhorn the highest point of the Rhine basin.
4 The Rhine roughly forms the GermanSwiss border from Lake Constance with the exceptions of the canton of Schaffhausen and parts of the cantons of Zürich and BaselStadt until it turns north at the socalled Rhine knee at Basel leaving Switzerland.
5 After the Rhine emerges from Lake Constance what direction does it flow?	westward	1
6 What is the major tributary of the Rhine?	river Aare	1
7 How much water does the Aare give to the Rhine?	1 000 m3s 35 000 cu fts	2
8 Where is the highest point of the Rhine basin?	Finsteraarhorn	3
9 Where is the socalled Rhine Knee?	Basel	4
10 When the Rhine emerges from Lake Constance which way does it flow?	westward	1
11 What is the major tributary for the Rhine?	Aare	1
12 The Rhine gets how much water from the Aare?	1 000 m3s 35 000 cu fts 	2
13 What is the highest point of the Rhine basin called?	Finsteraarhorn	3
14 Theres a rough border between Switzerland and what other country formed by the Rhine?	German	4
1 In the centre of Basel the first major city in the course of the stream is located the Rhine knee this is a major bend where the overall direction of the Rhine changes from West to North.
2 Here the High Rhine ends.
3 Legally the Central Bridge is the boundary between High and Upper Rhine.
4 The river now flows North as Upper Rhine through the Upper Rhine Plain which is about 300 km long and up to 40 km wide.
5 The most important tributaries in this area are the Ill below of Strasbourg the Neckar in Mannheim and the Main across from Mainz.
6 In Mainz the Rhine leaves the Upper Rhine Valley and flows through the Mainz Basin.
7 What is the first major city in the stream of the Rhine?	Basel	1
8 What is the bend of Rhine in Basel called?	Rhine knee	1
9 What is the boundary between the High and Upper Rhine?	Central Bridge	3
10 How long is the Upper Rhine Plain?	300 km long	4
11 How wide is the Upper Rhine Plain?	40 km wide	4
12 What is the first major city in the course of the Rhine?	Basel	1
13 What is the first major bend in the Rhine called?	Rhine knee	1
14 The bend on the Rhine goes from the West to what direction?	North	1
15 What ends at this bend in the Rhine?	High Rhine	2
16 What is the legal boundary behind the High and Upper Rind?	Central Bridge	3
1 The Upper Rhine region was changed significantly by a Rhine straightening program in the 19th Century.
2 The rate of flow was increased and the ground water level fell significantly.
3 Dead branches dried up and the amount of forests on the flood plains decreased sharply.
4 On the French side the Grand Canal dAlsace was dug which carries a significant part of the river water and all of the traffic.
5 In some places there are large compensation pools for example the huge Bassin de compensation de Plobsheim in Alsace.
6 Which century was there a program to straighten the Rhine?	19th Century	1
7 What happened to the rate of flow in the Rhine during the Rhine straightening program?	increased	2
8 What happened to the ground water in the Rhine during the Rhine straightening program?	fell significantly	2
9 Which canal was dug in France to carry Rhines water?	Grand Canal dAlsace	4
10 What is the Bassin de compensation de Plobsheim in Alsace?	large compensation pools	5
11 What region of the Rhine was changed by the Rhine Straightening program?	Upper Rhine	1
12 When did the Rhine Straightening program begin?	19th Century	1
13 What happened with the rate of flow in the Rhine with the straightening program?	increased	2
14 What happened with the ground water level with the Rhine straightening program?	fell significantly	2
15 What carries a significant amount of the Rhine flow through France?	Grand Canal dAlsace	4
1 The Rhine is the longest river in Germany.
2 It is here that the Rhine encounters some more of its main tributaries such as the Neckar the Main and later the Moselle which contributes an average discharge of more than 300 m3s 11000 cu fts.
3 Northeastern France drains to the Rhine via the Moselle smaller rivers drain the Vosges and Jura Mountains uplands.
4 Most of Luxembourg and a very small part of Belgium also drain to the Rhine via the Moselle.
5 As it approaches the Dutch border the Rhine has an annual mean discharge of 2290 m3s 81000 cu fts and an average width of 400 m 1300 ft.
6 Where does the Rhine encounter its tributary the Neckar?	Germany	1
7 What is the average discharge of the Moselle to the Rhine?	300 m3s 11 000 cu fts	2
8 What is the longest river in Germany?	Rhine	1
9 What is a main tributary to the Rhine that goes through Northeastern France and part of Belgium?	Moselle	4
10 What is the average width of the Rhine?	400 m 1 300 ft	5
11 The Rhine is the longest river in what country?	Germany	1
12 Which country does the Rhine encounter its main tributaries?	Germany	1
13 Which of the tributaries in Germany contributes most?	Moselle	2
14 What country does the Moselle take the Rhine to?	France	3
15 How much does the Rhine discharge at the Dutch border?	2 290 m3s 81 000 cu fts	5
1 Between Bingen and Bonn the Middle Rhine flows through the Rhine Gorge a formation which was created by erosion.
2 The rate of erosion equaled the uplift in the region such that the river was left at about its original level while the surrounding lands raised.
3 The gorge is quite deep and is the stretch of the river which is known for its many castles and vineyards.
4 It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site 2002 and known as the Romantic Rhine with more than 40 castles and fortresses from the Middle Ages and many quaint and lovely country villages.
5 What flows between the Bingen and Bonn?	Middle Rhine	1
6 What gorge is between the Bingen and Bonn?	Rhine Gorge	1
7 How was the Rhine Gorge formed?	erosion	1
8 What is the area called near the Rhine Gorge with castles from the middle ages?	the Romantic Rhine	4
9 What flows between Bingen and Bonn?	Middle Rhine	1
10 Where does the Middle Rhine flow between Bingen and Bonn?	Rhine Gorge	1
11 What is the Rhine Gorge known for?	castles	3
12 What is the section of the Rhine Gorge recognized by UNESCO called?	Romantic Rhine	4
1 Until the early 1980s industry was a major source of water pollution.
2 Although many plants and factories can be found along the Rhine up into Switzerland it is along the Lower Rhine that the bulk of them are concentrated as the river passes the major cities of Cologne Düsseldorf and Duisburg.
3 Duisburg is the home of Europes largest inland port and functions as a hub to the sea ports of Rotterdam Antwerp and Amsterdam.
4 The Ruhr which joins the Rhine in Duisburg is nowadays a clean river thanks to a combination of stricter environmental controls a transition from heavy industry to light industry and cleanup measures such as the reforestation of Slag and brownfields.
5 The Ruhr currently provides the region with drinking water.
6 It contributes 70 m3s 2500 cu fts to the Rhine.
7 Other rivers in the Ruhr Area above all the Emscher still carry a considerable degree of pollution.
8 What contributed to water pollution in the Rhine?	plants and factories	2
9 What is Europes largest inland port?	Duisburg	3
10 What rive joins the Rhine in Duisburg?	Ruhr	4
11 What does the Ruhr provide to its community?	drinking water	5
12 Where are a bulk of factories concentrated along the Rhine?	Switzerland	2
13 What did industry do to the Rhine until the 1980s?	pollution	1
14 Which section of the Rhine is most factories found?	Lower Rhine	2
15 What country has the most factories that pollute the Rhine?	Switzerland	2
16 What city has the largest inland port in Europe?	Duisburg	3
17 Which river joins the Rhine in Duisburg?	Ruhr	4
1 The dominant economic sectors in the Middle Rhine area are viniculture and tourism.
2 The Rhine Gorge between Rüdesheim am Rhein and Koblenz is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
3 Near Sankt Goarshausen the Rhine flows around the famous rock Lorelei.
4 With its outstanding architectural monuments the slopes full of vines settlements crowded on the narrow river banks and scores of castles lined up along the top of the steep slopes the Middle Rhine Valley can be considered the epitome of the Rhine romanticism.
5 Besides viniculture whats a dominant economic sector of the Middle Rhine?	tourism	1
6 Theres a UNESCO World Heritage site in the Rhine Gorge between the Koblenz and what?	Rüdesheim am Rhein	2
7 What is the famous rock near Sanke Goarshausen?	Lorelei	3
8 What is considered the epitome of the Rhine romanticism?	Middle Rhine Valley	4
9 Besides viniculture what is the other dominate economic sector in the middle rhine?	tourism	1
10 What is the Rhine Gorge listed as?	UNESCO World Heritage Site	2
11 The Rhine Gorge is between Koblenz and what other city?	Rüdesheim am Rhein	2
12 What is the famous rock called that the Rhine flows around?	Lorelei	3
13 Where is the famous rock the Rhine flows around?	Sankt Goarshausen	3
1 The Lower Rhine flows through North RhineWestphalia.
2 Its banks are usually heavily populated and industrialized in particular the agglomerations Cologne Düsseldorf and Ruhr area.
3 Here the Rhine flows through the largest conurbation in Germany the RhineRuhr region.
4 One of the most important cities in this region is Duisburg with the largest river port in Europe Duisport.
5 The region downstream of Duisburg is more agricultural.
6 In Wesel 30 km downstream of Duisburg is located the western end of the second eastwest shipping route the WeselDatteln Canal which runs parallel to the Lippe.
7 Between Emmerich and Cleves the Emmerich Rhine Bridge the longest suspension bridge in Germany crosses the 400 m wide river.
8 Near Krefeld the river crosses the Uerdingen line the line which separates the areas where Low German and High German are spoken.
9 What city has the biggest port in Germany?	Duisburg	4
10 What is the Canal in Wesel?	WeselDatteln Canal	6
11 What does the WesselDatteln canal run parallel to?	Lippe	6
12 What is the largest suspension bridge in Germany?	Emmerich Rhine Bridge	7
13 How wide is the Rhine in Germany between Emmrich and Cleves?	400 m	7
14 What part of the Rhine flows through North RhineWestphalia?	Lower Rhine	1
15 What is the region called that is the largest conurbation of the Rhine?	RhineRuhr	3
16 What is the largest port in Europe called?	Duisport	4
17 What is the name of the longest bridge in Germany?	Emmerich Rhine Bridge	7
18 How wide is the Rhine in Germany?	400 m wide	7
1 From here the situation becomes more complicated as the Dutch name Rijn no longer coincides with the main flow of water.
2 Two thirds of the water flow volume of the Rhine flows farther west through the Waal and then via the Merwede and Nieuwe Merwede De Biesbosch merging with the Meuse through the Hollands Diep and Haringvliet estuaries into the North Sea.
3 The Beneden Merwede branches off near HardinxveldGiessendam and continues as the Noord to join the Lek near the village of Kinderdijk to form the Nieuwe Maas then flows past Rotterdam and continues via Het Scheur and the Nieuwe Waterweg to the North Sea.
4 The Oude Maas branches off near Dordrecht farther down rejoining the Nieuwe Maas to form Het Scheur.
5 What does the water flow of the Rhine merge with after flowing through Merwede?	Meuse	2
6 What is the Dutch name for the Rhine?	Rijn	1
7 How much of the water flow does the Waal get from the Rhine?	Two thirds	2
8 Which direction does two thirds of the Rhine flow outside of Germany?	west	2
9 Where does two thirds of the Rhine flow outside of Germany?	Waal	2
10 What does the Rhine merge with outside of Germany?	Meuse	2
11 Whats the name of where the Rhine branches off near Dordrecht?	The Oude Maas	4
1 The other third of the water flows through the Pannerdens Kanaal and redistributes in the IJssel and Nederrijn.
2 The IJssel branch carries one ninth of the water flow of the Rhine north into the IJsselmeer a former bay while the Nederrijn carries approximately two ninths of the flow west along a route parallel to the Waal.
3 However at Wijk bij Duurstede the Nederrijn changes its name and becomes the Lek.
4 It flows farther west to rejoin the Noord River into the Nieuwe Maas and to the North Sea.
5 If two thirds of the Rhine flows through the Maas where doe the other one third flow through?	Pannerdens Kanaal	1
6 The Rhine redistributes into the Ijssel and what other body?	Nederrijn	1
7 What does the Nederrikns name change into?	Lek	3
8 Where does the Lek join?	Noord River	4
9 If two thirds of the Rhine flows through Waal where does the other third flow through?	Pannerdens Kanaal	1
10 Other than the Ijssel where does the water from the Pannerdens Kanaal redsitrubute?	Nederrijn	1
11 How much of the Rhine flow does Ijssel carry?	one ninth	2
12 What does the Nederrijn change its name to?	Lek	3
13 Where does the Nederrijn change its name?	Wijk bij Duurstede	3
1 The name Rijn from here on is used only for smaller streams farther to the north which together formed the main river Rhine in Roman times.
2 Though they retained the name these streams no longer carry water from the Rhine but are used for draining the surrounding land and polders.
3 From Wijk bij Duurstede the old north branch of the Rhine is called Kromme Rijn Bent Rhine past Utrecht first Leidse Rijn Rhine of Leiden and then Oude Rijn Old Rhine.
4 The latter flows west into a sluice at Katwijk where its waters can be discharged into the North Sea.
5 This branch once formed the line along which the Limes Germanicus were built.
6 During periods of lower sea levels within the various ice ages the Rhine took a left turn creating the Channel River the course of which now lies below the English Channel.
7 What is the name for the smaller streams along the region northern Germany?	Rijn	1
8 The smaller streams are used for what?	draining the surrounding land	2
9 What is the name of the old north branch of the Rhine?	Kromme Rijn	3
10 What is the translation of the old north branch of rhe Rhine?	Bent Rhine	3
11 What part of the Rhine flows west at Katwijk?	Old Rhine	3
1 The RhineMeuse Delta the most important natural region of the Netherlands begins near Millingen aan de Rijn close to the DutchGerman border with the division of the Rhine into Waal and Nederrijn.
2 Since the Rhine contributes most of the water the shorter term Rhine Delta is commonly used.
3 However this name is also used for the river delta where the Rhine flows into Lake Constance so it is clearer to call the larger one RhineMeuse delta or even Rhine–Meuse–Scheldt delta as the Scheldt ends in the same delta.
4 What is the name of the Delta in the Netherlands?	RhineMeuse	1
5 Where does the Delta in the Netherlands begin?	Millingen aan de Rijn 	1
6 What is the nickname for the Delta in the Netherlands?	Rhine Delta	2
1 The shape of the Rhine delta is determined by two bifurcations first at Millingen aan de Rijn the Rhine splits into Waal and Pannerdens Kanaal which changes its name to Nederrijn at Angeren and second near Arnhem the IJssel branches off from the Nederrijn.
2 This creates three main flows two of which change names rather often.
3 The largest and southern main branch begins as Waal and continues as Boven Merwede Upper Merwede Beneden Merwede Lower Merwede Noord River North River Nieuwe Maas New Meuse Het Scheur the Rip and Nieuwe Waterweg New Waterway.
4 The middle flow begins as Nederrijn then changes into Lek then joins the Noord thereby forming Nieuwe Maas.
5 The northern flow keeps the name IJssel until it flows into Lake IJsselmeer.
6 Three more flows carry significant amounts of water the Nieuwe Merwede New Merwede which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Boven to Beneden Merwede the Oude Maas Old Meuse which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Beneden Merwede into Noord and Dordtse Kil which branches off from Oude Maas.
7 At Millingen aan de Rijn where the Rhine splits what does it change its name to?	Nederrijn at Angeren	1
8 How many main flows are branched off from the Nederrijn?	three	2
9 What is the largest main branch of the Rhine?	Waal	3
10 What is the translation of Oude Maas?	Old Meuse	6
11 What is the English translation of Het Scheur?	the Rip	3
1 Before the St Elizabeths flood 1421 the Meuse flowed just south of todays line MerwedeOude Maas to the North Sea and formed an archipelagolike estuary with Waal and Lek.
2 This system of numerous bays estuarylike extended rivers many islands and constant changes of the coastline is hard to imagine today.
3 From 1421 to 1904 the Meuse and Waal merged further upstream at Gorinchem to form Merwede.
4 For flood protection reasons the Meuse was separated from the Waal through a lock and diverted into a new outlet called Bergse Maas then Amer and then flows into the former bay Hollands Diep.
5 What flood impacted the Meuse?	St Elizabeths	1
6 What year did the flood that impacted the Meuse take place?	1421	1
7 Where did the Meuse flow before the flood?	MerwedeOude Maas	1
8 When did the Meuse and Waal merge?	1421 to 1904	3
9 What did the MerwedeOude Maas form with Waal and Lek?	archipelagolike estuary	1
1 The hydrography of the current delta is characterized by the deltas main arms disconnected arms Hollandse IJssel Linge Vecht etc.
2 and smaller rivers and streams.
3 Many rivers have been closed dammed and now serve as drainage channels for the numerous polders.
4 The construction of Delta Works changed the Delta in the second half of the 20th Century fundamentally.
5 Currently Rhine water runs into the sea or into former marine bays now separated from the sea in five places namely at the mouths of the Nieuwe Merwede Nieuwe Waterway Nieuwe Maas Dordtse Kil Spui and IJssel.
6 What do closed rivers serve as after they close?	drainage channels	3
7 What changed the Rhines Delta?	construction of Delta Works	4
8 What is the term for closing off rivers that are no longer connected?	dammed	3
9 When was the construction that changed the Rhines Delta?	20th Century	4
1 The RhineMeuse Delta is a tidal delta shaped not only by the sedimentation of the rivers but also by tidal currents.
2 This meant that high tide formed a serious risk because strong tidal currents could tear huge areas of land into the sea.
3 Before the construction of the Delta Works tidal influence was palpable up to Nijmegen and even today after the regulatory action of the Delta Works the tide acts far inland.
4 At the Waal for example the most landward tidal influence can be detected between Brakel and Zaltbommel.
5 What type of Delta is the RhineMeuse?	tidal delta	1
6 Besides rivers what shapes the sedimentation of the rivers?	tidal currents	1
7 What does a high tide risk near lands?	tear huge areas of land into the sea	2
8 Between Brakel and what other city can the most landward tidal influence be detected?	Zaltbommel	4
1 In southern Europe the stage was set in the Triassic Period of the Mesozoic Era with the opening of the Tethys Ocean between the Eurasian and African tectonic plates between about 240 MBP and 220 MBP million years before present.
2 The present Mediterranean Sea descends from this somewhat larger Tethys sea.
3 At about 180 MBP in the Jurassic Period the two plates reversed direction and began to compress the Tethys floor causing it to be subducted under Eurasia and pushing up the edge of the latter plate in the Alpine Orogeny of the Oligocene and Miocene Periods.
4 Several microplates were caught in the squeeze and rotated or were pushed laterally generating the individual features of Mediterranean geography Iberia pushed up the Pyrenees Italy the Alps and Anatolia moving west the mountains of Greece and the islands.
5 The compression and orogeny continue today as shown by the ongoing raising of the mountains a small amount each year and the active volcanoes.
6 The present Mediterranean Sea descends from what sea?	Tethys sea	2
7 What period did plates reverse directions to compress the Tethys floor?	Jurassic Period	3
8 Microplates squeezing and rotating created the features of what?	Mediterranean geography	4
9 What period opened the Tethys Ocean?	Mesozoic Era	1
10 What pushed up the Pyrenees?	Iberia	4
1 From the Eocene onwards the ongoing Alpine orogeny caused a N–S rift system to develop in this zone.
2 The main elements of this rift are the Upper Rhine Graben in southwest Germany and eastern France and the Lower Rhine Embayment in northwest Germany and the southeastern Netherlands.
3 By the time of the Miocene a river system had developed in the Upper Rhine Graben that continued northward and is considered the first Rhine river.
4 At that time it did not yet carry discharge from the Alps instead the watersheds of the Rhone and Danube drained the northern flanks of the Alps.
5 What rift system developed in the Alpine orogeny?	N–S	1
6 What elements from the rift system in the Alpine orogeny in Southwest Germany?	Upper Rhine Graben	2
7 What time did a river system develop in the Upper Rhine Graben?	Miocene	3
8 The Rhine and what other river drained the northern flanks of the alps?	Danube	4
1 Through stream capture the Rhine extended its watershed southward.
2 By the Pliocene period the Rhine had captured streams down to the Vosges Mountains including the Mosel the Main and the Neckar.
3 The northern Alps were then drained by the Rhone.
4 By the early Pleistocene period the Rhine had captured most of its current Alpine watershed from the Rhône including the Aar.
5 Since that time the Rhine has added the watershed above Lake Constance Vorderrhein Hinterrhein Alpenrhein captured from the Rhône the upper reaches of the Main beyond Schweinfurt and the Vosges Mountains captured from the Meuse to its watershed.
6 How did the Rhine extend watershed southward?	stream capture	1
7 What period did the Rhine capture streams?	Pliocene period	2
8 Where are the streams the Rhine captured?	Vosges Mountains	2
1 Around 25 million years ago ending 11600 years ago was the geological period of the Ice Ages.
2 Since approximately 600000 years ago six major Ice Ages have occurred in which sea level dropped 120 m 390 ft and much of the continental margins became exposed.
3 In the Early Pleistocene the Rhine followed a course to the northwest through the present North Sea.
4 During the socalled Anglian glaciation 450000 yr BP marine oxygen isotope stage 12 the northern part of the present North Sea was blocked by the ice and a large lake developed that overflowed through the English Channel.
5 This caused the Rhines course to be diverted through the English Channel.
6 Since then during glacial times the river mouth was located offshore of Brest France and rivers like the Thames and the Seine became tributaries to the Rhine.
7 During interglacials when sea level rose to approximately the present level the Rhine built deltas in what is now the Netherlands.
8 What period was 25 million years ago?	Ice Ages	1
9 How many major ice ages have occurred?	six	2
10 How far did the sea level drop in the ice ages?	120 m	2
11 In early Pleistocene what direction did the Rhine flow?	northwest	3
12 During glacial times where was the mouth of the Rhine located?	Brest	6
1 The last glacial ran from 74000 BP  Before Present until the end of the Pleistocene 11600 BP.
2 In northwest Europe it saw two very cold phases peaking around 70000 BP and around 29000–24000 BP.
3 The last phase slightly predates the global last ice age maximum Last Glacial Maximum.
4 During this time the lower Rhine flowed roughly west through the Netherlands and extended to the southwest through the English Channel and finally to the Atlantic Ocean.
5 The English Channel the Irish Channel and most of the North Sea were dry land mainly because sea level was approximately 120 m 390 ft lower than today.
6 When did the last glacial start?	74 000 BP	1
7 When did the last glacial end?	11 600 BP	1
8 Which direction did the Rhine flow during the last cold phase?	west	4
9 How much lower was the North Sea in the last cold phase than it is today?	120 m	5
10 Besides the North Sea and the Irish Channel what else was lowered in the last cold phase?	English Channel	5
1 Most of the Rhines current course was not under the ice during the last Ice Age although its source must still have been a glacier.
2 A tundra with Ice Age flora and fauna stretched across middle Europe from Asia to the Atlantic Ocean.
3 Such was the case during the Last Glacial Maximum ca.
4 22000–14000 yr BP when icesheets covered Scandinavia the Baltics Scotland and the Alps but left the space between as open tundra.
5 The loess or windblown dust over that tundra settled in and around the Rhine Valley contributing to its current agricultural usefulness.
6 What was the source of the Rhine in the last Ice Age?	glacier	1
7 What stretched across middle Europe in the last ice age?	tundra	2
8 When was the Last Glacial Maximum?	22 000–14 000 yr BP	4
9 What covered Scandinavia the Baltics Scotland and the Alps in the last Ice Age?	icesheets	4
10 What is the term for windblown dust in a tundra?	loess	5
1 As northwest Europe slowly began to warm up from 22000 years ago onward frozen subsoil and expanded alpine glaciers began to thaw and fallwinter snow covers melted in spring.
2 Much of the discharge was routed to the Rhine and its downstream extension.
3 Rapid warming and changes of vegetation to open forest began about 13000 BP.
4 By 9000 BP Europe was fully forested.
5 With globally shrinking icecover ocean water levels rose and the English Channel and North Sea reinundated.
6 Meltwater adding to the ocean and land subsidence drowned the former coasts of Europe transgressionally.
7 When did Europe slowly begin to warm up from the last Ice Age?	22 000 years ago	1
8 What did frozen subsoil and expanded alpine glaciers begin to do?	thaw	1
9 Where did the discharge from glaciers go in Europe in the last Ice Age?	Rhine	2
10 When did rapid warming begin and help vegetation?	13 000 BP	3
11 When was Europe fully forested and recovered from the last Ice Age?	9000 BP	4
1 Since 7500 yr ago a situation with tides and currents very similar to present has existed.
2 Rates of sealevel rise had dropped so far that natural sedimentation by the Rhine and coastal processes together could compensate the transgression by the sea in the last 7000 years the coast line was roughly at the same location.
3 In the southern North Sea due to ongoing tectonic subsidence the sea level is still rising at the rate of about 1–3 cm 039–118 in per century 1 metre or 39 inches in last 3000 years.
4 When did tides and currents similar to our current system begin?	7500 yr ago	1
5 Why did natural sedimentation by the Rhine compensate the transgression bby the sea?	Rates of sealevel rise	2
6 How long has the Rhine coastline been in the same location?	last 7000 years	2
7 Why is the current sea level rising?	tectonic subsidence	3
8 How quickly is the sea level rising?	1–3 cm 039–118 in per century	3
1 At the begin of the Holocene 11700 years ago the Rhine occupied its LateGlacial valley.
2 As a meandering river it reworked its iceage braidplain.
3 As sealevel continued to rise in the Netherlands the formation of the Holocene RhineMeuse delta began 8000 years ago.
4 Coeval absolute sealevel rise and tectonic subsidence have strongly influenced delta evolution.
5 Other factors of importance to the shape of the delta are the local tectonic activities of the Peel Boundary Fault the substrate and geomorphology as inherited from the Last Glacial and the coastalmarine dynamics such as barrier and tidal inlet formations.
6 When was the Holocene?	11 700 years ago	1
7 When did the formation of the Holocene RhineMeuse delta begin?	8 000 years ago	3
8 Where did the Rhine occupy during the Holocene?	LateGlacial valley	1
9 What country did the Rhine continue to rise during the holocene?	Netherlands	3
1 Since 3000 yr BP  years Before Present human impact is seen in the delta.
2 As a result of increasing land clearance Bronze Age agriculture in the upland areas central Germany the sediment load of the Rhine has strongly increased and delta growth has sped up.
3 This caused increased flooding and sedimentation ending peat formation in the delta.
4 The shifting of river channels to new locations on the floodplain termed avulsion was the main process distributing sediment across the subrecent delta.
5 Over the past 6000 years approximately 80 avulsions have occurred.
6 Direct human impact in the delta started with peat mining for salt and fuel from Roman times onward.
7 This was followed by embankment of the major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries which took place in the 11–13th century AD.
8 Thereafter canals were dug bends were short cut and groynes were built to prevent the rivers channels from migrating or silting up.
9 When have humans started impacting the delta?	3000 yr BP	1
10 What has increased sediment and delta growth also produced in the Rhine?	increased flooding and sedimentation	3
11 What increased in the Rhine because of the land clearance in the upland areas?	sediment load	2
12 When did embankment of the major Rhine distributaries take palce?	11–13th century	7
13 How many avulsions have occurred in the past 6000 yeas?	80	5
1 At present the branches Waal and NederrijnLek discharge to the North Sea through the former Meuse estuary near Rotterdam.
2 The river IJssel branch flows to the north and enters the IJsselmeer formerly the Zuider Zee brackish lagoon however since 1932 a freshwater lake.
3 The discharge of the Rhine is divided among three branches the River Waal 69 of total discharge the River Nederrijn – Lek 29 of total discharge and the River IJssel 19 of total discharge.
4 This discharge distribution has been maintained since 1709 by river engineering works including the digging of the Pannerdens canal and since the 20th century with the help of weirs in the Nederrijn river.
5 Where do the branches Waal and NederrijnLek discharge to?	North Sea	1
6 What do the Waal and the NederrijnLek discharge throguh?	Meuse estuary	1
7 Where does the Ijssel branch flow?	IJsselmeer	2
8 What did the Zuider Zee brackish lagoon change into?	freshwater lake	2
9 How many branches does the Rhine branch into?	three	3
1 The Rhine was not known to Herodotus and first enters the historical period in the 1st century BC in Romanera geography.
2 At that time it formed the boundary between Gaul and Germania.
3 The Upper Rhine had been part of the areal of the late Hallstatt culture since the 6th century BC and by the 1st century BC the areal of the La Tène culture covered almost its entire length forming a contact zone with the Jastorf culture ie.
4 the locus of early CelticGermanic cultural contact.
5 In Roman geography the Rhine formed the boundary between Gallia and Germania by definition eg.
6 Maurus Servius Honoratus Commentary on the Aeneid of Vergil 8727 Rhenus fluvius Galliae qui Germanos a Gallia dividit The Rhine is a river of Gaul which divides the Germanic people from Gaul.
7 When was the Rhine first discovered?	1st century BC	1
8 The Rhine first formed a boundary between Gaul and what else?	Germania	2
9 Since when was the Rhine part of the areal of Hallstatt culture?	6th century BC	3
10 Who first wrote about the Rhines discovery and border?	Maurus Servius Honoratus	6
1 From the death of Augustus in AD 14 until after AD 70 Rome accepted as her Germanic frontier the waterboundary of the Rhine and upper Danube.
2 Beyond these rivers she held only the fertile plain of Frankfurt opposite the Roman border fortress of Moguntiacum Mainz the southernmost slopes of the Black Forest and a few scattered bridgeheads.
3 The northern section of this frontier where the Rhine is deep and broad remained the Roman boundary until the empire fell.
4 The southern part was different.
5 The upper Rhine and upper Danube are easily crossed.
6 The frontier which they form is inconveniently long enclosing an acuteangled wedge of foreign territory between the modern Baden and Württemberg.
7 The Germanic populations of these lands seem in Roman times to have been scanty and Roman subjects from the modern AlsaceLorraine had drifted across the river eastwards.
8 When did Augustus die?	AD 14	1
9 The Rhine and what other river were accepted as the Germanic frontier?	Danube	1
10 When did the Rhine stop being the Roman boundary?	the empire fell	3
11 Which direction did Romans use to drift through the Rhine?	eastwards	7
12 Where are the upper Rhine and upper Danube crossed?	southern	4
1 The Romans kept eight legions in five bases along the Rhine.
2 The actual number of legions present at any base or in all depended on whether a state or threat of war existed.
3 Between about AD 14 and 180 the assignment of legions was as follows for the army of Germania Inferior two legions at Vetera Xanten I Germanica and XX Valeria Pannonian troops two legions at oppidum Ubiorum town of the Ubii which was renamed to Colonia Agrippina descending to Cologne V Alaudae a Celtic legion recruited from Gallia Narbonensis and XXI possibly a Galatian legion from the other side of the empire.
4 How many legions in five bases were along the Rhine by the Romans?	eight	1
5 Vetra and I Germanica and XX Valeria were the two legions for what?	army of Germania Inferior	3
6 What was the Colonia Agrippinas original name?	Ubiorum	3
7 What did the number of legions in Roman times depend on?	threat of war	2
8 What does Colonia Agrippinas original name translate into?	town of the Ubii	3
1 Germanic tribes crossed the Rhine in the Migration period by the 5th century establishing the kingdoms of Francia on the Lower Rhine Burgundy on the Upper Rhine and Alemannia on the High Rhine.
2 This Germanic Heroic Age is reflected in medieval legend such as the Nibelungenlied which tells of the hero Siegfried killing a dragon on the Drachenfels Siebengebirge dragons rock near Bonn at the Rhine and of the Burgundians and their court at Worms at the Rhine and Kriemhilds golden treasure which was thrown into the Rhine by Hagen.
3 When did Germanic tribes cross the Rhine to migrate?	5th century	1
4 What did Germanic tribes establish with help from the Rhine?	kingdoms	1
5 What is the translation of Siebengebirge?	dragons rock	2
6 Who is the hero who killed a dragon on the Drachenfels?	Siegfried	2
7 Who threw gold into the Rhine according to legend?	Hagen	2
1 By the 6th century the Rhine was within the borders of Francia.
2 In the 9th it formed part of the border between Middle and Western Francia but in the 10th century it was fully within the Holy Roman Empire flowing through Swabia Franconia and Lower Lorraine.
3 The mouths of the Rhine in the county of Holland fell to the Burgundian Netherlands in the 15th century Holland remained contentious territory throughout the European wars of religion and the eventual collapse of the Holy Roman Empire when the length of the Rhine fell to the First French Empire and its client states.
4 The Alsace on the left banks of the Upper Rhine was sold to Burgundy by Archduke Sigismund of Austria in 1469 and eventually fell to France in the Thirty Years War.
5 The numerous historic castles in RhinelandPalatinate attest to the importance of the river as a commercial route.
6 When did the Rhine become borders with Francia?	6th century	1
7 When was the Rhine fully within the Holy Roman Empire?	10th century	2
8 The Rhine flowed through Swabia Franconia and what other location in the 10th Century?	Lower Lorraine	2
9 Who sold the Upper Rhine to Burgundy?	Archduke Sigismund	4
10 When was the Upper Rhine sold to Burgundy?	1469	4
1 Since the Peace of Westphalia the Upper Rhine formed a contentious border between France and Germany.
2 Establishing natural borders on the Rhine was a longterm goal of French foreign policy since the Middle Ages though the language border was – and is – far more to the west.
3 French leaders such as Louis XIV and Napoleon Bonaparte tried with varying degrees of success to annex lands west of the Rhine.
4 The Confederation of the Rhine was established by Napoleon as a French client state in 1806 and lasted until 1814 during which time it served as a significant source of resources and military manpower for the First French Empire.
5 In 1840 the Rhine crisis prompted by French prime minister Adolphe Thierss desire to reinstate the Rhine as a natural border led to a diplomatic crisis and a wave of nationalism in Germany.
6 What was the name of the time the Upper Rhine form a border between France and Germany?	Peace of Westphalia	1
7 What was a long term goal of French foreign policy along the Rhine?	Establishing natural borders	2
8 Who established the Confederation of the Rhine?	Napoleon	4
9 When was the confederation of the Rhine?	1806	4
10 When was the Rhine crisis?	1840	5
1 At the end of World War I the Rhineland was subject to the Treaty of Versailles.
2 This decreed that it would be occupied by the allies until 1935 and after that it would be a demilitarised zone with the German army forbidden to enter.
3 The Treaty of Versailles and this particular provision in general caused much resentment in Germany and is often cited as helping Adolf Hitlers rise to power.
4 The allies left the Rhineland in 1930 and the German army reoccupied it in 1936 which was enormously popular in Germany.
5 Although the allies could probably have prevented the reoccupation Britain and France were not inclined to do so a feature of their policy of appeasement to Hitler.
6 When was Rhineland subject to the Treaty of Versailles?	end of World War I	1
7 When would the occupation of allies leave Rhineland?	1935	2
8 After 1935 who would be forbidden to enter Rhineland?	German army	2
9 What do some believe the Treaty of Versailles assisted in?	Adolf Hitlers rise to power	3
10 When did the German army reoccupy Rhineland?	1936	4
1 In World War II it was recognised that the Rhine would present a formidable natural obstacle to the invasion of Germany by the Western Allies.
2 The Rhine bridge at Arnhem immortalized in the book A Bridge Too Far and the film was a central focus of the battle for Arnhem during the failed Operation Market Garden of September 1944.
3 The bridges at Nijmegen over the Waal distributary of the Rhine were also an objective of Operation Market Garden.
4 In a separate operation the Ludendorff Bridge crossing the Rhine at Remagen became famous when US forces were able to capture it intact – much to their own surprise – after the Germans failed to demolish it.
5 This also became the subject of a film The Bridge at Remagen.
6 Seven Days to the River Rhine was a Warsaw Pact war plan for an invasion of Western Europe during the Cold War.
7 Where is the Rhine Bridge?	Arnhem	2
8 What was the Rhine considered to invaders in WWII?	formidable natural obstacle	1
9 When was Operation Market Garden?	September 1944	2
10 What bridge did the Germans fail to demolish?	Ludendorff Bridge	4
11 What was the Warsaw Pact war plan?	Seven Days to the River Rhine	6
1 Until 1932 the generally accepted length of the Rhine was 1230 kilometres 764 miles.
2 In 1932 the German encyclopedia Knaurs Lexikon stated the length as 1320 kilometres 820 miles presumably a typographical error.
3 After this number was placed into the authoritative Brockhaus Enzyklopädie it became generally accepted and found its way into numerous textbooks and official publications.
4 The error was discovered in 2010 and the Dutch Rijkswaterstaat confirms the length at 1232 kilometres 766 miles.
5 note 1.
6 What was the accepted length of the Rhine prior to 1932?	1 230 kilometres 764 miles	1
7 Who stated a change of the length of the Rhine?	Knaurs Lexikon	2
8 Why was the Rhine measurement changed?	typographical error	2
9 in 1932 what was the Rhine measurement changed to?	1 320 kilometres 820 miles	2
10 When was the Rhine measurement corrected back to the original?	2010	4
1 Following a referendum in 1997 in which the Scottish electorate voted for devolution the current Parliament was convened by the Scotland Act 1998 which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature.
2 The Act delineates the legislative competence of the Parliament – the areas in which it can make laws – by explicitly specifying powers that are reserved to the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
3 The Scottish Parliament has the power to legislate in all areas that are not explicitly reserved to Westminster.
4 The British Parliament retains the ability to amend the terms of reference of the Scottish Parliament and can extend or reduce the areas in which it can make laws.
5 The first meeting of the new Parliament took place on 12 May 1999.
6 When was the current parliament of Scotland convened?	Following a referendum in 1997	1
7 What act set out the Parliaments powers as a devolved legislature?	Scotland Act 1998	1
8 The legislative competence of the Parliament species what areas?	in which it can make laws	2
9 To what body are certain powers explicitly specified as being reserved for?	Parliament of the United Kingdom	2
10 The Scottish Parliament may legislate as it pleases as long as the powers arent already reserved by where?	Westminster	3
1 For the next three hundred years Scotland was directly governed by the Parliament of Great Britain and the subsequent Parliament of the United Kingdom both seated at Westminster and the lack of a Parliament of Scotland remained an important element in Scottish national identity.
2 Suggestions for a devolved Parliament were made before 1914 but were shelved due to the outbreak of the First World War.
3 A sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland during the late 1960s fuelled demands for some form of home rule or complete independence and in 1969 prompted the incumbent Labour government of Harold Wilson to set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British constitution.
4 One of the principal objectives of the commission was to examine ways of enabling more selfgovernment for Scotland within the unitary state of the United Kingdom.
5 Kilbrandon published his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a directly elected Scottish Assembly to legislate for the majority of domestic Scottish affairs.
6 What remained an important issue in Scottish national identity for many years?	lack of a Parliament of Scotland	1
7 How many hundred of years was Scotland directly governed by the parliament of Great Britain?	three hundred	1
8 Why were the initial suggestions for a devolved parliament before 1914 shelved?	First World War	2
9 When was there a sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland?	the late 1960s	3
10 What did Kllbrandons report in 1973 recommend establishing?	directly elected Scottish Assembly	5
1 During this time the discovery of oil in the North Sea and the following Its Scotlands oil campaign of the Scottish National Party SNP resulted in rising support for Scottish independence as well as the SNP.
2 The party argued that the revenues from the oil were not benefitting Scotland as much as they should.
3 The combined effect of these events led to Prime Minister Wilson committing his government to some form of devolved legislature in 1974.
4 However it was not until 1978 that final legislative proposals for a Scottish Assembly were passed by the United Kingdom Parliament.
5 Which sea was oil discovered in?	North	1
6 What campaigh did the Scottish National Party SNP run?	Its Scotlands oil	1
7 When did Prime Minister Wilson commit to some form of devolved legislature?	1974	3
8 What did the SNP publicly opine about the oil revenues?	not benefitting Scotland as much as they should	2
9 When was the final legislative proposals for a Scottish Assembly passed?	1978	4
1 Under the terms of the Scotland Act 1978 an elected assembly would be set up in Edinburgh provided that the majority of the Scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 March 1979 that represented at least 40 of the total electorate.
2 The 1979 Scottish devolution referendum to establish a devolved Scottish Assembly failed.
3 Although the vote was 516 in favour of a Scottish Assembly this figure did not equal the 40 of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure as 329 of the eligible voting population did not or had been unable to vote.
4 Where was an elected assembly to be set up under the terms of the Scotland Act of 1978?	Edinburgh	1
5 How many of the Scottish electorate would need to for it on the referendum?	majority	1
6 What percentage of the vote for a Scottish Assembly in favor of it?	516	3
7 How did trying to establish a devolved Scottish Assembly go in 1979?	failed	2
8 What percentage of Scotlands voting population failed to actually vote?	329	3
1 Throughout the 1980s and 1990s demand for a Scottish Parliament grew in part because the government of the United Kingdom was controlled by the Conservative Party while Scotland itself elected relatively few Conservative MPs.
2 In the aftermath of the 1979 referendum defeat the Campaign for a Scottish Assembly was initiated as a pressure group leading to the 1989 Scottish Constitutional Convention with various organisations such as Scottish churches political parties and representatives of industry taking part.
3 Publishing its blueprint for devolution in 1995 the Convention provided much of the basis for the structure of the Parliament.
4 In the range between 1980 and 1990 what did demand for grow?	a Scottish Parliament	1
5 Whose control of the UKs government helped fuel a desire for a Scottish Parliament?	the Conservative Party	1
6 When was the Scottish Constitutional Convention held?	1989	2
7 What provided much of the basis for the structure of the Parliament in 1995?	blueprint	3
1 Since September 2004 the official home of the Scottish Parliament has been a new Scottish Parliament Building in the Holyrood area of Edinburgh.
2 The Scottish Parliament building was designed by Spanish architect Enric Miralles in partnership with local Edinburgh Architecture firm RMJM which was led by Design Principal Tony Kettle.
3 Some of the principal features of the complex include leafshaped buildings a grassroofed branch merging into adjacent parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings.
4 Throughout the building there are many repeated motifs such as shapes based on Raeburns Skating Minister.
5 Crowstepped gables and the upturned boat skylights of the Garden Lobby complete the unique architecture.
6 Queen Elizabeth II opened the new building on 9 October 2004.
7 Where has the official home of the Scottish Parliament been since 2004?	Scottish Parliament Building	1
8 Who designed the Scottish Parliament building?	Enric Miralles	2
9 What nationality is the architect Enric Miralles?	Spanish	2
10 What shape are some of the buildings in the Parliament complex?	leafshaped	3
11 Who opened the new Parliament building on October 9 2004?	Queen Elizabeth II	6
1 Whilst the permanent building at Holyrood was being constructed the Parliaments temporary home was the General Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland on the Royal Mile in Edinburgh.
2 Official photographs and television interviews were held in the courtyard adjoining the Assembly Hall which is part of the School of Divinity of the University of Edinburgh.
3 This building was vacated twice to allow for the meeting of the Churchs General Assembly.
4 In May 2000 the Parliament was temporarily relocated to the former Strathclyde Regional Council debating chamber in Glasgow and to the University of Aberdeen in May 2002.
5 What was the building vacated twice to allow for?	meeting of the Churchs General Assembly	3
6 Where was Parliaments temporary home whilst the permanent building was being built?	General Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland	1
7 Where were interviews held while the parliament was in its temporary building?	courtyard	2
8 In May 2002 where would you go to address the Parliament?	University of Aberdeen	4
9 Where was Parliament temporarily relocated to in May of 2000?	former Strathclyde Regional Council debating chamber in Glasgow	4
1 In addition to the General Assembly Hall the Parliament also used buildings rented from the City of Edinburgh Council.
2 The former administrative building of Lothian Regional Council on George IV Bridge was used for the MSPs offices.
3 Following the move to Holyrood in 2004 this building was demolished.
4 The former Midlothian County Buildings facing Parliament Square High Street and George IV Bridge in Edinburgh originally built as the headquarters of the pre1975 Midlothian County Council housed the Parliaments visitors centre and shop whilst the main hall was used as the Parliaments principal committee room.
5 Who did the Parliament rent additional buildings from?	City of Edinburgh Council	1
6 What  former administrative building was used for the MSPs offices?	Lothian Regional Council	2
7 What happened to the building on George IV Bridge when the Parliament was done with it?	demolished	3
8 What do the former Midlothian County Buildings face?	Parliament Square  High Street and George IV Bridge in Edinburgh	4
9 Which hall was used as Parliaments principle committee room?	main	4
1 After each election to the Scottish Parliament at the beginning of each parliamentary session Parliament elects one MSP to serve as Presiding Officer the equivalent of the speaker currently Tricia Marwick and two MSPs to serve as deputies currently Elaine Smith and John Scott.
2 The Presiding Officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 MSPs which is the only secret ballot conducted in the Scottish Parliament.
3 Principally the role of the Presiding Officer is to chair chamber proceedings and the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body.
4 When chairing meetings of the Parliament the Presiding Officer and hisher deputies must be politically impartial.
5 During debates the Presiding Officer or the deputy is assisted by the parliamentary clerks who give advice on how to interpret the standing orders that govern the proceedings of meetings.
6 A vote clerk sits in front of the Presiding Officer and operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks.
7 Who is elected to serve as the Presiding Officer at the beginning of each parliamentary session?	one MSP	1
8 Who is currently speaker of the Scottish Parliament?	Tricia Marwick	1
9 What type of ballot is used to elect the Presiding Officer and deputies of the Parliament?	secret	2
10 How many MSPs are there?	129	2
11 Who is responsible for operating the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks?	A vote clerk	6
1 As a member of the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body the Presiding Officer is responsible for ensuring that the Parliament functions effectively and has the staff property and resources it requires to operate.
