2 Convening the Parliamentary Bureau which allocates time and sets the work agenda in the chamber is another of the roles of the Presiding Officer.
3 Under the Standing Orders of the Parliament the Bureau consists of the Presiding Officer and one representative from each political parties with five or more seats in the Parliament.
4 Amongst the duties of the Bureau are to agree the timetable of business in the chamber establish the number remit and membership of parliamentary committees and regulate the passage of legislation bills through the Parliament.
5 The Presiding Officer also represents the Scottish Parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity.
6 Who is responsible for ensuring the Parliament works smoothly?	Presiding Officer	1
7 Who sets the work agenda and allocates time in the chamber?	the Parliamentary Bureau	2
8 How many seats must a political party have to be represented on the Parliamentary Bureau?	five	3
9 Who represents the Scottish Parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity?	The Presiding Officer	5
1 The debating chamber of the Scottish Parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle which reflects the desire to encourage consensus amongst elected members.
2 There are 131 seats in the debating chamber.
3 Of the total 131 seats 129 are occupied by the Parliaments elected MSPs and 2 are seats for the Scottish Law Officers – the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General for Scotland who are not elected members of the Parliament but are members of the Scottish Government.
4 As such the Law Officers may attend and speak in the plenary meetings of the Parliament but as they are not elected MSPs cannot vote.
5 Members are able to sit anywhere in the debating chamber but typically sit in their party groupings.
6 The First Minister Scottish cabinet ministers and Law officers sit in the front row in the middle section of the chamber.
7 The largest party in the Parliament sits in the middle of the semicircle with opposing parties on either side.
8 The Presiding Officer parliamentary clerks and officials sit opposite members at the front of the debating chamber.
9 What is the seating arrangement of the debating chamber?	hemicycle	1
10 Why is the seating of the debating chamber arranged as it is?	encourage consensus amongst elected members	1
11 How many seats are in the debating chamber?	131	2
12 How many members in the seats of the Scottish Parliament are members of the Scottish Government?	2	3
13 What can the nonelected members from the Scottish Government not do?	vote	4
1 In front of the Presiding Officers desk is the parliamentary mace which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from Scottish rivers and inscribed with the words Wisdom Compassion Justice and Integrity.
2 The words There shall be a Scottish Parliament which are the first words of the Scotland Act are inscribed around the head of the mace which has a formal ceremonial role in the meetings of Parliament reinforcing the authority of the Parliament in its ability to make laws.
3 Presented to the Scottish Parliament by the Queen upon its official opening in July 1999 the mace is displayed in a glass case suspended from the lid.
4 At the beginning of each sitting in the chamber the lid of the case is rotated so that the mace is above the glass to symbolise that a full meeting of the Parliament is taking place.
5 Where does the gold in the parliamentary mace come from?	Scottish rivers	1
6 What is the parliamentary mace made of?	silver	1
7 Who presented the mac to the Scottish Parliament when it was initially opened?	the Queen	3
8 What words are inscribed on the mace of parliament?	Wisdom  Compassion  Justice and Integrity	1
9 What is the mace displayed in?	a glass case suspended from the lid	3
1 Parliament typically sits Tuesdays Wednesdays and Thursdays from early January to late June and from early September to mid December with twoweek recesses in April and October.
2 Plenary meetings in the debating chamber usually take place on Wednesday afternoons from 2 pm to 6 pm and on Thursdays from 915 am to 6 pm.
3 Chamber debates and committee meetings are open to the public.
4 Entry is free but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space.
5 Meetings are broadcast on the Parliaments own channel Holyroodtv and on the BBCs parliamentary channel BBC Parliament.
6 Proceedings are also recorded in text form in print and online in the Official Report which is the substantially verbatim transcript of parliamentary debates.
7 Which month is the first in the year Parliament takes a two week vacation?	April	1
8 Where do plenary meetings take place?	debating chamber	2
9 Who are debates and meetings open to?	the public	3
10 How much does it cost to gain entry to a parliament meeting?	free	4
11 What contains a nearly verbatim of parliamentary debates?	the Official Report	6
1 The first item of business on Wednesdays is usually Time for Reflection at which a speaker addresses members for up to four minutes sharing a perspective on issues of faith.
2 This contrasts with the formal style of Prayers which is the first item of business in meetings of the House of Commons.
3 Speakers are drawn from across Scotland and are chosen to represent the balance of religious beliefs according to the Scottish census.
4 Invitations to address Parliament in this manner are determined by the Presiding Officer on the advice of the parliamentary bureau.
5 Faith groups can make direct representations to the Presiding Officer to nominate speakers.
6 What day of the week does the Time for Reflection take place?	Wednesdays	1
7 How long might a speaker address the members during the Time of Reflection?	up to four minutes	1
8 Who decides who gets to address the members of Parliament to share their thoughts on issues of faith?	Presiding Officer	4
9 Because speakers are drawn from across Scotland what do the represent the balance of?	religious beliefs	3
10 What can faith groups ask the Presiding Officer to do for them?	nominate speakers	5
1 The Presiding Officer or Deputy Presiding Officer decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak.
2 Normally the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak.
3 Typically ministers or party leaders open debates with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes and succeeding speakers allocated less time.
4 The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate.
5 Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems.
6 Members may call each other directly by name rather than by constituency or cabinet position and hand clapping is allowed.
7 Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English but members may use Scots Gaelic or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer.
8 The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.
9 Who decides who gets to speak in the chamber debates?	The Presiding Officer	1
10 What is also decided by the Presiding Officer?	amount of time for which they are allowed to speak	1
11 What does the Presiding Officer try to achieve a balance of between speakers?	different viewpoints	2
12 What members typically open debates?	ministers or party leaders	3
13 What language other than English has the Scottish Parliament had meetings in?	Gaelic	8
1 Each sitting day normally at 5 pm MSPs decide on all the motions and amendments that have been moved that day.
2 This Decision Time is heralded by the sounding of the division bell which is heard throughout the Parliamentary campus and alerts MSPs who are not in the chamber to return and vote.
3 At Decision Time the Presiding Officer puts questions on the motions and amendments by reading out the name of the motion or amendment as well as the proposer and asking Are we all agreed.
4  to which the chamber first votes orally.
5 If there is audible dissent the Presiding Officer announces There will be a division and members vote by means of electronic consoles on their desks.
6 Each MSP has a unique access card with a microchip which when inserted into the console identifies them and allows them to vote.
7 As a result the outcome of each division is known in seconds.
8 What time do the MSPs normally decide on the motions and amendments from that day?	5 pm	1
9 What is heralded by the sounding of the division bell?	Decision Time	2
10 What do MSPs who are not in the chamber when the division bell rings return to do?	vote	2
11 How do members vote when there is a division?	electronic consoles on their desks	5
12 How long does it take to know the outcome of a division?	seconds	7
1 The outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote.
2 Parties entrust some MSPs known as whips with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line.
3 MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions since those who do are unlikely to reach higher political ranks in their parties.
4 Errant members can be deselected as official party candidates during future elections and in serious cases may be expelled from their parties outright.
5 Thus as with many Parliaments the independence of Members of the Scottish Parliament tends to be low and backbench rebellions by members who are discontent with their partys policies are rare.
6 In some circumstances however parties announce free votes which allows Members to vote as they please.
7 This is typically done on moral issues.
8 What can often be predicted beforehand?	votes	1
9 Who normally instructs members how to vote?	political parties	1
10 Who has the task of ensuring party members vote according to the party line?	whips	2
11 What type of issues are members typically allowed to vote as they please?	moral	7
12 What happens if a member doesnt vote the party line?	deselected as official party candidates during future elections	4
1 Immediately after Decision Time a Members Debate is held which lasts for 45 minutes.
2 Members Business is a debate on a motion proposed by an MSP who is not a Scottish minister.
3 Such motions are on issues which may be of interest to a particular area such as a members own constituency an upcoming or past event or any other item which would otherwise not be accorded official parliamentary time.
4 As well as the proposer other members normally contribute to the debate.
5 The relevant minister whose department the debate and motion relate to winds up the debate by speaking after all other participants.
6 When is the Members Debate held?	Immediately after Decision Time	1
7 Why are debates on proposed motions by an MSP conducted?	not a Scottish minister	2
8 How long does the Members Debate last?	45 minutes	1
9 Who contributes to Members Business in addition to the proposer?	other members	4
10 What does the minister who was the catalyst of the Members Business do by speaking after everyone else?	winds up	5
1 Much of the work of the Scottish Parliament is done in committee.
2 The role of committees is stronger in the Scottish Parliament than in other parliamentary systems partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the government and partly to compensate for the fact that there is no revising chamber.
3 The principal role of committees in the Scottish Parliament is to take evidence from witnesses conduct inquiries and scrutinise legislation.
4 Committee meetings take place on Tuesday Wednesday and Thursday morning when Parliament is sitting.
5 Committees can also meet at other locations throughout Scotland.
6 Where is much of the work of the Scottish Parliament done?	committee	1
7 What are committees in the Scottish Parliament compared to other systems?	stronger	2
8 What is one avenue being compensated for by having committees serve such a large role?	no revising chamber	2
9 Taking evidence from witnesses is one of committees what?	principal role	3
10 Where might committees meet outside of Parliament?	other locations throughout Scotland	5
1 Committees comprise a small number of MSPs with membership reflecting the balance of parties across Parliament.
2 There are different committees with their functions set out in different ways.
3 Mandatory Committees are committees which are set down under the Scottish Parliaments standing orders which govern their remits and proceedings.
4 The current Mandatory Committees in the fourth Session of the Scottish Parliament are Public Audit Equal Opportunities European and External Relations Finance Public Petitions Standards Procedures and Public Appointments and Delegated Powers and Law Reform.
5 Who are committees comprised of?	a small number of MSPs	1
6 What do the membership of the committees reflect?	balance of parties	1
7 Different committees have what set out in different ways?	functions	2
8 What type of committee is set down under the SPs standing orders?	Mandatory	3
9 What session is the Scottish Parliament in?	fourth	4
1 Subject Committees are established at the beginning of each parliamentary session and again the members on each committee reflect the balance of parties across Parliament.
2 Typically each committee corresponds with one or more of the departments or ministries of the Scottish Government.
3 The current Subject Committees in the fourth Session are Economy Energy and Tourism Education and Culture Health and Sport Justice Local Government and Regeneration Rural Affairs Climate Change and Environment Welfare Reform and Infrastructure and Capital Investment.
4 When are subject committees established?	beginning of each parliamentary session	1
5 How many ministries of the Scottish government does a committee typically correspond to?	one	2
6 Economy Energy and Tourism is one of the what?	current Subject Committees	3
7 What is the Scottish Parliament currently in the fourth of?	Session	3
1 A further type of committee is normally set up to scrutinise private bills submitted to the Scottish Parliament by an outside party or promoter who is not a member of the Scottish Parliament or Scottish Government.
2 Private bills normally relate to largescale development projects such as infrastructure projects that require the use of land or property.
3 Private Bill Committees have been set up to consider legislation on issues such as the development of the Edinburgh Tram Network the Glasgow Airport Rail Link the AirdrieBathgate Rail Link and extensions to the National Gallery of Scotland.
4 What is set up to scrutinize private bills submitted by party outsiders?	type of committee	1
5 What topic do private bills typically have?	largescale development projects	2
6 Who decides how land or property is allowed to be used?	Scottish Government	1
7 What kind of committee considered legislation on the development of the Edinburgh Tram Network?	Private Bill	3
1 The Scotland Act 1998 which was passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom and given royal assent by Queen Elizabeth II on 19 November 1998 governs the functions and role of the Scottish Parliament and delimits its legislative competence.
2 The Scotland Act 2012 extends the devolved competencies.
3 For the purposes of parliamentary sovereignty the Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster continues to constitute the supreme legislature of Scotland.
4 However under the terms of the Scotland Act Westminster agreed to devolve some of its responsibilities over Scottish domestic policy to the Scottish Parliament.
5 Such devolved matters include education health agriculture and justice.
6 The Scotland Act enabled the Scottish Parliament to pass primary legislation on these issues.
7 A degree of domestic authority and all foreign policy remain with the UK Parliament in Westminster.
8 The Scottish Parliament has the power to pass laws and has limited taxvarying capability.
9 Another of the roles of the Parliament is to hold the Scottish Government to account.
10 What act sets forth the functions of the Scottish Parliament?	Scotland Act 1998	1
11 Who gave her royal assent to the Scotland Act of 1998?	Queen Elizabeth II	1
12 What does the Scotland Act of 2012 extend?	devolved competencies	2
13 What body constitutes the supreme legislature of Scotland?	Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster	3
14 Who has the role of holding the Scottish Government to account?	Scottish Parliament	8
1 The specific devolved matters are all subjects which are not explicitly stated in Schedule 5 to the Scotland Act as reserved matters.
2 All matters that are not specifically reserved are automatically devolved to the Scottish Parliament.
3 Most importantly this includes agriculture fisheries and forestry economic development education environment food standards health home affairs Scots law – courts police and fire services local government sport and the arts transport training tourism research and statistics and social work.
4 The Scottish Parliament has the ability to alter income tax in Scotland by up to 3 pence in the pound.
5 The 2012 Act conferred further fiscal devolution including borrowing powers and some other unconnected matters such as setting speed limits and control of air guns.
6 Where are reserved matters stated in the Scotland Act?	Schedule 5	1
7 If a matter is not specifically reserved who is it devolved to?	Scottish Parliament	2
8 Why do police and fire services fall under the purview of the Scottish Parliament?	automatically devolved	2
9 How much can the SP alter income tax in Scotland?	up to 3 pence in the pound	4
10 Setting speed limits was one of the further devolutions which was conferred by what act?	2012 Act	5
1 Reserved matters are subjects that are outside the legislative competence of the Scotland Parliament.
2 The Scottish Parliament is unable to legislate on such issues that are reserved to and dealt with at Westminster and where Ministerial functions usually lie with UK Government ministers.
3 These include abortion broadcasting policy civil service common markets for UK goods and services constitution electricity coal oil gas nuclear energy defence and national security drug policy employment foreign policy and relations with Europe most aspects of transport safety and regulation National Lottery protection of borders social security and stability of UKs fiscal economic and monetary system.
4 What is the name of matters outside the legislative ability of the Scottish Parliament?	Reserved	1
5 Issues dealt with at Westminster are not ones who is able to deal with?	Scottish Parliament	2
6 Where are issues like abortion and drug policy legislated on?	Westminster	2
7 Most aspects of transport safety is a subject dealt with by whom?	UK Government ministers	2
1 Bills can be introduced to Parliament in a number of ways the Scottish Government can introduce new laws or amendments to existing laws as a bill a committee of the Parliament can present a bill in one of the areas under its remit a member of the Scottish Parliament can introduce a bill as a private member or a private bill can be submitted to Parliament by an outside proposer.
2 Most draft laws are government bills introduced by ministers in the governing party.
3 Bills pass through Parliament in a number of stages.
4 What may be presented to Parliament in various ways?	Bills	1
5 Who may introduce new laws or amendments to laws already on the books as a bill?	the Scottish Government	1
6 An MSP may introduce a bill as what?	a private member	1
7 Who may also submit private bills to Parliament?	an outside proposer	1
8 How do bills pass through Parliament?	in a number of stages	3
1 Stage 1 is the first or introductory stage of the bill where the minister or member in charge of the bill will formally introduce it to Parliament together with its accompanying documents – Explanatory Notes a Policy Memorandum setting out the policy underlying the bill and a Financial Memorandum setting out the costs and savings associated with it.
2 Statements from the Presiding Officer and the member in charge of the bill are also lodged indicating whether the bill is within the legislative competence of the Parliament.
3 Stage 1 usually takes place initially in the relevant committee or committees and is then submitted to the whole Parliament for a full debate in the chamber on the general principles of the bill.
4 If the whole Parliament agrees in a vote to the general principles of the bill it then proceeds to Stage 2.
5 What is stage 1 in the life of a bill?	introductory	1
6 What are presented to parliament in addition to the bill itself?	accompanying documents	1
7 What do statements from the PO and member in charge of the bill also indicate?	whether the bill is within the legislative competence of the Parliament	2
8 Where are bills typically gestated in Stage 1?	in the relevant committee or committees	3
9 If Parliament agrees in a vote to the general principle of a bill what does it then proceed to?	Stage 2	4
1 Stage 3 is the final stage of the bill and is considered at a meeting of the whole Parliament.
2 This stage comprises two parts consideration of amendments to the bill as a general debate and a final vote on the bill.
3 Opposition members can table wrecking amendments to the bill designed to thwart further progress and take up parliamentary time to cause the bill to fall without a final vote being taken.
4 After a general debate on the final form of the bill members proceed to vote at Decision Time on whether they agree to the general principles of the final bill.
5 What is the final stage of a bill in the Scottish Parliament?	Stage 3	1
6 How many parts does the consideration of a bill in Stage 3 have?	two	2
7 What vote on a bill takes place in Stage 3?	final	2
8 What type of amendments might members opposed to a bill put on the table?	wrecking	3
9 When do members proceed to vote on whether they agree to the principles of the final bill?	Decision Time	4
1 Royal assent After the bill has been passed the Presiding Officer submits it to the Monarch for royal assent and it becomes an Act of the Scottish Parliament.
2 However he cannot do so until a 4week period has elapsed during which the Law Officers of the Scottish Government or UK Government can refer the bill to the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom for a ruling on whether it is within the powers of the Parliament.
3 Acts of the Scottish Parliament do not begin with a conventional enacting formula.
4 Instead they begin with a phrase that reads The Bill for this Act of the Scottish Parliament was passed by the Parliament on Date and received royal assent on Date.
5 Who does the Presiding Officer submit the final bill to?	the Monarch	1
6 Why is the final bill passed to the Monarch?	royal assent	1
7 What is the minimum amount of time before a bill can go into law?	a 4week period	2
8 Who is a bill referred to for a ruling on whether its within the powers of the Parliament?	Supreme Court of the United Kingdom	2
9 What does the template for bills passed by the Scottish Parliament include?	Date	4
1 The party or parties that hold the majority of seats in the Parliament forms the Scottish Government.
2 In contrast to many other parliamentary systems Parliament elects a First Minister from a number of candidates at the beginning of each parliamentary term after a general election.
3 Any member can put their name forward to be First Minister and a vote is taken by all members of Parliament.
4 Normally the leader of the largest party is returned as First Minister and head of the Scottish Government.
5 Theoretically Parliament also elects the Scottish Ministers who form the government of Scotland and sit in the Scottish cabinet but such ministers are in practice appointed to their roles by the First Minister.
6 Junior ministers who do not attend cabinet are also appointed to assist Scottish ministers in their departments.
7 Most ministers and their juniors are drawn from amongst the elected MSPs with the exception of Scotlands Chief Law Officers the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General.
8 Whilst the First Minister chooses the ministers – and may decide to remove them at any time – the formal appointment or dismissal is made by the Sovereign.
9 What party forms the Scottish Parliament?	hold the majority of seats	1
10 Who is eligible to toss their name in the hat to be First Minister?	Any member	3
11 Who is elected at the beginning of each term?	First Minister	2
12 Other than Scotlands Chief Law Officer from whence are most ministers drawn from amongst?	elected MSPs	7
13 Who makes formal appointment or dismissal decisions?	the Sovereign	8
1 Under the Scotland Act 1998 ordinary general elections for the Scottish Parliament are held on the first Thursday in May every four years 1999 2003 2007 and so on.
2 The date of the poll may be varied by up to one month either way by the Monarch on the proposal of the Presiding Officer.
3 If the Parliament itself resolves that it should be dissolved with at least twothirds of the Members voting in favour or if the Parliament fails to nominate one of its members to be First Minister within 28 days of a General Election or of the position becoming vacant the Presiding Officer proposes a date for an extraordinary general election and the Parliament is dissolved by the Queen by royal proclamation.
4 Extraordinary general elections are in addition to ordinary general elections unless held less than six months before the due date of an ordinary general election in which case they supplant it.
5 The following ordinary election reverts to the first Thursday in May a multiple of four years after 1999 ie 5 May 2011 7 May 2015 etc.
6 .
7 What day of the week are general elections held?	Thursday	1
8 What month every four years are the ordinary general elections held on?	May	1
9 Who may change the date by up to a month on the proposal of the PO?	the Monarch	2
10 If an extraordinary election is held within less than six months before the date of an ordinary election what does it do to the ordinary election?	supplant it	4
11 How many days does the Parliament have to nominate a First Minister after a General Election?	28	3
1 Several procedures enable the Scottish Parliament to scrutinise the Government.
2 The First Minister or members of the cabinet can deliver statements to Parliament upon which MSPs are invited to question.
3 For example at the beginning of each parliamentary year the First Minister delivers a statement to the chamber setting out the Governments legislative programme for the forthcoming year.
4 After the statement has been delivered the leaders of the opposition parties and other MSPs question the First Minister on issues related to the substance of the statement.
5 What enables the Scottish Parliament to scrutinize the government?	Several procedures	1
6 Who can question statements the First Minister or members of the cabinet make?	MSPs	2
7 What does the First Minister deliver at the beginning of each parliamentary year?	legislative programme for the forthcoming year	3
8 What do the leaders of the opposition parties and other MSPs question the First Minister about?	issues related to the substance of the statement	4
1 Parliamentary time is also set aside for question periods in the debating chamber.
2 A General Question Time takes place on a Thursday between 1140 am and 12 pm where members can direct questions to any member of the Scottish Government.
3 At 230pm a 40minute long themed Question Time takes place where members can ask questions of ministers in departments that are selected for questioning that sitting day such as health and justice or education and transport.
4 Between 12 pm and 1230 pm on Thursdays when Parliament is sitting First Ministers Question Time takes place.
5 This gives members an opportunity to question the First Minister directly on issues under their jurisdiction.
6 Opposition leaders ask a general question of the First Minister and then supplementary questions.
7 Such a practice enables a leadin to the questioner who then uses their supplementary question to ask the First Minister any issue.
8 The four general questions available to opposition leaders are.
9 What is set aside for question periods in the debating chamber?	Parliamentary time	1
10 On what day does a General Question Time take place?	Thursday	2
11 Who may members direct questions towards during General Question Time?	any member of the Scottish Government	2
12 What may members question the First Minister about directly during First Ministers Question Time?	issues under their jurisdiction	5
13 How many general questions are available to opposition leaders?	four	8
1 Of the 129 MSPs 73 are elected to represent first past the post constituencies and are known as Constituency MSPs.
2 Voters choose one member to represent the constituency and the member with most votes is returned as a constituency MSP.
3 The 73 Scottish Parliament constituencies shared the same boundaries as the UK Parliament constituencies in Scotland prior to the 2005 reduction in the number of Scottish MPs with the exception of Orkney and Shetland which each return their own constituency MSP.
4 Currently the average Scottish Parliament constituency comprises 55000 electors.
5 Given the geographical distribution of population in Scotland this results in constituencies of a smaller area in the Central Lowlands where the bulk of Scotlands population live and much larger constituency areas in the north and west of the country which have a low population density.
6 The island archipelagos of Orkney Shetland and the Western Isles comprise a much smaller number of electors due to their dispersed population and distance from the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh.
7 If a Constituency MSP resigns from Parliament this triggers a byelection in his or her constituency where a replacement MSP is returned from one of the parties by the plurality system.
8 What is the number of Constituency MSPs?	73	1
9 When was there a reduction in the number of Scottish MPs?	2005	3
10 How many members can voters choose to represent the constituency?	one	2
11 Why do the island archipelagos comprise a smaller number of electors?	dispersed population and distance	6
12 What is the current number of electors currently in a Scottish Parliament constituency?	55 000	4
1 The total number of seats in the Parliament are allocated to parties proportionally to the number of votes received in the second vote of the ballot using the dHondt method.
2 For example to determine who is awarded the first list seat the number of list votes cast for each party is divided by one plus the number of seats the party won in the region at this point just constituency seats.
3 The party with the highest quotient is awarded the seat which is then added to its constituency seats in allocating the second seat.
4 This is repeated iteratively until all available list seats are allocated.
5 How are the total numbers of seats allocated to parties?	proportionally to the number of votes received	1
6 What method is used for tallying votes in the second vote of the ballot?	the dHondt method	1
7 The party awarded a seat is the one with the highest what?	quotient	3
8 What set is a seat added to after being allocated?	constituency seats	3
9 How is the process of allocating seats repeated until all available seats have been determined?	iteratively	4
1 As in the House of Commons a number of qualifications apply to being an MSP.
2 Such qualifications were introduced under the House of Commons Disqualification Act 1975 and the British Nationality Act 1981.
3 Specifically members must be over the age of 18 and must be a citizen of the United Kingdom the Republic of Ireland one of the countries in the Commonwealth of Nations a citizen of a British overseas territory or a European Union citizen resident in the UK.
4 Members of the police and the armed forces are disqualified from sitting in the Scottish Parliament as elected MSPs and similarly civil servants and members of foreign legislatures are disqualified.
5 An individual may not sit in the Scottish Parliament if he or she is judged to be insane under the terms of the Mental Health Care and Treatment Scotland Act 2003.
6 What does being an MSP share with the House of Commons?	a number of qualifications	1
7 When was the British Nationality Act passed?	1981	2
8 How old most a person be to apply to be an MSP?	over the age of 18	3
9 Members of which organizations are disqualified from sitting in the SP as elected MSPs?	police and the armed forces	4
10 What act sets the term for judging the boundaries of sanity to which individuals wishing to sit on the SP must adhere?	Mental Health Care and Treatment Scotland Act 2003	5
1 The election produced a majority SNP government making this the first time in the Scottish Parliament where a party has commanded a parliamentary majority.
2 The SNP took 16 seats from Labour with many of their key figures not returned to parliament although Labour leader Iain Gray retained East Lothian by 151 votes.
3 The SNP took a further eight seats from the Liberal Democrats and one seat from the Conservatives.
4 The SNP overall majority meant that there was sufficient support in the Scottish Parliament to hold a referendum on Scottish independence.

1 For the Conservatives the main disappointment was the loss of Edinburgh Pentlands the seat of former party leader David McLetchie to the SNP.
2 McLetchie was elected on the Lothian regional list and the Conservatives suffered a net loss of five seats with leader Annabel Goldie claiming that their support had held firm.
3 Nevertheless she too announced she would step down as leader of the party.
4 Cameron congratulated the SNP on their victory but vowed to campaign for the Union in the independence referendum.

1 A procedural consequence of the establishment of the Scottish Parliament is that Scottish MPs sitting in the UK House of Commons are able to vote on domestic legislation that applies only to England Wales and Northern Ireland – whilst English Scottish Welsh and Northern Irish Westminster MPs are unable to vote on the domestic legislation of the Scottish Parliament.
2 This phenomenon is known as the West Lothian question and has led to criticism.
3 Following the Conservative victory in the 2015 UK election standing orders of the House of Commons were changed to give MPs representing English constituencies a new veto over laws only affecting England.
4 What consequence of establishing the Scottish Parliament applies to Scottish MPs sitting in the UK House of Commons?	able to vote on domestic legislation that applies only to England  Wales and Northern Ireland	1
5 What are MPs unable to vote upon?	domestic legislation of the Scottish Parliament	1
6 What phenomenon has led to criticism?	West Lothian question	2
7 What party had a victory in the 2015 UK election?	the Conservative	3
8 MPs representing English constituencies can only veto laws affecting which country?	England	3
1 Islamism also known as Political Islam Arabic إسلام سياسي‎ islām siyāsī is an Islamic revival movement often characterized by moral conservatism literalism and the attempt to implement Islamic values in all spheres of life.
2 Islamism favors the reordering of government and society in accordance with the Sharia.
3 The different Islamist movements have been described as oscillating between two poles at one end is a strategy of Islamization of society through state power seized by revolution or invasion at the other reformist pole Islamists work to Islamize society gradually from the bottom up.
4 The movements have arguably altered the Middle East more than any trend since the modern states gained independence redefining politics and even borders according to one journalist Robin Wright.
5 What is an Islamic revival movement?	Islamism	1
6 What aspects of life does Islamism seek to integrate itself into?	all spheres of life	1
7 What goal does Islamism have when it comes to society and government?	reordering	2
8 What have the two different Islamist movements been described as oscillating between?	poles	3
9 One strategy of Islamization is to seize power by what methods?	revolution or invasion	3
1 Moderate and reformist Islamists who accept and work within the democratic process include parties like the Tunisian Ennahda Movement.
2 JamaateIslami of Pakistan is basically a sociopolitical and democratic Vanguard party but has also gained political influence through military coup détat in past.
3 The Islamist groups like Hezbollah in Lebanon and Hamas in Palestine participate in democratic and political process as well as armed attacks seeking to abolish the state of Israel.
4 Radical Islamist organizations like alQaeda and the Egyptian Islamic Jihad and groups such as the Taliban entirely reject democracy often declaring as kuffar those Muslims who support it see takfirism as well as calling for violentoffensive jihad or urging and conducting attacks on a religious basis.
5 What process do moderate and reformist Islamists work within the boundaries of?	democratic	1
6 Where does Hamas originate?	Palestine	3
7 What is the goal of Islamist groups like Hezbollah and Hamas?	abolish the state of Israel	3
8 What do radical Islamist organizations reject entirely?	democracy	4
9 On what basis do the radical Islamist organizations conduct their attacks?	religious	4
1 Another major division within Islamism is between what Graham E Fuller has described as the fundamentalist guardians of the tradition Salafis such as those in the Wahhabi movement and the vanguard of change and Islamic reform centered around the Muslim Brotherhood.
2 Olivier Roy argues that Sunni panIslamism underwent a remarkable shift in the second half of the 20th century when the Muslim Brotherhood movement and its focus on Islamisation of panArabism was eclipsed by the Salafi movement with its emphasis on sharia rather than the building of Islamic institutions and rejection of Shia Islam.
3 Following the Arab Spring Roy has described Islamism as increasingly interdependent with democracy in much of the Arab Muslim world such that neither can now survive without the other.
4 While Islamist political culture itself may not be democratic Islamists need democratic elections to maintain their legitimacy.
5 At the same time their popularity is such that no government can call itself democratic that excludes mainstream Islamist groups.
6 What exists between fundamentalist Islamism and reformist Islamism?	major division	1
7 What did Olivier Roy state underwent a remarkable shift in the second half of the 20th century?	Sunni panIslamism	2
8 What did the Salafi movement put emphasis on?	sharia rather than the building of Islamic institutions 	2
9 What has Islamism been increasingly interdependent with following the Arab Spring?	democracy	3
10 Why do Islamists need democratic elections?	to maintain their legitimacy	4
1 Islamism is a controversial concept not just because it posits a political role for Islam but also because its supporters believe their views merely reflect Islam while the contrary idea that Islam is or can be apolitical is an error.
2 Scholars and observers who do not believe that Islam is merely a political ideology include Fred Halliday John Esposito and Muslim intellectuals like Javed Ahmad Ghamidi.
3 Hayri Abaza argues the failure to distinguish between Islam and Islamism leads many in the West to support illiberal Islamic regimes to the detriment of progressive moderates who seek to separate religion from politics.
4 What type of role that Islamism seeks makes it a somewhat controversial concept?	political	1
5 What do supporters of Islamism believe their views reflect?	Islam	1
6 The idea that Islam can be apolitical isnt able to be embraced by whom?	its supporters	1
7 What does the inability to separate Islam from Islamism lead many in the West to support?	illiberal Islamic regimes	3
8 What do progressive moderates of Islam seek to separate?	religion from politics	3
1 Islamists have asked the question If Islam is a way of life how can we say that those who want to live by its principles in legal social political economic and political spheres of life are not Muslims but Islamists and believe in Islamism not just Islam.
2 Similarly a writer for the International Crisis Group maintains that the conception of political Islam is a creation of Americans to explain the Iranian Islamic Revolution and apolitical Islam was a historical fluke of the shortlived era of the heyday of secular Arab nationalism between 1945 and 1970 and it is quietistnonpolitical Islam not Islamism that requires explanation.
3 What term do Islamists think should be applied to them?	Muslims	1
4 What does a writer for the International Crisis Group think the concept of political Islam is a creation of?	Americans	2
5 What was apolitical Islam?	a historical fluke	2
6 When was the heyday of secular Arab nationalism?	between 1945 and 1970	2
7 What rather than Islamism requires explanation?	nonpolitical Islam	2
1 During the 1970s and sometimes later Western and proWestern governments often supported sometimes fledgling Islamists and Islamist groups that later came to be seen as dangerous enemies.
2 Islamists were considered by Western governments bulwarks against—what were thought to be at the time—more dangerous leftistcommunistnationalist insurgentsopposition which Islamists were correctly seen as opposing.
3 The US spent billions of dollars to aid the mujahideen Muslim Afghanistan enemies of the Soviet Union and nonAfghan veterans of the war returned home with their prestige experience ideology and weapons and had considerable impact.

1 Egyptian President Anwar Sadat – whose policies included opening Egypt to Western investment infitah transferring Egypts allegiance from the Soviet Union to the United States and making peace with Israel – released Islamists from prison and welcomed home exiles in tacit exchange for political support in his struggle against leftists.
2 His encouraging of the emergence of the Islamist movement was said to have been imitated by many other Muslim leaders in the years that followed.
3 This gentlemens agreement between Sadat and Islamists broke down in 1975 but not before Islamists came to completely dominate university student unions.
4 Sadat was later assassinated and a formidable insurgency was formed in Egypt in the 1990s.
5 The French government has also been reported to have promoted Islamist preachers in the hope of channeling Muslim energies into zones of piety and charity.
6 Who is the President of Egypt?	Anwar Sadat	1

9 When did the so called gentlemens agreement between Sadat and the Islamists break down?	1975	3
10 How was Sadat rewarded by the Islamists for his attempts to bring Egypt into modern times and civilization?	assassinated	4
1 The interpretation of Islam promoted by this funding was the strict conservative Saudibased Wahhabism or Salafism.
2 In its harshest form it preached that Muslims should not only always oppose infidels in every way but hate them for their religion  for Allahs sake that democracy is responsible for all the horrible wars of the 20th century that Shia and other nonWahhabi Muslims were infidels etc.
3 While this effort has by no means converted all or even most Muslims to the Wahhabist interpretation of Islam it has done much to overwhelm more moderate local interpretations and has set the Saudiinterpretation of Islam as the gold standard of religion in minds of some or many Muslims.
4 What type of interpretation of Islam does Salafism promote?	conservative	1

1 Islamist movements such as the Muslim Brotherhood are well known for providing shelters educational assistance free or low cost medical clinics housing assistance to students from out of town student advisory groups facilitation of inexpensive mass marriage ceremonies to avoid prohibitively costly dowry demands legal assistance sports facilities and womens groups.
2 All this compares very favourably against incompetent inefficient or neglectful governments whose commitment to social justice is limited to rhetoric.

1 While studying law and philosophy in England and Germany Iqbal became a member of the London branch of the All India Muslim League.
2 He came back to Lahore in 1908.
3 While dividing his time between law practice and philosophical poetry Iqbal had remained active in the Muslim League.
4 He did not support Indian involvement in World War I and remained in close touch with Muslim political leaders such as Muhammad Ali Johar and Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
5 He was a critic of the mainstream Indian nationalist and secularist Indian National Congress.
6 Iqbals seven English lectures were published by Oxford University press in 1934 in a book titled The Reconstruction of Religious Thought in Islam.
7 These lectures dwell on the role of Islam as a religion as well as a political and legal philosophy in the modern age.
8 What was Iqbal studying in England and Germany?	law and philosophy	1
9 What organization did Iqbal join in London?	the All India Muslim League	1
10 Who was Iqbal a critic of?	the mainstream Indian nationalist and secularist Indian National Congress	5
11 What year did Iqbal return to Lahore?	1908	2
12 What book was Iqbals seven English lectures published as?	The Reconstruction of Religious Thought in Islam	6
1 Iqbal expressed fears that not only would secularism and secular nationalism weaken the spiritual foundations of Islam and Muslim society but that Indias Hindumajority population would crowd out Muslim heritage culture and political influence.
2 In his travels to Egypt Afghanistan Palestine and Syria he promoted ideas of greater Islamic political cooperation and unity calling for the shedding of nationalist differences.
3 Sir Muhammad Iqbal was elected president of the Muslim League in 1930 at its session in Allahabad as well as for the session in Lahore in 1932.
4 In his Allahabad Address on 29 December 1930 Iqbal outlined a vision of an independent state for Muslimmajority provinces in northwestern India.
5 This address later inspired the Pakistan movement.
6 What did Iqbal fear would weaken the spiritual foundations of Islam and Muslim society?	secularism and secular nationalism	1
7 Iqbal worried that Indias mostly Hindu population would do what to Muslim heritage and culture?	crowd out	1
8 When Iqbal promoted ideas of greater Islamic political unity what did he encourage ending?	nationalist differences	2
9 When was Iqbal elected president of the Muslim League?	1930	3
10 What did Iqbals Allahabad address inspire?	Pakistan movement	5
1 Sayyid Abul Ala Maududi was an important early twentiethcentury figure in the Islamic revival in India and then after independence from Britain in Pakistan.
2 Trained as a lawyer he chose the profession of journalism and wrote about contemporary issues and most importantly about Islam and Islamic law.
3 Maududi founded the JamaateIslami party in 1941 and remained its leader until 1972.
4 However Maududi had much more impact through his writing than through his political organising.
5 His extremely influential books translated into many languages placed Islam in a modern context and influenced not only conservative ulema but liberal modernizer Islamists such as alFaruqi whose Islamization of Knowledge carried forward some of Maududis key principles.
6 Who was an important figure in the twentiethcentury Islamic revival in India?	Sayyid Abul Ala Maududi	1
7 Maududi was trained as a lawyer but chose what professional for himself instead?	journalism	2
8 When did Maududi found the JamaateIslami party?	1941	3
9 Where did Maududi exert the most impact?	through his writing	4
10 Where did Maududis books place Islam?	in a modern context	5

12 Though trained as a lawyer what profession did Maududi pursue instead?	journalism	2
13 Where did Maududi exert the most impact?	through his writing	4
14 Where did Maududis books place Islam?	a modern context	5
1 Maududi also believed that Muslim society could not be Islamic without Sharia and Islam required the establishment of an Islamic state.
2 This state should be a theodemocracy based on the principles of tawhid unity of God risala prophethood and khilafa caliphate.
3 Although Maududi talked about Islamic revolution by revolution he meant not the violence or populist policies of the Iranian Revolution but the gradual changing the hearts and minds of individuals from the top of society downward through an educational process or dawah.

1 Roughly contemporaneous with Maududi was the founding of the Muslim Brotherhood in Ismailiyah Egypt in 1928 by Hassan al Banna.
2 His was arguably the first largest and most influential modern Islamic politicalreligious organization.
3 Under the motto the Quran is our constitution it sought Islamic revival through preaching and also by providing basic community services including schools mosques and workshops.
4 Like Maududi Al Banna believed in the necessity of government rule based on Shariah law implemented gradually and by persuasion and of eliminating all imperialist influence in the Muslim world.

1 The quick and decisive defeat of the Arab troops during the SixDay War by Israeli troops constituted a pivotal event in the Arab Muslim world.
2 The defeat along with economic stagnation in the defeated countries was blamed on the secular Arab nationalism of the ruling regimes.
3 A steep and steady decline in the popularity and credibility of secular socialist and nationalist politics ensued.
4 Baathism Arab socialism and Arab nationalism suffered and different democratic and antidemocratic Islamist movements inspired by Maududi and Sayyid Qutb gained ground.

1 For some decades prior to the First Palestine Intifada in 1987 the Muslim Brotherhood in Palestine took a quiescent stance towards Israel focusing on preaching education and social services and benefiting from Israels indulgence to build up a network of mosques and charitable organizations.
2 As the First Intifada gathered momentum and Palestinian shopkeepers closed their shops in support of the uprising the Brotherhood announced the formation of HAMAS zeal devoted to Jihad against Israel.
3 Rather than being more moderate than the PLO the 1988 Hamas charter took a more uncompromising stand calling for the destruction of Israel and the establishment of an Islamic state in Palestine.
4 It was soon competing with and then overtaking the PLO for control of the intifada.
5 The Brotherhoods base of devout middle class found common cause with the impoverished youth of the intifada in their cultural conservatism and antipathy for activities of the secular middle class such as drinking alcohol and going about without hijab.

1 An Islamist movement influenced by Salafism and the jihad in Afghanistan as well as the Muslim Brotherhood was the FIS or Front Islamique de Salut the Islamic Salvation Front in Algeria.
2 Founded as a broad Islamist coalition in 1989 it was led by Abbassi Madani and a charismatic Islamist young preacher Ali Belhadj.
3 Taking advantage of economic failure and unpopular social liberalization and secularization by the ruling leftistnationalist FLN government it used its preaching to advocate the establishment of a legal system following Sharia law economic liberalization and development program education in Arabic rather than French and gender segregation with women staying home to alleviate the high rate of unemployment among young Algerian men.

3 In 1996 a more conservative and antidemocratic Islamist movement known as the Taliban rose to power defeated most of the warlords and took over roughly 80 of Afghanistan.

1 The Taliban were spawned by the thousands of madrasahs the Deobandi movement established for impoverished Afghan refugees and supported by governmental and religious groups in neighboring Pakistan.
2 The Taliban differed from other Islamist movements to the point where they might be more properly described as Islamic fundamentalist or neofundamentalist interested in spreading an idealized and systematized version of conservative tribal village customs under the label of Sharia to an entire country.
3 Their ideology was also described as being influenced by Wahhabism and the extremist jihadism of their guest Osama bin Laden.

1 In July 1977 General ZiaulHaq overthrew Prime Minister Zulfiqar Ali Bhuttos regime in Pakistan.
2 Ali Bhutto a leftist in democratic competition with Islamists had announced banning alcohol and nightclubs within six months shortly before he was overthrown.
3 ZiaulHaq was much more committed to Islamism and Islamization or implementation of Islamic law became a cornerstone of his elevenyear military dictatorship and Islamism became his official state ideology.
4 Zia ul Haq was an admirer of Mawdudi and Mawdudis party JamaateIslami became the regimes ideological and political arm.
5 In Pakistan this Islamization from above was probably more complete than under any other regime except those in Iran and Sudan but ZiaulHaq was also criticized by many Islamists for imposing symbols rather than substance and using Islamization to legitimize his means of seizing power.
6 Unlike neighboring Iran ZiaulHaqs policies were intended to avoid revolutionary excess and not to strain relations with his American and Persian Gulf state allies.
7 ZiaulHaq was killed in 1988 but Islamization remains an important element in Pakistani society.

1 The Islamic State formerly known as the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and before that as the Islamic State of Iraq and called the acronym Daesh by its many detractors is a WahhabiSalafi jihadist extremist militant group which is led by and mainly composed of Sunni Arabs from Iraq and Syria.
2 In 2014 the group proclaimed itself a caliphate with religious political and military authority over all Muslims worldwide.
3 As of March 2015update it had control over territory occupied by ten million people in Iraq and Syria and has nominal control over small areas of Libya Nigeria and Afghanistan.
4 While a selfdescribed state it lacks international recognition.
5 The group also operates or has affiliates in other parts of the world including North Africa and South Asia.

1 Originating as the Jamaat alTawhid walJihad in 1999 it pledged allegiance to alQaeda in 2004 participated in the Iraqi insurgency that followed the March 2003 invasion of Iraq by Western forces joined the fight in the Syrian Civil War beginning in March 2011 and was expelled from alQaeda in early 2014 which complained of its failure to consult and notorious intransigence.
2 The group gained prominence after it drove Iraqi government forces out of key cities in western Iraq in a 2014 offensive.
3 The group is adept at social media posting Internet videos of beheadings of soldiers civilians journalists and aid workers and is known for its destruction of cultural heritage sites.
4 The United Nations has held ISIL responsible for human rights abuses and war crimes and Amnesty International has reported ethnic cleansing by the group on a historic scale.

1 In its focus on the Caliphate the party takes a different view of Muslim history than some other Islamists such as Muhammad Qutb.

1 The US government has engaged in efforts to counter Islamism or violent Islamism since 2001.
2 These efforts were centred in the US around public diplomacy programmes conducted by the State Department.
3 There have been calls to create an independent agency in the US with a specific mission of undermining Islamism and jihadism.

1 Imperialism is a type of advocacy of empire.
2 Its name originated from the Latin word imperium which means to rule over large territories.
3 Imperialism is a policy of extending a countrys power and influence through colonization use of military force or other means.
4 Imperialism has greatly shaped the contemporary world.
5 It has also allowed for the rapid spread of technologies and ideas.
6 The term imperialism has been applied to Western and Japanese political and economic dominance especially in Asia and Africa in the 19th and 20th centuries.
7 Its precise meaning continues to be debated by scholars.
8 Some writers such as Edward Said use the term more broadly to describe any system of domination and subordination organised with an imperial center and a periphery.
9 The word imperialism has its origins in which ancient language?	Latin	2
10 By what means is imperialism usually administered?	military force	3
11 The term imperialism has been applied to western countries and which eastern county?	Japan	6
12 Imperialism is responsible for the rapid spread of what?	technologies and ideas	5
1 Imperialism is defined as A policy of extending a country’s power and influence through diplomacy or military force.
2 Imperialism is particularly focused on the control that one group often a state power has on another group of people.
3 This is often through various forms of othering see other based on racial religious or cultural stereotypes.
4 There are formal or informal imperialisms.
5 Formal imperialism is defined as physical control or fullfledged colonial rule.
6 Informal imperialism is less direct however it is still a powerful form of dominance.
7 Imperialism extends a countrys power and what?	influence	1
8 colonial rule would be considered what type of imperialism?	Formal imperialism	5
9 imperialism often divides countries by using which technique?	othering	3
10 Informal imperialism is still dominant however less what?	direct	6
1 The definition of imperialism has not been finalized for centuries and was confusedly seen to represent the policies of major powers or simply generalpurpose aggressiveness.
2 Further on some writerswho.
3 used the term imperialism in slightly more discriminating fashion to mean all kinds of domination or control by a group of people over another.
4 To clear out this confusion about the definition of imperialism one could speak of formal and informal imperialism the first meaning physical control or fullfledged colonial rule while the second implied less direct rule though still containing perceivable kinds of dominance.
5 Informal rule is generally less costly than taking over territories formally.
6 This is because with informal rule the control is spread more subtly through technological superiority enforcing land officials into large debts that cannot be repaid ownership of private industries thus expanding the controlled area or having countries agree to uneven trade agreements forcefully.
7 A forced trade agreement between two countries would be an example of what?	informal imperialism	4
8 colonial rule or physical occupation of a territory is an example of what kind of imperialism?	formal	4
9 Some have generalized the meaning of the word imperialism down to generalpurpose what?	aggressiveness	1
10 What subtle tool can be used in an informal imperialistic situation to expand a controlled area?	ownership of private industries	6
11 Which is more costly formal or informal imperialism?	informal	6
1 The word ‘empire’ comes from the Latin word imperium for which the closest modern English equivalent would perhaps be ‘sovereignty’ or simply ‘rule’.
2 The greatest distinction of an empire is through the amount of land that a nation has conquered and expanded.
3 Political power grew from conquering land however cultural and economic aspects flourished through sea and trade routes.
4 A distinction about empires is that although political empires were built mostly by expansion overland economic and cultural influences spread at least as much by sea.
5 Some of the main aspects of trade that went overseas consisted of animals and plant products.
6 European empires in Asia and Africa have come to be seen as the classic forms of imperialism and indeed most books on the subject confine themselves to the European seaborne empires.
7 European expansion caused the world to be divided by how developed and developing nation are portrayed through the world systems theory.
8 The two main regions are the core and the periphery.
9 The core consists of high areas of income and profit the periphery is on the opposing side of the spectrum consisting of areas of low income and profit.
10 These critical theories of Geopolitics have led to increased discussion of the meaning and impact of imperialism on the modern postcolonial world.
11 The Russian leader Lenin suggested that imperialism was the highest form of capitalism claiming that imperialism developed after colonialism and was distinguished from colonialism by monopoly capitalism.
12 This idea from Lenin stresses how important new political world order has become in our modern era.
13 Geopolitics now focuses on states becoming major economic players in the market some states today are viewed as empires due to their political and economic authority over other nations.
14 The amount of land a country controls is its greatest what?	distinction	2
15 Western Imperialism divided the globe according to which theory?	the world systems theory	7
16 Who suggested that imperialism was the highest form of capitalism?	Lenin	11

18 Most imperialism was carried out using which method of transport?	seaborne	6
1 The term imperialism is often conflated with colonialism however many scholars have argued that each have their own distinct definition.
2 Imperialism and colonialism have been used in order to describe ones superiority domination and influence upon a person or group of people.
3 Robert Young writes that while imperialism operates from the center is a state policy and is developed for ideological as well as financial reasons colonialism is simply the development for settlement or commercial intentions.
4 Colonialism in modern usage also tends to imply a degree of geographic separation between the colony and the imperial power.
5 Particularly Edward Said distinguishes the difference between imperialism and colonialism by stating imperialism involved the practice the theory and the attitudes of a dominating metropolitan center ruling a distant territory while colonialism refers to the implanting of settlements on a distant territory.
6 Contiguous land empires such as the Russian or Ottoman are generally excluded from discussions of colonialism.
7 116 Thus it can be said that imperialism includes some form of colonialism but colonialism itself does not automatically imply imperialism as it lacks a political focus.
8 further explanation needed.
9 Imperialism is confused with what other term?	colonialism	1
10 What does colonialism lack that imperialism has?	political focus	7
11 Colonialism as a policy is caused by financial and what other reasons?	ideological	3
12 Who besides the Russians are often left out of the colonialism debat?	Ottoman	6
13 Imperialism and colonialism both assert a states dominance over what?	person or group of people	2
1 Imperialism and colonialism both dictate the political and economic advantage over a land and the indigenous populations they control yet scholars sometimes find it difficult to illustrate the difference between the two.
2 Although imperialism and colonialism focus on the suppression of an other if colonialism refers to the process of a country taking physical control of another imperialism refers to the political and monetary dominance either formally or informally.
3 Colonialism is seen to be the architect deciding how to start dominating areas and then imperialism can be seen as creating the idea behind conquest cooperating with colonialism.
4 Colonialism is when the imperial nation begins a conquest over an area and then eventually is able to rule over the areas the previous nation had controlled.
5 Colonialisms core meaning is the exploitation of the valuable assets and supplies of the nation that was conquered and the conquering nation then gaining the benefits from the spoils of the war.
6 The meaning of imperialism is to create an empire by conquering the other states lands and therefore increasing its own dominance.
7 Colonialism is the builder and preserver of the colonial possessions in an area by a population coming from a foreign region.
8 Colonialism can completely change the existing social structure physical structure and economics of an area it is not unusual that the characteristics of the conquering peoples are inherited by the conquered indigenous populations.
9 Political advantage is an attribute of which state policies?	Imperialism and colonialism	1
10 Colonialism often means a country doing what?	taking physical control of another	2
11 How would one create an empire by means of Imperialism?	conquering the other states lands	6
12 What is colonialisms core meaning?	exploitation	5
13 what do conquering people pass down to native populations?	characteristics	8
1 A controversial aspect of imperialism is the defense and justification of empirebuilding based on seemingly rational grounds.
2 J.
3 A Hobson identifies this justification on general grounds as It is desirable that the earth should be peopled governed and developed as far as possible by the races which can do this work best ie.
4 by the races of highest social efficiency.
5 Many others argued that imperialism is justified for several different reasons.
6 Friedrich Ratzel believed that in order for a state to survive imperialism was needed.
7 Halford Mackinder felt that Great Britain needed to be one of the greatest imperialists and therefore justified imperialism.
8 The purportedly scientific nature of Social Darwinism and a theory of races formed a supposedly rational justification for imperialism.
9 The rhetoric of colonizers being racially superior appears to have achieved its purpose for example throughout Latin America whiteness is still prized today and various forms of blanqueamiento whitening are common.
10 what is the most controversial aspect of imperialism?	empirebuilding	1
11 Friedrich Ratzel thought what was needed for a state to survive?	imperialism	6
12  J A Hobson wanted which races to develop the world?	highest social efficiency	4
13 Which theory justifies imperialism in part?	theory of races	8
14 In Latin America what is the most revered skin color?	whiteness	9

2 These societies also served as a space for travellers to share these storiesPolitical geographers such as Friedrich Ratzel of Germany and Halford Mackinder of Britain also supported imperialism.
3 Ratzel believed expansion was necessary for a state’s survival while Mackinder supported Britain’s imperial expansion these two arguments dominated the discipline for decades.

1 Geographical theories such as environmental determinism also suggested that tropical environments created uncivilized people in need of European guidance.
2 For instance American geographer Ellen Churchill Semple argued that even though human beings originated in the tropics they were only able to become fully human in the temperate zone.
3 Tropicality can be paralleled with Edward Said’s Orientalism as the west’s construction of the east as the “other”.
4 According to Siad orientalism allowed Europe to establish itself as the superior and the norm which justified its dominance over the essentialized Orient.

1 The principles of imperialism are often generalizable to the policies and practices of the British Empire during the last generation and proceeds rather by diagnosis than by historical description.
2 British imperialism often used the concept of Terra nullius Latin expression which stems from Roman law meaning empty land.
3 The country of Australia serves as a case study in relation to British settlement and colonial rule of the continent in the eighteenth century as it was premised on terra nullius and its settlers considered it unused by its sparse Aboriginal inhabitants.
4 What law justified British imperialism?	Terra nullius	2
5 When did Great Britain colonize Australia?	the eighteenth century	3

8 Terra Nullius is a Latin expression meaning what in English?	empty land	2
1 Orientalism as theorized by Edward Said refers to how the West developed an imaginative geography of the East.
2 This imaginative geography relies on an essentializing discourse that represents neither the diversity nor the social reality of the East.
3 Rather by essentializing the East this discourse uses the idea of placebased identities to create difference and distance between we the West and them the East or here in the West and there in the East.
4 This difference was particularly apparent in textual and visual works of early European studies of the Orient that positioned the East as irrational and backward in opposition to the rational and progressive West.
5 Defining the East as a negative vision of itself as its inferior not only increased the West’s sense of self but also was a way of ordering the East and making it known to the West so that it could be dominated and controlled.
6 The discourse of Orientalism therefore served as an ideological justification of early Western imperialism as it formed a body of knowledge and ideas that rationalized social cultural political and economic control of other territories.
7 Orientalism refers to how the West developed a what of the East?	an imaginative geography	1
8 Early Western texts referencing the East describe the people as being what?	irrational and backward	4
9 The West saw the East as what?	inferior	5
10 What was used by the West to justify control over eastern territories?	Orientalism	6
11 The West saw themselves as what compared to the east?	progressive	4
1 To better illustrate this idea Bassett focuses his analysis of the role of nineteenthcentury maps during the scramble for Africa.
2 He states that maps contributed to empire by promoting assisting and legitimizing the extension of French and British power into West Africa.
3 During his analysis of nineteenthcentury cartographic techniques he highlights the use of blank space to denote unknown or unexplored territory.
4 This provided incentives for imperial and colonial powers to obtain information to fill in blank spaces on contemporary maps.

9 Who besides the british colonized Africa?	French	2
1 Imperialism has played an important role in the histories of Japan Korea the Assyrian Empire the Chinese Empire the Roman Empire Greece the Byzantine Empire the Persian Empire the Ottoman Empire Ancient Egypt the British Empire India and many other empires.

1 Cultural imperialism is when a countrys influence is felt in social and cultural circles ie.
2 its soft power such that it changes the moral cultural and societal worldview of another.
3 This is more than just foreign music television or film becoming popular with young people but that popular culture changing their own expectations of life and their desire for their own country to become more like the foreign country depicted.
4 For example depictions of opulent American lifestyles in the soap opera Dallas during the Cold War changed the expectations of Romanians a more recent example is the influence of smuggled South Korean drama series in North Korea.
5 The importance of soft power is not lost on authoritarian regimes fighting such influence with bans on foreign popular culture control of the internet and unauthorised satellite dishes etc.
6 Nor is such a usage of culture recent as part of Roman imperialism local elites would be exposed to the benefits and luxuries of Roman culture and lifestyle with the aim that they would then become willing participants.
7 When imperialism impacts social norms of a state what is it called?	Cultural imperialism	1
8 What is Cultural Imperialism often referred to as?	soft power	5
9 Which American show changed the views of Romanians during the cold war?	Dallas	4
10 Which historic empire used cultural imperialism to sway local elites?	Roman	6
11 How do regimes fight against cultural imperialism?	bans	5
1 The Age of Imperialism a time period beginning around 1700 saw generally European industrializing nations engaging in the process of colonizing influencing and annexing other parts of the world in order to gain political power.
2 citation needed Although imperialist practices have existed for thousands of years the term Age of Imperialism generally refers to the activities of European powers from the early 18th century through to the middle of the 20th century for example the The Great Game in Persian lands the Scramble for Africa and the Open Door Policy in China.
3 When did the age of Imperialism begin?	around 1700	1

5 How many years have imperialistic practices existed?	thousands	2
6 When did the age of imperialism end?	middle of the 20th century	2

1 During the 20th century historians John Gallagher 1919–1980 and Ronald Robinson 1920–1999 constructed a framework for understanding European imperialism.
2 They claim that European imperialism was influential and Europeans rejected the notion that imperialism required formal legal control by one government over another country.
3 In their view historians have been mesmerized by formal empire and maps of the world with regions colored red.
4 The bulk of British emigration trade and capital went to areas outside the formal British Empire.
5 Key to their thinking is the idea of empire informally if possible and formally if necessary.
6 attribution needed Because of the resources made available by imperialism the worlds economy grew significantly and became much more interconnected in the decades before World War I making the many imperial powers rich and prosperous.
7 When was John Gallagher born?	1919	1
8 When did Ronald Robinson die?	1999	1
9 What profession were Ronald Robinson and John Gallagher?	historians	1
10 What grew on a global scale as a result of imperialism?	the worlds economy	6
11 Who was made rich and prosperous prior to World War 1	many imperial powers 	6.
1 Europes expansion into territorial imperialism was largely focused on economic growth by collecting resources from colonies in combination with assuming political control by military and political means.
2 The colonization of India in the mid18th century offers an example of this focus there the British exploited the political weakness of the Mughal state and while military activity was important at various times the economic and administrative incorporation of local elites was also of crucial significance for the establishment of control over the subcontinents resources markets and manpower.
3 Although a substantial number of colonies had been designed to provide economic profit and to ship resources to home ports in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries Fieldhouse suggests that in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries in places such as Africa and Asia this idea is not necessarily valid.

7 Who did Britain exploit in India?	the Mughal state	2
1 Along with advancements in communication Europe also continued to advance in military technology.
2 European chemists made deadly explosives that could be used in combat and with innovations in machinery they were able to manufacture improved firearms.
3 By the 1880s the machine gun had become an effective battlefield weapon.
4 This technology gave European armies an advantage over their opponents as armies in lessdeveloped countries were still fighting with arrows swords and leather shields eg.
5 the Zulus in Southern Africa during the AngloZulu War of 1879.
