1 In anglophone academic works theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience.
2 The term Imperialism was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli.
3 It was shortly appropriated by supporters of imperialism such as Joseph Chamberlain.
4 For some imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy others alleged that it was characterized by political selfinterest and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed.
5 Liberal John A Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term.
6 Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism the Highest Stage of Capitalism.
7 In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion.
8 This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians.
9 Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of imperialism.
10 Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century but a world system extending over a period of centuries often going back to Christopher Columbus and in some accounts to the Crusades.
11 As the application of the term has expanded its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes the moral the economic the systemic the cultural and the temporal.
12 Those changes reflect  among other shifts in sensibility  a growing unease even squeamishness with the fact of power specifically Western power.
13 Theories on imperialism use which country as a model?	British	1
14 When did the term imperialism first come to be used by its current definition?	in the late 1870s	2
15 What was the idealized value of imperialism?	philanthropy	4
16 According to Lenin why must capitalistic countries have an imperialistic policy?	to constantly expand investment	7
1 The correlation between capitalism aristocracy and imperialism has long been debated among historians and political theorists.
2 Much of the debate was pioneered by such theorists as J.
3 A Hobson 1858–1940 Joseph Schumpeter 1883–1950 Thorstein Veblen 1857–1929 and Norman Angell 1872–1967.
4 While these nonMarxist writers were at their most prolific before World War I they remained active in the interwar years.
5 Their combined work informed the study of imperialism and its impact on Europe as well as contributed to reflections on the rise of the militarypolitical complex in the United States from the 1950s.
6 Hobson argued that domestic social reforms could cure the international disease of imperialism by removing its economic foundation.
7 Hobson theorized that state intervention through taxation could boost broader consumption create wealth and encourage a peaceful tolerant multipolar world order.
8 some debate that there is a correlation between capitalism imperialism and what?	aristocracy	1
9 When was the militarypolitical complex reflected upon within the scope of understanding imperialism?	the 1950s	5
10 When were Joseph Schumpeter and Norman Angell at their most prolific writing period?	before World War I	4
11 Hobson argued that imperialism was an international what?	disease	6
12 How did Hobson argue to rid the world of imperialism?	taxation	7
1 The concept environmental determinism served as a moral justification for domination of certain territories and peoples.
2 It was believed that a certain persons behaviours were determined by the environment in which they lived and thus validated their domination.
3 For example people living in tropical environments were seen as less civilized therefore justifying colonial control as a civilizing mission.
4 Across the three waves of European colonialism first in the Americas second in Asia and lastly in Africa environmental determinism was used to categorically place indigenous people in a racial hierarchy.
5 This takes two forms orientalism and tropicality.
6 What served as a justification for imposing imperialistic policies on certain peoples or regions?	environmental determinism	1
7 What was thought to decide a persons behavior?	the environment in which they lived	2
8 Humans in tropical environments were considered what?	less civilized	3
9 Europe first colonized the Americas then Asia but what continent was third?	Africa	4
10 What were the two forms of environmental determinism?	orientalism and tropicality	5
1 According to geographic scholars under colonizing empires the world could be split into climatic zones.
2 These scholars believed that Northern Europe and the MidAtlantic temperate climate produced a hardworking moral and upstanding human being.
3 Alternatively tropical climates yielded lazy attitudes sexual promiscuity exotic culture and moral degeneracy.
4 The people of these climates were believed to be in need of guidance and intervention from the European empire to aid in the governing of a more evolved social structure they were seen as incapable of such a feat.
5 Similarly orientalism is a view of a people based on their geographical location.
6 Who thought the world could be split into climatic zones?	geographic scholars	1
7 Which regions have temperate climates?	Northern Europe and the MidAtlantic	2
8 What did the the Europeans think the peoples in the tropics were in need of?	guidance	4
9 What was a similar view about the Asian continent called?	orientalism	5
10 Who did the geographic scholars work for?	colonizing empires	1

1 It became a moral justification to lift the world up to French standards by bringing Christianity and French culture.
2 In 1884 the leading exponent of colonialism Jules Ferry declared France had a civilising mission The higher races have a right over the lower races they have a duty to civilize the inferior.
3 Full citizenship rights – ‘’assimilation’’ – were offered although in reality assimilation was always on the distant horizon.
4 Contrasting from Britain France sent small numbers of settlers to its colonies with the only notable exception of Algeria where French settlers nevertheless always remained a small minority.

1 From their original homelands in Scandinavia and northern Europe Germanic tribes expanded throughout northern and western Europe in the middle period of classical antiquity southern Europe in late antiquity conquering Celtic and other peoples and by 800 CE forming the Holy Roman Empire the first German Empire.
2 However there was no real systemic continuity from the Western Roman Empire to its German successor which was famously described as not holy not Roman and not an empire as a great number of small states and principalities existed in the loosely autonomous confederation.
3 Although by 1000 CE the Germanic conquest of central western and southern Europe west of and including Italy was complete excluding only Muslim Iberia.
4 There was however little cultural integration or national identity and Germany remained largely a conceptual term referring to an amorphous area of central Europe.

1 Not a maritime power and not a nationstate as it would eventually become Germany’s participation in Western imperialism was negligible until the late 19th century.
2 The participation of Austria was primarily as a result of Habsburg control of the First Empire the Spanish throne and other royal houses.
3 further explanation needed After the defeat of Napoleon who caused the dissolution of that Holy Roman Empire Prussia and the German states continued to stand aloof from imperialism preferring to manipulate the European system through the Concert of Europe.
4 After Prussia unified the other states into the second German Empire after the FrancoGerman War its longtime Chancellor Otto von Bismarck 1862–90 long opposed colonial acquisitions arguing that the burden of obtaining maintaining and defending such possessions would outweigh any potential benefits.
5 He felt that colonies did not pay for themselves that the German bureaucratic system would not work well in the tropics and the diplomatic disputes over colonies would distract Germany from its central interest Europe itself.

1 During the First SinoJapanese War in 1894 Japan absorbed Taiwan.
2 As a result of the RussoJapanese War in 1905 Japan took part of Sakhalin Island from Russia.
3 Korea was annexed in 1910.
4 During World War I Japan took Germanleased territories in China’s Shandong Province as well as the Mariana Caroline and Marshall Islands.
5 In 1918 Japan occupied parts of far eastern Russia and parts of eastern Siberia as a participant in the Siberian Intervention.
6 In 1931 Japan conquered Manchuria from China.
7 During the Second SinoJapanese War in 1937 Japans military invaded central China and by the end of the Pacific War Japan had conquered much of the Far East including Hong Kong Vietnam Cambodia Myanmar the Philippines Indonesia part of New Guinea and some islands of the Pacific Ocean.
8 Japan also invaded Thailand pressuring the country into a ThaiJapanese alliance.
9 Its colonial ambitions were ended by the victory of the United States in the Second World War and the following treaties which remanded those territories to American administration or their original owners.

1 Bolshevik leaders had effectively reestablished a polity with roughly the same extent as that empire by 1921 however with an internationalist ideology Lenin in particular asserted the right to limited selfdetermination for national minorities within the new territory.
2 Beginning in 1923 the policy of Indigenization korenizatsiia was intended to support nonRussians develop their national cultures within a socialist framework.
3 Never formally revoked it stopped being implemented after 1932.
4 After World War II the Soviet Union installed socialist regimes modeled on those it had installed in 1919–20 in the old Tsarist Empire in areas its forces occupied in Eastern Europe.
5 The Soviet Union and the People’s Republic of China supported post–World War II communist movements in foreign nations and colonies to advance their own interests but were not always successful.

1 Trotsky and others believed that the revolution could only succeed in Russia as part of a world revolution.
2 Lenin wrote extensively on the matter and famously declared that Imperialism was the highest stage of capitalism.
3 However after Lenins death Joseph Stalin established socialism in one country for the Soviet Union creating the model for subsequent inward looking Stalinist states and purging the early Internationalist elements.
4 The internationalist tendencies of the early revolution would be abandoned until they returned in the framework of a client state in competition with the Americans during the Cold War.
5 With the beginning of the new era the after Stalin period called the thaw in the late 1950s the new political leader Nikita Khrushchev put even more pressure on the SovietAmerican relations starting a new wave of antiimperialist propaganda.
6 In his speech on the UN conference in 1960 he announced the continuation of the war on imperialism stating that soon the people of different countries will come together and overthrow their imperialist leaders.
7 Although the Soviet Union declared itself antiimperialist critics argue that it exhibited tendencies common to historic empires.
8 Some scholars hold that the Soviet Union was a hybrid entity containing elements common to both multinational empires and nation states.
9 It has also been argued that the USSR practiced colonialism as did other imperial powers and was carrying on the old Russian tradition of expansion and control.
10 Mao Zedong once argued that the Soviet Union had itself become an imperialist power while maintaining a socialist façade.
11 Moreover the ideas of imperialism were widely spread in action on the higher levels of government.
12 Non Russian Marxists within the Russian Federation and later the USSR like Sultan Galiev and Vasyl Shakhrai considered the Soviet Regime a renewed version of the Russian imperialism and colonialism.
13 Trotsky thought what was needed for a true Russian revolution	a world revolution 	1.
14 Who wrote that imperialism is the highest stage of capitalism?	Lenin	2
15 Who argued that the USSR had itself become an imperialist power?	Mao Zedong	10
16 Who was the leader of Russia in the 1960s?	Nikita Khrushchev	5
17 What policy did Stalin implement shortly after Lenins Death?	socialism in one country	3
1 The First British Empire was based on mercantilism and involved colonies and holdings primarily in North America the Caribbean and India.
2 Its growth was reversed by the loss of the American colonies in 1776.
3 Britain made compensating gains in India Australia and in constructing an informal economic empire through control of trade and finance in Latin America after the independence of Spanish and Portuguese colonies about 1820.
4 By the 1840s Britain had adopted a highly successful policy of free trade that gave it dominance in the trade of much of the world.
5 After losing its first Empire to the Americans Britain then turned its attention towards Asia Africa and the Pacific.
6 Following the defeat of Napoleonic France in 1815 Britain enjoyed a century of almost unchallenged dominance and expanded its imperial holdings around the globe.
7 Increasing degrees of internal autonomy were granted to its white settler colonies in the 20th century.
8 What was the first British empire based on?	mercantilism	1
9 When did Great Britain lose its colonies in North America?	1776	2
10 What policy gave Britain dominance in world trade?	free trade	4
11 When did the Spanish and Portuguese colonies gain their independance	about 1820 	3.
12 When was the defeat of Napoleonic France?	1815	6
1 A resurgence came in the late 19th century with the Scramble for Africa and major additions in Asia and the Middle East.
2 The British spirit of imperialism was expressed by Joseph Chamberlain and Lord Rosebury and implemented in Africa by Cecil Rhodes.
3 The pseudosciences of Social Darwinism and theories of race formed an ideological underpinning during this time.
4 Other influential spokesmen included Lord Cromer Lord Curzon General Kitchner Lord Milner and the writer Rudyard Kipling.
5 The British Empire was the largest Empire that the world has ever seen both in terms of landmass and population.
6 Its power both military and economic remained unmatched.
7 By the late 19th century which country had the largest empire ever to exist in the world?	The British Empire	5
8 What kinds of sciences were Social Darwinism and theories of race?	pseudosciences	3
9 Rudyard Kipling was an influential spokesman for what?	The British spirit of imperialism	2
10 In which continent besides Asia were major gains made by the British Empire in the late 19th century?	Middle East	1
1 The early United States expressed its opposition to Imperialism at least in a form distinct from its own Manifest Destiny through policies such as the Monroe Doctrine.
2 However beginning in the late 19th and early 20th century policies such as Theodore Roosevelt’s interventionism in Central America and Woodrow Wilson’s mission to make the world safe for democracy changed all this.
3 They were often backed by military force but were more often affected from behind the scenes.
4 This is consistent with the general notion of hegemony and imperium of historical empires.
5 In 1898 Americans who opposed imperialism created the AntiImperialist League to oppose the US annexation of the Philippines and Cuba.
6 One year later a war erupted in the Philippines causing business labor and government leaders in the US to condemn Americas occupation in the Philippines as they also denounced them for causing the deaths of many Filipinos.
7 American foreign policy was denounced as a racket by Smedley Butler an American general.
8 He said Looking back on it I might have given Al Capone a few hints.
9 The best he could do was to operate his racket in three districts.
10 I operated on three continents.
11 How did the United States plan to subdue imperialistic tendencies?	the Monroe Doctrine	1
12 What was the name of Theodore Roosevelt’s policy of imperialism?	interventionism	2
13 What caused the US public to condemn the occupation of the philippines?	a war erupted	6
14 Which country besides the Cuba did the United states try to annex in 1898?	the Philippines	5
15 What did Smedley Butler call US foreign Policy?	a racket	7
1 One key figure in the plans for what would come to be known as American Empire was a geographer named Isiah Bowman.
2 Bowman was the director of the American Geographical Society in 1914.
3 Three years later in 1917 he was appointed to then President Woodrow Wilsons inquiry in 1917.
4 The inquiry was the idea of President Wilson and the American delegation from the Paris Peace Conference.
5 The point of this inquiry was to build a premise that would allow for US authorship of a new world which was to be characterized by geographical order.
6 As a result of his role in the inquiry Isiah Bowman would come to be known as Wilsons geographer.
7 Who was the director of the American Geographical Society in 1914?	Isiah Bowman	1
8 When was Isiah Bowman appointed to President Wilsons Inquiry?	1917	3
9 Who besides Woodrow Wilson himself had the idea for the inquiry?	American delegation from the Paris Peace Conference	4
10 What was the premise of Woodrow Wilsons inquiry?	US authorship of a new world	5
11 What was Isiah Bowman nick name as known by the public	Wilsons geographer 	6.
1 Some have described the internal strife between various people groups as a form of imperialism or colonialism.
2 This internal form is distinct from informal US imperialism in the form of political and financial hegemony.
3 This internal form of imperialism is also distinct from the United States formation of colonies abroad.
4 Through the treatment of its indigenous peoples during westward expansion the United States took on the form of an imperial power prior to any attempts at external imperialism.
5 This internal form of empire has been referred to as internal colonialism.
6 Participation in the African slave trade and the subsequent treatment of its 12 to 15 million Africans is viewed by some to be a more modern extension of Americas internal colonialism.
7 However this internal colonialism faced resistance as external colonialism did but the anticolonial presence was far less prominent due to the nearly complete dominance that the United States was able to assert over both indigenous peoples and AfricanAmericans.
8 In his lecture on April 16 2003 Edward Said made a bold statement on modern imperialism in the United States whom he described as using aggressive means of attack towards the contemporary Orient due to their backward living lack of democracy and the violation of women’s rights.
9 The western world forgets during this process of converting the other that enlightenment and democracy are concepts that not all will agree upon.
10 Some people describe what between individuals or groups as imperialism or colonialism?	internal strife	1
11 the US expansion Westward could be viewed as what type of colonialism?	internal colonialism	5
12 How many Africans were brought into the United States during the slave trade?	12 to 15 million	6
13 Who does Edward Said say is being attacked by US imperialism?	the contemporary Orient	8
1 The Ottoman Empire was an imperial state that lasted from 1299 to 1923.
2 During the 16th and 17th centuries in particular at the height of its power under the reign of Suleiman the Magnificent the Ottoman Empire was a powerful multinational multilingual empire controlling much of Southeast Europe Western Asia the Caucasus North Africa and the Horn of Africa.
3 At the beginning of the 17th century the empire contained 32 provinces and numerous vassal states.
4 Some of these were later absorbed into the empire while others were granted various types of autonomy during the course of centuries.
5 When did the Ottoman Empire fall?	1923	1
6 Who reigned over the Ottoman empire when it was at its most powerful	Suleiman the Magnificent 	2.
7 How many provinces did the Ottoman empire contain in the 17th century?	32	3
8 The Ottoman empire controlled territory on three continents Africa Asia and which other?	Europe	2
9 When was the Ottoman empire at its height?	During the 16th and 17th centuries	2
1 With Istanbul as its capital and control of lands around the Mediterranean basin the Ottoman Empire was at the center of interactions between the Eastern and Western worlds for six centuries.
2 Following a long period of military setbacks against European powers the Ottoman Empire gradually declined into the late nineteenth century.
3 The empire allied with Germany in the early 20th century with the imperial ambition of recovering its lost territories but it dissolved in the aftermath of World War I leading to the emergence of the new state of Turkey in the Ottoman Anatolian heartland as well as the creation of modern Balkan and Middle Eastern states thus ending Turkish colonial ambitions.
4 What was the capital of the Ottoman empire?	Istanbul	1
5 Who did the Ottoman empire ally with in WW I?	Germany	3
6 What ended Turkish imperial Ambitions?	World War I	3
7 Which country today is a remnant of the Ottoman empire?	Turkey	3
1 The United Methodist Church UMC is a mainline Protestant Methodist denomination.
2 In the 19th century its main predecessor was a leader in Evangelicalism.
3 Founded in 1968 by the union of the Methodist Church USA and the Evangelical United Brethren Church the UMC traces its roots back to the revival movement of John and Charles Wesley in England as well as the Great Awakening in the United States.
4 As such the churchs theological orientation is decidedly Wesleyan.
5 It embraces both liturgical and evangelical elements.
6 What does UMC stand for?	United Methodist Church	1
7 What is the United Methodist Church?	mainline Protestant Methodist denomination	1
8 When was the UMC founded?	1968	3
9 Who founded the UMC?	union of the Methodist Church USA and the Evangelical United Brethren Church	3
10 What is the churchs theological orientation?	Wesleyan	4
1 The United Methodist Church is the largest denomination within the wider Methodist movement which has approximately 80 million adherents across the world.
2 In the United States the UMC ranks as the largest mainline Protestant denomination the largest Protestant church after the Southern Baptist Convention and the third largest Christian denomination.
3 As of 2014 worldwide membership was about 12 million 72 million in the United States and 44 million in Africa Asia and Europe.
4 It is a member of the World Council of Churches the World Methodist Council and other religious associations.
5 In 2015 Pew Research estimated that 36 of the US population or 9 million adult adherents selfidentify with the United Methodist Church revealing a much larger number of adherents than registered membership.
6 What is the largest denomination within the wider Methodist movement?	United Methodist Church	1
7 Approximately how many adherents does the United Methodist Church have across the world?	80 million	1
8 In the United States the UMC ranks as the largest what?	mainline Protestant denomination	2
9 What percentage of the US population selfidentify with UMC?	36	5
1 The movement which would become The United Methodist Church began in the mid18th century within the Church of England.
2 A small group of students including John Wesley Charles Wesley and George Whitefield met on the Oxford University campus.
3 They focused on Bible study methodical study of scripture and living a holy life.
4 Other students mocked them saying they were the Holy Club and the Methodists being methodical and exceptionally detailed in their Bible study opinions and disciplined lifestyle.
5 Eventually the socalled Methodists started individual societies or classes for members of the Church of England who wanted to live a more religious life.
6 When did the movement that would become The United Methodist Church begin?	mid18th century	1
7 Where did the movement that would become The United Methodist Church begin?	within the Church of England	1
8 Why was the student group called the Methodists?	being methodical and exceptionally detailed in their Bible study	4
1 In 1735 John and Charles Wesley went to America to teach the gospel to the American Indians in the colony of Georgia.
2 In less than two years the Holy Club disbanded.
3 John Wesley returned to England and met with a group of clergy he respected.
4 He said they appeared to be of one heart as well as of one judgment resolved to be BibleChristians at all events and wherever they were to preach with all their might plain old Bible Christianity.
5 The ministers retained their membership in the Church of England.
6 Though not always emphasized or appreciated in the Anglican churches of their day their teaching emphasized salvation by Gods grace acquired through faith in Christ.
7 Three teachings they saw as the foundation of Christian faith were.
8 In what year did John and Charles Wesley come to America to teach the gospel?	1735	1
9 In 1735 where did John and Charles Wesley teach the gospel in America?	colony of Georgia	1
10 In 1735 who did John and Charles Wesley teach the gospel to in America?	American Indians	1
11 What did The Holy Clubs teachings emphasize?	salvation by Gods grace	6
1 Though John Wesley originally wanted the Methodists to stay within the Church of England the American Revolution decisively separated the Methodists in the American colonies from the life and sacraments of the Anglican Church.
2 In 1784 after unsuccessful attempts to have the Church of England send a bishop to start a new church in the colonies Wesley decisively appointed fellow priest Thomas Coke as superintendent bishop to organize a separate Methodist Society.
3 Together with Coke Wesley sent a revision of the Anglican Prayerbook and the Articles of Religion which were received and adopted by the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784 officially establishing the Methodist Episcopal Church.
4 The conference was held at the Lovely Lane Methodist Church considered the Mother Church of American Methodism.
5 What caused the separation of the Methodists in the American colonies?	American Revolution	1
6 When did Wesley appoint Thomas Coke as bishop?	1784	2
7 Who did Wesley appoint as bishop in 1784?	Thomas Coke	2
8 Where was the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784 held?	Lovely Lane Methodist Church	4
9 What is considered the Mother Church of American Methodism?	Lovely Lane Methodist Church	4
1 St Georges United Methodist Church located at the corner of 4th and New Streets in the Old City neighborhood of Philadelphia is the oldest Methodist church in continuous use in the United States beginning in 1769.
2 The congregation was founded in 1767 meeting initially in a sail loft on Dock Street and in 1769 it purchased the shell of a building which had been erected in 1763 by a German Reformed congregation.
3 At this time Methodists had not yet broken away from the Anglican Church and the Methodist Episcopal Church was not founded until 1784.
4 What church is located at the corner of 4th and New Streets in Philadelphia?	St Georges United Methodist Church	1
5 What is the oldest Methodist church in continuous use in the United States?	St Georges United Methodist Church	1
6 When was the congregation at St Georges founded?	1767	2
7 Where did the congregation at St Georges initially meet in 1767?	sail loft on Dock Street	2
8 When was the Methodist Episcopal Church founded?	1784	3
1 Richard Allen and Absalom Jones became the first African Americans ordained by the Methodist Church.
2 They were licensed by St Georges Church in 1784.
3 Three years later protesting racial segregation in the worship services Allen led most of the black members out of St Georges eventually they founded the Mother Bethel AME Church and the African Methodist Episcopal denomination.
4 Absalom Jones became an Episcopal priest.
5 In 1836 the churchs basement was excavated to make room for a Sunday School.
6 In the 1920s a court case saved the church from being demolished to make way for the Benjamin Franklin Bridge.
7 The case resulted in the bridge being relocated.
8 Historic St Georges welcomes visitors and is home to archives and a museum on Methodism.
9 Who became the first African Americans ordained by the Methodist Church?	Richard Allen and Absalom Jones	1
10 Richard Allen and Absalom Jones were licensed by what church?	St Georges Church	2
11 Richard Allen and Absalom Jones were licensed by St Georges Church in what year?	1784	2
1 In the more than 220 years since 1784 Methodism in the United States like many other Protestant denominations has seen a number of divisions and mergers.
2 In 1830 the Methodist Protestant Church split from the Methodist Episcopal Church over the issue of laity having a voice and vote in the administration of the church insisting that clergy should not be the only ones to have any determination in how the church was to be operated.
3 In 1844 the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church split into two conferences because of tensions over slavery and the power of bishops in the denomination.
4 When did the Methodist Protestant Church split from the Methodist Episcopal Church?	1830	2
5 Why did the Methodist Protestant Church split from the Methodist Episcopal Church?	issue of laity having a voice and vote in the administration of the church	2
6 When did the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church split into two conferences?	1844	3
7 Why did the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church split into two conferences?	because of tensions over slavery and the power of bishops in the denomination	3
1 On April 23 1968 the United Methodist Church was created when the Evangelical United Brethren Church represented by Bishop Reuben H Mueller and The Methodist Church represented by Bishop Lloyd Christ Wicke joined hands at the constituting General Conference in Dallas Texas.
2 With the words Lord of the Church we are united in Thee in Thy Church and now in The United Methodist Church the new denomination was given birth by the two churches that had distinguished histories and influential ministries in various parts of the world.
3 When was the United Methodist Church created?	April 23  1968	1
4 Where did two leaders join hands and give birth to a new denomination?	constituting General Conference in Dallas  Texas	1
5 Who was one man who joined hands and said Lord of the Church we are united in Thee?	Bishop Lloyd Christ Wicke	1
1 The United Methodist Church understands itself to be part of the holy catholic or universal church and it recognizes the historic ecumenical creeds the Apostles Creed and the Nicene Creed which are used frequently in services of worship.
2 The Book of Discipline also recognizes the importance of the Chalcedonian Creed of the Council of Chalcedon.
3 It upholds the concept of the visible and invisible Church meaning that all who are truly believers in every age belong to the holy Church invisible while the United Methodist Church is a branch of the Church visible to which all believers must be connected as it is the only institution wherein the Word of God is preached and the Sacraments are administered.
4 The UMC understands itself to be part of what church?	holy catholic or universal church	1
5 What book recognizes the importance of the Chalcedonian Creed?	The Book of Discipline	2
6 What is the concept of the visible and invisible Church?	meaning that all who are truly believers in every age belong to the holy Church invisible	3
1 Some argue that The United Methodist Church can lay a claim on apostolic succession as understood in the traditional sense.
2 As a result of the American Revolution John Wesley was compelled in 1784 to break with standard practice and ordain two of his lay preachers as presbyters Thomas Vasey and Richard Whatcoat.
3 Dr Thomas Coke already an Anglican priest assisted Wesley in this action.
4 Coke was then set apart as a superintendent bishop by Wesley and dispatched with Vasey and Whatcoat to America to take charge of Methodist activities there.
5 In defense of his action to ordain Wesley himself cited an ancient opinion from the Church of Alexandria which held that bishops and presbyters constituted one order and therefore bishops are to be elected from and by the presbyterate.
6 He knew that for two centuries the succession of bishops in the Church of Alexandria was preserved through ordination by presbyters alone and was considered valid by the ancient church.
7 Methodists today who would argue for apostolic succession would do so on these grounds.
8 Why was Wesley compelled to break with standard practice and ordain two of his lay preachers as presbyters?	result of the American Revolution	2
9 Who assisted Wesley with ordaining Whatcoat and Vasey as presbyters?	Dr Thomas Coke	3
10 Who were the two lay preachers that Wesley ordained as presbyters?	Thomas Vasey and Richard Whatcoat	2
1 While many United Methodist congregations operate in the evangelical tradition others reflect the mainline Protestant traditions.
2 Although United Methodist practices and interpretation of beliefs have evolved over time these practices and beliefs can be traced to the writings of the churchs founders especially John Wesley and Charles Wesley Anglicans but also Philip William Otterbein and Martin Boehm United Brethren and Jacob Albright Evangelical Association.
3 With the formation of The United Methodist Church in 1968 theologian Albert C Outler led the team which systematized denominational doctrine.
4 Outlers work proved pivotal in the work of union and he is largely considered the first United Methodist theologian.
5 When was the UMC formed?	1968	3
6 Who were two of the founders of the United Methodist Church?	John Wesley and Charles Wesley	2
7 In 1968 who led the team which systematized denominational doctrine?	Albert C Outler	3
8 Who is largely considered the first United Methodist theologian?	Albert C Outler	3
1 Prevenient grace or the grace that goes before us is given to all people.
2 It is that power which enables us to love and motivates us to seek a relationship with God through Jesus Christ.
3 This grace is the present work of God to turn us from our sincorrupted human will to the loving will of the Father.
4 In this work God desires that we might sense both our sinfulness before God and Gods offer of salvation.
5 Prevenient grace allows those tainted by sin to nevertheless make a truly free choice to accept or reject Gods salvation in Christ.
6 What is the grace that goes before us?	Prevenient grace	1
7 What is that power that enables us to love?	Prevenient grace	1
8 What is Prevenient grace?	the grace that goes before us	1
9 Prevenient grace allowas those tainted by what to make a choice to accept or reject Gods salvation in Christ?	Prevenient grace	5
1 Justifying Grace or Accepting Grace is that grace offered by God to all people that we receive by faith and trust in Christ through which God pardons the believer of sin.
2 It is in justifying grace we are received by God in spite of our sin.
3 In this reception we are forgiven through the atoning work of Jesus Christ on the cross.
4 The justifying grace cancels our guilt and empowers us to resist the power of sin and to fully love God and neighbor.
5 Today justifying grace is also known as conversion accepting Jesus as your personal Lord and Savior or being born again.
6 John Wesley originally called this experience the New Birth.
7 This experience can occur in different ways it can be one transforming moment such as an altar call experience or it may involve a series of decisions across a period of time.
8 What is the grace that we receive by faith and trust in God?	Justifying Grace or Accepting Grace	1
9 What cancels our guilt and empowers us to resist the power of sin and to fully love God and neighbor?	justifying grace	4
10 What is justifying grace also known as today?	conversion	5
11 What is another name for being born again?	conversion	5
12 What did John Wesley originally call the experience of conversion?	New Birth	6
1 Sanctifying Grace is that grace of God which sustains the believers in the journey toward Christian Perfection a genuine love of God with heart soul mind and strength and a genuine love of our neighbors as ourselves.
2 Sanctifying grace enables us to respond to God by leading a Spiritfilled and Christlike life aimed toward love.
3 Wesley never claimed this state of perfection for himself but instead insisted the attainment of perfection was possible for all Christians.
4 Here the English Reformer parted company with both Luther and Calvin who denied that a man would ever reach a state in this life in which he could not fall into sin.
5 Such a man can lose all inclination to evil and can gain perfection in this life.
6 What is Sanctifying Grace?	grace of God which sustains the believers in the journey toward Christian Perfection	1
7 What is that grace of God which sustains the believers in the journey towards Christian Perfection?	Sanctifying Grace	1
8 What is Christian Perfection?	a genuine love of God with heart  soul  mind  and strength  and a genuine love of our neighbors as ourselves	1
9 What is a genuine love of God with heart soul and mind?	Christian Perfection	1
1 Wesleyan theology stands at a unique crossroads between evangelical and sacramental between liturgical and charismatic and between AngloCatholic and Reformed theology and practice.
2 It has been characterized as Arminian theology with an emphasis on the work of the Holy Spirit to bring holiness into the life of the participating believer.
3 The United Methodist Church believes in prima scriptura seeing the Holy Bible as the primary authority in the Church and using sacred tradition reason and experience to interpret it with the aid of the Holy Spirit see Wesleyan Quadrilateral.
4 Therefore according to The Book of Discipline United Methodist theology is at once catholic evangelical and reformed.
5 Today the UMC is generally considered one of the more moderate and tolerant denominations with respect to race gender and ideology though the denomination itself actually includes a very wide spectrum of attitudes.
6 Comparatively the UMC stands to the right of liberal and progressive Protestant groups such as the United Church of Christ and the Episcopal Church on certain issues especially regarding sexuality but to the left of historically conservative evangelical traditions such as the Southern Baptists and Pentecostalism in regard to theological matters such as social justice and Biblical interpretation.
7 However it should be noted that the UMC is made up of a broad diversity of thought and so there are many clergy and laity within the UMC that hold differing viewpoints on such theological matters.
8 What has been characterized as Arminian theology with an emphasis on the work of the Holy Spirit?	Wesleyan theology	1
9 What is seeing the Holy Bible as the primary authority in the Church?	prima scriptura	3
10 Today which church is generally considered one of the more moderate and tolerant denominations?	UMC	5
11 What states that United Methodist theology is at once catholic evangelical and reformed?	Book of Discipline	4
1 The United Methodist Church upholds the sanctity of human life both of the child and the mother.
2 As a result the church is reluctant to affirm abortion as an acceptable practice and condemns the use of lateterm or partial birth abortion except as a medical necessity.
3 The denomination as a whole is committed to assisting the ministry of crisis pregnancy centers and pregnancy resource centers that compassionately help women find feasible alternatives to abortion.
4 Still the denomination is prochoice and also was a founding member of the Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choiceand 2008 General Conference went on record in support of the work of the Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice.
5 When did the General Conference go on record in support of the work of the Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice?	2008	4
6 Is the UMC prolife or prochoice?	prochoice	4
7 The UMC was a founding member of what coalition?	Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice	4
1 The church also holds that they are equally bound to respect the sacredness of the life and wellbeing of the mother for whom devastating damage may result from an unacceptable pregnancy.
2 In continuity with past Christian teaching we recognize tragic conflicts of life with life that may justify abortion and in such cases we support the legal option of abortion under proper medical procedures.
3 As such two official bodies of the United Methodist Church are part of the Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choices governing coalition The General Board of Church and Society and the United Methodist Women.
4 The church cautions that Governmental laws and regulations do not provide all the guidance required by the informed Christian conscience.
5 The Church emphasizes the need to be in supportive ministry with all women regardless of their choice.
6 What are two official bodies of the UMC governing coalition?	The General Board of Church and Society  and the United Methodist Women	3
7 The church emphasizes the need to be in supportive ministry of what group?	all women	5
8 The church holds that they are equally bound to respect the sacredness of the life and wellbeing of whom?	the mother	1
1 Members of the United Methodist Church who identify with the prolife position have organized into the Taskforce of United Methodists on Abortion and Sexuality TUMAS to further their position within the denomination.
2 There was an attempt to withdraw the United Methodist Church membership in the Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice at their General Conference held in May 2012 with a petition that passed through the legislative subcommittee and committee votes but was not given a floor vote.
3 Rev.
4 Paul T Stallsworth president of the Taskforce of United Methodists on Abortion and Sexuality said he had every reason to believe that prolife delegates would have won a floor vote.
5 What is the taskforce that was organized to identify with the prolife position?	Taskforce of United Methodists on Abortion and Sexuality 	1
6 In what year was there an attempt to withdraw the UMC membership?	2012	2
7 Who is the president of TUMAS?	Rev Paul T Stallsworth	3
1 Historically the Methodist Church has supported the temperance movement.
2 John Wesley warned against the dangers of drinking in his famous sermon The Use of Money and in his letter to an alcoholic.
3 At one time Methodist ministers had to take a pledge not to drink and encouraged their congregations to do the same.
4 Today the United Methodist Church states that it affirms our longstanding support of abstinence from alcohol as a faithful witness to Gods liberating and redeeming love for persons.
5 In fact the United Methodist Church uses unfermented grape juice in the sacrament of Holy Communion thus expressing pastoral concern for recovering alcoholics enabling the participation of children and youth and supporting the churchs witness of abstinence.
6 Moreover in 2011 and 2012 The United Methodist Churchs General Board of Church and Society called on all United Methodists to abstain from alcohol for Lent.
7 Historically which movement has the Methodist Church supported?	temperance movement	1
8 When did the UMCs General Board of Church and Society call on all United Methodists to abstain from alcohol for Lent?	2011 and 2012	6
9 What was the name of Wesleys famous sermon in which he warned against the dangers of drinking?	The Use of Money	2
10 What does the United Methodist Church use in the sacrament of the Holy Communion?	unfermented grape juice	5
1 The United Methodist Church along with other Methodist churches condemns capital punishment saying that it cannot accept retribution or social vengeance as a reason for taking human life.
2 The Church also holds that the death penalty falls unfairly and unequally upon marginalized persons including the poor the uneducated ethnic and religious minorities and persons with mental and emotional illnesses.
3 The United Methodist Church also believes that Jesus explicitly repudiated the lex talionis in Matthew 53839 and abolished the death penalty in John 87.
4 The General Conference of the United Methodist Church calls for its bishops to uphold opposition to capital punishment and for governments to enact an immediate moratorium on carrying out the death penalty sentence.
5 The UMC condemns what type of punishment?	capital punishment	1
6 The UMC believes that Jesus abolished the death penalty in what Bible verse?	John 87	3
7 The UMC believes that Jesus repudiated the les talionis in what BIble verses?	Matthew 53839	3
8 What part of the UMC calls for its bishops to uphold opposition to capital punishment?	The General Conference	4
1 In addition the United Methodist Church prohibits the celebration of samesex unions.
2 Rev.
3 Jimmy Creech was defrocked after a highly publicized church trial in 1999 on account of his participation in samesex union ceremonies.
4 It forbids any United Methodist board agency committee commission or council to give United Methodist funds to any gay organization or group or otherwise use such funds to promote the acceptance of homosexuality.
5 Other ministers have been defrocked for officiating at samesex weddings and several trials of others are scheduled.
6 Still some congregations have sought other ways to recognize samesex couples.
7 For example one congregation hosted a proposal for a samesex couple announcing their engagement.
8 Moreover some churches especially in 2016 after samesex marriage was legalized nationwide have provided blessings for samesex marriages.
9 In April of 2016 a United Methodist bishop made a bold statement by performing a samesex marriage in church as a clear sign of his advocacy for change.
10 The UMC prohibits the celebration of what type of unions?	samesex unions	1
11 In what year was the trial of Rev Jimmy Creech?	1999	3
12 In what year was samesex marriage legalized nationwide?	2016	8
1 Nevertheless The United Methodist Church implores families and churches not to reject or condemn lesbian and gay members and friends and commits itself to be in ministry with all persons affirming that Gods grace love and forgiveness is available to all.
2 Additionally many organizations conferences and congregations have recently called for broader acceptance of the LGBT community within the UMC.
3 For example the Connectional Table a governing committee has voted in favor of a proposal that calls for a localized option which would permit ministers to officiate samesex weddings and it would allow conferences to ordain gay clergy.
4 Moreover many conferences have taken a position by voting in favor of samegender marriages with resolutions.
5 What is the governing committee  that voted in favor of a proposal that would permit ministers to officiate samesex weddings?	Connectional Table	3
6 Many organizations have recently called for broader acceptance of which community?	LGBT	2
7 Many conferences have taking a position by voting in favor of what?	samegender marriages with resolutions	4
1 In 1987 a United Methodist church court in New Hampshire defrocked Methodist minister Rose Mary Denman for openly living with a samesex partner.
2 In 2005 clergy credentials were removed from Irene Elizabeth Stroud after she was convicted in a church trial of violating church law by engaging in a lesbian relationship this conviction was later upheld by the Judicial Council the highest court in the denomination.
3 The Judicial Council also affirmed that a Virginia pastor had the right to deny local church membership to a man in an openly gay relationship.
4 This affirmation however was based upon a senior pastors right to judge the readiness of a congregant to join as a full member of the church.
5 However at the same time the UMC Judicial Council in 2008 ruled that conferences can determine their own policy related to transgender pastors and therefore some regional conferences have voted to recognize ordained transgender pastors.
6 The BaltimoreWashington Conference of the UMC has approved the appointment of an openly partnered lesbian to the provisional diaconate.
7 In what year was Rose Mary Denman defrocked for openly living with a samesex partner?	1987	1
8 In what year was Irene Elizabeth Stroud convicted in a church trial?	2005	2
9 What group has approved the appointment of an openly partnered lesbian to the provisional diaconate?	BaltimoreWashington Conference of the UMC	6
1 The United Methodist Church opposes conscription as incompatible with the teaching of Scripture.
2 Therefore the Church supports and extends its ministry to those persons who conscientiously oppose all war or any particular war and who therefore refuse to serve in the armed forces or to cooperate with systems of military conscription.
3 However the United Methodist Church also supports and extends its ministry to those persons who conscientiously choose to serve in the armed forces or to accept alternative service.
4 The church also states that as Christians they are aware that neither the way of military action nor the way of inaction is always righteous before God.
5 What does the UMC oppose as incompatible with the teaching of Scripture?	conscription	1
6 The church states that as Christians they are aware that neither the way of what is righteous before God?	the way of military action	4
7 The Church supports those persons who conscientiously oppose what?	all war	2
1 The United Methodist Church maintains that war is incompatible with Christs message and teachings.
2 Therefore the Church rejects war as an instrument of national foreign policy to be employed only as a last resort in the prevention of such evils as genocide brutal suppression of human rights and unprovoked international aggression.
3 It insists that the first moral duty of all nations is to resolve by peaceful means every dispute that arises between or among them that human values must outweigh military claims as governments determine their priorities that the militarization of society must be challenged and stopped that the manufacture sale and deployment of armaments must be reduced and controlled and that the production possession or use of nuclear weapons be condemned.
4 Consequently the United Methodist Church endorses general and complete disarmament under strict and effective international control.
5 The UMC maintains that war is incompatible with what?	Christs message and teachings	1
6 The Church rejects was as an instrument of what?	instrument of national foreign policy	2
7 What does the UMC endorse under strict and effective international control?	general and complete disarmament	4
1 The United Methodist Church teaches that pornography is about violence degradation exploitation and coercion and deplores all forms of commercialization abuse and exploitation of sex.
2 The Sexual Ethics Task Force of The United Methodist Church states that Research shows it pornography is not an innocent activity.
3 It is harmful and is generally addictive.
4 Persons who are addicted to pornography are physiologically altered as is their perspective relationships with parishioners and family and their perceptions of girls and women.
5 Which task force states that pornography is harmful?	The Sexual Ethics Task Force of The United Methodist Church	2
6 The UMC teaches that pornography is about what?	violence  degradation  exploitation  and coercion	1
7 According to the UMC persons who are addicted to pornography have altered perceptions of whom?	girls and women	4
1 The UMC supports federal funding for research on embryos created for IVF that remain after the procreative efforts have ceased if the embryos were provided for research instead of being destroyed were not obtained by sale and those donating had given prior informed consent for the research purposes.
2 The UMC stands in opposition to the creation of embryos for the sake of research as a human embryo even at its earliest stages commands our reverence.
3 It supports research on stem cells retrieved from umbilical cords and adult stem cells stating that there are few moral questions raised by this issue.
4 The UMC supports federal funding for research on embryos created for what purpose?	IVF	1
5 The UMC supports research on what cells retrieved from umbilical cords?	stem cells	3
6 The UMC stands in oppopsition to the creation of embroys for the sake of what?	research	2
1 The common pattern comes from John Wesley who wrote that there is no Liturgy in the world either in ancient or modern language which breathes more of a solid scriptural rational piety than the Common Prayer of the Church of England.
2 When the Methodists in America were separated from the Church of England John Wesley himself provided a revised version of The Book of Common Prayer called the Sunday Service of the Methodists in North America.
3 Wesleys Sunday Service has shaped the official liturgies of the Methodists ever since.
4 What is the revised version of The Book of Common Prayer called?	Sunday Service of the Methodists in North America	2
5 When did John Wesley provide a revised version of The Book of Common Prayer?	When the Methodists in America were separated from the Church of England	2
6 The Sunday Service of the Methodists in North America was a revised version of what book?	The Book of Common Prayer	2
1 Like other historic Christian churches The United Methodist Church has official liturgies for services of Holy Communion baptism weddings funerals ordination anointing of the sick and daily office prayer services.
2 Some clergy offer healing services while exorcism is an occasional practice by some clergy in The United Methodist Church in Africa.
3 These services involve the laying on of hands and anointing with oil.
4 Along with these there are also special services for holy days such as All Saints Day Ash Wednesday Maundy Thursday Good Friday and Easter Vigil.
5 These services are contained in The United Methodist Hymnal and The United Methodist Book of Worship 1992.
6 Many of these liturgies are derived from the Anglican traditions Book of Common Prayer.
7 In most cases congregations also use other elements of liturgical worship such as candles vestments paraments banners and liturgical art.
8 In what country does some clergy in the UMC occasionally practice exorcism?	Africa	2
9 Many liturgies are derived from what book?	Book of Common Prayer	6
10 Healing services involve the laying on of hands and what else?	anointing with oil	3
1 Methodist institutions may be named after a biblical figure eg St James UMC.
2 Methodists also honor notable heroes and heroines of the Christian faith and look to these prominent saints as providing examples of holy living and commitment to Christ that are worthy of imitation see 1 Corinthians 111.
3 Such exemplary saints include martyrs confessors of the Faith evangelists or important biblical figures such as Saint Matthew Lutheran theologian and martyr to the Nazis Dietrich Bonhoeffer Salvation Army Founder William Booth African missionary David Livingstone and Methodisms revered founder John Wesley are among many cited as Protestant saints.
4 What may be named after a biblical figure?	Methodist institutions	1
5 Who is the founder of the Salvation Army?	William Booth	3
6 Who is Methodisms revered founder?	John Wesley	3
1 The United Methodist Church is organized into conferences.
2 The highest level is called the General Conference and is the only organization which may speak officially for the church.
3 The General Conference meets every four years quadrennium.
4 Legislative changes are recorded in The Book of Discipline which is revised after each General Conference.
5 Nonlegislative resolutions are recorded in the Book of Resolutions which is published after each General Conference and expire after eight years unless passed again by a subsequent session of General Conference.
6 The last General Conference was held in Tampa Florida in 2012.
7 The event is currently rotated between the US jurisdictions of the church.
8 The 2016 General Conference will be in Portland Oregon.
9 Bishops Councils Committees Boards Elders etc are not permitted to speak on behalf of The United Methodist Church as this authority is reserved solely for the General Conference in accordance with the Book of Discipline.
10 What church is organized into conferences?	United Methodist Church	1
11 What is the only organization which may speak officially for the church?	General Conference	2
12 What book is revised after every General Conference?	The Book of Discipline	4
13 What is the highest level of the UMC?	General Conference	2
14 How often does the General Conference meet?	every four years	3
1 Subordinate to the General Conference are the jurisdictional and central conferences which also meet every four years.
2 The United States is divided into five jurisdictions Northeastern Southeastern North Central South Central and Western.
3 Outside the United States the church is divided into seven central conferences Africa Congo West Africa Central  Southern Europe Germany Northern Europe and the Philippines.
4 The main purpose of the jurisdictions and central conferences is to elect and appoint bishops the chief administrators of the church.
5 Bishops thus elected serve Episcopal Areas which consist of one or more Annual Conferences.
6 The United States is divided into how many jurisdictions?	five	2
7 How many central conferences are outside of the United States?	seven	3
8 What is the main purpose of the jurisdictions and central conferences?	to elect and appoint bishops	4
9 Who are the chief administrators of the church?	bishops	4
10 What consist of one ore more Annual Conferences?	Episcopal Areas	5
1 Decisions inbetween the fouryear meetings are made by the Mission Council usually consisting of church bishops.
2 One of the most high profile decisions in recent years by one of the councils was a decision by the Mission Council of the South Central Jurisdiction which in March 2007 approved a 99year lease of 36 acres 150000 m2 at Southern Methodist University for the George W Bush Presidential Library.
3 The decision generated controversy in light of Bushs support of the Iraq War which the church bishops have criticized.
4 A debate over whether the decision should or could be submitted for approval by the Southern Jurisdictional Conference at its July 2008 meeting in Dallas Texas remains unresolved.
5 Who makes decisions in between the fouryear meetings?	Mission Council	1
6 The Mission Council usually consists of whom?	church bishops	1
7 In March 2007 the Mission Council of the South Central jurisdiction approved a 99year lease on how many acres?	36	2
8 Why was the 36 acres leased?	for the George W Bush Presidential Library	2
9 Where is the George W Bush Presidential library?	Southern Methodist University	2
1 The Judicial Council is the highest court in the denomination.
2 It consists of nine members both laity and clergy elected by the General Conference for an eightyear term.
3 The ratio of laity to clergy alternates every eight years.
4 The Judicial Council interprets the Book of Discipline between sessions of General Conference and during General Conference the Judicial Council rules on the constitutionality of laws passed by General Conference.
5 The Council also determines whether actions of local churches annual conferences church agencies and bishops are in accordance with church law.
6 The Council reviews all decisions of law made by bishops The Judicial Council cannot create any legislation it can only interpret existing legislation.
7 The Council meets twice a year at various locations throughout the world.
8 The Judicial Council also hears appeals from those who have been accused of chargeable offenses that can result in defrocking or revocation of membership.
9 How many members make up the Judicial Council?	nine	2
10 What is the highest court in the United Methodist denomination?	Judicial Council	1
11 How long is the term of a Judicial Council member?	eightyear term	2
12 How many times a year does The Council meet?	twice a year	7
13 Where does The Council meet?	various locations throughout the world	7
1 The Annual Conference roughly the equivalent of a diocese in the Anglican Communion and the Roman Catholic Church or a synod in some Lutheran denominations such as the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America is the basic unit of organization within the UMC.
2 The term Annual Conference is often used to refer to the geographical area it covers as well as the frequency of meeting.
3 Clergy are members of their Annual Conference rather than of any local congregation and are appointed to a local church or other charge annually by the conferences resident Bishop at the meeting of the Annual Conference.
4 In many ways the United Methodist Church operates in a connectional organization of the Annual Conferences and actions taken by one conference are not binding upon another.
5 What is the basic unit of organization within the UMC?	The Annual Conference	1
6 The term Annual Conference is often used to refer to what?	geographical area it covers as well as the frequency of meeting	2
7 Clergy are members of what group rather than of any local congregation?	their Annual Conference	3
1 The Book of Discipline is the guidebook for local churches and pastors and describes in considerable detail the organizational structure of local United Methodist churches.
2 All UM churches must have a board of trustees with at least three members and no more than nine members and it is recommended that no gender should hold more than a 23 majority.
3 All churches must also have a nominations committee a finance committee and a church council or administrative council.
4 Other committees are suggested but not required such as a missions committee or evangelism or worship committee.
5 Term limits are set for some committees but not for all.
6 The church conference is an annual meeting of all the officers of the church and any interested members.
7 This committee has the exclusive power to set pastors salaries compensation packages for tax purposes and to elect officers to the committees.
8 What is the guidebook for local churches and pastors?	The Book of Discipline	1
9 What is the least number of members a board of trustees can have?	three	2
10 What is the greatest number of members a board of trustees can have?	nine	2
11 What is an annual meeting of all the officers of the church and any interested members?	church conference	6
12 Which committee has the exclusive power to set pastors salaries?	church conference	6
1 Throughout its history the United Methodist Church has placed great emphasis on the importance of education.
2 As such the United Methodist Church established and is affiliated with around one hundred colleges and universities in the United States including Syracuse University Boston University Emory University Duke University Drew University University of Denver University of Evansville and Southern Methodist University.
3 Most are members of the International Association of Methodistrelated Schools Colleges and Universities.
4 The church operates three hundred sixty schools and institutions overseas.
5 The UMC established and is affiliated with approximately how many colleges and universities in the US?	one hundred	2
6 How many schools and institutions does the church operate overseas?	three hundred sixty	4
7 Most schools established by the UMC are members of what group?	International Association of Methodistrelated Schools  Colleges  and Universities	3
1 The first Methodist clergy were ordained by John Wesley a priest of the Church of England because of the crisis caused by the American Revolution which isolated the Methodists in the States from the Church of England and its sacraments.
2 Today the clergy includes men and women who are ordained by bishops as elders and deacons and are appointed to various ministries.
3 Elders in the United Methodist Church itenerate and are subject to the authority and appointment of their bishops.
4 They generally serve as pastors in local congregations.
5 Deacons are in service ministry and may serve as musicians liturgists educators business administrators and a number of other areas.
6 Elders and deacons are required to obtain a masters degree generally an MDiv.
7  or another equivalent degree before commissioning and then ultimately ordination.
8 Elders in full connection are each a member of their Annual Conference Order of Elders.
9 Likewise each deacon in full connection is a member of their Annual Conference Order of Deacons.
10 Who ordained the first Methodist clergy?	John Wesley	1
11 Clergy usually serve as what in local congregations?	pastors	4
12 Elders in full connection are each a member of what?	Annual Conference Order of Elders	8
13 Each deacon in full connection is a member of what?	Annual Conference Order of Deacons	9
1 All clergy appointments are made and fixed annually by the resident bishop on the advice of the Annual Conference Cabinet which is composed of the Area ProvostDean if one is appointed and the several District Superintendents of the Districts of the Annual Conference.
2 Until the bishop has read the appointments at the session of the Annual Conference no appointments are officially fixed.
3 Many Annual Conferences try to avoid making appointment changes between sessions of Annual Conference.
4 While an appointment is made one year at a time it is most common for an appointment to be continued for multiple years.
5 Appointment tenures in extension ministries such as military chaplaincy campus ministry missions higher education and other ministries beyond the local church are often even longer.
6 What is composed of the Area ProvostDean ad the several District Superintendents of the Districts in the Annual Conference?	Annual Conference Cabinet	1
7 All clergy appointments are made for how long?	one year at a time	4
8 No appointment is official fixed until what occurs?	bishop has read the appointments at the session of the Annual Conference	2
1 Elders are called by God affirmed by the church and ordained by a bishop to a ministry of Word Sacrament Order and Service within the church.
2 They may be appointed to the local church or to other valid extension ministries of the church.
3 Elders are given the authority to preach the Word of God administer the sacraments of the church to provide care and counseling and to order the life of the church for ministry and mission.
4 Elders may also be assigned as District Superintendents and they are eligible for election to the episcopacy.
5 Elders serve a term of 2–3 years as provisional Elders prior to their ordination.
6 Who is called by God affirmed by the church and ordained by a bishop?	Elders	1
7 Who appoints elders?	the local church	2
8 How many years do Elders serve as provisional Elders prior to their ordination?	2–3 years	5
9 Who may assign Elders?	District Superintendents	4
1 Deacons are called by God affirmed by the church and ordained by a bishop to servant leadership within the churchThey are ordained to ministries of word service compassion and justice.
2 They may be appointed to ministry within the local church or to an extension ministry that supports the mission of the church.
3 Deacons give leadership preach the Word contribute in worship conduct marriages bury the dead and aid the church in embodying its mission within the world.
4 Deacons assist elders in the sacraments of Holy Communion and Baptism and may be granted sacramental authority if they are appointed as the pastor in a local church.
5 Deacons serve a term of 2–3 years as provisional deacons prior to their ordination.
6 Deacons serve a term of how many years as provisional deacons?	2–3 years	5
7 Who gives leadership preaches the Word and conducts marriages among other duties?	Deacons	3
8 Who assist elders in the sacraments of Holy Communion and Baptism?	Deacons	4
9 What are Deacons granted if they are appointed as pastor in a local church?	granted sacramental authority	4
1 At the 1996 General Conference the ordination order of transitional deacon was abolished.
2 This created new orders known as provisional elder or provisional deacon for those who seek to be ordained in the respective orders.
3 The provisional elderdeacon is a seminary graduate who serves a twothreeyear term in a fulltime appointment after being commissioned.
4 During this two or threeyear period the provisional elder is granted sacramental ministry in their local appointment.
5 For the first time in its history nonordained pastors became a normal expectation rather than an extraordinary provision for ministry.
6 In what year was the ordination order of transitional deacon abolished?	1996	1
7 What is the title for a seminary graduate who serves a twothreeyear term in fulltime appointment after being commissioned?	The provisional elderdeacon	3
8 What provided for the creation of new orders known as provisional elder?	1996 General Conference	1
1 Local Pastors are called by God affirmed by the church and appointed by a bishop to a ministry of Word Sacrament Order and Service within the church.
2 The Local Pastor are given the authority to preach the Word of God administer the sacraments of the church to provide care and counseling and to order the life of the church for ministry and mission but are not ordained.
3 When elders are not available to be appointed to a local church either through shortage of personnel or financial hardship of a pastoral charge the bishop may appoint a local pastor to serve the pastoral appointment.
4 Local Pastors are often bivocational living out their ministerial call in the local church and in their field of employment.
5 Fulltime and parttime licensed local pastors under appointment are clergy and hold membership in the annual conference and not in the local church.
6 A Local Pastors official title is Licensed Local Pastor and is appointed as clergy to the local church where they preach conduct divine worship and perform the regular duties of a pastor.
7 The licensed local pastor has the authority of a pastor only within the context and during the time of the appointment and shall not extend beyond it.
8 Local pastors are not required to have advanced degrees but are required to attend licensing school and attend and pass an approved fiveyear course of study at an approved United Methodist seminary or course of study school successfully complete written and oral examinations and appear before the District Committee on Ministry and the Conference Board of Ordained Ministry.
9 They may continue towards Associate Membership allowing them to retire as clergy.
10 They also may continue towards ordination if they complete their bachelors degree requirements of their particular Conference Board of Ordained Ministry as well as an advanced course or study or prescribed seminary courses at an approved seminary.
11 Upon retirement local pastors return to their charge conference as lay members.
12 What is a local pastors official title?	Licensed Local Pastor	6
13 Who has the authority of a pastor only within the context and during the time of the appointment?	licensed local pastor	7
14 How many years must a local pastor attend a course of study at United Methodist approved seminary?	five	8
15 What type of membership will allow local pastors to retire as clergy?	Associate Membership	9
1 The United Methodist Church UMC practices infant and adult baptism.
2 Baptized Members are those who have been baptized as an infant or child but who have not subsequently professed their own faith.
3 These Baptized Members become Professing Members through confirmation and sometimes the profession of faith.
4 Individuals who were not previously baptized are baptized as part of their profession of faith and thus become Professing Members in this manner.
5 Individuals may also become a Professing Member through transfer from another Christian denomination.
6 What are members who have been baptized as an infant or child but who have not subsequently professed their own faith?	Baptized Members	2
7 How to Baptized Members become Professing Members?	confirmation and sometimes the profession of faith	3
8 Name one way in which a person can become a Professing Member?	transfer from another Christian denomination	5
1 Unlike confirmation and profession of faith Baptism is a sacrament in the UMC.
2 The Book of Discipline of the United Methodist Church directs the local church to offer membership preparation or confirmation classes to all people including adults.
3 The term confirmation is generally reserved for youth while some variation on membership class is generally used for adults wishing to join the church.
4 The Book of Discipline normally allows any youth at least completing sixth grade to participate although the pastor has discretionary authority to allow a younger person to participate.
5 In confirmation and membership preparation classes students learn about Church and the MethodistChristian theological tradition in order to profess their ultimate faith in Christ.
6 Unlike confirmation and profession of faith what is a sacrament in the UMC?	Baptism	1
7 How do students learn about the church?	confirmation and membership preparation classes	5
8 What directions the local church to offer membership preparation to all people?	The Book of Discipline	2
9 What do students learn about in confirmation and membership preparation classes?	Church and the MethodistChristian theological tradition	5
1 Another position in the United Methodist Church is that of the lay servant.
2 Although not considered clergy lay speakers often preach during services of worship when an ordained elder Local Pastor Associate Member or deacon is unavailable.
3 There are two categories of lay servants local church lay servant who serve in and through their local churches and certified lay servants who serve in their own churches in other churches and through district or conference projects and programs.
4 To be recognized as local church lay servant they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference and complete the basic course for lay servant.
5 Each year they must reapply reporting how they have served and continued to learn during that year.
6 To be recognized as certified lay servant they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference complete the basic course and one advanced lay servant course and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking.
7 They must report and reapply annually and they must complete at least one advanced course every three years.
8 Local church and certified  are two types of what?	lay servants	3
9 How can someone be recognized as local church lay servant?	they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference  and complete the basic course for lay servant	4
10 How often must local lay servant reapply?	annually	7
11 How many courses must a local lay servant take?	at least one advanced course every three years	7
1 The United Methodist Church is one tradition within the Christian Church.
2 The United Methodist Church is active in ecumenical relations with other Christian groups and denominations.
3 It is a member of the National Council of Churches the World Council of Churches Churches Uniting in Christ and Christian Churches Together.
4 In addition it voted to seek observer status in the National Association of Evangelicals and in the World Evangelical Fellowship.
5 However there are some in The United Methodist Church who feel that false ecumenism might result in the blurring of theological and confessional differences in the interests of unity.
6 What is one tradition within the Christian Church?	United Methodist Church	1
7 What type of status did the UMC vote to seek in the National Association of Evangelicals?	observer status	4
8 Some in the UMC feel that false ecumenism might result in what?	blurring of theological and confessional differences in the interests of unity	5
1 The United Methodist Church has since 1985 been exploring a possible merger with three historically AfricanAmerican Methodist denominations the African Methodist Episcopal Church the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church and the Christian Methodist Episcopal Church.
2 A Commission on Pan Methodist Cooperation and Union formed in 2000 to carry out work on such a merger.
3 In May 2012 The United Methodist Church entered into full communion with the African Methodist Episcopal Church African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church African Union Methodist Protestant Church Christian Methodist Episcopal Church and Union American Methodist Episcopal Church in which these Churches agreed to recognize each others churches share sacraments and affirm their clergy and ministries.
4 In what year was the Commission on Pan Methodist Cooperation and Union formed?	2000	2
5 When did the UMC enter into full communion with several churches?	May 2012	3
6 Since what year has the UMC been exploring a possible merger with three historically AfricanAmerican denominations?	1985	1
1 Like many other mainline Protestant denominations in the United States the United Methodist Church has experienced significant membership losses in recent decades.
2 At the time of its formation the UMC had about 11 million members in nearly 42000 congregations.
3 In 1975 membership dropped below 10 million for the first time.
4 In 2005 there were about 8 million members in over 34000 congregations.
5 Membership is concentrated primarily in the Midwest and in the South.
6 Texas has the largest number of members with about 1 million.
7 The states with the highest membership rates are Oklahoma Iowa Mississippi West Virginia and North Carolina.
8 At the time of its formation how many members did the UMC have?	11 million	2
9 At the time of its formation how many congregations did the UMC have?	42 000	2
10 In 2005 approximately how many members were in the UMC?	8 million	4
11 In 2005 approximately how many congregations were in the UMC?	34 000	4
12 Which state has the largest number of members?	Texas	6
1 By the opening of the 2008 General Conference total UMC membership was estimated at 114 million with about 79 million in the US and 35 million overseas.
2 Significantly about 20 of the conference delegates were from Africa with Filipinos and Europeans making up another 10.
3 During the conference the delegates voted to finalize the induction of the Methodist Church of the Ivory Coast and its 700000 members into the denomination.
4 Given current trends in the UMC—with overseas churches growing especially in Africa and US churches collectively losing about 1000 members a week—it has been estimated that Africans will make up at least 30 of the delegates at the 2012 General Conference and it is also possible that 40 of the delegates will be from outside the US One Congolese bishop has estimated that typical Sunday attendance of the UMC is higher in his country than in the entire United States.
