5 By the opening of the 2008 General Conference what was the total UMC membership?	114 million	1
6 By the opening of the 2008 General Conference what was the total UMC membership in the US?	79 million	1
7 By the opening of the 2008 General Conference what was the total UMC membership overseas?	35 million	1
1 The UMC is also a member of the Wesleyan Holiness Consortium which seeks to reconceive and promote Biblical holiness in todays Church.
2 It is also active in the World Methodist Council an interdenominational group composed of various churches in the tradition of John Wesley to promote the Gospel throughout the world.
3 On July 18 2006 delegates to the World Methodist Council voted unanimously to adopt the Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification which was approved in 1999 by the Vatican and the Lutheran World Federation.
4 Which group seeks to reconceive and promote Biblical holiness in todays church?	Wesleyan Holiness Consortium	1
5 What is an interdenominational group composed of various churches to promote the Gospel throughout the world?	World Methodist Council	2
6 When did delegates to the World Methodist Council vote to adopt the joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification?	July 18  2006	3
1 The French and Indian War 1754–1763 was the North American theater of the worldwide Seven Years War.
2 The war was fought between the colonies of British America and New France with both sides supported by military units from their parent countries of Great Britain and France as well as Native American allies.
3 At the start of the war the French North American colonies had a population of roughly 60000 European settlers compared with 2 million in the British North American colonies.
4 The outnumbered French particularly depended on the Indians.
5 Long in conflict the metropole nations declared war on each other in 1756 escalating the war from a regional affair into an intercontinental conflict.
6 When was the French and Indian War?	1754–1763	1
7 Who fought in the French and Indian war?	colonies of British America and New France	2
8 How many people were in French North American Colonies?	roughly 60 000 European settlers	3
9 How many people were in British North American Colonies?	2 million	3
1 The war was fought primarily along the frontiers between New France and the British colonies from Virginia in the South to Nova Scotia in the North.
2 It began with a dispute over control of the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers called the Forks of the Ohio and the site of the French Fort Duquesne and presentday Pittsburgh Pennsylvania.
3 The dispute erupted into violence in the Battle of Jumonville Glen in May 1754 during which Virginia militiamen under the command of 22yearold George Washington ambushed a French patrol.
4 Where was war fought?	primarily along the frontiers between New France and the British colonies	1
5 How did war start?	dispute over control of the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers  called the Forks of the Ohio	2
6 When did violence start in war?	Battle of Jumonville Glen in May 1754 	3
1 In 1755 six colonial governors in North America met with General Edward Braddock the newly arrived British Army commander and planned a fourway attack on the French.
2 None succeeded and the main effort by Braddock was a disaster he was defeated in the Battle of the Monongahela on July 9 1755 and died a few days later.
3 British operations in 1755 1756 and 1757 in the frontier areas of Pennsylvania and New York all failed due to a combination of poor management internal divisions and effective Canadian scouts French regular forces and Indian warrior allies.
4 In 1755 the British captured Fort Beauséjour on the border separating Nova Scotia from Acadia soon afterward they ordered the expulsion of the Acadians.
5 Orders for the deportation were given by William Shirley CommanderinChief North America without direction from Great Britain.
6 The Acadians both those captured in arms and those who had sworn the loyalty oath to His Britannic Majesty were expelled.
7 Native Americans were likewise driven off their land to make way for settlers from New England.
8 When did colonial governors meet with General Edward Braddock about attack on the french?	1755	1
9 How successful was initial effort by Braddock?	disaster he was defeated in the Battle of the Monongahela	2
10 Why did British operation fail in 1755 56 57?	combination of poor management  internal divisions  and effective Canadian scouts  French regular forces  and Indian warrior allies	3
11 In 1755 what fort did British capture?	Fort Beauséjour	4
12 What order did British make of French?	expulsion of the Acadians	4
1 After the disastrous 1757 British campaigns resulting in a failed expedition against Louisbourg and the Siege of Fort William Henry which was followed by Indian torture and massacres of British victims the British government fell.
2 William Pitt came to power and significantly increased British military resources in the colonies at a time when France was unwilling to risk large convoys to aid the limited forces it had in New France.
3 France concentrated its forces against Prussia and its allies in the European theatre of the war.
4 Between 1758 and 1760 the British military launched a campaign to capture the Colony of Canada.
5 They succeeded in capturing territory in surrounding colonies and ultimately Quebec.
6 Though the British were later defeated at Sainte Foy in Quebec the French ceded Canada in accordance with the 1763 treaty.
7 Who increased British military resources in colonies?	William Pitt	2
8 How much resources were French placing in North America?	unwilling to risk large convoys to aid the limited forces it had in New France	2
9 Where was France concentraing efforts?	against Prussia and its allies in the European theatre of the war	3
10 Where were British defeated in Canada?	Sainte Foy in Quebec	6
1 The outcome was one of the most significant developments in a century of AngloFrench conflict.
2 France ceded its territory east of the Mississippi to Great Britain.
3 It ceded French Louisiana west of the Mississippi River including New Orleans to its ally Spain in compensation for Spains loss to Britain of Florida Spain had ceded this to Britain in exchange for the return of Havana Cuba.
4 Frances colonial presence north of the Caribbean was reduced to the islands of Saint Pierre and Miquelon confirming Britains position as the dominant colonial power in eastern North America.
5 What territory was ceded to Britain?	territory east of the Mississippi to Great Britain	2
6 What land was ceded to Spain?	French Louisiana west of the Mississippi River including New Orleans to its ally Spain	3
7 What was the significance of British win?	confirming Britains position as the dominant colonial power in eastern North America	4
1 The conflict is known by multiple names.
2 In British America wars were often named after the sitting British monarch such as King Williams War or Queen Annes War.
3 As there had already been a King Georges War in the 1740s British colonists named the second war in King Georges reign after their opponents and it became known as the French and Indian War.
4 This traditional name continues as the standard in the United States but it obscures the fact that Indians fought on both sides of the conflict and that this was part of the Seven Years War a much larger conflict between France and Great Britain.
5 American historians generally use the traditional name or sometimes the Seven Years War.
6 Other less frequently used names for the war include the Fourth Intercolonial War and the Great War for the Empire.
7 When was King Georges war?	1740s	3
8 What is the confusion of the French and Indian war?	Indians fought on both sides of the conflict  and that this was part of the Seven Years War	4
9 What was the Seven Years War?	much larger conflict between France and Great Britain	4
10 What are other alternative names for French and Indian War?	Fourth Intercolonial War and the Great War for the Empire	6
1 In Europe the North American theater of the Seven Years War usually is not given a separate name.
2 The entire international conflict is known as the Seven Years War.
3 Seven Years refers to events in Europe from the official declaration of war in 1756 to the signing of the peace treaty in 1763.
4 These dates do not correspond with the fighting on mainland North America where the fighting between the two colonial powers was largely concluded in six years from the Battle of Jumonville Glen in 1754 to the capture of Montreal in 1760.
5 What time framd does the Seven Years War cover?	declaration of war in 1756 to the signing of the peace treaty in 1763	3
6 How long did the fighting last in Seven Years War?	six years	4
7 When was Montreal captured?	1760	4
8 What was first battle in 1754?	Battle of Jumonville Glen	4
1 The French population numbered about 75000 and was heavily concentrated along the St Lawrence River valley with some also in Acadia presentday New Brunswick and parts of Nova Scotia including Île Royale presentday Cape Breton Island.
2 Fewer lived in New Orleans Biloxi Mississippi Mobile Alabama and small settlements in the Illinois Country hugging the east side of the Mississippi River and its tributaries.
3 French fur traders and trappers traveled throughout the St Lawrence and Mississippi watersheds did business with local tribes and often married Indian women.
4 Traders married daughters of chiefs creating highranking unions.
5 What was French population in North America?	about 75 000	1
6 Where were French North Americans settled?	heavily concentrated along the St Lawrence River valley  with some also in Acadia	1
7 Where did French fur trappers travel?	St Lawrence and Mississippi watersheds  did business with local tribes  and often married Indian women	3
1 British settlers outnumbered the French 20 to 1 with a population of about 15 million ranged along the eastern coast of the continent from Nova Scotia and Newfoundland in the north to Georgia in the south.
2 Many of the older colonies had land claims that extended arbitrarily far to the west as the extent of the continent was unknown at the time their provincial charters were granted.
3 While their population centers were along the coast the settlements were growing into the interior.
4 Nova Scotia which had been captured from France in 1713 still had a significant Frenchspeaking population.
5 Britain also claimed Ruperts Land where the Hudsons Bay Company traded for furs with local tribes.
6 What was the ratio of British settler to French?	20 to 1	1
7 Where did British settlers live?	from Nova Scotia and Newfoundland in the north  to Georgia in the south	1
8 Where were populations centered in colonies?	along the coast  the settlements were growing into the interior	3
1 In between the French and the British large areas were dominated by native tribes.
2 To the north the Mikmaq and the Abenaki were engaged in Father Le Loutres War and still held sway in parts of Nova Scotia Acadia and the eastern portions of the province of Canada as well as much of presentday Maine.
3 The Iroquois Confederation dominated much of presentday Upstate New York and the Ohio Country although the latter also included Algonquianspeaking populations of Delaware and Shawnee as well as Iroquoianspeaking Mingo.
4 These tribes were formally under Iroquois rule and were limited by them in authority to make agreements.
5 In between French and British what groups controlled land?	native tribes	1
6 What tribes were in Father Le Loutres War?	Mikmaq and the Abenaki	2
7 Where did Iroquois Confederation control?	presentday Upstate New York and the Ohio Country	3
8 What rule did some native live under?	Iroquois rule  and were limited by them in authority to make agreements	4
1 Further south the Southeast interior was dominated by Siouanspeaking Catawba Muskogeespeaking Creek and Choctaw and the Iroquoianspeaking Cherokee tribes.
2 When war broke out the French used their trading connections to recruit fighters from tribes in western portions of the Great Lakes region an area not directly subject to the conflict between the French and British including the Huron Mississauga Ojibwa Winnebago and Potawatomi.
3 The British were supported in the war by the Iroquois Six Nations and also by the Cherokee – until differences sparked the AngloCherokee War in 1758.
4 In 1758 the Pennsylvania government successfully negotiated the Treaty of Easton in which a number of tribes in the Ohio Country promised neutrality in exchange for land concessions and other considerations.
5 Most of the other northern tribes sided with the French their primary trading partner and supplier of arms.
6 The Creek and Cherokee were subject to diplomatic efforts by both the French and British to gain either their support or neutrality in the conflict.
7 It was not uncommon for small bands to participate on the other side of the conflict from formally negotiated agreements as most tribes were decentralized and bands made their own decisions about warfare.
8 What are the Siouanspeaking tribes?	Catawba  Muskogeespeaking Creek and Choctaw	1
9 What areas did French recruit natives from?	western portions of the Great Lakes region	2
10 What tribes supported British?	Iroquois Six Nations  and also by the Cherokee	3
1 At the start of the war no French regular army troops were stationed in North America and few British troops.
2 New France was defended by about 3000 troupes de la marine companies of colonial regulars some of whom had significant woodland combat experience.
3 The colonial government recruited militia support when needed.
4 Most British colonies mustered local militia companies generally ill trained and available only for short periods to deal with native threats but did not have any standing forces.
5 What was Frensh military presence at start of war?	no French regular army troops were stationed in North America	1
6 How much British military was in North America at start of War?	few British troops	1
7 What was normal British defense?	mustered local militia companies  generally ill trained and available only for short periods  to deal with native threats  but did not have any standing forces	4
1 Célorons expedition force consisted of about 200 Troupes de la marine and 30 Indians.
2 The expedition covered about 3000 miles 4800 km between June and November 1749.
3 It went up the St Lawrence continued along the northern shore of Lake Ontario crossed the portage at Niagara and followed the southern shore of Lake Erie.
4 At the Chautauqua Portage near presentday Barcelona New York the expedition moved inland to the Allegheny River which it followed to the site of presentday Pittsburgh.
5 There Céloron buried lead plates engraved with the French claim to the Ohio Country.
6 Whenever he encountered British merchants or furtraders Céloron informed them of the French claims on the territory and told them to leave.
7 What was extent of Celerons expedition?	about 3 000 miles 4 800 km between June and November 1749	2
8 Who was on Celerons expedition?	200 Troupes de la marine and 30 Indians	1
9 How did Celeron handle business on trip?	British merchants or furtraders  Céloron informed them of the French claims on the territory and told them to leave	6
1 When Célorons expedition arrived at Logstown the Native Americans in the area informed Céloron that they owned the Ohio Country and that they would trade with the British regardless of the French.
2 Céloron continued south until his expedition reached the confluence of the Ohio and the Miami rivers which lay just south of the village of Pickawillany the home of the Miami chief known as Old Briton.
3 Céloron threatened Old Briton with severe consequences if he continued to trade with the British.
4 Old Briton ignored the warning.
5 Disappointed Céloron returned to Montreal in November 1749.
6 How did Natives in Logstown take Celerons information?	informed Céloron that they owned the Ohio Country and that they would trade with the British regardless of the French	1
7 Where did Old Briton call home?	village of Pickawillany	2
8 How did Celeron handle meeting with Old Briton?	threatened Old Briton with severe consequences if he continued to trade with the British	3
9 What was Old Britons response to Celeron?	ignored the warning	4
1 In his extensively detailed report Céloron wrote All I can say is that the Natives of these localities are very badly disposed towards the French and are entirely devoted to the English.
2 I dont know in what way they could be brought back.
3 Even before his return to Montreal reports on the situation in the Ohio Country were making their way to London and Paris each side proposing that action be taken.
4 William Shirley the expansionist governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay was particularly forceful stating that British colonists would not be safe as long as the French were present.
5 Conflicts between the colonies accomplished through raiding parties that included Indian allies had taken place for decades leading to a brisk trade in European colonial captives from either side.
6 How did Celeron feel about Native relations?	very badly disposed towards the French  and are entirely devoted to the English	1
7 How were leaders back in Europe feeling about news from Celeron expedition?	proposing that action be taken	3
8 How did William Shirley feel about French advancement?	British colonists would not be safe as long as the French were present	4
1 In 1749 the British government gave land to the Ohio Company of Virginia for the purpose of developing trade and settlements in the Ohio Country.
2 The grant required that it settle 100 families in the territory and construct a fort for their protection.
3 But as the territory was also claimed by Pennsylvania both colonies began pushing for action to improve their respective claims.
4 In 1750 Christopher Gist acting on behalf of both Virginia and the company explored the Ohio territory and opened negotiations with the Indian tribes at Logstown.
5 He completed the 1752 Treaty of Logstown in which the local Indians through their HalfKing Tanacharison and an Iroquois representative agreed to terms that included permission to build a strong house at the mouth of the Monongahela River the site of presentday Pittsburgh Pennsylvania.
6 By the late 17th century the Iroquois had pushed many tribes out of the Ohio Valley and kept it as hunting ground by right of conquest.
7 When did British government give land for development of Ohio Country?	1749	1
8 Who was given land by British goovernment for development of Ohio Country?	Ohio Company of Virginia	1
9 Who explored Ohio territory in 1750?	Christopher Gist	4
10 What agreement was made for trade with natives and British?	Treaty of Logstown	5
11 According to agreement between Iroquois and British where was a strong house to be built?	mouth of the Monongahela River the site of presentday Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania	5
1 The War of the Austrian Succession whose North American theater is known as King Georges War formally ended in 1748 with the signing of the Treaty of AixlaChapelle.
2 The treaty was primarily focused on resolving issues in Europe.
3 The issues of conflicting territorial claims between British and French colonies in North America were turned over to a commission to resolve but it reached no decision.
4 Frontiers from between Nova Scotia and Acadia in the north to the Ohio Country in the south were claimed by both sides.
5 The disputes also extended into the Atlantic Ocean where both powers wanted access to the rich fisheries of the Grand Banks off Newfoundland.
6 What was the North American portion of War of Austrian Succession?	King Georges War	1
7 What was the end of the War of the Austrian Succession?	1748 with the signing of the Treaty of AixlaChapelle	1
8 What issues were not addressed in the Treaty of AixlaChapelle?	conflicting territorial claims between British and French	3
9 When a commission reached no decision what happened?	Frontiers from between Nova Scotia and Acadia in the north  to the Ohio Country in the south  were claimed by both sides	4
1 On March 17 1752 the GovernorGeneral of New France Marquis de la Jonquière died and was temporarily replaced by Charles le Moyne de Longueuil.
2 His permanent replacement the Marquis Duquesne did not arrive in New France until 1752 to take over the post.
3 The continuing British activity in the Ohio territories prompted Longueuil to dispatch another expedition to the area under the command of Charles Michel de Langlade an officer in the Troupes de la Marine.
4 Langlade was given 300 men including FrenchCanadians and warriors of the Ottawa.
5 His objective was to punish the Miami people of Pickawillany for not following Célorons orders to cease trading with the British.
6 On June 21 the French war party attacked the trading centre at Pickawillany capturing three traders and killing 14 people of the Miami nation including Old Briton.
7 He was reportedly ritually cannibalized by some aboriginal members of the expedition.
8 What Governor in charge of New France died in 1752?	Marquis de la Jonquière	1
9 How many were in Langlades expedition?	300 men  including FrenchCanadians and warriors of the Ottawa	4
10 Was was the plan for Langlades mission?	punish the Miami people of Pickawillany for not following Célorons orders to cease trading with the British	5
11 What was result of French attack of trading centre?	capturing three traders and killing 14 people of the Miami nation  including Old Briton	6
1 In the spring of 1753 Paul Marin de la Malgue was given command of a 2000man force of Troupes de la Marine and Indians.
2 His orders were to protect the Kings land in the Ohio Valley from the British.
3 Marin followed the route that Céloron had mapped out four years earlier but where Céloron had limited the record of French claims to the burial of lead plates Marin constructed and garrisoned forts.
4 He first constructed Fort Presque Isle near presentday Erie Pennsylvania on Lake Eries south shore.
5 He had a road built to the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek.
6 Marin constructed a second fort at Fort Le Boeuf presentday Waterford Pennsylvania designed to guard the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek.
7 As he moved south he drove off or captured British traders alarming both the British and the Iroquois.
8 Tanaghrisson a chief of the Mingo who were remnants of Iroquois and other tribes who had been driven west by colonial expansion.
9 He intensely disliked the French whom he accused of killing and eating his father.
10 Traveling to Fort Le Boeuf he threatened the French with military action which Marin contemptuously dismissed.
11 Who took command of French in spring of 1753?	Paul Marin de la Malgue	1
12 Where did Marin build first fort?	Fort Presque Isle near presentday Erie  Pennsylvania	4
13 Where was Marins second fort constructed?	Fort Le Boeuf presentday Waterford  Pennsylvania	6
14 What was Marins orders?	protect the Kings land in the Ohio Valley from the British	2
15 What native chief travelled to French fort and threatened Marin?	Tanaghrisson	8
1 The Iroquois sent runners to the manor of William Johnson in upstate New York.
2 The British Superintendent for Indian Affairs in the New York region and beyond Johnson was known to the Iroquois as Warraghiggey meaning He who does great things.
3 He spoke their languages and had become a respected honorary member of the Iroquois Confederacy in the area.
4 In 1746 Johnson was made a colonel of the Iroquois.
5 Later he was commissioned as a colonel of the Western New York Militia.
6 They met at Albany New York with Governor Clinton and officials from some of the other American colonies.
7 Mohawk Chief Hendrick Speaker of their tribal council insisted that the British abide by their obligations and block French expansion.
8 When Clinton did not respond to his satisfaction Chief Hendrick said that the Covenant Chain a longstanding friendly relationship between the Iroquois Confederacy and the British Crown was broken.
9 What was William Johnsons role in British military?	British Superintendent for Indian Affairs in the New York region and beyond	2
10 What was William Johnsons Iroquois name?	Warraghiggey  meaning He who does great things	2
11 What title did Iroquois give Johnson?	colonel of the Iroquois	4
12 Who was the speaker of the tribal council?	Mohawk Chief Hendrick	7
1 Governor Robert Dinwiddie of Virginia was an investor in the Ohio Company which stood to lose money if the French held their claim.
2 To counter the French military presence in Ohio in October 1753 Dinwiddie ordered the 21yearold Major George Washington whose brother was another Ohio Company investor of the Virginia Regiment to warn the French to leave Virginia territory.
3 Washington left with a small party picking up along the way Jacob Van Braam as an interpreter Christopher Gist a company surveyor working in the area and a few Mingo led by Tanaghrisson.
4 On December 12 Washington and his men reached Fort Le Boeuf.
5 Governon Robert Dinwiddie had an investment in what significan company?	Ohio Company	1
6 Who did Dinwiddie order to address French in Virginia territory?	Major George Washington	2
7 Who was added to party as Washington went on the way?	Jacob Van Braam as an interpreter Christopher Gist  a company surveyor working in the area and a few Mingo led by Tanaghrisson	3
8 When did Washington reach Fort Le Boeuf?	December 12	4
1 Jacques Legardeur de SaintPierre who succeeded Marin as commander of the French forces after the latter died on October 29 invited Washington to dine with him.
2 Over dinner Washington presented SaintPierre with the letter from Dinwiddie demanding an immediate French withdrawal from the Ohio Country.
3 SaintPierre said As to the Summons you send me to retire I do not think myself obliged to obey it.
4 He told Washington that Frances claim to the region was superior to that of the British since RenéRobert Cavelier Sieur de La Salle had explored the Ohio Country nearly a century earlier.
5 Who invited Washington to dine with him?	Jacques Legardeur de SaintPierre	1
6 What letter did Washington present to  SaintPierre ?	Dinwiddie demanding an immediate French withdrawal from the Ohio Country	2
7 How did SaintPierre respond to Washington?	As to the Summons you send me to retire  I do not think myself obliged to obey it	3
8 Why did French feel they had right to Ohio claim?	Frances claim to the region was superior to that of the British	4
1 Even before Washington returned Dinwiddie had sent a company of 40 men under William Trent to that point where in the early months of 1754 they began construction of a small stockaded fort.
2 Governor Duquesne sent additional French forces under ClaudePierre Pecaudy de Contrecœur to relieve SaintPierre during the same period and Contrecœur led 500 men south from Fort Venango on April 5 1754.
3 When these forces arrived at the fort on April 16 Contrecœur generously allowed Trents small company to withdraw.
4 He purchased their construction tools to continue building what became Fort Duquesne.
5 How many men did Duquesne send to relieve  SaintPierre ?	Contrecœur led 500 men south from Fort Venango on April 5  1754	2
6 When did British begin to build fort under William Trent?	early months of 1754	1
7 What was the fort that was being built to be named?	Fort Duquesne	4
1 After Washington had returned to Williamsburg Dinwiddie ordered him to lead a larger force to assist Trent in his work.
2 While en route Washington learned of Trents retreat.
3 Since Tanaghrisson had promised support to the British Washington continued toward Fort Duquesne and met with the Mingo leader.
4 Learning of a French scouting party in the area Washington with Tanaghrisson and his party surprised the Canadians on May 28 in what became known as the Battle of Jumonville Glen.
5 They killed many of the Canadians including their commanding officer Joseph Coulon de Jumonville whose head was reportedly split open by Tanaghrisson with a tomahawk.
6 The historian Fred Anderson suggests that Tanaghrisson was acting to gain the support of the British and regain authority over his own people.
7 They had been inclined to support the French with whom they had long trading relationships.
8 One of Tanaghrissons men told Contrecoeur that Jumonville had been killed by British musket fire.
9 Upon learning of a French scounting party in the area what did Washington do?	with Tanaghrisson and his party  surprised the Canadians on May 28 in what became known as the Battle of Jumonville Glen	4
10 What were casualties of battle?	killed many of the Canadians  including their commanding officer  Joseph Coulon de Jumonville	5
11 Why was Tanaghrisson supporting British efforts?	regain authority over his own people They had been inclined to support the French  with whom they had long trading relationships	6
1 News of the two battles reached England in August.
2 After several months of negotiations the government of the Duke of Newcastle decided to send an army expedition the following year to dislodge the French.
3 They chose Major General Edward Braddock to lead the expedition.
4 Word of the British military plans leaked to France well before Braddocks departure for North America.
5 In response King Louis XV dispatched six regiments to New France under the command of Baron Dieskau in 1755.
6 The British intending to blockade French ports sent out their fleet in February 1755 but the French fleet had already sailed.
7 Admiral Edward Hawke detached a fast squadron to North America in an attempt to intercept the French.
8 What was the goal of Braddocks expedition?	dislodge the French	2
9 When did French learn about Braddocks plans?	plans leaked to France well before Braddocks departure	4
10 How did King Louis XV respond to British plans?	dispatched six regiments to New France under the command of Baron Dieskau in 1755	5
11 What were British plans against French?	blockade French ports  sent out their fleet in February 1755	6
1 An early important political response to the opening of hostilities was the convening of the Albany Congress in June and July 1754.
2 The goal of the congress was to formalize a unified front in trade and negotiations with various Indians since allegiance of the various tribes and nations was seen to be pivotal in the success in the war that was unfolding.
3 The plan that the delegates agreed to was never ratified by the colonial legislatures nor approved of by the crown.
4 Nevertheless the format of the congress and many specifics of the plan became the prototype for confederation during the War of Independence.
5 What political response was convening in JuneJuly 1754?	Albany Congress	1
6 What was the goal of congress?	formalize a unified front in trade and negotiations with various Indians  since allegiance of the various tribes and nations was seen to be pivotal	2
7 Was the plan formalized?	The plan that the delegates agreed to was never ratified by the colonial legislatures nor approved of by the crown	3
8 What was the importance of the congress?	format of the congress and many specifics of the plan became the prototype for confederation during the War of Independence	4
1 Braddock with George Washington as one of his aides led about 1500 army troops and provincial militia on an expedition in June 1755 to take Fort Duquesne.
2 The expedition was a disaster.
3 It was attacked by French and Indian soldiers ambushing them from up in trees and behind logs.
4 Braddock called for a retreat.
5 He was killed.
6 Approximately 1000 British soldiers were killed or injured.
7 The remaining 500 British troops led by George Washington retreated to Virginia.
8 Two future opponents in the American Revolutionary War Washington and Thomas Gage played key roles in organizing the retreat.
9 Who went to Fort Dusquesne in June 1755?	Braddock with George Washington as one of his aides led about 1 500 army troops	1
10 How much success did this expedition with Braddock find?	The expedition was a disaster	2
11 How many casualties did British get?	Approximately 1 000 British soldiers were killed or injured	6
12 What future Revolutionary key figures participated in this attack?	Washington and Thomas Gage	8
1 The French acquired a copy of the British war plans including the activities of Shirley and Johnson.
2 Shirleys efforts to fortify Oswego were bogged down in logistical difficulties exacerbated by Shirleys inexperience in managing large expeditions.
3 In conjunction Shirley was made aware that the French were massing for an attack on Fort Oswego in his absence when he planned to attack Fort Niagara.
4 As a response Shirley left garrisons at Oswego Fort Bull and Fort Williams the latter two located on the Oneida Carry between the Mohawk River and Wood Creek at presentday Rome New York.
5 Supplies for use in the projected attack on Niagara were cached at Fort Bull.
6 Whose activities were the French able to gain knowledge of?	Shirley and Johnson	1
7 What difficulties was Shirly having?	efforts to fortify Oswego were bogged down in logistical difficulties  exacerbated by Shirleys inexperience	2
8 Where was Shirey going to be when Fort Oswego was to be attacked?	planned to attack Fort Niagara	3
9 Who did Shirley leave at Oswego?	garrisons	4
1 Johnsons expedition was better organized than Shirleys which was noticed by New Frances governor the Marquis de Vaudreuil.
2 He had primarily been concerned about the extended supply line to the forts on the Ohio and had sent Baron Dieskau to lead the defenses at Frontenac against Shirleys expected attack.
3 When Johnson was seen as the larger threat Vaudreuil sent Dieskau to Fort St Frédéric to meet that threat.
4 Dieskau planned to attack the British encampment at Fort Edward at the upper end of navigation on the Hudson River but Johnson had strongly fortified it and Dieskaus Indian support was reluctant to attack.
5 The two forces finally met in the bloody Battle of Lake George between Fort Edward and Fort William Henry.
6 The battle ended inconclusively with both sides withdrawing from the field.
7 Johnsons advance stopped at Fort William Henry and the French withdrew to Ticonderoga Point where they began the construction of Fort Carillon later renamed Fort Ticonderoga after British capture in 1759.
8 Who was New Frances governor?	Marquis de Vaudreuil	1
9 How did Vaudreuil react when Johnson was seen as larger threat?	sent Dieskau to Fort St Frédéric to meet that threat	3
10 Who won the battle of Lake George?	inconclusively  with both sides withdrawing from the field	6
11 Where did Johnson stop?	Fort William Henry	7
12 Where was French withdrawal to?	Ticonderoga Point 	7
1 Colonel Monckton in the sole British success that year captured Fort Beauséjour in June 1755 cutting the French fortress at Louisbourg off from landbased reinforcements.
2 To cut vital supplies to Louisbourg Nova Scotias Governor Charles Lawrence ordered the deportation of the Frenchspeaking Acadian population from the area.
3 Moncktons forces including companies of Rogers Rangers forcibly removed thousands of Acadians chasing down many who resisted and sometimes committing atrocities.
4 More than any other factor the cutting off of supplies to Louisbourg led to its demise.
5 The Acadian resistance in concert with native allies including the Mikmaq was sometimes quite stiff with ongoing frontier raids against Dartmouth and Lunenburg among others.
6 Other than the campaigns to expel the Acadians ranging around the Bay of Fundy on the Petitcodiac and St John rivers and Île SaintJean the only clashes of any size were at Petitcodiac in 1755 and at Bloody Creek near Annapolis Royal in 1757.
7 Who captured Fort Beausejour?	Colonel Monckton	1
8 How were British able to cut supplies to Louisbourg?	deportation of the Frenchspeaking Acadian population from the area	2
9 What other clashes were involved in taking Louisbourg?	Petitcodiac in 1755 and at Bloody Creek near Annapolis Royal in 1757	6
1 Following the death of Braddock William Shirley assumed command of British forces in North America.
2 At a meeting in Albany in December 1755 he laid out his plans for 1756.
3 In addition to renewing the efforts to capture Niagara Crown Point and Duquesne he proposed attacks on Fort Frontenac on the north shore of Lake Ontario and an expedition through the wilderness of the Maine district and down the Chaudière River to attack the city of Quebec.
4 Bogged down by disagreements and disputes with others including William Johnson and New Yorks Governor Sir Charles Hardy Shirleys plan had little support.
5 After Braddock died who controlled North American British forces?	William Shirley	1
6 In what meeting did Shirley lay out plans for 1756?	Albany	2
7 What proposed attacks did Shirley plan?	capture Niagara  Crown Point and Duquesne  he proposed attacks on Fort Frontenac on the north shore of Lake Ontario	3
8 Where was Shirley planning an expedition?	through the wilderness of the Maine district and down the Chaudière River to attack the city of Quebec	3
1 Newcastle replaced him in January 1756 with Lord Loudoun with Major General James Abercrombie as his second in command.
2 Neither of these men had as much campaign experience as the trio of officers France sent to North America.
3 French regular army reinforcements arrived in New France in May 1756 led by Major General LouisJoseph de Montcalm and seconded by the Chevalier de Lévis and Colonel FrançoisCharles de Bourlamaque all experienced veterans from the War of the Austrian Succession.
4 During that time in Europe on May 18 1756 England formally declared war on France which expanded the war into Europe which was later to be known as the Seven Years War.
5 Who was appointed as second in command to Lor Loudoun in 1756?	Major General James Abercrombie	1
6 Who led New France reinforcements in 1756?	Major General LouisJoseph de Montcalm	3
7 When did England formally declare war on France?	May 18  1756	4
1 Governor Vaudreuil who harboured ambitions to become the French commander in chief in addition to his role as governor acted during the winter of 1756 before those reinforcements arrived.
2 Scouts had reported the weakness of the British supply chain so he ordered an attack against the forts Shirley had erected at the Oneida Carry.
3 In the March Battle of Fort Bull French forces destroyed the fort and large quantities of supplies including 45000 pounds of gunpowder.
4 They set back any British hopes for campaigns on Lake Ontario and endangered the Oswego garrison already short on supplies.
5 French forces in the Ohio valley also continued to intrigue with Indians throughout the area encouraging them to raid frontier settlements.
6 This led to ongoing alarms along the western frontiers with streams of refugees returning east to get away from the action.
7 Where was there a weakness in British supply chain?	Oneida Carry	2
8 What was the attack on the British weakness?	Battle of Fort Bull	3
9 How much gun powder was destroyed in attack?	45 000 pounds	3
10 What plans of the British did this attach on Oneida Carry set back?	hopes for campaigns on Lake Ontario  and endangered the Oswego garrison	4
1 The new British command was not in place until July.
2 When he arrived in Albany Abercrombie refused to take any significant actions until Loudoun approved them.
3 Montcalm took bold action against his inertia.
4 Building on Vaudreuils work harassing the Oswego garrison Montcalm executed a strategic feint by moving his headquarters to Ticonderoga as if to presage another attack along Lake George.
5 With Abercrombie pinned down at Albany Montcalm slipped away and led the successful attack on Oswego in August.
6 In the aftermath Montcalm and the Indians under his command disagreed about the disposition of prisoners personal effects.
7 The Europeans did not consider them prizes and prevented the Indians from stripping the prisoners of their valuables which angered the Indians.
8 Who refused to act until Loudoun approved plans?	Abercrombie	2
9 Where did Montcalm move his heaquarter to show strategic advancement?	Ticonderoga	4
10 Where did Moncalm slip away to attack left largely unprotected?	Oswego	5
11 What disagreement did Montcalm and Indians have?	disposition of prisoners personal effects	6
1 Loudoun a capable administrator but a cautious field commander planned one major operation for 1757 an attack on New Frances capital Quebec.
2 Leaving a sizable force at Fort William Henry to distract Montcalm he began organizing for the expedition to Quebec.
3 He was then ordered by William Pitt the Secretary of State responsible for the colonies to attack Louisbourg first.
4 Beset by delays of all kinds the expedition was finally ready to sail from Halifax Nova Scotia in early August.
5 In the meantime French ships had escaped the British blockade of the French coast and a fleet outnumbering the British one awaited Loudoun at Louisbourg.
6 Faced with this strength Loudoun returned to New York amid news that a massacre had occurred at Fort William Henry.
7 What was Loudouns plans for 1757?	attack on New Frances capital  Quebec	1
8 What was the purpose of Loudouns troops at Fort Henry?	to distract Montcalm	2
9 Who ordered Loudoun to attack Louisbourg?	William Pitt	3
10 Given the strength of French forces at Louisbourg what did Loudoun do?	returned to New York amid news that a massacre had occurred at Fort William Henry	6
1 French irregular forces Canadian scouts and Indians harassed Fort William Henry throughout the first half of 1757.
2 In January they ambushed British rangers near Ticonderoga.
3 In February they launched a daring raid against the position across the frozen Lake George destroying storehouses and buildings outside the main fortification.
4 In early August Montcalm and 7000 troops besieged the fort which capitulated with an agreement to withdraw under parole.
5 When the withdrawal began some of Montcalms Indian allies angered at the lost opportunity for loot attacked the British column killing and capturing several hundred men women children and slaves.
6 The aftermath of the siege may have contributed to the transmission of smallpox into remote Indian populations as some Indians were reported to have traveled from beyond the Mississippi to participate in the campaign and returned afterward having been exposed to European carriers.
7 What troops attacked Fort William Henry in early 1757?	French irregular forces Canadian scouts and Indians	1
8 On what lake did troops attack fort willima henry in winter?	Lake George	3
9 During withdrawal from Fort William Henry what did some Indian allies of French do?	attacked the British column  killing and capturing several hundred men  women  children  and slaves	5
1 Vaudreuil and Montcalm were minimally resupplied in 1758 as the British blockade of the French coastline limited French shipping.
2 The situation in New France was further exacerbated by a poor harvest in 1757 a difficult winter and the allegedly corrupt machinations of François Bigot the intendant of the territory.
3 His schemes to supply the colony inflated prices and were believed by Montcalm to line his pockets and those of his associates.
4 A massive outbreak of smallpox among western tribes led many of them to stay away from trading in 1758.
5 While many parties to the conflict blamed others the Indians blamed the French for bringing bad medicine as well as denying them prizes at Fort William Henry the disease was probably spread through the crowded conditions at William Henry after the battle.
6 Montcalm focused his meager resources on the defense of the St Lawrence with primary defenses at Carillon Quebec and Louisbourg while Vaudreuil argued unsuccessfully for a continuation of the raiding tactics that had worked quite effectively in previous years.
7 What was causing New France to have issues with resupplying?	British blockade of the French coastline limited French shipping	1
8 What other reason caused poor supply of New France from a difficult winter?	poor harvest	2
9 Where was Montcalm focusing the defense for New France?	St Lawrence  with primary defenses at Carillon  Quebec  and Louisbourg 	6
1 The British failures in North America combined with other failures in the European theater led to the fall from power of Newcastle and his principal military advisor the Duke of Cumberland.
2 Newcastle and Pitt joined in an uneasy coalition in which Pitt dominated the military planning.
3 He embarked on a plan for the 1758 campaign that was largely developed by Loudoun.
4 He had been replaced by Abercrombie as commander in chief after the failures of 1757.
5 Pitts plan called for three major offensive actions involving large numbers of regular troops supported by the provincial militias aimed at capturing the heartlands of New France.
6 Two of the expeditions were successful with Fort Duquesne and Louisbourg falling to sizable British forces.
7 What led to Newcastles fall from power as military advisor?	British failures in North America  combined with other failures in the European theater	1
8 Who did Abercrombie replace as commander in chief?	Loudoun	3
9 Pitts plan called for what attacks?	three major offensive actions involving large numbers of regular troops	5
10 How many of the Pitts planned expeditions were successful?	Two of the expeditions were successful  with Fort Duquesne and Louisbourg	6
1 The third invasion was stopped with the improbable French victory in the Battle of Carillon in which 3600 Frenchmen famously and decisively defeated Abercrombies force of 18000 regulars militia and Native American allies outside the fort the French called Carillon and the British called Ticonderoga.
2 Abercrombie saved something from the disaster when he sent John Bradstreet on an expedition that successfully destroyed Fort Frontenac including caches of supplies destined for New Frances western forts and furs destined for Europe.
3 Abercrombie was recalled and replaced by Jeffery Amherst victor at Louisbourg.
4 How many Frenchman won Battle of Carillon?	3 600	1
5 How many troops were defeated for British in BAttle of Carillon?	18 000 regulars  militia and Native American allies	1
6 What success did Abercrombie gain out of the defeat at Carillon?	sent John Bradstreet on an expedition that successfully destroyed Fort Frontenac	2
7 What impact did this loss have on Abercrombie?	recalled and replaced by Jeffery Amherst  victor at Louisbourg	3
1 In the aftermath of generally poor French results in most theaters of the Seven Years War in 1758 Frances new foreign minister the duc de Choiseul decided to focus on an invasion of Britain to draw British resources away from North America and the European mainland.
2 The invasion failed both militarily and politically as Pitt again planned significant campaigns against New France and sent funds to Britains ally on the mainland Prussia and the French Navy failed in the 1759 naval battles at Lagos and Quiberon Bay.
3 In one piece of good fortune some French supply ships managed to depart France eluding the British blockade of the French coast.
4 In 1758 what was duc de Choiseuls plan for focused military efforts?	invasion of Britain  to draw British resources away from North America and the European mainland	1
5 How successful was the French revised efforts?	The invasion failed both militarily and politically  as Pitt again planned significant campaigns against New France	2
6 What naval battles did France lose in 1759?	Lagos and Quiberon Bay	2
1 British victories continued in all theaters in the Annus Mirabilis of 1759 when they finally captured Ticonderoga James Wolfe defeated Montcalm at Quebec in a battle that claimed the lives of both commanders and victory at Fort Niagara successfully cut off the French frontier forts further to the west and south.
2 The victory was made complete in 1760 when despite losing outside Quebec City in the Battle of SainteFoy the British were able to prevent the arrival of French relief ships in the naval Battle of the Restigouche while armies marched on Montreal from three sides.
3 Who defeated Montcalm at Quebec?	James Wolfe	1
4 What was the significance of victory at Forth Niagara for British?	cut off the French frontier forts further to the west and south	1
5 What battle outside Quebec City did British lose in 1760?	Battle of SainteFoy	2
6 What victory at thwarted efforts of French relief ships	naval Battle of the Restigouche 	2.
1 In September 1760 and before any hostilities erupted Governor Vaudreuil negotiated from Montreal a capitulation with General Amherst.
2 Amherst granted Vaudreuils request that any French residents who chose to remain in the colony would be given freedom to continue worshiping in their Roman Catholic tradition continued ownership of their property and the right to remain undisturbed in their homes.
3 The British provided medical treatment for the sick and wounded French soldiers and French regular troops were returned to France aboard British ships with an agreement that they were not to serve again in the present war.
4 In Sept 1760 who negotiated a capitulation from Montreal?	Governor Vaudreuil	1
5 What were requests made to British?	freedom to continue worshiping in their Roman Catholic tradition  continued ownership of their property 	2
6 What British General negotiated at Montreal?	General Amherst	1
1 The war in North America officially ended with the signing of the Treaty of Paris on 10 February 1763 and war in the European theatre of the Seven Years War was settled by the Treaty of Hubertusburg on 15 February 1763.
2 The British offered France the choice of surrendering either its continental North American possessions east of the Mississippi or the Caribbean islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique which had been occupied by the British.
3 France chose to cede the former but was able to negotiate the retention of Saint Pierre and Miquelon two small islands in the Gulf of St Lawrence along with fishing rights in the area.
4 They viewed the economic value of the Caribbean islands sugar cane to be greater and easier to defend than the furs from the continent.
5 The contemporaneous French philosopher Voltaire referred to Canada disparagingly as nothing more than a few acres of snow.
6 The British for their part were happy to take New France as defence of their North American colonies would no longer be an issue and also because they already had ample places from which to obtain sugar.
7 Spain which traded Florida to Britain to regain Cuba also gained Louisiana including New Orleans from France in compensation for its losses.
8 Great Britain and Spain also agreed that navigation on the Mississippi River was to be open to vessels of all nations.
9 When did the North American French and Indian War end?	signing of the Treaty of Paris on 10 February 1763	1
10 When was the European portion of the Seven Years War complete?	Treaty of Hubertusburg on 15 February 1763	1
11 What choice did French have for surrendering land?	continental North American possessions east of the Mississippi or the Caribbean islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique	2
12 Why did France choose to give up continental lands?	value of the Caribbean islands sugar cane to be greater and easier to defend than the furs from the continent	4
1 Britain gained control of French Canada and Acadia colonies containing approximately 80000 primarily Frenchspeaking Roman Catholic residents.
2 The deportation of Acadians beginning in 1755 resulted in land made available to migrants from Europe and the colonies further south.
3 The British resettled many Acadians throughout its North American provinces but many went to France and some went to New Orleans which they had expected to remain French.
4 Some were sent to colonize places as diverse as French Guiana and the Falkland Islands these latter efforts were unsuccessful.
5 Others migrated to places like SaintDomingue and fled to New Orleans after the Haitian Revolution.
6 The Louisiana population contributed to the founding of the modern Cajun population.
7 The French word Acadien evolved to Cadien then to Cajun.
8 How many French colonists were gained by British?	80 000	1
9 When was the deportation of Acadians?	1755	2
10 Where did British resettle many Acadians?	throughout its North American provinces	3
11 Although some Acadians went to France and other destiantions what North American city did many move to?	New Orleans	5
1 Following the treaty King George III issued the Royal Proclamation of 1763 on October 7 1763 which outlined the division and administration of the newly conquered territory and to some extent continues to govern relations between the government of modern Canada and the First Nations.
2 Included in its provisions was the reservation of lands west of the Appalachian Mountains to its Indian population a demarcation that was at best a temporary impediment to a rising tide of westwardbound settlers.
3 The proclamation also contained provisions that prevented civic participation by the Roman Catholic Canadians.
4 When accommodations were made in the Quebec Act in 1774 to address this and other issues religious concerns were raised in the largely Protestant Thirteen Colonies over the advance of popery the Act maintained French Civil law including the seigneurial system a medieval code soon to be removed from France within a generation by the French Revolution.
5 Who issued the Royal Proclamation of 1763?	King George III	1
6 What was the objective of Royal Proclamation of 1763?	outlined the division and administration of the newly conquered territory	1
7 What lands were reserved for natives?	west of the Appalachian Mountains	2
1 For many native populations the elimination of French power in North America meant the disappearance of a strong ally and counterweight to British expansion leading to their ultimate dispossession.
2 The Ohio Country was particularly vulnerable to legal and illegal settlement due to the construction of military roads to the area by Braddock and Forbes.
3 Although the Spanish takeover of the Louisiana territory which was not completed until 1769 had modest repercussions the British takeover of Spanish Florida resulted in the westward migration of tribes that did not want to do business with the British and a rise in tensions between the Choctaw and the Creek historic enemies whose divisions the British at times exploited.
4 The change of control in Florida also prompted most of its Spanish Catholic population to leave.
5 Most went to Cuba including the entire governmental records from St Augustine although some Christianized Yamasee were resettled to the coast of Mexico.
6 Where did many Spanish Catholic move after British takeover in Florida?	Most went to Cuba 	5
7 What made Ohio Country vulnerable?	military roads to the area by Braddock and Forbes	2
8 When was Spanish takeover of Louisiana Territory complete?	1769	3
9 What natives were displaced by British takeover in Florida?	Choctaw and the Creek	3
10 What did the loss mean to France?	disappearance of a strong ally and counterweight to British expansion  leading to their ultimate dispossession	1
1 Philosophers in antiquity used the concept of force in the study of stationary and moving objects and simple machines but thinkers such as Aristotle and Archimedes retained fundamental errors in understanding force.
2 In part this was due to an incomplete understanding of the sometimes nonobvious force of friction and a consequently inadequate view of the nature of natural motion.
3 A fundamental error was the belief that a force is required to maintain motion even at a constant velocity.
4 Most of the previous misunderstandings about motion and force were eventually corrected by Galileo Galilei and Sir Isaac Newton.
5 With his mathematical insight Sir Isaac Newton formulated laws of motion that were not improvedon for nearly three hundred years.
6 By the early 20th century Einstein developed a theory of relativity that correctly predicted the action of forces on objects with increasing momenta near the speed of light and also provided insight into the forces produced by gravitation and inertia.
7 What concept did philosophers in antiquity use to study simple machines?	force	1
8 What was the belief that maintaining motion required force?	fundamental error	3
9 Who had mathmatical insite?	Sir Isaac Newton	5
10 How long did it take to improve on Sir Isaac Newtons laws of motion?	nearly three hundred years	5
11 Who develped the theory of relativity?	Einstein	6
1 With modern insights into quantum mechanics and technology that can accelerate particles close to the speed of light particle physics has devised a Standard Model to describe forces between particles smaller than atoms.
2 The Standard Model predicts that exchanged particles called gauge bosons are the fundamental means by which forces are emitted and absorbed.
3 Only four main interactions are known in order of decreasing strength they are strong electromagnetic weak and gravitational.
4 2–1079 Highenergy particle physics observations made during the 1970s and 1980s confirmed that the weak and electromagnetic forces are expressions of a more fundamental electroweak interaction.
5 What has partical physics made to describe subatomic forces?	Standard Model	1
6 What are the exchanged particles predicted by the standard Model?	gauge bosons	2
7 What is the strongest main interaction?	strong	3
8 What is the weakest main interaction?	gravitational	3
9 What are weak and electromatic forces expressions of?	electroweak interaction	4
1 Aristotle provided a philosophical discussion of the concept of a force as an integral part of Aristotelian cosmology.
2 In Aristotles view the terrestrial sphere contained four elements that come to rest at different natural places therein.
3 Aristotle believed that motionless objects on Earth those composed mostly of the elements earth and water to be in their natural place on the ground and that they will stay that way if left alone.
4 He distinguished between the innate tendency of objects to find their natural place eg for heavy bodies to fall which led to natural motion and unnatural or forced motion which required continued application of a force.
5 This theory based on the everyday experience of how objects move such as the constant application of a force needed to keep a cart moving had conceptual trouble accounting for the behavior of projectiles such as the flight of arrows.
6 The place where the archer moves the projectile was at the start of the flight and while the projectile sailed through the air no discernible efficient cause acts on it.
7 Aristotle was aware of this problem and proposed that the air displaced through the projectiles path carries the projectile to its target.
8 This explanation demands a continuum like air for change of place in general.
9 Who provided a philosophical discussion of force?	Aristotle	1
10 What was the concept of force an integral part of?	Aristotelian cosmology	1
11 How many elements did Aristotle believe the terrestrial sphere to be made up of?	four	2
12 Where did Aristotle believe the natural place for earth and water elements?	on the ground	3
13 What did Aristotle refer to forced motion as?	unnatural	4
1 The shortcomings of Aristotelian physics would not be fully corrected until the 17th century work of Galileo Galilei who was influenced by the late Medieval idea that objects in forced motion carried an innate force of impetus.
2 Galileo constructed an experiment in which stones and cannonballs were both rolled down an incline to disprove the Aristotelian theory of motion early in the 17th century.
3 He showed that the bodies were accelerated by gravity to an extent that was independent of their mass and argued that objects retain their velocity unless acted on by a force for example friction.
4 When were the shortcomings of Aristotles physics overcome?	17th century	1
5 Whose work  corrected Aristotles physics in the seventeenth century?	Galileo Galilei	1
6 What did objects in forced motion contain according to the late Medieval idea that influence Aristotle?	impetus	1
7 Who experimented by rolling stones and canonballs down a steep incline?	Galileo	2
8 What force acted on bodies to retard their velocity?	friction	3
1 Newtons First Law of Motion states that objects continue to move in a state of constant velocity unless acted upon by an external net force or resultant force.
2 This law is an extension of Galileos insight that constant velocity was associated with a lack of net force see a more detailed description of this below.
3 Newton proposed that every object with mass has an innate inertia that functions as the fundamental equilibrium natural state in place of the Aristotelian idea of the natural state of rest.
4 That is the first law contradicts the intuitive Aristotelian belief that a net force is required to keep an object moving with constant velocity.
5 By making rest physically indistinguishable from nonzero constant velocity Newtons First Law directly connects inertia with the concept of relative velocities.
6 Specifically in systems where objects are moving with different velocities it is impossible to determine which object is in motion and which object is at rest.
7 In other words to phrase matters more technically the laws of physics are the same in every inertial frame of reference that is in all frames related by a Galilean transformation.
8 Whose First Law of Motion says that unless acted upon be forces objects would continue to move at a constant velocity?	Newton	1
9 What insight of Galileo was associated with constant velocity?	lack of net force	2
10 Who proposed that innate intertial is the natural state of objects?	Newton	3
11 What law connects relative velocities with inertia?	Newtons First	5
12 What are the laws of physics of Galileo in reference to objest in motion and rest?	the same	7
1 For instance while traveling in a moving vehicle at a constant velocity the laws of physics do not change from being at rest.
2 A person can throw a ball straight up in the air and catch it as it falls down without worrying about applying a force in the direction the vehicle is moving.
3 This is true even though another person who is observing the moving vehicle pass by also observes the ball follow a curving parabolic path in the same direction as the motion of the vehicle.
4 It is the inertia of the ball associated with its constant velocity in the direction of the vehicles motion that ensures the ball continues to move forward even as it is thrown up and falls back down.
5 From the perspective of the person in the car the vehicle and everything inside of it is at rest It is the outside world that is moving with a constant speed in the opposite direction.
6 Since there is no experiment that can distinguish whether it is the vehicle that is at rest or the outside world that is at rest the two situations are considered to be physically indistinguishable.
7 Inertia therefore applies equally well to constant velocity motion as it does to rest.
8 What doesnt change from being at rest to movement at a constant velocity?	laws of physics	1
9 What path does a ball thrown up and down in a moving vehicle take when seen by an outside observer?	parabolic	3
10 What sate are things inside of a moving vehicle as seen by a  person inside the vehicle?	at rest	5
11 What applies to equally to constant velocity motion as it does to rest	Inertia 	7.
1 The concept of inertia can be further generalized to explain the tendency of objects to continue in many different forms of constant motion even those that are not strictly constant velocity.
2 The rotational inertia of planet Earth is what fixes the constancy of the length of a day and the length of a year.
3 Albert Einstein extended the principle of inertia further when he explained that reference frames subject to constant acceleration such as those freefalling toward a gravitating object were physically equivalent to inertial reference frames.
4 This is why for example astronauts experience weightlessness when in freefall orbit around the Earth and why Newtons Laws of Motion are more easily discernible in such environments.
5 If an astronaut places an object with mass in midair next to himself it will remain stationary with respect to the astronaut due to its inertia.
6 This is the same thing that would occur if the astronaut and the object were in intergalactic space with no net force of gravity acting on their shared reference frame.
7 This principle of equivalence was one of the foundational underpinnings for the development of the general theory of relativity.
8 What concept explains why objects continue in constant motion?	inertia	1
9 What makes day length constant on Earth?	rotational inertia of planet	2
10 Who explained that inertial reference frames equaled reference frames subject to constant acceleration?	Albert Einstein	3
11 What do astronaughts experience while in freefall?	weightlessness	4
12 What was the basis mentioned for the develpment of the general theory of relativity?	principle of equivalence	7
1 Newtons Second Law asserts the direct proportionality of acceleration to force and the inverse proportionality of acceleration to mass.
2 Accelerations can be defined through kinematic measurements.
3 However while kinematics are welldescribed through reference frame analysis in advanced physics there are still deep questions that remain as to what is the proper definition of mass.
4 General relativity offers an equivalence between spacetime and mass but lacking a coherent theory of quantum gravity it is unclear as to how or whether this connection is relevant on microscales.
5 With some justification Newtons second law can be taken as a quantitative definition of mass by writing the law as an equality the relative units of force and mass then are fixed.
6 What describes the proportionality of acceleration to force and mass?	Newtons Second Law	1
7 What kind of measurements define accelerlations?	kinematic	2
8 What has an equivalence between mass and spacetime?	General relativity	4
9 What is missing a theory on quantum gravity?	General relativity	4
10 In Newtons second law what are the units of mass and force in relation to microscales?	fixed	5
1 Newtons Third Law is a result of applying symmetry to situations where forces can be attributed to the presence of different objects.
2 The third law means that all forces are interactions between different bodiesNote 3 and thus that there is no such thing as a unidirectional force or a force that acts on only one body.
3 Whenever a first body exerts a force F on a second body the second body exerts a force −F on the first body.
4 F and −F are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.
5 This law is sometimes referred to as the actionreaction law with F called the action and −F the reaction.
6 The action and the reaction are simultaneous.
7 When forces are from the presence of differnet objects what law gives symmetry?	Newtons Third	1
8 What law staes that forces are interactions between bodies?	Newtons Third	1
9 What kind of force does not exist under Newtons third law?	unidirectional	2
10 What is the equality of forces between two objects exerting force on each other?	magnitude	4
1 This means that in a closed system of particles there are no internal forces that are unbalanced.
2 That is the actionreaction force shared between any two objects in a closed system will not cause the center of mass of the system to accelerate.
3 The constituent objects only accelerate with respect to each other the system itself remains unaccelerated.
4 Alternatively if an external force acts on the system then the center of mass will experience an acceleration proportional to the magnitude of the external force divided by the mass of the system.
5 191.
6 What experiences acceleration when external force is applied to a system?	center of mass	4
7 In what kind of system of particles are there no unbalanced iinternal forces?	closed	1
8 What is the magnitude of force divided by when external force is added?	mass of the system	4
1 Since forces are perceived as pushes or pulls this can provide an intuitive understanding for describing forces.
2 As with other physical concepts eg.
3 temperature the intuitive understanding of forces is quantified using precise operational definitions that are consistent with direct observations and compared to a standard measurement scale.
4 Through experimentation it is determined that laboratory measurements of forces are fully consistent with the conceptual definition of force offered by Newtonian mechanics.
5 What does pushing and pulling perceptions provide for describing forces?	intuitive understanding	1
6 What is used to quantify the intuitive undestanding of forces?	standard measurement scale	3
7 What offers a conceptual definition of force?	Newtonian mechanics	4
8 How are laboratory measurements of forces determined?	experimentation	4
1 Forces act in a particular direction and have sizes dependent upon how strong the push or pull is.
2 Because of these characteristics forces are classified as vector quantities.
3 This means that forces follow a different set of mathematical rules than physical quantities that do not have direction denoted scalar quantities.
4 For example when determining what happens when two forces act on the same object it is necessary to know both the magnitude and the direction of both forces to calculate the result.
5 If both of these pieces of information are not known for each force the situation is ambiguous.
6 For example if you know that two people are pulling on the same rope with known magnitudes of force but you do not know which direction either person is pulling it is impossible to determine what the acceleration of the rope will be.
7 The two people could be pulling against each other as in tug of war or the two people could be pulling in the same direction.
8 In this simple onedimensional example without knowing the direction of the forces it is impossible to decide whether the net force is the result of adding the two force magnitudes or subtracting one from the other.
9 Associating forces with vectors avoids such problems.
10 How are forces classified with regard to push and pull strengt?	vector quantities	2
11 What physical quantities do not have direction?	denoted scalar quantities	3
12 How do you avoid problems when determining forces involved on an object from two or more sources?	Associating forces with vectors	9
13 If you do not know both magnitude and direction of two forces on an object what would you call that situation?	ambiguous	5
14 How do you determine the acceleration of a rope when two people are pulling it?	Associating forces with vectors	9
1 Historically forces were first quantitatively investigated in conditions of static equilibrium where several forces canceled each other out.
2 Such experiments demonstrate the crucial properties that forces are additive vector quantities they have magnitude and direction.
3 When two forces act on a point particle the resulting force the resultant also called the net force can be determined by following the parallelogram rule of vector addition the addition of two vectors represented by sides of a parallelogram gives an equivalent resultant vector that is equal in magnitude and direction to the transversal of the parallelogram.
4 The magnitude of the resultant varies from the difference of the magnitudes of the two forces to their sum depending on the angle between their lines of action.
5 However if the forces are acting on an extended body their respective lines of application must also be specified in order to account for their effects on the motion of the body.
6 In what conditions were forces first measured historically?	static equilibrium	1
7 What do forces have with regard to additive quantities?	magnitude and direction	2
8 What is the resultant force called when two forces act on a particle?	net force	3
9 When forces are acting on an extended body what do you need to account for motion effects?	respective lines of application	5
10 What geometric shape is used in equations to determine net force?	parallelogram	3
1 As well as being added forces can also be resolved into independent components at right angles to each other.
2 A horizontal force pointing northeast can therefore be split into two forces one pointing north and one pointing east.
3 Summing these component forces using vector addition yields the original force.
4 Resolving force vectors into components of a set of basis vectors is often a more mathematically clean way to describe forces than using magnitudes and directions.
5 This is because for orthogonal components the components of the vector sum are uniquely determined by the scalar addition of the components of the individual vectors.
6 Orthogonal components are independent of each other because forces acting at ninety degrees to each other have no effect on the magnitude or direction of the other.
7 Choosing a set of orthogonal basis vectors is often done by considering what set of basis vectors will make the mathematics most convenient.
8 Choosing a basis vector that is in the same direction as one of the forces is desirable since that force would then have only one nonzero component.
9 Orthogonal force vectors can be threedimensional with the third component being at rightangles to the other two.
10 Whwn forces are at right ngles to each other what can they be broken down to?	independent components	1
11 If a force is pointing horizontally to the northeast how many forces can you split the force into?	two	2
12 What do you get when you figure the sum of forces with vector addition?	the original force	3
13 What are the independant components of a vector sum that has been determined by scalar addition of individual vectors?	orthogonal	5
14 What can orthogonal forces be when there are three components with two at right angles to each other?	threedimensional	9
1 Pushing against an object on a frictional surface can result in a situation where the object does not move because the applied force is opposed by static friction generated between the object and the table surface.
2 For a situation with no movement the static friction force exactly balances the applied force resulting in no acceleration.
3 The static friction increases or decreases in response to the applied force up to an upper limit determined by the characteristics of the contact between the surface and the object.
4 What can keep an object from moving when it is being pushed on a surface?	static friction	1
5 What is generated between a surface and an object that is being pushed?	static friction	1
6 Static friction balances what force when there is no movement of an object on a surface?	applied	2
7 What makes static friction go up or down in responce to contact characteristics between an object and the surface it is on?	applied force	3
1 A static equilibrium between two forces is the most usual way of measuring forces using simple devices such as weighing scales and spring balances.
2 For example an object suspended on a vertical spring scale experiences the force of gravity acting on the object balanced by a force applied by the spring reaction force which equals the objects weight.
3 Using such tools some quantitative force laws were discovered that the force of gravity is proportional to volume for objects of constant density widely exploited for millennia to define standard weights Archimedes principle for buoyancy Archimedes analysis of the lever Boyles law for gas pressure and Hookes law for springs.
4 These were all formulated and experimentally verified before Isaac Newton expounded his Three Laws of Motion.
5 What can scales and spring balances measure between two forces by using static equilibrium?	forces	1
6 What force acts on an object suspended on a spring scale in addition to gravity?	spring reaction force	2
7 What equals the spring reaction force on an object suspended on a spring reaction scale?	gravity	2
8 Objects of constant density are proportional to volume by what force to define standard weights?	gravity	3
9 Who expounded the Three Laws of Motion?	Isaac Newton	4
1 Dynamic equilibrium was first described by Galileo who noticed that certain assumptions of Aristotelian physics were contradicted by observations and logic.
2 Galileo realized that simple velocity addition demands that the concept of an absolute rest frame did not exist.
3 Galileo concluded that motion in a constant velocity was completely equivalent to rest.
4 This was contrary to Aristotles notion of a natural state of rest that objects with mass naturally approached.
5 Simple experiments showed that Galileos understanding of the equivalence of constant velocity and rest were correct.
6 For example if a mariner dropped a cannonball from the crows nest of a ship moving at a constant velocity Aristotelian physics would have the cannonball fall straight down while the ship moved beneath it.
7 Thus in an Aristotelian universe the falling cannonball would land behind the foot of the mast of a moving ship.
8 However when this experiment is actually conducted the cannonball always falls at the foot of the mast as if the cannonball knows to travel with the ship despite being separated from it.
9 Since there is no forward horizontal force being applied on the cannonball as it falls the only conclusion left is that the cannonball continues to move with the same velocity as the boat as it falls.
10 Thus no force is required to keep the cannonball moving at the constant forward velocity.
11 Who first described dynamic equilibrium?	Galileo	1
12 What does motion at a constant velocity equal?	rest	3
13 Who had the idea of a natural state for objects at rest?	Galileo	3
14 Where will a canonball dropped from the crows nest of a ship land according to Aristotle?	behind the foot of the mast	7
15 Where does a canonball dropped from the crows nest of a ship actually land?	foot of the mast	8
1 A simple case of dynamic equilibrium occurs in constant velocity motion across a surface with kinetic friction.
2 In such a situation a force is applied in the direction of motion while the kinetic friction force exactly opposes the applied force.
3 This results in zero net force but since the object started with a nonzero velocity it continues to move with a nonzero velocity.
4 Aristotle misinterpreted this motion as being caused by the applied force.
5 However when kinetic friction is taken into consideration it is clear that there is no net force causing constant velocity motion.
6 What occurs when traveling across a surface at a constant velocity with regard to friction?	dynamic equilibrium	1
7 What directly opposes the force applied to move an object across a surface?	kinetic friction force	2
8 What has to accounted for that causes no net force being the cause of constant velocity motion?	kinetic friction	5
9 Who thought that applied force caused movement of an object regardless of nonzero velocity?	Aristotle	4
1 The notion force keeps its meaning in quantum mechanics though one is now dealing with operators instead of classical variables and though the physics is now described by the Schrödinger equation instead of Newtonian equations.
2 This has the consequence that the results of a measurement are now sometimes quantized ie.
3 they appear in discrete portions.
4 This is of course difficult to imagine in the context of forces.
5 However the potentials Vxyz or fields from which the forces generally can be derived are treated similar to classical position variables ie .
6 What equation currently decribes the physics of force	Schrödinger 	1.
7 What equation desribed the physics of force before the current Schrodinger equation?	Newtonian	1
