8 How are the forces derived from fields treated similarly to?	classical position variables	5
9 What type of measurements result under Schrodinger equations when using operators instead of Newtonian variables?	quantized	2
10 What notion keeps its meaning through both Netonian and Schrodinger physics equations?	force	1
1 However already in quantum mechanics there is one caveat namely the particles acting onto each other do not only possess the spatial variable but also a discrete intrinsic angular momentumlike variable called the spin and there is the Pauli principle relating the space and the spin variables.
2 Depending on the value of the spin identical particles split into two different classes fermions and bosons.
3 If two identical fermions eg.
4 electrons have a symmetric spin function eg.
5 parallel spins the spatial variables must be antisymmetric ie.
6 they exclude each other from their places much as if there was a repulsive force and vice versa ie.
7 for antiparallel spins the position variables must be symmetric ie.
8 the apparent force must be attractive.
9 Thus in the case of two fermions there is a strictly negative correlation between spatial and spin variables whereas for two bosons eg.
10 quanta of electromagnetic waves photons the correlation is strictly positive.
11 What is the intrisic angular variable called when particles act upon one another?	spin	1
12 What is the principle about relating spin and space variables?	Pauli	1
13 What value does the seperating into fermions and bosons depend?	spin	2
14 If the apparant force of two fermions is attractive what is the spin function?	antiparallel	7
15 If the apparant force of two fermions is repulsive what is the spin function?	parallel	5
1 In modern particle physics forces and the acceleration of particles are explained as a mathematical byproduct of exchange of momentumcarrying gauge bosons.
2 With the development of quantum field theory and general relativity it was realized that force is a redundant concept arising from conservation of momentum 4momentum in relativity and momentum of virtual particles in quantum electrodynamics.
3 The conservation of momentum can be directly derived from the homogeneity or symmetry of space and so is usually considered more fundamental than the concept of a force.
4 Thus the currently known fundamental forces are considered more accurately to be fundamental interactions.
5 199–128 When particle A emits creates or absorbs annihilates virtual particle B a momentum conservation results in recoil of particle A making impression of repulsion or attraction between particles A A exchanging by B.
6 This description applies to all forces arising from fundamental interactions.
7 While sophisticated mathematical descriptions are needed to predict in full detail the accurate result of such interactions there is a conceptually simple way to describe such interactions through the use of Feynman diagrams.
8 In a Feynman diagram each matter particle is represented as a straight line see world line traveling through time which normally increases up or to the right in the diagram.
9 Matter and antimatter particles are identical except for their direction of propagation through the Feynman diagram.
10 World lines of particles intersect at interaction vertices and the Feynman diagram represents any force arising from an interaction as occurring at the vertex with an associated instantaneous change in the direction of the particle world lines.
11 Gauge bosons are emitted away from the vertex as wavy lines and in the case of virtual particle exchange are absorbed at an adjacent vertex.
12 How are the particle forces and accelerations explained as by gauge bosons exchange?	mathematical byproduct	1
13 What is the redundant concept coming from momentum conservation?	force	2
14 What is more fundamental than force in quanton field theory?	conservation of momentum	3
15 What diagrams are used to simplify particle interactions on a fundamental level?	Feynman	7
16 Matter particles are shown as what kind of lines in a Feynman diagram?	straight	8
1 All of the forces in the universe are based on four fundamental interactions.
2 The strong and weak forces are nuclear forces that act only at very short distances and are responsible for the interactions between subatomic particles including nucleons and compound nuclei.
3 The electromagnetic force acts between electric charges and the gravitational force acts between masses.
4 All other forces in nature derive from these four fundamental interactions.
5 For example friction is a manifestation of the electromagnetic force acting between the atoms of two surfaces and the Pauli exclusion principle which does not permit atoms to pass through each other.
6 Similarly the forces in springs modeled by Hookes law are the result of electromagnetic forces and the Exclusion Principle acting together to return an object to its equilibrium position.
7 Centrifugal forces are acceleration forces that arise simply from the acceleration of rotating frames of reference.
8 1211359.
9 How many interactions are all of the universal forces based on?	four	1
10 What nuclear forces only act at short distances?	strong and weak	2
11 What force acts between electric charges?	electromagnetic	3
12 What do gravitational forces act between?	masses	3
13 What prohibits atoms from passing through each other?	Pauli exclusion principle	5
1 The development of fundamental theories for forces proceeded along the lines of unification of disparate ideas.
2 For example Isaac Newton unified the force responsible for objects falling at the surface of the Earth with the force responsible for the orbits of celestial mechanics in his universal theory of gravitation.
3 Michael Faraday and James Clerk Maxwell demonstrated that electric and magnetic forces were unified through one consistent theory of electromagnetism.
4 In the 20th century the development of quantum mechanics led to a modern understanding that the first three fundamental forces all except gravity are manifestations of matter fermions interacting by exchanging virtual particles called gauge bosons.
5 This standard model of particle physics posits a similarity between the forces and led scientists to predict the unification of the weak and electromagnetic forces in electroweak theory subsequently confirmed by observation.
6 The complete formulation of the standard model predicts an as yet unobserved Higgs mechanism but observations such as neutrino oscillations indicate that the standard model is incomplete.
7 A Grand Unified Theory allowing for the combination of the electroweak interaction with the strong force is held out as a possibility with candidate theories such as supersymmetry proposed to accommodate some of the outstanding unsolved problems in physics.
8 Physicists are still attempting to develop selfconsistent unification models that would combine all four fundamental interactions into a theory of everything.
9 Einstein tried and failed at this endeavor but currently the most popular approach to answering this question is string theory.
10 212–219.
11 Who formed the universal theory of gravitation?	Isaac Newton	2
12 In what century was quantum mechanics made?	20th	4
13 What kind of selfconsistent models are physicists trying to make that would create a theory of everything?	unification	8
14 What type of physics model did Einstein fail to make?	selfconsistent unification	8
1 What we now call gravity was not identified as a universal force until the work of Isaac Newton.
2 Before Newton the tendency for objects to fall towards the Earth was not understood to be related to the motions of celestial objects.
3 Galileo was instrumental in describing the characteristics of falling objects by determining that the acceleration of every object in freefall was constant and independent of the mass of the object.
4 Today this acceleration due to gravity towards the surface of the Earth is usually designated as  and has a magnitude of about 981 meters per second squared this measurement is taken from sea level and may vary depending on location and points toward the center of the Earth.
5 This observation means that the force of gravity on an object at the Earths surface is directly proportional to the objects mass.
6 Thus an object that has a mass of  will experience a force.
7 Who identified gravity as a force?	Isaac Newton	1
8 Who came up with the concept that falling objects fell at the same speed regardless of weight?	Galileo	3
9 How fast do objects fall on Earth?	about 981 meters per second squared	4
10 Where was the measurment for the standard gravity on Earth taken?	sea level	4
11 What is an objects mass proportional to at the surface of the Earth?	force of gravity	5
1 Newton came to realize that the effects of gravity might be observed in different ways at larger distances.
2 In particular Newton determined that the acceleration of the Moon around the Earth could be ascribed to the same force of gravity if the acceleration due to gravity decreased as an inverse square law.
3 Further Newton realized that the acceleration due to gravity is proportional to the mass of the attracting body.
4 Combining these ideas gives a formula that relates the mass  and the radius  of the Earth to the gravitational acceleration.
5 How might gravity effects be observed differently according to Newton?	at larger distances	1
6 What could be attributed to gravity acceleration around the Earth?	the Moon	2
7 What is gravitational acceleration proportional to?	mass	3
8 What is included along with gravitational acceration and mass of the Earth in a formula about rotation about the Earth?	radius  of the Earth	4

1 It was only the orbit of the planet Mercury that Newtons Law of Gravitation seemed not to fully explain.
2 Some astrophysicists predicted the existence of another planet Vulcan that would explain the discrepancies however despite some early indications no such planet could be found.
3 When Albert Einstein formulated his theory of general relativity GR he turned his attention to the problem of Mercurys orbit and found that his theory added a correction which could account for the discrepancy.
4 This was the first time that Newtons Theory of Gravity had been shown to be less correct than an alternative.
5 What planet seemed to buck Newtons gravitational laws?	Mercury	1

1 Since then and so far general relativity has been acknowledged as the theory that best explains gravity.
2 In GR gravitation is not viewed as a force but rather objects moving freely in gravitational fields travel under their own inertia in straight lines through curved spacetime – defined as the shortest spacetime path between two spacetime events.
3 From the perspective of the object all motion occurs as if there were no gravitation whatsoever.
4 It is only when observing the motion in a global sense that the curvature of spacetime can be observed and the force is inferred from the objects curved path.
5 Thus the straight line path in spacetime is seen as a curved line in space and it is called the ballistic trajectory of the object.
6 For example a basketball thrown from the ground moves in a parabola as it is in a uniform gravitational field.
7 Its spacetime trajectory when the extra ct dimension is added is almost a straight line slightly curved with the radius of curvature of the order of few lightyears.
8 The time derivative of the changing momentum of the object is what we label as gravitational force.
9 What theory best explains gravity?	general relativity	1
10 What spacetime path is seen as a curved line in space?	ballistic trajectory	5
11 What is the derivative of an objects changing momentum called?	gravitational force	8
12 In what sense must you be observing the curvature of spacetime?	global	4
1 Through combining the definition of electric current as the time rate of change of electric charge a rule of vector multiplication called Lorentzs Law describes the force on a charge moving in a magnetic field.
2 The connection between electricity and magnetism allows for the description of a unified electromagnetic force that acts on a charge.
3 This force can be written as a sum of the electrostatic force due to the electric field and the magnetic force due to the magnetic field.
4 Fully stated this is the law.
5 What is  the time rate of change of electric charge?	electric current	1
6 What magnetic and electric force acts on a charge?	unified electromagnetic	2
7 What is the law named that defines a charge moving through a magnetic field?	Lorentzs Law	1
8 Whatare the electrostatic and magnetic force awritten as the sum of?	electrostatic force	3
1 The origin of electric and magnetic fields would not be fully explained until 1864 when James Clerk Maxwell unified a number of earlier theories into a set of 20 scalar equations which were later reformulated into 4 vector equations by Oliver Heaviside and Josiah Willard Gibbs.
2 These Maxwell Equations fully described the sources of the fields as being stationary and moving charges and the interactions of the fields themselves.
3 This led Maxwell to discover that electric and magnetic fields could be selfgenerating through a wave that traveled at a speed that he calculated to be the speed of light.
4 This insight united the nascent fields of electromagnetic theory with optics and led directly to a complete description of the electromagnetic spectrum.
5 Who first fully explained the origins of magnetic and electric fields?	James Clerk Maxwell	1
6 When did the origins of magnetic and electric fields occur?	1864	1
7 How many scalar equations were formed into a set by James Maxwell?	20	1
8 How many vector equations did Heaviside and Gibbs reformilate Maxwells 20 scalar equtions into?	4	1
9 Who discovered that magnetic and electric could selfgenerate?	Maxwell	3
1 However attempting to reconcile electromagnetic theory with two observations the photoelectric effect and the nonexistence of the ultraviolet catastrophe proved troublesome.
2 Through the work of leading theoretical physicists a new theory of electromagnetism was developed using quantum mechanics.
3 This final modification to electromagnetic theory ultimately led to quantum electrodynamics or QED which fully describes all electromagnetic phenomena as being mediated by wave–particles known as photons.
4 In QED photons are the fundamental exchange particle which described all interactions relating to electromagnetism including the electromagnetic force.
5 Note 4.
6 What was dificult to reconcile the photoelectric effect and the missing ultraviolet catastrophe?	electromagnetic theory	1
7 What was used to create a new electromagnetic theory to reconcile the troubles with electromagnetic theory as it used to stand?	quantum mechanics	2
8 What did electromagnetic theory  finally lead to?	quantum electrodynamics	3
9 What are the waveparticles called that mediate all electromagnetic phenomena?	photons	3
10 What is QED short for?	quantum electrodynamics	3
1 It is a common misconception to ascribe the stiffness and rigidity of solid matter to the repulsion of like charges under the influence of the electromagnetic force.
2 However these characteristics actually result from the Pauli exclusion principle.
3 citation needed Since electrons are fermions they cannot occupy the same quantum mechanical state as other electrons.
4 When the electrons in a material are densely packed together there are not enough lower energy quantum mechanical states for them all so some of them must be in higher energy states.
5 This means that it takes energy to pack them together.
6 While this effect is manifested macroscopically as a structural force it is technically only the result of the existence of a finite set of electron states.
7 What is often misunderstood as the cause of matter rigidity?	repulsion of like charges	1
8 What actually causes rigidity in matter?	the Pauli exclusion principle	2
9 What is needed to pack electrons densely together?	energy	5
10 How is the Pauli exclusion priciple manifested in the macro world?	as a structural force	6
11 What is often misunderstood as the cause of matter rigidity?	repulsion of like charges	1
12 What actually causes rigidity in matter?	the Pauli exclusion principle	2
13 What is needed to pack electrons densely together?	energy	5
14 How is the Pauli exclusion priciple manifested in the macro world?	as a structural force	6
1 The strong force only acts directly upon elementary particles.
2 However a residual of the force is observed between hadrons the best known example being the force that acts between nucleons in atomic nuclei as the nuclear force.
3 Here the strong force acts indirectly transmitted as gluons which form part of the virtual pi and rho mesons which classically transmit the nuclear force see this topic for more.
4 The failure of many searches for free quarks has shown that the elementary particles affected are not directly observable.
5 This phenomenon is called color confinement.
6 What does stong force act upon?	elementary particles	1
7 What can be seen between hadrons?	residual of the force	2
8 What is the force between nucleons?	nuclear	2
9 How are nuclear forces transmitted?	as gluons	3
10 What is the term for the lack of obsevable free quarks?	color confinement	5
1 The weak force is due to the exchange of the heavy W and Z bosons.
2 Its most familiar effect is beta decay of neutrons in atomic nuclei and the associated radioactivity.
3 The word weak derives from the fact that the field strength is some 1013 times less than that of the strong force.
4 Still it is stronger than gravity over short distances.
5 A consistent electroweak theory has also been developed which shows that electromagnetic forces and the weak force are indistinguishable at a temperatures in excess of approximately 1015 kelvins.
6 Such temperatures have been probed in modern particle accelerators and show the conditions of the universe in the early moments of the Big Bang.
7 What does the W and Z boson exchange create?	weak force	1
8 What is the observable effect of W and Z boson exchange?	beta decay	2
9 What is the effect of beta decay?	radioactivity	2
10 How many times less is the strenght of the weak field compared to the strong?	1013	3
11 At what temperature do weak and electromagnetic forces appear the same?	approximately 1015 kelvins	5
1 The normal force is due to repulsive forces of interaction between atoms at close contact.
2 When their electron clouds overlap Pauli repulsion due to fermionic nature of electrons follows resulting in the force that acts in a direction normal to the surface interface between two objects.
3 93 The normal force for example is responsible for the structural integrity of tables and floors as well as being the force that responds whenever an external force pushes on a solid object.
4 An example of the normal force in action is the impact force on an object crashing into an immobile surface.
5 What is the repulsive force of close range atom interaction?	normal force	1
6 What occurs when electron clouds overlap from different atoms?	Pauli repulsion	2
7 What causes Pauli repulsion?	fermionic nature of electrons	2
8 What is the force that causes rigid strength in structures?	normal	3
1 Tension forces can be modeled using ideal strings that are massless frictionless unbreakable and unstretchable.
2 They can be combined with ideal pulleys which allow ideal strings to switch physical direction.
3 Ideal strings transmit tension forces instantaneously in actionreaction pairs so that if two objects are connected by an ideal string any force directed along the string by the first object is accompanied by a force directed along the string in the opposite direction by the second object.
4 By connecting the same string multiple times to the same object through the use of a setup that uses movable pulleys the tension force on a load can be multiplied.
5 For every string that acts on a load another factor of the tension force in the string acts on the load.
6 However even though such machines allow for an increase in force there is a corresponding increase in the length of string that must be displaced in order to move the load.
7 These tandem effects result ultimately in the conservation of mechanical energy since the work done on the load is the same no matter how complicated the machine.
8 What can be used to model tension forces?	ideal strings	1
9 What do you use to let idea strings switch direction?	ideal pulleys	2
10 In what way do idea strings transmit tesion forces?	actionreaction pairs	3
11 What is the final effect of adding more and more idea strings to a load?	conservation of mechanical energy	7
12 What can increase the tension force on a load?	movable pulleys	4
1 Newtons laws and Newtonian mechanics in general were first developed to describe how forces affect idealized point particles rather than threedimensional objects.
2 However in real life matter has extended structure and forces that act on one part of an object might affect other parts of an object.
3 For situations where lattice holding together the atoms in an object is able to flow contract expand or otherwise change shape the theories of continuum mechanics describe the way forces affect the material.
4 For example in extended fluids differences in pressure result in forces being directed along the pressure gradients as follows.
5 What did Newtons mechanics affect?	idealized point particles	1
6 What didnt Newtons mechanics affext?	threedimensional objects	1
7 In what kind of fluid are pressure differences caused by direction of forces over gradients?	extended	4
8 What may a force on one part of an object affect?	other parts	2
9 What does matter actually have that Newtonian mechanics doesnt address?	extended structure	2

1 Torque is the rotation equivalent of force in the same way that angle is the rotational equivalent for position angular velocity for velocity and angular momentum for momentum.
2 As a consequence of Newtons First Law of Motion there exists rotational inertia that ensures that all bodies maintain their angular momentum unless acted upon by an unbalanced torque.
3 Likewise Newtons Second Law of Motion can be used to derive an analogous equation for the instantaneous angular acceleration of the rigid body.
4 What is the force equivalent of torque compared to angular momentum?	rotational equivalent for position	1
5 What would change the rotational inertia of a body under Newtons First Law of Motion?	unbalanced torque	2
6 To calculate instant angular acceleration of a rigid body what would you use?	Newtons Second Law of Motion	3
1 where  is the mass of the object  is the velocity of the object and  is the distance to the center of the circular path and  is the unit vector pointing in the radial direction outwards from the center.
2 This means that the unbalanced centripetal force felt by any object is always directed toward the center of the curving path.
3 Such forces act perpendicular to the velocity vector associated with the motion of an object and therefore do not change the speed of the object magnitude of the velocity but only the direction of the velocity vector.
4 The unbalanced force that accelerates an object can be resolved into a component that is perpendicular to the path and one that is tangential to the path.
5 This yields both the tangential force which accelerates the object by either slowing it down or speeding it up and the radial centripetal force which changes its direction.
6 Where does centripetal force go?	toward the center of the curving path	2
7 How do centripetal forces act in relation to vectors of velocity?	perpendicular	3
8 What force changes an objects direction of travel?	centripetal	5
9 What is another word for centripetal force?	radial	5

1 A conservative force that acts on a closed system has an associated mechanical work that allows energy to convert only between kinetic or potential forms.
2 This means that for a closed system the net mechanical energy is conserved whenever a conservative force acts on the system.
3 The force therefore is related directly to the difference in potential energy between two different locations in space and can be considered to be an artifact of the potential field in the same way that the direction and amount of a flow of water can be considered to be an artifact of the contour map of the elevation of an area.
4 What is the only form potential energy can change into?	kinetic	1
5 What is the only form kinetic energy can change into?	potential	1
6 What is preserved in a closed system of forces when acted upon?	net mechanical energy	2
7 What is the force between two locations related to?	difference in potential energy	3
8 What is the force called rgarding a potential field between two locations?	artifact	3
1 For certain physical scenarios it is impossible to model forces as being due to gradient of potentials.
2 This is often due to macrophysical considerations that yield forces as arising from a macroscopic statistical average of microstates.
3 For example friction is caused by the gradients of numerous electrostatic potentials between the atoms but manifests as a force model that is independent of any macroscale position vector.
4 Nonconservative forces other than friction include other contact forces tension compression and drag.
5 However for any sufficiently detailed description all these forces are the results of conservative ones since each of these macroscopic forces are the net results of the gradients of microscopic potentials.
6 What is sometimes impossible to model?	forces	1
7 Why are some forces due to that are impossible to model?	gradient of potentials	1
8 What do electrostatic gradiient potentials create?	friction	3
9 Tension compression and drag are what kind of forces?	Nonconservative	4
1 The connection between macroscopic nonconservative forces and microscopic conservative forces is described by detailed treatment with statistical mechanics.
2 In macroscopic closed systems nonconservative forces act to change the internal energies of the system and are often associated with the transfer of heat.
3 According to the Second law of thermodynamics nonconservative forces necessarily result in energy transformations within closed systems from ordered to more random conditions as entropy increases.
4 In what treatment are nonconservative and conservative forces described?	statistical mechanics	1
5 What changes macroscopic closed system energies?	nonconservative forces	2
6 What is the exchange of heat associated with?	nonconservative forces	2
7 What is the law of thermodynamics associated with closed system heat exchange?	Second	3
8 What makes energy changes in a closed system?	nonconservative forces	3
1 The poundforce has a metric counterpart less commonly used than the newton the kilogramforce kgf sometimes kilopond is the force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram of mass.
2 The kilogramforce leads to an alternate but rarely used unit of mass the metric slug sometimes mug or hyl is that mass that accelerates at 1 m·s−2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf.
3 The kilogramforce is not a part of the modern SI system and is generally deprecated however it still sees use for some purposes as expressing aircraft weight jet thrust bicycle spoke tension torque wrench settings and engine output torque.
4 Other arcane units of force include the sthène which is equivalent to 1000 N and the kip which is equivalent to 1000 lbf.
5 What is the metric term less used than the Newton?	kilogramforce	1
6 What is the kilogramforce sometimes reffered to as?	kilopond	1

8 What seldom used term of a unit of force equal to 1000 pound s of force?	kip	4
